description: Much could be made of the secret of attracting grandmasters to a tournament, but it is not much of a secret, at all: the higher the prize money, the greater the success for the organizers.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES remained unchanged from October to November owing to a dip in agricultural prices, but industrial commodities rose 0.6 percent in the month . . . Unemployment in November stood at 8.3 percent of the work force, down from 8.6 percent In October. . .A survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management Inc. concludes that the current recovery will continue through 1976, but at a more moderate pace... The Commerce Department said that industry plans a moderate increase in capital spending in the first half of 1976... The Conference Board reported that capital appropriations in the third quarter totaled $10.8 billion, down from $11.1 billion in the second quarter.

title: State Offering Trees for Sale
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y.  The State Department of Environ, mental Conservation has pegged this year's offering of inexpensive trees and shrubs to owners of one acre or more on Long Island as a Bicentennial planting project.

title: Peace in the Mideast . .
description: If the central goal of United States policy in the Middle East were only to expand American influence and exclude that of the Soviet Union, then the United Stateswould have suffered a severe setback with the recent shift of diplomatic emphasis to the issue of the Palestinian Arabs.

title: South Seaside Park Is Suing for Secession From Berkeley
description: SOUTH SEASIDE PARKA majority of the residents of this sleepy 10blocklong community has begun legal proceedings calling for secession from Berkeley Township and annexation by Seaside Park.

title: Livingston Bows to Barringer
description: A bungled snap from center on an extrapoint try prevented Livingston High School from gaining a tie yesterday and the team lost a 1413 decision to Newark Barringer in the North Jersey Section 2, Group 4, championship football game before 7,500 spectators in Livingston.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Rancho Deluxe, directed by Frank Perry and written by Thomas McGuane, the novelist (NinetyTwo in The Shade), is a most engaging, deliberately cool comedy about coping in the contemporary AMerican West, specifically Montana, a magnificently scenic wasteland where the fight against boredom becomes nothing less than an affirmation of life:Beautifully acted by a cast headed by Jeff Bridges and Sam Waterston, the film is very funny and almost too smart for its own good. If it were a man, you'd call him a wisenheimer, until you understood that his cocky selfassurancehis complete inability to resist showing offwas fundamental to his living at all.

title: The C.I.A. in Chile
description: Revolutions and counterrevolutions Inevitably produce political myths. Like all myths that succeed in getting hold of the popular imagination, these legends contain an element of truth; but they also contain large amounts of exaggeration, invention, and imported emotion that is derived from other situations or historical analogies.

title: 2D JET NEARCRASH ALARMS AIRLINES
description: Federal officials carried on an urgent inquiry yesterday into the second incident in 10 days in which two airliners came within about 100 feet of a midair collision.

title: Miss O'Reilly Wed To Stephen Smith
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Ellen O'Reilly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert. B. O'Reilly of Kingston, to Stephen Moore Smith, son of Mrs. John Francis McKenna of Chatham, N. J., and William Leigh Smith of Buffalo.

title: Gospel Jubilee Set In Camden Friday
description: CAMDENNine choral groups will take part in the Rutgers Gospel Jubilee Friday night. The program will be held in the campus theater, starting at 8 P.M.

title: Legislative Leaders Pessimistic On New Tax
description: TRENTONThe legislative effort to formulate an emergency $36 million tax package, a move designed to reduce commuter fares and eliminate Medicaid cuts, crumbled in the hands of Senate Democratic leaders last week, leaving speculation that the Legislature would refuse to enact any taxes for anything this year.

title: PORPOISE DEATHS STIR NEW DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6A Government attempt to reduce the number of porpoises killed by the American tuna fleet has met opposition from both environmentalists and the tuna industry.

title: Suffolk and Nassau To Aid Alcoholics
description: MINEOLA  Nassau and Suffolk counties have started programs to identify and provide help for the alcoholics on their payrolls.

title: Noted Hoboken Dog Trainer
description: HOBOKENManus, Pinkwater, writes, illustrator, dog trainer and exalter of the charms of Hoboken, has chosen to live as a loftdweller in this historic port city, thus following the footsteps of a great many other artists.

title: Murtagh Must Share Cases Of Nadjari With 2 Others
description: The chief judge of the State Court of Appeals announced yesterday that in the future Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh must share his authority with two other judges in presiding over criminal corruption cases brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: Westport Weekly Is Sold
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 6The Fairpress, a controlledcirculation newspaper published weekly and based here, has been sold to the WestchesterRockland New York Newspapers, a member of the Gannett group, it was reported last night. The purchase endedmore than seven months of negotiations with H. K. Williams 3d and George Waters. The Fairpress's owners. Mr. Williams is publisher of The Dunkirk (N.Y.) Observer and Mr. Waters publishes The Rome (N.Y.) Sentinal.

title: LETTERS
description: Incentives

title: French Ski Racer Dies; Collombin Hurt in Fall
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 6 (UPI)Only hours after a French skier, Michel Dujon, died today from a fractured skull, Roland Collombin, one of the favorites for the Olyrmpic downhill gold medal, fractured his spine in practice at the first World Cup meet of the season.

title: Doctors Meet in Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 6 (Agence FrancePresse) More than 1,000 doctors from all parts of the Frenchspeaking world gathered this week in Dakar for the 40th French Medical Congress at which a wide range of topics of interest both to industralized and developing countries were discussed.

title: Y.W.C.A. Holiday Gifts
description: A selection of Christmas gift items is available at the 610 Shop at the Young Women's Christian Association, 610 Lexington Avenue, through Dec. 18. Hours are 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Monday through Thursday. Proceeds will go toward the Y.W.C.A.'s fundraising campaign.

title: Fashion
description: Style is about to be celebrated, with Diana Vreelandthe colorful doyenne of fashion as mistress of ceremonies. If you have it, you have it, Mrs. Vreeland declares. Her conviction that style is Godgiven (Animals have it; children have it) stems from a lifetime's practice as spotter and arbiter of style. Over a period of 38 years, she was an editor at Harper's Bazaar and then was Vogue's editorinchief. In that time span, she became what has been described somewhat hyperbolically by one magazine writer as this century's single most powerful influence on American fashion.

title: Giants Play Colts; Jets Visit Patriots
description: The Baltimore Colts that the Giants encounter at Shea Stadium todayare as similar to the old Colts as the Boys' Club is to the Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Office Buildings In City Falling To Foreclosure At Quicker Pace; Arrearages Up
description: Ten foreclosure suits were filed against New York City office buildings in 1974. In the first half of this year, 25 were filed, and by the end of this year, some experts believe, the figure may rise to 42.

title: Beth Koster Sets Nuptials
description: Beth Ellen Koster, a fourthyear medical student at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, and Dr. Stuart Charles Yudofsky, a psychiatrist, plan to many in June. Dr. Yudofsky is director of the inpatient psychiatric service at the Presbyterian Hospital and assistant director of undergraduate psychiatric education at Physicians and Surgeons.

title: MUSIC VIEW; Too Much Classical Music? Impossible!
description: As one who, through an unfortunate set of circumstances, recently underwent what amounted to a graduate seminar in listening to classical music over the New York FM station I read Edmund Morris's piece in these pages a few weeks ago with a good deal of amused interest. Morris, if you remember, argued that there was too much good music on the air, citing such things as a month that contained six Eroica performances; citing the multiplicity of recordings of tany popular work (29 of the Tchaikovsky B flat Piano Concerto alone). He jeered at supermarket record packagingall 103 Haydn symphonies, nearly all of Schubert's 600odd songs. An embarass de richesse, concluded Morris, that leads to coarsened sensibilities.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500: SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the account of the wedding of Ann Shedlin to Daniel Tucker Kamin, published last Sunday in The New York Times, the mother of the bride was incorrectly listed. The bride is the daughter of Allan Shedlin of New York and of Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of Rye, N. Y.

title: Houses, Too, Now Pose For the Family Album
description: Professionally taken pictures of the family at home are not new. But these days photographers are easing out Mom, Dad and the kids. The star is the house itselfthe art collection in the entry hall, the garden in bloom or the living room decorated for the holidays.

title: Tear Gas in Boston Hotel
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)A tear gas grenade went off in a firstfloor corridor of Boston's Copley Plaza Hotel last night, injuring three persons and forcing about 1,400 partygoers to leave the hotel's ballrooms and a bar. A second device, which did not go off, was found about 20 feet away in the same wing of the hotel.

title: The World
description: The search for nutmeg and cloves first led Europeans to the South Moluccas, the legendary Spice Islands that lie where the Celebes Sea meets the Pacific. For four centuries the islands were successively under Portuguese, Spanish and Dutch rule, and in 1949 they became part of a newly independent Indonesia.

title: Educator Weds Katherine Page
description: Katherine Hall Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Page of Livingston, N. J., and Deer Isle, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Prof. Alan V. Hein of the psychology faculty at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A visit with Ingmar Bergman
description: STOCKHOLM. As a person, Ingmar Bergman is not at all what you would expect from his films, with their introspection and penetrating sense of isolation. He is a tall, vigorous man, friendly and effortlessly charming, who has about him a continual buzz of energyan energy contained and used, not frittered away. He laughs often and easily and possesses what W. B. Yeats called the terrible gift of intimacy, which means that you find yourself talking to him almost immediately as if you and he had known each other for years. But unlike most possessors of this gift, he is generous with himself and speaks freely of his personal concerns and hesitations. For a man whose art, like Strindberg's, has often been an instrument of despair, he seems astonishingly open and at ease in himself. He has only one nervous tic: As he talks, he turns in his hand a chunk of wood, darkened and grainy from much handling. Years ago, he gave up smoking, after severe nicotine poisoning. The wood, presumably, gives him something to do with his hands.

title: LaidOff Policemen Open a Drive For Public Support on Rehiring
description: The 3,000member Former Police Officers' Association, an organization of laidoff city police officers and Transit Authority patrolmen, have begun a oneweek drive in Queens to obtain public support in getting their jobs back.

title: Murderer Refuses to Testify on Musician's Slaying
description: A convicted murderer who said he was afraid of revenge by prison inmates has refused to testify at the trial of Beverly Donna Hodge, who has been accused of hiring him and another man to kill her husband in their Lincoln Towers apartment in October 1973.

title: GENERAL ASSAILS CURBS IN VIETNAM
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the United States commanner in Vietnam from 1969 to 1968, asserts that the American failure to win there must be attributed to politicians and policy makers in Washington who forced us to fight with one hand.

title: RighttoDie' Movements Springing Up in Europe
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP)Righttodie movements are springing up in Western Europe, stirred in part by the controversial Karen Anne Quinlan case in the United States.

title: Native of Folsom Recalls A Quiet Place With a Past
description: FOLSOMA nice, quiet place, Folsom, and it stayed pretty much the same for about a century. Then, not quite a quarter of a century ago, developers flooded the cranberry bogs and began to put up homes around the resulting lakes. Ten years ago, Gertrude Eckhardt went back home to Folsom and decided to write about it all.

title: Phyllis Hajduk Bride of Peter Hawkins
description: Phyllis Hajduk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Hajduk of Clifton, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter G. Hawkins, son of the Rev. and Mrs. John R. Hawkins Jr. of Claverack, N. Y.

title: PLANT IN BALTIMORE CITED FOR POLLUTION
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP)The Maryland health department, reversing an earlier decision, has cited the FMC Corporation for polluting Baltimore's air with a dangerous chemical and has ordered the company to show why its plant should not be closed.

title: Indonesian Attack Reported By DAVID A. ANDELMAN
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 7Troops and warships believed to belong to Indonesia sailed into the harbor of Dili, the capital of Portuguese Timor early today, and apparently occupied the town with little or no resistance, according to radio broadcasts monitored in Darwin, Australia.

title: FILM UNION SUED OVER JOB POLICY
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6Tak Fujimoto is a 36yearold cinematographer who was critically praised for his work on two motion pictures, Badland and Caged Heat. But, he cannot get a job at a major Hollywood studio.

title: Delay on Woodson Is Seen
description: TRENTONAlthough S. Howard Woodson announced last week that he would relinquish his post as Assembly Speaker at the end of the current legislative session, the prospect of another bitter Democratic primary in Mercer County is expected to keep him from moving right into the Byrne administration as president of the state's Civil Service Commission.

title: Everybody Loves Cuyp
description: A good cheap art book is hard to find. But so is a good cheap anything, these days, and there is no reason in logic why a scrupulously prepared survey of a great artist's career, which will give pleasure for a lifetime, should cost less than a dull dinner and a night's lodging.

title: ExCarey Aide Gets Post
description: ALBANY, Dec. 6 (UPI) Governor Carey yesterday appointed Thomas A. Conniff of Brooklyn, the Governor's counsel while he was a Congressman, to the Human Rights Appeal Board. Mr. Conniff, 40 years old, is a partner in the law firm of Muldoon and Horagn in New York City and New Rochelle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: New Forms of Tyranny

title: JEANNETTE BOURNE, A CIVIC LEADER, DIES
description: Jeannette T. Bourne, a civic leader in Morristown, N.J., died Friday at Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived on Overbrook Road in Morris Township.

title: Jannett Trevor Downer Engaged
description: Jannett Trevor Downer, a credit analyst in the global credit department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and John Marshall Sayre Jr., an officer's assistant in the commercial lending division of the Chemical Bank, plan to marry here next spring.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the account of the wedding of Ann Shedlin to Daniel Tucker Kamin, published last Sunday in The New York Times, the mother of the bride was incorrectly listed. The bride is the daughter of Allan Shedlin of New York and of Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of Rye, N. Y.

title: He Discovered Dylan, Basie And Holiday
description: John Hammond has had a, more important career behind the scenes in American music than many have had in front of them. As Columbia Records' vice president in charge of talent acquisition, Hammond has been an active manaboutmusic for over 40 years, the discoverer of such musicians as Count Basie, Charlie Christian and Billie Holiday in jazz, and of Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen in pop.

title: A Fan's Books
description: Evidently it is an article of faith among publishers that if a person is interested in some game he will buy a book about it, or someone will buy it for him. This, it is believed in the trade, is a typical exchange between Christmas shoppers:

title: His Political Unorthodoxy May Be His Most Winning Point
description: The notion that Senator James Lane Buckley is an unorthodox politician will find few challengers among his colleagues. The Senator himself thinks the description sounds fine.

title: Margaret Roth Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Ann Roth and Arthur J. Rosenthal, both of Cambridge, Mass., were married there yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Herbert F. Vetter Jr., a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the First Parish Church.

title: Leonia Riding Center: Indoor, Outdoor Fun
description: LEONIA  Riding is a challenge to judgment, discipline and timing; I recall these values from my own riding days, and it's fun.

title: Stracey Dethrones Napole
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 6 (AP)  John Stracey of Britain halted the. sixyear reign of Jose Napoles in the welterweight division tonight stopping the 31yearold champion in the sixth round of a World Boxing Council title fight.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Encounter: A Long Night With the Berbers
description: AS a tourist I've felt as conspicuous as the next American. I've snapped a noisy Nikkormat shutter in quiet English chapels at the moment or consecration, played Frisbee in Shanghai, worn Lacoste alligator shirts in India. I once toasted Queen Elizabeth with a bottle of Jack Daniels in Bimini, just a week=or so a large, unamused Bahamian told meafter official liberation from the Mother Country. But all that is nothing next to walking through the streets of Tangier, Morocco, with fly rods strapped to your backpack, reels bulging from your pockets, and Royal coachmen flies stuck to your hat.

title: Artists, Writers Talk About Funds
description: RIVERHEAD  When artists and writers get together, they find a lot to talk about. And one of the most pressing subjects, naturally, is money.

title: Concert: 2 Igors Impress
description: In the baker's dozen years since Igor Oistrakh made his New York debut, he has grown from the talented son of a famous father into one of the Soviet Union's preeminent violinists. At Carnegie Hall Friday evening, Mr. Oistrakh and an extraordinary pianist named Igor Tchernishev gave a generous program that included Sonatas by Mozart, Bartk and Brahms, the three Mythes of Karol Szymanowski and a couple of Paganini's blazing virtuoso studies.

title: Photography: A Changing Scene
description: At the daylong symposium on Collecting the Photograph, held at Lincoln Center In September, one of the panelistsPeter C. Bunnell, professor of the history of photography and modern art at Princeton Universitydeclared that we could never again have a single book legitimately entitled The History of Photography.

title: City's Fiscal Crisis Is Adding to Demands on Catholic Charities
description: The quality of mercy was sorely strained in recent months when funding for humanitarian concerns and services to meet human needs succumbed to the budgetcutting ax of a financially besieged New York City government.

title: World Church Council Elects 2 Women
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 6The general assembly of the World Council of Churches swept aside objections to its strict operating rules today and for the first time elected two womenincluding an American and a Russian as presidents,

title: Brawler at the U.N.
description: On the night before the General Assembly of the United Nations was to vote on the resolution proclaiming that Zionism is a form of racism and racial discrimination, Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief of the United States Mission. was putting a high gloss of outrage on a speech he hoped he wouldn't have to make.

title: Linda Margulies Bride of A. D. Roberts
description: In the Congregational Church in Londonderry, Vt., yesterday afternoon, Linda Browne Marguiles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Margulies of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Westhampton Beach., L.I., became the bride of Anthony D. Roberts. He is the son of Mrs. Henry Steele Roberts of Englewood, Fla., and the late Mr Roberts.

title: Kidnappers Take 42 Cents
description: SALEM, Mass., Dec. 6 (AP) Robert Paluzzi of Beverly was kidnapped a knifepoint early today, taken for a ride and robbed of 42 cents, the police said. They quoted the 23yearold a having aid that two youths had entered his car while he was parked at a donut bop and demanded he go for a ride with them. Ultimately, the car crahed and the youth fled.

title: $10 Fee for Probationer
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 6 (UPI)Despite a charge that it amounted to a return to a debtor's prison concept, Frank Sheffield, a Tallahassee lawyer, has said that Cheryl B. Vignochito, a client, will pay a $10 monthly fee required by a 1973 law making probationers and parolees contribute to the costs of their supervision.

title: Less House for a Home
description: LOS ANGELESFrom California to New England, the nation's home builders are rushing to offer less.

title: A Major Issue at the Coming Paris Conference Will Be Food
description: On Dec. 16, representatives of a score of countries will assemble in Paris to discuss economic issues. In contrast to the Rambouillet conference last month, which included only six of the leading Western industrial countries, this meeting will include poor countries as well. India, Brazil, and Egypt will be there along with the United States, West Germany, and Japan.

title: Kidnappers Hold Bank Aide; Ransom Reported Available
description: DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP)Kidnapers today held a 25yearold assistant bank manager they abducted as he arrived for work yesterday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. But there were reports that a $250,000 ransom demand for his release had been made available to his abductors.

title: Bomb Explodes at U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (UPI) A bomb exploded in a chemistry building at the University of California at Los Angeles last night. There were no injuries. The bomb was suspended from the outside of the building and detonated there, the police said. Officials estimated the damage at about $10,000.

title: UTILITY DEPOSITS LIMITED BY STATE
description: The New York State Public Service Commission has limited the conditions under which electric, gas and telephone utilities can require residential customers to post security deposits.

title: Suspect Is Charged With Slaying One Of 6 Carolina Dead
description: LAKE CITY, S. C., Dec. 6 (AP)A Charleston man was arrested today and charged with the murder of one of six persons whose bodies were uncovered this week in a remote section of Florence County, the authorities said.

title: Off the Tour Route in Mexico: An Earthy Enclave Called Catemaco
description: ALONG the muchbeaten path from Veracruz to the Yucatan, a natural stoppingoff place is the fishing and vacation town of Catemaco. Mexican vacationers know Catemaco well, gathering at Christmas, New Year's and Easter, when the streets fill with masked grotesques dancing to marimba music or children in costume carrying trees decorated with balloons and paper chains. But few travelers from the United States make their way here. a pity, in a way, since it reveals aspects of Mexico not seen in the usual tourist haunts. Aside from those holiday times, it is quiet, the onestory houses and several hotels spread out widely, and it receives visitors equably.

title: 62 Inmates and 1 State Trooper Indicted: 5 Trials, 2 Convictions
description: For four days before the 1971 police assault at Attica, the state bargained with the inmates to release their hostages and end the uprising. Most of the prisoners' demands for reform were accepted by the state, but the authorities balked at giving inmates immunity from prosecution. The bloody encounter left 39 inmates and guards dead.

title: Ojai: Good Vibes
description: THEY say 12 million Americans are playing tennis nowadays, a statistic I am inclined to believe this afternoon. My wife taps my arm: See all the pretty tennis shorts moving like butterflies under the orange trees. On the instant, the 3 o'clock chimes ring out, liquid silver, from the Spanishstyle campanile above the Ojai, Calif., Post Office, above the arcades on Ojai Avenue, the main street, and we might be in Toledo, Spain, except that in Toledo, where the ancient church bells rejoice the livelong day, hardly anyone plays tennis.

title: Businessmen Briefed on Dealing Abroad
description: NEWARK  New Jersey businessmen, feeling the pangs of a depressed economy and seeking new outlets for their goods and services, will conclude this week a wideranging course on how to increase their sales in the foreign marketplace.

title: Headliners
description: Feuding between Maurice H. Nadjari, New York special anticorruption prosecutor, and State Supreme Court Justice John M Murtagh, who is empowered to hear all his corruption cases, has again erupted. For the third time in the last month, Justice Murtagh last week threw out a major case brought by Mr. Nadjari. Though Mr. Nadjari has often been criticized for his methods in gathering evidence, none of his cases had previously been dismissed. In each of the three cases, Justice Murtagh found the evidence legally insufficient to establish guilt. The latest case involved perjury indictments against Judge Paul R. Rao and two lawyers. Mr. Nadjari, who had remained silent after the previous dismissals, issued a public statement attacking Justice Murtagh for his ruling. That statement could mean the end for Maury, said one of Mr. Nadjari's supporters. His political opponents have sought to eliminate Mr. Nadjari's special status as. a prosecutor, or to lower it to a level equal to elected district attorneys.

title: Improved FosterCare System Proposed After 10Year Study
description: A plan aimed at improving the city's fostercare system proposes that families should be helped to keep their own children so, that foster care, will not be needed, that the rate of adoptions should be doubled, that the number of smaller group homes should be expanded and that institulions should be converted to treatment centers for disturbed children.

title: Simple Cures for Doors That Won't Close Properly
description: When a door starts to stick or rub every time it is closed, the first cure that occurs to most people is to use a hand plane, sanding machine or scraper to trim off the edge where rubbing is evident. Yet in many cases the problem can be solved without resorting to such drastic measures. In fact, it is best to avoid planing or sanding until all other methods have failed because if the trouble is due to other causes then trimming the edges may turn out to be only a temporary cure and, of course, wood that is rebe restored.

title: An Offering Of Anchors To the British
description: E IN BRITAIN are without anchors. We are drifting. A common enemy in two world wars drew us together in united actionand we defeated him. Another enemy is at the gates today, and we keep silence. We are afraid to speak out: It is time we spoke plainly.

title: How Senate Voted On City Loans Bill
Taiwan Sees No U.S. Shift in Wake of Ford Trip
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 6Taiwan officials are voicing confidence that no dramatic changes in AmericanChinese relations will occur for at least a year, now that President Ford has completed his trip to Peking without any harsh surprises fodr the Government here.

title: Book: The Game of Business
description: In his introduction the author states that his object has been to keep the book within the range of the common reader.  These were most comforting words to this reader, who had understood game theory to be some arcane branch of mathematics that was at best unintelligible and at worst not very practical.

title: Jim Burton's New Composition Strikes Many Discordant Notes
description: Jim Burton, a 501.10 composer, has made some genuinely pleasant music in the rerent past, most of it involving the production of strikingly new and alluring sonorities in a gently theatrical, nonverbal context. But when Mr. Burton has given to his instincts for overtheatricalization with actual dialogue and lyrics, the results haven't always been so happy, and they weren't very happy Friday night at the Kitchen.

title: Jeanne A. Campbell Is Married to Albert R. Koehl
description: Jeanne Anne Campbell and Albert R. Koehl were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in the Parish of Christ the Redeemer in Pelham, N. Y., by the Rev. David S. Hoag.

title: CANADIAN TRIBES DROP LAND CLAIM
description: MONTREAL Two Canadian Indian tribes whose land claims once led a court to order work halted on the $12 billion James Bay development project in ??thern Quebec have agreed to surrender their rights in a recently signed treaty.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayCamden County K.C. all breed, Ivystone Inn, Route 130, north of Union Avenue, Pennsauken, N.J.; 1,082 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Britons Suffer in Doctors' Slowdown
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  The other night a 50yearold man arrived at a Hertfordshire hospital complaining of chest pains. Refused admission, he drove to a hospital five miles away, where doctors discovered he had suffered not one but two mild heart attacks.

title: Jakarta Says Timor City Falls to ProIndonesians
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sunday, Dec. 7The capital of Portuguese Timor, Dili, fell today to proIndonesian forces, the Foreign Minister of Indonesia, Adam Malik, told reporters here.

title: Deborah Wagstaff, Teacher, Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Wagstaff 3d of Tequasta, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Wagstaff, to E. Stanton Wainwright, a chartered accountant with the London firm of Spicer & Pegler.

title: Nastase, Borg in Final
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 6Me Nastase played his best tennis for longer than I can remember today and gained the final of the Grand Prix Masters tournament with Bjorn Borg, who didn't play good.

title: New Mexico Acts to Give Office Access to Disabled
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Dec. 6Gov. Jerry Apodaca said this Week that he would enforce a law requiring offices of state agencies to be fully accessible to our handicapped citizens.

title: The Quiet Revolution: America Goes Metric
description: The race throughout industry to replace feet, quarts and pounds with meters, liters and kilograms is entering the home stretch.

title: The Ballet: Nutcracker
description: Let us admit it, The Nutcracker is not really a ballet for your everyday balletgoer. One of New York City Ballet's most devoted, and also most sensitive, fans, the artist Edward Gorey, once took in a whole season of The Nutcrackerat least so legend has it. Who was around to witness the feat, however? Personally as a critic, I try to see most of the varying casts each seasonoccasionally wandering in just to see the last act (which is where most of the important solo dancing comes), or occasionally just slipping in for the pas de deux.

title: Dasher, Dancer Co.
description: Parents, this is Old Nick; St. Nick, talking to you and have I got a sleighfull of slightfullsbooks with Christmas themesfor all of your little ones. Of course, giving such books on Christmas morn is like applying preemergent crabgrass control after the weeds have blossomed. These books are in anticipation of the holiday. What you should give as Christmas gifts are on page 66.

title: TV VIEW
description: The monthly CBS daytime magazine called Magazine, one of the nicer things a network has done for women in some time, is experimenting with a new communications device, which turns out to be one of the more wellintentioned but absurd gimmicks of recent years. This Wednesday at 10 A.M., the Magazine hour will include, in addition to a Canadian journalist's interview with Indira Gandhi, India's Prime Minister, a brief segment called Face to Face. Its purpose is unquestionably laudable: to give TV viewers an opportunity to use television as a forum for their questions and complaints about the medium.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There's a cheery bartender in By Bernstein who bangs the evening open with a big bass drum and then rests his elbows on his glistening counter to tell us what the evening's all about. It's made up, he explains, of songs that were once in shows, or were once projected for shows that never quite made it to the startingline, but were abandoned for a variety of reasons. If an entertainment was out of town, for instance, and running 20 minutes long, a perfectly good tune might have to be tossed into the Hotel Touraine's wastebasket. Or if a lass with a limited throat who was otherwise indispensable couldn't sing the song, it would have to go, not she. And so on.

title: Forecast Fallout
description: The cloudy crystal ball department.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: The World
description: Without abandoning its apartheid race policies, South Africa in recent years has sought diplomatic and trade relations with moderate black governments. At the same time, to try to stop the southward spread of black leftist regimes, the South Africans have sent forces to help the whitesupremacist Rhodesian Government combat a guerrilla insurgency.

title: Jigsaw Puzzle Makers Can Be Merciless
description: Although Jigsaw puzzles were all the rage in this country during the 1920's and 1930's, the end of the depression and the widespread introduction of radio and television caused their popularity to fade. However, in recent years the reintroduction of elaborate and sophisticated adult puzzles has made them so popular again that the production and sale a jigsaw puzzles is now a multimillion dollar industry, in the United States.

title: Statia's Heritage: Gifts From the Sea
description: The sea and I play games every morning on this shining beach of black sand, where the white breakers bear gifts in their frothy fingers. Hidden among handfuls of smooth and colorful stones are bits of delicate Italian faience and French porcelain, Venetian trade beads, fragments of filigreed ivory from the Orient and pieces of lapis lazuli. Remnants of treasures from the four corners of the world, they are reminders of the days 200 years ago when storehouses bursting with riches stood on the beach and this Caribbean island of Saint Eustatius, now unpretentious and somnolent, shone with silver and gold.

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR AVIATION HIGH
description: The school is flanked by a gas station and men's clothing factory, across the street from the elevated subway tricks, in an industrial section of Long Island City. Next to the sevenstory school building of glass and brick, some 16 airplanes, including a biplane, two helicopters, two twinengine Beechcrafts and two reconnaissance drones left over from the Vietnam war, are scattered about a hangar and an apron. The whole, with its 2,700 students, is the Aviation High School, an exemplar

title: Santa Was an American
description: Our native mythology is largely derivative. We do have a few homegrown legends (Johnny Appleseed, Paul Bunyan . . .) and some tall tales about George Washington, but most of our great myths are borrowed from Europe.

title: Anthropologist, Football and Unusual Tribal Rituals
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Colleges Seek New Ways To Save Heat and Power
description: Like so many other American institutions, colleges and universities in the United States have already gone as far as they can with turning down thermostats, posting little turn me off stickers over light switches, installing dimmer bulbs and locking buildings not in use.

title: Humanities Project Thriving
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  In December 1971, officials of the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington proposed the establishment of a statelevel organization in New Jersey. The proposal, which was broached to three state scholars and humanists, was accepted and led to the formation of the New Jersey Committee for the Humanities, an official affiliate of the national endowment.

title: NEWS CONDEMN U.N. AND U.S. OVER P.L.O.
description: Jewish organizations joined over the weekend in assailing the United Nations Security Council's invitation to the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in a debate.

title: Cheery Hill Sued on Tax Setup
description: CHERRY HILLDavid S. Myers Jr. says that he never really worried about property taxes until his home in this affluent Camden County Township was reassessed two years ago.

title: Koch Protests Plan by a TaxExempt Foundation to Hire Cavanagh
description: The propriety of a taxexempt foundation's hiring the outgoing First Deputy Mayor, James A. Cavanagh, while 40,000 other city employees are let go and even have to go on welfare was criticized by Representative Edward I. Koch.

title: FRENCH CANADIANS HARASS ONTARIO
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 6French Canadians of Ontario are systematically harassing official agencies in a campaign to force provincial authorities to follow the federal policy of bilingualism in public services.

title: Suzanne Weiss, Accountant, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Weiss of Lawrence, L. I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne J. Weiss, to Steven H. Schram, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schram of Teaneck, N. J. A wedding next June is planned.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: Births

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ing the Fashion Photograpgy Exhibition, with Robert Littman who talks about the twoyear endeavor involving 300 photographs, today, 2 P.M. Room 106, Lowe Hail, Hofstra University. Free.

title: ExHead of A.E.C To Speak in Union
description: UNIONDr. Dixy Lee Ray, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, will speak at Kean College tomorrow night in another presentation of the college's Adventures in Ideas series.

title: Montclair Expands Program on Asia
description: MONTCLAIRAn expanded program of Asian studies has been added to Montclair State College's spring semester. The project is said to be the first of its kind and scope to be offered at any of New Jersey's eight state colleges.

title: Miss SzuTu Engaged To T. M. Antonsen Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Y. S. SzuTu of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vivien S. SzuTu to Thomas M. Antonsen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonsen of Ramsey, N.J.

title: Local Debt In the Wake Of Default
description: WASHINGTON  Although the event has not received as much attention as it might have in the fastmoving series of developments affecting New York City, a city default of sorts has already been decreed by the state legislature.

title: Neighborhoods In Brooklyn Start Here? And End Here?
description: Where does BedfordStuyvesant end and Crown Heights begin? At what point does one step from Williamsburg into Bushwick? Why has South Brooklyn shrunk?

title: Shutt Gets 3 Goals As Canadiens Win
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (UPI) Steve Shutt scored three goals in a game for the second time in his career and Yvan Cournoyer added two goals and four assists today as the Montreal Canadiens routed the Washington Capitals. 93.

title: Integration Cost in Boston Expected to Top $50 Million
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The combined costs of Boston's Phase 1 and 2 school desegregation programs will go over $50 million.

title: Looking Back From the Year 2000 at Violence, Avarice and Ali's 215th Defense
description: LONDON, Jan. 1, 2000By some miracle we survive to see the 21st century. For millions it is sheerly due to Red China's anticancer vaccine discovery back in 1985. In my. trade of sports writings where excess in all things was once an industrial hazard, there are other reasons. With whisky at $168 a bottle, who can afford alcoholism? And the 1993 Act of Parliament at least forced fresh air back into our lungs by banning the manufacture of all tobacco products.

title: Dr. Richard Chamberlain Dies; A Pioneer in Nuclear Medicine
description: Dr. Richard H. Chamberlain, a pioneer in nuclear medicine and the use of radioactive materials for diagnosis and therapy, died Friday in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 60 years old and lived in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia.

title: Campaign Law Sentence
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 6 (AP)Builders Transportation Corporation of Memphis was placed on one year's probation after pleading guilty Thursday to Federal charges of making illegal contributions to Gov. Ray Blanton's unsuccessful United States Senate race in 1972.

title: Alison B. Montgomery Bride of Harold E. Clark Jr.
description: Alison Biadford Montgomery and Harold E. Clark Jr. were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins. He was assisted by the Rev. Noel Sokoloff of Hanover, N. H., the bride's cousin.

title: Travel Notes: Across The Atlantic by Ship
description: TODAY'S North Atlantic ship crossings are a far cryin numbers, at leastfrom the pre jet era, when more than 800,000 passengers annually sailed across the ocean. But the lure has not yet faded. There are still close to 100,000 travelers a year who have the time, desire and bankroll to sail rather than fly between New York and Europe. Next year they will be able to choose among 26 sailings from New York on regular passenger liners, not to mention a variety of freighter trips.

title: Boxing Club Fights for Life
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The Franklin Boxing Club and Gym, which marked its second anniversary last month, has more boxers coming to practice than ever before. It also has more problems.

title: Publishers Go to the Movies
description: I can't, and won't, pretend objectivity about LIFE GOES TO THE MOVIES (TimeLife Books, $19.95). I was that magazine's movie reviewer for the last seven years of its existence, and the editor of this book, David E. Scherman, was my editor during what was, for me, one of the happiest times of my professional life. Obviously, I was favorably disposed toward this book long before I opened it.

title: Inside TV's Family Hour Feud
description: The Family Viewing Hour, which like Longfellow's Children's Hour, occurs between the dark and the daylight was designed to be a pause, in the day's occupations when the sex and mayhem that normally fills America's television screens is replaced by shows that according to Tom Swafford, CBS's VicePresident of Program Practices, would embarrass neither parents nor children. The policy, which controls the nature of television programming between the hours of 7 and 9 P.M. (EST), when approximately 14 million children (18 percent of the total audience at that time) are watching, was put into effect by the networks on Sept. 8 and has been a source of conflict, ever since. It is a conflict that has been fueled by public statements about censorship and private worries about money.

title: COINING TRASH GOLD STRIKE ON THE DISASSEMBLY LINE
description: There are two ways of getting steelout of the ground, in the form of iron ore, and out of garbage and trash, in the form of rusty cans, bent paper clips, broken toys, old refrigerators and the like. The steel is the same. But, in a world of dwindling natural resources and growing environmental pollution, the two methods differ in ways that have profound implications for the future of industrialized societies. For every ton of steel produced from recycled municipal solid waste instead of ore, the following things happen:

title: CUBANS SAID TO AID BOMBINGS IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI Dec. 6 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation charged today that a lack of cooperation in the city's Cuban exile community has hampered the investigation of seven bombings Wednesday night and Thursday.

title: A Pair of Escapees Caught in Kentucky After Hijacking Bus
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6 (AP) Two armed fugitives commandeered a city bus, a taxi and a private automobile and then boarded another bus as paying passengers in a trek that ended with their arrest today in Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: Knicks' Substitutes Help Defeat Braves
description: Buoyed by a 41point second quarter, their best effort of the season, and key help from the bench, the Knicks ran to an 10898 victory over the tumbling Buffalo Braves last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: DogHandling Class Set in Moorsetown
description: MOORESTOWNThe Burlington County Y.M.C.A. is offering a dogobedience course that will begin on Jan. 17 and continue for eight weeks. The course is open to anyone with a dog of least 4 months old and owners at least 12.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey.
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good. three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Caroling Scheduled By Fort Lee Choir
description: FORT LEE  The 60voice Fort Lee High School Concert Choir will present a program of Christmas carols at Horizon House on the evening of Dec. 16.

title: Engagements
description: BrowneHicks

title: 55 Torture Deaths In Brazil Since '69 Cited by Prisoners
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Brazilian political prisoners have accused the security forces of torturing to death at least 55 fellow prisoners since 1969.

title: The Nation
description: No one can say precisely when a Presidential campaign begins; it is like trying to tell where the waves come from. But the campaign of 1976, the 48th in the history of the Republic, is surely the longest, having begun sometime in 1974. It has now reached the intensive stage, that period when candidates, political activists and their journalistic camp followers workthemselves (and much of the public) into a state of insensibility. What follows is an annotated calendar of the year ahead.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Puts a $20 MillionPlus Presence in Washington
description: Money rolls into the American Petroleum Institute and big oil expands its presence in Washington.

title: ELECTION PANEL GETS HAYS PLEDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Rep resentative Wayne L. Hays has promised not to kill proposed regulations of the Federal Election Commission by bottling them up in committee Congress gives him authority to exercise such a pocket veto.

title: S. N. Stein Fiance Of Judith Karlen
description: Dr. and Mrs. William S. Karlen of Maplewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Nan Karlen, to Steven Neal Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob K. Stein of Cincinnati.

title: Kuwait's Bonds
description: Kuwait has a stake in Israel's future. Three months ago the United Realty Corporation of Kuwait, an Arabowned company, bought 17 downtown Boston office buildings from Maurice Gordon and Sons Realty Company. One of the landlord's tenants is the Development Corporation for Israel, which is in business to sell State of Israel bondsand uses Israeli bonds to pay the $1,500 a month rent.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: In an interesting letter published in these pages last week under the engagingly alliterative headline Kudos to Kalstone Rachel Jacoff defended David Kalstone's recent article Why the Russians Dance Circles Around Us in a somewhat simplistic fashion. Apparently my attack on that article and in particular my remarks about the Ballet Theater's performances of Giselle in Washington came as quite a shock. My remarks were not based on, those performanceswhich I did not see, as I explained at the time; My remarks were based on the fact that Professor Kalstone was taking two contrasted performances of Giselle to demonstrate his contention of the ineffable superiority, through training of Russian dancers over American dancers.

title: Abbie Hoffman Tells of His Life During 20 Months as a Fugitive
description: AUSTIN. Tex. Dec. 6 (AP)Abbie Hoffman, founder of the Yippies, author and perhaps the best known radical on the run, has worked as a teacher, posed as a wealthy Texas oilman and had three nose operation in more than 20 months as a fugitive.

title: Mother, 85, Fights to Keep Quadriplegic Son
description: The situation is almost beyond belief. Mrs. R. is 85 years old, frail and ill, and yet she manages against all odds to keep herself and her 50yearold quadriplegic son, Martin, going in a small apartment in Westchester County. She is totally responsible for his care. To get Martin to walk, she places his feet on hers, grips him around the waist, and totes him even to the bathroom, because he can do nothing for himself.

title: Cherry Hill Sprucing Up Route 70 With Plants
description: CHERRY HILLA new administration in this affluent township is wondering whether fresh beauty, in the form of new trees, flowers and shrubs, can make Route 70 more acceptable as a main street.

title: NEWSMAN FIGHTS CONTEMPT JAILING
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6A newsman for a New Orleans television station has gone to jail twice and says he will go back again to serve the remainder of a 30day sentence, if legal efforts fail to free him of contempt of court charges.

title: Rutherford Sees Better Racing As Result of EngineRule Freeze
description: While some name drivers have been saying that the United States Auto Club made a mistake by freezing the championship division engine rules for the next five years, Jonnny Rutherford thinks it was a good move. I'll make you a bet that our racing will be fantastic in 1976, he said. The competition was very strong this year, and I think that the engine rules, more than anything else, were responsible.

description: Lucinda Anne Cooke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Wadsworth Cooke Jr. of Babylon, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward McCoy Mullin, son of Michael M. Mullin Jr. of New York and the late Mrs. Mullin.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: STREET LIGHT DAMAGE (Nov. 23) Miss E.A.P., Staten Island, noted that when a housing project was built next to her property, high intensity lights were installed by her backyard fence, which shine on her garden at night. She observed that her fruit trees were less fruitful, her mums have not yet bloomed and the flowers near the lights were sparse. She wondered if the lights were affecting her garden plants. Neal R. Tempel, writes from the biology department of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, L.I. that lights do indeed alter the plant's photoperiod mechanism and the problem is becoming more common since the new installations of the sodium vapor lamps. He enclosed an article from the New York State Environment describing U.S. Department of Agriculture Research on high pressure sodium lamps. The researchers have found that although these lamps are twice as efficient as mercury lamps, they emit more yellow and red light. The red part of the spectrum is the growth triggering light which affects flowering, branching, dormancy and other growth responses. The researchers recommended using the sodium vapor lamps only on streets or highways for safety where light tolerant plants can be grown. Metal hallide lamps, though less efficient, are preferred in malls and parks where there are dense plantings.

title: The Uncertain Battle
description: Congressional approval of President Ford's plan for limited, shortterm financial assistance to New York marks a crucial turning point in this city's battle for survival. But the victory in Washington was won at heavy cost and the fight is far from over. Although bankruptcy has been averted, the worst is yet to come in terms the sacrifices that will be required of all New Yorkers restore their metropolis to fiscal and economic health.

description: A major salmon fishing ground could be established in the world's southern oceans as a result of explorations begun in southern Chile by American scientists, with the cooperation of the Chilean navy and support from the Rockefellen Foundation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State of New Jersey has the right to deny pregnant women welfare benefits for their unborn children, a threejudge United States District Court panel in Camden has ruled. The decision rejected a challenge to the state's welfare policies by the Camden Regional Legal Services office, which asserted that the state had a responsibility to care for children before they are born as well as afterward. Judges S. Clarkson Fischer, Mitchell Cohen and James Hunter 3d ruled that the state did not deny New Jersey women equal protection under the law because of the option, which Congress placed in the Social Security Act.

title: File of High Court Nominee Lists No Extra Income
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6Documents filed in Federal court here by Judge John Paul Stevens, President Ford's choice for the vacant United States Supreme Court seat, state that he has not earned any outside income or accepted any gifts, in excess of $100 during the, five years he has served on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

description: OTTAWA. Dec. 6, (Reuters) Defense Minister James Richardson has said Canada will spend an estimated $25.5 million in assigning armed forces personnel to duties at the Olympic Games in Montreal next summer.

title: 200 Years of American. Music On 100 Disks
description: In a spanking new office in New York's East Fifties, where the paint is scarcely dry and the pictures are yet unhung, a new nonprofit recording project is under way quite unlike anything ever before envisaged. A big name stands behind itthe Rockefeller Foundationand a noble goal ahead of it: the creation of a 100disk recorded anthology, to be called New World Records, which will reflect American musical life from our earliest beginnings to the present. The total cost of the plan, which includes free distribution to some 8,000 universities, schools, libraries, noncommercial radio stations and the like, plus atcost distribution to 120,000 other institutions, is estimated to run about $4 million. The time span for the release of the recordings is three years, with the first ten albums to come next April, the final ten in the fall of 1978. total cost of the plan, which includes free distribution to some 8,000 universities, schools, libraries, noncommercial radio stations and the like, plus atcost distribution to 120,000 other institutions, is estimated to run about $4 million. title: China Hand Says Tape Is Red, Too
description: PEKINGIt had taken almost three months for our belongings to be unloaded and make their way through China's congested port and railway system. But finally there was our large wooden packing crate, sitting in a railway freight yard on the south side of Peking.

title: PHYSICIAN NOTES EUTHANASIA SHIFT
description: Dr. Urs Peter Hammerli, a Swiss physician who last January was accused of murder because he did not forcefeed terminally ill patients, said here yesterday that attitudes toward passive euthanasia were changing as more people were personally exposed to the question of whether to prolong life when there was no prognosis for recovery.

title: Western Kentucky Beats New Hampshire in Bowl
description: BATON ROUGE, DEC. 6 (AP) A swarming, ballhawking defense and an 87yard punt return by Rick Caswell paced Western Kentucky to a 14.3 victory over the University of New Hampshire today in the Grantland Rice Bowl and earned the victors a berth in the Division II national football championship game next weekend.

title: TV Notes: How Sweep Weeks Hype the Ratings
description: During certain fourweek stretches in the months of November, February and May, much of the networks' more lackluster fare is replaced by a parade of flashy treats. For instance, Tuesday night is not normally when CBS schedules a movie, but that's where the network displayed MGM's That's Entertainment a couple of weeks ago. On a recent Thursday night, NBC wiped its regular schedule clean for specials starring McLean Stevenson, AnnMargret and Dean Martin. On a Friday evening ABC recently offered a Movie of the Week double feature, Wonder Woman and Hey, I'm Alive. What all three networks were doing was showcasing spiffy items in an effort to spruce up their weakestrated nights during what is referred to in the industry as sweep weeks.

title: Air Force to Cut Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The Air Force has announced that as many as 2,945 civilian workers will lose their jobs logistics installations in six states by next July. It said they are workers whose skills are surplus.

description: Following passage by the Senate early yesterday morning of legislation to authorize Federal loans to New York City, Governor Carey has begun searching for an outstanding investment banker to direct the rescue of four independent state agencies, which are threatened with default unless $2.5 billion in financing can be arranged for them over the next 30 months.

title: Future Social Events
description: Dec. 10The Bicentennial specialty of the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute will be fashion plates, an exhibition called American Women of Style created by Diana Vreeland and made possible by a grant from SCM, the conglomerate, which has added art sponsorship to its diversifications. So there has to be a chic benefit preview. Mrs. Charles W. Engelhard is the chairman, and it couldn't come at a better time of year because the Metropolitan's angelic Christmas tree in the Medieval Sculpture Court will be the centerpiece for cocktails. An allAmerican dinner in the Fountain Restaurantsmoked rainbow trout, turkey with chestnut dressing, creamed onions, cranberry sauce and baked caramel apples will have one French touch  Veuve Clicquot champagne. Then guests may dance to a discothque in the Great Hall or inspect the fashion panorama in the Costume Institute. The American women whose clothes are represented start with Elsie de Wolfe, Lady Mendl, called the country's first professional interior decorator; Irene Langhorne Gibson, the Gibson girl; Consuelo Vanderbilt, Duchess of Marlborough, later Mrs. Jacques Balsan; Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, sculpture and museum founder; Isadore Duncan, who created her own draperies, dancing and life style; Irene Castle, who taught American women to discard petticoats and corsets, to abbreviate skirts and bob their hair, and Josephine Baker, who wowed them in France. The exhibition will be open to the public next Saturday through next August. Preview cocktails, dinner, etc., $125; just viewing, $25.

title: Vander Meer's Feat Voted Reds Best

The media representatives also selected Pete Rose, third baseman, the most memorable personality ever associated with the team. Vander Meer pitched the first nohit game against Boston at Crosley Field in Cincinnati on June 11, 1938, and followed it up with a nohitter in Brooklyn on June 15.

title: Down Memory Lane

It was going to be a fife and drum pageant, when charming, overshadowed old cities like Boston, New Orleans and Philadelphia would have a chance to reassert themselves and fine states like Missouri, Wisconsin, New Mexico could hold celebrations. Behind the fun of the Injun raids, of Benedict Arnold's expedition to Quebec reenacted, it was going to be part of the carefully orchestrated triumphal Nixon windup of eight years in office, beginning a generation of peace.

title: Boundless Resource
description: Among the shakiest of the bridges linking our interdependent society are those between the now almost totally separate worlds of education and of work. Except for an increasingly outmoded system of vocational schools and a newer network of technically oriented junior colleges, there are more cutoff points than interconnections between the two worlds. Youth is the time for learning, maturity for earning and old age for obsolescencetime traps that prove frustrating to millions of Americans even when mass unemployment does not make a mockery of the boundary lines.

description: JERSEY CITYThere is culture in Hudson County, and the county's Cultural Council is trying to awaken the area to its richness.

title: How to Collect Handcuffs

Many deserve that fate, or worse, yet some are fine substantive books. We have tried to distinguish the genuine article from the gussiedup pretenders.

title: How Met Museum Chased and Captured 20,000 Works of Art Is Described in Book by Roving and Staff
description: How does an art museum capture 20,000 desirable objects in the short space of 10 years? By searching them out and researching them, then stalking donors, haunting dealers, maneuvering at auction, sitting out bequests and out witting other acquisitors.

title: Dolls for Adults
description: When I was younger I remember being just captivated by dolls. Birthdays, Christmases, anytime doll gifts were to be received was paradise. Just the word doll was thrilling. I loved Baby dolls, Barbie dolls, Old fashioned dolls, princess dolls, talking, crying and eating dolls, and particularly four porcelain dolls that my mother kept on  the mantle piece. Why those four were so especially attracting to me, I do not know; but I think it was the mystifying fact that she was a grownup and they were her dolls. Which suprised me because she was always saying to me, Not another doll? and had never seemed particularly enthralled with my playing with them.

title: Grain Prices Penalizing the Already Poor
description: With the news last week of the most disastrous Soviet grain harvest in a decade, in dramatic contrast with the record crops in the United States, came the realization that this country, more than ever, holds the key to the world's food supply.

The soloists were Elizabeth Farr and Beverly Rinaldi, sopranos; Carole Walters, mezzosoprano; Frank Hoffmeister, tenor, and Herbert Beattie, bass.

title: Mary Ivancevic, James Nichols Plan Marriage
description: Mary Ivancevic and James C. Nichols plan to be married April 10 in New Canaan, Conn. The future bride is supervisor of the order department of the Wilks Scientific Corporation in Norwalk, Conn., and her fianc is a service technician with the concern.

title: Supershop

Late in October, Water Tower Place a 74story multipurpose building opened on Michigan Avenue, the Windy City's Magnificent Mile. From the outside Water Tower Place looks like a gigantic bluegray, warehouse, but inside is a dazzling display2 department stores, stories of boutiques, offices and apartments, with Marshall Field and Lord & Taylor the big stores. Even before all the boutiques were open Water Tower Place was drawing customers into the neighborhood.
