description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Dec. 6The Allmand Development Corporation of Ann Arbor has signed an agreement to College from the Rev. Rex and structures of Mackinac Colleg from the Rev. Rex Humbartl, the radio end television evangelist, and his Cathedral of Tomorrow in Akron, Ohio.

title: Commune In Disguise Flourishes In Suburbs
description: The Elm Lane Eight, a legally established partnership, is a group of three couples, two singles and three children living together in a house in a New York suburb.

title: MISHIMA'S VIEWS ESPOUSED BY FEW
description: TOKYO, Dec. 6When the famed Japanese writer and nationalist, Yukio Mishima, stunned his compatriots with his spectacular suicide five years ago, he also aroused fears of a revival of Japanese ultranationalism.

title: U.S GRAIN INQUIRY HINTS AT RIGGING OF SNIP SUBSIDIES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Federal agents are investigating suspected manipulation of United States shipping subsidies for shipments of grain in the Food for Peace program, according to Government sources.

title: Celtics Set Back Hawks As Cowens Paces Rally
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (AP)Dave Cowens sparked a Boston rally that earned a 111104 N.B.A. victory over Atlanta tonight.

title: Coaches in Tie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (UPI)Dick Vermiel, who led the University of California, Los Angeles, to its first Rose Bowl appearance in nine years, and Don James, whose surprising Washington team missed being the Bowl representative by only 4 points, were named today cowinners of the Pacific 8 Conference Football Coachoftheyear award.

title: Court Due to Rule On School Funding
description: TRENTONTwo and onehalf years ago, the State Supreme Court ruled that the existing system of financing public schools in New Jersey was unconstitutional. The court held then that the system's reliance on local property taxes as its primary means of financial support had created wide and inequitable disparities between the quality, of education in wealthy and poor communities.

title: The New Personal Pension Plans
description: The first annual deadline for setting up Individual Retirement Accounts is now less than four weeks away, and among those vying for the business, the strains of competition are beginning to tell.

title: Miss Becton Has Nuptials
description: Lizabeth Louise Becton and Richard Allan Cronenberg were married yesterday in the Reformed Church of Cherry Hill in River Edge, N. J. by the Rev. Eltje Brunemeyer.

title: Boulez Leads a Premiere
description: The first of this season's two Prospective Encounters, presented by the New York Philharmonic under Pierre Boulez's direction at Cooper Union, was given on Friday night. It began with the premiere of Lucia Dlugoszewski's Abyss and Caress.

title: Food News
description: MADISONHenry's Delicatessen on Main Street is a delicatessen with a college degree, which is as it should be in a college town.

title: Mazzei Italian Friend of Jefferson and The Revolution
description: FLORHAM PARK  The zealousness and vital contributions of an Italian in the formation of the United States are the subject of a recently published book, Philip Mazzei: Jefferson's Zealous Whig.

title: A Gift List of Books for Fanciers, Starting With Tome for All Breeds
description: With the holiday season rapidly approaching, now is the time fanciers are seeking books as gifts. We have tried to include a sampling to cover the overall picture of the sport. There are individual breed works, a comprehensive volume including all the American Kennel Club breeds, a training manual for the ambitious owner who wants to make a watchdog of his pet, something to satisfy the birddog enthusiast and a volume about talking dogs. Next Sunday we will include others.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: Elizabeth Arden, Inc., has subleased 40,415 square feet of office space at 1345 Avenue of the Americas from Burlington Industries for five years at an aggregate rent of $1.9million.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A continuing flow of letters from readers indicates that there is still more than a little confusion about the differences between the U.S. Mint's regular annual sixcoin proof set and the Mint's special threecoin Bicentennial proof set. To help eliminate some of this confusion, photographs of each type of set are presented at right.

title: James Langley Fiance of Miss Kushner
description: Judith Kushner, a translator at the United Nations, and James Roberts Langley, a senior marketing representative with the Exxon Corporation here, plan to be married Jan. 11.

title: U.S. Customs to Revise Its Revenue Collection
description: The United States Customs is about to set out on a new tack to streamline its revenue collection.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Weddings

title: San Francisco Booters, S. Illinois Gain Final
description: EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., Dec. 6Physical strength, tenacity and determination prevailed today in the University Division soccer semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament before a capacity crowd of about 5,000 fans.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: I.R.A. Gunmen Hold Couple Hostage After a Police Chase Through London
description: LONDON, Sunday, Dect. 7 (Reuters)Gunmen belonging to the I.R.A. Provisionals held a young couple hostage in their (central London home early today and demanded a plane to take them back to Ireland.

title: North Vietnam Returning Bodies of 3 U.S. Pilots
description: PARIS, Dec. 6North Vietnam's Ambassador told a United States Congressional group here today that it was returning the bodies of three American pilots and looked forward to normal and even friendly relations with the United States.

title: Corporate Santa Pays the Days
description: The favorite stocking stuffer of any work force at Christmas will be the paid days off for the holiday weeks. This year, according to a PrenticeHall survey of 298 companies across the nation, most will give their workers Christmas Thursday plus Friday off, making for a four day weekend. But a substantial number will let workers off half or even all of Wednesday, Dec. 24, too.

title: Appraising, a Jewel of a Business
description: CARLE PLACEMichael Delmonte knows that a recession is going on because his business is booming.

title: Exhibition of Crafts At Garden Invokes Bicentennial Theme
description: A woman wearing a yellow bonnet and a full length skirt sat at a wheel spinning wool from sheep raised on a farm in New Jersey.

title: Miss Sauerbrunn Bride in Capital
description: Jennifer Jordan Sauerbrunn and Eric Lawrence Harper were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington, by the Rev. Hugh McGlashon Jr. of Mount Holly, N.J., an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Byrne Is Favored to Win Battle Over the Senate Leadership
description: TRENTON  The battle over who is to lead the Democratic majority in the Senate has turned into a personal confrontation between Governor Byrne and Senator James P. Dugan, the Democratic state chairman. The odds are that Mr. Byrne will prevail this time.

title: Results in College and School Sports
L.I. Retail Sales Go Up
description: Long Island retailers are hoping for a strong recovery now that the Christmas shopping season is in full swing. Many feel that prospects are better this year than last December, but that too many ifs remain for merchants to relax and enjoy the Yuletide cheer.

title: Woody Allen in a Comedy About Blacklisting? Don't Laugh
description: Intriguing. Zero Mostel and Woody Allen. Together again at last for the first time. On the silver screen. But perhaps even more intriguing is the subject and the style of the movie that they're making together, The Front, which is at the moment being filmed at a mixed assortment of locations around Manhattan and scheduled to open here next spring. The time of The Front is 1953, when Dwight D. Eisenhower was frequently in the White House, when Christine Jorgensen was having his/her sex changed in Denmark, when Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin was at the height of his despotic powers, and when tens of millions of Americans were whiling away their time ??eaming up droodles. In 1953, too, the blacklist was in force throughout the American broadcasting and movie industries, and the blacklist is what The Front chances to be all about.

title: CONDUCTING DEBUT BY GERARD SCHWARZ
description: Gerard Schwarz is a busy man. Aside from being coprincipal trumpeter of the New York Philharmonic and recording disks of trumpet and cornet confections every other minute, he composes, solos frequently andnowconducts.

title: East Brunswick Students Offering CableTV News Shows
description: EAST BRUNSWICKHigh school students here are recording local events on videotape, editing the tapes into a weekly, halfhour news and features program and then broadcasting the show over a cabletelevision system.

title: Marriage Set By Miss Tully
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tully of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Mary Tully, to James B. Moore 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs, James B. Moore Jr., also of Pelham Manor.

title: SAN DIEGO IMPOSES NIGHTFLIGHT CURB
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 6A curfew prohibiting aircraft takeoffs from San Diego's Lindbergh Field between midnight and 6 A.M. has been ordered in what the city's Port Commission called the most restrictive noiseabatement action by any metropolitan airport in the country.

title: Oklahoma Takes Swim
description: BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 6 (AP)  Oklahoma swimmers won three events, including the 400yard medley, the 200yard freestyle relay and the 300yard backstroke, and beat Colorado for the team title today in the 10th annual Big Eight Conference swimming relays. The Sooners had 94 points and the Buffaloes 81. Kansas, the defender, had 69.

title: ART VIEW
description: The first generation of American modernist paintersMarsden Hartley, Alfred Maurer, Arthur G. Dove, John Marin, Max Weber, et. al.has proved to be remarkably difficult to keep in properfocus. The shifting perspectives of art history, far from clarifying the achievements of this remarkable group of artists, have often served to obscure them. In their lifetimes, these painterswere frequently obliged to suffer adverse comparisons with the work of their great European contemporaries. Their posthumous fame has been similarly overshadowedby the international renown of the New York School, They have been unfortunate, too, in attracting few spokesmen or scholars of compelling intellectual distinction. Though they have by no means lacked some gifted and vocal champions, both in their time and in ours, the literature on these painters tends nonetheless to be secondrate or out of date. It is no exaggeration to say that today their work exists in an intellectual vacuum.

title: Lawyers Are Touched In Adversary Exercise
description: The law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, which has successfully defended Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, had no trouble yesterday defending its own goal line.

title: Huntington Is Looking Back
description: Huntington in Our Sime, a booklet of photographs illustrating the town's growth since the turn of the century and enlivened with anecdotes from local residents was published last week by the Huntington Historical Society.

title: This Week in Sports
description: College Basketball

title: The OPEC Nations Are Keeping Less Than Expected
description: WASHINGTONAlmost exactly a year ago the quarterly Foreign Affairs published an article called How Can the World Afford OPEC Oil? by five economists from four countries, including two from the United States. In raising the specter of a financial problem of staggering proportions, along with other difficulties, the article was representative of its time. It was essentially alarmist.

title: Handmade With Your Own Hands
description: In the years of the Great Depression, Americans tried to heal themselves by going to the movies twice a week. But times have changed and so have we. This time we're making it through on selfhelp and handicrafts, and you don't have to be too observant to spot the trend. There are three meditation books on the best seller lists, and one publisher is churning out craft books so fast that they sent me one book with grease marks lovingly reproduced on the color plates, another book with a text that referred to illustrations that weren't in the book and still another book with the binding on upside down.

title: Birds Rare and Common
description: It is difficult to remember a time when the year's crop of nature volumes did not include a veritable treasure of bird books, and in recent years publishers have striven to create truly beautiful books, at times relying less on text than in the past. Again, 1975 has kept pace with tradition.

title: Good Looking History
description: The coffee table book may soon be a thing of the past, whipped and ravaged and leeched by inflation and recession. Still, here, and against the massed evil forces of economics and technology, are some good, and even some fine, illustrated books about the past and its people.

title: MILLION IN ANGOLA CALLED DESTITUTE
description: UIGE, Angola, Dec. 4  As many as one million tribal people live without food, clothing or medical attention in the villages of northern Angola, according to the key health official in Uige.

title: 8 Saved as Freighter Sinks
description: MIAMI, Dec. 6 (AP)  A United States  registered freighter sank in the Atlantic 10 miles off Miami today, and its eight crew members were rescued after a radio station fishing forecaster spotted their lifeboat from a helicopter, the Coast Guard said. The 125foot Geda was loaded with cargo when it sank.

title: Gunman Kills a Man and Shoots Two During Show at the Apollo
description: As an audience of 2,000 watched a postmidnight performance at the Apollo Theatre in Harlem, an unknown assailant slipped into a box and fired five shots, killing an 18yearold spectator and wounding another man and a 16yearold girl.

title: How Tall Do You Want Your Venus de Milo?
description: Anyone, provided he has a High ceiling and a thick pocketbook, can have his own fullscale plaster Venus de Milo or Winged Victory. All it takes is room enough to display the 6foot, 6inch tall Venus and the $600 purchase price. The 9foot tall Victory, which costs $1,100, requires an additional 6 feet, 18 inches for its wing span. For the less affluent, the statues come in four smaller sizes ranging down to 18 inches at $54 for the Venus, and 12 inches at $32 for the Victory.

title: The Look Book
description: Look was born in Des Moines, Iowa, in 1937 and died in New York City in 1971. During these unsettling years the magazine lived through the end of a depression, three wars, five Presidents, uncountable changes in popular taste, a whole new array of social concerns and a revolution in communications technology that eventually put it out of business. Modeled after newspaper

title: TENANTS PROTEST COLUMBIA POLICY
description: About 50 residents of apartments owned by Columbia University rallied, chanted and sang yesterday morning in Morningside Heights to protest eviction actions the University has started against 200 tenants who are no longo affiliated with Columbia.

title: Tank FarmSuperport Hearing Set Despite Protest
description: TRENTONDespite vehement objections from local environmentalists, Commissioner David J. Bardin of the state's Department of Environmental Protection has refused to postpone a public hearing on a proposal to construct 270 storage tanks and a superport on a peninsula of Upper New York Bay land between Jersey City and Bayonne. The meeting is scheduled for Thursday.

title: AfterSchool Projects in Huntington Are Attracting Children
description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON Schoolchildren everywhere usually share one traitThey cannot get out of the building fast enough when the school day has ended.

title: Endpaper
description: Once upon a time, five years ago to be exact, I met a prince who lived in a castle in a fairy kingdom. He looked sad. We had dinner together aud he told me about his strange problem.

title: The Region
description: All three legislatures in the tristate area met in special session last week, an oddity coincidental in time and purpose. All three convened over problems of money, or rather lack of it and none has yet found a solution.

title: Figure in Presidential Race Sues on University Ouster
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 6 (AP) Channing E. Phillips, the first black to be nominated for the Presidency of the United States, has filed a $200,000 lawsuit against Virginia Union University for dismissing him from the school's vice presidency.

title: U.S. IS ASKED TO CURB CIVILIAN JETS' NOISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency believes that the Government's noise regulations for commercial jetliners should be extended to smaller civilian jets.

title: Two Second Basemen
description: As small second basemen, they understood each other. Growing up, Joe Morgan identified with Nellie Fox as a battler, the type of guy I admired; if he can do it at his size, I can do it. Joe Morgan of the Cincinnati Reds was the Most Valuable Player in the National League last season. Not since Nellie For of the Chicago White Sox in 1959 had a second baseman been so honored. But their bond developed a decade ago with the Houston Astros when Joe Morgan was a rookie and Nellie Fox was completing a 19year major league career. Somebody else might have made it difficult for a rookie to succeed him, but Nellie Fox made it easy. That was typical of Nellie Fox, who died of cancer last week in a Baltimore hospital at age 47, only two days after Joe Morgan last talked to him.

title: They Make Up a scattered Nation of 2.5 Million People
description: JERUSALEMEgyptian President Anwar elSadat declared recently that 1976 will be The Year Palestine. Other Arab leaders urge establishment of a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and in Gaza. The. Palestinians now have a voice at the United Nations. There is general admissionexcept on the part of the Goverment of Israelthat the Palestinian question is central to a Middle East settlement.

title: Senator Dole Weds Miss Hanford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Federal Trade Commissioner Elizzabeth Hanford were married today in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral. The Rev. Edward L. R. Elson, Chaplain of the Senate, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Cunningham Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cunningham of Flushing, Queens, and Shelter Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Cunningham, to Robert A. Caccese, son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Caccese of Brooklyn and Shelter Island. Miss Cunningham is an alumna of Marymount Manhattan College. Her fianc, a student at Brooklyn Law School, is a graduate of the University of Denver.

title: Insurance Rating Unit Set
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has signed a bill creating a public bureau to evaluate premium rate increases sought by insurance companies. Mr. Dukakis said Thursday that the new Insurance Rating Bureau would give the, commonwealth, for the first time, the resources it needs to do the job of regulating auto insurance companies.

title: Harris Blocks Bayh Here On Liberals' Endorsement
description: Senator Birch Bayh won the majority support of the New Democratic Coalition here yesterday but fell short of endorsement by a hairline margin at a typically chaotic and dramatic delegate assembly of the coalition.

title: ARGENTINE STRIFE: TWO DEATHS A DAY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6For the last 18 months, an average of two persons a day have been killed in political violence in Argentina.

title: LEVITT QUESTIONS U.D.C. TESTIMONY
description: State officials are mystified about an audit that former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller testified was about to be released, giving the Urban Development Corporation a very good bill of health on the management of its projects.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Canada Revises Salmon Fishing Code
description: The winds of democracy are tattering the ensign of a centuryold Atlantic salmon fishing tradition in Canada's province of Quebec.

title: Charles F. Junod Jr., 64, ExOfficer of Pfizer, Dies
description: Charles F. Junod Jr., a former marketing and sales executive, died Friday night of a heart attack at the New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Pelham Manor. N.Y.

title: Volunteer Army Opposed
description: MADISON, Wis., Dec. 6 (AP) The United States should start thinking about reinstating the draft, according to former Secretary of the Army Robert Froehlke. Mr. Froehlke said he would favor a universal draft to obtain workers for many different kinds' of national projects, not just military service.

title: Essex House Faces Wrecker
description: NEWARKThe towering, redbrick Essex House, for 50 years a haven for New Jersey's social elite, has become a vacant and vandalized shell that will soon fall victim to a wrecker's ball.

title: U.S. to Increase Food Aid Abroad After Good Crop
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The United States will provide needy countries with 6.5 million tons of food aid in the 12 months ending next July 1, a 5 percent increase over plans, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said yesterday.

title: Heating Is Set Jan. 13 to Discuss Condominium Complex Proposed for Levittown
description: LEVITTOWNA plan to rezone 16 acres of this massproduced singlefamily community to allow construction of 329 condominium townhouses will be discussed at 6, public hearing of the Hempstead Town Board on Jan. 13 at Town Hall.

title: Paysons To Stay as Met Owners
description: Ownership of the New York Mets will remain in the family of Mrs. Charles S. (Joan) Payson, who died on Oct. 4, and M. Donald Grant will contiune as chairman of the board and chief executive officer.

title: Miss Meseroie, Jay W. Siegfried Plan Marriage
description: Mrs. Clinton Vanderbilt Meserole Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Point O'Woods, LI., has announced the engagement of her daugher, Barbara Ann Meserole, to Jay Worth Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Siegfried of Lexington, Mass., and Bridgehampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for next June.

title: 11 Privately Owned Bus Lines in City to Raise Fares After Jan. 1
description: Bus fares on 11 privately owned bus lines serving 400,000 riders in the city will rise to 50 cents from 35 cents after the first of the year.

title: At 74, Farley Reminisces on Politics
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Frank S. (Hap) Farley, in his time New Jersey's most influential politician and a state legislator for a record 34 consecutive years, marked his 74th birthday. Friday with a dinner party for his family and friends.

title: PANIC GRIPS BEIRUT AMID NEW KILLINGS AND KIDNAPPINGS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6A mood of panic seized the people of this city today as a wave of kidnappings and killings spread through tense neighborhoods, shattering the quiet of more than a week in the long months of ChristianMoslem strife.

title: DR. MORRIS A. SAGER
description: Dr. Morris A. Sager, former chief urologist at Sydenham Hospital, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 108 West 86th Street.

title: Radio
description: 88:15 A.M., WNYCAM: Once Upon a Time. The Pied Piper of Hamlin.

title: RIDGE WON'T CANCEL YOSHIMURA CHARGES
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. (AP)A judge says there is sufficient evidence to link Wendy Yoshimura, the 32yearold friend of Patricia Hearst, to a Berkeley garage where explosives and firearms were found three years ago.

title: DUTCH IN IMPASSE WITN TERRORISTS
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 6Negotiations between the Dutch Government and East Asian terrorists were deadlocked today as the young gunmen increased their demands.

title: Man Held in Slaying Said to Be Motivated by Hex
description: A 33yearold Ghanaian allegedly stabbed to death a fellow countryman and neighbor on a Bronx street early yesterday morning, reportedly because he felt the victim had placed a hex on him that caused repeated auto accidents, the police reported.

title: Paris Debate: First Mayor in Century
description: PARIS, Dec. 6The first holder of the office ended his term on the scaffold and the last one fled in a popular upriisng. Now, after a coolingoff period of more than a century, Paris is thinking about installing another mayor.

title: Selected Tax Swaps
description: OneWay*

title: Janis IanSociety's Child Grows Up
description: After five years of selfimposed exile, Janis Ian has returned to pop music. At her Carnegie Hall concert Friday night, Ian will appear, not as the popland child prodigy of 10 years ago, but to judge by her latest records, as a mature musician of taste and technical excellence. Ian's second album for Columbia, Between the Lines, which has remained solidly on the Billboard, Cashbox and Record World top 100 lists for the last three months, is one of those raritiesa bestseller that focuses on musicianship. Though not without its flaws, Between the Lines has substance and depth, qualities absent from Ian's adolescent career and her hit song of those years, Society's Child, a bristling tirade against adult injustice. This precocious hit was followed by Janey's Blues, Honey Do Ya Think? and New Christ Cardiac Hero which zeroed in on dishonesty, exploitation, lack of communication, even suicidal impulses. At 15goingon16 Ian became the urchin at large, pinpointing the hypocrisies.of society, ever at the mercy of its mores, wounded by its snubs.

title: ALEX TALLER DEAD; SCULPTOR AND DEAN
description: Alex Taller, a sculptor and former assistant dean of administration at Hunter College, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old.

title: Skin Diver Attacked
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) A young skin diver was bitten on the leg today by what he described as a big white shark, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: GOLDPLATED

title: Art Museum Opens in Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH  Hockey downstairs; art upstairs. The cohabitants of the Nassau County Arena may be an odd couple, indeed, but for the newly created Long Beach Museum of Art, life on the sports facility's mezzanine, with the New York Rangers practicing in the rink below, is an ingenious solution to a ticklish housing problem.

title: Kenneth Lewis Fiance Of Jeanne S. Hyman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Hyman of Roslyn Heights, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Susan Hyman, to Kenneth Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Lewis of Huntsville, Ala., and the Bronx.

title: The Army Ploughs the Sea
description: RIO DE JANEIROAfter the retirement of Simn Bolivar, who led this continent on the road to independence, the disillusioned liberator concluded that Latin America was ungovernable and those who served the revolution ploughed the sea.' His great colleague, Jos de San Martin, observed: How poor the people and the nations that have to suffer gloriously triumphant generals.

title: Crespin's Carmen Is In Love WithDeath
description: 'Carmen' is a kind of comeback, if you want, admits soprano Regine Crespin, who sang the role for the first time a month ago at the Met, and will continue to do so through Christmas Eve. Given Mme. Crespin's reputation as a major singer who has been having vocal problems, not to mention being the Met's first French Carmen in years, this was a closely noted debut.

title: The McCarter's Chief Quits
description: PRINCETONDaniel Seltzer, the actor and scholar, resigned last week as president and chairman of the board of the McCarter Theater Company. In addition to seeking his successor, officials of the theater, which is on the Princeton University campus but is independent of the school, are faced with the problem of replacing two major grants whose expiration next year threatens to tip the McCarter's precariously balanced budget.

title: Round the Garden Benefit
description: Proceeds from the Dec.17 evening performance of Round and Round the Garden at the Morosco Theater will go to the Experiment in International Living. Tickets at $60, $45 and $30 may be purchased from Mrs. Gillette Boland, 40 East 68th Street.

title: Kim Hunter a Campus Star
description: WAYNEKim Hunter, the first Academy Awardwinning actress to join the William Paterson College faculty as a guest artist, is starring in a student production of The Lion in Winter, which opened this weekend.

title: Moeller and Dorsett Head AllEast Team
description: Chet Moeller of Navy was the best defensive player in Eastern college football again this year. The senior rover back is finished with his Navy football career and probably never will play professional football because he has to serve a minimum of five years as a Naval officer after graduation next spring.

title: More RailFare Rises Feared
description: TRENTON  The reorganization of seven bankrupt Northeast railroads into the new Governmentbacked Conrail system may deal a severe blow to New Jersey's program of supporting commuter rail service, according to the state's Department of Transportation.

title: SchoolBudget Limit Creating Problems
description: TRENTON  The state's new limitations on increases in. school budgets for the 197677 school year, as per mined by the Public School Education Act of 1975, have been greeted by many local school districts is another dilemma.

title: GOODRICH CURBS CHLORIDE HAZARD
description: B. F. Goodrich, the company where the cancercausing hazard of vinyl chloride was discovered nearly two years ago, announced last week that in accordance with current Federal regulations it had succeeded in controlling worker exposure to the chemical.

title: Essex Brightens Up Life for the Elderly
description: ORANGE  They're old, they're poor, they probably live alone and they haven't seen a doctor in years.

title: FILM UNION SUED OVER JOB POLICY
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6Tak Fujimoto is a 36yearold cinematographer who was critically praised for his work on two motion pictures, Badland and Caged Heat. But, he cannot get a job at a major Hollywood studio.

title: Bay State Transit Loss
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority lost 100,000 daily passengers, or 17 percent of its ridership, in the three years that ended in 1974, the state auditor has reported. The auditor said the agency lost 75,000 daily passengers in 1972, 11,000 in 1973 and 14,000 last year.

title: Mother, 4 Children Are Shot to Death In Home in Teaneck
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 6A mother and her four children were shot to death today in their home in this suburban Bergen County community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ELEVATOR UNION REJECTS PAY OFFER
description: Negotiations yesterday failed to produce a settlement aimed at ending the sixweek old strike by elevator maintenance and repairmen when negotiators for Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters rejected the latest offer by the employers.

title: Club Opens Its Observatory
description: CRANFORD  An astronastronomy club here has opened the doors of its observatory to the public, and the response has been 12,000 visitors in the last years.

title: Food
description: One of the most coveted appetizers in the French restaurants of Manhattan, particularly those of the bistro type, is listed on the menu as saucisson  I'ail, which translates easily as garlic sausage. Actually, the vast majority of these freshly made and semidry products are purchased from Italian pork stores that specialize in sausages. Sources in Manhattan include Salumeria Biellese, 362 Eighth Avenue (at 28th Street), and Faicco's, 260 Bleecker Street. It is not all that difficult to prepare these sausages in the home, however. For those who would make their own, we offer a recipe for garlic sausages. There are also instructions for cooking the sausages, whether bought or homemade, plus a recipe for a warm potato salad, the ideal accompaniment for the dish.

title: A MixedUp Tennis World Needs a Czar
description: Baseball, football, hockey, basketball they all have their czars, usually called commissioners. Tennis, the fastestgrowing spectator and participant sport in this country, lacks not only a leader but also a rhyme and rhythm in its organization.

title: Bar Group Asks End to Lawyers' Advertising Ban
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI) An, American Bar Association coramittee called today for an end to the association's longstanding ban against advertising by lawyers.

title: Aqueduct Rice Charts
description: Saturday, Dec. 6. 24th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: STAMPS
description: The United Nations is starting out the new year with a philatelic flurry, an issue of four new definitives, in denominations of 3, 4, 30 and 50 cents. The stamps are coming out Jan. 9, 1976.

title: PAPERS EXAMINE CITIES' FINANCES
description: Most newspapers around the country have editorialized at great length on New York City's financial problems, but only a handful have bothered to take a long, hard look at their own local fiscal situation.

title: Former Federal Aide Is Named Head of Nassau Office of Manpower Programs
description: MINEOLADr. George S. Roukis of New Hyde Park, L.I. former deputy assistant Secretary of Labor in Washtingtion, was named last week executive director of the Nassau Office of Manpower Programs by County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

title: Coop Art Works Shown
description: The exhibition of art works from Brooklyn cooperative galleries that opened last week in the Community Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum is a sign of the importance and central role that cooperative galleries now enjoy in the community. They have become so significant in Brooklyn, in fact, that they now outnumber the commercial galleries.

title: Blockbusting Curbs Added in Brooklyn
description: A fouryearold state order designed to curb realestate blockbusting in Brooklyn has been extended from East Flatbush and Crown Heights into Flatlands, Mill Basin and Dart of Canarsie.

title: Model Show to Aid Railroad Museum
description: WESTFIELD  A modelrailroad hobby show and, sale will be held next Saturday at Westfield High School. 550 Dorian Road.

title: Susan Thau Engaged To Mitchell H. Katz
description: Dr. and Mrs. M. David Thau of Westbury, L. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Fern Thau, to Mitchell Haven Katz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Katz of Brooklyn.

title: Damascus Identifies for Now, With the Palestinians
description: BEIRUTA week ago, Syria's President Hafez elAssad and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, were sitting together in Damascus, waiting for news from New York.

title: Marriage Planned By Anne P. Blaxter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Vaughan Blaxter Jr. of Pittsburgh, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Penrose Blaxter, to David Arthur Page. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lloyd Page of New Berlin, N. Y.

title: What's Doing in SAN JUAN
description: ANCIENT CITYAt the entrance to San Juan harbor the massive gray walls of El Morro soar to height of 140 feet above the ocean. The fortification, whose construction began in 1539, once completely surrounded the sevenblocksquare area that is now Old San Juan. In its heyday the fortified city was a major port for Spanish galleons carrying gold and goods from the New World to Spain and it successfully repulsed attacks by Sir Francis Drake and Sir John Hawkins. In 1598, however the Earl of Cumberland breached the land wall of El Morro and took San Juan. To make the city impregnable from the land side, the Spanish in the 18th century built the intricate 27acre complex of San Cristobal about half a mile from El Morro. Unlike the olderfortress with its single compact unit of five levels, San Cristobal was built with five independent outworks, or small forts, in front of the main fort, all six units connected by tunnels or moats. Today, with Puerto Rico an American Commonwealth, both El Morro and San Cristobal are administered by the National Park Service and are open daily from 8 A.M. to P.M.; guided tours: 50 cents for adults, free for children under 16.

title: United Airlines Struck
description: A strike by service employees grounded all United Airlines flights, although negotiations on a new wage contract continued. Page 52.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Lawyers, Sociologists Debate Busing
description: LOUISVILLE, Dec. 6Lawyers and sociologists took differing stands on school busing this weekend at a conference on alternatives to busing held in this city, which has experienced violent demonstrations against school integretion.

title: CARTER RETRACTS BID FOR A PARDON
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis withdrew their application yesterday for pardons on a triplemurder conviction, saying that they wanted their names cleared completely in the courts.

title: NoGrowth: A New Era of LessIsMore
description: There used to be a familiar slogan at groundbreaking ceremonies and on signs announcing public projects: Nassau CountyFastest Growing County in the U.S.A.

title: A New College Takes Shape
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFSA new college deliberately geared for a nontraditional student body is slowly taking shake on the site of the defunct Englewood Cliffs College, which was disbanded a year ago because of fiscal problems.

title: Seesaw Club Scene Of Ellen Hanley's Singing Comeback
description: Ellen Hanley, an adorrunentl of Broadway (Fiorenor, 1776) and Julius Monk's satirical revues in the 1950's and 60's, has emerged from a period of childrearing retirement to pick up her singing career again at Seesaw, a club on Lexington Avenue at 81st Street for which intimate is almost an understatement.

title: The Best Sellers of 1975
description: In This Issue

title: Sunday Observer
description: As Americans lose the ability to speak coherently to each other in words, they speak increasingly in clothing, jewelry, gimcracks and hair. Just the other night I met a woman whose finger told me she was divorced. The finger bore the latest thing in talking jewelrya divorce ring. A divorce ring looks like a wedding band with a crack in it and costs between 5300 and $350.

title: Dear Miss Farthingale, Thank You for Your Tragedy ...
description: LONDON What shall we call you? asked the Royal Shakespeare Company's chief of publicity. Anything rather than dramaturg, don't you agree? It makes people imagine a fierce old German professor poring over folios and popping toads into cauldrons.

title: Moynihan Chides U.N. on Israel Issue
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6The chief American delegate at the United Nations, Daniel P. Moynihan, said today that he was astonished that the Security Council had adjourned its debate on the Israeli air strikes in Lebanon until Monday, rather than coping with the issue over the weekend.

title: Music in Review
description: When Gina Capkas came to a group of songs by composers of her native Lithuania, her singing took on a natural flow that was not often in evidence during the rest of her Carnegie Recital Hall debut last Sunday night.

title: Kent Place Clinging To AllGirl Tradition
description: SUMMITWellesley won't do ?? and Smith and Mount Holyoke won't do it. Now, Kent Place School, which sends many of its graduates to those prestigious colleges, says it won't do it, either.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Photographers can use their picturesregardless of whether they be blackandwhite or color prints, or even transparencies  to create many different types of Christmas gifts for friends and relatives. Involving very little expense, while deriving a great deal of fun and satisfaction in the process, the photographer can transform many ordinary household items into handsome, personalized presents that will be treasured by those who receive them. Milk cartons, pill bottles, tin cans, stones, plywood, bricks, burlap, shirts. tablecloths or sheets  almost anything can be used to create a striking or amusing photographic present.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I'm in the process of putting up paneling in my basement and I would like to know if I can glue the panels directly to the cement block wall, or if it is necessary to put up furring strips first. If gluing is feasible, what kind of glue would I use? G.C.G., New Prague, Minn.

title: Cooking by the Book
description: Something must be radically wrong with a country that will not buy novels but will gobble up cookbooks of almost any kind. Americans, the moral seems to be, can neither read nor cook. At least, however, the boom market in cookbooks indicates that we are trying to improve the quality of what we eat. And the publishing industry has responded to this demand with a few extraordinary collections of recipes amid the annual flurry of preChristmas junk.

title: Bill Levitt Plans a Comeback at 68
description: LOS ANGELESWhat we have to have is a good home that sells for a realistic price for under $25,000, and that's what I want to build. The building industry today has priced itself out of the market; people can't afford what they build.

title: MADRID ARRESTS PARDONED PRIEST
description: MADRID, Dec. 6The Rev. Francisco Garcia Salve, a Roman Catholic workerpriest who had been a clandestine labor leaded, was back in jail today less than a week after he had been freed under a pardon decreed by King Juan Carlos I.

title: ROME ABORTION BILL CLEARS AN OBSTACLE
description: ROME, Dec. 6 (Reuters)A bill to legalize abortion in Italy has cleared a major hurdle here, with the defeat of an amendment that sought to classify abortion as a punishable offense except under certain circumstances.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: A number of people have argued this year that United States trade policy is turning increasingly protectionist and that the Trade Act of 1974, the new legislative foundation for our trade policy, carries the potential for implementing that protectionism.

title: Figures in the Foreground
description: When art refuses to speak, the criticand, sometimes, the artistsupplies the words, Amid this season's barrage of explication, promotion, evaluation, the talk is often cloudy, sometimes cosmic (if not comic) in its implications and, on gratifying occasions, rational and instructive.

title: ROBERT D. HOFFMAN, MINING ENGINEER, 77
description: Robert D. Hoffman, a mining engineer and geologist, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 77 years old and had homes at 151 Central Park West and Stonington, Conn.

title: Letters
description: Liberated marriages

title: AllEast College Team
description: Quarterbacks: Joe Caviello, F. and M.; Lynn Hieber, Indiana Univ., (Pa.); Jim Kubacki, Harvard.

title: Hofstra Sees Hope In Increase Of Students
description: HEMPSTEAD  Hofstra University, which recently dismissed 111 of its 600 administrative workers because of budgetary problems, received a ray of hope for the future last week with what it termed a dramatic rise in the number, of applications for admission for 1976.

title: BRIDGE
description: All the popular conventions become somewhat more sophisticated in the hands of expert partnerships. A case in point is the grand slam force, a jump to five notrump asking for a grand slam if partner has two of the top three trump honors.

title: Correction
description: In an article on education and sexrole stereotyping that appeared in The Review Nov. 23, the results of research on changing children's sexrole concepts through teacher intervention were incorrectly stated. Dr. Marcia Guttentag's work has shown that at the ninthgrade level girls became more flexible in their definitions of masculinity and feminity as a result of intervention; boys in ninth grade generally became more narrow.

title: Commerce Dept. Favors Nonreturnable Bottles
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) A Commerce Department study released this week recommends against any national legislation restricting nonreturnable beverage containers. It said such legislation probably would do more harm than good.

title: Norway and Soviet Union Fail to Agree on Barents Sea
description: OSLO, Norway, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Norway and the Soviet Union failed to resolve their differences over how to draw a dividing line o nthe Continental shelf in the Barents Sea, well informed sources said Friday.

title: Ideas&Trends
description: High school guidance counselorsamong the first cut in New York City's school budget slashesare variously described as necessary, unnecessary, recycled teachers, student advocates, minishrinks, another dogood part of the educational bureaucracy. Nearly every high school has one.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bergen Does Well In Salary Survey
description: HACKENSACK  Employees of medium  sized companies make out better, as a rule, than those working for small or large concerns, according to the annual wage and fringebenefit study conducted by the Bergen County Chamber of Commerce.

title: Eagleton Institute of Politics Is Nearing its 20th Anniversary
Daughter to the Forbeses
description: A daughter was born Nov. 20 in Morristown N.J.) Memorial Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Forbes of Far Hills, N. J. Mrs. Forbes is the former Baroness Astrid Mathilde Cornelia von Hey of Herrnsheim, West Germany. Her husband, an advertising salesman for Forbes magazine, is also curator of the Forbes Art Collection owned by Forbes Inc., of which his father, Malcolm S. Forbes, is president. The magazine was founded by the late B. C. Forbes, greatgrandfather of the baby, who has been named Charlotte Adelaide Mathilde.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the DaySection 1

title: Blackmailer Gone Wrong
description: When Francis Patrick Dunne realized he would have to make his own way in the world, he cast about for wellpaid work with pleasant hours that would throw him in with a nice class of people. Blackmail seemed to meet the specifications, especially with regard to the associations he would enjoy. You can't blackmail a bum, he points out. However, there was a certain element of risk involved, so he lowered his standards and became a racing steward. Now, having passed his 76th birthday recently, he has retired, which means he still works as a steward but not so often.

title: Choreography for Graham Is a Gut Reaction
description: Fifty years ago in the middle of the Jazz Age, Martha Graham hired a Broadway Theater for one night and gave an evening of her own dances. It was a declaration of where she belongednot in vaudeville, or ladies' matinees, or the European avantgarde, but here in the American theater. She is now 81 years old and has never lowered her sights.

title: Artists Try Hand At Quilt Making
description: PORT WASHINGTONThe result of a quilting bee, in days of old, was a quilt. But the modern version that produced the work now on display at the Central. Hall Gallery was threaded with contemporary concerns.

title: Art at Rutgers and Drew
description: New exhibitions of art are being staged by students at Drew and Rutgers Universities.

title: Artists Criticized by Other Artists
description: SOUTHAMPTONPatricia Ralph was one of nine painters and sculptors selected from 106 applicants to participate in the Long Island Artists Showcase, sponsored by Southampton College. She sat in front of a wall covered with her canvases, faced a panel of experts gathered for A Critique of New Talent and asked: Is there unity in my work? I seem to feel that I need to find my direction.

title: 72 Dr. Emil Wins
description: C. Herbert Kaufman's Dr. Emil, who has found it difficult to gain stakes victories, and Braulio Baeza, an old hand at winning them, combined their abilities yesterday to finish first in the $56,050 Discovery Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: ESCAPE BY 5 YOUTHS FOILED ON RIKERS IS.
description: Five teenage murder and robbery suspects were seized by correction officers on Rikers Island last night after they broke through a groundfloor window at the Adolescent Reception Detention Center and scrambled over a 16foothigh cyclone fence topped with barbed wire.

title: Minot Pitman Jr. Weds Ann Bridgman
description: Ann Bridgman, an artist, was married yesterday afternoon to H. Minot Pitman Jr. Both are of Wilton, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. in the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title: She Was The Top: A Duchess's Memoirs Of a Lively Lifetime
description: LONDONIf I could live my life over again, I'd love to. I only hope I'd come back a little wiser.

title: SixDay Deer Hunt To Start Tomorrow
description: ATLANTIC CITYAgainst a background of controversy over new ammunition requirements and methods of herd control, some 100,000 deer hunters are expected to take to tie fields tomorow in every New Jersey county except Hudson.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Vanquishes Seton Hall, 119 to 93
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 6 Rutgers nationallyranked basketball team routed Seton Hall tonight, 11993, in a Big Seven game involving New Jersey teams.

title: Canadian Laurentians: Two Kinds of Skier, Two Kinds of Resort
description: THE Alps and the Rockies seemed too far and too expensive; New England seemed too familiar. So we opted for the Laurentian Mountains in French Canada and a ski package that, on paper at least, offered all we wanted.

title: Yankees to Open Rebuilt Stadium April 15
description: On April 18, 1923, Jacob Ruppert opened Yankee Stadium, a magnificent baseball park that cost the brewery owner $3 million,

title: Allin B. Crouch, ExOfficer With Irving Trust Company
description: Allin B. Crouch, a former executive vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died Friday following surgery in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived at 55 Forest Drive, Springfield, N.J.

title: After New York: The Need for a Federal HelptheCities Policy
description: When the House of. Representatives last week was approving a $2.3 billion loan to save New York City from default, Representative Henry S. Reuss of Wisconsin, chairman the House Banking Committee, said that the measure was only a stopgap, that we can be sure the problem will come back to haunt us. It is the opinion of many urban experts that Mr. Reuss is right, and that the promised fiscal assistance is at best temporary relief.

title: Arts and Letters Names 3
description: The American Academy of Arts and Letters, the nation's highest honor society in the arts, has elected three members, John Hersey, its secretary announced yesterday. This brings the membership to its full complement of 50. To be inducted next May 19 are the writer Ralph Ellison, the architect I. M. Pei and the sculptor Naum Gabo.

title: Homemade Feeders Fill the Hungry Bills
description: SALISBURY, CONN. There was a time when people didn't feed birds. I can remember when even the sparrows were too timid to come and take a handout, usually a handful of stale bread crumbs. Now the chickadees come and tap on the window if breakfast is ten minutes late, and unless the meal includes firstclass sunflower seeds the chicks sulk and glare at you and practically threaten to go on a hunger strike. But if you give them what they want they will sit on your shoulder and twitter when you go outdoors, even take seeds from your hand. They won't actually genuflect and tug at a forelock, but they know how to make you feel important.

title: Tunney, Though Almost Certain of Renomination, Seems Likely to Face a Tough Campaign
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 There are early signs that Senator John V. Tunney faces a difficult campaign for reelection.

title: All United Planes Grounded by Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) A strike by service workers grounded all 2,800 United Airlines flights today and tomorrow, although negotiations on a new wage contract continued.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 6 (UPI)The Detroit Tigers who lost 102 games last season, acquired a pair of experienced playersMilt May, a catcher, and Dave Roberts, a southpaw pitcherin a sevenplayer trade today with the Houston Astros.

title: Elizabeth to Give Yearly Sum To Help on Royal Family Cost
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP)Queen Elizabeth II will make an annual contribution from her private funds to the nation's bill of nearly $2 million to maintain the royal family, Prime Minister Harold Wilson has told Parliament.

title: Lincoln CenterLive?
description: Televising a play, an opera, a symphony or a ballet live from Lincoln Center could bring all the excitement of presence instead of a vague feeling of watching a filmed or taped performance from the last row of the last balcony. The fact that creative techniques now exist to capture precisely what is happening on stage at the moment it is happening could lead to a major breakthrough for American television. Lincoln Center executives are now looking for a receptive television market for their productions.

title: Funds of Trusts and Estates Help Give Appeal a Head Start
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund started its 64th annual appeal yesterday with $375,214.26 already donated by estates, trust funds and 198 contributors.

title: City Is the Beneficiary Of a Boise Garage Sale
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 7 (AP) New York City is about $300 richer, thanks to a garage sale held by Shirley Greer Clark to help the city deal with its financial problems.

title: Bridge:
description: Canada has never included a woman player in its open team for world championship competition, but it will do so next year in the Olympiad in Monte Carlo.

title: About New York
description: New York may not he to song what at Paris and Sorrento are, but it, too, has been inspiration for scores of scores over the years. It has not, even in its current crisis, insinuated its name into a national anthem as Marseilles did in France during the crisis of 1789, but it has not lacked its bards.

title: Mindy Flaum Bride of Bruce Finestone
description: Mindy Sue Flaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart D. Flaum of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Bruce Alan Finestone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Finestone, also of Oceanside.

title: Opinions by Stevens Hint Attitudes of Nominee to Court
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Senate Judiciary Committee begins tomorrow its confirmation hearings on President Ford's nominee to the Supreme Court, John Paul Stevens, a Federal appeals court judge whose written opinions have followed established procedures rather than a political or legal ideology.

title: More About Francis Patrick Dunne
description: It was mentioned in this space yesterday that Francis Patrick Dunne had retired as a racing steward at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga. Two of the other stewards, Warren Mehrtens and Nathanial Hyland, worked a fiveday week so Dunne takes over on their days off and when one is on vacation. He has recommended a sixmonth vacation for each. I like the arrangement, he said. I haven't a lot of interests away from racing, except for crossword puzzles and reading, and a man can't spend all his time doing that. Actually, his interests are a lot wider than he suggests. If they weren't he wouldn't have the reputation he enjoys of an inventor. His first invention to make a stir was designed for sale to Turf and Field Club members. It was a coffin with a builtin lockbox so you could take it with you. He also designed a simplified calendar for stewards of the Jockey Club. was a block of granite engraved with the capitals, XX", so they could look at it and tell what century they were in.

title: TV Coverage of Ford in China: Was It Journalism?
description: If television's coverage of President Ford's trip to China degenerated into a media event, as Eric Sevareid observed on a CBS commentary last week, the event finally suggested more about TV journalism than anything else. Once again, the very nature of the TV beast was brought into question. Is it a machine for gathering and processing news? Or is it mere ly a conduit for transmitting events? Is it, in the traditional sense, journalism? Or is it, in a contemporary mediaconscious sense, entertainment?

title: 5 Killed in Car Collision
description: ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 7 (AP)Four teenagers and a 7yearold boy were killed in a twocar collision in this south, Georgia town last night after one of the drivers ran a stop sign at 50 miles an hour the police said. Six persons were injured.

title: Rosenberg Files Show F. B. I. Pressed Hard to Expand Spy Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The mass of material on the Rosenberg espionage case made public last week shows strenuous efforts by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to expand the charges against the defendants. Ethel and Julius Rosenberg were electrocuted in 1953, and Morton Sobell was sentenced with them in 1951 to 30 years' imprisonment.

title: Nuggets Top Nets By 123119
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 7. The New York Nets, nearly asleep on the court for threequarters of their game against the Denver Nuggets tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, awoke too late and lost, 123119.

title: POLITICAL TENSION IN PORTUGAL EBBS
description: LISBON, Dec. 7Portugal's political crisis eased today as two of the principal antagonists, the Communists and the Popular Democrats, took conciliatory stands.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1975

title: Scant Clues Found Where 5 Met Death
description: TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 7There was nosign of forcible entry, no indication of anything removed from the house, no motivation yet turned up by investigators today for how Jean Diggs and her foud children, a highly regarded family, were shot to death in their brick and stucco home here late Friday or early Saturday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Spokesmen for the Village Gate, a Greenwich Village theater cabaret, said yesterday that they would challenge in Federal Court this week a ruling by the State Liquor Authority banning total nudity in places that sell alcoholic beverages. Last Thursday the authority canceled the liquor license of the nightspot effective Dec. 12 on the ground that its production of Let My People Come was lewd and indecent.

title: John Knight 3d Slain in Robbery; Member of Newspaper Family
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) John S. Knight 3d, a member of the Knight publishing family, was beaten and stabbed to death today during an apparent robbery attempt in his apartment, the nonce said.

title: PORTUGAL SEVERS TIES TO INDONESIA
description: LISBON, Dec. 7Portugal broke diplomatic relations with Indonesia tonight after Indonesian troops entered Portuguese Timor.

title: Stony Brook Curbs Building Use to Cut Deficit in Its Budget
description: STONY BROOKTo help deal with an anticipated $2 million budget deficit, officials at the State University campus here are extending the winter intercession by a week, curtailing the use of buildings, and halting all university services for two days.

title: Chemical, Paper and Metal Industries Say Economy Will Be Hurt by Costs of Achieving Zero Pollution
description: The chemical, paper and pulp, metal and mining industries are stepping up their opposition to strict pollution controls.

title: Australia Port Escapes Worst Cyclone Damage
description: PORT HEDLAND, Australia, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP)Winds of 120 miles an hour from a cyclone tore off the roofs from more than 1,000 houses and destroyed all but a wing of the municipal hospital here early today, a police spokesman reported.

title: Illegal Narcotics Traffic Is Worst Here in 5 Years
description: New York is experiencing its worst illegal narcotics trafficking problems in five years, according to high law enforcement officials.

title: Specialists' Discontent
description: Although business is back on Wall Street, some poweiful members of the financial communitythe specialists who make the market on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchangeare seething with discontent. One question concerns how much representation the public should have on the exchange's board of directors. Another is whether the market the specialists run is competitive enough to guarantee investors fair prices on the stocks they buy and sell.

title: Machine Age Is Squeezing Jersey Oystermen
description: PORT NORRIS, N. J.When Bobby Morgan and the boys gather over breakfast these days in Jelly Bean's Oyster Cove Cafe, a cozy hangout a few hundred yards inland from the wharves where the men's families have been unloading oysters since the Civil War, the talk is less of shellfish than of machines.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Deny Ford Aides Access To Contributor List
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Republican National Committee, caught in an unusual campaign crossfire, has refused to give the President Ford Committee access to it mailing list of major political contributors.

title: Soviet Said to Suggest Compromise on Arms
description: TOKYO, Dec. 7 (UPI)The Soviet Union is reported to have told the United States that it may be willing to cornpromise to break the deadlock in negotiations on a treaty to limit offensive strategic nuclear arms.

title: Carey BusinessTax Plan: Increases and Incentives
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that increased business taxes and a system of offsets  tax credits and incentives for job developmentwould be included in the package of new state taxes and budget cuts that he will announce tomorrow.

title: Music: Aaron Copland as Conductor
description: In a century when many composers have worked to sound anonymous, to write music that sounds like everyone else's, Aaron Copland has spoken in his own voice. Whether one likes his music or not, whether the future will find it worth listening to, or even whether individuality in art is destined to remain important, Mr. Copland has produced a body of work that can be celebrated for its high quotient of listenability. It is likable music, most of it, meant to please listeners, and successful in that.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Constance McLaughlin Green, Pulitzer History Winner, Dies
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 7 (AP)Constance McLaughlin Green, the historian who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1963, died Friday at her daughter's home here. She was 78 years old.

title: With Unclean Hands
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7The first requisite of civilization, Freud said, is justicethat is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favor of an individual? Or against one, he might have added. The abuses of power in the world since Freud wrote that in 1930 have made clear how much our safety depends on applying the rules equally, to those we like and dislike, those in favor and out.

title: TWO UNIONS RATIFY NEWSPAPER PACTS
description: Union photoengravers and stereotypers, in seprate membership meetings, yesterday ratified new threeyear contracts with The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Cowboys Defeated By Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7The idea, according to Don Coryell, the Cardinals' coach, was to try for bigplay football right from the startto go out there and get as many points as possible. The St. Louis team did just that today by running up a 283 lead on the Cowboys in the first half and thus won a key game from Dallas, 3117.

title: Personal Finance: Suggestions on Finding Lawyer
description: Millions of middleclass American families regularly consult doctors and dentists. For many of these families, however, such continuing relationships with lawyers are apt common.

title: Luanda's Armies Gain
description: HUAMBO, Angola, Dec. 4As seen from here, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, aided by vast quantities of Soviet arms and by Cuban fighting men, his made sharp military advances on three fronts in recent days.

title: 11 of 24 AutoRepair Shops Pass a Test on Honesty
description: Of 24 repair shops asked to fix a car with a minor and easily detectable mechanical fault, 13 either completely misdiagnosed the problem or performed or recommended expensive and unnecessary work, according to an investigation by The New York Times in conjunction with the Suffolk County Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: The Dance: Ritha Devi
description: One of the most unusual and engrossing programs of Indian classical dance to be presented here was given by Ritha Devi on Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

description: The Southeastern Conference basketball coaches in a preseason poll selected Tennessee as the favorite for the league championship.

title: PRINCETON HOPES FOR SAUDI GRANT
description: PRINCETONFour Princeton University administrators have ended a week of informal negotiations with Saudi Arabian officials aimed at obtaining a gift for the school's lifesciences program.

title: IMPORT CONTROLS NEAR FOR BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Dec. 7  After weeks of delay, Britain is expected to announce limited import controls this week. The announcement is likely to be accompanied by a lightly muffled prayer that the country's many trading partners will be understanding enough not to retaliate.

title: Illegal Narcotics Traffic Is Worst Here in 5 Years
description: New York is experiencing its worst illegal narcotics trafficking problems in five years, according to high law enforcement officials.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Glass Industry Hurt
description: New Jersey's glassmanufacturing industry, which leads the nation, is losing ground to other states, according to industry leaders. They report that increases in fuel costs and the state's stringent environmental code make it difficult for them to complete. Details will be found on Page 35.

title: Music Fraternity, A Chamber Group, Gives First Recital
description: The Music Fraternity, a new chambermusic ensemble under the direction of Sergiu Luca, a violinist, gave Its first performance yesterday afternoon at the Hunter College Assembly Hall.

title: Harris's 38.7% Is Biggest Vote At Massachusetts Group Parley
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 7A divided Massachusetts liberal activist organization was unable today to chose among Democratic Presidential candidates for its endorsement.

title: INDONESIANS HOLD PORTUGUESE TIMOR AFTER INCURSION
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Dec. 8Indonesian troops moved today to consolidate their hold over Portuguese Timor after having seized control of Dili, the capital, early yesterday.
