description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Dec. 9Attacking on a broad front, Moslem and leftist gunmen clashed in several sections of Beirut yesterday with Christians from the Phalangist Party.

title: Business Briefs
description: Oil Bloc's Money Reserve Rise Halts

title: ATTRITION IS HIGH, CITY REPORT SAYS
description: City officials reported to the State Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday that the attrition rate among city workers was proving significantly higher than anticipated.

title: F.T.C. Assails Lag In Curbing Turner
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission, closed its case today against Glenn W. Turner, the Florida promoter, criticizing itself and other agencies for not moving Sooner to protect thousands of consumers from a wide variety of specific mispresentations and high pressure sales tactics.

title: Pike Spurns Ford Offer on Spy Data, Moves Against Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence today rejected a compromise offer from President Ford intended to head off a contempt  of  Congress action against Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger for failure to supply information on covert intelligence operations.

title: CBS Sets Bolshoi Special
description: CBSTV will broadcast a performance by the Bolshoi Ballet of Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet. The production will be videotaped in Moscow on Jan. 23 at the Bolshoi Theater but a date for the American broadcast has not yet been selected. The TV special will be filmed by the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Name Change Suggested For Kennedy Stadium
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)Representative M. G. Snyder, Republican of Kentucky, suggested today that the name of Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium be changed if efforts proceed to remove J. Edgar Hoover's name from the new Federal Bureau of Investigation building.

title: MORE SEEK TO ACT AS OWN LAWYERS
description: The number of persons serving as their own legal counsel in court is growing in large numbers, although the odds are against them, the courts discourage them and prosecutors and public defenders disapprove of their legal dabbling.

title: Books of The Times
description: This is a puzzling bookthis collection of letters written home by Sylvia Plath from 1950 to 1963, selected and edited by her mother, Aurelia Schober Plath. A myth has grown up around the brilliant young poet since her death in 1963. It is a myth compounded out of her suicide, the dark themes of her final poems and the apparently autobiographical portrait presented in her novel The Bell Jar. It is what the English critic and novelist A. Alvarez called in The Savage God the myth of the poet as a sacrificial victim, offering herself up for the sake of her art, having been dragged by the Muses to that final altar through every kind of distress. In several important ways, Letters Home serves to dispel that myth.

title: A.B.A. Players Get Delay
description: The American Basketball Association players have won at least a temporary delay of today's scheduled draft of unassigned players by the National Basketball Association.

title: G.E. Testifies on PCBDischarge Cuts
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8The General Electric Company indicated today that it could limit its discharges of toxic PCB's into the Hudson River to 3 ounces a day by June 1, 1977, but that it still felt that the zero discharge ordered by the State Department of Environmental Conservation for next Sept. 30 was not feasible. At present, the company said, it discharges about two pounds a day into the river.

title: Angola's 3Way War: An Uneasy Wedding of 2 Sides
description: HUAMBO, Angola, Dec. 4 There had been four days of unexplained delay before the installation here of a coalition government made up of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola and the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. A young sociology student, working in the National Front's ministry of information, was apologizing for the delay.

title: RENT RISES LISTED FOR 180,000 UNITS
description: Tenants of about 180,000 rentcontrolled apartments here fewer than onethird the number of such apartments in the citywill have their rents increased up to 7.5 percent effective next month, the Beame administration announced yesterday.

title: Comment by Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Asked to respond to the remarks of Mr. Sisana Sisan, a State Department spokesman said he had no information that supports the allegation that the United States gave $150 million to former Laotian officers and political leaders.

title: Group in Senate Opposes Ford On Commonwealth in Marianas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8A group of United States Senators is seeking to block a move by the Ford Administration to give the northern Mariana Islands the status of an American commonwealth, Senate aides said today.

title: Friends Praise Father of Slain Family
description: Wesley Diggs is a Pisces and there is a little astrological plaque in the office in one of the bars he owns in Harlem that friends say describes him perfectly.

title: BestDressed Patricia Buckley: Prouder of Role as Housewife
description: Sometimes she describes herself as a jolly green giant. Other times, she thinks she looks like a pregnant stork. She hates shopping, and her closets wouldn't give anyone an inferiority complex.

title: Postal Service Raises Special Service Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)  The United States Postal Service announced today that it would increase fees for special services such as money orders and special delivery effective Jan. 3.

title: Dolphins Winning With Nos. 1, 2 or 3
description: Does it make any difference who plays the quarterback position for the Miami Dolphins? Apparently not. With Bob Griese, the No. I operative out for the season following foot surgery, and Earl Morrall, the No. 2 man, absent for at least another week while a torn knee ligament heals, the Dolphins pres ent Don Strock at the most important position of all. Strock, starting his first regular season game in the National Football League last Sunday, completed 12 out of 15 passes as Miami beat Buffalo, 3121, and he will be the offensive director when the Dolphins play the Colts in a key game at Baltimore this Sunday.

title: Insanity Defense Planned In Sara Jane Moore Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UPI)Attorneys for Sara Jane Moore, accused of trying to kill President Ford, said today that they would use an insanity defense in her trial scheduled to begin next week.

title: Comparison of the Lowly
description: When major league baseball had a team called the Senators, it was said that Washington was first in war, first in peace and last in the American League. New York, it could be said, is first in losing football teams.

title: Rally Protests Planned Opening Of East Side Alcoholism Center
description: About 50 angry representatives of East Side neighborhood groups gathered last night; outside a remodeled storefront a 207 East 14th Street to protest the scheduled opening there of a rehabilitation center for alcoholics.

title: London Gunmen Appear to Reject Deal
description: LONDON, Dec. 8Four gunmen believed by the police to belong to the Irish Republican Army, who are barricaded with two hostages in a central London apartment, were offered food and cigarettes today in exchange for one hostage.

title: 3 Accused of Inmate's Murder In Brooklyn Jail Ordered Freed
description: A State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the acquittal of three men accused of having murdered a fellow inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention and declared, I'd be shirking my responsibility if I did not.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: WILLIAM FEICK
description: William Feick, a retired vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived on Dingletown Road in Greenwich.

title: NEW TIMOR REGIME REPORTED FORMED
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 8 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today that proIndonesian parties in Portuguese Timor had set up a provisional government in the wake of the takeover of the capital by Indonesian forces.

title: More Garbage Pickups Set By City as Strike Goes On
description: Mayor Beame ordered the city's Sanitation Department yesterday to increase pickups of garbage and trash accumulations that have become increasingly hazardous in the eightdayold strike of private cartmen.

title: HIGH COURT BARS WIDER I.O.S. SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Supreme Court rejected today a bid to include foreign investors in a multimilliondollar securities suit filed by purchasers of shares of I.O.S. Ltd., the bankrupt investor service operated by Bernard Cornfeld.

title: Kissinger Urges Israelis To Debate P.L.O. in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has asked Israel to drop its boycott and agree to debate Middle East issues in the United Nations Security Council with the Palestine Liberation Organization next month.

title: North Stars Poor Only on Ice
description: The Minnesota North Stars' longest winning streak since the 1972  73 season was broken Sundaynight by the Philadelphia Flyers in a 61 contest. The North Starshad won three cohsecutive games. Witha record second only to the Washington Capitals' expansion team in hopelessnessseven victories and 17 losses the Minnesota club has been losing thousands of seasonticket holders, dropping to 7,600 regulars from 11,500 last season. It has been speculated that the franchise lost $900,000 last season and will lose more this season.

title: Hoffa Tipster Gone; CBS Is Out $10,000
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 8About 4 o'clock last Friday morning, a toughtalking man who said his name was Chuck Medlinidentified by the Justice Department as an exconvictleft the downtown Holiday Inn in Tampa, Fla., to try to find a woman he said was his cousin. He has not returned.

title: FOES OF RIGHTISTS ATTACK IN BEIRUT ON A BROAD FRONT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Dec. 9Attacking on a broad front, Moslem and leftist gunmen clashed in several sections of Beirut yesterday with Christians from the Phalangist Party.

title: Plan Proposed to Save Police Stations and Jobs
description: Leon A. Katz, chairman of the City Council's Public Safety Committee, proposed yesterday eliminating police surgeons and ending the police civilianization program as part of a $22 million plan to save 883 police positions and four station houses scheduled to be closed Jan. 1.

title: Variety of CoastalZone Projects Approved as State Issues Permits
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8 (AP)The state announced approval today of permits for construction projects in the New Jersey coastal zone where it controls development.

title: TOP DRUG DEALERS NAMED BY POLICE
description: Thirteen drug traffickersfour whites, five blacks and four Hispanic personsare now believed by narcotics investigators to be the dominant figures in the city's heroin and cocaine underworlds.

title: Nationalizing of Oil Completed by Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 8 (Reuters)Iraq completed today the nationalization of its oil industry by taking over the remaining foreignheld shares in the Basrah Petroleum Company.

title: 2 More Close Calls Aloft Near Chicago Reported
description: Shortly before and after the nearcollision of two airliners near Chicago Friday afternoon, there were two other incidents in which airliners and smaller planes came close to hitting one another, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: FORD IS OPTIMISTIC ON CYPRUS PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)  President Ford said today that recent American initiatives had advanced prospects for settlement of the Cyprus dispute to a point where Greece and Turkey are expected to enter peace negotiations shortly.

title: Charge on Superdome Dealings A Setback for Ambitious Mayor
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 Mayor Moon Landrieu, who is gaining national stature by his efforts to solve urban problems, is facing a loss of popularity in his own city, largely because of problems with the Louisiana Superdome.

title: Stars and Sunflowers in a Ballet Debut
description: A mysterious group called Stars of the American Ballet made its first appearance in the area Sunday at the Westchester Premier Theater in Tarrytown and turned out to be made up of old friends named Patricia McBride, Helgi Tomasson, Hilda Mor ales, Keith Martin, Marianna Tcherkassky, Warren Conover, Kirk Peterson and even more friends.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article on the Senate leadership in The New York Times last Friday, Senator Mike Mansfield's age was given incorrectly as 78 years. The Senator is 72.

title: CHURCHES' COUNCIL WAVERS ON SOVIET
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 8The assembly of the World Council of Churches voted today to voice concern over restrictions to religious freedom in the Soviet Union but then withdrew the motion on procedural grounds and referred the matter back to committee.

title: Dance: Martha Graham Back With Her Company
description: After far too long an absence, Martha Graham is back on Broadway. Well not quite but if not Martha, who is now the presiding genius of her company rather than its resident goddess, at least her dancers, and for their longest season yet32 performances. The company, in superb fettle, opened last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater with a gala at which Miss Graham really did preside, speaking at the beginning of the evening.

title: Sooners' Leroy Selmon Tells Some Tales of Recruiting
description: Leroy Selmon, the allAmerica defensive tackle at Oklahoma, said that he and his brother, Dewey, were offered $180 a month and a $1.000 bonus each by a college four years ago when they were promising young linemen in their senior year at Eufaula (Okla.)

title: SOLZHENISTYN STAND BY FORD DENOUNCED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., released a confidential administration memo today that cautioned President Ford last summer that he would be sending Moscow a deliberate negative signal on dtente if he received Aleksandr I. Solzhenistyn.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturiities.

title: Morton Agrees to Yield Boycott List to House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Secretary of Commerce Rogers C. B. Morton agreed today to make available to a House subcommittee a list of American companies that have reported they were asked to support an Arab boycott of Israel and of companies that do business with Israel.

title: British Price Index Up
description: LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters)The British wholesale price index for all items rose a provisional 0.75 percent to 198.6 (base 1970) in November after a 1.25 percent rise in October, the Department of Industry said today.

title: Contract Award
description: The international subsidiary of Pullman Inc. has signed a letter of intent to build the main plant of a $360 million liquefied natural gas plant 40 miles outside of Kuwait, it was announced yesterday. The contract calls for completion in 27 months, with a $3,000 daily penalty for tardiness.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2d Avenue Widening Is Abandoned

title: Peak Cigarette Tax Sought in Jersey To Save Services
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8Democratic and Republican legislative leaders reached a tenuous agreement today on a supplemental $35.5 million state budget appropriation that inchided as its only new tax a 3cent increase of the existing 19centapack tax on cigarettes.

title: RICHARD I. BROWN, TRUCK EXECUTIVE
description: Richard I. Brown, a New Jersey trucking executive, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 41 years old and lived at 17 Bennett Road, Teaneck. N. J.

title: Cup Tennis Rained Out
description: TOKYO, Dec. 8 (AP)The second round of the Eastern Zone Davis Cup tennis competition between Japan and India was rained out today for the third day in a row. India leads the threeoffiveset series, 10.

title: Carey's Tax. Plan Would Give A Break to Businesses in State
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8Governor Carey is expected to propose tomorrow a restructuring of the corporate income tax that will, in effect, penalize outofstate companies that sell their products here, while, giving a tax break to companies with heavy investments of property and personnel in the state.

title: Poets in the Schools Is Exciting Program To Educators Here
description: Are we going to have a chance to write poetry again? Please? Myra Klahr was asked. The hand tugging at her sleeve belonged not to an eager child, but to one of the nearly 100 school administrators who attended a daylong seminar yesterday on the Poets in the Schools program in New York State, of which Miss Klahr is the director.

title: Father Questioned in Teaneck Killings; Revenge Is Regarded as Crime Motive
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 8Wesley Diggs, whose wife and four children were murdered two days ago in their Teaneck home, volunteered to submit to a liedetector test today as Bergen County investigators searched for a motive for the killings.

title: Canada Price Index Rises
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 8 (Reuters)The Canadian general wholesale price index rose 0.3 percent in October to 503.5 (1935 to 1939 equals 100) from a revised September figure of 502.2, Statistics Canada said today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: ??1975, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, Dec. 8. 25th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: A Communist Arab Is Elected as Mayor of Nazareth
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Dec. 10A Communist was elected this morning as Mayor of Nazareth, the town in Galilee where Jesus was raised.

title: Advertising
description: Corporations are becoming less interested in involvement in spectator sports and more interested in participation sports, according to John D. Carroll and Robert J. Arrix, former college athletes who are now making their daily bread by bringing marketers and sports together.

title: Kraft Heads Team
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP)Robert Kraft was elected president of the Boston Lobsters of World Team Tennis today.

title: CHARLES S. GREGG
description: Charles S. Gregg, who retired in 1972 after more than half a century as a newspaperman, died Monday in a hospital in Cherry Hill, N. J. He was 76 years old.

title: Exxon Says Dependence On Foreign Oil May Rise
description: United States dependence on foreign oil is likely to increase to 49 percent by 1990 from its present level of about 39 percent, according to a study prepared for the top management of the Exxon Corporation.

title: People and Business
description: Two Federal officials testified at Congressional hearings yesterday in Washington that the banking industry's growing role in the business of buying and selling stock securities may pose some problems in the nation's money markets.

title: Dance:
description: There is a very special sensibility and sensitivity to Paul Sanasardo and the Sanasardo Dance Company, which last night gave the world premiere of A Memory Suite at the hot and cavernous City Center Basement, which is called accurately, but somehow euphemistically, Downstairs at City Center.

title: Warehouse Burns 3 Hours
description: A threealarm fire that burned for more than three hours yesterday caused heavy, damage in a warehouse of the Bedford Acme Surgical Company at 1294 BedfordAvenue in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section. Four firemen were treated for heat exposure and smoke inhalation, a department spokesman reported.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ashe Leads in Annual Judging To Select No. 1 Player in World
description: Who is No. 1? That question pops up in tennis at the end of every year. Sometimes the answer is clear as to who deserves to be rated the best player in the world, sometimes it's not.

title: Abbatiello Makes His Presence Felt
description: At the Race Tracks

title: THIRD DAILY DROP SHOWN BY AMEX
description: Stocks drifted lower on the American Stock Exchange for the third session in a row, with the index closing at 81.19 yesterday, off 0.60. Volume moved up to 1.75 million shares from 1.69 million on Monday.

title: BIG GRAIN SALES OVER, U.S. FEELS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (Reuters)The Agriculture Department predicted today that the Soviet Union would not make any more significant purchases if American grain despite sharply reduced estimates of this year's harvest in the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: SOVIET VIOLATION OF PACT DISCUSSED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger opened the lid a bit today on the normally supersecret subject of alleged Soviet violations of the 1972 accords to limit strategic arms.

title: Panel Approves Expenses In New Hampshire Vote Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Senate Rules Committee unanimously approved today payments totaling $292,100 for the expenses of Senator John A. Durkin, Democrat of New Hampshire, and former Republican Representative Louis C. Wyman, stemming from New Hampshire's Senate election issue.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Ed Austin and Huibert Zuur, two graduates of the Halston school, set up shop for themselves about two years ago. Essentially, they adhere to the master's basic concept of minimal fashions, though they have a tendency to get a bit more trendy.

title: Status Quo in Spain
description: There is one imperative for the political and economic health of postFranco Spain: The Madrid Government must surmount at last the psychological barrier of the Pyrenees so the country can take its natural place inside the European Community. But in order to do that it first must grant freedom for political parties, carry out a free election and install a functioning parliamentary system.

title: Ford Signs Aid Bill; Bankruptcy Change For City Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9President Ford today signed into law, without ceremony, a $2.3 billion seasonal loanauthorization bill that New York City and State officials said would prevent a city default.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Market Is Irregular; Dow Index Up 2.52
description: Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday and for the second consecutive day the market was mixed at the close in moderate trading.

title: Compromise Energy Bill Is Sent Out by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9A HouseSenate conference reported today a compromise energy policy bill that would set the stage for suspending price controls on most petroleum products, such as heating oil and gasoline, while rolling back crude oil prices.

title: WILLARD KLOSE
description: Willard Klose, a retired advertising executive, died Sunday at his home, Echo Valley Farm, Red Hook, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title: About Education
description: Despite inflation, recession and a declining birth rate, the nation's private colleges and universities are not as badly off as many experts have declared them to be, according to a new diagnosis of their health.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Dally Racing Form)

title: Collapse of the Old Order
description: WASHINGTON  Around Christmas time before each Presidential election, the political world of Washington begins to turn over. The old leaves at the top of the executive and legislative branches start dropping off. There is an obvious change in what officials say and do. They begin thinking about their private lives, their personal ambitions and disappointments, and this is what is happening here now.

title: Veto for Peace
description: Only a United States veto has prevented the Security, Council from destroying itself as a potentially useful agency for peace in the Middle East. Unlike the General Assembly, where meaningless and tendentious resolutions have become the norm, the more responsible Security Council has provided, in two resolutions of Nov. 22, 1967, and Oct. 22, 1973, the legal framework for the diplomatic efforts of the past eight years.

title: Mrs. Abzug's Fee For Coast Speech Ruled Acceptable
description: WASHINGTON,Dec. 9The Federal Election Commission ruled today that a speaker's fee paid to a Congressional candidate by a political group is not a campaign contribution as long as the audience does not include potential voters in the election involved.

title: British Universities, Losing Big Sums, May Increase Tuition for Foreigners
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  British universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, are losing so much money educating soaring numbers of foreign students that tuitions are likely to be raised or quotas set on admissions.

title: SWISS BANK REQUEST ON ASSETS REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Federal District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell rejected today the Swiss Credit Bank's request to revoke an order requiring it to transfer an estimated $150 million to $200 million in assets from Switzerland to the United States.

title: VIETNAM DOCTORS SEEKING U.S. ROLE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP)  Dr. Tien Trong Vu, delivered 50 babies in his native Vietnam but was not allowed to deliver his own daughter just after he reached American soil.

title: Court Bars Aid to ExMayor
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP)The Appellate Division of Superior Court declined today to make a municipality pay the legal fees of a former Mayor cleared of misconduct in office charges. The former Mayor, George I. Roberts, had asked the court to reverse a lower court and direct Somers Point to pay a $23,344 legal bill he had run up defending himself against the charge made while he was Mayor.

title: Some Help Neediest To Show Gratitude
description: The 64th annual Christmas appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund heard from 21 contributors who gave $702.76, to bring the fund's overall total to $384, 868.02.

title: 3 JERSEYANS SEEK A LAS VEGAS CASINO
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 9 (UPI)Three New Jersey men are trying to buy the Centerfold Casino in Las Vegas.

title: Plans to Enforce AutoRepair Law Called Inadequate by Some Officials
description: State and local consumerprotection officials have charged that the New York State Motor Vehicle Department's plans for enforcing the state's new autorepair law are inadequate and may result in reduced protection for consumers.

title: Hearst Defense to Oppose Move to Restrain the Press
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 (UFI)Defense attorneys said today that they would oppose a Government effort to win a press restraining order in the Patricia Hearst case.

title: BREZHNEV ASSERTS SLANDER IN WEST POISONS DETENTE
description: WARSAW, Dec. 9Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, charged today that influential circles in the West had poisoned the international atmosphere since the summit conference on European cooperation and security in Helsinki last August.

title: Israeli West Bank Squatters Are Moved in Compromise
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 Reuters)Young orthodox Jews trying to build an unauthorized village near Nablus in the occupied West Bank today moved to a nearby army camp under a compromise worked out with Defense Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Inspection Line Crawls Along And Drivers in Jersey Fume
description: WAYNE, N. J.Automobile inspections are a way of life in New Jersey; said Roger Gilmore, assistant supervisor of the motor vehicle inspection here. We've had statemandated automobile inspection for almost 35 to 40 years and people are used to it.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CROWNS AND COUNTRIES A goodwill holiday exhibition from abroad, The Kings and Queens of England, goes on view today through Dec. 31 as a symbol of AngloAmerican kinship and as a salute to our Bicentennial. The display consists of 65 lifesize bronzed Fibreglas figures, authentically garbed as the 39 reigning monarchs over 11 centuries (871 to 1952), from Alfred the Great to George VI. The show is intended to dramatize the influence of the British monarchy on government, law and justice in this country and on world events.

title: He Designs Italian Meals And Kitchens as Well
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J.  Over the years we have known personally but a few kitchen consultants. We have, on the other hand, known a lot of designed kitchens, and it has long been our conceit that most professionals who plan cooking spaces would not know a skillet from a saucepan, or a scrambled egg from an omelette. That is why we accepted with alacrity when we were told that John Cristaldi was both a firstrate Italian cook and a kitchen consultant.

title: Ky Is Booed From Stage By Students at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 9 (UPI) Nguyen Cao Ky, the former South Vietnamese Premier, was booed off the stage at Cornell UniVersity tonight by students chanting Out! Out! Out! and making Fascist salutes.

title: 4 Are Named to High Posts In Mental Hygiene Agency
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP)Four new highlevel administrators in the State Mental Hygiene Department were named today as part of Governor Carey's reorganization plan for the muchcriticized agency. The appointments were announced by Dr. Lawrence Kolb, Mental Hygiene Commissioner.

title: Consumer Agency May Ask Warning On Poinsettia Use
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it was trying to decide whether poinsettia plants and mistletoe sprigs sold for Christmas decorations should be labeled as possibly poisonous if eaten.

title: A Gift of the Sea Becomes a Jewel
description: There's something to suit every taste and pocketbook at the gallery Laura Kruger fand Madeleine Van Eerde opened recently at 842 Madison Avenue near 69th Street and they intend to keep it that way with a new group show of jewelry rand sculpture every six weeks as well as a roster of permanent exhibitors.

title: MildMannered Cartoonists Go To Aid of Superman's Creators
description: In his outstretched left arm he supported Joseph Shuster. In his right, Jerry Siegel. In the middle was the man who came to Earth with powers and abilities far beyond those of mortal men, in his familiar confident posture, flying skyward.

title: Nassau County Enters Entente With Soviet
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 9Dtente has entered the field of local planning.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Tin Export Curb Extended
description: The International Tin Council said today it had extended export controls on tin through the quarter beginning Jan. 1 to March 31, 1976, restricting total permissible exports to 32,000 metric tons, against 35,000 metric tons in the previous quarter.

title: Notes on People
description: Yelena Sakharov arrived yesterday in Oslo, Norway, from Italy to accept the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist.

title: Court Backs Police Questioning In 6to2 Ruling Viewed as Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 2 today that after a suspect exercises his right to remain silent about one crime the police may still question him about another.

title: 17 Women on Rikers I. Receive Certificates for Secretarial Skills
description: Seventeen graduates of a class in secretarial skills and typing at the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island received certificates and prizes yesterday as friends, relatives, fellow inmates and former graduates of the course applauded and cheered.

title: Soviet Farm Failures
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9  This year's harvest disaster, based on a grain yield seemingly as low as 137 million tons, has once again raised questions about the Soviet Union's ability to feed its people adequately. The 1975 grain deficiency appears to run nearly 79 million tons below the original target. In practical terms, this works out to a per capita harvest yield as small as that of 1913, a mediocre czarist year that Soviet statisticians cite as a prerevolutionary base to demonstrate the nation's progress under Communism.

title: Bert Brandt Is Dead at 59; Former U.P.I. Photographer
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)Bert Brandt, former United Press International photographer, died today at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Ford Signs Aid Bill; Bankruptcy Change For City Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9President Ford today signed into law, without ceremony, a $2.3 billion seasonal loanauthorization bill that New York City and State officials said would prevent a city default.

title: MORRISCOHN, EXPERT ON WATER POLLUTION
description: Morris M. Cohn, a sanitary engineer and expert on water pollution, died here Sunday at his home. He was 77 years old and lived at 1100 Madison Avenue.

title: St. John's Tops Tennessee
description: An inspired and unranked St. John's team, playing calm, disciplined basketball, defeated sixthranked Tennessee and its expatriate New Yorkers last night, 7970, in a rousing game at Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens.

title: Firestone Reports Decline in Earnings
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, second to Goodyear among the nation's largest tire producers, reported yesterday a continued decline in earnings of 12.4 percent for the fourth quarter and 12.8 percent for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31.

title: JOAO CASTRO, ENVOY OF BRAZIL TO U.S., 56
description: Joo Augusto de Araujo Castro, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States since 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Princeton's Streak of 16 Is Snapped by Villanova
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 9 Villanova held off a lstminute Princeton rally tonight to defeat the Tigers, 5149, at Jadwin Gymnasium. Villanova's victory snapped Princeton's 16game twoseason winning streak.

title: Candidate in West Virginia
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 9 (AP)The Rev. Ezra Graley, 46 years old, a leader of the Kanawha County textbook protest, announced today his candidacy for Democratic governorship nomination.

title: City's Friend in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 William Proximire's first encounter with New York City was in 1937, when he spent his summer vacation from college selling men's shirts at Macy's. Littleneck shirts the first weeks, bigneck shirts the last weeks, he recalls. His second was in 1940, when he spent several months as a $25aweek student clerk at the investment banking house of J. P. Morgan.

title: AGREEMENTREACHED IN 5WEEK ITT STRIKE
description: A tentative agreement that would end a fiveweek walkout against ITT World Communications Inc. was announced yesterday.

title: World Bank Back in U.S. Debt Market
description: The World Bank, which used to depend predominantly on United States investors for its capital and then shifted to Japan and oilproducing countries, has returned to the American credit market. It is scheduled to sell today $750 million of notes and bonds, its largest financing here so far.

title: Theft of $200,000 Is Laid to. a Lawyer in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 9Westchester County law enforcement authorities said today that a Tuckahoe lawyer, Daniel N. Bibona, would be charged later this week with stealing more than $200,000 from the estate of his former priest, the late Msgr. Joseph A. Kerwin.

title: Carey Urges Harsher Law Against Juvenile Violence
description: Harsher treatment for juveniles who commit violent crimes was urged yesterday by Governor Carey. We will introduce legislation calling for mandatory sanctions for juveniles14 or olderfound guilty of a major violent crime and found dangerous to society by a Family Court judge, the Governor said.

title: BIG U.S. ROLE SEEN IN PERIL TO OZONE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The use of aerosoldispensed hairsprays, antiperspirants and deodorants in the United States accounts for nearly half the world's air pollution by fluorocarbons, which may be dangerously depletine the upper atmosphere's protective layer of ozone according to a report released today by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: White House Briefing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The White House gave an oral briefing today to the delegation from the House Select Intelligence Committee on the subpoenaed information about covert activities.

title: $597 MILLION CUT IN STATE SPENDING SOUGHT BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9Telling the Legislature that we are on the edge of the abyss, Governor Carey called today for a $597million cut in state spending for such programs as Medicaid, education and local revenue sharing and the immediate enactment of $555 million in permanent tax increases on corporations, banks, gasoline, automobiles, and various consumer items.

title: PORTUGAL ASSAILS INDONESIAN MOVE
description: LISBON, Dec. 9Portugal's Foreign Minister, Maj. Ernesto Melo Antunes, declared today that Lisbon was still responsible for the sovereignty of Portuguese Timor. He condemned Indonesia for what he called armed aggression against the Southeast Asian island territory.

title: Hesburgh Gets Award At Dinner
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, C.S.C., president of the University of Notre Dame, and David Packard, chairman of the board of HewlettPackard Company of California, received last night the two highest awards presented annually by the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.

title: Paris's Fashionable First District Grows a Bit Shabby and Bawdy
description: PARIS, Dec. 9  Their neighborhood museum is the Louvre. Their main street is the Avenue de l'Opera. Their secondfavorite garden is the Tuileries.

title: A Typical Stockholder: She Is 53 and Works
description: The typical shareowner who emerges from the stockholder estimate released by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday is a 53yearold woman who lives in a large metropolitan area such as Chicago or New York.

title: Rings Worth $175,000 Stolen in Holdup at Bar
description: Three gunmen held up a recently opened East Side bar last night and escaped with two rings valued by the owner at $175,000.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
description: (OTB Payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Unhired Women Sue Alabama On Minimum Sizes for Officers
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 9Two Alabama women filed suit today in Federal Court here maintaining that the state's minimum height and weight standards for law enforcement personnel discriminate against women and violate constitutional guarantees of due process under law.

title: EDWARD P. O'CONNOR
description: Edward P. O'Connor, a retired high school principal, died Monday at the Ferncliff Nursing Home, Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: College Enrollments Rise 8.8%, Greatest Surge Since the Sixties
description: Colleges and universities across the country, after several years of an enrollment slowdown, experienced this year their greatest surge in enrollment since the booming growth during the 1960's.

title: Amsterdam Terrorists Issue Demands to Indonesia
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 10 Seven terrorists holding 25 hostages in the Indonesian Consulate in Amsterdam issued a set of tough political demands to the Indonesian Government today.

title: Coach Defines Giants' Troubles: Concentrating on Wrong Things
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 9The Giants supposedly have been playing the game of football this seasontheir own peculiar versionbut it is now disclosed that they really have been playing something else the game of What If.

title: Foundation Is Set Up As Tribute to Tucker
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation, a nonprofit organization, has been established in the memory of the Metropolitan Opera tenor who died last January. The foundation's first grant will be $2,500 to the Metropolitan Opera National Council for a prize to be given next March to the winner of the council's annual Metropolitan Opera Auditions.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Coast Brush Fire Contained
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP)A winddriven brush fire was contained yesterday after burning more than 1,700 acres and destroying five structures in the rugged mountains east of here.

title: Conferees Agree on Ceiling Of $374.9 Billion Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)A Senate  House conference committee announced final agreement today on a $374.9 billion spending limit and a $74.1 billion deficit for the Government in the current fiscal year.

title: U.S. IS RULED OWNER OF FORMER SPY SHIP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that Global Marine Inc. of Los Angeles has agreed to notify stockholders that the Hughes Glomar Explorer was owned by the United States Government.

title: Besieged London Gunmen Halt Talks on Phone and Refuse Food
description: LONDON, Dec. 9Irish gunmen continued to be besieged in a small apartment with two hostages tonight, refusing food passed to them by the police and tossing out a specially rigged up telephone.

title: Rockefeller Urges RevenueSharing Action for City
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9Vice President Rockefeller said today that the financial package developed to save New York City from default could collapse unless Congress acted within two weeks to approve a Federal revenuesharing program.

title: F.T.C. to Investigate Polls To See if They Are Coded
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission said today that some public opinion polls may be using questionnaires that have been secretly coded to reveal the identity of the persons interviewed.

title: Islanders Rout North Stars
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 9 A look of calm crossed Bryan Trottier's face. He was standing squarely in the slot during an Islander power play and Jean Potvin was about to smack a shot from the point. Trottier already knew what was going to happen.

title: CBS Tipster Decision on Highest Level, Salant Says
description: The decision to pay for information that possibly would lead CBS to the body of James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who has not been seen since July 30, was made at the highest level of the news division, Richard S. Salant, president of CBS News, said yesterday.

title: Lie Tests Are Postponed For Head of Slain Family
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 9The polygraph testin of Wesley R. Diggs, the 40yearold New York City businessman who found his wif eand four children slain in their $50,000 Teaneck home Saturday, has been postponed because of Mr. Diggs's emotional state, according to Joseph C. Woodcock, Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in The New York Times yesterday on school integration in Louisville, Ky., reported that racial stereotypes there are not moderating on the basis of firsthand experiences in the classrooms. The word not should have been now.

title: Stocks as Causal Force
description: Last week's stunning 41.87 drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, which this week's market action has done virtually nothing thus far to reverse, raises serious doubts about the optimistic forecasts that were so common just before the market broke so sharply downward.

title: Veeck Has Funds to Pay White Sox Price Today
description: HOLLYWOOD. Fla., Dec. 9Bill Veeck, one of the more inventive and controversial promoters in sports, found a financial angel today and headed here to make a dramatic return to professional baseball as the new owner of the Chicano White Sox.

title: Looking North at Uncle Sam
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  I first met Henry Kissinger at dinner in Paris, June 26, 1962, a few weeks after he quit his job as an adviser to the Kennedy Administration. He had just been in Brazil and thought we were badly mishandling the brand new Alliance for Progress. We make the mistake of comparing the potentialities of Latin America with those of Europe when the Marshall Plan was conceived, he said.

title: $597 MILLION CUT IN STATE SPENDING SOUGHT BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9Telling the Legislature that we are on the edge of the abyss, Governor Carey called today for a $597million cut in state spending for such programs as Medicaid, education and local revenue sharing and the immediate enactment of $555 million in permanent tax increases on corporations, banks, gasoline, automobiles, and various consumer items.

title: DORAN R. DOLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Doran R. Dole, father of Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican of Kansas, died today after suffering a heart attack and undergoing emergency surgery in George Washington Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Russell, Kan.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Kennedy and Castro: No Smoking Gun but ...
description: In not directly linking President Kennedy to the assassination attempts on Fidel Castro, the Senate intelligence committee acted just the way the House Judiciary Committee wanted to act in the Watergate affair.

title: Council of Churches Prods the Russians on Safeguarding Religious Freedom
description: NAIROBI. Kenya, Dec. 9The World Council of Churches today ended a long debate over religious freedom in the Soviet Union by adopting a compromise resolution calling on the Russians, without naming them, to safeguard such freedom.

title: College Enrollment Up
description: Colleges across the country, after several years of enrollment slowdown experienced this year the highest enrollments since the boom of the Sixties. Page 43.

title: Traffic Toll Off in October
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP)Some 3,980 persons died in traffic accidents on the nation's highways in October, an 8 percent increase from the same period in 1974, according to the National Safety Council. The trend has been downward since late summer of this year, particularly offsetting increases in traffic fatalities that occurred last spring, according to Vincent Tofany, the council's president.

title: Taxes and Fees Included In Carey's Budget Plan
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9Governor Carey's proposals to the Legislature for $555 million in new taxes and $320 million million in accelerated collections and other devices includes the following:

title: Women on Staff at U.N. Fight Male Chauvinism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9The picket signs were in the languages used at the United Nations, but the messages were unusual.

title: Roberto Suspended 4 Games by N.H.L.
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP)  The National Hockey League president, Clarence Campbell, suspended today Phil Roberto of the Detroit Red Wings for four games as punishment for an incident in Vancouver last Wednesday.

title: NEW SOVIET ROLE IN AFRICA ALLEGED
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 9Soviet warships are using Nigeria's ports, and a number of MIG21J fighterbombers have been delivered to the politically and economically important West African state, according to a report prepared by intelligence officers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Larchmont Board Ends Creche Display
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 9The Christmas crche will be missing this year from the lawn of the Larchmont Village Hall.

title: Melville Shoe Set To Pay $40 Million For Marshall's Inc.
description: Merger News

title: U.S. Sues 5 Railroads to Block Asset Sales Before TakeOver
description: The Government charged yesterday that its plan for reorganizing the bankrupt Northeast railroads faced a massive attack from the Penn Central and four other carriers it accused of trying to sell off assets designated for Conrail, the new Federally sponsored railroad.

title: G.E. Witness Concedes Errors In His Data on PCB in Hudson
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9A principal expert witness for General Electric conceded today that there had been errors, omissions and reporting confusion in the data he presented about levels of PCB in fish in the Hudson River.

title: Bucks Defeat Knicks by 109100 Here
description: Brian Winters, the kid who grew up in New York as a Knick rooter, helped the Milwaukee Bucks heat them last night, 109100, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bears Lose Peiffer
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UPI)Dan Pieffer, center for the Chicago Bears, had surgery today to remove cartilage from his right knee and will not play Sunday against, the St. Louis Cardinals, the club announced. Doctors said Pieffer would be hospitalized three or four days before beginning rehabilitation exercises. Dan Neal will start at center Sunday.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Every year Americans spend about $4 billion for doityourself relief from all manner of ailments mental, physical and biological.

title: Olivier, Prince of Players, Recalls His Slings and Arrows
description: Laurence Olivier hailed a taxicab and, standing next to the cabbie's window, with impeccable manners he told the driver his destination. The driver crackled with antipathy. Don't stand there! he barked at the greatest actor in the Englishspeaking world. Just get in! Like an apprentice spear carrier, Lord Olivier dutifully complied.

title: Guild Members at The Post Vote to Authorize a Strike
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Post have voted 168 to 9 to authorize a strike if they are unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract, Harry Fisdell, executive vice president of the New York Guild, announced yesterday.

title: Red Smith
description: When the Baltimore Colts mauled the Giants, 210, last Sunday, Craig Morton, the New York quarterback, spent much of the afternoon on his back with people named Fred Cook, Joe Ehrmann, Mike Barnes and John Dutton astride his breastbone. Eight sacks in one game set an unwelcome record for Morton, who has been flattened on 42 attempts to pass in 12 games. Comparison emphasizes the odious nature of these figures; in 1972, which was the last year the Giants won oftener than they lost, their passers were creamed only eight times in all 14 games. When Sunday's boos and catcalls died, Morton said: I'm getting paid to do a job and I'm not doing it. New York football fans have little to cheer about this year, but here is a chance to applaud class above and beyond the call of any contract. How many others in the same situation could refrain from mentioning how nice it. would he if somebody blocked somebody now and then and a receiver occasionally got clear?

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Over the last nine months, some major banks in New York have been changing their method of computing finance charges on their credit cards to a system that adds interest to the cost of a purchase before some customers have even been billed for the item.

title: ISRAELIS PLEASED BY U.S. VETO IN U.N.
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9Israel today expressed its official satisfaction with the United States veto last night of a resolution in the Security Council, but Israeli officials said privately that important differences still separated Washington and Jerusalem on how to deal with the Palestinian issue.

title: Capitol Blunder
description: The Congressional space grab that would take the incomplete Madison Library, the new building of the Library of Congress, and convert it into another House Office Building is one more monumental blunder in the ludicrous ad hoc history of Government building on Capitol Hill.

title: Owners of Stocks Decline By 18.3 Percent Since 1970
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the ranks of the nation's stockholders had declined for the first time in the 23 years it had kept check on the number of individuals who owned part of American business.

title: Stevens Calls Court Pay Too Low; Puts His Net Worth at $171,284
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 Judge John Paul Stevens, testifying for the second day at the Senate hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court, complained today that salaries paid to Federal judges were too sow.

title: ARMY INTERVENES IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Dec. 10  The Lebanese Government sent army commandos yesterday to separate Christian and Moslem factions fighting for control of Beirut, and in at least one area the troops reportedly came under fire from both sides.

title: Lie Test Put Off for Head of Slain Family
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 9The polygraph testing of Wesley R. Diggs, the 40yearold New York City businessman who found his wife and four children shin in their $50,000 Teaneck home Saturday, has been postponed because of Mr. Diggs's emotional state, according to Joseph C. Woodcock, Jr., the Bergen County Prosecutor.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: The Lab That Is A Maker Of Tastes In Food
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J.From the outside it looks just like any other low, sprawling industrial complex, but once inside a strange, indefinable odor greets a visitor like a slap in the face. It's business as usual at Crompton & Knowles.

title: Bridge:
description: It is usually right to do the obvious at the bridge table, and to assume that the opponents will do the obvious. However, the assumption may not be valid against an opponent who is either exceptionally stupid or exceptionally astute.

title: The Stage:
description: In the summer of 1940, as he recalls in his Memoirs, in ecstasy over a romance and with a premonition of [the] doom of the affair, Tennessee Williams wrote Purification, his only verse play.

title: Gulf Oil Aide Tells Of Texas Donations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Gulf Oil Corporation's Texas lobbyist has testified that he has donated thousands of dollars to candidates for state office since 1960.

title: The Morgan Takes Lamb Into Its Fold
description: Charles Lamb has been called the most lovable author in English letters, but he bids fair to be the most lamentably ignored. This year marks the 200th anniversary of his birth (Feb. 10), and that has been all that marked the occasion.

title: Mother of 11 Is Sworn In as Lawyer
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9When the youngest of her 11 children entered first grade three years ago, Dorothy G. Black decided to follow her into the world of learning, and she entered law school.

title: Vietnamese Children Here Hope for White Christmas
description: For the first time in his life, 11yearold Thanh Huynh is looking forward to celebrating a white Christmas.

title: Head of U. of Virginia Stirs Racial Dispute
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 9In the final years before his death in 1826, Thomas Jefferson spent much of his time peering down from Monticello, his complex mountaintop home at a complex of neo  Roman buildings then beginning to rise on the plain here. The complex, which came to be called the University of Virginia, represented Jefferson's final act of architectural and intellectual genius. He saw it as a vehicle for the extension of the democratic principles he had lived by. Sometimes he would use a telescope to monitor the progress on the plain.

title: Business Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI)A plan to reorganize the Equity Funding Corporation, the company involved in one of the major financial scandals of the century, was approved today by Federal Judge Harry Pregerson.

title: Pakistan Envoy to Dacca
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Wednesday Dec. 10 (Reuters)Pakistan today named a former senior Government official, Mohammad Khurshid, as its first ambassador to Bangladesh. The two countries established diplomatic relations Oct. 3. Mr. Khurshid has operated a farm near Rawalpindi since retiring from Government service in 1967 after a string of senior posts.

title: DressingRoom Spying to Stop Thefts at Gimbels Is Struck Down
description: The practice by Gimbels department store of spying on customers in dressing rooms to catch them shoplifting was ruled unconstitutional by a Criminal Court judge yesterday.

title: Bunning Rehired as Pilot
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP)Jim Bunning was renamed today manager of the Philadelphia Phillies' TripleA International League farm team, which has been moved from Toledo to Oklahoma City for the 1976 season. The 44yearold former major league pitcher has been a manager in Philadelphia's system for the last four years.

title: Gen. Wayne R. Allen Dies; Served in Three Conflicts
description: SANTA BARBARA. Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI)Maj. Gen. Wayne R. Allen, who was Los Angeles County's first chief administrative officer, died Saturday of a heart attack in St. Francis Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Teamster Reported Seen in Hoffa Car on Day of Disappearance
description: DETROIT, Dec. 9  One of three New Jersey teamsters who appeared in a police lineup last Saturday was identified by one witness as having driven off with James R. Haffa the day he disappeared, a Federal source close to the investigation said today.

title: All About LowCalorie Beer
description: Whitey Ford and Mickey Mantle have been on television often in the last year with a sales pitch intended to tell people how nonfilling and low in calories Lite beer is.

title: Regional Group Challenges Juan Carlos
description: MADRID, Dec. 9A group of opposition political leaders, meeting secretly in Barcelona today, reportedly established a council that is intended to be the nucleus of a provisional government for the northeastern Spanish region of Catalonia.

title: HARRY H. SPENCER
description: Harry H. Spencer, who had been an investment banker with F. S. Smithers & Co. here before his retirement in 1940, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 96 years old and lived in Greenwich Lodge, Greenwich, and on Fire Island, L. I., where he was president of the Point O Woods Association.

title: TRADECURB PLAN IN BRITAIN FOUGHT
description: PARIS, Dec. 9  Britain's plans to impose import controls to help resolve its growing financial problems are running into mounting criticism from the nation's trading partners and the international organizations with which Britain must deal.

title: Police Towaway Fee Will Go Up to $65
description: The fee for towing away illegally parked cars in Manhattan will be raised from $50 to $65 next month, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd announced yesterday.

title: 8% RISE EXPECTED IN DEFENSE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The defense budget for the current fiscal year, as it is finally emerging from Congress, provides $7.4 billion less than requested by the Administration but 8 percent more than, appropriated last year by Congress.

title: VALUATIONS DIFFER ON MASSENA PLANT
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9The Public Service Commission reported today two different values for the costs and earnings of the power facilities in the upstate town of Massena, which has voted to take over and operate the plant of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving
description: I have lived in my present neighborhood, on West 125th Street, for the last eighteen years. This has influenced my life to this present day, and will always have an impact on me as long as I live.

title: Back on Course
description: The state's two ranking lawenforcement officers, Chief Judge Breitel and Attorney General Lefkowitz, have taken a useful step to advance the effort to clean up New York City's criminal justice system.

title: Malawi Is Said to Detain 30,000 in Jehovah Sect
description: LONDON, Dec. 9 (UPI)  A spokesman for the Jehovah's Witnesses has said that at least 30,000 members of the sect were being held in detention camps in the southeastern African country of Malawi and that some had been murdered.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Ayckbourn Trilogy Sets Up Calendar
description: Alan Ayckbourn's trilogy of plays, Table Manners, Living Together and Round and Round the Garden, now running in rotation at the Morosco Theater, 217 West 45th Street, apparently is posing no problem to patrons interested in buying tickets to some or to all of the plays

title: 2 Reserves Lift Braves Over Kings
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 9 (AP)Don Adams and Bob Weiss came into the game and sparked a rally that sent the Buffalo Braves to a 126107 victory over the Kansas City Kings in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: 7th Body Is Found Buried In South Carolina Grave
description: LAKE CITY, S.C., Dec. 9 (AP)A seventh body was found buried today in a rural area of Florence County a mile east of where six other bodies were found in shallow graves last week, the authorities said. Three persons have been arrested and charged with murder in the case.

title: Bernstein Comes To Aid of Candide
description: In an effort to bolster lagging business at Candide, the longrunning musical at the Broadway Theater, Leonard Bernstein, who wrote the show's music, will conduct the overture at today's matinee. A spokesman for the musical said yesterday that it had been running at a slight loss since the settlement of the musicians' strike, which shut down 12 musicals for 25 days.

title: Excerpts From Brezhnev's Address in Warsaw
description: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered in Warsaw yesterday by Leonid L Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, as made available in English by Tess, the Soviet press agency:

title: Superdome Is Sued By Fans in Attempt To Prohibit Smoking
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9An attorney for six sports fans who say their health has been damaged by tobacco fumes in the Louisiana Superdome filed suit today to prohibit smoking and the sale of cigarettes in the stadium.

title: BREZHNEV ASSERTS SLANDER IN WEST POISONS DETENTE
description: WARSAW, Dec. 9Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, charged today that influential circles in the West had poisoned the international atmosphere since the summit conference on European cooperation and security in Helsinki last August.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AM  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Levi Forming Agency to Guide Inquiries Into Any Misconduct
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today that he would appoint an internal Justice Department agency to oversee investigations of alleged misconduct by department employes, including Federal Bureau of Investigation personnel.

title: State Supreme Court Bars Halt in Transit Fare Rises
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9The New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to grant an injunction to halt the new fare increases for trains and buses affecting 700,000 commuters in the state.

title: LISBON AIDE BACKS COMMUNIST ROLE
description: LISBON, Dec. 9Portugal's Foreign Minister said today that while the Communist Party had some moral responsibility for the unsuccessful leftwing military uprising two weeks ago, the party was indisponsible to the advance of the Portuguese revolution.

title: Price Level Here For Market Basket Almost Unchanged
description: For the seventh week in succession the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City remained virtually unchanged last week, dropping 0.1 per cent, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Governor Gets Plea on Nursing Homes
description: The owners of 91 private nursing homes in the city called upon Governor Carey yesterday to intervene to avert a strike threatened for 7 A.M. tomorrow by their nurses and other employees.

title: Indicators Disclose The State's Economy Improved in October
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP)Despite unemployment exceeding 13 percent, New Jersey's economy improved during October, the State Department of Labor land Industry has reported.

title: Kissinger Puts Off His Visit to Soviet For Talks on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he had put off until next month a visit to Moscow designed to seek a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations on limiting strategic arms.

title: Senate Votes NOW Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House yesterday a bill that would permit thrift institutions in all six New England states to offer accounts similar to checking accounts, but on which depositors may receive interest. The accounts, known as NOW for negotiated order of withdrawal accounts, are now authorized in Massachusetts and New Hampshire.

title: U. S. Judge Rejects Bid By Gilmour
description: Citing management tolerance of plaintiff's past shortcomings, a Federal judge refused yesterday to grant an injunction that would permit William (Buddy) Gilmour to resume driving at New York harness tracks.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in The New York Times yesterday on school integration in Louisville, Ky., reported that racial stereotypes there are not moderating on the basis of firsthand experiences in the classrooms. The word not should have been now.

title: Highlights of Carey Plan
description: Following are the highlights of the program submitted by Governor Carey today to deal with the state's fiscal problems:

title: Carey Would Intercept Pension Funds To Rescue State Construction Agencies
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9Governor Carey's proposal for a $2.45 billion rescue of the state's construction agencies from their credit crisis would involve a complicated, and as yet uncommitted, variety of fundschiefly a controversial advance intercept of contributions to the state pension funds.

title: A Clarification
description: Earnings figures for the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, referred to yesterday in the People and Business column as down 7.7 percent for the third quarter, reflected net income after securities transactions. Operating earnings were up 5.2 percent.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A New Hampshire soldier whose murder trial ended in a hung jury will be retried, according to officials at Mount Holly. The soldier, Sgt. Richard W. DuBois, 23 years old of Laconia, was convicted Monday of conspiracy to commit murder, but the Burlington County Court jury was unable to reach a verdict on the murder charge. Sergeant DuBois admitted strangling Philip Spillane, a 33yearold Willingboro business man, last June 13, but testified he did not believe he had killed him.

title: SERVICE FOR WILDER FIELD NEAR HIS HOME
description: A funeral service for Thornton Wilder, the playwright and novelist, was held yesterday in a setting reminiscent of his play Our Town.

title: Charleston Election Increases Blacks on City Council to 50%
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 9 For the first since Reconstruction, voters of the city of Charleston today elected a City Council half of whose members are black. At the same time voters rejected the bids, however, of the first woman and the first black candidate for Mayor.

title: Boys and Girls of Winter In Town for Skate Titles
description: Her name is Priscilla Hill. She's 14 years old, shy, softspoken and already a veteran of international figure skating competition. She won the Prague Skate in Czechoslovakia last November and is one of the leading contenders for the Eastern senior women's crown this week.

title: Soviet Farm Failures
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 9  This year's harvest disaster, based on a grain yield seemingly as low as 137 million tons, has once again raised questions about the Soviet Union's ability to feed its people adequately. The 1975 grain deficiency appears to run nearly 79 million tons below the original target. In practical terms, this works out to a per capita harvest yield as small as that of 1913, a mediocre czarist year that Soviet statisticians cite as a prerevolutionary base to demonstrate the nation's progress under Communism.

title: Sanitationmen Bar Special Overtime
description: The city's effort yesterday to accelerate the removal of hazardous accumulations of garbage and rubbish was hampered when the union representing cityemployed sanitationmen refused to have its men work overtime.

title: About Real Estate
description: Out went Elizabeth Arden. Then, a few months later, in came Stout Sportswear.

title: E.P.A. Tentatively Decides SST Is Too Noisy for Capital or City
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)The Environmental Protection) Agency has tentatively decided that flying the noisy Concorde supersonic jet aircraft into New York city is undesirable and that flying it into Washington is questionable.

title: Yale Theater Gets $30,000 for Troilus
description: The Yale Repertory Theater has received a grant of $30,000 from the Corbett Foundation of Cincinnati to provide financial support for its final production of the 197576 season, Shakespeare's Troilus and Cressida.

title: U.S. Sues 5 Railroads to Block Asset Sales Before TakeOver
description: The Government charged yesterday that its plan for reorganizing the bankrupt Northeast railroads faced a massive attack from the Penn Central and four other carriers it accused of trying to sell off assets designated for Conrail, the new Federally sponsored railroad.

title: $3.1 BILLION IN AID APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) A twoyear, $3.1 billion foreign aid bill, including $1.4 billion in food aid for poor nations, got Congress' final approval in the House today and went to President Ford.The authorization bill requires that the poorest nations get the food money first. It also urges President Ford to maintain a target of 10 million tons of United States food aid a year to needy nations.

title: South Boston High Placed Under U.S. Court Officer
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. of Federal District Court placed racially troubled South Boston High School in Federal receivership today and stripped the Boston School Committee of much of its control over school desegregation.

title: Public Library Begins A FundRaising Drive
description: The New York Public Library has opened a campaign to raise $3 million in private contributions to support its research collections.

title: State Chancellor Assailed For Plans to Lay Off 400
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)The New Jersey Education Association today accused the Chancellor of Higher Education, Ralph A. Dungan, with dereliction of duty in his plans to lay off more than 400 college teachers in September if the states financial problems are not solved.

title: Players to Set Contract Plans
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 9A twoday meeting of player representatives of the 24 major league baseball teams will start at the Americana Hotel here tomorrow, to he devoted mainly to defining positions and devising strategy for the general labor agreement that has to be negotiated in the next few months.point, winning on Messersmith would mean a strong bargaining position, in that other gains could be exacted for yielding back some controls. Losing on Messersmith would be a tactical defeat, giving them less to bargain with.

title: Soviet Opens Trial of Kovalev, Dissident Biologist
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP)Sergei A. Kovalev, a biologist and charter member of the Soviet branch of Amnesty International, went on trial today on charges of antiSoviet activity.

title: About New York
description: Next year the nation will celebrate its Bicentennial, but those who care to can also take the time to observe the 100th birthday of Riverside Park, a stringbean strip that lies between the lordly Hudson River and the stone mounds of West Side Manhattan.

title: Colleze Enrollment Up
description: Colleges across the country, after several years of enrollment slowdown, experienced this year the highest enrollments since the boom of the Sixties. Page 43.

title: M.A.C. Head's Prediction: City's Pain Just Starting
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, predicted yesterday that services provided by the city would be severely constricted in the next several years as a result of the fiscal plan it must adhere to.

title: Bach Mass Sung in the Big Tradition
description: The 19thcentury tradition of performing Bach's choral works with too many singers and too many instrumentalists dies hard, and probably will linger on for as long as symphony orchestras feel morally or contractually bound to fill up their stages with musicians at every concert. The Philadelphia Orchestra's performance of the Mass in B minor on Monday night at Carnegie Hall followed that tradition and was, of its type, a worthy representative.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Gas Main Explodes on East Side

title: Program by Carey Would Bring More Budget Cuts Here and in Other State Cities
description: ALBANY, Dec. 9Governor Carey's proposed spending cuts would force New York City and other localities to trim their budgets still further at a time when they are already beset with fiscal problems.

title: River Open After Crash
description: NEW CASTLE, Del. Dec. 9 (AP)The Delaware River was reopened to ship traffic yesterday after divers found a tugboat that capsized and sank, Sunday, leaving two crewmen presumed dead. Six other crewmen were rescued when the 79foot tug Saratoga sank after it was rammed by a ship it was towing.

title: Kissinger Puts Off His Visit to Soviet For Talks on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that he had put off until next month a visit to Moscow designed to seek a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations on limiting strategic arms.

title: 2 ExHayden Executives Are Disciplined by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Disciplinary action was taken today against two former executives of Hayden Stone Inc., a New York brokerage house that was beset by financial difficulties in 1970.

title: Books of The Times
description: The discovery a few years ago that New York has tens of thousands of poor Jews, large numbers of them elderly and living alone in decaying, dangerous neighborhoods, apparently came as a shock to many. The surprise arose because American stereotypes about Jews tend to approach those of the famous general who explained not so long ago what he saw as the political consequences of alleged Jewish power in the banks and in communications. Everybody has heard of Jewish businessmen, lawyers, doctors and even, unfortunately, nursing home owners. The much larger number of Jewish taxi drivers, clerks, barbers, shoemakers, factory hands and the like rarely commands attention. It seems like more than a half century since Michael Gold published his Jews Without Money.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1975

title: Contempt Vote on Kissinger Is Linked to Data Ford Gives
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.(AP)Representative Otis G. Pike, chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that he would drop contempt action against Secretary of State Henry, A. Kissinger if a delegation from his committee decided that a compromise offered by President Ford was satisfactory.

title: DOCTORS CONFER WITH GOV. BROWN
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI) Gov. Edmund G. Brown. Jr. met today with a small group of doctors who are demanding action to counter soaring malpractice insurance rates that have brought a reduction in nonemergency surgery and a warning that thousands of doctors will stop practicing by New Year's Day.

title: ARMY INTERVENES IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Dec. 10  The Lebanese Government sent army commandos yesterday to separate Christian and Moslem factions fighting for control of Beirut, and in at least one area the troops reportedly came under fire from both sides.

title: Turning Point Puts Synthesizer's Hum Into Its JazzRock
description: Things were humming Monday evening at the Chelsea Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street, when Turning Point, a jazzrock sextet, gave two concerts as part of a new Monday night jazz series there. The humming, which was strong and persistent throughout the first concert, came primarily from a synthesizer operated by Ben Aronov. although two electric keyboards played by Tom Pierson and the electric bass that Ron McClure alternated with an acoustic bass may have contributed, too.

title: MONSANTO TO RAISE RESIN PRICES JAN. 5
description: The Monsanto Polymers and Petrochemicals Company, an operating subsidiary of the Monsanto Company, said yesterday that it planned to increase prices on all grades of butvar and formar resins by 10 cents a pound, effective Jan. 5. These resins are used in the adhesive coating, paper and textile industries.

title: Argentine Police Leave
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 (AP) The police withdrew tonight from the facilities of the newspaper Crnica, which the Government shut down a year ago. It was closed for proposing an invasion of the Britishheld Falkland Islands, which are claimed by Argentina.

title: Deer Shot 5 Minutes After Start Of Disputed Great Swamp Hunt
description: BASKING RIDGE, Dec. 9The first whitetail deer shot in the controversial Great Swamp public deer hunt was pulled from the wet underbrush at 7:05 this morning, five minutes after the hunt officially began. But it was not until late morning that an animal of trophy qualitya fourpoint, 120pound buckwas bagged.

title: Jay Eisenstat, 33, Executive Of FilmProducing Concern
description: Jay Eisenstat, executive vice president of Myers & Eisenstat Films, television and film producer, died yesterday of cancer in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 33 years old and lived at 110 West 86th Street.

title: Paris Publishing House for Women Is a Best Seller
description: PARISA publishing house run entirely by women and issuing works exclusively by women on subjects of special interest to women is proving a success here.

title: Holiday Buffet Menu
description: Appropriately timed for the Bicentennial, this handsomely illustrated, wellwritten and fascinating book is an account of the development of American food, along with bits of lore and local customs.

title: Childhood Images: Etched in Memory, Crafted in Wood
description: William Accorsi recreates childhood. He takes funny old memories and makes them into cutout wooden sculptures: cowboys and Indians, and little people perched on blocks, and spindly ladders leading up to nowhere in particular.

title: Carey Urges Harsher Law Against Juvenile Violence
description: Harsher treatment for juveniles who commit violent crimes was urged yesterday by Governor Carey. We will introduce legislation calling for mandatory sanctions for juveniles14 or oldertound guilty of a major violent crime and found dangerous to society by a Family Court judge, the Governor said.

title: N.F.L. Clears Tannen
description: The Jets' Steve Tannen satisfied the National Football League yesterday that he was not involved in the alleged bookmaking operation of his partner in a boutique in Florida.

title: Implementation of CarRepair Law Is Up to Consumer
description: The new state autorepair law in New York makes the job of selfprotection easier by giving consumers new legal rights. But consumers must assert those rights, or the new law will make little difference to them.

title: WINE TALK
description: PARIS, Dec. 9They were sitting around a tiny horseshoeshaped bar in a former locksmith's shop in the Cit Berryer, an 18thcentury shopping arcade near the Place de la Madeleine.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
