description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Appellate Division Upholds The Shortened School Day
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday upheld unanimously the agreement between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers for a shortened instructional day in elementary, intermediate and junior high schools.

title: YIELDS INCREASE; CALENDAR HEAVY
description: As this week's active financing schedule swung into full speed yesterday, interest rates rose, a new Bell System bond issue was priced to yield 9.35 percent and the Treasury Deparunent announced plans to raise $3 billion of new cash within the next two weeks. The combination of higher interest rates and heavy financing activity caused a number of new issues to be postponed: Carter Hawley Hale Stores' $60 million of debentures; Associates Corporation of North America's $100 million; and the Central Telephone Company's. $20 million.

title: People in Sports
description: Ed Johnstone, leading scorer for the American Hockey League's Providence Reds, has been recalled by the Rangers, who are in a bind for right wings because of injuries. The 21yearold Johnstone replaces Bill Collins, who is sidelined for six weeks with an ailing knee, and is expected to be in uniform for tonight's game against the Buffalo Sabres in Madison Square Garden. Johnstone had 14 goals and 16 assists in 26 games for Providence.

title: Market Place
description: The big question facing thousands of holders of soontomature New York City notes is whether to swap them for new Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

title: Pro Punters Told They Need Tutor
description: About Pro Football

title: Kentucky Installs Woman
description: FRANKFURT, Ky., Dec. 9 (AP)Kentucky installed the nation's second woman Lieutenant Governor today when Thelma Stovall was sworn in with Gov. Julian Carroll. Mrs. Stovall, 56 years old, resigned from her third fouryear term as Secretary of State.

title: State Upheld in Its Suit To Open Beach at Deal
description: FREEHOLD. Dec. 9 (AP)Superior Court judge today upheld a suit by the State Public Advocate aimed at opening the Deal Casino and its beach to the general public.

title: COMPLIANCE SEEN ON ARAB BOYCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9A Commerce Department official disclosed today that in nearly threefourths of 50,000 trading transactions with Arab countries since 1970, American companies had declined to tell the United States Government whether they had complied with Arab boycott demands.

title: Simon Bars Any Negotiations With Congress on TaxCut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said today that there was no room for negotiation between President Ford and Congress over the President's intention to veto any taxcut bill that did not also contain a spending ceiling.

title: South Boston High Placed Under U.S. Court Officer
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. of Federal District Court placed racially troubled South Boston High School in Federal receivership today and stripped the Boston School Committee of much of its control over school desegregation.

title: John Patterson, 50, Professor Of Journalism at Columbia, Dies
description: John M. Patterson, an associate professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Haven, Conn. He was 50 years old and lived in Westnort, Conn.

title: Rites Today for Dr. Wade
description: A funeral service for Dr. Leo Wade, a retired executive of the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research, will be conducted at 11 A.M. today at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. Dr. Wade died Sunday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: OIL SPILLS CALLED PERIL TO CLIMATE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9Oil spills on Arctic ocean ice could conceivably create changes in the earth's climate, a scientist said here today.

title: Memorial Services
description: TAUMEdward Lawrie. A memorial service for Prof. Edward Lawris Tatum will be held in Caspary Auditorium of the Rockefeller University, York Ave. and 66th St., on Thursday, Dec. 11 at 11 A.M. Friends are invited.

title: The Albany Abyss
description: Warning that New York State, like New York City, stands on the edge of the abyss, Governor Carey yesterday prescribed a program for fiscal salvation which, like that for the city, is painful, perilous, precariousand inescapable.

title: Tax Restructuring Urged in Jersey City
description: Restructuring the local property tax could encourage development in Jersey City and even enable the city to drop its temporary oneyear payroll tax without losing revenue, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Olivier, Prince of Players, Recalls His Slings and Arrows
description: Laurence Olivier hailed a taxicab and, standing next to the cabbie's window, with impeccable manners he told the driver his destination. The driver crackled with antipathy. Don't stand there! he barked at the greatest actor in the Englishspeaking world. Just get in! Like an apprentice spear carrier, Lord Olivier dutifully complied.

title: No Quick Decision Expected On Taxi FareRise Request
description: Moses Kove, chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, said yesterday that it would likely be weeks before his commission made a decision on the request of taxifleet owners for a 7.5 percent increase in fares.

title: Education Office Acts to Clarify Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The Federal Government spends, $7.4 billion a year on education, but if the. Government's education administrators had their way the nation would spend $25 billion a year for schooling of children and adults.

title: GRAIN CONTRACTS ADVANCE A LITTLE
description: Confirmation by the Agriculture Department that this year's Soviet grain crop totaled only about 137 million metric tons helped move grain and soybean prices up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Winds of the Young Blow Holiday Airs
description: In the big scheme, it prob ably doesn't count. It wasn't the SALT talks or a United Nations resolution against Zionism or finding Jimmy Hoffa's body. It was a rehearsal for the Christmas concert at a local junior high school. I have a reasonable good ear in music, said Shakespeare. Let's have the tongs and the bones. Big schemes, anyway, tend to turn out badly.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMOOTH HARMONY The keyboard music of Len Berge adds to the pleasantry of a new restaurant called Pev (6888778), at 1078 First Avenue (between 58th and 59th Streets). This is a convenient dropin spot around cocktail time or later, with cheerful lighting, beige walls and a subdued dcor of the 1930's.

title: Larchmont Creche Placed At Episcopal Church Site
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 10 The Larchmont crche, which had become the focus of a bitter community dispute over the placement of religious symbols on municipal property, was erected today on the lawn of St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: CITY TAKES GRANT TO HIRE FIREMEN
description: The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to accept a $2.87 million Federal grant that will permit the Fire Department to rehire 101 laidoff firement in addition to 150 who wilt return on Monday.

title: Singer to Meet Amid Talk of Change
description: Directors of the troubled Singer Company hold their monthly meeting today amid reports that the new management intends to get rid of its business machines division. The division has been idenified as a major problem area for the company.

title: Photo Rule For Driving Is Debated
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10, (AP)Governor Byrne expressed concern over the possible costs and inconveniences of a proposed law to require photographs on driver's licenses at a public hearing he conducted today on the measure. The legislation has cleared both the Senate and Assembly and is now before the Governor.

title: Court Order Puts Off a Strike Threatened for Nursing Homes
description: A strike threatened, for today by 12,000 workers in 91 private nursing homes in the city was temporarily averted yesterday when their union agreed to a State Supreme Court order barring the walkout for five days and directing that the contract dispute be arbitrated.

title: Creator of Tiffany Display Toasts Passing Parade
description: Gene Moore's life is an ode to taste. He has spent the better part of his life creating windows on fifth.Avenue, the last 20 years for Tiffany & Co.

title: Lockheed Rises to Top As Defense Contractor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation moved into first place among the nation's defense contractors in the fiscal year ended June 30, the Pentagon said today.

title: SCHOOL BOARD CUTS PRIVILEGES ON FARES
description: The Board of Education decided last night to put an end to reducedfare privileges for 34,800 junior and senior high school students who live less than a mile from school.

title: Brezhnev Ends Polish Visit
description: WARSAW, Dec. 10 (Reuters) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the So viet leader, left for home today after having attended the sev??th Polish Communist Party congress

title: WHITLAM'S DEFEAT IN AUSTRALIA SEEN
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 10Australia's bitterest election campaign in a generation drew to a close tonight with opinion polls indicating that the interim Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, was far ahead of his ousted rival, Gough Whitlam.

title: Magical, Happy San Francisco Also Has Problems, and Tears
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 The Indian summer this year, clinging on even toward mid  December, has created a languor and sense of magic that make it seem that this lovely place could have no longterm problems.

title: STEFAN GROSSMAN AT OTHER END CLUB
description: Stefan Grossman is a folkmusic survivor, a genuine holdover from the days when the scene was Greenwich Village coffee shops and minds were expanded merely by a basic and plain 12bar blues. Mr. Grossman man was appearingalso teaching and talkingat the Other End, Bleecker. Street, on Tuesday, and was a true delight.

title: Decision in Boston
description: In placing South Boston High School under Federal receivership and stripping the Boston School Committee of much of its control over desegregation and security, Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. has made a drastic, decisive and altogether courageous move.

title: '75 Cannons Make Trek Again
description: Two hundred years ago yesterday, Henry Knox, a 25yearold bookseller from Boston, left Fort Ticonderoga on an epic march, hauling cannons through the wilderness to Boston, whore their arrival helped General George Washington drive the British out of the city.

title: Cindy Nelson 3d in Skiing to 2 Austrians
description: APRICA, Italy, Dec. 10 (AP)  Brigitte Totschnig won a women's downhill ski race today and took the lead for the 1976 World Cup, restoring the shaken prestige of the Austrian team after the retirement of the fivetime champion, AnneMarie Proell.

title: FISKE IS ENDORSED FOR U.S. ATTORNEY
description: Robert B. Fiske Jr., a 44yearold Wall Street lawyer, is expected to be selected for the post of United States Attorney here.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 6.439 percent.

title: JACKSON ASSAILS KISSINGER AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that Secretary, of State Henry A. Kissinger had failed to dispel his concern that the Soviet Union had violated the purposes and spirit of the 1972 strategic arms limitation agreements.

title: What Bill Veeck Holds for the Futu??
description: He's back in baseball. He never should have left, but it wasn't his fault that he did. Doctors advised Bill Veeck in 1961 to delegate more authority in operating the Chicago White Sox. but he soon decided to sell his syndicate's majority control.

title: Provenzano and 2 Other Teamster Aides Indicted for Kickback Deal
description: Anthony Provenzano, a New Jersey Teamster Union official with reputed Mafia connections, was named with two, other men yesterday on a Federal charge of conspiracy to arrange a kickback for a $2 million loan from union pension funds.

title: Courville Receives Golf Award
description: Jerry Courville, a softspoken, 40yearold steel salesman who has won more than 50 golf tournaments in and near the metropolitan area. received the Distinguished Service Award, of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at its annual meeting at the Biltmore.

title: HUMPHREY DRIVE OPENED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Representative Paul Simon of Illinois, a liberal Democrat with close ties to Mayor Richard, J. Daley:s Chicago organization, is forming a committee within the House to draft Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota for his party's Presidential nomination next year.

title: Oklahoma a Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)  President Ford declared Oklahoma a disaster area today after severe storms and tornadoes struck the state last Friday, causing widespread damage. The President's action will permit the use of Federal funds for relief and recovery efforts in the affected areas.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES JACK HID THE JACK
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10 (AP)A Representative's brother testified in Federal court today that he regularly jacked up his house to hide money.

title: Indiana Museum Gets $5 Million Art Grant
description: The Krannert Charitable Trust has presented the Indianapolis Museum of Pitt with a grant for $5 million in the form of a dollarfordollar matching challenge as part of a projected $30 million endowment fund effort on the part of the museum. The income from the latter endowment will apply solely for museum operations.

title: Goodman Asks a State Inquiry Of Illegal GrandJury Leaks
description: Calling for an end to a trend that seriously jeopardizes civil liberties, State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday requested an immediate investigation by the State Commission of Investigation into illegal grandjury leaks.

title: French Backers of Concorde Challenge U.S. Data on Noise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)French directors of the British  French Concorde program said today that American charges that the supersonic jet is too noisy to land in the United States were unscientific.

title: F.B.I. Gives Judge Stevens High Rating for Court Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)  F.B.I. investigators gave, Judge John Paul Stevens, nominee to the Supreme Court, a highly commendatory rating today, and the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said the Senate may vote on the confirmaiion before Congress adjourns Dec. 19.

title: Byrne Offers Help on Teaneck Slayings
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 10Governor Byrne interceded today in the investigation into the murders of five members of the family of Wesley R. Diggs of Teaneck, which he said had shocked all New Jerseyans.

title: Bricklayers Accept Cut In Wages to Spur Jobs
description: To spur renovation and construction of small residences and shopping centers and reduce the 80 percent unemployment rate among the metropolitan area's 4,000 bricklayers, the workers agreed yesterday to take a 25 percent cut in wages and also a reduction in fringe benefits. The cut does not apply to work on large commercial structures.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Wednesday Foreign Exchange in dollars and decimals ofa dollar, New York prices at 2 p.m.

title: CORRECTION
description: The names of John Edward Holownia and Bruce Howard Belsky were inadvertently left off the list, published in The New York Times Friday, of those passing the bar examination. A third listing in the Second Department should have read Susan Carol Levine.

title: 40Foot Fordham Shot Defeats Harvard, 7068
description: Kevin Brown hit a 40foot desperation shot at the buzzer that gave Fordham a 7068 triumph over Harvard last night at the Rams' Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: Light Opera Stages Vagabond King With a Royal Air
description: The Light Opera of Manhattanor LOOM, as it calls itself  mounted its biggest production to date on Tuesday evening. In staging Rudolf Fiml's The Vagabond King, LOOM thrust forward all of its resources. There algo was in anniversary, of, sorts, on hand. LOOM did not make much of it, but Friml's popular, drippingly nostalgic Vagabond King is 50 years old; it had its premiere in New York on Sept. 21, 1925, to enormous acclaim. Some of its music is still in everybody's ear. Who does not remember the Song of the Vagabonds (And to HELL with Burgundy), Someday, and Only a Rose?

title: BRITONS IN DEBATE ON DEATH PENALTY
description: LONDON, Dec. 9The reinstatement of capital punishment for terrorists has emerged as a major political issue in Britain in the aftermath, of a bombing and murder campaign attributed to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Social Security Staffs Get Right to Doff Ties
description: Acting on a knotty issue that has made some men hot under the collar, a Federal arbitrator has ruled that local Social Security employees cannot be required to wear neckties.

title: Broadway Clean Sweep
description: Some 200 of Broadway's theater people picked up brooms and took to the streets yesterday to dramatize the theater community's concern with the quality of the environment which surrounds the theater district.

title: No Hoffa Indictment In the Near Future, U.S. Attorney Says
description: DETROIT, Dec. 10Ralph Guy, the United States Attorney here, said at a news conference today that there were no indictments expected in the Hoffa case in the near future.

title: Disaster Areas on Coast
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 10 (AP)Seven Washington counties and the city of Aberdeen have declared themselves disaster areas because of flood damage, according to the State Department of Emergency Services. The counties are Grays Harbor, King, Lewis, Skagit, Snohomish, Thurston and Whatcom.

title: Housing Agency Assailed As a Chief Slumlord of U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 10The front, door of the modest blue frame house at 532 North Leamington on the Northwest Side was open. The cheap metal eye hooks that once held a padlock had long before been pried from the soft wood.

title: Seller of Apartments To Accept City Paper
description: The realty concern of SulzbergerRolfe Inc. announced yesterday that to show its faith in the city it would accept New York City bonds and notes and Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds at 100 percent face value as, payment for apartments it was selling in an East Side building.

title: Where There's Smoke,' a Study in Blackmail, Opens
description: In the 1950's, Andr Cayatte, a French lawyer-turned-film-maker, made two films ("We Are All Murderers," "Justice Is Done") that received a good deal of favorable attention here. On the basis of everything he's done since, that acclaim seems to have been unwarranted.Mr. Cayatte's newest film to be released in this country, "Where There's Smoke," virtually defines the pedestrian movie. It proceeds earnestly, step by step, from one obvious point to another, like a man walking around a golf course without clubs, just for the exercise."Where There's. Smoke" (II-n'y-a pas de Fume Sans Feu), which opened yesterday at the Cinema Studio, is about political corruption in a rich Paris suburb where to be mayor, apparently, offers such magnificent rewards (whether it's power, money or simply girls, the film never says) that the incumbent party resorts to bribery, blackmail and murder to stay in office.Though Mr. Cayatte was once a lawyer, he doesn't acknowledge that there may be two sides to any question or that characters, like motives, may be mixed. "Where There's Smoke" is the story of the mostly successful efforts of the incumbent mayor to discredit his principal opposition, a clean-living young doctor (Bernard Fresson), by circulating a fake photograph showing the doctor's brave, loyal wife (Annie Girardot) participating in an orgy, which, if you've seen an Annie Girardot movie lately, is the last thing she would do.The film in fact is less about political corruption and the lust for power than the technology of blackmail. The only sequence of interest in the movie shows how it's possible to fake a photograph, to place one person's head on the body of another, in such a way that even laser beams cannot detect the deception.This may give you pause, if not quite making you stop and think.

title: Market Place
description: A rash of bank dividend cuts has contributed to further selling of the already depressed bank stocks as investors worry that more banks will trim their payouts.

title: Churches End Kenya Talks With an Appeal for Changes
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 10 (AP)The World Council of Churches ended its assembly here today with a call for a radical transformation of civilization to free it from forces seen as spoiling the earth and blighting its people.

title: Less of Everything
description: More than in any year in decades, the poor of this city have need of private help. Victims of the city's financial collapse, they have been discovering week by week new ways in which the stricken municipality has been obliged to reduce its services to those echo can least spare them. With jobs scarcer than a year ago and prices higher, they face the Christmas season and the foreseeable future with less of everything they needhealth facilities, food, youth services, daycare centers, neighborhood selfhelp projects and soon, if some legislators have their way, even welfare payments.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Bridge:
description: Next year may be Brazil's year. In the Bermuda Bowl in Monte Carlo in May, the Brazilians will have their best team: Gabriel Chagas and PedroPaul Assumpcao, Marcelo and Pedro Branco, and Gabino Cintra and Christian Fonseca. It is far from clear that there will be any team to beat them.

title: $15 Billion Seen Going to Pollution Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Russell W. Peterson, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, said today that the 1975 expenditures by government and private industry for pollution control would total $15.7 billion and generate a million jobs.

title: Terrorists Ambush a General Amid Argentine Military Unrest
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10Leftwing extremists wounded an air force general and his bodyguard today.

title: INVESTOR SUITS REDUCE BOND BIDS
description: Investment bankers are becoming increasingly reluctant to bid on state and city bonds because they are growing more concerned about the completeness of official statements that local governments publish for potential investors. Three underwriting syndicates decided yesterday not to bid for a $25 million bond issue of Richmond, Va., a highly rated borrower that has sold bonds early each December for 20 years, because their lawyers were dissatisfied about the way information on the city was made available to investors.

title: City's Marshals Now Face Suspension for Misconduct
description: City marshals accused of misconduct will face disciplinary hearings by the city's Investigation Department and if convicted can be suspended for up to six months, under an order yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: Byrne Victory Seen In Leadership Fight With Party's Chief
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10Governor Byrne won a crucial political victory today, with the struggle for control of the Democratic majority leadership of the State Senate apparently resolved in his favor.

title: Center Stage Is Reborn in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 10On Jan. 10, 1974, Center Stage, Baltimore's resident theater, burned down. Last night the company opened the doors of its new $1.7 million theater with a production of Tartuffe. The rebirth of Center Stage in downtown Baltimore is a major artistic event for Marylandand also for the American theater. It shows what community enterprisecan do to revitalize the inner city, how art can collaborate with urban renewal.

title: HEINZ ENTERS RACE FOR SEAT IN SENATE
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (UPI) Representative H. John Heinz 3d, heir to the H. J. Heinz food fortune, today entered what he said would be a spirited race for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat held by Hugh Scott, who is retiring.

title: FMC CORP. TO RAISE CELLOPHANE PRICES
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday that its film and packaging division was raising prices of cellophane packaging films about 8 percent on average, effective Jan. 19. The increases are up to 13 cents a pound depending on the cellophane type and yield.

title: The Press And Trials
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10There is no grander sight in the land than the American press on a white horse riding into metaphorical battle for its own freedom. It takes a skeptic of the old school, a Mark Twain or Mr. Dooley, to do justice to the pomp of such occasions.

title: Chess:
description: No concept in the strategy of the game has increased in value as much as that of the initiative in recent years. Now it is no longer necessary to delve into the question of exactly what the result of pressing a slight initiative should beit is entirely sufficient to recognize that the capacity to originate operations is an advantage in itself.

title: Alleged Bribes Cited in TV License Figh??
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10A challenger for the television license of the R.K.O. General station in Boston asked the Federal Communications Commission today to deny R.K.O. General Inc. its license renewal because of bribes the company has allegedly paid overseas.

title: FORD URGES INQUIRY ON JET NEARMISSES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  President Ford directed Transportation Secretary William Coleman today to look into the circumstances of recent incidents involving near collisions of jet aircraft.

title: India's Editors Ask Regime to Review New Press Curbs
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 10Indian editors, in what some of them fear might be one of the last battles they will be permitted to fight against the Government, today criticized the sweeping new federal controls imposed earlier this week on the country's newspapers.

title: Personal Finance: Tax Services Curbed
description: Getting ready to file his income tax returns earlier this year, a taxpayer was attracted by a sign in a storefront office that said instant tax refunds. He hired the the owner of the office to prepare his returns and received his instant refund. But he did not realize that the money received was actually an interest  bearing loan to be repaid with the refunds from the taxing authorities.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
U.S. Bars Paiis Exhibit and Causes a Stir
description: PARIS, Dec. 10An exhibit prepared by a prestigious French cultural organization has been removed from the American Cultural Center in Paris because it contained objectionable political materials, according to United States officials.

title: City's Marshals Now Face Suspension for Misconduct
description: City marshals accused of misconduct will face disciplinary hearings by the city's Investigation Department and if convicted can be suspended for up to six months, under an order yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: F.B.I. Holds Convict Who Offered Tip on Hoffal
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10Clarence N. Medlin, an escaped convict who disappeared last Friday in Florida, reportedly with $9,000 paid by CBS News for information he stated he had on the location of the body of James R. Hoffa, was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here today.

title: Filth in the Streets
description: New York City, freshly delivered from the instant threat of fiscal collapse, now finds itself sinking under vast piles of uncollected garbage. The strike of private sanitation crews is creating intolerable health and fire hazards, and peace efforts by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, have brought no hope for early settlement.

title: Phils Obtain Kaat In 5Player Trade
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 10Within minutes of acquiring control of the Chicago White Sox, Bill Veeck approved a fiveplayer, trade that sent Jim Kaat, one of baseball's most distinguished lefthanded pitchers, to the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: GARBAGE PILES UP IN CARTING STRIKE
description: Reeking, leaking, rotting, rainsoaked garbage heaped high yesterday in crowded commercial sections of New York Citythe worst of it in Manhattanas the strike by private cartmen stretched through its 10th day.

title: Fairleigh Campus Sale
description: RUTHERFORD, Dec. 10 (UPI) The Fairleigh Dickinson University board of trustees approved a proposal today to try to sell the University's Wayne campus in order to close a $2 million deficit. The trustees approved the plan despite a warning by the university president, Jerome Pollak. He said that the university may not be able to end a 20year contract involving the purchase of the 34acre campus.

title: Books of The Times
description: At first glance, Walter Kerr's The Silent Clowns impressed me as a perfect candidate for the annual giftbook roundup. Oversized format, with many pages designed to suggest the subtitle frames of an old movie. Loads of striking illustrations from the films of the silent era, famous and obscure. Some text, yesbut surely not very much: After all, it is a book about visual imagessome of the most succinct visual images that civilization has ever produced and we all know what happens when even the most articulate begin writing about the visual. Then I began browsing in The Silent Clowns, and before I knew it I was reading. Most curious:I was readthat the silents did not precede the talkies for reasons of technology. No, sound (and color, too) was available much earlier than is commonly assumed; the choice of silence (in black and white) was a deliberate one made for complex esthetic reasons.

title: Christmas Often Too Spirited for Pups
description: No, Virginia, Christmas is not the time to have Santa Claus leave a puppy under the tree. It would be much better to have a dog collar there and pick up the pup a few days later. For a puppy, or even an older dog, Christmas can be a day of too many strange people and too much excitement. As far as the tree is concerned, be careful a pet doesn't chew on any of the decorations or eat any of the pine needles that fall.

title: Holleran Team Advances
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10Romer Holleran and William Shettle defeated two fellow Philadelphians, John Mirkil and Dick Boenning, 84, 84, in gaining the semifinal round of the United States open court tennis doubles championship today at the Racquet Club.

title: Paranoia and Policy
description: LOCARNOMURALTO, SwitzerlandIf someone will not touch a doorknob because he might catch a dangerous bacillus, we call this person neurotic or his behavior irrational. But we cannot tell him that what he fears is not possible. Even fullfledged paranoia demonstrates that one can be insane and yet that one's capacity for purely logical thinking is not impaired.

title: Business Briefs
description: GENEVA, Dec. 10 (Reuters)The European Economic Community and the United States appear to have broken a protracted procedural deadlock over agriculture that has held up talks to liberalize world commerce, Common Market sources said today.

title: Grandmother and Child Rate Christmas Window: 4 Hollies to 1
description: Little Red Riding Rood and Goldilocks are playing at Altman's, a band of fairies are furling and unfurling butterfly wings at Lord & Taylor and there's flower ballet at Saks Fifth Avenue. The best free bhows in townthe Christmas windows of department stores and other shopsare playing to packed sidewalks on Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S. Ski Team Needs Windfall Of HalfMillion for Busy Winter
description: With the 1976 Winter Olympics less than two months away and with the American Alpine team campaigning in Europe, the crosscountry squad training in Wisconsin and the jumping team tuning up in Canada, the United States Ski Educational Foundation yesterday reported a need for more financial assistance.

title: Cleric Loses Church Case Over Ordination of Women
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) An ecclesiastical appeals court today affirmed that the Rev. William A. Wendt, an Episcopal priest, hen disobeyed his bishop by allowing an irregularly ordained woman priest to celebrate holy communion in his church here.

title: Hearing on Tax Aid Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) A House Government Operations subcommittee has scheduled a hearing next Monday to look into the Internal Revenue Service's taxpayer assistance program, Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, announced today. The panel will also examine the I.R.S.'s efforts to prevent abuses by commercial tax preparers.

title: Byrne Gets Final Report On CarterArtis Appeal
description: Assemblyman Eldridge Hawkins, a Democrat of Essex County, turned over a final report on his investigation of the CarterArtis triplemurder conviction in New Jersey to Governor Byrne yesterday.

title: Buck Rally Fails; Celtics Win, 11198
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP)Glenn McDonald singlehandedly stopped a Milwaukee comeback early in the fourth period and the Boston Celtics then routed the Bucks, 11198, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Carting Trade Has History of StrongArm Tactics
description: The private carting industry, caught up in a strike that has left the city littered with garbage and rubbish, is composed of about 450 companies, most of them, small and many of them familyowned.

title: Ross M. Newhouse Dead; Vice President of Galleries
description: Ross M. Newhouse, vice president and secretary of the Newhouse Galleries, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 1165 Park Avenue.

title: VIOLENCE FLARES Al BOSTON SCHOOL
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10Racially tense South Boston High School began its first day under court supervision with fist fights today, and a fire bomb was thrown into the office of a black civil rights group.

title: Giscard in Egypt for Arms and Economic Talks
description: CAIRO, Dec. 10President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France arrived here today for a fiveday state visit that is expected to pave the way for French arms sales to Egypt and for participation of French industries in Egyptian development plans.

title: Big '75 Grain Harvest Is Indicated for China
description: PEKING, Dec. 10 (Reuters) A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed today that last year's grain harvest was 274.9 million metric tons.

title: Swiss Back Jet Jurchase
description: BERNE. Dec. 10 (AP)The upper house of the Swiss Parliament voted 34 to 0 yesterday to approve the proposed purchase by the Swiss armed forces of 72 Americanbuilt Tiger II5E jet fighter planes for about $450 million. The house was told that an investigation had disclosed no evidence of impropriety in connection with the projected purchase from Northrop Corporation.

title: Swiss Back Jet Purchase
description: BERNE, Dec. 10 (AP)The upper house of the Swiss Parliament voted 34 to 0 yesterday to approve the proposed purchase by the Swiss armed forces of 72 Americanbuilt Tiger II5E jet fighter planes for about $450 million. The house was told that an investigation had disclosed no evidence of impropriety in connection with the projected purchase from the Northrop Corporation.

title: Housing Agency Assailed As a Chief Slumlord of U.S.
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 10The front door of the modest blue frame house at 532 North Leamington on the Northwest Side was open. The cheap metal eye hooks that once held a padlock had long before been pried from the soft wood.

title: Death of an Infant is Laid to Slowdouin By British Doctors
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP)The father of a 5Monthold girl who died after being refused admission to two hospitals acAaused British hospital doctors today of playing God with human lives by conducting their work slowdown.

title: Concert: Queler Opera
description: Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York usually devote themselves to resuscitations of complete fulllength operas in their Carnegie Hall concerts, but on Tuesday night they presented a mixed bag of shorter works and excerpts.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS EXTENSION OF CUT IN INDIVIDUAL TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate Finance Committee, with the concurrence of more than half its Republican, members, voted today to keep present rates for individual income tax withholding in effect through the first half of next year.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Gets Post in Congress Party
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 10 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's younger son, Sanjay joined the hierarchy of the ruling Congress Party today, marking his formal entry into politics.

title: European Football
description: U.E.F.A, CUP

title: Opera
description: There was very little going on at Tuesday night's performance of Un Ballo in Mischera that would have forced the conclusion that one was at the Metropolitan Opera or any other firstrank house. Entirely respectable but certifiably minor singers filled most of the important roles, the chief exception being Sherrill Milnes, singing his first Renato of the season.

title: Key Word In Lisbon: Discipline
description: LISBON, Dec. 10  The revolutionary songs and slogans are gone. Nostalgic songs and bright folk music now occupy the Portuguese airwaves.

title: Deficit Cited in Call For Blue Cross Rise
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)Blue Cross of New Jersey has a $13 million deficit and needs an increase in its premium rates, an official of the State Insurance Department said yesterday.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Dec. 10. 7975

title: Demoted Chief of C.A.B. Quits Agency at White House Request
description: Robert D. Timm, demoted a year ago by President Ford from his chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board, and to date merely a board member, resigned from the agency yesterday at the request of the White House.

title: TOT BANKERS SAY STATE MUST RAISE ITS TAXES AT ONCE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 10  Hours after the Republican legislative leaders publicly rejected Governor Carey's call for new taxes and immediate action to close the state's budget gap, a group of top New York City bankers, said today that immediate tax increases were essential to allow the state and its agencies to get back into the credit market.

title: Palestinian at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10  When the Palestine Liberation Organization was invited for the first time the other day to participate in the Security Council. Basel Amin Aql moved to a seat at the conference table dressed in a blue blazer and beige slacks.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Moslem gunmen continued to battle with Christians for control of Beirut despite clashes with Lebanese troops in the hotel and commercial district. The mission of the troops was to separate the factions. Several luxury hotels were set afire and the St. Georges Hotel was burned out. Police sources set the twoday death toll at 235. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: CORRECTION
description: The names of John Edward Holownia and Bruce Howard Belsky were inadvertently left off the list, published in The New York Times Friday, of those passing the bar examination. A third listing in the Second Department should have read Susan Carol Levine.

title: VIOLENCE FLARES AT BOSTON SCHOOL
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10Racially tense South Boston High School began its first day under court supervision with fist fights today, and a fire bomb was thrown into the office of a black civil rights group.

title: The Center of Attraction Is a Tradition at Power
description: Reminders of Power Memorial's tradition of big men appear throughout the basketball scene. The No. 1 reminder is Kareem AbdulJabbar, the Los Angeles Laker center who was known as Lew Alcindor when he starred at the Manhattan School a decade ago. Other more recent graduates include Len Elmore, center for the Indiana Pacers, and Bob Misevicius, Providence Colloge's big men. There Is a new face at the gymnasium on West 61st Street. His name is Larry Petty and he seems set to on the tradition.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: House Votes to Widen Absentee Ballot Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)The House voted 374 to 43 today to extend the Tight to vote by absentee ballot in Federal elections to all eligible United States citizens residing abroad.

title: Besieged Gunmen In London Refuse Food, Cut Phone
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (Reuters) Three Irish Republican Army guerrillas who have held a couple in a central London apartment since Saturday refused today to accept a supply of food only lours after they had severed their telephone link with the police.

title: William A. Wellman Dies; Directed Movie Classics
description: William A. Wellman, the nearly legendary Hollywood director who made 82 movies, including Wings, Beau Geste, the original A Star Is Born, Public Enemy and the classic antilynching film, The OxBow Incident, died of leukemia late Tuesday in his Los Angeles home. He was 79 years old.

title: Indonesia Suspends DutchTrade Talks; Strife Held Cause
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 10 (AP)Indonesia has suspended trade talks with the Netherlands, apparently because the Dutch Government has been unable to end the occupation of the Indonesian Consulate in Amsterdam by South Moluccan nationalists, the Dutch Economics Ministry announced today.

title: Veeck Gets Approval As White Sox Owner
description: HOLLYWOOD, Pa., Dec, 10Bill Veeck, who once sent a midget to bat as a pinchhitter, was readmitted to baseball tonight with new cash and the old flair as the owner of the Chicago White Sox.

title: House Committee Drops Charge Against Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The House Select Committee on Intelligence today withdrew its recommendation that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger be held in contempt of Congress for failing to provide the committee with subpoenaed documents.

title: Sacramento Dropping Soliah Bank Robbery Case
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 10The Sacramento County district attorney. John Price, said today that he would not prosecute Steven F. Soliah in connection with a bank robbery in which a woman customer was shot to death. Mr. Soliah was one of Patricia Hearst's companions when she was a fugitive.

title: TOP BANKERS SAY STATE MUST RAISE ITS TAXES AT ONCE
description: ALBANY,. Dec. 10  Hours after the Republican legislative leaders publicly rejected Governor Carey's call for new taxes and immediate action to close the state's budget gap, a group of top New York City bankers said today that immediate tax increases Were essential to allow the state and its agencies to get back into the credit market.

title: MARKET MOVES UP; DOW GAINS BY 9.84
description: The stock market posted a clear advance yesterday in moderate trading activity. For the first time in December the list showed more advances than declines, and the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed with its best gain in a montha rise of 9.84 points.

title: About the Giants
description: The Giants placed John Mendenhall on injured reserve yesterday to make room for David Simonson, a tackle they signed to beef up the offensive line. Mendenhall had been bothered by a sore ankle since the season opener. . . . Simonson, 66 and 248, was a 12thround draft choice by the Baltimore Colts last season and played 13 games. He was one of the Colts' last four cuts this year. . . . John Hicks, who has a sprained ankle, didn't work out and remains questionable for Sunday's game.

title: New Chief Is Chosen
description: The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it would nominate John F. Bookout for president and chief executive officer to replace Harry Bridges, who will retire upon reaching the mandatory retirement age of 60. The change in command will take place May 1, 1976. Mr. Bookout, who is 53 years old, is now executive vice preIsident in charge of exploration and production and a director of the company, which is an affiliate of the Royal Dtuch/ Shell Group. From 1970 to 1974 Mr. Brookout was president of Shell Canada. Shell also announced other top management changes. Charles L. Blackburn, vice president for Shell's transportation and supplies organization, will succeed Mr. Bookout as executive vice president for exploration and production. He has also been elected a director.

title: Retail Sales in Month Up More Than $500 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Commerce Department reported today that retail sales rose by more than $500 million in November, and sales for both September and October have been revised upward, indicating a distinctly stronger tone for consumer spending than had been conveyed by earlier estimates for those months.

title: Brother's Appointment Fails to Split Boston Family
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10 AP)Joseph M. McDonough, an educator, was listening to the radio when he learned that a Federal judge had put him in daytoday charge of South Boston High School.

title: Carey's Proposal for Lottery Would Put It Under Tax Unit
description: ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP)Governor Carey today sent the Legislature a bill to revamp the suspended state lottery, but which would leave details on how to run the game up to bureaucrats.

title: Cruiser Out of Commission
description: NORFOLK, Va. (AP)  The Navy said yesterday that the cruiser Belknap, damaged Nov. 22 in a collision with the carrier John F. Kennedy, would be taken out of commission temporarily and towed to Philadelphia for repairs. A Navy spokesman said that most of the Belknap's 350man crew would be reassigned to other ships.

title: F.B.I. Chief Asks Accounting in Harassment of King
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation, said today that those bureau policymakers respon sible for the harassment of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. should be brought to account.

title: TROOPS IN BEIRUT BATTLING GUNMEN; BIG HOTELS BURNED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Dec. 11  Lebanese troops clashed with gunmen in Beirut hotel and commercial districts yesterday on the second day of their officially announced mission of separating warring Christian and Moslem factions.

title: Misinformation?
description: The campaigns of misinformation, of slander against Socialist countries, all sorts of pinpricks intended to cause a reply reaction and poison the situationall this, of course, by no means accords with the spirit of the decisions adopted at the [Helsinki] European conference.

title: CHARLES R. BEDDOWS JR.
description: Charles R. Beddows Jr., first vice president in charge of the commodities lending group of the Bankers Trust Company, died yesterday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 4 Folkstone Drive, Westfield, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEAT CROP IS UP BY 19% TO RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) America's 1975 wheat crop was up 19 percent from last year's harvest to a record 2.13 billion bushels and was worth $7.4 billion to farmers, also a record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Israel Worried by Election of Arab Red in Nazareth
description: JERUSALEM. Dec. 10The landslide election yesterday of an outspoken Arab nationalist as Mayor of Nazareth was regarded here today as the most conspicuous display of Palestinian nationalist sentiment among the Arabs of Israel since the founding of the nation.

title: Parseghian Nears a Decision; Gap With Jets Is Narrowing
description: In four more days, Ara Parseghian will start to think of his return to football. A key question in his mind is whether he can stand the pressures of coaching the New York Jets after he walked away from the pressures of coaching Notre Dame.

title: Herman M. Schulman, 64, Mallinckrodt Executive, Dies
description: Herman M. Schulman, assistant to the board vice chairman of Mallinckrodt Inc., chemical manufacturer, and former president and owner of the Washine Chemical Corporation, now a division of Mallinckrodt, died Monday at his home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived also in Hackensack, N. J.

title: A.T.&T. Planning $500 Million Increase In Construction Expenditures for 1976
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which supplies 80 percent of the nation's telephone services, plans to increase construction expenditures by $500 million next year, to $10 billion, John D. deButts, chairman of the company, said here yesterday. Despite the rise, Mr. deButts said, an increase in internally generated funds will probably enable the company to seek no more new capital next year beyond the $2.9 billion sought this year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1975

title: Sales of California Offshore Oil Leases Start Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10The Federal Government will begin the first sale of leases tomorrow in its controversial accel??ted development of oil resources on the outer continental shelf.

title: Diabetes Rated 3d Killer; U.S. Panel Calls for Help
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Diabetes has become the nation's thirdranking cause of death, is increasing rapidly and should be given broadened and enlarged attention through research and other programs, a national commission reported to the Congress today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: S.E.C. and Gulf Seek 3d Delay On Filing PoliticalFund Report
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10The Securities and Exchange Commission and an investigatory committee of the Gulf Oil Corporation have asked the Federal Court in Washington for a third extension on the filing of a report that is to detail how the company's $10.3 million political slush fund came into being and what happened to the money.

title: MOYNIHANACCUSED IN U.N.ON ANGOLA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10The Soviet Union and Cuba replied to American criticism of their military activities in Angola today with strong personal attacks on Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief American delegate, but the debate in the General Assembly ended in a tactical defeat of sorts for the Russians and their allies.

title: Yule Log Ceremony at Douglass College Joyfully Welcomes Winter Holiday Season
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 10 The winter holiday season was welcomed here joyously this evening with the sound of organ music and female voices singing Christmas carols as a young woman dressed entirely in white kindled friendship and peace logs as part of the 57th annual celebration of the yule log ceremony.

title: Jeff Heath, ExOutfielder With Cleveland, 59, Dies
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 10 (AP)Jeff Heath, a former outfielder who compiled a .293 career batting average in 13 years in the major leagues, died at his home yesterday of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: Advertising
description: The Glass Containers Manufacturing Institute, Washington, announced yesterday it was giving its advertising account to DancerFitzgeraldSample. That makes two new, clients this week for the agency, which is having a hot 1975. The hottest part was winning the $30million Toyota account earlier this fall.

title: CLARA KENT PEARCE
description: Clara Kent Pearce, daughter of Rockwell Kent, the artist, died Monday at her home in IrvingtononHudson, N.Y. She was 62 years old.

title: William Wellman Dies
description: William A. Wellman, director of 82 movies, includsuch classics as Wings, Beau Geste, Public Enemy and the original version of A Star Is Born, died. Page 48.

title: STRIKERS IN SPAIN PUSH FOR REFORMS
description: MADRID, Dec. 10 (UPI)Thousands of workers walked off their jobs and students boycotted classes today in strikes called by underground leftwing organizations demanding political reform.

title: Songbirds Learn to Sing by Studying Their Elders
description: The meadowlark's lyric song, the plaintive whistle of the whitecrowned sparrow and the ringing call of the veery, like the sounds of many other songbirds, were probably learned at an early age by the birds as they began to imitate their elders.

title: Witnesses Assail Insurance Plan Covering Catastrophic Illnesses
description: A catastrophic illness health insurance plan being proposed by the State Standing Committee on Health was roundly denounced by most witnesses testifying yesterday at a public hearing to get public opinion on the proposed plan.

title: Washington Post Is Hiring Nonunion Pressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) The Washington Post said today that it was recruiting temporary nonunion pressmen and would begin hiring permanent replacements for striking pressmen by Sunday night unless management's latest contract offer was accepted

title: Byrne Gets Key Report On Carter
description: Assemblyman Eldridge Hawkins, a Democrat of Essex County, turned over a final report on his investigation of the CarterArtis triplemurder conviction in New Jersey to Governor Byrne yesterday.

title: Driver's. Trot Ban: End Seen
description: Ben Webster's attorney said yesterday he wouldn't be surprised to see his client back driving next week when Roosevelt Raceway opens its 69night winter meeting. I am expecting action by management within a very short space of time, said the attorney, Jacob P. Lefkowitz. Investigations can't go on endlessly, and lead nowhere. That would be an abuse of management's business  judgment discretion.

title: ENERGYLOAN FOES WIN ON HOUSE RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10A coalition of House liberals and conservatives scored an interim victory today in an effort to keep Congress from authorizing $6 billion of Federal guarantees of loans to finance commercial energy projects.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state announced that the Little Nursing Home Montclair had been ordered to close because it had failed to correct serious deficiencies. The Department of Health said the facility had been told to transfer its patients to a licensed nursing home as of next Jan. 4, when its license will be revoked. Health inspectors reported finding nine serious deficiencies at the Little Nursing Home Nov. 13 Among them were failure to provide roundtheclock nursing service, unavailability of a registered nurse seven days a week, and failure to have licensed nurses to administer all medications. The state also warned the Clover Rest Nursing home of Montclair and Wiersa's Nursing Home of Allendale that their license had been reduced to provisional status because of deficiencies and that they had 90 days to correct the problems.

title: U.S.Soviet Pact Seen On Grain Rates and Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)The State Department said today that it expected to reach agreement soon with the Soviet Union on freight rates for American grain shipments to the Soviet Union and on importing cheap Soviet oil into the United States.

title: Negotiations Broken Off In United Airlines Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) Negotiations have broken off indefinitely between United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, and representatives of a striking machinist union, the National Mediation Board said today.

title: Wider Worker Role Set In Germany's Industries
description: BONN, Dec. 10 (AP)West Germany's two Government parties have agreed on a new version of a bill to give the workers up to half the seats on the boards of directors of West Germany's 650 biggest companies.

title: REFORM DEFENDED BY EXARMY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Howard H. Callaway testified, today that as Secretary of the Army he had reformed rather than abused the military promotion system, as charged by dismissed career officers seeking reinstatement.

title: Some Art Is Art, and Some Not
description: NEWARK, Dec. 10An assortment of objectsart and otherwisewere taken to the Newark Museum today, borne by apprehensive owners in boxes, tissue paper and shopping bags.

title: People and Business
description: Donald C. Platten, chairman of the Chemical Bank, the nation's seventh largest, said yesterday that New York City's financial crisis would not damage the United States banking system.

title: Singer Near Decision
description: Directors of the Singer Company will meet today amid reports that the new management intends to get rid of its business machines division. Page 77.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice Sidney H. Asch of State Supreme Court dismissed nine damage suits totaling more than $1 million brought by neighbors against Mr. and Mrs. James Wilkerson, owners of the house at 18 West 11th Street that was destroyed by a bomb explosion on Feb. 23. 1970. The house reportedly, had been occupied by members of the radical underground Weathermen's group.

title: Zoners Ban Massage Parlors in Times Square
description: In an effort to force socalled massage parlors out of the Times Square area, the City Planning Commission unanimously approved a zoning amendment yesterday that would require physical culture or health establishments to be either in hotels having more than 200 rooms or in community facilities.

title: William Wellman Dies
description: William A. Wellman, director of 82 movies including such classics as Wings, Beau Geste, Public Enemy and the original version of A Star Is Born, died. Page 48.

title: NATO GROUP COOL TO KISSINGER PLAN
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 10Western defense ministers ended a twoday meeting here today on a note that appeared to presage difficulties for a key proposal of Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Loch Ness Monster Is Given Credential Of Scientific Name
description: LONDON, Dec. 10Undeterred by cynics and scoffers, the men who believe in the Loch Ness monster stood foursquare in its cause today.

title: Returns as Chairman
description: Benjamin Bartel, an attorney who briefly had been chairman of Alexander's Inc. several years ago, was elected again to that post after the company's annual meeting yesterday in Edison Township, N.J. Mr. Bartel, who is 59 years old, continues as senior partner of Bartel, Engelman & Fishman, a New York law firm.

title: Wisconsin Rejects Proposal To Change Primary's Date
description: MADISON, Wis., Dec. 10The state Assembly, disregarding warnings that Wisconsin's Presidential primary election next April 6 would be overshadowed by a primary in New York the same day, has killed a bill that would have moved the Wisconsin date forward a week, from April 6 to March 30.

title: Xerox to Sponsor Esquire Article
description: The Xerox Corporation, whose sponsorship has resulted in some fine moments on television, is extending the sponsorship concept to print.

title: State Welfare Cuts Appear Likely As G.O.P. Accepts Carey's Proposal
description: ALBANY, Doc. 10The possibility of state welfare cute became all but certain today as the. Legislature's Republican leadership accepted Governor Carey's proposed $140 million goal, but indicated that it preferred to cut the grant levels to the poor more than he had proposed.

title: Squires' Players Reject a Pay Deferment, Agree to Cut Costs
description: The Virginia Squires have appealed to their players in an effort to prevent the team from becoming the fourth American Basketball Association franchise to go out of business in less than two months.

title: MSGR. THOMAS F. KANE
description: Msgr. Thomas F. Kane, pastor of St. Sylvia's Roman Catholic Church in Tivoli, N. Y., died Sunday evening of cancer in his rectory. He was 71 years old.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: CHANGES NARROW IN SOYBEAN PRICES
description: Grain and soybean prices held relatively steady yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Sir John WheelerBennett Dies; Historian and Diplomacy Expert
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP)Sir John WheelerBennett, historian and an authority on international affairs, died yesterday at St. Thomas's hospital here. He was 73 years old.

title: Hubert vs. Rocky?
description: WASHINGTONBy all the odds, Nelson A. Rockefeller and Hubert H. Humphrey should be looked upon as a pair of Harold Stassens, showing up at conventions and an occasional fundraising event, deferred to out of respect for age and an ability to cheat absolute political death. They should be a couple of John Waynes playing longservice colonels in some pesthouse of a Southwestern cavalry post.

title: Kevin Porter Out For Five Weeks
description: Kevin Porter of the Detroit Pistons, the National Basketball Association's assist leader, is not expected to be sidelined for the season, contrary to the announcement after his knee injury Tuesday night in the game against the Golden State Warriors.

title: Byrne Offers State Help In Teaneck Murder Cases
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 10 Governor Byrne interceded today in the investigation into the murders of five members of the family of Wesley R. Diggs of Teaneck, which he said had shocked all New Jerseyans.

title: Remote Electronic Services of 2 Illinois Banks Are Ruled Illegal
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (UPI)United States District Court Judge Hubert L. Will ruled today that certain types of remote electronic banking facilities constitute bank branches and are in violation of Illinois law.

title: Marriage Classes A re Ordered For Catholic Weddings in State
description: NEWARK, Dec. 10 (AP)Beginning Jan. 1, couples who wish to have Roman Catholic marriage services in New Jersey will be required to attend classes on the physical, emotional and religious aspects of marriage.

title: Unfunny Gags
description: WASHINGTONWhen the individual defendant's right to a trial before unprejudiced jurors comes into conflict with the press's right to report the news, which right should prevail?

title: TV: Rona Barrett Interviews Four Dream Actors
description: With the departure of Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons from the Hollywood factory years ago, analysts of pop culture soberly concluded that the age of the gossip columnist was dead, victim of the new Age of Candor in which there were no secrets left for breathless publication. In fact, the gossip business has fallen on lean times. But then there is Rona Barrett, the poorlittleplaingirl from New York who, with the admitted help of cosmetics and endless probing, has become the glittering blond chronicler of international celebrity antics. Miss Rona, as she prefers to be called, has survived.

title: U.S. Drug Agent Arrested
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP)A Federal drug agent has been arrested and charged with attempting to distribute narcotics. Sherman A. Lucas 3d, a 33yearold former Philadelphia homicide detective, was taken into custody here yesterday on a warrant from Arizona. Federal authorities said he tried to purchase an ounce of heroin from a confidential informant in Arizona for $800 to sell for a profit.

title: 33 Hurt in Washington Blast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) At least 33 persons were injured this morning by an explosion in the basement of a downtown Washington office building in its final stages of construction. Two men had been working on an electric panel when it exploded, investigators said. The workmen, Curtis Trimmer and John Rucker, were in critical condition at George Washington University Medical Center. Officials said most of the others had suffered the effects of smoke inhalation.

title: Cypriots Denounce Ford For Optimism on Accord
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 10 (AP)The Cyprus Government said today that President Ford's report to Congress that there's had been progress toward a Cyprus settlement is rather optimistic and we do not think it corresponds to reality.

title: House Committee Drops Charge Against Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The House Select Committee on Intelligence today withdrew its recommendation that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger be held in contempt of Congress for failing to provide the committee with subpoenaed documents.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Board in Canada Says Postal Accord Violated Wage Curb
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 10 (Reuters) The AntiInflation Board of Canada has ruled that a proposed contract that ended a sixweek national postal strike last week violated the Government's wage and price control program, official sources said today.

title: NATHAN BIRNBAUM, C.C.N.Y. PROFESSOR
description: Nathan Birnbaum, professor emeritus of chemistry at City College, died Tuesday at Colorado General Hospital in Denver. He was 68 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N. J.

title: State of the State
description: The state of the State of New York may not be quite so bad as that of New York Cityyet. But it could quickly become worse if members of the Legislature, particularly the Republican leadership, continue to treat Albany's interrelated deficit and credit crises in the cavalier manner with which they have received Governor Carey's emergency fiscal proposals.

title: Good Samaritan Dies After Chasing Mugger
description: A 66yearold man who bolted from his car on a residential street in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn to chase a mugger, collapsed and died of a heart attack yesterday after running after the assailant.

title: Sabres, Rangers Play Tie
description: Effort returned to Madison Square Garden ice last night, and with it exciting twoway hockey that drew a standing ovation from an appreciative audience. However, justice did not triumph for the Rangers, who had to be content with a 22 tie with the Buffalo Sabres. their second deadlock in the last two National Hockey League meetings.

title: Study Finds City Will Continue to Lose Office Jobs as Conditions Deteriorate
description: Conditions for businesses that operate offices in New York will continue to deteriorate in the next 10 years and this will force more corrorate headquarters and more office jobs out of the city, according to a new study published yesterday by a leading firm of relocation consultants.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday.

title: Annual Christmas Party Held by Cardinal Cooke
description: Performers in the musical Godspell ran shouting past 4yearold Harry to the stage at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, but Harry, who lives at the New York Foundling Hospital, never took his eyes off the large red plastic truck he held in his lap.

title: WEALTHTAX PLAN SLOWED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Dec. 10A proposed tax on personal wealth, an important ideological goal of Britain's governing Labor Party, ran into trouble today.

title: Rabin Threatens to Step Down But Aides Say It Is a Marieuver.
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 10Prime minister Yitzhak Rabin threatened at a party caucus here, last night to resign in a move described by his aides today, as more of a challenge to his critics to come up with alternative proposals than a serious intention to give up his office.

title: SAKHAROV IN VIGIL AT FRIEND'S TRIAL
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10As his Nobel Peace Prize was being presented today in Oslo, Andrei D. Sakharov was standing outside a courtroom in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, trying vainly to attend the trial of his good friend and fellow dissident, Sergei A. Kovalev.

title: F. T. C. AFFIRMS AIRCO DIVESTMENT
description: A decision by the Federal, Trade Commission yesterday that the acquisition of 35 percent of Airco Inc. of Montvale N.J., by British Oxygen Compang of London would stifle competition here for helium, nitrogen, carbon dioxide and other industrial gases brought an immediate protest from British Oxygen.

title: Carey and Burns Meet On H.F.A. Fiscal Crisis
description: ALBANY, Dec. 10Governor Carey journeyed to Washington today to confer with Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, but came away no closer to a solution that would avert a default of the State Housing Finance Agency on Monday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Russel A. Plimpton, Headed Minneapolis Institute of Art
description: Russel A. Plimpton, former director of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, died Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: LongTime Friends Donate to Neediest
description: Longtime supporters of the New York Times Neediest ?? Fund were among the 46 contributors who yesterday made gifts to the 64th annual appeal.

title: 3 HELD IN ABDUCTION OF DETROIT BANKER
description: DETROIT, Dec. 10 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the arrests today of two men on charges stemming from the abduction six days ago or Tames J. Crawford, an assistant bank manager in Detroit. Police sources said a third man also was detained.

title: FATHER BORGSTEDT
description: The Very Rev. Gregork Borgstedt, a member of the Order of St. Benedict, died Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Elmira, N. Y. He was 67 years old and lived in the Benedictine Monastery of St. Saviour at nearby Pine City.

title: Curbs on Use of Mailing Lists Debated Before Privacy Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Richard A. Viguerie, who directs George C. Wallace's direct  mail fundraising campaign, told the Privacy Protection, Study Commission today that any restriction on the use of mailing lists would restrict free speech and severely hamper fund raising for causes and candidates of all persuasions.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Indianapolis Power and Light Company filed yesterday, with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 2 million common, shares. The offering, expected early next month, will be made through underwriters headed by Lehman Brothers; Merril Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and Salomon Brothers.

title: Indians Hire Colavito
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP)Rocky Colavito will return to the Cleveland Indians as batting coach, the club said today. The slugger retired as a player after the 1968 season.

title: 1975 Fund Surplus Lower for OPEC
description: The nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will have accumulated surplus funds of about $40 billion by the end of this year, compared with a total of about $60 billion in 1974, Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald L. Parsky, said yesterday.

title: GARBAGE PILES UP IN CARTING STRIKE
description: Reeking, leaking, rotting, rainsoaked garbage heaped high yesterday in crowded commercial sections of New York. Citythe worst of it in Manhattanas the strike by private cartmen stretched through its 10th day.

title: The Sakharov Statement
description: OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 (AP)Following, in translation, is the text of Andrei D. Sakharov's statement today accepting the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize, as read in his absence by his wife, Yelena Bonner:

title: FRANCIS V. M'GAW
description: Francis V. McGaw, an executive with Select Magazines here, since 1957, died Monday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 20 Church Street, Greenwich.

title: Prisoners at Rikers Find Deep Basis for Disorders
description: The disorder on Rikers Island last month was caused by excessive bail, inadequate legal representation and months of administrative delays in the court system, several prisoners said at an informal meeting on the island yesterday.

title: Doll Shove Opens at World Trade Center
description: The Enchanted World of Dolls, a Christmas display of more than 200 dolls, doll houses and miniature rooms from 50 countries, opened at the World Trade Center yesterday.

title: PRICE LIMIT ADDED TO RAILHELP BILL
description: The House Commerce Committee set the stage yesterday for a possible compromise with the Ford Administration on a sweeping bill to reorganize the seven bankrupt Northeast railroads and aid other troubled carriers around the nation.

title: The Lenox Quartet Inaugurates Series At Kaufmann Hall
description: When the newly refurbished Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. opened unofficially last Saturday night, its acoustical baffles and screens hadn't yet been installed. Tuesday night they were in place, if not yet with the masking that will eventually screen the lighting's inner workings.

title: Senate Votes Loan Funds And New Bankruptcy Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate, in pro forma actions today, appropriated $2.3 billion in funds for seasonal loans to avert a New York City default and approved a revised Municipal Bankruptcy Law to ease the city's ability to petition for bankruptcy.

title: U.S. Steel Expects No '76 Spending Cuts but Foresees Rise in Prices
description: The United States Steel Corporation does not at this time expect to cut back its projected 1976 capital spending of about $1 billion, Edgar B. Speer, chairman, said yesterday at the company's annual press luncheon here.

title: Rights Unit Asks More Housing for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The United States Commission on Civil Rights criticized the Federal Government today, for not building housing for poor and moderateincome families, and asked for a new effort to build] at least 600,000 units of such housing yearly between now and 1978.

title: Son of U.S. Ambassador Held In Britain in Cocaine case
description: FOLKESTONE, England Dec. 10 (AP)The 24yearold son of the United States Ambassador to Mexico is being held without bail on a charge of attempting to import almost three pounds of cocaine into Britain.

title: REALESTATE LOBBY HELPED 100 IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Common Cause said today that 100 members of the House who voted on the side of the realestate industry on a recent tax bill amendment received a total of $100,000 from the industry's political arm last year.

title: News Publisher Honored
description: W. H. James, president and publisher of The Daily News, was given the First Amendment Freedom Award by the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith at a dinner in his honor last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Mr. James was honored for his commitment to freedom of the press and other constitutional rights.

title: ALVIN ROSS, ARTIST AND EDUCATOR, 65
description: Alvin Ross, a painter and educator, died Tuesday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 55 years old and lived in Provincetown, Mass.

title: Connecticut Man, 31, Arrested in Roadside Murders of Two Women
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 10A 31yearold Connecticut man was charged today with two longunsolved murders of young women, one in this state and one in New York.

title: A Footloose Kicker Returns
description: Rich Szaro, a leftfooted soccer  style place  kicker, was born in Europe, went to high school in New York, graduated from Harvard and has traveled throughout the world in recent years.

title: Conrad's Film Opticals at the Whitney
Amex to Add 4 Options
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the admission to trading of four new option classes next Wednesday. They are the El, Paso Company, the J. C. Penney Company. Norton Simon Inc. and the Simplicity Pattern Company.

title: Control Board's Powers Are Upheld by Lefkowitz
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled yesterday that the Emergency Financial Control Board had the legal right to review, control and supervise the formal management of the city, including the right of final review of contracts approved by the Board of Estimate.

title: THOMAS A. BUCKNER JR.
description: Thomas A. Buckner Jr., who retired in 1958 as an assistant secretary and member of the underwriting committee of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Monday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. He was 82 years old.

title: Diabetes Rated 3d Killer; U.S. Panel Calls for Help
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Diabetes has become the nation's thirdranking cause of death, is increasing rapidly and should be given broadened and enlarged attention through research and other programs, a national commission reported to the Congress today.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Growing hope that the White House and Congress would compromise on a taxcut plan for 1976 helped send prices higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading.

title: Screen: Icy Breasts, a French Import
Fiske Is Supported By Javits, Buckley For U.S. Attorney
description: Robert B. Fiske Jr., a 44yearold Wall Street lawyer, is expected to be selected for the post of United States Attorney here.

title: JOHN LYNCH
description: John Lynch, a retired production control supervisor for the Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company in Metuchen, N. J., died Tuesday after having suffered a heart attack in his home at 66 Locust Street, Carteret, N. J. He was 66 years old.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS EXTENSION OF CUT IN INDIVIDUAL TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate Finance Committee, with the concurrence of more than half its Republican members, voted today to keep present rates for individual income tax withholding in effect through the first half of next year.

title: LEE GOLDMAN
description: Lee Goldman, associate professor of design at CarnegieMellon University, died Saturday. He was 53 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: ForemanLyle Bout Set for Jan. 24
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP)George Foreman, the former world heavyweight champion, opens his bid for another shot against Muhammad Ali when he battles Ron Lyle in a 12round bout at Las Vegas on Jan. 24.

title: U.S. SEEMS TO BAR A NUCLEAR DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Government. which is in the midst of a debate over whether the United States should sell nuclear production equipment overseas, apparently forced a large American company to withdraw a tentative offer to provide such equipment to Brazil.

title: WRITER SWITCHES, TO JAZZ PLAYING
description: Richard Sudhalter, the jazz cornetist who is leading a luartet at the Riverboat, carries an assortment of credentials that makes him unique in the jazz world.

title: Bestwick Named Coach at Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 10 (AP)The University of Virginia named a Georgia Tech assistant, Dick Bestwick, as football coach today.

title: TROOPS IN BEIRUT BATTLING GUNMEN; BIG HOTELS BURNED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Dec. 11  Lebanese troops clashed with gunmen in Beirut hotel and commercial districts yesterday on the second day of their officially announced mission of separating warring Christian and Moslem factions.

title: RAILROADS TO SEEK FREIGHTRATE RISE
description: Railroads operating throughout the East and the South agreed yesterday to file applications with the Interstate Commerce Commission shortly after Jan. 1 for another freightrate increase. Traffic executives of railroads in the West also met yesterday but decided to study the situation further.

title: U.S. to Sell Israel 25 F15's, Saudis Order a $1.8 Billion Project
description: WASHINGON, Dec. 10The Defense Department notified Congress today of plans to sell Israel 25 F15 jet fighters, the most advanced interceptor in the Air Force Inventory, for $600 million.

title: Time Sets Canada Closing
