title: Prose of a New York poet
description: In a way, the original generation of the New York School of poets, in which the late Frank O'Hara figured so prominently, was like an East Coast. cosmopolitan version of the Beat Generation, which came to light in the midfifties in San Francisco. Paradoxically,

title: Giants Hosts to Saints
description: Open a telephone book, flip through the pages and randomly pick out 21 names, and you'll have a group of names that, are as familiar as the starting lineup of the New Orleans Saints.

title: Dixon Stands By Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITYThe Joseph Dixon Crucible Company, maker of the wellknown Ticonderoga pencil and employer of 550 people, announced last week that it would not follow the lead of other major companies in moving to the suburbs from this jobstarved community, its home for the last 128 years.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The Norman Conquests have come, been seen, and conquered. In fact, Alan Ayckbourn's three fulllength plays (to be attended on three successive or nonsuccessive evenings, in any order at all) have finally and definitively solved the holiday houseguest problem. Your holiday houseguest problem, I mean; the plays take place at midsummer, with white and red roses stabbing thumbs in the garden. Let's say that you've got someone coming these next few weeks or sorelatives, friends, unavoidable foesand you've got to tend to them. Simple. You just buy them the whole Norman Conquests package as an extremely.thoughtful Christmas gift and you're home freeor at home, free, while they troop off to the Morosco. If you don't like your guests, you're rid of them for three glorious nights. If you do like them, what you lose in pleasant company will be made up to you in fawning gratitude. Because all three nights are very, very funny.

title: POLITICS CHARGED IN SCIENCE PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Members of Congress and Dr. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, are involved In a running dispute over political screening of members of scientific advisory committees

title: Adults Get a Lift With HangGliding
description: MONTVILLEIt's not often a teacher will tell a student to go take a flying leap and expect to get away with it, but students in the hanggliding course at the Montville Township Adult School are finding this to be the best advice they can get.

title: Sandra Palmer Is Near Her Goal of $100,000 in Earnings for 1975
description: Sandra Palmer had just sunk a 60foot shot out of the sand at the 18th hole for an eagle 3 that won the $10,000 first prize of the 1971 Las Vegas women's open golf tournament. Earlier this week, during a practice break at the Mission Hills Country Club in Palm Springs, Calif., where she was preparing for the Colgate Triple Crown tournament, Miss Palmer recalled her victory in the Las Vegas and more recent tournaments.

title: Black Suspect in Murder of a Police Officer Alleges That the Grand jury Was Knowingly Deceived
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13A black man accused of participating in a politically motivated murder of a San Francisco policeman four years ago has moved to have charges against him dropped on the ground that the Deputy District Attorney knowingly deceived the grand jury that indicted him.

title: Disney Project Advanced
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) Walt Disney World will begin building its World Showcase, the initial phase of an Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow, in 1976 instead of 1977 as originally planned. The Showcase will house exposition halls for 10 to 30 nations as a display center for their cultures and products.

title: Bill to Aid City Put the State's Congressmen in Debtto Everyone
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The 39member New York State Congressional delegation, which voted unanimously and lobbied vigorously for the $2.3 billion. loan for New York City, has issued nearly as many I.O.U.'s as the debtridden city it fought to save.

title: Elizabeth W. McAdams Is Married
description: Elizabeth Winslow McAdams and William B. Cutler of New York were married here yesterday afternoon at St. James' Episcopal Church by the Rev. Fredrick Hill.

title: Christina L. Wyeth Is Engaged To Wed Alexis Coster Manice
description: Christina Langley Wyeth's engagement to Alexis Coster Manice has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Jarvis Wyeth of Simsbury, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Stafford McLean of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and DeForest Manice of New York.

title: Jill Goldstein Engaged to Jesse Hackell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard W. Goldstein of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jill Ellen Goldstein, to Jesse Michael Hackell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hackell of Long Beach, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Fashion
description: A special present for someone special should be something no one else will give her, something definitely chosen to suit herperhaps from among the gifts suggested here. Many are oneofakind antiques, which makes them something quite special.

title: Brooklyn Bystander Shot As Man Fires at Thieves
description: Anthony Mele, a 60yearold retired police officer, was wounded yesterday by gunfire following a nearby holdup as he was placing Christmas decorations in front of his home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: The Nation
description: Dissatisfied with the way in which his 1974 busing order was being obeyed, Federal Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. has taken away some of the powers of the elected Boston School Committee and placed one of its schools in the hands of a courtappointed receiver.

title: Shift in ThirdWorld Aid to Be Sought
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec 13Changes in development policy that would shift at least some of the new wealth generated in the third world away from urban minorities and into the pockets of the 300 million people estimated to be unemployed or working for starvation wages, most of them in rural areas, will be laid before the World Employment Conference in Geneva next June 417.

title: F.E.I. Admits Taiwan, Balks on China
description: The Federation Equestre Internationale has made Ta{wan a member but kept out China. The annual meeting of the F.E.I, the world governing body of equestrian sports, was held in Brussels, Belgium earlier this week. Federation officials said it had been expected that the General Assembly, meeting under the F.E.I president, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, would put off a decision on Taiwan and China until the International Olympic Committee had given its ruling on the China question. China some time ago applied for membership in the I.O.C.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Some thoughts on film acting: Two weeks ago I did not walk out on a particularly phony little French melodrama called Act of Aggression. In fact I very seldom walk out on anything, no matter how bad. Sitting in the theater is one of the things a critic is paid to do and if someone has worked the better part of two years on a film, spending two hours watching it seems to be the least a critic can do. There are exceptions and, under ordinary circumstances, Act of Aggression would have been one of them. It's a souped up, sensationalized, semiwhodunit about a French businessman (JeansLouis Trintignant) who seeks to avenge the rapemurders of his wife and small daughter by a gang of badmannered motorcyclists.

title: Paperbacks
description: This Yuletide bookstore tables are stacked with an unprecedented numberliterally hundredsof handsome paperbacks, large in format, crowded with reproductions of paintings, drawings and photographs, that will make welcome gifts. Many have already been given critical attention in the Book Review. The list that follows can only suggest the variety available.

title: Reagan Film Provokes Democrats in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (UPI)California Democrats, demanding equal time for their Presidential candidates, today threatened court action against a local television station that aired the cowboy western movie Law and Order, starring Ronald Reagan in the role of a sheriff.

title: Kennedy Steps Up Drive On Birds on the Runways
description: Intensifying their campaign to minimize the birdstrike hazard at Kennedy International Airport, local authorities have applied for permission to conduct a limited foodpoisoning experiment at a nearby garbage dump.

title: AngolaAid Issue Opening Rifts in State Department
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13A sharp dispute over covert operations by the Ford Administration in Angola has bitterly divided the State Department and resulted in the resignation of the head of its bureau of African affairs, according to wellinformed Government sources.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Tomorrow night Manhattan plays Hofstra at the Nassau Coliseum at 8:45 P.M. On Saturday night, American U. visits St. John's for an 8:30 game.

title: England, Italy Put In One Cup Group
description: England and Italy, which, along with Brazil, will participate in a tournament to celebrate the Bicentennial here, have been drawn in the same group in the qualifying rounds of the World Cup. Thus, only one of the two can reach the final round in World Cup play, in Argentina in 1978. The managers of both teams, Don Revie of England and Enzo Bearzot of Italy, have expressed their displeasure with the draw, conducted by the International Federation, the world's governing body of soccer. The draw, held in Guatemala last month, found other equally strong teams grouped together and gave others a clear advantage in their groups, as with East Germany, which is a lot stronger than Austria, Turkey and Malta.

title: Fairbanks Bowl Coach
description: MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 13 (AP) The New England Patriots' coach, Chuck Fairbanks, was named today to direct the North team in the 27th annual Senior Bowl allstar game Jan. 11. Jack Pardee of the Chicago Bears previously was announced as the coach of the South squad.

title: Saudi Arabia Reports Many Killed in Fire
description: BAHRAIN, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Many Moslem pilgrims have been killed and injured in a threehour fire that swept through a camp at the town of Mina in Saudi Arabia, informed sources said here today.

title: The girl who tried to be good
description: Though it is nearly 12 years since Sylvia Plath ended her life, her legend is still being fussed over. The cultists have oversimplified and pinned on her their label of victim: Poor girl (as they want to have it), deserted by her husband, alone with two children in a cold London flat, writing those lethal poems in Ariel before dawn and the baby's first cry. Because of its lilting rage, Daddy is, alas, her most famous poem, taught to death, while the adolescent anger of The Bell Jar, with its easy irony and selfcontempt, has become a classroom tractits modest literary merits inflated by its autobiographical angst.

title: Funny in the twenties, political in the thirties
description: Really funny writers are so rare that when they appear in quantity, as they did during the 1920's, here, the general level of wit goes up around them. James Thurber, Robert Benchley, Dorothy Parker, Wolcott Gibbs, E. B. White, George S. Kaufman, Marc Connelly, Ring Lardner, Frank Sullivan and a dozen lesser wags made New York the world capital of humor in the twenties, just as Paris was the world capital of art. In that antic heyday one could almost become a humorist without trying, which is apparently what happened to Donald Ogden Stewart.

title: Hundreds of Sharks Put Sydney Bathers to Flight
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 13 (Reuters)  Thousands of bathers, including many children, were forced to flee the water at Sydney's northern beaches yesterday when hundreds of sharks were spotted nearby.

title: A Comparison of Air Fares
description: The following are approximate comparative roundtrip fares from New York for travel on scheduled flights and O.T.C.'s. The scheduled fares are for roundtrip air transportation alone. The O.T.C. fares include seven nights in a hotel, except where otherwise indicated. If the chart shows any pattern, it is that O.T.C.'s tend to be less of a bargain in the Caribbean than elsewhere, because of the thigh price of hotel rooms and the existence of bulk fares on scheduled flights.

title: Bird Sanctuary Set For Tourne Park
description: BOONTON TOWNSHIPA oneacre bird sanctuary has been established in Tourne Park. The preserve, to be administered by the Morris County Park Commission, honors the late Eleanor M. Hinrichsen.

title: PANEL CONSIDERS PATIENTS' CONSENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13How can a person who is neither rational nor entirely free give consent rationally and freely to be a subject of a medical experiment?

title: Legislature May Sit Till New One Opens
description: TRENTON  The 196th session of the New Jersey Legislature is expected to convene for the last time here tomorrow. But given the magnitude of the calendar of bills and the record of House, procrastination in both Houses legislative leaders said this weekend that it was entirely possible that the lameduck session would continue into early next year.

title: Rutgers' Edwards M.V.P. in Football
description: Curt Edwards, running back and cocaptain of the 1975 Rutgers football team, has received the Homer Hazel Trophy as the Scarlet Knights' most valuable player. Edwards averaged 105 yards a game.

title: Another Tunnel?
description: Suddenly and secretly, the United States is once again contesting Communist military power in a remote place. The Ford Administration is doing so apparently to satisfy American national interest defined as it was defined when the United States entered and enlarged the war in Indochina.

title: World News Briefs
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13 (AP)The Soviet Union, angry over Egypt's friendliness with the West, has refused to reschedule payment of Cairo's massive debts, Egyptian officials said today. The move seemed to send EgyptianSoviet relations toward a new low.

title: Most Persons on Welfare Here Said to Be LongTerm Cases
description: A new study of the city's welfare recipients for the Federal Manpower Administration challenges a widely held view that welfare is intermittent aid for people going on and off low wage jobs.

title: JANIS IAN, 23, SINGS WITH NEW MATURITY
description: Janis Ian is moving along in the world. Hers Is a classic rock n roll storya major hit recording at 16 (Society's Child, which she never sings now), disappearance and then nervous return to live performance a couple of years ago. On Friday, she appeared in solo concert at Carnegie Hall, emerging on stage in control of her self, her music and musicians and newly confident.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Monzon Victor on Knockout
description: PARIS, Dec. 13  Carlos Monzon retained his share of the world middleweight title tonight when his opponent, Gratien Tonna, put on a poor acting job after he had done a poor job of fighting.

title: Events Today
description: Fifth Avenue Holiday Festival: choral groups, jazz, dancers and puppets on Fifth Avenue, which will be closed to traffic from 34th to 57th Streets; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.

title: Virginia Plant Shut, 28 Hospitalized in Pesticide Case
description: HOPEWELL, Va., Dec. 13 (UPI)Last summer, when a Health Department investigator went to an old gas station that had been converted into the world's only producer of the pesticide kepone he found the employees immersed in the white powdery chemical.

title: Pope Writes Prayer to Mary Asking World Reconciliation
description: ROME, Dec. 13 (AP)Pope Paul VI has written a prayer to the Virgin Mary calling for reconciliation among people and nationsthe theme of the Holy Yearin this critical hour for the spiritual and civil fate of the world.

title: Shriver Asks Subsidies to Create jobs
description: Sargent Shriver, concluding six days of campaigning in the city for the Democratic Presidential nomination, suggested yesterday that Government subsidies to private industry could be used to help reduce the level of unemployment.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: This summer we had all our windows replaced with doublehung, aluminumframe, thermal pane windows. Now after the first cold spell the frames started to sweat a great deal causing an accumulation of water on the inside of the sill. Is there anything we can do about this, or is this a problem about which we should contact the company who installed the windows?J.A.P., Glen Burnie, MD.

title: Natural GasThe Financing Controversy Builds
description: A major Federal program intended to stimulate the exploration and development of natural gas is scheduled to expire at the end of this month. And despite the current and projected shortage of gas in the nation's pipelines, the Federal Power Commission is being urged by a large part of the industry to let the program die.

title: Authenticating Old PhotosA Job for a Sleuth
description: The growing popularity of old photographs has raised important questions about their authenticity. How can a collector be sure that a given late 19th or early 20th century photograph is indeed the work of the photographer to whom it is attributed?

title: Red Sox Open April 9
description: BOSTON (AP)The Boston Red Sox will open defense of the American League championship next year with a series in Baltimore April 9, 10 and 11, and then begin their home schedule April 12 against the Cleveland Indians.

title: The Economic Forecast Was Right On
description: WASHINGTONOn a bitter cold day early last February, with the nation in a deepening recession and no clear evidence of when it might end, President Ford sent Congress his budget. The budget itself was unremarkable (and its figures for spending, receipts and the deficit are long since out of date). But, because of a provision in the new Congressional Budget Reform Law the budget document contained something newprojections of the key measures of the economy for five years ahead.

title: Remember the neediestShare Blessings With Others
description: There are those in the city who, because of sickness or circumstance, have just about given up. It is as if lack of hope has closed the lid on their lives.

title: 9City Tour Opens For Triangle Club
description: PRINCETONFifty members of the Princeton Triangle Club piled into a bus here last week for a twoweek tour of nine cities with a musical delivery called American Zucchini.

title: Jazz Notes: A Society for Closet Jammers
description: The closet jammers of jazz people who want to take part in jam sessions but have no place to do itare being Lured into the open by an organization called the Jazzmania Society. The Society, which holds jam sessions every Thursday, Friday, Saturday end Sunday nights in a room loft with a casual, livingroom atmosphere at 14 E. 23 St., was started last January by Mike Morgenstern, a frustrated jammer who had been renting a studio on Sunday afternoons so that he could play his bass clarinet with some similarly inclined musicians who answered a fourline ad he had run in the Village Voice.

title: Modern Disposers Are Quieter, More Efficient
description: Food waste disposers in home kitchens have been widely used in homes and apartments for many years: and are now more popular than ever. Because they get rid of food waste before it actually becomes garbage, they provide a function that the newly popular compactor still does not fulfill. The waste is disposed of before odors can develop, and the amount or bulk garbage to he handled (both by the homeowner and the local garbage pickup service) is thus greatly minimized. It leaves only empty cans, bottles, car?? and other non  food items to be carried away.

title: Suslov to Visit Cuba
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (AP)Mikhail A. Suslov, a member of the Politburo, will head the Soviet delegation to the Cuban Communist Party congress in Havana next week, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.

title: New & Noval
description: Anyone who has a copy of Walter Sullivan's Continents in Motion would know that earthquakes are not unknown in the East. But the residents of Old Brompton, R. I., are not up on their seismological homework and therefore scoff at the diagnosis of Harry Vail. a geologist who correctly assesses the warning signs of a big quake. Even Vail's wife Kay puts her faith in poltergeists when prequake tremors send objects careening around.

title: Frances Martha Griffith Bride Of Stephen Laserson, Banker
description: Frances Martha Griffith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Willard Griffith of Short Hills, N. J. Roadtown, Tortola, British Virgin Islands, and Sans Souci, Ontario, was married early yesterday evening to Stephen Alexander Laserson. He is a son of Mrs. Ruth Arden Laserson of New York and the late J. William Laserson.

title: In Russia, The Circus Is An Art Form
description: Moscow The Soviet Circus troupe which will be at New York's Felt Forum from Tuesday through Jan. 4 as part of a threemonth tour of the United States has left behind in the Soviet Union a host of hometown circuses that hold to the high standards of what, in this country, deserves to be called an art form. Permanent circuses perform year round in 61 Soviet cities, and 15 other circuses travel constantly around the country. Talent is drawn from a nationwide reservoir of 2,640 fulltime professional performers who are shifted from city to city. In the Soviet Union, the circus is a serious business.

title: An Antipolitician Politician Almost Makes It in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec 13The latest of those strange California creatures, the antipolitician politician, was almost as successful as his predecessors last Thursday when John Barbagelata lost a close runoff election for Mayor here.

title: U.S. and Soviet to Recess Arms Talks for Holidays
description: GENEVA, Dec. 13 (UPI)the United States and Soviet Union said yesterday that they would recess their arms talks next week for the Christmas and New Year holidays.

title: For young readers
description: Barbara Brenner has a nice touch for fiction. In this compact introduction to the ecology of the Arizona desert, she easily persuades us that she is Alan Pippin (Pip for short) and that this is Pip's engaging personal report of a summer vacation spent with his sister Jan, a botanist doing research in Phoenix. (Pip has to ask his father's help to make a noose for catching lizards, yet he writes with a lucidity and organization his father might well envy, but no matter; Pip is obviously a very smart, likable 12yearold and you take him as he isdirect and amusing.)

title: Large Rise in Paroles of Prison Inmates Protested by Law Officials in California
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 13  A largescale release of inmates from California prisons under a new parole policy has stirred widespread protest and warnings by law enforcement officials of a massive new peril to society.

title: Family Mobility Surveyed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)One out of every five families moved between October 1972 and October 1973, according to a Government report. The survey, conducted by the Housing and Urban Development and Commerce Departments, said nearly 75 percent of the nation's families moved since 1960 and 40 percent of thosemoved between 1970 and 1973.

title: BRIDGE
description: Great bidders are ten times as numerous as great dummyplayers. Great dummyplayers are ten times as numerous as great defenders.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Just about 10 years ago the art and practice of modern dance was pretty much centered at the Kaufmann Hall of the 92nd Street Y (the Hall has been sensationally remodeled lately, by the way) and the Hunter College Playhouse. There were, of course, the avantgardehouses, such as the wonderful Judson Memorial Church in Washington Square, and an odd but useful theater called the St. Marks Playhouse, long since abandoned. Martha Graham, it is true, attempted Broadway seasons, as did, on occasion, Paul Taylor. And an effort to establish some kind of ecumenical and nationally oriented moderndance company was attempted at Lincoln Center in 1964 and almost instantly floundered.

title: Dwight York Prep Benefit
description: The Dwight York Preparatory School will present a student production of the musical Take Me Along on Wednesday as a benefit for its scholarship fund. Tickets for the event at the Marymount Manhattan College Theater are $6, from the school, 116 East 85th Street.

title: A List of Recommended Books for Dog Enthusiast's Library
description: There is help for every dog, and more, in a variety of publications currently offered. For the novice doghandler, there's a book on selection and care and another with depictions of the 121 American Kennel Club breeds.

title: Job Prospects Improving for '76 College Seniors
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 13Graduating seniors in the class of 1976 should have a slightly better chance of finding jobs than those who graduated last dune. One survey puts the increase at 9 percent.

title: Of Things To Come
description: Although they claim to keep their eyes firmly fixed on the future, science fiction writers have rarely dared to take up Ezra Pound's artistic challenge: Make it new. With a few exceptions, the best S. F. stories are written in a style that one critic has charitably labeled transparent. The lack of stylistic experimentation is often defended as a necessary corollary of science fiction's unbounded freedom in other areas. According to one argument, when a writer is busy making up whole worlds and cultures, he has to keep the language simple to avoid losing the reader. In recent years, a few brave spirits like J. G. Ballard and Samuel Delany have successfully defied this conventional wisdom, Now Felix C. Gotschalk has weighed in with GROWING UP IN TIER 3000 (Ace, paper, $1.25).

title: An Adult's Fancy Often Turns To Childhood Toys
description: MIDLAND PARK  As Christmas approaches, children's daydreams tend to dwell on Santa's pending arrival and the bagful of toys he is expected to bring. For many grownups, however, playthings are a yearround item.

title: Winter Nears at Washington's Headquarters
description: MORRISTOWN  A bulldozer sits in a muddy clearing near the weathered shingles of the 1752 farmhouse where Tempe Wick hid her horse from plundering American soldiers.

title: Peanut farmer for President
description: Jimmy Carter was hustling through the first day of his 17th campaign trip to Florida. It was a routine day's runningforPresidenta Sertoma Club luncheon in St. Petersburg, newsconference receptions at Sarasota and Port Charlotte in the afternoonuntil he encountered the blonde at the bar in the Cove Inn Club.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1975

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Ewa Klobukowska of Poland was co holder of the world 100meter dash record for women when doctors found in September 1987 that she had one chromosome too many to qualify as a woman for athletic competitor. The 21yearold sprinter was ruled ineligible for the European Cup women's trackand field competition in the Soviet Union.

title: Miss Attridge To Be a Bride
description: Margaret Clarke Attridge, a summa cum laude graduate of the Indiana University Law School, and Dr. Timothy D. Watson, who graduated with honors from the Indiana's School of Dentistry, plan to be married in late spring.

title: Davidson StarsWings Lose, 52
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13That's more like it. The New York Rangers, playing once again like a hustling hockey team whose members know one another, outclassed the Detroit Red Wings, 52, tonight before a crowd of 12,227 in Oympia Stadium.

title: ROBERT BERGLAS
description: Robert Berglas, a free lance writer, was found dead Thursday in his apartment at 30 East End Avenue. He was 33 years old. While the cause of death was under investigation, the police said there was no indication of a breakin nor was there any evidence of a struggle.

title: L. JOSEPH STONE, EDUCATOR, DEAD
description: Dr. L. Joseph Stone, professor of psychology at Vassar College and coauthor with Joseph Church of the widely used textbook Childhood and Adolescence: A Psychology of the Growing Person, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: The Spirit of Christmas in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIROne of the most pleasant traditions at the Montclair Museum is the Christmas show, which draws each year upon its collection of European art for objects relating to the birth of Christ.

title: NewStyle Tourney Honors Mulloy, 62
description: Gardnar Molloy, who has won 49 national tennis titles and a place in the game's Hall of Fame, is being honored this week in the way he likes best.

title: SIDNEY HECHINGER
description: Sidney Hechinger, director of design and construction for the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died of cancer Friday evening at the hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 11 East 98th Street.

title: Codicil May Revive Old Mill Playhouse
description: MULLICA TOWNSHIPThe ticket kiosk at an old playhouse deep in the Atlantic County pines Is shut tight with corrugated metal, the theater entrance is boarded and about the only sound that disturbs the quiet of the thick forest is an occasional passing car.

title: Lisbeth Hall Engaged to Paul Bonner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Swick of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Swick's daughter, Lisbeth Corine Hall, to Paul Augustus Bonner, son of Mrs. Charlotte Rantoul Bonner of Boston and Ipswich, Mass., and Paul Hyde Bonner Jr. of New York.

title: Graduate Courses in Business Scheduled
description: WEST LONG BRANCHStarting with the spring semester in January, Monmouth College will offer graduate courses in business for the first time. They will be conducted at Ocean County College in Toms River.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meeting and public hearings will be conducted this week:

title: The Boundaries of Detente Have Not Been Easy to Set
description: WASHINGTONThe United States and the Soviet Union have been struggling for more than two years about whether dtente applies only to their bilateral relations and Europe or extends to all parts of the world. The latest point of contention is Angola, and the following statements of their positions show how far apart they really are.

title: A Pencil With a Past
description: The Ticonderoga pencil, a popular tool of American schoolchildren since the days of the oneroom schoolhouse, is a direct descendant of the invention nobody seems to care about; Joseph Dixon's graphite writing stick.

title: Shore Resorts Facing Pollution Charges
description: TRENTONThe Cape May report communities of Wildwood and Cape May face contempt charges next Friday that could result in fines and the closing of their beaches because of their failure to improve seweragetreatment plants whose effluent is polluting Delaware Ray and the tidal waterways.

title: Clergymen Endorse Right to Abortion
description: The New Jersey Religious Coalition for Abortion Rights said last week that 65 religious leaders within the state had signed a statement opposing the adoption of a constitutional amendment that would weaken the United States Supreme Court decision on abortion.

title: Theater
description: Arts and Leisure Guide

title: Mrs. Carner's 70 Leads, Colgate Golf by a Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 13 (UPI)  JoAnne Garner of Lake Worth, Fla., shot a twounderpar 70 today and took a oneshot lead over Judy Rankin and Jane Balock in a windblown first round of the 36hole Colgate triple crown.

title: Whatever He Decides on Any Issue, There Are Critics Left and Right
description: JERUSALEMThe scene was the carpeted, woodpanelled caucus room in the Knesset, Israel's Parliament; the occasion a debate on the Government's stand on unauthorized Israeli settlement attempts on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan. After four hours of bitter argument laced with caustic comments about the Government's lack of resolve, an incensed Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin sent a shock wave through the room. If the party would not back him up on this issue, he said, he would resign.

title: SECRECY IS URGED IN LOCKHEED CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, has urged a Federal court to try, to make sure that information sought from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, if provided, remains secret.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy J. Carpenter Will Remarry
description: Mr. and Mrs. D. Brooks Barlow of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Joan Carpenter, to David Alton James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. James of San Diego, Calif.

title: Marriage Announcement 17  No Title
description: Engagements

title: Hard Sell A Pitfall Of Window Shopping
description: We are going to do something a little different from most of the other companies We are going to custommake each of these windows for you.

title: The Skiing Clinic
description: This is the time of year when most skiers begin getting but their gear in anticipation of a safari into the snow country. It's a time when many start wondering whether the equipment they used last year is going to withstand the rigors of another winter. It's generally agreed that skis, boots, poleS and apparel have a life expectancy of at least three years, depending in. Part on how often they've been Used. A regular: weekend schussboomer may require replacements after only one season. In most cases, gear that is slightly defective can be repaired at little expense. A damaged metal loop on a boot, a gouge in the undersurface of a ski or a torn basket pole can be replaced in a matter of minutes.

title: Ruling on Crash With Camel
description: LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) The high court has awarded $220,000 in damages to a man crippled when the car in which he was riding collided with a camel. Christopher Culliman, 28 years old, was a passenger in a car that hit a camel and overturned on a desert road in Kuwait last year. The damages were awarded against the driver of the car, Robert Bray.

title: Esquire Finds No Critics of Planned Article Paid for by Xerox
description: Officials of Esquire magazine and of the Xerox Corporation report no adverse reactions, so far, to the announcement that Esquire will publish a 23 page article in February sponsored by Xerox.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1975

title: Paris School Is Training France's New Ruling Elite
description: PARIS, Dec. 14The students and alumni wear no oldboy blazers or neckties, sing no sentimental drinking songs and attach little significance to what their soccer team does on the playing field.

title: 42 Victims of Crocodiles
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Fortytwo people were killedbelieved to have been eaten by crocodilesafter their motorboat sank in central Celebes, the news agency Antara reported today.

title: Ford Is Reported Restoring Third of Defense Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)President Ford restored more than onethird of a $6.5 billion White House cut in the new 1977 defense budget, informed Government sources said today.

title: FIRST OIL DRILLING TO BEGIN OFF COAST
description: CAPE MAY, Dec. 14 (UPI) What is said to be the first offshore oil drilling on the East Coast of the United States began this weekend with the arrival of a giant drilling platfom 80 miles east of this New Jersey shore community.

title: The Energy Bill
description: There might have been a sense of relief that a yearlong deadlock on energy policy between Democratic Congress and Republican President was on the verge of resolution. Instead, the omnibus energy bill now nearing final passage in Congress has only revived the same kind of demagogic exchanges of halftruths that has inhibited energy policymaking from the start.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Juvenile Home Quarantined
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (UPI). The Central Los Angeles County Juvenile Hall was under limited quarantine after it was found that a 15yearold boy is suspected to have meningococcal meningitis, officials said today. The disease affects the central nervous system and leads to inflammation of membranes enclosing the brain and spinal cord.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Newark Will Lay Off 532 Employees Because of a Sharp Drop in State Aid
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today that increasing costs and a sharp decline in state aid would necessitate the layoff of 532 city employees, including 225 members of the police, department and 115 firemen.

title: Jewish Congress Honors Sassoon for Beauty Role
description: The American Jewish Congress presented its first annual Beauty Hall of Fame Award last night to Vidal Sassoon, the hair stylist, who served with Israel's army during the first ArabIsraeli war.

title: Florida Parachutist Killed
description: INDIANTOWN, Fla., Dec. 14 (UPI)A 21yearold skydiver fell 7,500 feet to his death today after he apparently was knocked unconscious in a midair collision with a fellow parachutist during a formation excercise. The dead man, a member of the Southeastern Parachute Association, was identified as John T. Abbaticchio of Fort Lauderdale.

title: C5A JET REPAIRS TO COST 1.5 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The latest. Defense Department estimates show that it will cost $1.3 billion to fix defective wings on the C5A cargo plane, which already is a symbol of Pentagon cost overruns.

title: Sweden in Hockey Tie
description: GOTEBURG, Sweden, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Sweden and Czechoslovakia played a 55 tie today in the opening game of the annual Izvestia Cup ice hockey tournament.

title: Integrity in the Business Landscape
description: There is a massive loss of faith in the business community by the American peopleand perhaps a loss of faith on the part of businessmen as well.

title: N.F.L. Scoring and Statistics
description: AT FOXBORO, MASS.

title: Lynn Higashi Wed to David Kaufelt
description: Lynn Mitsuko Higashi, director of marketing for Georges Gotlib Inc., a package design company, was married here yesterday morning to David Allan Kaufelt, novelist and director of public interest at the Henry Street Settlement. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at Mr. Kaufelt's home.

title: Orthodox Churches to Form Panel for Vatican Talks
description: ROME, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  The Eastern Orthodox churches have decided to establish a joint commission to prepare for unification talks with the Roman Catholic Church, a senior Orthodox prelate announced today.

title: Arthur Treacher Dies
description: Arthur Treacher, who personified the butler in plays, movies and television programs, died in Manhasset at 81 Page 34.

title: WhiteBlack Job Gap Up
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) A faster economic recovery would be more likely to narrow the unemployment gap between blacks and whites, according to a Congressional Budget Office report released today. It said that the difference between white and nonwhite unemployment rates grew from 4.3 percentage points in the fourth quarter of 1973 to 6.1 in the third quarter of 1975.

title: $437 Given To Neediest By Postmen
description: Two postal workers took a brief respite from their duties to visit the offices of The New York Times to deliver $437 in checks and cash as a contribution to the Neediest Cases Fund from the employees of the General Post Office, at 31st Street and Eiehth Avenue.

title: CORRECTION
description: The amount of folic acid suggested for women as a daily supplement was stated incorrectly Nov. 22 in an article in The New York Times on the nutritional needs, of women. The suggested supplement is 200 to 400 micrograms a day.

title: Aggressive Leader for Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Monday, Dec. 15He was not elected to be Prime Minister, he was elected to do a job of work and he's getting on with the work, said a senior adviser to Australia's new Prime Minister today. It was entirely in character that yesterday morning, after a victory celebration in Melbourne that went far into the night, Malcolm Fraser, the nation's new leader, was up early. First he conferred with his advisers; later he decided to spend a little time with his family.

title: Fifth Ave. Decked in Holiday Finery
description: Mayor Beame got a dollar bill! from a little girl and a kiss from a man yesterday afternoon as he went strolling down Fifth , Avenue with his wife, Mary, enjoying its conversion into a pedestrian mall.

title: From Wild Thyme to Frog Songs, Museum Shops Can Provide Unusual Gifts
description: Tithe was when a museum was a place you went to study the past, not to buy the present.

title: Prince Darlington Wins
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Vinni Amico an apprentice, rode Prince Darlington, six furlongs in 1:10 3/5 and won the $8,000 Helioscope Purse by a neck at Suffolk Downs today. The winner paid $9.40.

title: FRANCE WILL HELP EGYPT MAKE ARMS
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14France has agreed to help Egypt set, up its own armaments industry, according to a joint communiqu released tonight on the visit to Egypt of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France.

title: 2 Slain and 3 Hurt in Home For Handicapped in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP)At least one man, and perhaps two men, entered a home for handicapped persons in an apparent robbery attempt today and killed two staff workers and injured three other persons the police said.

title: Bond Traders Optimistic As New Issues Sell Fast
description: The atmosphere in the credit markets is a good deal more optimistic today than it was a week ago. Bond prices last week rose in the face of a huge supply of new issues for sale and a large $2.4 billion increase in the nation's money supplytwo factors that investment bankers and bond traders had worried might depress prices and cause interest rates to rise.

title: The President's Friend
description: WASHINGTON  Senators Frank Church and Gary Hart, acting like a couple of frightened men, have been forcing intelligence committee staff members to sign affidavits swearing the staffers were not the source of leaks of the committee's most closely guarded secret.

title: House Unit Demands Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The House Intelligence Committee has asked the Ford Administration to explain exactly, what role it is playing in Angola, the House Democratic Leader, Thomas P. O'Neill, said today.

title: Barbara Rosen Bride In Jersey of P.L. Gould
description: Barbara Jill Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Rosen of Kearny, N. J., was married yesterday evening to Peter L. Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gould of Bayside, Queens.

title: Bangladesh Still Lives With Starvation Despite Vast Quantities of Foreign Aid
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 9  By air and by sea, from countries of every political stripe, this impoverished land is receiving one of the world's largest infusions of foreign aid.

title: SOVIET DISCLOSES NEW 5YEAR PLAN WITH LOWER GOAL
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14The Soviet Union today publicly outlined its new fiveyear plan, with more modest hopes for economic growth and a return to the traditional reliance on heavy industry.

title: Simon Preston at New Tully Hall Organ
description: The new pipe organ at Alice Tully Hall has become exactly what its proponents said it would  the central showcase for organ virtuosos in the city and perhaps the country. course the instrument and the space have their limitations, particularly for the grander Romantic works. But it's still a wonderful organ to look at and to listen to.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS GRUMMAN STUDY
description: A Senate subcommittee on multinational corporations will investigate recent disclosures by the Grumman Corporation, the country's fifth largest defense contractor, that it had arranged to pay Iranian lobbyists more than $20, million in commissions as part of a $2 billion deal to sell Iran the controversial F14 Tomcat jet fighter.

title: Fifth Ave. Decked In Holiday Finery For City Strollers
description: Mayor Beame got a dollar bill from a little girl and a kiss from a man yesterday afternoon as he went strolling down Fifth Avenue with his wife, Mary, enjoying its conversion into a pedestrian mall.

title: Marsteller Making Promotions
description: The founding fathers of Marsteller Inc. and BursonMarsteller, its public relations arm, are moving up the secondgeneration management. But William A. Marsteller, 61 years old, and Harold Burson, 54, are still the chief executive officers.

title: Father Shoots a Doctor At a Center for Children
description: A distraught parent visiting his two young children in a Jewish children's placement center in Brooklyn yesterday shot and critically wounded a staff psychiatrist and was arrested after exchanging shots with the police, authorities said.

title: Montana Officials Assail Plan for Energy Complex
description: HELENA, Mont., Dec. 14Top state officials here have criticized a proposal, in a study prepared for the Federal Energy Administration, to build a massive energyproducing complex for the region at an abandoned Air Force base in northeastern Montana.

title: WILLIAM H. GLAZIER, HEALTH LEADER, 58
description: William H. Glazier, acting chairman of the community health department at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a communityhealth leader, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home, 15 London Terrace, New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 58 years old.

title: One Town's Economic Fortunes in the Holidays
description: QUAKERTOWN, Pa.  This town of 8,000, founded by the Quakers and later populated by the Pennsylvania Dutch, has a magic location, its strongest boosters believe. It is near two major highways, it is situated between two large cities and it is appealingly rural without the pollution or congestion of Philadelphia and Allentown.

title: RIKERS INMATES LOCKED IN CELLS
description: Fiftyfive Rikers Island prisoners who defied orders to move into another cellblock Saturday until 80 batonequipped guards staged a show of force remained locked in their cells yesterday; shut off from the normal Sunday routine.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: FORD IS PLANNING DRAFT REVISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) President Ford is prepared to issue a Presidential proclamation that would radically restructure the Selective Service System by instituting a oneday national registration and abolishing local draft boards.

title: Zoo Seeking to Restore Wildness to Its Animals
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14Scien Lists at the Brookfield Zoo have begun an experiment with two pumas that they hope will help wild animals born or bred in captivity to keep their natural hunting instincts as sharply honed as if the animals were running free.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Panel to Ask Juvenile Crime Penalties
description: A national commission preparing guidelines for the nation's juvenilejustice system, has recommended major changes to shift the approach of the family courts from an insulated tribunal, where judges and lawyers attempt primarily to help youngsters, to an adversary proceeding similar to the adult criminal court system.

title: Custody of Vietnamese Boys Disputed
description: BLACKSTONE, Va., Dec. 14 (AP)Two Vietnamese boys whose mother says that, for their safety, she had an American take them out of South Vietnam months before the Communist takeover, are caught in the middle of a custody battle in Virginia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Health Department has warned consumers against picking and eating wild mushrooms, no matter how experienced privatemushroom pickers believe themselves to be. Deputy Commissioner Jean B. Cropper cited the reports of illness and death received by the department each year, including that of one recent victim who died from poisoning after having eaten wild mushrooms for 50 years. Testing boiled wild mushrooms with a silver spoon belongs in the realm of old wives' tales, Mr. Cropper noted.

title: HOSTAGES FREED FROM DUTCH TRAIN
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 14Six young Asian terrorists surrendered peacefully to the police today after having held 23 persons hostage for 12 days on a train near the northern Dutch town of Beilen.

title: Celtics Defeat Jazz
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (UPI)Charlie Scott was the spark, scoring 15 points in the final quarter as the Boston Celtics beat the New Orleans Jazz, 10293, tonight.

title: Ablagia, a Little Man, Brings St. John's to the Heights
description: At St. John's they call Frank Alagia, The Flea.

title: Baird Brothers Win
description: The seventh annual Long Island platform tennis championship was won yesterday by the firstseeded team of Steve and Chip Baird of New York. They defeated the second  seeded team of Keith Jennings and Chum Steele of Boston in the final, 64, 63, 62.

title: 90% of Restaurants Found Unsanitary in 9City Sample
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 14 (UPI)  Unsanitary conditions may be found in nearly 90 percent of restaurants that serve the public, according to a random sampling by Federal inspectors in nine cities.

title: A LANDMARK HOTEL IS RAZED IN DURHAM
description: DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 14 Shortly after dawn today the old Washington Duke Hotel, a 16story downtown landmark, was leveled by dynamite in a demolition operation that drew several thousand spectators.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The latest Defense Department estimates show that it will cost $1.3 billion to fix defective wings on the C5A cargo plane, which already is a symbol of Pentagon cost overruns.

title: Maurice Edelman, 64, Novelist, Journalist and Labor M.P., Dies
description: Maurice Edelman, a novelist and journalist who served as a Labor Member of the British Parliament since 1945, died yesterday at Brompton Hospital in London. He was 64 year old.

title: Black Politicians Divided On '76 Campaign Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14At a meeting of black politicians here this weekend, Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary, Ind., for the sake of unity, wanted his fellow Democrats to agree on a specific strategy for next year's Presidential campaign, possibly even endorsing a candidate.

title: 6Mile Road Race Taken by Wilson
description: Marvin Wilson of the Pioneer Club won a sixmile race sponsored by the Road Runner Club of New York in Central Park yesterday. He covered the course in 29 minutes 55 seconds.

title: Blalock Captures Playoff
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)Jane Blalock sank a 20foot birdie putt on the first hole of a threeway, suddendeath playoff today and captured the $50,000 Colgate Triple Crown women's golf tournament at the Mission Hills Country Club.

title: From 110 Stories Up: A Silent City Far Below
description: Even the World Trade Center's greatest detractors have expected that there would be one good aspect to the overall horror of the design of the 110story twin towers, and it is so: The view from the top is something spectacular, unlike anything else in this city, where skyscraper viewing posts have been common ever since the Latting Observatory tower was erected on West 42d Street in 1853.

title: Issues and Debate
description: The once sciencefictional idea of genetic engineering, with its implications of altermg the characteristics of human beings to ward off disease or to create armies of obedient slaves, has taken a long step toward reality in the last two years.

title: ROBERT F. KELLEY, PUBLICITY MAN, 75
description: Robert F. Kelley, public relations director for the New York Racing Association from 1945 to 1959, died yesterday in the Huntington (L.I.) Nursing Home. He was 75 years old.

title: In Memoriam
description: AUGERRachel. Un feul etre vous manque et tout est depuple. Until we meet again. All my love, May.

title: Cyprus Approves U.N. Move
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 14 (Reuters) spokesman for the Cyprus Government said today that it approved the extension of the mandate for United Nations forces to remain on this island until next June 15.

title: Advertising
description: The ThompsonKoch Company is pitching hard to get more business from Sterling Drug, the country's 16th largest national advertiser with 1974 billings of $85 million.

title: A NEW CEASEFIRE IS SET IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14A new ceacefire, the 16th in eight months of civil strife, was agreed upon here tonight as the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization stepped in to try to check the rapid deterioration of Lebanese Government authority.

title: Ultimatum for C.U.N.Y.
description: In broad outline, the Board of Regents' plan for the City University's future constitutes a rational response to that institution's fiscal distress. There can be no question that the state will eventually have to assume a substantially larger share of C.U.N.Y.'s financinga share closer to the cost of educating students on the campuses of the State University. Nor is it realistic, especially in the light of the state's own budget tightness, to believe that such a shift of the budgetary focus to Albany can be effected without a similar shift in control over policymaking for the City University.

title: Colts Beat Dolphins; Cards Capture Title
description: The Baltimore Colts defeated the Miami Dolphins, 107, in overtime yesterday and thus delayed final selections for the first round of the bowl playoffs Dec. 27 and 28. The two teams are now tied in the American Conference Eastern Division.

description: Jerome Kern's musical hit Very Good Eddie, which was, first produced here in 1915, will open on Broadway next Sunday, at the Booth Theater.

title: Aspin Says PCB Imports Are Up 38.9% in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) United States Customs Service figures released today by Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, indicate that polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) are being imported this year at levels 38.9 percent higher than just three years ago.

The warning was made in a report distributed by the department's office of economic adjustment, following a study of the relationship between past personnel reductions and the area's economy.

description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 14 After three quarters of desultory basketball against the Indiana Pacers, the Nets mobilized their forces in the last 12 minutes and scored a strong 9993 victory today.

One of Martha Graham's major works, Herodiade, was revived for the first time since, I believe, 1963, at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Saturday night. It is one of the few major Graham works I had, for some reason or the other, never seen.

title: Naumburg: 50 Years of MusicianMaking
description: Whether right or not, a successful career as a performing musician in this country has largely depended on the reviews that follow an appearance here. Today there are a number of organizations that help young artists by sponsoring their New York debuts.

description: SAN DIEGO, Dec.14The New York Jets, who helped launch Monday night football five years ago, will be on national display tomorrow, night here against the Charlers. The game can be seen in New York on Channel 7 at 9 P.M.

description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Dec. 9  Tropical but far from lush, the Comoro Islands strike the visitor above all by their extreme poverty and a sense of neglect, by their own elite and by the French colonial power.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14Leftist guerrillas are holding a businessman who figures in an investigation of Government corruption and are demanding a $10 million ransom for him.

In each case, a Labor Party that had governed for only three years was turned out decisivelyso emphatically in Australia as to raise doubts about the party's survival.

title: About New York
description: We have already been having previews of winter, which opens here next week. Winter has been having a run of innocuous performances in recent years, and the buffs have been living on the snows of '47 and the blizzard of '88 for want of something more recent to brag about.

title: Ohio Teacher Strike Backfires on Shanker's Union
description: SOUTH POINT, Ohio, Dec. 14 The latest battle in the war between the nation's two largest leachers' organizations, a representational skirmish in this tiny Ohio River town, has ended in embarrassment for the American Federation of Teachers.

title: American Builder Chosen Fora Gas Plant in Kuwait
description: MENA ALAHMADI, Kuwait, Dec. 10 The Kuwaiti Government has chosen a United States concern, the M. W. Kellogg Company, to build a $400 million natural gas processing plant here as part of $3 billion effort to expand and diversify Kuwait's oil industry, wellplaced Arab and European informants have reported.

title: No Questions, Please
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14In the last six months the Ford Administration has secretly supplied $25 million in arms and money to factions it favors in Angola. The President has just approved another $25 million. American pilots are flying five American artillery spotter planes in and out of Angola from neighboring Zaire.

title: Cards Clinch East Crown and Convince Skeptics
description: When the St. Louis Cardinals beat out the Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys for the National Conference's Eastern Division championship last year, many observers thought that the Cardinals had used luck, more than talent to gain the title.

title: Recital: Eugene Fodor
description: Eugene Fodor's career will be one to follow with interest. The 26yearold American violinist, who tied for second prize in the Tchaikovsky Violin Competition at Moscow in 1974, plays his instrument with impressive technical command but as yet there is little interpretive depth in his performances. That comes next, perhaps.

title: Herbert Russell Morss Jr., Judge in Vermont, 65, Dies
description: Judge Herbert Russell Morss Jr. of Vermont District Court died Saturday in a onecar accident in Royalton, Vt. He was 65 years old and lived in Chelsea, Vt.

title: With a Rope, a Rabbit and a Stick
description: Leo Camarillo roared down Interstate 35 toward Oklahoma City and the National Finals Rodeo, towing his roping horse, Super Stick, in a trailer. The N.F.R. is every cowboy's goal, for only the top 15 in each event are eligible for this grand finale of the rodeo year. For Leo Camarillo the 17th stampede represented the impossible dream because, although his specialty is the team roping event, he was leading the world for the allaround championship. Rodeo titles are based on money won, and the allaround champion is the wrangler witn the largest total earned in two or more events. A team roper splits all purses with his partner, so at the Chase Manhattan he stands only knee high to a bulldogger. Camarillo's 1975 share of the loot, $26,504, is an alltime high for team roping, but a pittance alongside the $40,939 Tom Ferguson won roping calves by himself last year. Nevertheless, by adding more than $12,000 in Calf roping and about $9,000 wrestling steers, Camarillo led Ferguson by $3,266 and Larry Mahan by $3,597 as they headed for the finals.

title: Prof. Stephen Xydis, Taught Social Sciences at Hunter
description: Stephen G. Xydis, a professor of social sciences at Hunter College and an authority on Cyprus, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived at 315 Central Park West.

title: Personal Finance
description: The cost of sending a child to college is a major item in the budget of many families, so any taxsaving or taxdeferring device related to education expenses has widespread interest. A recent ruling by the Internal Revenue Service on employer educational benefit trusts could therefore apply to a variety of individuals and corporations.

title: TENANT RALLY ASKS RENT CONTROL FIGHT
description: Political leaders and representatives of 10 tenant associations throughout the city rallied yesterday in the treelined enclave of Tudor City Park, overlooking the United Nations, to urge tenants to unite in support of rent control, which they believe is threatened by the current city fiscal crics.

title: GEN. JAMES CANNON LED REFUGEE CAMP
description: FORT SILL, Okla., Dec.. 14 (UPI)Brig. Gen. James W. Cannon, who directed the opening of the country's largest refugee center at Fort Chaffee, Ark., died yesterday of lung cancer at Reynolds Army Hospital. He was 46 years old.

description: Outgoing

title: Adroit 'Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother'
description: "Unless I'm very much mistaken," says Sigerson Holmes (Gene Wilder), drawing the words out with care and smiling slightly, preparing to stun his audience with a grand new insight, "'hadderd' is the Egyptian word 'to eat fat.'"Sigerson is deciphering a coded message that has just been delivered to his tacky London flat in "The Adventure of Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother" and, of course, he's immediately off on the wrong track."The Adventure of Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother," which opened at two theaters here yesterday, is a charming slapstick comedy that honors Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's original creation as much by what it doesn't do as by what it does do. The film is a marvelously lowbrow caper but it makes no attempt to parody the great Sherlock himself, who is treated with cheerful if distant awe and respect, measured entirely in terms of Sigerson's ineptitude.Sigerson Holmes, somewhat manic, capable of fits of intense, wrongheaded concentration, is the unique creation of Gene Wilder, who not only stars in the film but who also wrote and directed it.It's correct to report that Sigerson is younger than his brother Sherlock (younger also than their brother, Mycroft, who does not appear in this adventure). He's also luckier and much, much blonder, but he is just a teeny-tiny bit dense, which is something he can never admit in his sibling fury.Sigerson loathes Sherlock with a depth that is reserved only for the loathing that one brother cherishes for another. Yet that doesn't prevent Sigerson from hanging a shingle outside his door that reads "S. Holmes, Consulting Investigator," which occasionally catches a client who had intended to hire Sherlock.Like "Young Frankenstein," the script for which was written by Mr. Wilder and Mel Brooks, "Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother" is full of affection and generous feelings for the genre it's having fun with. It never mistakes the conventions of the Sherlock Holmes world for jokes in themselves. It's not Victorian London nor Conan Doyle conceits that are funny. The humor is in the spectacle of Sigerson's solemnly demonstrating his inability to do absolutely anything right.Always just offscreen, and sometimes briefly on, is the imposing presence of older brother Sherlock (played with nice style by Douglas Wilmer), who is the architect of the plot that Sigerson thinks he is solving by himself with some help from his equivalent of Dr. Watson. This character is a retired London detective named Orville Sacker who, as played by Marty Feldman, is just the Dr. Watson that Sigerson deservesoptimistic, wise-talking, obsequious and incurably nuts.Mr. Wilder has surrounded himself with great comic actors and gives them all the opportunity to perform, especially Madeline Kahn, who may possibly be the funniest woman in films today. Miss Kahn plays Jenny Hill, who introduces herself as an actress ("I am simultaneously funny and sad"), but whose identities change from time to time, as befits a mystery.In addition there are Leo McKern, as Professor Moriarty, still a ruthless villain but who, in Mr. Wilder's screenplay, doesn't know what to do with the decimal point in long division; Dom DeLuise, as a crazy Italian opera star with a misguided desire to succeed in espionage, and John Le Mesurier, as an aging British foreign secretary who has a letch for pretty nannies.The film has a PG rating becauseI supposeof a few sexy gags of the kind that will go over the heads of the very young and will certainly not impair the morals of the kids who will understand them. "Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother" seems to be composed mainly of jokes that will delight the young while effectively recalling for the rest of us how hilarious it was to see a man lose his pants at a stuffy dinner party or the shambles that can be made of grand opera when the wrong people get on the stage.Mr. Wilder, always a fine, very straight comic actor, here makes an impressive debut as a comedy director.

title: Commission Pluralism
description: Back in the early days of the Kennedy Administration, John Kenneth Galbraith told his diary that Walter Heller showed me a memorandum he had just sent to the President recommending against the creation of a blueribbon commission. . . . It was crisp and tough and made the essential point, which is that blueribbon is a synonym for stuffed shirt.

title: EDWIN G. SCHNEIDER
description: Edwin G. Schneider, who retired in 1969 as vice president in charge of the engineering and electronic systems group of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, died Saturday of a lung ailment in Fort Myers, Fla., where he lived. He was in his early 70's.

title: Appeal Today of Conviction in Queens Based on Petitioner's Landmark Case
description: Dollree Mapp made legal history in 1961, when the Supreme Court of the United States, in overturning her obscenity conviction, ruled that (legally seized evidence could not be used in state criminal trials.

title: ANEW CEASEFIRE Is SET IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 14A new ceacefire, the 16th in eight months of civil strife, was agreed upon here tonight as the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization stepped in to try to check the rapid deterioration of Lebanese Government authority.

title: Israelis Seek to Develop A Fuel Oil Out of Algae
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Israeli scientists say they have produced small quantities of highgrade fuel oil from algae grown in saline pools, but they warn that much more experimentation is needed.

title: Father of 5 Faces Death Penalty; First Mandatory Sentence Here
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 14  Joseph Davis, who is to be sentenced here tomorrow to a mandatory death penalty for the 1974 murder of a Yonkers policeman, sat at a small bare table and shook his head slowly, trying to find the right words.

title: 3D KNIGHT SUSPECT IS CAUGHT IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, Monday, Dec 15 (UPI)  Salvatore Soli, the third suspect sought in the Philadelphia slaying of John. S. Knight 3d, the newspaper heir, was arrested at a Miami motel late Sunday. A female companion alerted the authorities to his whereabouts.

title: Ga. Tech Aide Leaves
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 14 (UPI)Georgia Tech's defensive backfield coach, Dave Braine, has resigned and joined the staff of Virginia's new coach, Dick Bestwick.

title: Flames' Late Surge Overcomes Sabres, 74
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 14 (UPI)Larry Romanchych had three goals tonight and Bill Flett scored twice as Atlanta broke a 22 tie and defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 74.

title: 2 Sandhill Cranes Leave By Airplane for Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Two sandhill cranes given by President Ford to Emperor Hirohito of Japan on his recent visit to the United States left today by plane from Dulles International Airport for Japan.

title: 138 Moslems Killed lAnd 151 Are Injured Infire Near Mecca
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14 A total of 138 Moslem pilgrims died a few miles from Mecca, the holy city of Islam, when fire swept through their tent camp two days ago, the Saudi Interior Ministry said here tonight.

title: The HouseKissinger Battle Over Contempt: A Compromise on Presidential Power and Confidentiality
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 14 We were looking right down the barrel of a gun, a high White House official said. He was talking about a threatened! Congressional contempt citation against Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger for having refused to produce documents, describing covert foreign operations, that had been demanded by the House Select Committee on Intelligence. The test of will between the White House and Congress was resolved last week when the Ford Administration agreed to supply the committee with the information it sought without handing over. the subpoenaed documents.

title: Bridge:
description: A world champion who was not there played a major role in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the StatlerHilton Hotel Saturday. Vito Pittala, a hero of the fighting recovery that enabled Italy to retain its world team title in Bermuda last January, was in town and had expressed interest in Playing in the tournament.

title: U.S. Says State Has Spent $11 Billion On Medicaid Without Control of Fraud
description: New York State has spent $11billion in Medicaid funds without an effective control of abuses and fraud, a Federal study charged today.

title: Giants End Losing String by Beating Saints, 2814, on 3dPeriod Surge
description: The pattern at the start was all too frustratingly familiar to the woeful Giants yesterday. Rondy Colbert fumbled away a punt, New Orleans scored a quick touchdown, the Giants' offense generated a net yardage of minus 1 in the first quarterand what else was new at Shea Stadium.

title: The Tap Is Turned Off At an Old East Side Pub
description: In an atmosphere lightened only slightly by flowing ale, dozens of the faithful returned yesterday to pay their last respects to Connelly's, an oldstyle Irish pub that closed its doors last night after 60 years on the East Side.

title: Cookbook Profits Pay for a Water Main
description: JEROME, Ariz.This old mining town has come up With a recipe for fiscal selfsufficiency.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Buckley Brings G.O.P. Fight Into Open
description: In contrast to Democrats, Republicans usually fight their battles in private. Such is the case in the current tugofwar between Senator James L. Buckley and the Republican state chairman, Richard Rosenbaum. The Senator and his right  hand man, Leonard Saffir, have been pressuring Republican county chairmen to declare openly their support of Mr. Buckley's renomination. Most of them are Buckley fans.

title: Eastern Bloc's Debt High; Banks Slow to Lend More
description: Eastern European countries have run up a debt in the west of some $32 billion, up by $7 billion to $9 billion from the end of 1974, financial analysts here estimate. As a result, bankers report an increasing reluctance on the part of major international banks to lend any more to the Communist countries.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: VETERANS Two film careers of note, one off the screen and the other on, will be saluted today in the Museum of Modern Art's series of MondaysatNoon short subject (repeated Tuesdays). The halfhour documentary Arthur & Lillie, a hit of the last New York Film Festival, pays tribute to Arthur Mayer, the octogenarian publicity mandistributorprofessor and adviser to a cavalcade of film talent over the years, and to his wife, Lillie, whose activities go from women's suffrage to women's liberation. The revealing and candidly affectionate closeup of the couple was made by students of Mr. Mayer who, near 90, teaches film at Stanford and Dartmouth Universities and the University of Southern California.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: There's a new form of Federal unemployment assistance that could benefit some outofwork residents of New Jersey with close to double the maximum benefit that they can now receive under state unemployment insurance.

title: French Pullout Leaves Colony Near Insolvency
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Dec. 9A United Nations mission that visited this newly independent country a few days ago has sent an urgent appeal to United Nations headquarters for immediate help to prevent famine and the imminent disruption or breakdown of all essential services.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Swiss Skier Gains First Cup Victory
description: MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 14 (UPI)Engelhard Pargaetzi of Switzerland, a veteran of four World Cup seasons without a victory, finally triumphed today on a tricky giant slalom course deadened by fresh falling snow.

title: Prize Mine
description: The world's largest coal mining operation has been awarded a prize worth nearly a quartermillion dollars for combining an outstanding addition to the supply of energy with beneficial effects on the environment. The Krupp Foundation Prizeno more ironically dedicated to its purpose than the Nobel Peace Prize to the cause of peacehas gone to the Rheinischo Braunkohlenwerke AG (Rheinbraun for short) for having, over two decades, removed some 100 million tons of surface coal a year with benefit, rather than harm, to the densely populated and agriculturally rich region in which the mining was done.

title: White Pupils' Rolls Drop A Third in Boston Busing
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14The public schools here have lost at least 17,760 white students, nearly a third of the white enrollment, since coortordered busing for school desegregation began 18 months ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: This onevolume selection of James Joyce's letters is an interesting distillate of the threevolume collection published between 1957 and 1966. It is made especially worthwhileindeed essential to any halfway serious student of Joyceby its inclusion of 10 letters never before published (five to Joyce's patroness Harriet Shaw Weaver; two each to his wife, Nora Barnacle, and Lady Gregory; and one to Ezra Pound), as well as unpublished passages heretofore omitted from many others. Moreover, editor Richard Ellmann's Introduction Is a perceptive distillate. Having written the definitive biography to date. James Joyce, and edited Volumes II and III of Joyce's letters (Volume I was edited by Stuart Gilbert), Professor Ellmann is familiar with every detail and nuance of Joyce's life and work.

title: Earthquake Hits California
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)An earthquake rumbled through the desert north of here this morning but paused no apparent domage.

title: Colts Subdue Dolphins On Overtime Kick, 107
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 14The Baltimore Colts in the playoffs? In the Super Bowl?

title: Colson joins Former Senator Hughes In Sermon on Aftermath of Watergate
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 14Harold E. Hughes, the former Democratic Senator from Iowa, and Charles W. Colson, a White House aide to then President Richard M. Nixon, gave a joint sermon in the Princeton, University chapel today on The American Experience in the Aftermath of War and Watergate.

title: ExAide to Jackson Becomes Carter FundRaiser
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 Morris S. Dees Jr., the mastermind behind Senator George McGovern's moneybymail drive in the late 1972 Presidential campaign and more recency a consultant to Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, has signed on as finance chairman for former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia. He has pledged to raise $500,000 for the Carter campaign by Feb. 15, but since Mr. Carter is snort of cash, Mr. Dees will be looking first for big contributions to pay the startup costs of a mass mailing. Roger Altman, a banker with Lehman Brothers on Wall Street, is seeking backing for Mr. Carter in New York.

title: JOAN LITTLE HELD IN BOND POSTING CASE
description: DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 14 (AP) Joan Little, who had been sought by the police for failing to post bond for her appeal to the state Supreme Court on a breaking and entering conviction, was taken into custody at a motel here tonight, the police said.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP)The St. Louis Blues dismissed Coach Garry Young tonight and replaced him temporarily with Lynn Patrick. It was the third time Patrick had been given the job in the National Hockey League team's eight years. He has been serving as the club's senior vice president. The announcement came before the start of the Blues' game with the Hawks here. The Blues had won only once in their 10 previous games. Last year, under Young, they had a 3226.11 wonlosttied mark and reached the playoffs.

title: Deaths
description: BEENBernice. Beloved daughter of Betty and the late Oscar. Dear sister of Joyce Nagler. Loving aunt of Renay and Oscar. Services were held Sunday, December 14.

title: Robert W. Smith, Publisher Of Minneapolis Newspapers
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 (AP) Robert W. Smith, since 1973 publisher of The Minneapolis Star and The Minneapolis Tribune, died yesterday at his home in suburban Wayzata. He was 59 years old.

title: Thais Take Games
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 14 (AP)Thailand clinched the Southeast Asia Peninsular Games overall medal race today with two days still left in the competition. The Thais had accumulated 67 gold medals, 33 silvers and 31 bronzes. Singapore was second with 35 golds and Burma third with 24.

title: Fares Rising Today On Buses in Jersey; State Weighs Aid
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14Fare increases on all the major subsidized intrastate bus lines will take effect tomorrow for 630,000 bus riders in the state. The new rates are a result of the unwillingness of the Legislature to appropriate $10.2 million requested by Governor Byrne to restore bus and rail subsidies. A new round of fare increases is expected to be ordered by Feb. 1 .

title: Miss Kunsberg Wed to R. H. Rosenfield
description: Sandra Kunsberg, a lawyer here with the Environmental Protection Agency, and Rahert H. Rosenfield, a lawyer with the firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn here, were married yesterday afternoon in Scarsdale, N.Y., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Kunsberg, the bride's parents.

title: Year of No Growth For Life Insurance
description: The sale of life insurance to individuals, traditionally considered immune to the ups and downs of the nation's economy, is expected to show virtually no growth this year for the first time in 25 years. The impact of the nation's economy was cited as the principal reason.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Milk Price Rise Continues
description: The trend of higher milk prices continued last month as the uniform farm price per hundredweight of milk delivered to pool handlers rose to $10.13 in November in the New YorkNew Jersey area, according to Thomas A. Wilson, market administrator of the New YorkNew Jersey Milk Marketing Area. The price was $9.94 in October and $8.47 in Nov. 1974.

title: French Pullout Leaves Colony Near Insolvency
description: MORONI, Comoro Islands, Dec. 9A United Nations mission that visited this newly independent country a few days ago has sent an urgent appeal to United Nations headquarters for immediate help to prevent famine and the imminent disruption or breakdown of all essential services.

title: BURNS ASKS REFORM TO FIGHT INFLATION
