description: AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 14 (AP) The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Arthur F. Burns, said today that the persistence of inflation in the face of 8 or 9 per cent unemployment indicated that something was basically wrong with the American economy.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Cleanup of Garbage By Private Carters Slows Down Here
description: A snag developed yesterday in the garbage cleanup by private carters following the 11day strike, with pickups totaling less than half of those made on Saturday.

title: HOUSE FIRE KILLS PARAPLEGIC AND 4
description: SOUTHPORT, N.Y., Dec. 14A 28yearold paraplegic, his wife and three children were killed when a fire swept through their twofamily, twostory house here before dawn.

title: COUPLE AND TROOPER KILLED IN GUNFIRE
description: A 24yearold state trooper was shot to death and his assailant slain b yanother trooper last night after the gunman had reportedly slain a young woman at their home in Orange County the police said.

title: 19 Hurt in Fraternity Clash
description: DE KALB, Ill., Dec. 14 (UPI) At least 19 persons were injured last night in a brawl between 100 members of two fraternities during initiation rites at the Northern Illnois University home student center.

title: 4 Dead in Gas Explosion Near Niagara
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Dec. 14A railroad tank car loaded with poisonous chlorine gas exploded on a siding outside a chemical plant tonight, killing four workers and injuring 69 other persons, four of them critically.

title: Cattle Die in Tornado
description: HAMILTON, Mo., Dec. 14 (UPI)A tornado destroyed two houses, several barns and one shed a mile east of here today. No injuries were reported. Several head of cattle in one of the barns were trapped in the debris and killed.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Austerity in Hartford
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso's decision to lay off up to 10 percent of Connecticut's 40,000 employees was a tough response to labor leaders and lawmakers who turned down her alternative austerity proposals, including extending the state employees' work week from 35 to 40 hours.

title: Stage: Life Class at the Theater Club
description: Life Class, now having its first American production at the Manhattan Theater Club, is one of David Storey's most serious, ambitious plays. Although, in common with the author's The Changing Room and The Contractor, the motif is a shared activity in this case an art class engaged in drawing a nude modelit is not, as with those other plays, principally a drama about character. Life Class is basically about the relationship between life and art.

title: Man Who Broke Up Queens Fight Died Of a Heart Attack
description: The assistant medical examfiner, John J. Furey, ruled yesterday that Frederick C. Pirona, whose body was found Thursday night in a Queens parking lot after he had intervened ?? a fight between three teenage girls, had died of a heart attack and was not a victim of homicide.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Opponent of E.R.A. Confident of Its Defeat
description: ST. LOUISPhyllis Schlafly, the 50yearold conservative Republican who heads, the nationwide crusade against the EqualRights Amendment, was rushing to a class at the Washington University Law School here the other day when she found her path blocked by a semiangry young woman student.

title: I.M.F. GOLD PLAN RUNS INTO A SNAG
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The plan of the International Monetary Fund to sell onesixth of its gold to aid the world's poorest countries is stalled, at least temporarily, by a dispute over whether central banks of individual countries can buy gold on the market at the same time.

title: Firefighting a Perilous Job
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 14 (UPI)  Firefighting is the most dangerous occupation in the United States, a firemen's union said today. The International Association of Fire Fighters said its survey showed that 84 firemen per 100,000 lost their lives on the job last year23 percent higher than 1973. That compares with an onthejob death rate of 71 per 100,000 for mining and 51 per 100,000 for police work, the association said.

title: S.I. Community Tries to Recover Statue Missing From City Parks Department
description: A proud, graceful lady who stood with flowing gowns and outstretched arms at the central crossroad of Pleasant Plains, S.I., since 1923 has disappeared, and the residents of the small community want her back.

title: Aqueduct Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Excerpts From Summary of Soviet 5Year Plan
description: The document stresses that the main socio  economic tasks of the ninth fiveyear plan have been fulfilled. The scale and technical level of production has risen, the material and technical base of all the branches of the economy has consolidated. The defense capacity of the country was insured at the appropriate level.

title: 12Day SitIn Protests Arming Of Police at California Colleges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14Student sitins aimed at disarming the campus police at two California universities entered their 12th day today with the students pledging to continue the protest through the Chrismas holidays.

title: Y.M.H.A. Ground Broken
description: Ground was broken yesterday for a $24 million Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association Community Center at Nostrand Avenue and Avenue V in the Kings BaySheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. The center, covering an area of 40,000 square feet, will be ready for use in early 1977.

title: Seoul Lists Emigrants
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 14 (UPI)A total of 34,373 South Koreans have emigrated to foreign countries so far this year, Government statistics showed today. The United States topped the list of recipient nations with 26,446, followed by Canada with 3,492 and Paraguay with 1,978.

title: Arthur Miller Turns Detective in Murder
description: In the beginning, Arthur Miller said, he was not sure. He said he had thought that Peter Reilly could have murdered his mother, but he wondered how he could have done it without getting blood on his clothes. The playwright said it bothered him.

title: Miss Moore Has Lenin On Jail Reading List
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Sara Jane Moore, waiting to hear tomorrow whether a judge will accept her surprise change to a guilty plea on charges of trying to assassinate President Ford, said in an interview today that she was reading the works of the Communist Party founder. Vladimir Ilich Lenin, in jail.

title: Arthur Treacher, 81, Butler Supreme, Dies
description: Arthur Treacher, the Englishborn actor who personified the archetypical butler in scores of plays, movies and television programs, died yesterday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Passenger Trains Collide in Portugal, Killing at Least 16
description: LISBON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)At least 16 persons were killed and up to 60 were injured when two trains collided in thick fog tonight at the small town of Fornos de Algodres, 130 miles northeast of here, a railroad sookesman said.

title: Johnstown Flood Survivor
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 14 (UPI)Alice Young, oldest local survivor of the 1889 Johnstown flood, died yesterday. She would have been 102 years old Dec. 26. In recent years, Mrs. Young has been a resident of the Presbyterian Home here. According to local records, a woman in the Lancaster area who is 102 is the oldest survivor of the Johnstown flood; which killed 2,200 persons on May 31, 1889.

title: Arthur Miller Turns Detective in Murder
description: In the beginning, Arthur Mil??er said, he was not sure. He said he had thought that Peter Reilly could have murdered his mother, but he wondered how he could have done it without getting blood on his clothes. The playwright said it bothered him.

title: Union Sues to Keep Army Base Open
description: FORT MONMOUTH, Dec. 14 A union representing employees of the Army Electronics Command here has filed suit to prevent what it considers the eventual closing of this military base, and several Monmouth County municipalities are expected to join the action this week.

title: British Football
description: By Reuters

title: Archdiocese of Newark Ordains 76 as Deacons
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14  Fifteen Spanishspeaking men were among the 76 persons ordained today as permanent deacons in the Roman Catholic Chucrh. The men, who have been training for holy orders since September, 1973, were ordained by Archbishop Peter L. Gerety in bilingual services in Sacred Heart Cathedral here.

title: KelleyStroukoff Team Wins Gold Dance on Ice
description: Susan Kelley and Andrew Stroukoff of Boston, favored to win the Gold Dance event of the 1976 Eastern Figure Skating Championship at the Sky Rink, did not disappoint their following yesterday.

title: Ohio Teacher Strike Backfires on Shanker's Union
description: SOUTH POINT, Ohio, Dec. 14 The latest battle in the war between the nation's two largest teachers' organizations, a representational skirmish in this tiny Ohio River town, has ended in embarrassment for the American Federation of Teachers.

title: FARMERS PROTEST LISBON'S POLICIES
description: RIO MAIOR, Portugal, Dec. 14Thousands of farmers, angry but orderly, held a rally there today and demanded an end to illegal occupation of land and the Government's agrarian reform program.

title: Former CBS News Executive Named Editor of The Nation
description: Blair Clark, a former general manager of CBS News and associate publisher of the New York Post, has been named editor of The Nation, a magazine of opinion.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
GEORGE W. HANDLEY, INSURANCE EXPERT
description: George W. Handley, a senior vice president and director of Marsh & McLennan Inc., international insurance brokers, who was national service officer in charge of all marine insurance for the concern, died here Thursday of a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived in Wyckoff. N.J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Nov. 20 editorial Enter Reagan raises the legitimate proposition that Governor Reagan's record should be examined in measuring his qualifications for the Presidency, yet the examination is only cursory.

title: MRS. ISAAC FELD
description: Jennie Mansh Feld, mother of Irvin Feld, president and producer of the Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died Friday in Washington, where she lived. She was 89 years old. Her husband, Isaac, died in 1946.

title: Coaches in IC4A Fight Squad Rules
description: Coaches from the IC4A member colleges have recommended that the schools withdraw from the National Collegiate Athletic Association. At a meeting at Manhattan College on Sunday, 100 coaches from 69 of the 119 schools passed a resolution calling for the withdrawal if the N.C.A.A. did not rescind its rules limiting size of traveling and home squads, numbers of coaches and meets.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, Dec. 15. 31st day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: Report on Marine's Death
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Dec. 15 (AP)A 29yearold Marine recruit who collapsed and died at the Parris Island training depot had heatstroke brought on by meningoencephalitis, according to a coroner's report. The report was filed by Beaufort County Coroner Roger Pinckney with the Naval Hospital at Beaufort, where Lawrence Warner, of Plainville, Conn., died.Dec. 3.

title: Court to Review Miranda Ruling in Test of Rights of a Suspect
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Supreme Court decided today to take another look at the guarantees set forth in one of the landmark high court rulings of the Earl Warren era the Miranda decision in 1966, which spelled out a suspect's right to remain silent in the face of police questioning.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: $1.9 BILLION G.E. BID IN MINING MERGER
description: In one of the largest acquisition proposals in the nation's history, the General Electric Company, the nation's largest maker of electric products and power equipment, announced last night that it was planning to take over Utah International Inc., a major United States mining company.

title: Creating Jobs Is Not Easy
description: WASHINGTONThis country is desperately short on public goods and services of the most basic nature, Senator Hubert Humphrey said here the other day. How ironic, how tragic it is that there are millions of idle people on the one hand and so much undone work on the other.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1975

title: Frazier: Great Year if Knicks Were Winning
description: With Walt Frazier every move has a meaning. There is a beauty and ballet to the way he plays basketball and the way he contorts his body with majestic ease. Frazier conveys excitement to those who watch his hands, his anticipation and deceptiveness. Except for his flashing eyes, the expression on his bearded face is an austere blank. He does things quickly and quietly, is seldom ruffled, seldom works up a sweat and never disputes an official's call.

title: Government Statement Due On British Chrysler's Fate
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP)British Industry Secretary Eric Varley said today he would make a Parliamentary statement tomorrow on the future of Chrysler United Kingdom Ltd., the lossridden British wilt of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: AUSTRALIA PLANS CABINET CHANGES
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 15Australia's new conservative Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, today began revising the nation's administrative system after elections that gave his coalition a strong majority and toppled the. Labor Party.

title: Ceneda Faces Jail
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 15 (AP)  Orlando Cepeda, former baseball star, was unable to raise, $5,000 cash to cover bail in Federal court today. He was charged last Friday with possession of 165 pounds of Marijuana.

title: Overhaul of SEEK Proposed in Study By University Panel
description: After a sevenmonth study, a City University task force has called for a revision of the administration of the, university's SEEK program. But at the same time the panel proclaimed the program an educational. success.

title: TV: Lear's Latest, One Day at a Time
description: This month's new Norman, Lear situation comedy is One Day at a Time. The series begins its ratings run tonight at 9:30 on CBS. Like any Lear product, it is slick in terms of thoroughly professional production values. Like any ordinary TV sitcom, though, it is also irritatingly superficial and labored.

title: Football Hearings End
description: The National Labor Relations Board's hearings into 15 National Football League Players Assocation charges of unfair labor practices against the N.F.L. Management Council and the 26 teams it represents for actions surrounding the 1974 pro football strike ended yesterday. Judge Charles W. Schneider gave attorneys for both sides 35 days to file written briefs.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Joseph, Genovese Jr, 46, Head of Drugstore Chain
description: Joseph W. Genovese Jr., board chairman of the Genovese Drug Stores Inc., a chain in Long Island, Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey, died Sunday in Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park, after surgery. He was 46 years old and lived in Syosset, L. I.

title: U.S. Aides Divided
description: PARIS, Dec. 15 Reporters aboard Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger'S plane were told today that the only choice Washington had in the Angolan situation last summer was to send military aid or to see the Westernsupported forces there collapse.

title: Church Denies CoverUp Of a Kennedy Friendship
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Senator Frank Church acknowledged today that the Senate Select. Committee on Intelligence Operations had uncovered evidence that President Kennedy and two reputed organized crime leaders had a close friendship with the same woman in 1961 and 1962. But he denied published suggestions that the committee had tried to cover up information about the matter.

title: Harold Spitzer, 72, Dies ExNassau County Judge
description: Harold M. Spitzer, who retired last year as a Nassau County Court judge, died Sunday in the South Shore Division of Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 72 years old and lived at 102 Combs Avenue, Woodmere, L.I.

title: ...and Their Limits
description: These guidelines, instead of insuring that Cointelpro is a thing of the past, seem to seek simply to legitimate a new slim version of the program under guidelines so vague as to be virtually worthless as a form of control. Thus, the projected authority to obstruct or prevent groups planning activities that might interfere substantially with the essential functioning of government might be read to permit the F.B.I. to do anything from protecting the vital work of air traffic controllers to disrupting a proposed peace march in Washington.

title: The City U. and Its Budget
description: Background

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Indiana Wins in Overtime
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15 (AP)  Topranked Indiana rallied from 4 points down to force an overtime, then subdued Kentucky, 7768, in college basketball tonight before 16,615 fans.

title: C. Arnholt Smith Is Seized on 58 Counts
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 15 (AP)C. Arnholt Smith, once an important figure in national Republican Party circles, was arrested today on 58 counts, including bank fraud.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Charging that a new State Liquor Authority rule chilled his enjoyment of nonobscene nude dancing in bars, a retired New York City policeman joined a Long Island bar in a suit to have the regulation declared unconstitutional. The suit asks for the overthrow of a rule that bans all nude dancing in bars and allows topless dancing only if it is performed on a platform at least six feet away from any customer. Charles Clancy of Island Park, joined in a suit by TimRob Bar Inc., owner of the Hillside Lounge in New Hyde Park.

title: American University of Beirut May Become a Casualty of Lebanese Civil Strife
description: The president of the American University of Beirut, a centuryold landmark in the Middle East, said here yesterday that the school might betome one of the major victims of the current civil strife in Lebanon.

title: Orchestra at Met Flans Strike for Jan. 1
description: The orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Company has called a news conference for this morning to announce that it would strike the opera Jan. 1, if no new contract were agreed by then.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Tax Advice by I.R.S. Termed Inaccurate About Half the Time
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Individuals who take their tax returns to the Internal Revenue Service for help can expect accurate assistance less than half the time, a House Government Operations subcommittee was told today.

title: I.R.A. Aid Unit in the Bronx Linked to Flow of Arms
description: DUBLIN  A major dispute over the scale of American fundraising for the Irish Republican Army has pitted officials in the United States, Britain and Ireland against a Bronxbased relief organization for Roman Catholic women and children in Ulster.

title: Summary of Actions Taken on Criminal, Civil and Rights Issues by Supreme Court at Session in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: R. F. Kelley Funeral Today
description: A mass will be offered today for Robert F. Kelley, formerly public relations director for the New York Racing Association and sports writer for The New York Times, at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N. J., at 11 A.M. Mr. Kelley died on Sunday in Huntington, L. I.

title: Tokyo's Shinjuku : Chaos of Unplanning
description: We tend to think of Japan as a land of serene, natural forms and delicate, refined objects. But there is another aspect to Japan, as honkytonk as the traditional esthetic is quiet, as chaotic as the traditional esthetic is ordered.

title: TWO WHO HELPED OTHERS EULOGIZED
description: Andrew Maresca and Frederick C. Pirtme, who did not know each other and who died one day apart last week trying to aid someone in trouble, were buried yesterday after funerals in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: HERMAN VAN DER LINDE
description: Herman J. Van der Linde, chief assistant public defender of Rockland County and a former New York City lieutenant of detectives, died yesterday at his home in West Nyack, N.Y. He was 58 years old.

title: Jude Rules Miss Moore Is Competent to Change Plea to Guilty in Ford Shooting but Defers Acceptance
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15Sara Jane Moore was ruled mentally competent in Federal court today to change her plea to guilty of attempting to assassinate President Ford here on Sept. 22.

title: SENATE APPROVES TAX CUT MEASURE; COMPROMISE FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Senate passed the taxcut bill tonight, following what appeared to be the final collapse. of efforts to reach a compromise with President Ford over a ceiling on next year's Government spending. The vote was 73 to 19.

title: Low Crowd At Opening Of Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 15Just the other night, Alan Cohen, the president of Madison Square Garden, gave a stirring preopening speech to the workers of his Garden subsidiary, Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Harlan, Ky., Blacks Fight Attempt to Displace Them
description: HARLAN, Ky., Dec. 14The civil rights movement that swept the South in the last two decades bypassed Appalachia, for the most part, which surprised few people outside of the insular region.

title: White Students in Minority
description: MOUNT VERNON  Integration? School Superintendent William C. Prattella repeated what had been the subject of an hourlong discussion in his office at the Board of Education. Frankly, we don't have enough whites to integrate. There are 12 elementary schools in this city, but whites represent a majority in only three.

title: Cosmos Purchase Two From Atoms
description: The New York Cosmos announced yesterday they had reached agreement with the Philadelphia Atoms for the purchase of Bob Rigby, a goalie, and Bob Smith, a fullback.

title: Father Is Cleared By Polygraph Test In 5 Jersey Deaths
description: TEANECK, Dec. 15Wesley Diggs, whose wife and four children were slain here Dec. 4, took a liedetector test today at the Bergen County Prosecutor's office and cleared himself as a possible suspect.

title: Music: Talent Galore
description: Between the musicians who were on the stage of Carnegie Hall last night, and those in the audience, there must have been a couple of billion dollars' worth of talent on the premises. The occasion was the 50th anniversary celebration of the W. W. Naumburg Foundation.

title: NEWCAR SALES UP 43% FOR DEC 110
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15Domestic new car sales climbed more than 43 percent in early December to an annual selling rate of 8.9 million units, the highest this year

title: Dr. Israel Baroway Dies; Taught English at Queens
description: Dr. Israel Baroway, professor emeritus of English at Queens College, died Sunday in Flushing (Queens) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 4266 Phlox Place. Flushing.

title: MADRID CABINET PLEDGES REFORMS
description: MADRID, Dec. 15The new Spanish Cabinet, in its first policy statement, promised tonight to put high priority on widening civil liberties, especially the right of association, to draw Spain closer to the Western community.

title: College Admissions Freeze
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 15 (AP)  The University of Massachusetts has imposed a oneyear freeze on admissions to its nursing program because of budget restrictions. The admissions dean, William D. Tunis, said today that no freshmen, transfer students or applicants for a second bachelor's degree would be admitted to the nursing program either in January, or September of 1976.

title: Charles Rubinger Weds Gail Cohen
description: The marriage of Gail Helene Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Cohen of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, to Charles S. Rubinger, son of Bernard Rubinger of New York and the late Mrs.. Rubinger, took place here last evening. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Farkas, sister and brotherinlaw of the bride.

title: Rise of Industrial Output Lags But Inventories Show Growth
description: Two key economic statistics announced by the Government yesterday added to the confusion about the strength of the economic recovery under way.

title: ALBANY APPROVES RESCUE MEASURES FOR 3 AGENCIES
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, Dec. 16With less than an hour to spare before the deadline, the Legislature voted last night to keep the Housing Finance Agency and two other state agencies out of default for another month as Governor Carey dropped his insistence on an immediate Republican agreement on new taxes to close the state budget gap. The Assembly vote was 120 to 15, and in the Senate the vote was 53 to 1.

title: U.S. PLANS EASING OF HEALTH RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is making final plans to weaken its rules governing home health services paid for by Medicaid, opening up this relatively new healthcare field to profitmaking companies. In most states they could operate virtually without regulation.

title: Jersey Senate Backs Longer Racing Slates
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15The New Jersey Senate unanimously approved a bill tonight that would extend thoroughbred and harness racing in the state 100 days each yearly. The vote was 33 to 0.

title: COTTON CLUB GALA HAS SONGS AND TAPS
description: In its day the Cotton Club was the cream of the Harlem night spots offering the top in popular entertainment. In its present East Village reincarnation it achieves a balance between vintage tap dance talent and younger female dancers and singers that mixes some fresh faces with proven quality. The Cotton ClubGala at the La Mama Annex glittered on Sunday evening like gold at times and iron pyrites at others but was imbued with enough energy and laughter to satisfy all but the most jaded taste.

title: White House Aid Is Sought in Strikes
description: With holiday air traffic problems steadily mounting because of the United and National Airlines strikes, the nation's travel agents have appealed to the White House to intervene.

title: Namath Is Fined Before Jets Lose
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 15San Diego's largest footballs crowd of the season, 52,446, was only briefly disappointed tonight when it was learned that Joe Namath wouldn't start for the New York Jets for disciplinary reasons. Their attention quick shifted to enjoying their team's solid 2416 victory, only the second in 13 games for the Chargers.

title: 2 LEAD PRODUCERS PLAN PRICE CUTS
description: Two major lead producers announced yesterday that they were cutting prices.

title: Israel Asking Austerity Budget To Reduce Dependence on U.S.
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15  Israel's Finance Ministry has presented to the Cabinet an austerity budget designed to help slash the nation's deficit in the balance of payments and reduce political dependence on the United States.

title: Stocks Move Narrowly; Dow Average Gains 3.78
description: Stock prices continue to mill about in a narrow range yesterday. Trading remained quiet and selective, with no indication that a yearend rally was attt hand.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: WRITERS' POLL By The Associated Press

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: LOCKHEED DATA WILL GO TO S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15A Federal Judge ordered today the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to turn over to the Securities and Exchange Commission documents relating to foreign bribery that the commission had sub??

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Press at Olympics To Be Downtown
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 15The main press center for, the 1976 Olympic Games will occupy five floors in a 40story Place Desjardins office building in downtown Montreal, Simon St. Pierre, executive vice president of the Games Organizing Committee, announced today.

title: Lockhart's Swan Song Is Full of Discord
description: As Spider Lockhart, the dean of Giant players, left Shea Stagium after Sunday's game a group of fans partying in the parking lot invited him to join them for a drink.

title: Radio
description: 7 A.M., WFUVFM. Sonatas No. 2, 4, 5, Quantz; Sonata for Cello and Piano, Prokofiev; Sonata for Cello and Piano, Shostakovich; Little Glass Wot, VillaLobos.

title: City U. Cuts $54.6 Million, Modifies Open Admissions
description: The Board of Higher Education, its hope for a reprieve from City Hall and for emergency state funds at least temporarily exhausted, last night voted to cut $54.6 million from the university system's springterm budget. It also voted to impose minimum admission standards for all new students, starting next fall.

title: House Votes Ban On TV Blackouts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed today a bill that permanently forbids professional sports teams from imposing a television blackout on soldout home games, and extends the ban to postseason playoff contests.

title: Gilbert W. Kahn, Arts Patron And Investment Banker, Dead
description: Gilbert W. Kahn, investment banker and son of the late Otto H. Kahn, banker and patron of music and art, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Old Brookville, L. I., and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Bret C. Neece, 72, Dead; Appliance Manufacturer
description: Bret C. Neece, former chairman of Landers, Frary & Clark, appliance makers of New Britain, Conn., died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 72 years old.

title: MAN HELD IN MIAMI IN KNIGHT SLAYING
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (AP)Salvatore Soli, 38 years old, the third man wanted in the killing in Philadelphia of John S, Knight 3d, was arrested here today.

title: City U. Cuts $54.6 Million, Modifies Open Admissions
description: The Board of Higher Education, its hope for a reprieve from City Hall and for emergency state funds at least temporarily exhausted, last night voted to cut $54.6 million from the university system's springterm budget. It also voted to impose minimum admission standards for all new students, starting next fall.

title: Carey Repeats His Disclaimer On Any Presidential Ambitions
description: Trying to quash speculation that he was secretly seeking, the Presidency, Governor Carey reiterated yesterday that he had no Presidential aspirations and added that he would not become involved in efforts to send an uncommitted New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention next year.

title: CAVANAGH HIRING APPROVED BY FUND
description: The Fund for the City of New York unanimously approved last evening the hiring of First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh as a $35,000ayear consultant.

title: Music: A Crisp Messiah
description: David Randolph's annual Messiah series is a popular affairSunday evening's performance at Carnegie Hall, the third in the string of five, looked nearly fulland it has some demonstrable musical virtues. The orchestra is a crisp one; the large (approximately 150 on Sunday) Masterwork Chorus sings precisely and with good tone, some tenorial scrawniness aside; the edition is complete and stylistically conscientious, even if the vocal soloists' ornamentation is inconsistently applied and executed; and all the soloists, vocal and instrumental, are at least competent, with David Britton, the tenor, Michael May, the harpsichordist  organist, and Louis Ranger, the solo trumpet, standing out.

title: Peter Kemeny, ExEditor Of Garland Publishing, 36
description: Peter Kemeny, former editor in chief of Garland Publishing, a scholarlyreprint house, was killed last Thursday when he jumped from the platform of the JRT subway station at 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, according to a spokesman for the Midtown Precinct South on West 35th Street.

title: MARKET FORCES IN OIL ARE BACKED
description: Marxet presure creates by increased oil and gas production, rather than direct negotiations with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is the best way to lower energy costs, according to a task force study released yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

title: City Ballet
description: You need a scorecard to keep up with who dances what when during The Nutcracker and Sunday's two performances at the New York State Theater were replete with newcomers to the roles this season.

title: Aluminum Shipments Plunge, but Alcoa Is Optimistic
description: The Aluminum Association reported yesterday that industry shipments for the first nine months plunged 36.2 percent from the yearago level. The trade association also reported that net shipments of sheet and plate in October, at an estimated 356.3 million pounds, ran 7.2 percent behind the September level and 19.7 percent lower than a year ago.

title: Nominee to Head the Eximbank
description: Two months ago, Stephen McKenzie DuBrul Jr., a 46yearold investment banker, was at the White House on a business matter and was introduced to Douglas P. Bennett, the White House recruiter. Mr. DuBrul was asked if he would be interested in. becoming head of the ExportImport Bank. Mr. Bennett said that Bill Casey and Bill Simon know you and think you'd be great for the job, Mr. DuBrul, a partner in the investment banking house of Lazard Frres, recalled yesterday in his office here.

title: E.E.C. Signs Patent Deal
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 (AP)The nine countries of the European Economic Community signed today an agreement on a joint patent law. This will enable an inventor to get a patent with the same legal value in each member country of the Common Market by making a single application. The nine countries are Britain, West Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Denmark, and Ireland.

title: Washington Post Guild Votes Again to Defy Pickets
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Members of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post voted for the fifth time today to cross picket lines set up by striking pressmen and mailers at the newspaper and stay at their jobs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1975

title: FELDMAN ELECTED SENATE PRESIDENT
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15  The Democrtic majorities in the New Jersey Legislature elected their new leaders today for the next two years, choosing Matthew Feldman of Bergen County as Senate President and Joseph A. LeFante of Hudson Countyas Assembly Speaker.

title: Ford Increases Its Price. On 1976 Autos by 2.2%
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15  The Ford Motor company today raised prices on its 1976 model cars an average of $97, or 2.2 percent. The move was unexpected and comes at a time when the automobile industry is in the midst of a slow recovery.

title: Bomb Found Outside Bank
description: A bomb was found at 7:55 A.M. yesterday outside the offices of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company at 20 West Broadway. The area was blocked off, and the bomb was removed by members of the Police Department bomb section.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Supreme Court refused to allow the Federal. District Court in Newark to disbar Arthur Lawrence Abrams, who had been accused of helping his client bribe Jersey City officials. The court upheld a Circuit Court ruling that the District Court had no authority in the matter because the State Supreme Court had merely suspended him from practicing in state courts for one year.

title: Poll Finds 49% Opposed To U.N: Action on Zionism
description: The Harris poll reported yesterday that 49 percent of the American people surveyed disapproved of the United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism. Nine percent approved and 42 percent were not sure.

title: COURT TO REVIEW ZONING DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Supreme Court set the stage today for a potentially farreaching decision on the duty, if any, of a white suburb or residential enclave to change its zoning to open up the area to minority group residents.

title: White Students in Minority
description: MOUNT VERNON  Integration? School Superintendent William C. Prattella repeated what had been the subject of an hourlong discussion in his office at the Board of Education. Frankly, we don't have enough whites to integrate. There are 12 elementary schools in this city, but whites represent a majority in only three.

title: Notes on People
description: It has no tinselno sequins, Betty Ford pointed out yesterday as she led a tour of the White House Christmas tree and decorations, now open to public viewing. To the 18foot New Yorkgrown Douglas fir, topped by a cornhusk angel and hung with 2,000 homemade ornaments from across the country, Mrs. Ford added a redcloth bird she had made and a yarn doll made by her daughter Susan.

title: College Admissions Freeze
description: AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 15 (AP)  The University of Massachusetts has imposed a oneyear freeze on admissions to its nursing program because of budget restrictions. The admissions dean, William D. Tunis, said today that no freshmen, transfer students or applicants for a second bachelor's degree would he admitted to the nursing program either in January or September of 1976.

title: 22 Die in Nigeria Plunge
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Twentytwo persons traveling to a Jehovah's Witnesses assembly in eastern Nigeria over the weekend were killed when their truck veered off the road from IkotEkpene to ABA, according to press reports today.

title: R. I. P.  Free Tuition
description: When the members of the New York State Board of Regents traveled to Albany last week to consider the future of the City University, the die had already been cast on one issue: free tuition had to go. There was no longer any inclination to consider the merits of a free college education, much less to reminisce about that extraordinary concept's accomplishments. This was not the time, for example, to recall that for many years City College, where free tuition had originated 128 years ago, had turned out more graduates who eventually earned Ph.D.'s than any other college until it was edged out by Berkeley, which was part of the only other tuitionfree highereducation system.

title: Dutch Quarrels With Mediators Prolong Siege
description: AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 15Differences between the Dutch Government and mediators appear to be holding up efforts to win the release of 25 hostages held by seven Asian terrorists in the Indonesian Consulate here.

title: U.S. Offers Iran 10 of Its Costliest Radar Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The United States has offered to sell 10 of its most sophisticated radarsurveillance planes to Iran at a price of $187 milIlion each, Pentagon officials said today.

title: U.S. Juniors Score In Team Tennis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 15 (AP)Nial Brash and Walter Redondo got the United States off to a successful start in its bid for a third straight Sunshine Cup junior tennis team title by defeating Yugoslavia today, 20.

title: Dollar Gains in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 (UPI)The dollar maintanied its strong upward trend in Europe today, driving the British pound to a record low close against the United States currency.

title: TV: One Day at a Time
description: This month's new Norman Lear situation comedy is One Day at a Time. The series begins its ratings run tonight at 9:30 on CBS. Like any Lear product, it is slick in terms of thoroughly professional production values. Like any ordinary TV sitcom, though, it is also irritatingly superficial and labored.

title: Intruder Reported Seized Twice On the Grounds of White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Secret Service confirmed tonight that a man scaled the iron fence into the grounds of the White House the night before Thanksgiving and after being released on his own recognizance broke into the grounds again 10 days later.

title: Helping New York
description: To the people who live in the 1,000 small houses with postage  stamp patches of lawn in one corner of Jamaica, Queens, Irving Cline is known as the Man on the Bike.

title: Nuggets Trounce Squires, 131 to 110
description: NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 (AP)  The Denver Nuggets, led by David Thompson, shot 70 percent in the first half tonight and routed the Virginia Squires, 131110, in an American Basketball Association game before a capacity crowd of 10,010.

title: DENTAL SCHOOL GETS STATUS RESTORED
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 15 (UPI)The American Dental Association has restored full accreditation to the Fairleigh Dickinson University Dental School here, university officials announced today.

title: Former Brandt Aide and Wife Convicted as Spies
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Dec. 15 (Reuters)  A onetime close aide of former Chancellor Willy Brandt was found guilty of treason today and sentenced to 13 years in prison.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 15Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: MONTY PYTHON SUING TO STOP TV SPECIAL
description: Monty Python, the British comedy team, filed suit in Federal District Court yesterday to prevent ABCTV from broadcasting a Monty Python special on Dec. 26.

title: Coming Clean on Angola
description: One thing ought to be beyond debate about United States policy toward the catastrophic civil war in Angola: If there is a case for American help for the forces resisting the Sovietaided Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), it should be made openly before the Congress and the country.

title: Stenmark Triumphs In Slalom
description: VIPITENO, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP)Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden dominated both heats of the men's special slalom today and took the lead in the World Cup standings.

title: Donor to Fund for the Neediest Was Inspired by Ali.
description: An upstate reader who saw that remark by Muhammad Ali when the boxer voluntered to provide financial support for a center for aged. persons has, in turn, helped the 64th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Seattle Group Aims To Purchase Giants
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 15 (AP)A Seattle delegation that failed to get the Chicago White Sox for this Northwest city is making an effort to buy the San Francisco Giants.

title: SWISS BANK AGREES ON FUND TRANSFER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (Reuters)The Swiss Credit Bank has agreed to deposit and maintain funds in its New York branch equal to an amount held in Zurich by the defendants in a Securities and Exchange Commission suit, an S.E.C. spokesman has said.

title: OUTGOING U.S. ENVOY CHIDED BY TRUDEAU
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 15 (AP)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the departing United States ambassador might have stepped out of bounds in criticizing Canadian policies.

title: Bridge:
description: Winning by losing is what W. S. Gilbert would have called a most ingenious paradox.

title: Makeshift Repairs Give Stranded Tenants a Lift
description: One of the two elevators at 200 East 16th Street was working a little yesterday.

title: Kong Nickname Put On the Right Last Name
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Governor Byrne apparently got his nicknames mixed up over the weekend in a message read for him at a fundraising affair for Senator Harrison A. Williams.

title: PRICERISE CURBS SET FOR CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 15Strict new regulations to curb price rises were announced today by the Government a few hours before Canada's antiinflation guidelines for industry and labor were scheduled to become law.

title: Kissinger Visits Home Town, Gets Big Hand
description: FURTH, West Germany, Dec. 15Heinz Alfred Kissinger was a 15yearold secondaryschool student when he left Forth in August 1938, just ahead of the Nazi onslaught that claimed the lives of most of the 3,000 members of the Jewish community and destroyed seven of, the town's eight synagogues.

title: U.S. Asks Israeli Consultation on Raids
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15The Ford Administration is insisting on closer consultations with Israel in advance of any such sensitive political and military moves as the recent Israeli air raids against Palestinian targets in Lebanon, Israeli and American sources said today.

title: Chess:
description: Whoever neglects rookandpawn endings doesn't know what he is missing in terms of complex adventures and additional games won. After all, the Cuban genius Jos Raul Capablanca, world champion from 1921 to 1927, is said to have studied 1,000 rook  and  pawn endings, though he never felt the need to pursue systematically any other aspect of the game.

title: Survey of Children's TV Finds Ads Shorter but Not Fewer
description: Television networks and staions have reduced the amount of commercial time in children's programs by about 15 percent since 1971, yet the average number of advertisements in those programs hardly declined at all, according to a new study of Saturday and Sunday morning programming commissioned by Action for Children's Television, a Bostonbased consumeroriented organization.

title: Energy and ConstructionPicket Bills Are Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Starting its final week before adjournment, Congress pressed ahead today on two controversial measures that face possible Presidential vetoes.

title: JOAN LITTLE'S BOND INCREASED $10,000
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 15 (AP) The Chief Justice of the state Supreme Court increased Joan Little's bond from $15,000 to $25,000 today in her appeal of a breaking and entering conviction.

title: Books of The Times
description: Has the discovery of America been beneficial or harmful to the human race? This was thetopic of an essay competition sponsored by a French scholar in 1785. Of the eight essays that survive, four argue that it was and four that it was not. No prize was awarded.

title: People in Sports
description: For leading Navy to its first winning season since 1967, George Welsh was named yesterday recipient of the annual Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Trophy as the East's majorcollege football coach of the year.

title: MEXICO AGAIN VOTES TO ASSAIL ZIONISM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15Mexico declared in the General Assembly today that it did not equate Zionism with racism, but then voted for endorsement of International Women's Year decisions linking the two.

title: Cavanagh's Hiring As Fund Consultant Unanimously Voted
description: The Fund for the City of New York unanimously approved last evening the hiring of First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh as a $35,000ayear consultant.

title: SWISS FRANC ENTRY IN FLOAT IS PUT OFF
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Common Market finance ministers today postponed indefinitely attempts to bring the Swiss franc into their joint currency float but agreed to associate Switzerland with their daytoday currency support operations.

title: City Sponsors Drive to Give Aid to the Arts
description: A drive to raise $7 million to $10 million to support the city's crisisridden cultural institutions over the next two years was announced yesterday at an emergency meeting of concerned groups called by Martin E. Segal, chairman of, the city's Commission for Cultural Affairs.

title: City Links to Nature
description: Like most other institutions in this city, the New York Zoological Society is in financial trouble. While the society, which operates the Bronx Zoo and the Aquarium at Coney Island, is not a public agency61 percent of its budget is privately contributedit has until now been able to count on getting a sizable share of that budget from the city and the State Council on the Arts. With city and state just eluding bankruptcy, it will now have to get a much larger share from private contributions if it is to carry on a tradition that has made it an outstanding source of pleasure, education and animal conservation.

title: Section of Report Referring to Kennedy Friendship
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Following is the text of a section of a report released Nov. 20 by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on United States involvement in foreign assassination plots that touches on President Kennedy's relationship with a friend who also had ties to two hoodlums:

title: KEEPING OF U.D.C. IS URGED BY PANEL
description: The special commission investigating the collapse of the State Urban Development Corporation recommended yesterday that the agency be continued and that it undertake additional projects, but with basic reforms to prevent a repetition of the conditions that led to its downfall.

title: Parseghian in Town
description: Ara Parseghian will make an announcement here about his plans today, but the former Notre Dame coach cautioned that they did not concern the Jets. He is joining Viacom International, which produced such television shows as Hogan's Heroes and I Love Lucy.

title: Senate Schedules a Closed Session on Covert U.S. Role in Angola
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Senate postponed action today on a $120.9 billion defense appropriations bill and set Wednesday for a closed session on the United States' involvement in Angola.

title: Probable LineUps In N.F.L. Playoffs
description: The National Football League announced yesterday the site of two of the four postseason games scheduled for Dec. 2728 and held off on the other two until the makeup of the eight teams is finally determined this weekend with the close of the regular 14week campaign. The Pittsburgh Steelers, Central Division champions of the. American Conference, will be a home team on Dec. 27 and so will the Oakland Raiders, victors in the A.F.C. Western Division, the next day. The probable playoff pairings follow with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: ALBANY APPROVES RESCUE MEASURES FOR 3 AGENCIES
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15With less than an hour to spare before a midnight deadline, the Legislature tonight voted to keep the Housing Finance Agency and two other state agencies out of default for another month as Governor Carey dropped his insistence on an immediate Republican agreement on new taxes to close the state budget gap. The. Assembly vote was 120 to 15, and in the Senate the vote was 53 to 1.

title: $2 Billion City Loans Clear Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Congress gave final approval today to a $2.3 billion appropriation for seasonal loans for New York City, and sent the measure to President Ford for his expected swift signature and implementation.

title: What's in a Designer's Name? More Men Say It Spells Style
description: If you're not a man who can throw a baseball through the eye of a needle at 100 miles an hour or thread a golf ball consistently through every hazard man and nature can devise, perhaps the next best thing to be, these days, is a man whose name speaks of some familiarity with a needle, thread, cloth and design.

title: Arthur Miller and Others Contend Clock Absolves Youth Convicted of Matricide
description: After Arthur Miller approadhed The New York Times, he and a reporter visited detectives from the Sixth Homicide Zone in Harlem. They are tough, skeptical men, and they investigate nearly 300 homicides a year.

title: Market Place
description: The persistent theme of most professional money managers is that common stocks offer the best route to financial security. They consider the last five years, which include the worst bear market since the 1930's, an aberration.

title: The F.B.I. Guidelines . .
description: After the blizzard of profoundly troubling revelations of abuses of power perpetrated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation through its counterintelligence program (Cointelpro), the longawaited Department of Justice guidelines ostensibly designed to bring the bureau under departmental control are deeply disappointing.

title: Communists Forging Gentle Laotians Into More Spartan Society
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 11With a blend of moderate methods but revolutionary goals, the new Communist rulers of Laos have begun transforming the gentle people of this nation into a more regimented, spartan society.

title: Demarest Passes Antiloitering Ordinance
description: DEMAREST, Dec. 15 Hundreds of residents, most of them youngsters, gathered for the annual Christmas lighting of the borough's 35foot spruce, tree tonight, just before the Borough Council enacted an ordinance designed to prevent youngsters from hanging around.

title: Udall Opens Fund Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Representative Morris K. Udall said today that he was beginning a drive to raise $2.3 million for his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, primarily through contributions of $256 or less. The Arizona Congressman announced what he called lean cat program to supplement by April 1 the $750,000 that has been raised for his campaign far.

title: TakeOut Drive Is Shelved
description: New York's downstate harness tracks reportedly have temporarily abandoned their campaign for a higher parimutuel takeout on daily doubles and exactas.

title: PUPILS SUSPENDED AT HIGH IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)About half the white pupils at South Beston High School were suspended today after they walked out in an antibusing demonstration.

title: Foreign Markets
description: BRUSSELS (In Belgian francs)

title: U.S. Officials Discount Data on a New Disease
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 15Dr. Leonard Bachman, Pennsylvania's Health Secretary, said today that Federal health officials had concluded that facts supplied by Dr. Buford S. Washington, State Commissioner for Regional and Local Health, were insufficient to prove that he had uncovered a new disease termed pantosomatitis.

title: Manning Sidelined
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15 (AP)Archie Manning, the New Orleans quarterback, will be sidelined Sunday when the Saints meet the Chicago Bears, a spokesman for the National Football League team said today. Manning has been suffering with a sore throwing arm, and Coach Ernie Hefferle has decided to start a secondyear pro, Larry Cipa.

title: Kissinger Visits Home Town, Gets Big Hand
description: FURTH, West Germany, Dec 15Heinz Alfred Kissinger was, a 15yearold secondary school student when he left Frth in August 1938, just ahead of the Nazi onslaught that claimed the lives of most of the 3,000 members of the Jewish community and destroyed seven of the town's eight synagogues.

title: 3D INVESTMENT FIRM IS MOVING TO JERSEY
description: The Ukrainian National Association, owner of a 15story office building in Jersey City, disclosed yesterday that it had signed a contract to lease space to William V. Frankel & Company, a Wall Street investment dealer.

title: South Africa Says 61 of Enemy Were Killed at Angolan Border
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 15 (Reuters)South African troops were reported today to have killed 61 SouthWest African guerrillas in a battle inside Angola.

title: Church Denies CoverUp Of a Kennedy Friendship
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Senator Frank Church acknowledged today that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Operations had uncovered evidence that President Kennedy and two reputed organized crime leaders had a close friendship with the same woman in 1961 and 1962. But he denied published suggestions that the committee had tried to cover up information about the matter.

title: A Court Challenge Is Planned
description: NEWBURGH  Newburgh doesn't need Nyquist to tell it how to run its schools, said Edwin F. Klotz the other day. The local board alone has the right to assign pupils. We will fight him every inch of the way.

title: LAYOFFS PROTESTED BY L.I.R.R. POLICE
description: The police on the Long Island Rail Road staged a rally yesterday to protest the layoff of 20 of 144 in their ranks. Addressing 50 people who had turned out, Ken McFeeley, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said:

title: For a Dispossessed Farming Family, Lisbon's Agrarian Reform Is 'Robbery
description: LISBON, Dec. 15The Silvestre Ferreira family used to claim proudly that they owned the best dairy and grape farm in southern Portugal. Now they have lost everything.

title: Advertising
description: In advertising circles the old Schaefer beer campaign The one beer to have when you're having more than onewas considered by many the most effective beer advertising around because it appealed to the heavy user who accounted for a major part of consumption.

title: '70 Effort by Hoover to Discredit Jane Fonda Described in Memo
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15J. Edgar Hoover sought to discredit Jane Fonda in 1970 by authorizing the Federal Bureau of Investigation to send a letter to a Hollywood columnist accusing the actress of leading a refrain about killing President Nixon, according to a memorandum introduced in Federal District Court here today.

title: Dr. Mary Petermann, 67, Cancer Researcher, Dead
description: Dr. Mary L. Petermann, a biochemist who pioneered at the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research in defining rihosomes and clarifying their role in protein synthesis, died Saturday of cancer in the American Oncologic Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 67 years old.

title: Neeld, OneEyed Player, Makes Debut as Pro
description: Remember Greg Nee??, The 20yearold defenseman who was barred from the Natidnal Hockey League last summer because he had only one eye? Last Friday night he made his professional debut with the Toronto Toros ofthe World Hockey Association and nearly flubbed it. The Toros were fighting to hold a 43 lead over the Quebec Nordiques in the third period when Neeld took the puck in his own end and passed it right to Marc Tardif of the Nordiques. The W.H.A.'s leading scorer hit it into the Toros' net tying the game. Toronto, however, won, 64.

title: The Sleep of New Jersey
description: There are going to be some very cross Mafia dons if Jimmy Hoffa's body turns out to be buried in New Jersey. New Jersey is to the Mafia what the Arlington National Cemetery is to the Pentagon. The godfathers are strict about who is entitled to be buried there, and anyone who violates the rigid code of respect for the Jersey soil by interring an unqualified body is liable to have his own body left in a car trunk in the Bronx.

title: Richardson Will Not Run
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP)United States Ambassador Elliot L. Richardson rejected today any effort to enter his name in the 1976 Republican Presidential contest. He said he intended to take legal steps to have his name withdrawn from the Massachusetts Presidential primary.

title: Pennsylvania Aide Acquitted
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (UPI) George W. Collitt, 59 years old, of Harrisburg, the state's chief tax investigator, was acquitted in Federal District Court today of a charge of accepting a $500 payment from a cigarette wholesaler here in October. 1971.

title: Deaths
description: ABELESSol F., beloved husband of Lillian devoted father of Daniel Abeles and udith Si??. Cherished grandfather of Mitchell and Pamela Stein, dear brother of Edith Abeles and Sylvia Abramson. Service held december 15th

title: DRILLING IS BEGUN OFF STATE RESORT
description: SEA ISLE CITYDrilling for oil and natural gas off the New Jersey coast began today at a site about 85 miles northeast of this Cape May County resort.

title: Blues Select Boivin
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (AP)Leo Boivin, who played in the National Hockey League for 19 years, has been named assistant coach to the St. Louis Blues.

title: Death Sentence Is Imposed in Murder Of a Yonkers Policeman in '74 Holdup
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 15Acting Supreme Court Justice Howard Jones sentenced a man to death, today, noting that the sentence might have been averted if the man had disclosed the identity of the person who masterminded the crime for which he was convicted.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: SIXTH$12,000, allow., 3YO and up, 7f.

title: Rail Plan Called an Aid To Freight Service Here
description: Reorganization of railroad service in the Northeast and Midwest through the restructuring of bankrupt lines is expected to provide major improvements in freighthandling facilities here and to preserve endang??red freight routes serving the Port of New York.

title: Courts Used by Nadjari Withstand a Challenge
description: The Supreme Court yesterday refused to hear an appeal challenging the legality of the creation of a special term of the New York State Supreme Court to hear corruption cases presented by the special state prosecutor for New York City, Maurice H. Nadjari.

title: Dance: Night Journey a la Graham
description: Oedipal passions seem so natural to Martha Graham that they are scarcely complex. However her Night Journey, which was given for the first time this season at the Mark Hellinger Theater last night, this retelling of the Oedipus and Jocasta story has a very special intensity. In Graham dramaturgy love is either very simplea collision of celestial bodiesor quite convolutedly complicated.

title: VOTERS APPROVED CHARITY GAMBLING
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15  An amendment to the State Constitution that could pave the way for charitable groups to sponsor socalled Las Vegas Nights in New York was narrowly approved by the state's voters last month, the official tally showed today.

title: French Police Raid Homes and Offices Of Military's Foes
description: PARIS, Dec. 15 (AP)Security forces entered apartments and offices of antimilitarists in cities throughout France this morning, seizing documents and detaining a number of persons for questioning in connection with what the Government considers a conspiracy to demoralize the armed forces.

title: Lie Test Clears Diggs In Slaying of His Family
description: TEANECK, Dec. 15Wesley Diggs, whose wife and four children were slain here Dec. 4, took a liedetector test today at the Bergen County Prosecutor's office and cleared himself as a possible suspect.

title: SENATE APPROVES TAX CUT MEASURE; COMPROMISE FAILS;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Senate passed the taxcut bill tonight, following what appeared to be the final collapse of efforts to reach a compromise with President Ford over a ceiling on next year's Government spending. The vote was 73 to 19.

description: We all know it wellthat sinking feeling as the number of days before Christmas get fewer, and the number of crossedoff items on our gift lists seems to remain static.

description: Outgoing

title: People and Business
description: Richard O. Simpson, who recently announced his retirement as head of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, says senior members of the Federal agency's staff have drawn up a plan to phase the agency out of existence by 1982.

title: RED STONG, 73, WROTE COLUMN ON SCIENCE
description: Clair L. Stong, engineer, science writer and conductor of the Amateur Scientist column in the monthly Scientific American, died last Tuesday of cancer at his home in Dongan Hills, S. I. He was 73 years old and also lived in Vresco, Pa.

title: I.R.A. Aid Unit in the Bronx Linked to Flow of Arms
description: DUBLIN  A major dispute over the scale of American fundraising for the Irish Republican Army has pitted officials in the United States, Britain and Ireland against a Bronxbased relief organization for Roman Catholic women and children in Ulster.

title: Ford Tacitly Approves Attack on Reagan by Callaway
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15President Ford gave his tacit approval today to a sharp attook made by his campaign manager this weekend on Ronald Reagan, who is challenging Mr. Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: New Truce in Lebanon Slows Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15Fighting in Beirut and other parts of Lebanon tapered off today for the first time in a week as the battling private armies of Moslems and Christians, prodded by the Palestinians and the Lebanese Army, appeared to be moving warily and reluctantly toward the observance of yet another ceasefire.

description: Theodore W. Kheel met yesterday with negotiators for The New York Post and the Newspaper Guild in an effort to help resolve their differences and avert a strike threatened for 6 A.M. Thursday.

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

description: Football is said to prepare a college player for the bigger game of life. Football indeed, all sportsare supposed to be as important to a student's development as logic, literature and philosophy.

C. authority to issue qualification standards and financial responsibility requirements for investment advisers.

title: WILLIAM J. EARLEY
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 15 (AP)William J. Earley, a former halfback at the University of Notre Dame, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while playing golf. He was 54 years old.

title: The Primary Problem
description: Senator Mondale of Minnesota has joined the ranks of thoughtful politicians who are bent on modifying that once highly touted reform, the Presidential primary. The nominating process has come a long distance since such progressive states as Oregon and Wisconsin offered the direct primary as the way to freedom from party bosses. That purpose was sometimes well served; but, as with so many cures, the sideeffects have proved harmful in their own right.

title: E.P.A.'s Report on Concorde Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The transport counselors for the British and French Embassies accused the Environmental Protection Agency today of overstating the noise impact of the Concorde supersonic passenger jet.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 The following tables, based on data from the Congressional Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, show the Federal income tax that will be paid, by families of different size with typical deductions under present law, under the bill passed by the House of Representatives and under the Senate bill:

title: 1,000 Teachers Face End of Sabbaticals
description: The Board of Education expects to learn today whether it has City Hall approval for its plan to save $9 million by recalling 1,000 teachers who are now on oneyear sabbatical leaves.

title: Paktank Texas Is Planning To Merge Into Robertson
description: Pakhoed Holding N. V. of Rotterdam and Robertson Distribution Systems Inc. of Houston announced yesterday that Paktank Texas Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Pakhoed, would be merged into Robertson. It approved by holders of twothirds of the outstanding shares of Robertson, a merger would then take place whereby Robertson would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Pakhoed, and a $22 cash payment by Pakhoed would be made for each of Robertson's 1.16 million shares outstanding.

title: ... Meanwhile, Humans Eat Pet Food
description: RICHMOND, Va.The first time I witnessed people eating pet foods was among neighbors and acquaintances during my youth in the South. At that time it was not uncommon or startling to me to see clogfood patties sizzling in a pan on the top of a stove or kerosene space heater in a dilapidated house with no running water, no refrigerator, no heat, no toilet and the unrelentingstench of decaying insects. I simply thought of it as the unfortunate but unavoidable consequence of being poor in the South.

title: ROBERT L. GARNER, WORLD BANK AIDE
description: Robert L. Garner, a vice president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in its early years and the first president of its affiliate, the International Finance Corporation, died Saturday in Oklahoma City, where he was visiting his daughter. He was 81 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Prices of Grains and Soybeans Decline
description: Soybean and grain futures prices moved downward again yesterday, following through on the sharp break in prices last Friday. Some soybean con tracts made new lifeofcontract lows, including March de livery, which closed at $4.55, off 3 cents a pound, after being as low as 54.49 a bushal.

title: El BARS PLEDGE ON '76 TICKET SPOT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15George Bush, President Ford's choice for Director of Central Intelligence, refused today to pledge, as a prerequisite for Senate confirmation, that he would not accept a nomination as Vice President.

title: BISHOPS OF ITALY ASSAIL RED PARTY
description: ROME, Dec. 15The Roman Catholic Church intensified its effort to mobilize voters in Italy against the Communist Party today with a new attack saying that one cannot be a Christian and a Marxist at the same time.

title: Charity Gambling Won by 5,274 Votes; Lost in Early Count
description: ALBANY, Dec. 15An amendment to the State Constitution that could pave the Way for charitable groups to sponsor socalled Las Vegas Night's in New York was narrowly approved by the state's voters last month, the official tally showed today.

title: FOREIGN MINISTERS OF EAST BLOC MEET
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP)A conference of foreign ministers from Sovietbloc nations opened today in Moscow, the press agency Tass reported.

title: Legislature Fails to Vote Medicaid and Fare Funds
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15Efforts by Governor Byrne to head off planned cuts in state Medicaid subsidy program and new fare increases next year on New Jersey's railroads and buses succeeded in part this evening when a $27 million supplemental budget appropriation cleared the Senate.

title: Timorese Warns the U.N. About Another Vietnam
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15Jos Ramos Horta, representing the leftist Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor, told the Security Council today that there was another Vietnam in the making unless the United Nations prevailed on Indonesia to withdraw the troops it dispatched to the Portuguese colonly nine days ago.

title: The City Manager of Yonkers Refuses to Resign Under Fire
description: YONKERS, Dec. 15  City Manager J. Emmett Casey refused today to resign despite efforts by Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, a Republican, and some Democrats on the City Council to force his ouster.

title: African Leaders Confer
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 15 (AP)The presidents of Kenya and Zambia today blamed foreign involvement for stepping up the Angolan civil war, called for an immediate ceasefire and urged the three rival factions to form a government of national unity.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THEY'RE HERE The circus opens tonightnot Ringling Brothers but the Soviet Circus (formerly called the Moscow Circus), playing 32 performances at the Felt Forum through Jan. 4, when the troupe tours the country for the first time since 1972. This is the company's fifth return engagement. For the novice American viewer, each act is traditionally performed in a single center ring, Europeanstyle.

title: U.S. NOTES ARE SET WITH LOWER YIELD
description: The $2.5 billion of twoyear notes that the United States Treasury has scheduled for sale today will likely yield 7.25 percent to 7.30 percent, Government bond dealers estimated yesterday as bond prices advanced in a continuation of the move toward lower interest rates that began last Wednesday.

title: CALIFORNIA DOCTORS START A SLOWDOWN
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15Some 10,000 physicians in Southern California began a work slowdown today to protest skyrocketing rates for malpractice insurance.

title: Sammartino Winner
description: Bruno Sammartino, the Worldwide Wrestling Federation heavyweight champion, defeated Ivan Koloff in their fourth meeting last night. The match went on with a 12foot high fence within the ring at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 26,350, including 4,253, who paid to see it on closed circuit in the Felt Forum.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing

title: $1.9 BILLION G.E. BID IN MINING MERGER
description: In one of the largest acquisition proposals in the nation's history, the General Electric Company, the nation's largest, maker of electric products and power equipment, announced last night that it was planning to take over Utah International Inc., a major United States mining company.

title: VICTIM'S PARENTS SUE ON INSURANCE
description: NEWARK, Dec. 15 (AP)Nine months ago, Claudius Giesick admitted killing his wife, Patricia, to collect $250,000 in insurance on her life. He got a 21year jail term.

title: In Memoriam
description: CHARNEYGeorge (19551975), was a rare and precious human being. He was sensitive and compassionate, wise and witty, and the most decent man anyone could know. There was never a harsh ward from him except when he scourged Ignorance and bigotry. We are richer for having known him. All His Friends Who Loved Him.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Perhaps the setting for the Super Bowl games is too warm, too sunny. Too nice, really. Perhaps that's why the Super Bowl games are relatively unexciting. Perhaps the Super Bowl games should be played in cold and gloom. Those are the elements that usually surround the memorable pro football games, as they did Sunday when the Baltimore Colts won in overtime from the Miami Dolphins, 107, on Toni Linhart's 31yard field goal. Cold and gloom enhance pro football because pro football isn't a nice game that needs warmth and sun. Tennis is a nice game. Golf is a nice game. Baseball is a nice game. But pro football is a hard, rough game. Cold and gloom stimulate pro football's combative atmosphere. And in Baltimore on Sunday, it was cold but not too cold. It was gloomy enough for the lights in Memorial Stadium to be on. It even was foggy. And those elements contributed to a December game, the kind that turns a team's history, the kind the players and the people remember.

title: The Power Defaults On Beame 2 Times Atop Trade Tower
description: Mayor Beame got a first hand lesson yesterday in what the failure of power at the highest level means.

title: Study of Oil Concerns' Pollution Finds U.S. Role Is Major Factor
description: A twoyear study of air and water pollution by the nation's leading oil refineries has concluded that the caliber of governmental regulation is a more important factor in abatement than even a refinery's ownership.

title: Dancing for the Kaiser, a New Play Gone Old
description: Andre Colmar's new play, Dancing for the Kaiser, which opened Sunday at the Circle Repertory Company, is designed to resemble an old play. It not only takes place in 1918, but it also could have been written in 1918. It is an intricate yarn about an American dancer (somewhat like Isadora Duncan) who srole as Oscar Wilde's Salome triggers a moral crisis and a political dispute in wartime London.

title: Jackson in Bay State Race
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington announced today that he would enter in the Demlocratic primary in Massachusetts, taking a strong stand against forced busing. Senator Jackson is one of 16 potential starters in the party's March 2 primary. He said he would make a decision in a few days about entering New Hampshire's earlier Presidential primary.

title: Manslaughter Conviction
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 16 (AP)John H. Bailey, 24 years old, was convicted of manslaughter today in the shooting, of a 13yearold black girl after she allegedly stole peaches from a tree in his backyard. Mr. Bailey, who is white, was found guilty by a Superior Court jury of seven men and five women.

title: Police Seize 6 as Gamblers
description: Police officers yesterday raided a luncheonette at 507 West 159th Street in Washington Heights that they said was used as the headquarters for a policy gambling ring. They took into custody four men and two women and seized $35,000 in cash, four handguns, two shotguns and electronic equipment used to record wagers.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Dance: Miss Graham's Americana
description: Martha Graham is not so much a specially American choreographer as a peculiarly American choreographer. Modern dance is perhaps the only art formno, it is the only art formthat is indigenous to the United, States, and Miss Graham, as it were, is even more indigenous than most. She is an emblazoned eagle on the banner of American dance.

title: PARLEYS CONTINUE ON POST CONTRACT
description: Negotiators for The New York Post and the Newspaper Guild continued their bargaining talks yesterday in an attempt to reach agreement on a new contract and to avoid a strike threatened for 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: A CITY NOTES BILL STALLS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 61The Legislature abruptly recessed tonight in the face of strenuous objections by New York City officials to a bill that would have required the Emergency Financial Control Board to set aside nearly $100 million of city revenues each year for the next three years to pay off the holders of oneyear City notes when the threeyear moratorium on their payment ends.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Reeducation Keeps Laotians Up Late
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 11 Well after midnight on a recent warm evening, a tired peasant interrupted a young Pathet Lao official who was leading villagers in one of the sessions that are being called reeducation classes.

title: UNITED AND EASTERN SHOW SHARP LOSSES
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, and Eastern Airlines, the fourth largest, both reported yesterday sharp losses for November, although both carriers in that month were beneficiaries of additional traffic with National Airlines closed by a strike since Labor Day.

description: A Federal District Court judge issued a permanent injunction blocking proposed increases in mail rates that were to have gone into effect Dec. 28. Page 13.

description: The landmark status of Grand Central Terminal was reinstated yesterday when the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court voted 3 to 2 to overturn a decision by Justice Irving H. Saypol.

title: Davis Cup Restored to Prominence
description: The Davis Cup, long criticized as an outmoded, lackluster event, has gripped world attention again with one of its biggest weekends coming up I Sweden vs. Czechoslovakia at Stockholm in the 1975 final and the United States vs. Mexico at Mexico City in a 1976 American Zone semifinal.

title: Soviet Will Start Regular SST Air Service on Dec. 25
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (UPI)The Soviet Union announced today that the world's first supersonic airline service would begin Dec. 25, beating the BritishFrench Concorde into regular operation by 27 days.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: COACHES' POLL

title: People and Business
