description: Robert Blackwell, Assistant. Secretary of Cornmerde for Martime Affairs, arrived in Moscow yesterday in an attempt to resolve a dispute over shipping rates far :grain transported to the Soviet Union in United States vessels.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Toward a Thorough Defense Review

title: Floor Changes Urged
description: The New York Stock Exchange's floor committee has recommended trading  floor changes that would affect the operations of a great many members. Page 78.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Hillside Aged Program Center in Washington Heights was supposed to be shuttered and empty, but it was the scene of a celebration.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Notes on People
description: You would have thought that John V. Lindsay was still Mayor to hear him defend New York City yesterday before 500 members of the National Recycling Industries at the WaldorfAstoria. In answer to a Chicago questioner, who asked how it was that Mayor Richard J. Daley seemed to run things better, Mr. Lindsay said that Chicago doesn't have to pay a dime for welfare and almost nothing to hospitals.

title: And at Namibia's Back They Hear . . .
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest AfricaThe chaotic Angolan civil war between rival guerrilla groups and their sponsors in this vast territory's northern neighbor scares the wits out of almost everyone here.

title: POLLUTION DATA STIRS CHALLENGE
description: Most of the companies discussed in the report by the Council on Economic Priorities on oil refinery pollution said yesterday they found the work flawed.

title: JOHN PRINE APPEARS AT OTHER END CLUB
description: John Prine, the singer, is back working in small clubs with no group, just himself, his music and guitar. The result is a mixed bag. Unloading the negative first, Mr. Prine, who appeared at the Other End club on Monday, merely uses his guitar as a prop for his voice rather than a partner. He is very functional in this area and is also given to using a few variants of folkcountry music tunes, on which he grafts his lyrics.

title: United Airlines to Resume Talks Friday With Striking Machinists
description: The National Mediation Board yesterday called United Airlines and its striking machinists' union back to the bargainling table Friday in a resumed effort to end the 11day walklout that has crippled holiday air traffic.

title: TAX CUT BILL HITS A SNAG IN HOUSE IN A TEST ON VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The House of Representatives failed today to muster the twothirds majority needed under a special procedure to pass a bill for tax reductions next year. The failure suggested that the House might have trouble overriding President Ford's promised veto.

title: FORD SAID TO BAR A COMBAT ROLE IN ANGOLAN WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16President Ford has ruled out any form of combat intervention in Angola, including the sending of advisers, according to high and authoritative Administration officials, and Will not go beyond the current program of aiding two factions fighting a group supported by the Soviet Union.

title: Mayor of Yonkers Asks Ouster of City Manager
description: YONKERS, Dec. 16  Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli today charged his City Manager, J. Emmett Casey, with fiscal mismanagement and said he would ask the City Council to dismiss him.

title: STATE CITES ERRORS IN WELFARE CHECKS
description: A sample study of New York City welfare checks cashed outside the state that a quarter of them had been is sud improperly because of administrative deficiencies and welfare recipient wrongdoing, Richard, V. Horan, the state Welfare Inspector General, said yesterday.

title: Strauss Has a Plan for Convention Unity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16If the Democratic National Convention is deadlocked on a Presidential nomination after two ballots, Robert S. Strauss, the party chairman, plans to ask a representative negotiating committee of leading delegates to put together a unity ticket.

title: NoFault Premiums Up By 20% as Awards Rise
description: ALBANY, Dec. 16  Sharp rises in the cost of no fault auto insurance have led the state to permit companies to charge customers premium increases averaging 20 percent, thus wiping out the original savings built into the system.

title: G.&W. Declares Dividend
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (Reuters)Directors of Gulf and Western Industries Inc. declared today a 10 percent common stock dividend. It is payable Feb. 13 to shareholders of record Jan. 16. The company plans to continue its present quarterly cash dividend rate of 15 cents a share after the stock dividend.

title: $19,600 Bid Succeeds In Buying a Firehouse.
description: An abandoned threestory firehouse in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn was bought at an auction yesterday by a young man who turned pale with surprise when bidding stopped with his offer of $19,600.

title: Check for the Neediest Gives Donor a Good Feeling
description: Scores of letters to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund tell of the contributors' concern for the plight of those less fortunate. With the Christmas season here, many who give have the same thought that was expressed by one donor, Mrs. Robert Mathilde Christatos of East 62d Street.

title: SUCREST RAISES SUGAR PRICE 25C
description: The Sucrest Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the price of industrial sugar by 25 cents, effective today. This will make the new Mist price of fine granulated in 100  pound bags $21.45 while the price for bulk and No. 2 liquid sugar will go to $20.65. Other major sugar companies could not be reached for comment. In other pricing actions, the Phosphate Chemicals Export Association announced increases for various grades of phosphate products to reflect an increase of $25 a metric ton for P205, which is 100 percent phosphate.

title: TV VIOLENCE CITED AS BAD INFLUENCE
description: By the time the average American child graduates from high school, he has seen on television some 18,000 murders and countless highly detailed incidents of robbery, arson, bombing, forgery, smuggling, beating and torture, according to a Seattle physician who wants the medical profession to protest televised violence.

title: VOLATILE PRICES HURT POOR LANDS
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  In early 1974, copper was selling in international markets for more than $3,000 a ton. Now the price is about $1,000.

title: Airline Strike Cancels Lakewood's Bowl Trip
description: LAKEWOOD, Dec. 16 (AP) Members of the Lakewood High School band may not get closer to the Rose Bowl than their television sets.

title: A 2d Washington Hospital, St Elizabeths, Loses Rating
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)  St. Elizabeths Hospital, a mental institution run by the National Institute of Mental Health, has become the second District of Columbia hospital to lose its accreditation in less than a week.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Robert A. Kutcher was inadvertently omitted from the State Board of Law Examiners list of persons who passed the bar examination, as published in The New York Times on Dec. 5.

title: Music
description: The conductorless Orpheus Chamber Ensemble, having proved its orchestral prowess at Alice Tully Hall last month, moved to more intimate quarters to take up the cause of octets and other works that skirt the boundary between chamber and symphonic music. At the first of five Carnegie Recital Hall concerts Monday night, 10 of the 24 Orpheus members partook vivaciously of Mozart's Divertimento in D, K. 251, the gracious Octet, Op. 32, of Ludwig Spohr, and Schubert's breezy little Grazer Galop.

title: A Christmas Amnesty?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Before we come to the end of the old year, and go on to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence in 1976, is it not possible at least to think about an unconditional Christmas amnesty for the de fiabt exiles of the Vietnam war?

title: Colombia Is Deporting Ecuadorean Politicians
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 16 (Reuters)The Colombian Government said today that it was deporting seven prominent Ecuadorean politicians, including a former vice president of Ecuador, Carlos Arosemena.

title: Professional Football
description: National Conference

title: A Soviet Diary Critical of Mao
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Against the advice of a consultant. Doubleday has just published a Sovietsupplied book that purports to provide inside informationmuch of it derogatoryabout Mao Tsetwig and his Chinese Communist followers during World War II.

title: CITICORP TO INCUR DROP IN QUARTER
description: Citicorp, the largest banking organization in New York, disclosed yesterday that it would make record chargeoffs for bad loans in the fourth quarter and full year and would incur a quarterly earnings decline for the first time since 1969.

title: Flames Defeat Scouts by 31
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (UPI)Hilliard Graves scored the tiebreaking goal during a secondperiod scramble in front of the Kansas City net tonight and the Atlanta Flames went on to beat the Scouts, 31.

title: TERMS ADJUSTED ON BID BY TOTAL
description: Total Petroleum, North America Ltd. of Calgary, Canada, and the Hanover Petroleum Corporation of Dallas announced yesterday that they had revised terms of their merger agreement to avoid litigation that was threatened last month. Terms of an agreement first announced on Aug. 7, 1975, provided for Hanover shareholders to receive $5.40 in cash, $6.90 principal amount of debentures and sixthtenths of a warrant or one share of common stock. The warrants are exercisable at $12.50 a common share.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: POSTAL RATE RISE BLOCKED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The United States Postal Service was ordered today not to put into effect the increases in mail rates scheduled for Dec. 28.

title: Leader of Inmate Rights Drive Is on Governor's Clemency List
description: The name of Martin Sostre, a black Puerto Rican who in recent years has emerged as a symbol of the prisonerrights movement in the state, is on Governor Carey's clemency calendar and a decision on the case is expected within two weeks, the Governor's press secretary said yesterday.

title: BRITISH COMPUTERS FACE PRIVACY CURB
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (Reuters)The British Government today announced it would introduce legal safeguards to protect against dangers to privacy from the increasing use of computers

title: Consumer Checkup Stops, Fuel Trucks on Highways
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16Several hundred fuel delivery trucks were stopped on state roads yesterday and today by a task force spotchecking meters and other devices for conformance with consumer regulations Nearly 20 percent were found to have violations.

title: Record Book Facing Revision
description: The Cleveland Browns' offensive linemen were literally counting the yardage totals in the huddle for their Greg Pruitt last Sunday as the running back moved toward a total of 1,000 gained in an otherwise undist in guished Cleveland, season. Pruitt rushed for 214 yards in a victory over Kansas City and his total is 1,030.

title: Administration and Legislators Differ Over Angola
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 President Ford expressed serious concern today over action taken by the Soviet Union and Cuba in providing large quantities of equipment and men to Angola.

title: About New York
description: The candy store is a venerable New York institution, a youth center to which the kids repair with the faithfulness of a Wall Street banker to his club and a community center that does for the elders what a general store does for rural folk.

title: Cavanagh Tendered Last Hurrahsby 1,000 at Dinner
description: More than 1,000 people, representing a multipartisan cross section of the city's last, two political decades, heard First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh praised by the city's last three Mayors for being, as former Mayor. John V. Lindsay put it, part, of the great La Guardia tradition of civil service.

title: Landmark Supported
description: The landmark status of Grand Central Terminal was reinstated yesterday when the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court voted 3 to 2 to overturn a decision by Justice Irving H. Saypol. The appeals court denied the Penn Central's suit for permission to build a 55story building atop the terminal. Page 49.

title: From a Seoul Prison
description: The Park regime is tying me up in a conspiratorial net of incredible lies. They say I am a Communist who infiltrated the Catholic Church and pretended to be an advocate of democracy and human rights. I have been arrested and imprisoned on these charges.

title: Buford Tynes, Treasurer Of Philip Morris, Is Dead
description: Buford A. Tynes, treasurer of Philip Morris Inc., died Monday in a hunting accident in Dutchess County. He was 41 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue.

title: S.M.U. Under Inquiry
description: DALLAS, Dec. 16 (AP)Southern Methodist is to appear tomorrow before a National Collegiate committee on infractions in California regarding an investigation on the Mustangs' athletic program.

title: Edward T. Sandrow of L. I. Dies; ExHead of Rabbinical Assembly
description: Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow, who retired in 1971 as spiritual head of Congregation Beth El in Cedarhurst, L. I., died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Woodmere, L. I.

title: IVAN OBOLENSKY, 62, OF RUSSIAN NOBILITY
description: Ivan Peter Obolensky, a member of the White Russian aristocracy, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived at 1326 Madison Avenue.

title: Grand Old Profligates
description: The Republicans in the New York Legislature scored a victory of sorts over Governor Carey when they forced him to accept a temporary bailout of three endangered state agencies without acceding to Mr. Carey's demand for simultaneous movement toward balancing the state budget. It was not the kind of victory in which the G.O.P. can take prideespecially those members of the Grand Old Party who like to pose as paragons of fiscal rectitude.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: TAX CUT BILL HITS A SNAG IN HOUSE IN A TEST ON VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The House of Representatives did not muster the necessary twothirds majority today to pass, the taxcut bill under a special expedited procedure. The vote was 256 to 160, or 22 short of the necessary 278.

title: Fund to Guard Diplomats Wins Backing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Ford Administration agreed today to support compromise legislation that would reimburse New York and other cities up to $3.5 million for expenses incurred protecting foreign diplomats.

title: Jackson Suggests Ford Veto Bush for No 2 Spot
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, suggested today that President Ford might hold the key to getting smooth Senate confirmation for George Bush, his nominee to head the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Miss Little Is Released On Bail Pending Appeal
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 16 (UPI)Joan Little, after spending almost 48 hours in jail because she failed to sign routine bond papers, was released from women's prison this evening on $25,000 bail.

title: Center Ali Saved at Bell Has a Celebration
description: The Hillside Aged Program Center in the Washington Heights section was supposed to be shuttered and empty yesterday. Instead, it was the scene of a celebration.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Wiser, Who Quit T.W.A., Named Pan Am President
description: Six months after resigning as president of Trans World Airlines, Forwood C. Wiser was named yesterday to the same post with T.W.A.'s main international competitor, Pan American World Airways.

title: Floral Arrangers: If They Don't Know You, Their Skills May Wither
description: There are a number of fashionable florists in New York who can, and very often do, weave enchantment into their arrangements. Their imagination soars for their fashionable customers, and their finished products are usually esthetic delights.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Miss Moore's Guilty Plea In Ford Attack Accepted
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16Sara Jane Moore's plea of guilty of attempting to assassinate President Ford was accepted today in Federal Court.

title: Manuel Perez Guerrero
description: Like an actor who is discovered after years of competent but obscure work, Manuel Prez Guerrero, Venezuela's Minister of State for International Economic Affairs, is finally in the limelight. After a long and distinguished career as an international civil servant and in top posts in the Venezuelan Government, Mr. Perez Guerreroor P.G., as lie is called by associateshas emerged as one of the most influential men in the third world.

title: Mail Rate Rise Barred
description: A Federal District Court judge issued a permanent injunction blocking proposed increases in mail rates that were to have gone into effect Dec. 28. Page 13.

title: 289 Assaults on Teachers
description: The number of reported acts of crime and violence in the city's schools, including assaults on teachers, has risen sharply this fall, the Board of Education disclosed yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 17. 1975

title: To Faithful, Who Is What Rock's About
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16Thwarting the order of nature and the clammy strictures of time, the Who returned for a fullscale threepart American tour Nov. 20 in Houston. The band may make it to New York sometime during the second partin about 10 weeks. But in the meantime, last night's concert at the Spectrum here, which ended the first leg of the tour, is the closest the group is getting to Manhattan.

title: Policeman, Shot Oct. 7, Dies on L.
description: MINEOLA, LI., Dec. 18A 35yearold Nassau County police officer, Matthew Giglio, died today at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre of wounds suffered when he was shot on Oct. 7 while responding to call of a burglary in progress at a West Hempstead boutique.

title: Labor Forum Sees Strike's Rising in '76
description: The year 1976 will be a stormy labor year with more strikes than industry experienced in 1975, the Labor Relations Forum of the Conference Board predicted yesterday.

title: Army Pins 7364 Loss On Adelphi
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP)Gary Winton broke a 5454 tie with 5 straight points and Army went on to beat Adelphi, 7364, in college basketball tonight.

title: About Real Estate
description: The differences between the vacant Royal Manhattan Hotel on Eighth Avenue and the vacant office building at 305 East 45th Street are more apparent than the similarities, but they have one thing in common.

title: The Connally Touch From Dublin: Looks That Last
description: Rome has Valentino, Paris has Dior et al., and Dublin hasSybil Connally. A specialist in handling such delicacies as Irish lace, tweed, embroidery and crochet work, Miss Connally has been visiting this country with her goodies for 22 years, stopping off in such places as Palm Beach, Los Angeles and, once or twice a year, New York.

title: Advertising
description: With about as much fanfare as one can expect for the debut of a new cigarette brand, Philip Morris introduced yesterday Merit, which Joseph F. Cullman 3d, chairman, called a scientific breakthrough and a revolutionary achievement.

title: Beame Doubts Legality of City U. Teacher Furloughs
description: Mayor Beame has described as of dubious legality the Board of Higher Education's decision to close the City University and furlough its faculty and staff for a month this spring, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: POLICY OYER ANGOLA IS EXAMINED BY CBS
description: Seeing similarities to Vietnam in the United States policy dilemma over Angola, CBS News executives have scheduleda special series on the Angola conflicht to run on the Evening News With Walter Cronkite every night this week.

title: Stella Wright Homes Seek Tenants Again
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16  Stella Wright Homes, the beleaguered, highrise, lowincome publichousing project that was the site of the longest rent strike in the nation's, history, is slated to open its first model apartments on Thursday as part of a plan to attract new, residents.

title: TALKS BREAK DOWN AT WASHINGTON POST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)A handful of union members faced with the possible loss of their jobs through the hiring of permanent replacements returned to work at The Washington Post today. Contract negotiations to end the 2 month walkout resumed and then abruptly broke off.

title: Knicks Subdue Hawks On jumper by Monroe
description: would be left when we got the ball back.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Polishing apples has become as obsolete as rugbeating. These days, apples, like cucumbers, tomatoes, green peppers, citrus fruit and certain other fruits and vegetables, are often waxed, although there is not labeling at the point of sale to indicate that fact.

title: Prices Rise Slightly In Trading on Amex And OTC Market
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market moved slightly higher yesterday in heavier trading.

title: Gaulin Explores Animal World With Mime Dances at Cubiculo
description: Nonhuman and vaguely menacing creatures were the most exciting portrait material explored in mime by Paul Gaulin Monday evening at the Cubiculo. He has a long lean frame that lends itself to those spindly configurations that quiver with veiled danger.

title: Access to C.U.N.Y.
description: A number of the Board of Higher Education's proposed cuts in the City University budget raise questions both of practicality and legality; but any ultimately approved package will almost certainly include some modification of the present guidelines governing open admissions

title: Hunter Away, Wife Hits Prowler With an Arrow
description: Over the weekend, John Lisk, a cab driver who is also a bowandarrow enthusiast, drove more than 160 miles to go hunting. He came home emptyhanded.

title: Truckin' Man and His Radio Roll On Through the Night
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.Elmer Arbaugh, who is 49 years old and has been driving trucks for nearly three decades, is not sure just how longhaul truckers have suddenly become new media heroes.

title: CABARET ACT TRIED BY ELAINE PETRICOFF
description: Elaine Petricoff, a young singer who has appeared in Grease, The Me Nobody Knows and An Evening With Cole Porter, was trying her wings on a cabaret floor at Seesaw, Lexington Avenue at 81st Street, Monday evening. The results were rather like an attractively plumaged bird that is accidentally confined indoors, fluttering desperately in every direction.

title: CHESTER LONGWELL, GEOLOGIST, 88, DIES
description: Dr. Chester R. Longwell, professor emeritus of geology at Yale University and research associate at Stanford University, died Monday after having suffered a heart attack at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Educators Debate Security
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 What sometimes sounded more like a convention of prison wardens than a gathering of educators ended today with a consensus that extraordinary security precautions would be an unavoidable necessity in many schools for a long time to come in the face of mounting violence.

title: Council Sees City Lag on Reorganiztion
description: City Council members accused the Beame administration yesterday of dragging its feet on the reorganization of a number of superagencies and criticized the administration for sloppy work in, drawing up plans that had been repeatedly rejected as unworkable by the Council.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: YONKER, Wednesday, Dec. 17The City Council of Yonkers voted 7 to 6 this morning to oust J. Emmet Casey as City Manager.

title: WHITE HOUSE ORDERS REPORT ON INTRUDER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The White House today ordered an immediate report from the Secret Service on how a man intruded onto White House grounds twice within 10 days.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Callaway Says Ford Will Not Quit the Race
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 16 (AP)Howard H. Callaway, President, Ford's campaign director, said today he saw no circumstance under which Mr. Ford would withdraw from the Presidential race, even if he loses the key early primaries to Ronald Reagan.

title: On Graduate Studies
description: The proposal is sometimes heard these days that the City University of New York make its contribution to the relief of the city's financial problems by abolishing its graduate school. The economic argument is often reinforced by a quasimoral argument: that graduate education is per se elitist and that therefore graduate students, especially in a public system, should have much lower priority than, say, incoming freshmen.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Robert A. Kutcher was inadvertently omitted from the State Board of Law Examiners list of persons who passed the bar examination, as published in The New York Times on Dec. 5.

title: Rich and Poor Countries Open Economic Conference in Paris
description: PARIS, Dec. 16The foreign ministers of 27 nations opened the Conference on International Economic Cooperation here today, a ceremonial session to open what will probably be years of bargaining.

title: Jersey Fund Vote Fails
description: Efforts by the Byrne administration and Democratic leaders in the New Jersey Assembly to win quick Senate approval of the $27 million supplemental budget appropriation failed yesterday. As a consequence, proposed cutbacks in the state's Medicaid program will begin Jan. 1. Page 49.

title: Sonia Strauss Gruen Dies; Medical Bibliography Expert
description: Sonia Strauss Gruen, associate professor of medical bibliography at Albert Einstein Medical College, died yesterday at the college's hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 2090 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Britain Votes $335 Million Aid To Keep Chrysler Open There
description: LONDON, Dec. 16Prime Minister Harold Wilson overcame a stinging attack from all quarters of Parliament to win approval late tonight of a $335 million Government rescue of the Chrysler Corporation's British factories. The vote was 285 260.

title: Will Paris Talks Produce Dialogue?
description: Is the conference between rich and poor nations, which opened yesterday in Paris, destined to wind up as a dialogue between the deaf? Even President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France, who proposed the conference a year ago, warned at its opening that the muted possibility of confrontation and selfishness overhangs the proceedings.

title: SCHOOL PROJECTS URGED AT HEARING
description: All we can do is divide up the misery, at best, said a member of the City Planning Commission yesterday in reply to one of, scores of witnesses who had come to plead for the restoration of school construction projects suspended because of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Assembly Approves Ban On Public Pay Toilets
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)A bill sent to the Senate today would make it a misdemeanor to charge money for the use of a toilet in public facilities.

title: General Mills Shows Profit Increase
description: General Mills Inc., a leader in the packaged food field, reported yesterday profit increases of 29.1 percent for the quarter ended Nov. 23 and 28.7 percent for the halfyear period. James P. McFarland, chairman, said that sales and earnings were the highest for any quarter or six months in the company's 48year history.

title: November Housing Starts Fell 5.6% in First Drop in 5 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Newhome construction declined in November, another indication that the nation's economic recovery may he suffering a temporary slowdown, the Government reported today.

title: Britain Votes $335 Million Aid To Keep Chrysler Open There
description: LONDON, Dec. 16Prime Minister Harold Wilson overcame a stinging attack from all quarters of Parliament to win approval late tonight of a $335 million Government rescue of the Chrysler Corporation's British factories. The vote was 285 to 260.

title: Evi Mittermaier Gains First World Cup Victory
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 16 (UPI)Cutting corners on a course slowed by falling snow, Evi Mittermaier of West Germany raced to a surprise victory today in the third World Cup women's downhill of the Olympic ski season.

title: Allan Joseph MacEachen
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 16Allan J. MacEachen, the Canadian Foreign,.Minister, has an appropriate background to be cochairman of the Conference on International Economic Cooperation, which opened in Paris today.

title: Knicks' Box Score
description: KNICKS (97)

title: Lockheed Rocket Facility Is Sold Indirectly to Seoul
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16The South Korean Government, through an intermediary, has quietly purchased the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's complete facilities for manufacturing solidfueled rocket motors.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: MONDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: William A. Reedy, Editor Of Applied Photography, 59
description: William A. Reedy, the founder in 1946 and the editor of Eastman Kodak Company's Applied Photography, a journal for professional photographers and art directors, died Monday of cancer in a Rochester hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Spencerport, near Rochester.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: At least two .22caliber pistols were used in the slaying of five members of a Teaneck, N.J., family on Dec. 6 Bergen County officials said. The County Prosecutor, Joseph O. Woodcock Jr., said ballistics tests at the state police laboratory in Little Falls had determined that two weapons had been used in the slayings of the wife and four children of Wesley Diggs.

title: People in Sports
description: Bill Veeck, sitting at a conference table in Chicago, signed checks and passed them around yesterday to, complete the $9.7 million purchase of the White Sox. He was then given the keys to his new kingdom by the former owner, John Allyn, who still has 20 percent of the team, and quickly left for the ballpark to see if they still fit.

title: Knight of Indiana Loses Court Battle
description: Bobby Knight, coach of the undefeated Indiana University basketball team, was a loser in court yesterday when a judge denied his request for a temporary injunction to abolish the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 10player limit for traveling basketball squads.

title: Legislature Stalls Over a Plan To Assure City Notes' Payment
description: noteholders would voluntarily take the 10year M.A.C. bonds rather than wait three years for their principal on their oneyear notes. But it has become very real in the last few weeks as the M.A.C. exchange offer has faltered badly.

title: NoFault Premiums Up y 20% as Awards Rise
description: ALBANY, Dec. 16  Sharp rises in the cost of no fault auto insurance have led the state to permit companies to charge customers premium increases averaging 20 percent, thus wiping out the original savings built into the system.

title: Canadians Rebuke U.S. Ambassador; Shun Farewell Party
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 16Canadian Government ministers followed up a public rebuke to the departing United States Ambassador for his criticism of Canadian policies by staying away from his farewell reception last night.

title: Jury Is Studying Injuries Suffered by Miss Quinlan
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16A New Jersey statewide grand jury is investigating whether Karen Anne Quinlan was beaten before she was taken unconscious to a hospital last April 15 and whether there was an attempt by unnamed associates to kill her.

title: WINE TALK
description: A couple of years ago, one of the stops on a trip through the wine regions of Italy included a stop at a big, modern cooperative winery near Greve in the Chianti region south of Florence.

title: Copland on Appalachian Beginnings
description: Nervous, said Aaron Copland when asked how he felt about conducting his own Pulitzer Prize score, Appalachian Spring, for the Martha Graham Dance. Company last night at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, December, 16, 1975

title: Rich and Poor Countries Open Economic Conference in Paris
description: PARIS, Dec. 16The foreign ministers of 27 nations opened the Conference on International Economic Cooperation here today, a ceremonial session to open what will probably be years of bargaining.

title: Monday's Fight
description: HAMILTON, OntarioJohnny Summerhays, Branford, Ont., knocked out Johnny Bay, Hamilton, Ont., lightweights, 6 rounds.

title: S.M.U. Under Inquiry
description: DALLAS, Dec. 16 (AP)Southern Methodist is to appear tomorrow before a National Collegiate committee on infractions in California regarding an investigation on the Mustangs' athletic program.

title: Cooking With Gas
description: Without fully realizing what is happening, the House of Representatives is in danger of plunging headlong into the longterm deregulation of natural gas.

title: U.S. Unit Seeks Test Of Light Rail Transit In Some City Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Urban Mass Transportation Administration said today that it planned to look for a promising opportunity in coming months to build a demonstration light rail transit system in some city.

title: Nets Top Colonels By 9896
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 16 Brian Taylor scored 8 points for New York in the last 54 seconds of the game against the Kentucky Colonels tonight to propel the Nets to a startling 9826 victory.

title: Lydia Chaliapin, 74, Dead; Coached Met Russian Roles
description: Lydia Feodorovna Chaliapin, a voice teacher who had coached many well  known singers in Russian roles for performances at the Metropolitan Opera, died Monday at her home in Stafford Springs, Conn. She was 74 years old.

title: Carey Asks Inquiry Into Race Board
description: ALBANY, Dec. 16Governor Carey asked the State Investigation Commission today to look into charges that the State Racing and Wagering Board had failed to monitor the financial affairs of the harness racing industry.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Dec. 16 (AP)Japan's gross national product registered its first postwar decline, a drop of 0.2 percent, in. fiscal 1974, with the G.N.P. totalling $300.9 billion after adjustment for inflation, a government report released today said. The report said, however, the per capita national income totaled $3,433 to register a postwar record annual increase of 26.6 percent.

title: Stock Prices Climb In Heavier Trading
description: The stock market advanced yesterday in more active trading, encouraged, in part, by prospects of strong Christmas retail sales and the pickup in automobile sales reported on Monday for the first 10 days of this month.

title: Jury Is Studying Injuries Suffered by Miss Quinlan
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16A New Jersey statewide grand jury is investigating whether Karen Anne Quinlan was beaten before she was taken unconscious to a hospital last April 15 and whether there was attempt by unnamed associates to kill her.

title: FUTURES PRICE UP IN ANIMAL FEEDS
description: Buying by traders, surprised at the larger  than  expected number of cattle placed on feed this fall, sent corn and soybean futures up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Both are used as animal feeds.

title: Woman Court Assistant Breaks College Barrier
description: Linda Lawrence, who will admit only that I'm over 30, was officially named assistant basketball coach at Lehman College yesterday.

title: Tickets for Olympics
description: Tickets to most events at next summer's Olympic Games are still plentiful, and so are housing accommodations in the Montreal area.

title: 207 Near Collisions Of Planes in a Year Reported by F.A.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) There were 207 nearcollisions of aircraft before a series of similar incidents in the last month, the Federal Aviation Administrator, John L. McLucas, said today.

title: Vietnam War Study Project
description: A oneyear study of the problems of Vietnam war veterans, deserters and draft evaders will be conducted under the sponsorship of the University of Notre Dame at its Center for Civil Rights, the Ford Foundation announced yesterday. The foundation will support the project with a $225,000 grant.

title: Books of The Times
description: You know what the problem is. Anyone who has ever taken a socalled intelligence test knows what the problem is. The problem is this. You are asked (on the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale test), Why should we avoid bad company? If you answer, You might get involved in a situation you couldn't control, you are wrong and stupid. The correct answer is, It leads to temptation. Or a sixyearold is asked (on the StanfordBinet test), What is the difference between a bird and a dog? If the response is A bird can go faster than a dog or A dog chases a bird, it is wrong. The correct answer is A bird flies and a dog runs.

title: EDWARD G. GIERY SR.
description: Edward G. Giery Sr., director of security for the Rockefeller Center Corporation from 1954 to 1967, died Saturday. He was 73 years old and lived in Hampton Bays, L.I.

title: Rangers' LineUps
description: AT GARDEN, 7:30 P.M.

title: SCHOOL PROJECTS URGED AT HEARING
description: All we can do is divide up the misery, at best, said a member of the City Planning Commission yesterday in reply to one of scores of witnesses who had come to plead for the restoration of school construction projects suspended because of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Citizens' Band Radio: A Growing Fad
description: Each time he embarks on a highway tripsay, from his home town of Lincoln, Neb., to OmahaEarle Munns turns the citizens' band radio in his car to Channel 19, identifies himself as Paddlewheeler and asks for a reading eastbound on Rocky between here and Big O.

title: A Fingerprint Frees Man, 24, Convicted of Rape
description: A fingerprint on a light bulb played a crucial part in the freeing yesterday of a 24yearold man who had been convicted of rape on the testimony of two women last year.

title: Orphans of Slain Hero Are Given $435,328
description: The six orphaned children of Frank J. Walker, who was slain last January while coming to the aid of a police officer, yesterday were given $435,328 donated by policemen and others who had been moved by their plight.

title: Blacks on City U. Faculties Are Filing Bias Charge in LargeScale Dismissals
description: Black faculty members in the City University, most of whom have neither seniority nor tenure, have accused the university of wholesale black dismissals in the guise of retrenchment. And they are taking legal steps to reverse what they call the trend and to prevent themselves, the last hired, from being the first to be let go.

title: Bid for Assembly Vote on Funds Fails
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16Efforts by the Byrne administration and Democratic leaders of the Assembly to get a quick vote on the $27 million supplemental budget appropriation approved by the Senate last night failed today.

title: Serving Up Puppets Along With the Tuna
description: ELMSFORD, N. Y.On his first visit to the Children's Lunch, Theater here, 3yearold Sebastian Smith of Pleasantville, N. Y., spoke well of the tuna fish sandwich, the gingerbread man and the puppets, except for the green witch.

title: Opera: W. of Babylon
description: Charles Wuorinen's operainprogress, excerpts from which were previewed by the the Group for Contemporary Music on Monday night, is entitled The W. of Babylon, a coy and none too promising beginning. Mr. Wuorinen, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his electronic piece Time's Encomium, has set out this time to compose a satiric opera that, as he says, would be a thoroughcomposed work that would nevertheless incorporate allusions to other music, the other music being Mozartian, Purcellian, Verdian, Wagnerian operatic practice. No pastiche, no parody, no collage intended.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: RATES MOVE DOWN IN BOND MARKETS
description: While interest rates continued their weeklong decline yesterday, a heavy volume of new Treasury, corporate, taxexempt and foreign fixedincome securities was marketed with little indica tion that the trend toward lower yields had run its course. The Federal Government sold $2.5 billion of new twoyear notes at an average rate of 7.28 percent, which was within the range that had been expected.

title: Times Columnist Honored
description: Philip H. Dougherty, advertising columnist for The New York Times, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner of the Advertising, Broadcasting and Communciations division of the AntiDefamation League. Also honored at the dinner, held at the Pierre Hotel, was E. Manning Rubin, a senior vice president of Grey Advertising, who received the Samuel Dalsimer Human Relations award for his work in behalf of the A.D.L.

title: The Women's Movement in France: A Cause That Is Not Yet Celebre
description: PARISThe plainly dressed, grayhaired, middleaged woman stood implacably on the carpet outside the office of Franoise Giroud, the Secretary of State for Women's Affairs, and scolded a timidlooking male civil servant.

title: JOHN MIGLIETTA, OIL EXECUTIVE, 91
description: John Romeo Miglietta, an oil and mining executive who has been associated for many years with Texaco Inc., died Friday at his home, 333 East 68th Street. He was 91 years old.

title: Bodies of Two Girls Hunted Upstate
description: The state police have been digging for three days in a 58acre former hotel and bungalow colony in the Catskills in a search for the bodies of two teenagers believed to have been murdered.

title: CITY NOTES PLAN STALLS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 16The Legislature abruptly recessed tonight in the face of strenuous objections by New York City officials to a bill that would have required the Emergency Financial Control Board to set aside nearly $100 million of city revenues each year for the next three years to pay off the holders of oneyear city notes when the threeyear moratorium on their payment ends.

title: Wall Street Weighs G.E.'s $1.9 Billion Bid
description: Shares of Utah International Inc. were among the most actively traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with 273,100 shares changing hands and a closing price of $49.25 a share. The $2.25 rise from Monday's closing price represented the response of a stunned investment community to Monday night's announcement that the company was planning to merge with the General Electric Company.

title: E. P. A. Proposes Rules to Cut A CancerCausing Gas by 90%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency proposed regulations today to cut by 90 percent the amount of cancercausing vinyl chloride gas, to which 4.6 million people are exposed in factory areas.

title: Candidate for Stennis Seat
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 16 (UPI)  E. Michael Marks, a lawyer here, announced today, that he would seek the United States Senate seat held by John C. Stennis in the Democratic primary election next summer.

title: Market Place
description: Domestic television manufacturers are perplexed and angered by the Justice Department's apparent unwillingness to challenge foreign takeovers of United States makers of color sets.

title: NATO OFFERS PLAN ON ARMS REDUCTION
description: VIENNA, Dec. 16 (AP)  The North Atlantic Treaty Organization formally offered today to include 1,000 American nuclear warheads in eventual arms reductions in Central Europe in return for concessions by the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies on troops and tanks.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto for Harpsichord, Flute and Strings No. 6, Corrette; Norfolk Rhapsody No. 1, Vaughan Williams; Symphony No. 30, Mozart; Capriccio Italien, Tchaikovsky.

title: Cavanagh Tendered Last Hurrahsby 1,000 at Dinner
description: More than 1,000 people, representing a multipartisan cross section of the city's last two political decades, heard First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh praised by the city's last three Mayors for being, as former Mayor John V. Lindsay put it, part of the great La Guardia tradition of civil service.

title: Angola's Rival Factions
description: HUAMBO, AngolaCivil war is being waged in Angola by three competing factions that are divided more by tribal affiliations, regional loyalties and yearnings for power than by ideology. The issue of foreign involvement has overwhelmed the nationalist aspects of the conflict in this former Portuguese territory, which became independent on Nov. 11. With each faction accusing the others of selling out to different countries, the issue of foreign intervention has inflamed antagonisms that developed over the 14 years during the fight against Portuguese rule.

title: Supreme Court Delays Ruling on New Campaign Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Supreme Court recessed until Jan. 12 today without ruling on the legality of the new campaign law, and the Federal Election Commission moved to begin paying the Federal subsidies on Jan. 2 to candidates and political parties that the law authorizes.

title: Canadians Rebuke U.S. Ambassador; Shun Farewell Party
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 16Canadian Government ministers followed up a public rebuke to the departing United States Ambassador for his criticism of Canadian policies by staying away from his farewell reception last night.

title: Atomic Test Postponed
description: MERCURY. Nev., Dec. ??6 (AP)A technical problem forced a oneday delay t day of the detonation of a medium yield nuclear device at the Nevada Test Site, officials said. The Energy Research and Development Administration said the test was rescheduled for 7:15 A.M. tomorrow.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of 100,000 common shares of Connecticut Water Service Inc., at $10.25 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the Advest Company.

title: Daily Lottery Ends Dec. 31
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP)The state announced today that it would discontinue the daily, lottery game effective Dec. 31 because of declining sales. Henry Luther, director of the lottery, said the popularity of, the new PickIt Lottery, in which players select their own numbers, contributed to the decline of the daily lottery.

title: Truckin' Man and His Radio Roll On Through the Night
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Elmer Arbaugh, who is 49 years old and has been driving trucks for nearly three decades, is not sure just, how longhaul truckers have suddenly become new media heroes.

title: MEXICO U.N. VOTE DRAWS PROTESTS
description: America Jewish leaders expressed surprise and distress yesterday at Mexico's votes in the United Nations General Assembly Monday night implicitly linking Zionism with racism.

title: PETE E. COOLEY
description: Pete E. Cooley, former manlager of financial interests for Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, died Monday at Somerset Hospital, Somerville, N. J. He was 70 years old and a resident of Somerville.

title: Duvillard Wins Again
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 16 (UPI) Henri Duvillard of France recovered from a nearfall in the semifinals and went on to defeat Werner Bleiner of Austria in the final today of the first world professional ski meet's special slalom. Duvillard, 26 years old, won the giant slalom on Sunday.

title: Truce Holds in MidBeirut; Strife Continues Elsewhere
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16The ceasefire between Christian and Moslem armed factions that went into effect yesterday held up in the center of the capital today but fighting continued on a reduced scale in the suburbs and in the countryside.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Rangers' LineUps
description: AT GARDEN, 7:30 P.M. RADIOWNEW, WMCA, 7:30 P.M.

title: Angola Confusion
description: The essentials of the Soviet, Cuban and American Involvement in Angola have finally become public knowledge. The crucial need now is to arrive at a sensible policy.

title: FORD SAID TO BAR A COMBAT ROLE IN ANGOLAN WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 President Ford has ruled out any form of combat intervention in Angola, including the sending of advisers, according to high and authoritative Administration officials, and will not go beyond the current program of aiding two factions fighting a group supported by the Soviet Union.

title: Angolans in Luanda Exhibit 4 as South African Soldiers
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (Reuters) Four prisoners said to be regulars of the South African, Army captured on Angola's central front were displayed today by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, the Luanda radio reported.

title: 289 Assaults on Teachers
description: The number of reported acts of crime and violence in the city's schools, including assaults on teachers, has risen sharply this fall, the Board, of Education disclosed yesterday.

title: KANG SHENG DIES IN PEKING AT 76
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Dec. 17Kang Sheng, a deputy chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and one of the country's senior leaders, died yesterday in Peking after a prolonged illness. He was 76 years old.

title: DEAL WITH BRITISH PLEASES CHRYSLER
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16  Top Chrysler Corporation executives here were extremely pleased today with the deal they had arranged with the British Government to save the company's British subsidiary.

title: H.E.W. Acts Against Maryland In a College Integration Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare has begun enforcement action against Maryland for allegedly failing to implement its higher education desegregation plan. It is the first such action ever taken against an entire state program.

title: Ford Now Supports Funds To Guard Diplomats Here
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Ford Administration agreed today to support compromise leg islation that would. reimburse New York and other cities up to $3.5 million a year for expenses incurred protecting foreign diplomats.

title: In Memoriam
description: ASEN  Irma Bernice. Dear and devoted friend sorry missed, greatly loved.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL ON OLDAREA HOMES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)The Senate has completed action on a bill intended to discourage banks from refusing to provide mortgages to persons who want to buy homes in older urban neighborhoods.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SPLIT OF DEPUTIES HURTS PERONISTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16A rebellion has broken out in Peronist congressional ranks against the monarchical style of President Isabel Martinez de Pern, who reigns but no longer rules over Argentina's majority party.

title: Interior Chief and White House Budget Office Clash Over Funds for Park Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Thomas S. Kleppe, the new Secretary of the Interior, has clashed with the White House Office of Management and Budget over proposed, appropriations to acquire land for Federal and state parks and recreation areas.

title: Lacemaking: A Craft Still in the 16th Century
description: BRUGES, Belgium  Each afternoon the main hall of the School of the Apostoline Sisters in this peaceful Flemish city comes alive with a clickclack sound that is as important to Bruges as the chiming of its many church bells, but there is deep pessimism about the future.

title: About Education
description: If the complexities of American society have grown during the more than 300 years since the first public school was opened, Americans' expectations of their schools have multiplied in what sometimes seems like geometric progression.

title: European Football
description: By Reuters

title: Harris Presidential Campaign Faces Severe Test in Home State
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 15A littlenoticed date on next year's electoral calendar could produce a severe setback for the Presidential campaign of former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma.

title: Forego Is Top Horse 2d Year in Row
description: As expected, Mrs. Martha L. Gerry's thoroughbred star Forego, who spent the season conceding weight to his rivals with sparkling success, was named horse of the year yesterday for the second straight time. The 5yearold homebred son of Forli, sidelined near the campaign's close with a recurring leg ailment, also was picked in the Eclipse Award poll as the top performer in the 4yearolds and upward division. He just missed taking the champion sprinter titlea crown that also was his in 1974..

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: For Tom Signorelli, as Mac the Drunk, Lamppost Hilarity Is a Slice of Life
description: My God, how can Mac remember all those lines when he's so drunk? a man in the audience muttered as the five actors in Lamppost Reunion took their curtain calls the other night at the Little Theater on West 44th Street.

title: F.D.A. PANEL GETS DATA ON ESTROGEN
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., 16A committee of Food and Drug Administration experts heard additional evidence here today linking the use of estrogens during and after the menopause to an increased risk of developing cancer of the uterus.

title: TV: The Blue Knight on CBS Beat
description: Running into some trouble with Kate McShane, CBS has done the predictable TV thing and called a cop to take over the schedule on Wednesdays at 10 P.M. In this instance, the hero is George Kennedy as The Blue Knight, a middleaged policeman dedicated to walking the beat, to protecting his neighborhood turf. The scene is set with crazyangled shots of city streets. A closeup catches the twirling of a policeman's nightstick. The music soars into a driving tempo. And there, curled up in the immediate foreground, is the very real threat of instant boredom. TV's cop glut looms large once again.

title: Capital Night Owls Will Adore Pisces
description: WASHINGTON  A new private club named Pisces has been opened here in an attempt to do for night life what the Kennedys did for Potomac culture.

title: First Loan Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that New York City would receive its first Federal loan, of $130 million, on Thursday or Friday.

title: PORTUGAL FINDING ALLIES WARMER
description: LISBON, Dec. 16Portugal, which has made no essential changes in its foreign policy since crushing the leftist military rebellion on Nov. 25, is finding a much warmer reception among its traditional western allies.

title: Gradualism for Spain
description: Spain's new Foreign Minister, the Count of Motrico, calls himself a civilized rightist, and the description could apply as well, to most of his colleagues in the first Cabinet sworn in under King Juan Carlos I. The ministerial choices reflect the caution evident earlier in the King's appointment of the conservative Torcuato FernandezMiranda as President of Parliament and the decision to retain Generalissimo Franco's last Prime Minister, Carlos Arias Navarro.

title: Bridge:
description: All writers of bridge columns are occasionally contented to borrow the witticism of George Kaufman, who, when asked by a partner who had perpetrated some deplorable dummy play how he should have played the hand, replied, under an assumed name. But to find the right technical answer to some such questions may involve considerable thought.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: A Glossary of Truckers' Terms
description: The ordinary driver who wires a citizens' band radio into the family station wagon to join the trucker network is apt to find himself lost on a highway strewn with plain brown wrappers, chicken chokers and dozing smokeys. The following glossary will serve as something of a road man.

title: Red Smith
description: When the New York Jets were winningnow there is a man with a memoryit was customary for the owner of the team and Joe Willie Namath to sit together and share drinks on the plane traveling to and from games out of town. This caused some comment, but it was no great scandal because Namath occupied a special position in the organization. He was the $400,000 quarterback whose presence in the American Football League gave that upstart tong respectability. He was the only player in professional football whose preference in scotch (Johnny Walker Red) underwear (black) and girls (blonde, brunette and redhead) titillated readers of the national magazines. He was a folk hero, a sex symbol and a tough competitor with a strong and accurate arm, who learned to detect and exploit defensive weaknesses. The other players respected his skills, had faith in him as a winner and recognized that he was putting money in the pockets of all of them. In the circumstances, they didn't mind his having special privileges.

title: Work on Community College Faces Halt Over Financing
description: Construction of the $72 million campus for Manhattan Community College north of the World Trade Center will be halted when the steel work on the main building is completed unless new funds are Ptahcoming, William A. Sharkey, executive director of the State yesterday.

title: A Mecca for Sausafe and Ham Lovers
description: Smachnohobon appetit in Ukrainianis wish easily fulfilled at Kurowycky's on the Lower East Side, a veritable cornucopia of sausages and cooked meats, most of them readytoeat. Seen through the wide plate glass window, this gleaming shop with white tile and porcelainpaneled walls displays a roseamber array of smoked sausages and nuggets of pork tenderloin, slabs of bacon flecked with pickling spices, hot meat loaves fragrant with garlic and pepper, lean and meaty strips of ribs, smooth liver pats and glistening head cheese, and, most gloriously and conveniently at this holiday season, whole baked hams gilded with caramelized sugar.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Assemblyman Eugene Raymond 3d, Republican of Camden County, and his 1975 campaign manager were acquitted of charges they had defaced campaign signs of Mr. Raymond's opponents. Judge Theodore Davis of the Camden Municipal Court, assigned to hear the case in Pennsauken, handed down the verdict acquitting Mr. Raymond and Martin Love, both of Pennsauken, of disorderly person charges after two hours of testimony. Until the arrests of Mr. Raymond and Mr. Love this fall, Mr. Raymond and his running mate, former Assembly Speaker William K. Dickey, Republican of Camden County, had been favorites to regain their Assembly seats.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Summary

title: Radio
description: 610 A.M., WNCNFM. Prelude, Fugue and Allegro for Lute, Bach; Lestoco Overture, Auber; Brazilian National Anthem, Gottschalk; Konzertstuck Fantasia Appassionate, Vieuxtemps.

title: DEVELOPING LANDS PROD WEST ON AID
description: PARIS, Dec. 17Thirdworld leaders drew up sides between the industrial and developing nations at the international economic conference here today.

title: Subways to Trim Service In Rush Hours on Jan. 18
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday a 4 percent cutback in subway service effective Jan. 18 that will reduce rushhour service on all lines.

title: SUBWAYS TO DROP 279 RUNS JAN. 18
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday a 4 percent cutback in subway service effective Jan. 18 that will reduce rushhour service on all lines.

title: O'Brien Knockout Victor
description: Bobby O'Brien, 171 pounds, of New York, knocked out Roger Phillips, 167, of Pittsfield, Mass., in 1:38 of the third round of a scheduled eightround light b heavyweight bout last night at Sunnyside Gorden, Queens. O'Brien, a policeman, knocked Phillips down twice in each of the first two rounds and was floored himself early in the third before dropping Phillips for the full count.

title: Coaches Playing for OneonOneLiners
description: The basketball coaches in the 24th annual Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden presented the first act of their traveling road show yesterday, devoting their time to exchanging quips and overrating opponents.

title: Foreman Stops Brooks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 (AP)  The former heavyweight champion, George Foreman, floored Eddie Brooks twice in the third round and twice in the fourth before the referee stopped their scheduled 10  round heavyweight exhibition fight at Civic Auditorium tonight.

title: Wartime Notes Led Up To Death of the Reporter
description: On the cover, it said simply, Barney Darnton's Notebook 1942. In 1942, Barney Darnton was the New York Times correspondent in New Guinea. He died there, aged 45, a casualty of the war in the Pacific.

title: Levitt Would Weigh State Pensions' Use
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17Comp. troller Arthur Levitt said today that he would consider using state, pension funds to help the state borrow next spring, but not to rescue its construction agencies from default over the next three years.

title: EDGAR T. WILLIAMS
description: Edgar T. Williams, a real estate and insurance broker, died late Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Brooklyn. He was 63 years old and also had a home in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: DILWORTHLESLIE PLAYS FAURE WORKS
description: Samuel DilworthLeslie has given several Fecitals of mixed quality here in past years but always showed a growth in interpretive and technical power. In recent years the pianist has also focused on the music of one composer for whom he had a particular affinity. The composer is Faur, and Mr. DilworthLeslie has studied his works with Nadia Boulanger, who was a pupil of Faur. He has played the complete piano repertory in cycles of four programs in Paris and at Rutgers University, where he teaches, and he has now recorded it.

title: Wife May Have No Credit Rating
description: Many married women who are working and consider themselves independent and liberated may be nonpeople in the eyes of banks and other credit institutions, and may be unable to get a loan should they ever need one.

title: In Memoriam
description: FITZGERALDBill. Brother Bill, on your tenth anniversary, your memory will always linger on. Mass Friday, Dec. 19, at 6:45 P.M., Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 W. 71st St.

title: Former Friend of Miss Quinlan Questioned About Her Bruises
description: TRENTON, DEC. 17William Dixon Zywot, a former companion of Karen Anne Quinlan, was questioned by the state police today to see if he could shed light on why the young woman had numerous bruises when she was brought unconscious to Newton Memorial Hospital last April 15.

title: Nonwinner of $10,000 Gets $1 Back in Lottery
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 17 (AP)  A teenager who was told he can't collect a S10,000 Connecticut lottery prize because he is a mirror will get a $1 refund on the winning ticket.

title: F.B.I. Lists 110 in a Socialist Party as Threats
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation currently lists 110 members of the Socialist Workers Party on an index of individuals considered dangerous to national security, although an F.B.I. official has testified that the party is not violent.

title: Area's Residents Placed at 600 by Leader
description: NoHo is nowhere. It's not really a neighborhood; there's not even a grocery store, or a school, or a playground, or a voting booth. A couple of bars, a couple of liquor stores, a whiff of lunchrooms. Gray streets deserted, except for a few desultory trucks in the daytime and a few spots of animation at night outside the scattering of Off and OffOff theaters.

title: LastSecond Nugget Shot Downs Nets
description: DENVER, Dec. 17 (UPI)Bobby Jones hit a driving layup at the buzzer and the added a free throw that gave the Denver Nuggets a 106103 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: 2 More Brokerage Firms Planning Move to Jersey
description: The exodus of Wall Street firms to New Jersey continued to spread yesterday, with the number of securities houses leaving the city to escape transfer taxes now standing at five.

title: Soviet Aiding Chad on Food
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Dec. 17 (Agence FrancePress)The Soviet Union has provided the subSaharan nation of Chad with an Antonov12 cargo plane to fly food to drought zones in the north and east. It was announced here yesterday. The plane will make two trips a day for the next month.

title: Honors for Making the City Look Nicer
description: The greening of New York is not a task for cynics. It requires doggedness, imagination, muscle and a belief that the spadework is somehow all worthwhile.

title: Flyers Defeat Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI)Bob Kelly and Reggie Leach scored thirdperiod goals only 96 seconds apart tonight to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 42 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. It made the goalie, Wayne Stephenson, the first 20game winner in the National Hockey League this season.

title: Grant. Requests Approval To Move Its Headquarters
description: The W. T. Grant Company asked yesterday the approval of Federal Bankruptcy Judge John J. Galgay for its plan to move its corporate headquarters from 1515 Broadway to another. Manhattan location and to close an additional 134 stores next month.

title: CHARLES HARMON JR.
description: Charles Harmon Jr., a textile executive, died yesterday in the North Miami (Fla.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Queens Lawyer Slated For City Lobbying Post
description: Richard Rubin, a 35yearold Queens lawyer, went through the final clearances yesterday leading to appointment as leader of New York City's lobbying staff in Albany.

title: Chess:
description: Miguel Najdorf, now 65 years old, is still going strong, as he proved in sharing first prize in the Argentine, championship with his fellow grandmaster Oscar. Panno. This was the eighth time that Najdorf  El Viejo, as he is known in Buenos Aireshas captured top honors in the series, which began in 1921.

title: Dunlop Sees Difficult Construction Talks if Picketing Bill Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) Labor Secretary John T. Dunlop warned today that construction industry negotiations in 1976 would be unmitigated hell if President Ford vetoes a controversial bill expanding the picketing power of building trades unions.

title: Ethical Culture House Ruled a Nonlandmark
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday annulled the landmark status of the meeting house of the Society for Ethical Culture on Central Park West, declaring that the designation was confiscatory, unconstitutional, arbitrary and unreasonable.

title: Foes of Campaign Subsidy Law Ask Burger to Block Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Opponents of the new campaign law asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today to block payment of political subsidies by the Federal Election Commission until the Supreme Court had ruled on the constitutionality of the law.

title: G.E. Withdraws Its Figures on Low Levels of PCB
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17In an unexpected move, the General Electric Company publicly disassociated itself today from much of the testimony presented by its own expert witnesses on PCB with the explanation that the reliability of the data is extremely doubtful..

title: Dance: Graham Myths
description: In Errand Into the Maze, Martha Graham deals with a woman confronting her sexual fears. In Circe, she is concerned with man overcoming his baser feelings.

title: Paper Bag Snatched From Brooklyn Man With Life Savings
description: A retired 71yearold house painter who told detectives that he never left his Brooklyn home without carrying his life savings reportedly had a paper bag filled with $17,000 in cash snatched out of his hand in Coney Island yesterday by a 10to12yearold boy.

title: Ban on Conversion to Flats Is Discussed
description: New York City has a burgeoning supply of surplus loft space because of the closing in the last decade of manufacturing concerns that employed more than 250,000 people.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: For Children on Christmas Vacation, the Play's the Thing......Or Other Fun Things to Do
description: Christmas vacation for schoolchildren is a long one this year. To parents, it may seem even longer than it actually is. Before the gifts comeand afterward, what do you do with the children? One possibility is to turn to children's theater, which is alive and warm at Christmastime. Here are appraisals of several of the most, interesting shows, in town.

title: Dated Displays of the Woman's Issue
description: Timeliness can have a great deal to do with the impact of a movie, especially if the movie is a documentary dealing with a wellpublicized subject.

title: 11 O'Clock and All's WellSometimes
description: When last observed, Max McGee was sitting at a big table in Maxwell's Plum with five friends. It had to be Max McGee because he was wearing a big ring with three big diamonds that flashed like three mirrors held up to the sun. The diamonds symbolized the three consecutive National Football League championships that the Green Bay Packers won, including the first two Super Bowl games. It also had to be Max McGee because his five friends were females. But four understood the plans for the rest of the evening. Those four looked at the menu while the other looked at Max, no longer a member of the Packers but forever a part of their history. When the Packers won Super Bowl I, he caught two touchdown passes as a replacement for Boyd Dowler, the starting wide receiver. Max McGee hadn't expected to play and shortly before Coach Vince Lombardi yelled, McGee, get in there, Dowler's hurt, he was talking with Paul Hornung, an accomplice in various achievements that do not appear in the N.F.L. record manual.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Dec. 17, 1975

title: DOUBT IS VOICED ON BUSH APPROVAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The nomination of George Bush to be Director of Central Intelligence appeared to be in serious trouble in the Senate late today.

title: 6 BILLION RAIL AID PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The House passed today a $6 billion bill to reorganize seven bankrupt Northeastern railroads and to provide financial assistance to other rail systems across the nation. The vote was 197 to 23.

title: KICKBACK INQUIRY INVOLVES A BANK
description: YAPHANK, L. I., Dec. 17A Federal grand jury is investigating charges that executives of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn demanded cash kickbacks amounting to nearly $500,000 in exchange for their approval of a $14 million loan for the controversial Suffolk Meadows Quarterhorse Race Track here.

title: Celtics' Hot Spell Sets Back Kings
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 17 (AP) John Havlicek and Jo Jo White led a 3Gpoint thirdquarter outburst that enabled the Boston Celtics to beat the Kansas City Kings, 118104, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: 202 at Garfield Paper Mill Get Productivity Bonuses of $824
description: GAPFIELD, Dec. 17Produc tivity bonuses of $824 each were distributed today to 202 union employees of the Garden State Paper Company Inc. at its mill here.

title: MISS REEVES, SOLO, AT RENO SWEENEY'S
description: Martha Reeves is forever in rock n roll associated with a couple of hit recordings, Dancing in the Streets and Heat Wave, that she made over a decade ago and that turn up again and again in golden oldie and nostalgia repackages. Then it was Martha and the Vandellas, an allgirl group when allgirl groups were a staple on the rock scene and decidedly unmilitant.

title: ROAD PACT IS NEAR FOR 2 GERMANYS
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 17West German diplomats said here today that the two Germanys had reached a longterm agreement for the improvement of the road and rail connections that the isolated city of West Berlin has with the West.

title: Ban on Conversion to Flats Is Discussed
description: New York City has a burgeoning supply of surplus loft space because of the closing in the last decade of manufacturing concerns that employed more than 250,000 people.

title: N.I.T. Loss a Rival Event
description: The National Invitation Tournament, the oldest college basketball tournament, received a chance to improve its field considerably next March when it was disclosed. yesterday that the Collegiate Commissioners Association postseason tournament had been canceled. The C.C.A. affair lasted only two years, during which it failed to break even financially, but didn't fail to prevent some good teams from playing here in the N.I.T.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: YOU'RE THE TOP More royalty reminders have arrived for the holidays, along with the imported gallery of lifesize figures of British monarchs on display at the midtown Union Carbide Building. In another Bicentennial salute and the first of its cultural showcase events, the new local branch of the Union Bank of Bavaria has brought over from West Germany a collection of 50 international crown replicas painstakingly crafted by a team of goldsmiths, engravers, enamelers and stonecutters. The elaborate, jeweled diadems, scaled to the exact size and appearance of the originals, are on view through Christmas Eve in the lobby of the bank, 430 Park Avenue (at 55th Street). Visiting hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Monday through Friday.

title: An Israeli Minister Sees Mideast Standstill it '76
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Defense Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that despite American efforts to promote further movement toward peace, he did not expect any diplomatic progress in the Middle East next year because of the American Presidential election and the growing rivalry in the Arab world.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1975

title: F.D. A. Issues Drug Price Rules For States With Public Posting
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) In a new move to help consumers, the Food and Drug Administration issued rules today to guide retail pharmacists who publicly post or advertise prescription drug prices.

title: Music: Of 20th Century
description: Neva Pilgrim, soprano, and Paul Jacobs, pianist, were guest performers with Speculum Musicae at Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night for a concert of 20thcentury music in the Young Concert Artists Series.

title: ALBANY'S LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON A TAX PACKAGE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17  The Democratic leadership of the Assembly and the Republican leadership of the Senate have reached tentative agreement on a package of increased bank and business taxes to be enacted before the end of the month.

title: Symbolizing the U. S.
description: BALTIMOREUncle Sam has not been much in evidence lately. If he does turn up, he is likely to look pretty sick. The last time I saw him in a cartoon he was slumped in doctor's office. Looking depressed, he was complaining. Sometimes, for no reason, I suddenly burst into tears. Gone is the sprightly old codger of jaunty stance and belligerent gesture, whom we used to know on Army recruiting posters and on the cover of The Saturday Evening Post. What became of him? Partly, I think, he faded away when Americans could no longer identify themselves with the kindly, simplehearted uncle. But Sam's demise was undoubtedly insured by limitations of ethnic origin and gender. He could never be anything but a white AngloSaxon male. As a symbol of America he was already a quaint anachronism before women's liberation went to work on male authority. So enfeebled was the poor old fellow that the new feminists never deemed him worthy of scorn.

title: Capitol Christmas Tree
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  The 12th annual Capital christmas tree was lighted on the Elipse near the White House today by Representative Philipi Rupee, Republican of Michigan, who called it a symbolic tribute to those traditions which this nation has always cherished.

title: Italy Legalizes Possession Of Small Amounts of Drugs
description: ROME, Dec. 17 (Reuters)The Italian Parliament today enacted a law that decriminalizes possession for personal use of small quantities of illegal drugs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Former End Sues Chiefs for $79,800
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 17 (AP)A suit for $29,800 in back pay and $50,000 in damages has been filed against the Kansas City Chiefs of the National Football League by a former defensive end, Nick Roman.

title: Washington Star Wins Broadcasting Exemption
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  The publisher of The Washington Star, Joe L. Allbritton, won permission from the Federal Communications Commission today to acquire temporary control of the newspaper's profitable broadcast properties in an effort to save the financially troubled afternoon daily.

title: Islanders Beat Rangers, 30; Denis Potvin Gets Two Goals
description: The Islanders still own New York.

title: A.T.&T. NET UP 1% IN FINAL QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest corporate enterprise, reported yesterday a, slight gain in net income for the fiscal fourth quarter, ended Nov. 30, but a 2 percent decline for the full 12months.

title: SOLON DE LEON DIES; LABOR ECONOMIST, 92
description: Solon De Leon, one of the country's first labor economists, died Dec. 3 in Ellenville, N. Y. He was 92 years old and lived at 3949 45th Street, Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERHarry K. The Board of Directors and members of Deepdale Gardens Federal Credit Union regret the passing of Harry K. Adler, Past President and good friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Estaba Stops Foe, Retains Ring Title
description: ONNA, Okinawa, Dec. 17 (UPI)Luis Lumumba Estaba of Venezuela, 107 pounds, stopped Takenobu Shimabukoro, 108, of Japan at 1 minute 25 seconds of the 10th round today and retained his World Boxing Council junior flyweight title.

title: Bar Unit Scores Pending Bill On Spying as a Curb on Press
description: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has issued a report opposing new proposed Federal legislation involving defense secrets and espionage.

title: PAN AM WILL FLY TRAVELERS IN U.S.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, stepping into the growing holiday air travel crisis caused by strikes against United Airlines and National Airlines, granted Pan American World Airways limited authority yesterday to fly its first domestic passengers between New York, San Francisco and Seattle for the next six days.

title: The Conversion of Lofts Into Flats Is Discussed
description: lieve there are another 1,500 in the Washington Market area and perhaps 600 in SoHo, north of Houston Street.

title: William K. Wimsatt, 68, Dead; Yale Expert on 1700's Authors
