description: Prof. William K. Wimsatt Jr., a specialist on 18thcentury English literature, died yesterday at YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Security Troops Said to Join Lebanese Gunmen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 (Reuters)As many as 15 people were killed in Lebanon's northern city of Tripoli today where members of the internal security forces, supposedly neutral in the civil war, joined groups of gunmen, reliable sources said.

title: Nuclear Test Rescheduled
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 17 (UPI)Technical problems delayed for the third time today the testing of a nuclear device with a maximum yield about 10 times more powerful than the atomic bombs dropped on Japan. The test, code named Chiberta, was rescheduled for tomorrow.

title: Pro Football Statistics
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE RUSHING

title: Hound Dog Taylor, Musician In 'Bottleneck, Guitar Style
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP)The blues musician Theodore (Hound Dog) Taylor, whose bottleneck guitar style influenced many rock musicians, died today of lung cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: 600,000 Gallons of Oil Spilled at Prudhoe Bay
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, Dec. 17 (AP)About 600,000 gallons of oil has spilled at the Prudhoe Bay fields and the petroleum has spewed over two acres of frozen tundra on the edge of the Arctic Ocean.

title: Troubled Argentine government Sets General Election for October
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 17Argentina's Peronist Government, besieged by extremist violence, inflation and internal divisions, announced today a general election 10 months from now for President, Congress, and a constitutional assembly.

title: 3,000 More Layoffs Loom In the City's Teacher Staff
description: The city school system, which has already dropped 8,000 teachers since last June, plans to lay off 3,000 more when the spring term begins Feb. 2.

title: KICKBACK INQUIRY INVOLVES A BANK
description: YAPHANK, L.L, Dec. 17A Federal grand jury is investigating charges that executives of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn demanded cash kickbacks amounting to nearly $500,000 in exchange for their approval of a $14 million loan for the controversial Suffolk Meadows Quarterhorse Race Track here.

title: Yukica's Pact Renewed
description: NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP)Joe Yukica, Boston College football coach, has had his contract renewed for another year. Yukica, who has led the Eagles the last eight years, has a wonlost record of 5429.

title: Bill to Cut Crude Oil Price Ready to Go to President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate approved today and prepared to send to the White House legislation that would force an immediate reduction in the price of crude oil produced in the United States.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Aides to Governor Carey have turned over to the State Commission of Investigation financial data that prompted an inquiry into the State Racing and Wagering Board. The materials were given to David W. Brown, chairman of the commission, which is looking into charges that the board failed to monitor properly the harness racing industry, especially Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways. One of the chief aspects of the investigation will be to determine whether the state has been receiving a proper share of gambling revenue from the tracks.

title: Autos Are Excluded
description: LONDON, Dec. 17  After weeks of indecision and threats of retaliation by its major trading partners, the British Government today instituted import controls that were limited solely to a few goods from Portugal and Spain.

title: Yonkers City Manager Blames Mayor for the Fiscal Problems
description: YONKERS, Dec. 17City Manager J. Emmet Casey, who was suspended early today by the City Council for alleged fiscal mismanagement, has accused Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli of responsibility for the city's financial problems.

title: LESLIE H. QUACKENBUSH
description: Leslie H. Quackenbush, a retired vice president of States Marine Lines, died here Tuesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at the Pickwick Arms Hotel, 230 East 51st Street.

title: Miss Fromme Gets Life in Ford Attack
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 17  Lynette Alice Fromme, 27 years old, was sentenced today to life imprisonment for attempting to kill President Ford in Capitol Park here on Sept. 5.

title: Doctors' Scores Low in Test on Use of Antibiotics
description: In a recent test of how much doctors know about prescribing antibiotics, half the 4,513 phy sicians around the country who voluntarily took the 50question, multiplechoice test achieved scores of only 68 percent or worse.

title: Inadequate Fiscal Plan
description: A dispute that has arisen between city officials and the Republican legislative leadership in Albany raises disturbing questions about the commitment of City Hall to a new era of fiscal integrity and about the adequacy of the threeyear financial plan that is supposed to advance that goal.

title: Doubt on Bush Approval
description: Senate sources reported that President Ford's nomination of George Bush to be Director of Central Intelligence appeared to be in trouble because of Mr. Bush's refusal to rule out acceptance of a possible VicePresidential nomination. Page 35.

title: Jack Frost at Work Covering Ski Slopes
description: The temperature was in the low sixties at Butternut Basin, near Great Barrington, Mass., in the Berkshires on Monday. The carefully made snow that had reached the resort's crest was melting and water was seeping back into the reservoir whence it had come.

title: SPANISH TRAWLER SEIZED OFF JERSEY
description: A Spanish fishing trawler was seized by an oceangoing United States Coast Guard tugboat yesterday about 70. Miles southeast of Atlantic City for allegedly violating a ban on lobster fishing on the continental shelf.

title: MRS. JAVITS'S GEMS REPORTED MISSING
description: A pair of diamond earrings valued at $30,000 belonging to Marion Davits, the wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits, was reported missing yesterday from the couple's apartment at 322 East 57th Street.

title: So Your Dog Wants to Be in Motion Pictures?
description: Cairn terriers, Welsh springer spaniels and golden retrievers are the best breeds for theatrical careers or TV appearances, according to Capt. Arthur Haggerty. The former commanding officer of the 25th Infantry and 26th Infantry K9 corps and an expresident of the Bronx County Kennel Club, who now conducts a training school, addressed the Dog Fanciers Club here last week: He stressed that appearance is far more important than intelligence. The Cairn is a small dog, he said, and has a good textured coat. We would not use one that is too dark in color. The Welsh springer is a nice light shade, as is the golden. All three breeds are not too easily identifiable by the general public, which is also asset.

title: Bridge:
description: The perennial problem of slow play in New York tournaments appears to be on the verge of a solution. For many years, a tiny minority of excessively slow performers have prolonged each session of play unnecessarily, thereby causinggreat irritation to the vast majority of players who complete each deal within the allotted time of 7 minutes.

title: O.A.S. Approves a Meeting Of Its Assembly in Chile
description: WASHINGTON,Dec. 17 (AP) The Organization of American States approved today a resolution to hold its General Assembly meeting in Santiago, Chile, next year.

title: Arms Sales to China
description: The triangular relationship among China, the Soviet Union and the West enters a new phase with Britain's $160 million contract to provide Peking with RollsRoyce jet engines and the technology for their manufacture.

title: Taft, Westminster Victors in Hockey
description: Taft defeated St. Paul, 76, and Westminster beat the Hill, 43, in a prep school hockey doubleheader yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 2,512.

title: City Loses Millions In Matching Funds During Fiscal Crisis
description: The city is, being forced to forgo hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal and state grants for capital projects because it cannot afford matching funds, Martin Gallent, vice chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday.

title: Ghosts
description: Mention Vietnam now, and people react as to something in the dim past. They find it hard to believe that the war ended less than eight months ago that only last April Gerald Ford was seeking $972 million in aid to save Saigon. Men's ability to block the unpleasant from their minds is remarkable.

title: More in Bergen Using Private Schools in City
description: ENGLEWOOD, Dec. 17Apparently dissatisfied with local public schools and intent upon securing an elite education for their children, more and more Bergen County parents are sending their children to private schools in New York.

title: Oil Cleanup at 2 Weeks Coast Guard Estimates
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 17 (AP) The United States Coast'Guard estimated today that it would take at least two weeks to clean up a major oil spill that covered portions of a 14milelong public beach west of San Juan.

title: 1973 Arms CoverUp Is Laid to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Some 1973 intelligence reports that the Soviet Union might have violated the agreements on strategicarms limitation were withheld by Henry A. Kissinger from certain top Administration officials and Congressional leaders, according to documents and testimony at a House committee hearing today.

title: Employees Make a Go. Of Vacated Upstate Mill
description: The employees of a Saratoga Springs, N. Y., fabricknitting mill, who purchased it last spring when no one else wanted it will receive a 5 percent bonus this Christmas.

title: Five Are Arrested Here on Medicaid Larceny Charges
description: A dentist, a pharmacist and three chiropractors were arrested yesterday on grandlarceny and fraud charges steming from an investigation into widespread theft from the city's Medicaid program.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: U.S. AND CANADA STRESS HARMONY
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 17In a significant reference to growing, tensions between the United States and Canada, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Canadia's Foreign Minister, Allan J. MacEachen, issued a joint statement today expressing confidence that inevitable economic strains between the two countries would be surmounted.

title: G.E. Asks U. S. to Review TakeOver Plan for Utah
description: The Justice Department was formally asked yesterday by the General Electric Company and Utah International Inc. to make a review of G.E.'s proposed takeover of Utah International, a big mining company, under the department's business review procedures.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in some editions of The New York Times yesterday that the majority decision in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court upholding the landmark status of Grand Central Terminal was written by Judge Harold A. Stevens. Judge Stevens concurred in the opinion, which was written by Judge Francis T. Murphy.

title: Bonn Charges Bias in Selection of Tank
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17West German defense officials have, expressed concern to the Defense Department that the United. States Army is attempting to prevent an open competition in picking a new basic tank for the United States and West Germany.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Rutgers University announced that 198 first and secondyear faculty members, rather than 215, would be terminated because of the prospect of an insufficent state appropriation for the 197677 academic year. Dr. Henry R. Winkler, university senior vice president for academic affairs, told the Rutgers Board of Trustees in Piscataway that 17 members of the faculty in the university's library system and College of Nursing were considered too vital to lay off. The university had previously announced that letters of termination had been sent out on Dec. 1, but only 77 actually were. One hundred and twentyone more letters of termination are scheduled to be sent out by March 1.

title: Dismissal of 10,000 From Job Program To Begin Jan. 30
description: A City Hall spokesman said last night that on Jan. 30 the city would begin dismissing about 10,000 employees who were hired under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act (CETA). The dimissals will be made at the rate of 1,800 a month, he said.

title: Fashions That Earn Their Keep
description: Everybody knows about silk shirts and turtlenecks and sable coats. They're the blue chips of fashion, escaping the usual fate of fashion favorites, in one minute, out the next.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS STEVENS, 98 TO 0
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate confirmed the nomination of Judge John Paul Stevens to the Supreme Court by a vote of 98 to 0 today after just five minutes of discussion.

title: China Lofts 5th Earth Satellite; First Manned Flight Is Foreseen
description: PEKING, Dec. 17 (Reuters)China announced today the launching of its fifth earth satellite, and observers believe it could be a preparatory step toward Peking's first manned space flight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: INTEREST RATES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: The decline in interest rates that began a week ago gained strength yesterday afternoon after the Federal Reserve came into the credit markets and purchased Treasury notes and bonds to add reserves to the banking system for seasonal needs. Bond prices rose sharply and new issues, were priced aggressively to give investors lower yields than they would have received only two or three days ago, and yet there was still little sign that the current drop in interest rates was about to falter.

title: Soviet Officials Playing Down Involvement in Angolan War
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17Officials here have been attempting privately to play down the importance of Soviet military involvement in Angola, asserting that it is only tangential to the course of foreign policy and should not be allowed to damage SovietAmerican dtente.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Letter designates On listing

title: Rockefeller to Curb Role In 2 of Ford's Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Vice President Rockefeller said today that he would not campaign for President Ford in New Hampshire and Florida before the Presidential primaries in those states because some members of the. Republican Party considered him a liability.

title: Fordham Makes Brown Third Ivy Victim, 6564
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 17Fordham scored its third narrow basketball victory over an Ivy League opponent this month by edging Brown, 6564, tonight at the Providence Civic Center. Yale and Harvard were 2point victims.

title: OUTPUT OF GASOLINE DROPPED LAST WEEK
description: Leading petroleumsupply indicators fell last week, according to statistics supplied yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Tainted Antacid Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today the nationwide recall of thousands of bottles of liquid antacid that it said were contaminated with bacteria. Being pulled off store shelves are 7,116 bottles of Creamalin antacid liquid code number G101NJ, and 8,904 bottles of Wingel antacid liquid code number G416NH.

title: ExFriend of Miss Quinlan Questioned About Bruises
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17  Wil liam Dixon Zywot, a former companion of Karen Anne Quinlan, was questioned by the state police today to see if he could shed light on why the young woman had numerous bruises when she was brought unconscious to Newton Memorial Hospital last April 15.

title: Sirica Bars Plea to Delay Ruling On Postal Rate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)  United States District Judge John J. Sirica turned down today a motion to delay the effect of his decision barring the proposed Dec. 28 postal rate increase.

title: Israeli Asserts Cuba Has Troops in Syria
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. (AP)Israel's United Nations delegate, Chaim Herzog, said today that Cuban troops had been with the Syrian Army facing Israel on the Golan Heights for two years.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: One Act at a Time, Nimble and Swift, For Soviet Circus
description: What with Tuesday night's opening at the Felt Forum and all the talk about dtente and grain deals it is easy for the casual observer to sum up SovietAmerican relations as a matter of bread and circuses.

title: Connery and Caine Flee Kipling India
description: The setting is India in the late 19th century when the British raj was in his glory. It is a time of mission and mystery and the white man's burden, of appalling poverty and of wealth often described as untold. The cities teem with unruly humanity, with beggars, blind men, snake charmers, demented holy men, starving children. In the upland territories British soldiers guard the frontiers to places of which someone will say, quite seriously, "No white man has ever gone in there and come out alive."In marvelous old movies like "Lives of the Bengal Lancers" and "Gunga Din," this world is very far removed and terribly romantic, as it still is in John Huston's highly entertaining new film, "The Man Who Would Be King," based on the short story by Rudyard Kipling. The film opened yesterday at two theaters.The most pleasant surprise about "The Man Who Would Be King" is that although it is about as romantic and implausible an adventure as you're likely to see, it's not an anachronism. It's neither a silly update of an entertainment designed for pre-World War II Saturday-afternoon America, nor is it one of those films that are wise with hindsight about earlier eras, like John Milius's "The Wind and the Lion.""The Man Who Would Be King" manages to be great fun in itself while being most faithful to Kipling, whose story, written in the 1890's, is a kind of raffish metaphor for the British colonial experience that did not end for another half century. But this really isn't what "The Man Who Would Be King" is about. It's a tall tale, a legend, of steadfastness, courage, camaraderie, gallantry and greed, though not necessarily in that order.It's about two former English soldiers turned con artists, Danny Dravot (Sean Connery) and Peachy Carnehan (Michael Caine), who decide that Victoria's India is no longer big enough for them (and their growing reputations as blackmailers and forgers). They decide to carve out their own kingdom in Kafiristan, now a part of Afghanistan but then an undiscovered territory not visited by a known tourist or king since Alexander the Great.Danny and Peachy are grand, old-fashioned adventurers with the gift of gab and a sense of style. Outrageously disguised as a holy man and his servant, they climb mountains and cross glaciers to penetrate the forbidden territory where, through luck and a series of coincidences, they realize their wildest dreams.Danny gets himself crowned king and recognized as a god, the legitimate son of Alexander, and Peachy becomes chief of the armed forces and the treasure chamber. But while Peachy keeps his eye on the main chance, that is, an opportunity to abscond with the gold, Danny begins to like the divinity business and to take his responsibilities seriously, which is their downfall.Not in a very long while has Mr. Huston, who wrote the screenplay with Gladys Hill and also directed the film, been so successfully lighthearted and so consistently in command of his subject. Small-time frauds who get in over their heads have always appealed to him, and Danny and Peachy, as played by Mr. Connery and Mr. Caine, are two of his nicest discoveries  larger-than-life, robust, sometimes curiously prim but suddenly stalwart in the crises.Christopher Plummer also gives the film weight in the role of the young Rudyard Kipling who, as a newspaperman in India, participates in the beginning and the end of the story. Supporting the stars are Saeed Jaffrey, as a sort of glib Gunga Din character, who always begins a tale of woe by saying "oh me, by jove, alas," as if it were one word, and Shakira Caine (Mrs. Michael Caine), who plays an exotic heathen beauty.The movie, which was shot in Morocco, looks lovely and remote (how did we ever once settle for those black-and-white Hollywood hills?) and has just enough romantic nonsense in it to enchant the child in each of us.

title: A U.S. Ammunition Depot Is Turned Over to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 17 (Reuters)The United States handed over an empty ammunition depot to the Thai Government this week as part of its military withdrawal from its last Southeast Asian mainland bases.

title: Riverside's Giant Carillon Pealing Out Yuletide Carols,
description: High above the traffic horns and roar of Riverside Drive at 122d Street, James R. Lawson sat with clenched hands, pounding a keyboard of levers. His feet danced over the wooden pedals. With a florid toccata on the great carillon of Riverside Church, he pierced the city's cacophony.

title: Stan Smith Is Toppled
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 17 (UPI)Jaoa Soares, a littleknown Brazilian, upset secondseeded Stan Smith of the United States, 64, 63, today in the second round of the $37,800 New South Wales international tennis tournament. The 23yearold Soares said he had spent his life savings of $2,000 to compete on the Australian circuit Smih, still suffering from a tennis elbow, was heavily bandaged.

title: ALBANY'S LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON A TAX PACKAGE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 17  The Democratic leadership of the Assembly and the Republican leadership of the Senate have reached tentative agreement on a package of increased bank and business taxes to be enacted before the end of the month.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday. London: Morning fixing $138.75. down $0.05; afternoon fixing $138.85, up $0.05. Paris: Afternoon market quotation $140.89, up $0.41.

title: U.S. Reports a Rise In Personal Income
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Americans found themselves with a good deal more money to spend as the Christmas shopping season approached, a Commerce Department report said today.

title: A Judge Halts NursingHome Evacuation
description: A Federal judge has suspended the evacuation of a nursing home in lower Manhattan on the ground that the transfer was endangering the lives of patients.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Boy Who Lost an Eye at 3 Awarded $800,000 by Jury
description: A 7yearold boy, Lewis Davis fell into a Sidewalk depression in front of 1077 Bedford Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn when he was 3 years old, and lose the sight of an eye, was awarded $800,000 in damages yeterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The child's mother, Virginia D. Haywood, was awarded $65,000.

title: Cambodians Back Charter
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 17 (AP)A congress of 1,100 workers, farmers and soldiers approved a new constitution for Cambodia on Sunday, Radio Phnom Penn has announced. The broadcast said the congress wanted to create a true democracy, without either rich or poor, and a country that was, neutral, independent and nonaligned.

title: 3,000 More Layoffs Loom In the City's Teacher Staff
description: The city school system, which has already dropped 8,000 teachers since last June, plans to lay off 3,000 more when the spring term begins Feb. 2.

title: POOR LANDS SEEN SWAMPED BY DEBT
description: PARIS, Dec. 17Underdeveloped countries that do not have oil are exhausting their financial reserves so rapidly that they may not be able to pay their debts next year.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Beirut Fighting Contrasts Death With Life as Usual
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15 Lebanon's Christian President, Suleiman Franjieh, sits in his palace at Baabda in the hills east of the city, which he has not left for four months, looking through binoculars at the nighttime bombardments of rockets and mortars and the arching of tracer bullets. He is said to be expert at distinguishing between explosions.

title: Nantucket Base to Close
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP)The United States Navy says it will close its submarinedetection base on Nantucket Island next June because its equipment has become obsolete. The Navy said that the submarine detection equipment was being replaced by a satellite system that divides the oceans into grids.

title: Kissinger Aide in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 17 (AP)Under Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr. met with Syrian officials today, reportedly to discuss preparations for next month's United Nations Security Council debate on the Middle East.

title: State's Employees Threaten to Strike Over Their Bonuses
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)About half of the state's 72,000 employees will go on strike Jan. 5 if the Legislature fails to appropriate enough funds to pay their bonuses, union leaders warned today.

title: MOYNIHAN, AT U.N., ASSAILS ASSEMBLY AS IT ENDS SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17The 30th General Assembly session, ended its threemonth session, marked by frequent acrimony and confrontation, and Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate, declared it had been a profound, even alarming disappointment.

title: Carey Criticizes City U. On Faculty Furlough Plan
description: Governor Carey added his voice yesterday to the chorus of criticism of the Board of Higher Education's decision to furlough the City University's faculty and staff without pay under a budget cutting plan.

title: A Link to Diggs Murders Sought in Harlem Slaying
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17Bergen County detectives and other investigators are looking into the possibility of a link between the fatal shooting of a heroin dealer in New York City on Dec. 10 and the slaying of five members of the Diggs family in Teaneck several days earlier, authorities disclosed today.

title: PUERTO RICO BILL SEEKS NEW STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17A bill to make substantial changes in United States relations with Puerto Rico within the present commonwealth structure was introduced today in the House.

title: Beame Acts on Conditions on Rikers
description: In an attempt to ease tensions among both inmates and correction officers at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island, Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the rehiring of 50 dismissed correction officers and an accelerated bail review procedure to cut down on overcrowding at the prison.

title: President and Congress Enjoy Detente at Dance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)The Ford Administration and Capitol Hill reached dtente on the dance floor tonight at a Christmas ball thrown by President and Mrs. Ford for members of Congress in the White House.

title: Reference to Zionist Resolution Inserted in UNESCO Document
description: PARIS, Dec. 17Through the efforts of Arab nations, a UNESCO conference today inserted the United Nations General Assembly's antiZionism resolution into an official document of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Pan Am to Ease Jam
description: Pan American World Airways was given permission by the Civil Aeronautics Board to fly passengers between New York, San Francisco and Seattle for the next six days to ease the travel problems caused by strikes against United Airlines and National Airlines. Page 19.

title: Giving to Neediest Is a Family Tradition
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received a check for $25 yesterday with this letter:

title: New Sulky Draws Ire of OTB Bettors
description: Harness racing's failure to designate which horses are pulling a controversial new sulky has touched off protests from offtrack bettors. The new sulky, designed to take pressure off a horse's back, has enjoyed remarkable success since its introduction last week at Yonkers Raceway. Last Monday night, when the action shifted to RooseVeit Raceway, six of the 14 horses in eight races who used the new aluminum sulky were winners. The horseplayers have begun complaining about the lack of sulky designations on track programs and Offtrack Betting Corporation entry lists.

title: Jews Sue Kissinger on Saudi Job Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The American Jewish Congress, in a suit filed today against Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and three other Cabinet members, charged them with violating the Constitutional rights of American Jews by allowing them to be excluded from Government  supported programs in Saudi Arabia.

title: MOYNIHAN, AT U.N., ASSAILS ASSEMBLY AS IT ENDS SESSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17The 30th General Assembly tonight ended its threemonth session, marked by frequent acrimony and confrontation, and Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate, declared it had been a profound, even alarming disappointment.

title: KNIGHT'S MURDER IS CALLED SOLVED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17With one suspect dead, another in custody here and a third being extradited from Florida today, local homicide detectives, are suggesting that the murder of John S. Knight 3d, heir to the country's largest publishing empire, has been solved.

title: Text of Ford's Statement on Tax Cut Extension Veto
description: Good evening, everybody. I am vetoing the temporary tax cut extension bill sent to me by the Congress today. I have been telling the Congress ever since October that I would veto any tax cut if the Congress failed to cut Federal spending at the same time.

title: Personal Finance: A Feature in Group Insurance
description: Group life insurance has long been offered by companies to their employees as a fringe benefit. It is in fact, one of the most widely used fringe benefits in American industry.

title: Spain Is Expected to Ask More U.S. Arms
description: MADRID, Dec. 17American officials expect a formal request from Spain for more military supplies in the next few weeks, according to informed diplomatic sources here.

title: Riggins: He's Most Valuable
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 17 In the torpor of the final week of their worst season, the Jets proved today that, at least, they can recognize talent.

title: Betty's Husband in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) Betty Ford's staff members have begun to wear big blue and white campaign buttons saying Betty's Husband for President in 76. The members of the President's wife's staff say they bought the buttons from Representative Bill Frenzel, Republican of Minnesota. His spokesman said Mr. Frenzel was selling them as a campaign gimmick and for fun.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: 4 MEN ARE INDICTED FOR MEDICAID FRAUD
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)The state grand jury indicted four men today on charges of Medicaid fraud, accusing two nursinghome operators of padding their claims by more than $175,000 to pay for country. club dues, real estate taxes and snow plowing.

title: U.S. and Soviet Adjourn Talks on Strategic Arms
description: GENEVA, Dec. 17The United States and the Soviet Union today recessed until Jan. 12 their stalled talks on the limitation of strategic arms.

title: $500,000 in Gold Bars Found Aboard a Plane
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 17 (UPI)Twohundredsixty pounds of gold valued at more than $500,000, possibly stolen and bound for Saudi Arabia, has been found aboard a chartered plane. The charter company said that $800,000 more in gold was missing.

title: Miss Serrat, Dujon's Girl Friend, Ski Victor
description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 17 (UPI)Fabienne Serrat, the girl friend of the French skier, Michael Dujon, who was killed earlier this month, gave France its first victory of the World Cup season with two fast and flawless special slalom runs down a tricky course today.

title: Bill Calls on U.S. to Remove Forces From South Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)  Two Democratic Congressmen introduced legislation today to require the United States to undertake a phased withdrawal of all military forces from South Korea within a reasonable time.

title: United Brands Co. Fined by Europeans In Antitrust Case
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 17 (UPI)The European Economic Community has imposed a $1.2million fine on the United Brands Company for antitrust violations in the European. Banana Market, a company spokesman said today.

title: Parklands in Danger
description: I the Office of Management and Budget has its way, not a Federal dollar will be spent in the next fiscal year to purchase needed land to add to existing national or state parks and recreation areas, or to create new ones. Under the law, $300 million is deposited annually in a fund for this purpose, derived largely from revenues received from oil and gas leases on the outer continental shelf. With accumulated unspent funds, there should be available in fiscal 1977 something over a half billion dollars. To his credit, Secretary of the Interior Kleppe is urging President Ford to overrule the O.M.B. and ask Congress for a full $300 million appropriation.

title: Space Photos Show the Arabian Peninsula Drifting Toward Asia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Photographs taken by American astronauts on the joint U.S.Soviet space mission in July confirm that the whole Arabian Peninsula is slowly rotating toward Asia and that the region of the Golan Heights is probably geologically pivotal as well as politically.

title: T.W.A. Narrows Net Loss From YearEarlier Month
description: Trans World Airlines reported yesterday it had cut its net loss last month to $15.1 million from the $17.6 million reported for November of last year.

title: 1973 Arms CoverUp Is Laid to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 Some 1973 intelligence reports that the Soviet Union might have violated the agreements on strategicarms limitation were withheld by Henry A. Kissinger from certain top Administration officials and Congressional leaders, according to documents and testimony at a House committee hearing today.

title: 'Killer Elite,' or Copping Out of the Universal Sell-Out
description: Sam Peckinpah knows how to make movies but perhaps he has forgotten why. At least that is the feeling given by this bag of mixed, often damp fireworks about the alienation of people who do dirty tricks for the Central Intelligence Agency and discover that the tricks as well as the dirt are on them."The Killer Elite," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, resembles "Three Days of the Condor" so closely that it is as if Mr. Peckinpah had deliberately set himself to do flashier variations on the same theme.The theme is the world as universal sell-out. The metaphor is a covert intelligence organization that does malignant things ostensibly in a good cause. The protagonist is an individual who unwittingly falls afoul of one of the organization's plans, becomes its target and ultimately, after all kinds of mayhem, discovers its ends are as amoral as its methods, and walks out.James Caan plays the role Robert Redford had in "Three Days." Since he is a better actor than Mr. Redfordsharper, more urgenthe is more convincing. Since Mr. Peckinpah is more talented than Sidney Pollack, who did "Three Days," his film has moments, at least, of greater brilliance.Both pictures operate on the premise that the audience has brought along its eyes but left its head at home. Both are relentlessly far-fetched, presenting all the conceivable outrageousness of the clandestine world at the maximum, and without restaint. A work of art can't be credible when it makes everything happen that can happen.Mr. Peckinpah is mannered and inventive, and these qualities both give the film its strengths and undermine it horrendously. Cleverness, for one thing, gets in the way of comprehensibility. The plot revolves around the efforts of a fanatical group of Japanese terrorists to kill an anti-Communist Chinese leader.The attempt at the airport, with a spectacular slow-motion depiction of assassination by kungfu, is intercut with an indoor scene where the motives for all this are explained. The result is that the subsequent action is very hard to follow and it takes a long time to figure out which group of Orientals stands for what.There is a confrontation scene between the leader of the clandestine group and his main assistant, who is working for the other side. The two men glower but don't confront: they talk about the stock market, instead. Perhaps this is stylish, but it is hopelessly obscure, and the film, which lasts 123 minutes, has already been going on for about 100.On the other hand, Mr. Peckinpah uses his inventiveness to good purpose in the early part of the film. The protagonist has been grievously wounded by a fellow member of his organization. He sets himself to recover so he can avenge himself; his superiors vaguely discourage him.In his painful hospital recoverydone with some of the director's bent for sadistic directnesseach exercise, each effort to walk becomes another stage in the hero's progressive alienation from his organization.There is a fine scene at the end where the anticommunist leader is being taken by sailboat to presumed safety on a line of mothballed Navy ships. The dead warships, in a massive gray line, wait: a stunning image of entrapment.The climactic battle scene, aboard the warships, is ridiculously operatic, however. If a brief use of slow motion in the airport scene was effective, here it goes on endlessly. The notion of the various clandestine operatives standing around while the Chinese leader and his enemies fight things out with sabers is absurb; what is worse, the sight of it is absurd.If there ever was a screenplaythe credits claim that there waseither it was feeble to begin with, or Mr. Peckinpah has gone galloping all over the lot with it. This director thinks he can do anything he wants, and he is nearly right: But he is a long way from his audience.

title: Miss Fromme Gets Life in Ford Attack
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 17  Lynette Alice Fromme, 27 years old, was sentenced today to life imprisonment for attempting to kill President Ford in Capitol Park here on Sept. 5.

title: Bail for Miss Yoshimura Is Cut $75,000 to $25,000
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP)A judge reduced bail from $??00,000 to $25,000 today for Wendy Yoshimura, the underground companion captured with Patricia Hearst last September.

title: Dow Up 1.97 as Investors Ponder Taxes
description: Stock prices rose slightly in moderate trading yesterday as investors pondered the outlook for 1976 taxes.

title: Doubt on Bush Approval
description: Senate sources reported that President Ford's nomination of George Bush to be Director of Central Intelligence appeared to be in trouble because of Mr. Bush's refusal to rule out acceptance of a possible VicePresidential nomination. Page 35.

title: A Bikers Visit Recalled
description: WASHINGTONIt's midnight, Oct. 24, 1972. I should be in the white sheets of my bed, in my whitetrimmed suburban house, in my allwhite neighborhood, with my white, warm wife.

title: WILSON DENOUNCES U.S HELP FOR I. R. A
description: LONDON, Dec. 17Prime Minister Harold Wilson, in an unusual attack on misguided IrishAmerican supporters of the Irish Republican Army, said tonight that American funds were largely responsible for, the terrorism in Northern Ireland.

title: HAROLD C. HANOVER, A LABOR LEADER, 75
description: Harold C. Hanover, formerly president of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. and a member of the State Industrial Commission from 1962 to 1971, died of a heart attack Tuesday while in his car near his home at Eggertsville ,a suburb of Buffalo. He was 75 years old.

title: Environmentalists Ask Review Of Drinking Water Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17An environmentalist group today petitioned the United States Court of Appeals here to review the national interim standards on drinking water that were made public last week by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Veeck Names Richards, 67, As Manager of White Sox
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP)Paul Richards, a firm believer in speed, pitching and defense, was named manager of the Chicago White Sox today by Bill Veeck, their new owner.

title: Music: Bruckner's 8th
description: Only one work occupied Iast night's Chicago Symphony program at Carnegie Hall, but it was a monster. Carlo Maria Giulini conducted the orchestra in Anton Bruckner's Eighth Symphony. This is a work longer than Beethoven's Ninth  much longer, as Mr. Giulini conducted it. It also is a score full of problems, interpretive and textual.

title: Maleno Indicted in Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 14 (AP)  Mr. Maleno was indicted today for murder in the death of ?? Melendez.

title: 2 Wounded it Candy Store Holdup
description: A 32yearold man was shot in the head and critically wounded last night after coming to the aid of an offduty police officer who intercepted, three armed men fleeing from a candy store they had held up at 29 Tompkins Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: STRIKE RESTRICTION RELAXED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, Dec. 17  Amid growing clamor for a better deal for labor, President Ferdinand E. Marcos today partly relaxed the ban on strikes and picketing imposed six week's ago. He also decreed a wage increase for lowestincome earners.

title: NEXT TEST TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Congress passed the tax cut extension bill today, and President Ford, as expected, vetoed it promptly.

title: Advertising
description: For some, 1975 might be remembered as Horrorsville or simply Ugh. Others may just try to erase it completely from their minds.

title: Hammer Must Answer S.E.C. Questions on Occidental Gifts Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17A Federal judge today ordered Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, to submit to questioning by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning possible payments by Occidental to foreign government officials.

title: Reds' Hustling Rose Sportsman of Year
description: I give 110 percent. I don't give 100 percent because some guy opposite me might be giving that much. So said the indefatigable Pete Rose of the worldchampion Cincinnati Reds in accepting Sports Illustrated's 1975 award as sportsman of the year yesterday.

title: BRITAIN IS SCORED FOR CHRYSLER DEAL
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) British labor union leaders, politicians and businessmen accused today the Labor Government of capitulating under pressure to the Chrysler Corporation by agreeing to provide up to $325 million of mainly public money to save Chrysler's ailing British subsidiary from financial collapse.

title: Paul Mallon, 91, Art Dealer, Ancient Sculpture Specialist
description: Paul Mallon, a leading French dealer in ancient Mediterranean art, died Tuesday night at the Clinique de Clichy in Paris. He was 91 years old and lived in the Hotel Meurice there.

title: Iran Oil Exports Off 35%
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 17 (AP)Iranian crude oil exports dropped 35 percent in November from the yearearlier level, the National Oil Company announced today. The announcement said daily production dropped to 3.7 million barrels in November compared to 5.5 million in November 1974.

title: Spain Is Wary of Abrupt Change
description: MADRID, Dec. 17The key word in the official language these days is prudence.

title: AMEX PRICES TAKE A MIXED COURSE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday while those on the overthecounter market closed higher.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in some editions of The New York Times yesterday that the majority decision in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court upholding the landmark status of Grand Central. Terminal was written by Judge Harold A. Stevens. Judge Stevens concurred in the opinion, which was written by Judge Francis T. Murphy.

title: Helstoski's Brother Guilty in Tax Case
description: TRENTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Robert Helsloski, brother of Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of Bergen County, was found guilty today of filing false income tax returns.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The 30th General Assembly of the United Nations ended its threemonth session, marked by frequent acrimony and confrontation, and the United States called it a profound, even alarming disappointment. The chief American delegate, Daniel P. Moynihan, told the Assembly it had been repeatedly the scene of acts which we regard as abominations, clearly referring to its calling Zionism a form of racism. [1:5.]

title: Man Fatally Stabbed In Dispute at Theater
description: A 23yearold man was stabbed to death at about 6:30 P.M. yesterday in the balcony of the Criterion Theater on Broadway at 45th Street. A suspect was arrested at the scene.

title: MALCOLM B. REISS, AUTHORS' AGENT, 70
description: Malcolm B. Reiss, a literary agent and writer, died Tuesday of a heart attack at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and had homes in Wilton, Conn., and Sandwich, Mass.

title: U.S. Request for Angola Projected at $60 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that covert United States operations in Angola were currently projected by the Administration at a total of $60 million for the current fiscal year.

title: Soviet Officials Playing Down Involvement in Angolan War
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17Officials here have been attempting privately to play down the importance of Soviet military involvement in Angola, asserting that it is only tangential to the course of foreign policy and should not be allowed to damage SovietAmerican dtente.

title: MEDICAL CENTER AID IS URGED BY JORDAN
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 17 (UPI) Mayor Paul T. Jordan pledged today to donate 3 percent of his $36,000 salary to help overcome a multimilliondollar deficit at the Jersey City Medical Center.

title: Stage: Mercurial Prince for Beaumont's Hamlet
description: Sam Waterston's Hamlet is mercurial to the point of seeming capricious. Faced with a calm Ophelia, he becomes hysterical, commanding Get thee to a nunnery! as if it were a curse against all womankind. When Rosencranz and Guildenstern are agitated, he is icily calm. Realizing the full extent of Claudius's villainy, instead of shouting, he says (quietly but forcefully), Let the door be locked.

title: Stage: A Royal Family for Brooklyn
description: There are some gorgeously corny old plays that come up more gorgeous than corny. The Royal Family by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber is of that somewhat undistinguished but charming company. It is part of the Bicentennial season of the Kennedy Center and the Xerox Corporation (an organization that has made a fortune out of duplication), and the play has been seen in Princeton, N. J., and Washington, and last night it arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It was enormously welcome.

title: Payments Abroad Reported by Merck
description: Merck & Company told the Securities and Exchange Cornmission yesterday that an internal audit had so far established the company had made less than $3.9 million of questionable payments to foreign government officials between 1968 and this year.

title: Developer Proposes a Convention Center in Midtown
description: A major private developer will disclose plans today for a $110 million convention center on a West Side site of largely unused rail freight yards between 33d and 37th Streets.

title: Market Place
description: Moneymarket funds may provide a convenient parking place for the proceeds of mutualfund shares sold before yearend to realize tax losses.

title: Warriors 113, Piston 102
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP)The Golden State Warriors routed the Detroit Pistons, 113102 tonight, extending their N.B.A. winning streak to seven.

title: Papercraft Asking F.T.C. Approval to Sell CPS
description: The Papercraft corporation of Pittsburgh asked the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to approve the sale of its CPS industries, Inc., subsidiary to the Arcata National Corporation of Menlo Park, California. The agreement to sell for $10 million and other considerations, announced Nov. 26, would end a sevenyear battle beween Papercraft and the F.T.C. stemming from the Government agency's order that Papercraft sell the division, which it acquired in 1967 for $5.4 million.

title: Oval Ruminations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17I've been President for nearly a year and a half and I always knew there'd come a time like this.

title: Plea on $1 Million Bail
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (UPI) A municipal court judge refused yesterday to lower the $1 million bail set for Richard Keats, reputed mastermind of the attempted swindle of $3.5 million in city treasury checks. The decision of Judge Dickran Tevrezian Jr. came after Mr. Keats, a 39yearold pharmacist, pleaded not guilty to multiple counts of conspiracy, forgery and attempted grand theft.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS STEVENS, 98 TO O
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate confirmed the nomination of Judge John Paul Stevens to the Supreme Court by a vote of 98 to 0 today after just five minutes of discussion:

title: Books of The Times
description: An eminent anthropologist and naturalist who has written effectively about science for the lay person, Loren Eiseley, at the age of 68, has produced an autobiography of sorts. The qualification of sorts is necessary to distinguish his memoir from the usual, more formal, autobiography in which a person recounts his life and work with whatever degree of candor can be mustered. Such autobiographies are normally plum puddings of extracts from letters, of dates and diaries, and they constitute apologies, however thick the disguise. Dr. Eiseley's autobiography, by comparison, is scant on dates and documentationstrange business for a scientistand is full of reflections on himself, on his specialties and on the world. And it is, of course, an apologia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A knitting mill in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., purchased by its employees last April to save it from a permanent shut down, will pay a five percent bonus to all employees this Christmas.

title: U.S. Tax Levels, Options on Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The following tables, based on data from the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, show the Federal income tax paid now by families of different sizes, with typical deductions, and the taxes that would be paid if President Ford's veto of the tax bill is overridden and if it is sustained, thereby putting 1974 tax rates back into effect:

title: Noble Sissle Is Dead at 86; Band Leader and Lyricist
description: Noble Sissle, song writer, orchestra leader and at one time unofficial Mayor of Harlem, died yesterday at his home in Tampa, Fla., where he had lived for the last five years. He was 86 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Cuban Party Talks Open With Castro Accusing the C.I.A.
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17 (AP)Prime Minister Fidel Castro opened the First Cuban Communist Party Congress before more than 3,000 delegates and 86 foreign delegations in Havana today by listing crimes he said had been carried out against his country by the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: PRETORIA SPEAKS OF ITS INCURSION
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Dec. 17  South Africa announced today that four of its soldiers had been captured in Angola by Russianarmed gangs.

title: Three Are Accused of Fraud in $350,000 Insurance Scheme
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17 (AP)Three persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges they bilked insurance companies out of $350,000 by posing as businessmen seeking loans on their policies.

title: ASTOR FUND AIDS PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: The Vincent Astor Foundation has made a grant of $1 million to the New York Public Library with the stipulation that its income be applied to operating expenses.

title: G.M. TO INCREASE CAR PRODUCTION
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17The General Motors Corporation, backing up its optimistic predictions of recovery in the auto industry, announced today that it would increase its production of passenger cars during the first quarter of 1976 by resuming second shifts at two assembly plants.

title: Congress Moves To Reimburse City For U.N. Protection
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Congress moved with unusual speed today toward the approval, of compromise legislation to reimburse New York and other cities up to $3.5 million For expenses incurred in protecting foreign diplomats.

title: Luanda Group's Claim
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17A representative of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola said here today that its forces had captured 25 to 50 South African soldiers and would show them in Luanda in the next few days.

title: Accounting Board in Ruling On Losses in Writedowns
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the arbiter of accounting practices, announced yesterday that companies taking losses or write1 downs in accordance with a previously announced ruling must restate earnings for several years rather than lumping the charges together on one year's statement, as decided earlier.

title: Modest Gains Seen
description: PARIS, Dec. 17Western industrial nations will experience a moderate economic upswing next year, but unemployment may continue to rise for the group as a whole and inflation will still pose a dangerous threat, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Australia Is Expected to Protest on Baltic States
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 17The new conservative Government of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser is reported preparing to inform Moscow that Australia does not recognize the incorporation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania into the Soviet Union.

title: DEADLINE FOR STRIKE POSTPONED AT POST
description: The Newspaper Guild agreed last night to a mediator's request to postpone a strike deadline against The New York Post, originally set for 6 this morning, until 6 A.M. Jan. 5.

title: Kennedy Friend Denies Plot Role
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17Judith Campbell Exner maintained today that, although she had had a close personal relationship with President Kennedy while she was dating two leaders of a Chicago crime syndicate, she had never acted as an intermediary between the Mafia and the White House.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: More New Jersey Parents Are Sending Children to Private Schools in the City
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 17Apparently dissatisfied with local public schools and intent upon obtaining an lite education for their children, more and more Bergen County parents are sending their children to private schools in New York.

title: Bill to Cut Crude Oil Price Ready to Go to President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Senate approved today and prepared to send to the White House legislation that would force an immediate reduction in the price of crude oil produced in the United states.

title: NEXT TEST TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Congress passed the tax cut extension bill today, and President Ford, as expected, vetoed it promptly.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP (SecondRound Replay) Hereford United 2, Bournemouth 0. RUGBY UNION John Player Cup (First Round)

title: Ashe Replaces Connors as No. 1
description: Arthur Ashe, playing the best tennis of his career, was ranked No. 1 for 1975 by the United States Tennis Association yesterday and Jimmy Connors fell to No. 2.

title: Some Vietnamese Copier Pilots. Find Jobs
description: MORGAN CITY, La., Dec. 14Every time Phan Van Dung takes a helicopter over the rice fields and swampland of the Louisiana delta country, an old feeling spreads throughhis insides.

title: State Law Defining Legal Death Is Urged at Assembly Hearing
description: A state law defining legal death, and including the cessation of brain function as one of the criteria, was urged here yesterday by law enforcment, medical, legal and religious representatives.

title: People and Business
description: Howard M. Love, 45, was elected president and chief operating officer of the National Steel Corporation yesterday. He was also named a director and member of the executive committee.

title: Kennedy Friend Denies Plot Role
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17Judith Campbell Exner maintained today that, although she had had a close personal relationship with President Kennedy while she was dating two leaders of a Chicago crime syndicate, she had never acted as an intermediary between the Mafia and the White House.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Special Musical Programs to Mark Christmas
description: CAROL SERVICES

title: Notes on People
description: The crackdown against speeders on Connecticut highways, ordered by Gov. Ella T. Grasso, has snared three members of the state Legislature, it was revealed yesterday. All face fines of up to $100.

title: Dock Ellis Explains Himself
description: The Dock Ellis the Yankees are getting won't be the Dock Ellis the Pittsburgh Pirates had. At least that's What Dock Ellis says.

title: Mazda Circles Back to Piston Power
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17Mazda Motors, which fell into hard times because of consumer resistance to rotary engine cars, is putting its hopes of a comeback on a conventionally powered small car called the Miser.

title: Radio
description: 610 A.M., WNCNFM. Prelude, Fugue and Allegro for Lute, Bach; Lestoco Overture, Auber; Brazilian National Anthem, Gottschalk; Konzertstuck Fantasia Appassionate, Vieuxtemps.

title: New Pilot?
description: For four decades until his retirement in 1971, the dominant figure in the Port Authority was its executive director, Austin J. Tobin, a man of great capacity and inflexible will. Under his leadership the authority did an extraordinary job of building bridges, tunnels, airports and other facilities. Regrettably, it also developed many aspects of a supergovernment, resistant to community pressures for shifting its priorities in the direction of mass transportation.

title: Stevedores Reportedly Investigated for Fraud in Grain Loading
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Three stevedoring companies owned by large grain corporations are among subjects of a New Orleans investigation into waterfront corruption which includes payrollpadding and falsification of labor billings, according to sources closes to the inquiry.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed today a bill to subsidize the interest state and local governments pay when they borrow if the bonds they issue are made taxable rather than tax exempt.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DROP 2C A BUSHEL
description: Soybeans and grain showed only slight changes in lethargic trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Lack of interest was attributed partly to traders' desire of wanting to be out of the market over the holidays.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Bill to Veto
description: Under intense pressure from organized labor, both houses of Congress have now passed a construction common situs picketing bill that can only lead to damaging strikes and increased joblessness in an industry already depressed by the prohibitive cost of building.

title: HEALTH COVERAGE URGED BY PUBLIC
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Public opinion favors national health insurance but more has to be done to control health costs and improve the availability of health services before an insurance program can be considered, Vice President Rockefeller said today.

title: Low Grain Harvest Seen In the Russian Republic
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  Western experts, analyzing an article in Pravda, calculated today that this, year's grain harvest in the Russian Republic, the largest of the 15 in the Soviet Union, probably was less than 70 million tons was gathered.

title: Short Vacation Stirs Protest
description: WOONSOCKET, R.I. Dec. 17 (AP)About 600 junior high school students boycotted classes this morning to protest a shortened holiday vacation to make up days lost during a teachers' strike.

title: Jazz 105, Bullets 88
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (UPI)Otto Moore scored 20 points, pulled down 20 rebounds and blocked five shots tonight in leading the New Orleans Jazz to a 10588 N.B.A. victory over the Washington Bullets that ended a sixgame losing streak for the Jazz.

title: Portuguese Publishers Reject Officially Imposed Wage Pact
description: LISBON, Dec. 17Portuguese publishers and booksellers repused today to comply with a collective wage agreement despite threats that a devastating Christmas season strike would continue.

title: L.I. Car Chase Ends in Crash And arrest of Holdup Suspect
description: A chase through several Nassau County communities yesterday led to the capture of, a man who the police said had robbed a cab driver of $80 at gunpoint, locked him in the trunk and then sped off in the taxi.

title: MET AND ORCHESTRA DISCONTINUE TALKS
description: The union representing the Metropolitan Opera orchestra yesterday broke off negotiations with the Met after a 15minute meeting aimed at averting a strike Jan. 1.

title: An Overt Production Loses Atmosphere
description: Having killed Polonius, he enters wearing the arras as a huge cape. Then he tosses it on the floor and dives under it, emerging to play comic hideandseek with his outraged pursuers. Claudius greets the escapade archly, and Mr. Waterston apes his peacock walk. For an instant Hamlet becomes Chaplin.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nekoosa Increases Price of Newsprint
description: STAMFORD, Conn, Dec. 17 (UPI)  The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation raised the price of newsprint today by $20 a ton, effective March 1. This will lift to $280 Great North ern's new price for 30  pound newsprint. Some companies had already raised the price to $270. In the wake of the recent strike settlements in Canadian paper mills, industry sources in Montreal had predicted the average price of newsprint in the United States might rise by as much as $25 a ton by midspring or early summer of 1976.

title: Goncalves Loses a Post
description: LISBON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) General Gonalves, ousted as Prime Minister earlier this fall, has been dismissed from his post as head of the Institute of Higher Defense Studies, a military spokesman said today. The order came from the new. Chief of Staff. Gen. Antnio Ramalho Eanes, who was appointed after last month's military rebellion by leftist forces.

title: Rosewall Gains In Aussie Tennis
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Ken Rosewall of Australia, the topseeded playet, required only 15 minutes to gain a quarterfinal spot today in the men's singles of the New South Wales international open tennis championship. Finishing a thirdround match interrupted by rain yesterday. Rosewall defeated Rolf Gehring of West Germany, 64, 61. In another rainhalted match, Charles Pasarell defeated Richard Drysdale of Britain, 64, 62. John Marks of New South Wales also gained the third round, defeating a fellow countryman, Colin Dibley, 64, 62.

title: Soviet Win Continue Paying Higher Rate On Grain Shipments
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18  The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today on a new shipping accord that allows American ships to continue charging freight rates significantly higher than the market level to deliver American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Flash Fire and Scrambling for an Exit Is Reported by Some Who Reached It
description: Smoke and fire came from everywhere, said Pat Jacobs of Fort Worth as she stood outside the stillsmoldering Blue Angel night club early yesterday.

title: Auto Maker Awaiting Its Competitors' Moves
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said today that the company would have to reconsider its latest price increase on 1976, models if competitors did not Match the increase. Ford announced an increase.of $113 on the average base model on Tuesday.

title: Kerby Farrell, 62, Managed Cleveland Indians in 1957
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 18 (AP) Kerby Farell, who managed the Cleveland Indians in 1957, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. He was 62 years old.

title: Carey Settles for Package Of BusinessTax Increases
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18Governor Carey, faced with a choice of settling for a reduced tax pack. age or ending the year with no new taxes at all, accepted today the package designed by the Legislature's leadership that will yield $600 million in increased business taxes over the next 15 month's.

title: COURT WON'T HEAR JOAN LITTLE APPEAL
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 18 (AP) The North Carolina Supreme Court declined today to hear Joan Little's appeal from a 1974 conviction for breaking and entering and larceny.

title: Girl, Almost 12, Makes Bid on a Police Horse
description: An 11yearold girlwho will be almost 12 soonentered a bid yesterday, for the seven Police Department's bay geldings up for sale. Please, don't say no because I am a girl, she pleaded. I'm very strong and tall.

title: 7 Die in Nightclub Fire Delay on Alarm Assailed
description: Seven persons died and six were injured early yesterday in a fire that destroyed the Blue Angel, a nightclub on East 54th Street.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday:

title: G.N.P. GREW 13.4% IN THIRD QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The total output of the na tion's economy increased at an annual rate of 13.4 percent in the third quarter of 1975, the largest quarterly increase in 25 years, the Commerce Department said today in an updated report.

title: AL VINCENT KAZIE
description: Al Vincent Kazie, former supervisor of tabulation and computer maintenance for The Associated Press, died Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Conflict of Interest Laid To 3 on the P.S.C. Staff
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18A special panel examining the financial affairs of highranking state officials said today that at least three staff members of the Public Service Commission were in violation of new conflictofinterest regulations.

title: Memorial Services
description: STEINHenrietta. A memorial service for Henrietta Stein will be held at 6 P.M., on Sunday, December 21, 1975, at the Guggenheim Hall Auditorium, 5 E. 98 St., N.Y., N.Y.

title: Panel Backs Bush For C.I.A. as Ford Bars Political Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to approve the nomination of George Bush as Director of Central Intelligence, after President Ford ruled out the 51yearold former member of Congress as a possible running mate in 1976.

title: . . . and a Safeguard
description: The tragedy is that almost five years have been lost since the Nixon Administration opened study of the private option. Meanwhile, existing uranium enrichment capacity has become solidly booked into the 1980's, partly as a result of the energy crisis. The Administration unwisely declared a sudden moratorium last year on nuclear fuel commitments, raising worldwide doubts about the credibility of the United States as a nuclear fuel, supplier.

title: Red Snow Near Riviera
description: NICE, France, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Red snow fell over the mountains behind the French Riviera yesterday. The weather bureau explained that red sand from the Sahara had been blown across the Mediterranean with clouds and had fallen when .snows began in the mountains here.

title: An Artificial Leaf Helps In Photosynthesis Study
description: If Rube Goldberg had been a scientist, he might have invented a gadget that takes sunlight, water and carbon dioxide and converts them miraculously into oxygen and energy. A of leaf, in other word.

title: Mother of Unsers Dies
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M.; Dec. 18 (UPI)Mary Unser, head of one of the bestknown auto racing families in the country, died today apparently of a heart attack. She was 69 years old. Mrs. Unser was known as Mom to race car drivers and followers because of the racing exploits of her sons  Bobby and Al. Bobby Unser won his second Indianapolis 500 title this year. He and Al have won the title in four of the last eight years.

title: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: Developing Nation Loans Surge, Morgan Report
description: New international bank loans to the developing nations and Communist bloc borrowers increased sharply last year, a survey by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company showed yesterday.

title: Delaware Youth, 17, Faces Hanging in Killing Conviction
description: GEORGETOWN, Del., Dec. 18 A 17yearold Georgetown youth faces hanging after being convicted today of murder and rape by a Superior Court jury.

title: Finley Selects Tanner to Manage A's
description: OAKLAND, Dec. 18Chuck Tanner, dropped yesterday as manager of the Chicago White Sox, became Charley Einley's 11th manager in 16 years today as the owner of the Oakland A's hired him to take over the American League's fivetime Western Division champions.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners. Not all lifts operating.)

title: Buckley Reluctantly Gives Some Data on His Finances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Senator James L. Buckley, New York ConservativeRepublican, who had repeatedly declined to furnish any information ahciut his personal finances, today made a limited disclosure that he said was being provided in light of next year's election.

title: Governor Indicted In West Virginia On Extortion Count
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 18  Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on a charge of extorting $25,000 from a financier seeking a state bank charter.

title: Soviet Bloc Agrees To Study NATO Plan For Arms Cutbacks
description: VIENNA. Dec. 18 (Reuters) The Soviet bloc agreed today to study new Western proposals for military cutbacks in Europe but said NATO proposals to reduce tactical nuclear weapon stocks were inadequate.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Credit cards cannot be used to pay for legal services in New Jersey, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday. Although the American Bar Association has endorsed the idea, the court said interest rates and other fees charged by credit card companies would make it impractical to set up a system in the state. The court said that using credit cards to pay for legal services could run afoul of the usury laws and raise questions of ethics.

title: United Brands Nears Accord in Panama
description: The United Brands Company has ironed out most of the major problems on future banana operations in its series of meetings with the Government of Panama, Wallace W. Booth, president of United Brands, announced yesterday. A formal agreement is expected to be completed early next year. Mr. Booth said following a series of meetings with Panamanian Vice President Gerado Gonzalez in Panama.

title: STOCKS MOVE UP; DOW CLIMBS 5.82
description: The stock market shook off disappointment over the inability of the House of Representatives to override President Ford's veto of the tax bill and registered an advance in moderate trading activity yesterday.

title: Russian Leaves U.N. Assembly As Moynihan Quotes Sakharov
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18  The chief American delegate, Daniel P. Moynihan, quoted a passage by the dissident Soviet scientist Andrei D. Sakharov last night, creating a littlenoted diplomatic incident.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Thursday, Dec. 18. 34th day. Weather clear, track fast.  by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: FORD SUPPORTERS START FILIBUSTER FOR ANGOLAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Ford Administration sought today to reach a compromise with the Senate that would allow the United States to continue covert support operations in the Angolan civil war.

title: Gordon Stanley Marries Miss Kanarick
description: BradleyAlison Kanarick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Kanarick of Syosset, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Gordon Eugene Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Stanley of Warren, N. J.

title: Kilmer Has Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)  Billy Kilmer, the Washington Redskins quarterback, underwent surgery today to repair his separated right shoulder and a broken bone in his left foot. A club spokesman said the 36yearold Kilmer was resting comfortably at Silbley Memorial Hospital following 1 hour 45 minutes of surgery.

title: N.J. Race Dates Again in Conflict
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP,. N. J., Dec. 18Intrastate conflicts mark the 1976 racing schedule released today by the New Jersey Racmg Commission. The overlapping involves mainly the Summer meet dates at Monmouth Park, Atlantic City Race Course and givehold Raceway. As a result of similar conflicts this year, all three tracks, chiefly Atlantic City, suffered business losses. The commission, however, is urging Atlantic City to run its 38day summer meet, slated for July 19 through Aug. 31 at night at the height of the tourist season and when it would be free of competition. But Kenneth Dunn, Atlantic City's new general manager, says those days are unacceptable to useither at night or dining the day. A meet starting that late in summer would put us in a severe bind foreven decent horses not to mention quality animals, and the shortness of the meeting wouldn't make feasible the expenditure of more than a Halfmillion needed for the right transition.

title: Two Shot Dead in Djibouti
description: DJIBOUTI, Territory of Afars and Issas, Dec. 18 (AP)A police bodyguard of Prime Minister Ali Aref Bourhan today killed two youths and wounded a third person in the center of the city near the main mosque, the police reported.

title: Deaths
description: ABELBEYGeddes, M.D. The members of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecolon, of The Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn note with deep regret the untimely passing of our colleague, Dr. Geddes AbelBey.

title: Senator Pastore Hails Family Viewing on TV
description: Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, in a speech yesterday on the floor of the Senate congratulated the television industry for adopting a family viewing concept in the early evening, and he deplored the incredible callousness of Hollywood unions and producers opposing the plan.

title: EMHART AND USM PLAN HOLDING UNIT
description: The Emhart Corporation of Farmington, Conn., and the USM Corporation of Boston will be merged as wholly owned subsidiaries Into a new holding company, Emhart announced yesterday. Last month Emhart was successful in acquiring 1.24 million common shares of USM through a tender offer of $23 a share.

title: FORD IS CERTIFIED FOR CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON,. Dec. 18 (UPI)  The Federal Election Commission certified today that President Ford and two Democrats, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, of Texas and former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina, were eligible for Federal matching campaign funds.

title: GreekAmerican Investor To Raise Funds for Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) A GreekAmerican industrialist who was investigated in connection with foreign contributions to the NixonAgnew campaigns has joined President Ford's fundraising committee.

title: Prices of Bonds Rise Briskly
description: The credit markets, which faltered just a bit yesterday morning after their sixday advance, sprang back to life after the Federal Reserve reported a surprising $3 billion decline in the money supply. Bond prices surged and closed at their highest levels of the day as traders reached the quick assessment that the Fed must maintain an accomodative credit policy if it is to reach its money supply growth targets.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Nonprofit Group in Suffolk Indicted in False Bills to U.S.
description: A Suffolk County grand jury yesterday indicted the United Taxpayers of Suffolk County Inc., a nonprofit organization, its president, John Gargano, of Central Islip, and Ricardo Curiale of Islip, an associate, on charges of falsely billing the United States Department of Agriculture for summer luncheons.

title: Advertising
description: Just how powerful is public service advertising anyway? The Keep America Beautiful campaign from the Advertising Council doesn't seem to be stopping those who litter. But, then, maybe it would be worse without the advertising.

title: Bridge:
description: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Kallinger Sentenced to 30 to 80 Years
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 18Joseph Kallinger was sentenced today to 30 to 80 year in prison for binding and robbing four suburban Harrisburg women a year ago.

title: Buyers Find That Many Goodies in Santa's Pack Are Less Costly This Year
description: The Yule log won't cost most New Yorkes any more this Christmas than, it did in Christmases past, nor will the tree (real of manmade), the twinkling lights or the electricity to make them dance.

title: Market Place
description: One of the more conservative routes to profits in Wall Street Is through the writing of call options on shares in one's portfolio.

title: REBELS HOLDING OUT IN SAHARA, FIGHTING
description: MADRID, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Fighting in the extreme south of the Spanish Sahara between Mauritanian troops and nationalist guerrillas backed by Algeria is now confined to three, buildings in the frontier town of La Guera, Spanish military sources said today.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.2 From WeekAgo Leve
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell slightly to 189.7 from 189.9 last week.

title: Seoul's Entire Cabinee Resigns; Government Changes Expected
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 19The Prime Minister of South Korea, Kim Jong Pil, and his entire Cabinet submitted their resignations en masse this morning to President Park Chung Hee.

title: Sammartini Music For Church Is Led By Newell Jenkins
description: Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts have demonstrated an unusual loyalty to the music of Giovanni Battista Sammartini in, the past, and on Wednesday in Alice Tully Hall they capped that loyalty with an entire program devoted to his church music.

title: Appeal Is Made for Return Of Abducted Diabetic Girl
description: The mother and uncle of a 4yearold diabetic Bronx girl, apparently abducted Tuesday by her father from bed at Jacobi Hospital, were joined by the police yesterday in making a public appeal for her return before the lack of insulin treatment kills her, possibly within 72 hours.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: BIG HOLIDAY LAYOFF SET BY 2 CAR MAKERS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18Two of the four United States auto companies are planning heavy layoffs around the ChristmasNew Year's holiday period.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Stage: Glass Menagerie
