description: There is something both seductive and visible about a great playwright's first success. The Glass Menagerie was not indeed Tennessee Williams's first play  they closed Battle of Angels in a dimly shocked Bostonbut it was the play first to make him famous, moved him from rooming houses to hotel suites, and gave him that first taste of the Broadway dream. Is it as good as it was? Or rather is it as good as we thought it was because when an important play is revived it is not merely the play but a generation standing up on trial.

title: White House Denies Ford Lacked Candor in Statements on Nixon Pardon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The White House denied today a published report that President Ford had not acted in accordance with his public statements when he pardoned former President Richard M. Nixon stating. The President has dealt with candor and truthfulness at all times on this matter.

title: First U.S. Loan Heads to City As Ford Signs the Legislation
description: Without ceremony, President Ford signed into law yesterday a $2.3 billion revolvingloan program for the city, and hours later the first installment of Federal money, $130 million, was prepared for delivery to the city treasury via computer into comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's office.

title: Quakes Linked to a Fault
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 18 (UPI) A series of eight small earthquakes in the Vale, Ope., area could be related to a long fault line or to geothermal activity, Prof. James Applegate of the Boise State College geology department, said yesterday.

title: Fraser Revamps Australian Government
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 18 Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser announced tonight a complete restructuring of the Federal Government and named his 24member Cabinet to head the new departments.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)The National Football League promised today to allow home telecasts of its playoff games despite the failure of House and Senate confer?? to reach agreement on extending the antiblackout law that expires. Dec. 31.A representative of The league told Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, that the league would permit telecasts of the playoffs as if the current law still existed.

title: About Real Estate
description: Driving on Ditmas Avenue in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn in April, the builder and contractor Berel Zissman came upon a burnedout and abandoned fourstory apartment building. He was struck, as any passerby would be, by the incongruity of blight in an otherwise pleasant neighborhood of Sedate housing and fully grown trees.

title: Gen. Earle Wheeler Dies; ExHead of Joint Chiefs
description: Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, who served as Army. Chief of Staff from Oct, 1, 1962, through July 3, 1964, and then as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff until he retired in 1970, died yesterday afternoon at Frederick (Md.) Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: POOR LANDS SEE GAINS AT PARLEY
description: PARIS, Dec. 16Poor countries came to the world economic conference here this week. determined to begin getting a larger share of global wealth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping Spirit Takes Variety of Forms
description: If the departmentstore version of Santa Claus got his start right here in Metropolitan New York, as some local historians maintain there is every sign in these last hectic shopping days before Christmas that New York remains very much his town.

title: Collision Kills 3 Men
description: LINCOLNVILLE, Me., Dec. 18 (AP)Three men were killed and two were injured in the collision of a car and a tractortrailer truck on snowcovered U.S. 1 here today, the state police said.

title: Parliament Backs Chrysler Funding
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (UPI)Parliament approved today funding for the Government's plan to pump $335 million into Chrysler's ailing British subsidiary to save it from fiscal collapse. But more than 6,000 workers at the company's plant in Scotland unanimously rejected the proposal.

title: Hawks Top Lakers on Rally, 11498
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 18 (AP)Dwight Jones, 18yearold Bill Willoughby and John Drew combined to score 28 points in the fourth quarter tonight as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 11498, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Soviet Will Continue Paying Higher Rate On Grain Shipments
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18  The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today on a new shipping accord that allows American ships to continue charging freight rates significantly higher, than the market level to deliver American grainto the Soviet Union.

title: New Tax Plan: Everybody Knew Details Except the Legislators
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18State Senator Carol Bellamy found a new way today of being embarassed as a legislator.

title: Panel Told of F.B.I. Plot To Discredit a Professor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Federal Bureau of Investigation attempted to discredit a University of Chicago professor in 1968 who was later beaten by an unidentified assailant for his political views, according to F.B.I. documents obtained today from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: Where the Party Set Can Find One Another
description: The red carpet didn't arrive on time, so the guests in their evening finery had to troop down a grimy, paintsplotched stairway. A few grimaced, but never mind: They were on their way to Doubles; one of Manhattan's snazziest and most exclusive new private clubs.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.2 billion tonmiles, 1.7 percent below the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same 1975 period totaled 463,835 cars, 0.6 percent below last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 0.4 percent below last year.

title: Art World Stunned By Ruling on Rothko
description: Surrogate Millard L. Midonick's momentous decision against Frank Lloyd, the Marlborough Galleries and the executors of the, Mark Rothko estate was the talk of a stunned art world yesterday, and particularly of the tight little world of dealers on 57th Street and upper Madison Avenue.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: William Dixon Zywot testified for three hours before a statewide grand jury investigating whether Kafen Anne Quinlan had been beaten before she lapsed into a coma last April, and was released to return to his parents' home in Illinois. State law enforcement officials said later they had uncovered no evidence to date of any criminality connection with the investigation.

title: No. 2 Executive Named By Hearst Corporation
description: The Hearst Corporation has named Frank A. Bennack Jr., 42 years old, as executive vice president and No. 2 man in the privately held international publishing and broadcasting company. He is the youngest man in the history of the corporation to hold the post, which has been vacant since John R. Miller, 61, was named president and chief executive last March.

title: Examples of Tax Withholding
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The following tables, based on information supplied by the Internal Revenue Service, give examples of the amount of tax that is being withheld now and the amount that will be withheld if no extension of the 1975 tax cuts is approved.

title: General Wheeler Dies
description: Gen Earle G. Wheeler, who retired in 1970 as chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, died in Maryland at 67. Page 42.

title: Energy Cost Is Expected to Rise 10 to 15%
description: An official of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said here yesterday that the company expected to raise prices next year by 7 to 8 percent.

title: Ambidextrous Pilot
description: The telephone rang and rang and rang yesterday in the home of the former sports editor and columnist of the Waxahachie Daily Light, a pillar of the free press that for many years has fearlessly denounced the boll weevil and Spoken out in favor of an early spring for Waxahachie, Texas. According to an old Baseball Register, Paul Rapier Richard's hobby is farming, so perhaps he was out plowing the south forty, but it seemed more likely he was up in the Dallas Public Library poring over the 1975 records Brian Downing, Bucky Dent, Carlos May and other employees of the Chicago White Sox. He will want to know all he can learn about these young amen by the time he takes over as manager in training campunless Bill Veeck trades them out from under him before that. Many years ago Mary Frances Veeck realized that her spouse was deeply devoted to her and their marriage would be safe as long as he couldn't swap her for a lefthanded power hitter.

title: 3 Men Are Found Murdered In Newark Apartment House
description: The bodies of three young men, the apparent victims of an execution, were found yesterday afternoon in a sparsely furnished apartment on Newark's South Side. The police said the motive for the slayings was unclear.

title: S.E.C. Petitioners Seek Corporate Disclosures
description: A coalition of public interest and church groups has petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to require corporate disclosure of foreign payoffs and political contributions. The agency was asked to make corporate officers and auditors personally liable for misleading statements about such transactions.

title: JURY INDICTS CHIEF OF CINCINNATI POLICE
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 18 (AP)Cincinnati Police Chief Carl Goodin and six vice squad officers were indicted today on charges that included bribery, extortion and perjury.

title: Panel Backs Bush For C.I.A. as Ford Bars Political Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Senate Armed Services Committee voted today to approve the nomination of George Bush as Director of Central Intelligence, after President Ford ruled out the 51yearold former member of Congress as a possible running mate in 1976.

title: Grand Jury Bars Police Indictment In Death of L.I. Boy
description: A Manhattan grand jury has found insufficient evidence to indict an offduty police officer who fatally shot a 16yearold Long Island youth during a curbside dispute in midManhattan on Nov. 4.

title: ARGENTINE AIRMEN SEIZE 2 KEY BASES AND ABDUCT CHIEF
description: BUENOS AIRES Dec 18A group of Argentine Air Force officers kidnapped their. Cominander in Chief today, releasing him several hours later, and seized control of two air bases.

title: Loch Ness Monster Shown As Hoax by Another Name
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuters)A Scottish Member of Parliament has discovered an anagram for Nessiteras rhombopteryx, the name applied to the fabled Loch Ness monster by a United States researcher, Robert Rines and a leading British naturalist, Sir Peter Scott.

title: BISHOP ASKS ACTION ON WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)Bishop James S. Rausch, general secretary of the United States Catholic Conference, called on the United States today to ratify two international conventions aimed at protecting the political rights of women.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Ford Administration sought yesterday to reach a compromise with the Senate that would allow the United States to continue covert support operations in the Angolan civil war: The compromise was initiated by Senator Robert R. Griffin, a Michigan Republican, after John L. McClellan, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, failed to induce President Ford to concur in a system that would enable Congress to play a larger role in deciding on secret operations. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Pillsbury Net Is Up 21.1%; Other Companies Report
description: The Pillsbury Company, a major diversified food concern, reported yesterday profit increases of 21.1 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 22.5 percent for the half year ended Nov. 30.

title: Mock Rites at City College
description: About 60 City College students staged a mock funeral yesterday for the school's mascot, the Beaver, to protest recent cuts in the City University budget. They gathered on the college's north campus at 138th Street and marched down Convent Avenue carrying a cardboard coffin marked Student Body C.C.N.Y./Buried Alive.

title: Farewell To 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18In a few days, 1975 will be gone, another drop of time, and most Americans seem to be saying, good riddance. It was mainly a year of tidying up after old blunders and extravagances; of high pries, unemployment and inflation; of sweeping away the stench of Vietnam and Watergateall useful work, long delayed.

title: 2d Night of Mozambique Strife Is Intense
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Friday, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Troops loyal to the Government of Mozambique, aided by paramilitary forces, battled for the` second night to put down an uprising by soldiers and policemen in Lourengo Marques, the new nation's capital, according to radio reports monitored here.

title: Levi Names Aide to Head New Office of Investigations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Attorney General Edward H. Levi has appointed Michael Shaheen Jr. as the Justice Department's counsel on professional responsibility and the head of a new office to oversee investigations of alleged misconduct by department employees.

title: Little Damage Is Expected From an Oil Spill in Alaska
description: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 18 (UPI) A state official said today that there apparently would be little or no environmental damage from a spill of 600,000 gallons of diesel fuel oil at a construction site in the Prudhoe Bay oil fields.

title: Governors Cite Tax Burden
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Democratic and Republican governors told President Ford today that many states were in financial straits and urged him not to ask them to carry more of the tax burden for existing Federalstate programs. Mr. Ford got a report on the state of the states at a twohour meeting with nine governors.

title: A BLACK WILL HEAD RICHMOND SCHOOLS
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 18 (AP)Dr. Richard C. Hunter, 36 years old, was appointed today as School Superintendent, effective Feb. 1. He is the first black ever to head the city's school system, which has turned increasingly black the last few years with the advent of courtordered school busing.

title: 30th General Assembly: Strain and Frustration
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18The 30th General Assembly, which started hr September in a conciliatory and pragmatic mood, ended yesterday in a climate of strain and frustration. New conflicts  espedaily the Arabled campaign against Zionismsuffocated the spirit of negotiation between rich and poor nations.

title: CORRECTION
description: The picture accompanying the obituary of Noble Sissle in early editions of yesterday's New York Times was not that of Noble Sissle, as stated, but of Eubie Blake, a musician who will be 93 in February.

title: INDUSTRIAL BUYING SPURS COCOA RISE
description: Cocoa futures rose yesterday on buying by several leading users, including the Hershey Foods Corporation and de Zaan Inc., a Dutch cocoa powder manufacturer and subsidiary of W. R. Grace & Company.

title: Beatrice Phillips Wed To Henry N. Sachs
description: Beatrice Feingold Phillips of Boston, widow of Bernard Phillips, was married in Boston yesterday to Henry N. Sachs of New York, a widower. Rabbi Roland B. Gittelsohn performed the ceremony at noon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Goldman, brotherinlaw and sister of the bride.

title: Governor Indicted In West Virginia On Extortion Count
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 18  Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on a charge of extorting $25,000 from a financier seeking a state bank charter.

title: CHILE RELEASES 165 IN HOLIDAY AMNESTY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 18 (UPI)  President Augusta Pinochet today ordered the release of 165 political prisoners, including five priests.

title: 2 G.O.P. Maine Representatives Charge White House Pressure for Their Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The two Republican Representatives from Maine charged today that the White House had exerted improper pressure on them to try to get them to support President Ford's veto of the tax legislation.

title: DR. CELESTINE L. SMITH
description: Dr. Celestine L. Smith; former National Y.W.C.A. human relations specialist and a practicing psychologist, died Sunday in Mount Holly, N.J. She was 72 years old and lived in Medford Leas, N.J.

title: ECONOMISTS WARN ON TAX INCREASE
description: Some of the nation's leading private economists said yesterday after the House refused to override President Ford's veto of the tax cut bill that if the Federal Government's personal tax cut was not extended into next year, the economic recovery, which is already rather wobbly, could weaken even further.

title: Israel Turns Over Bodies Of 93 Egyptian Soldiers
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 18 (AP)Israel turned over to Egypt today the bodies of 93 soldiers killed in the Middle East wars of 1967 and 1973 the military command announced.

title: PRICES ARE HIGHER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Increasing, hopes that a taxcut compromise can still be accomplished between Congress and President Ford helped advance prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: ARGENTINE AIRMEN SEIZE 2 KEY BASES AND ABDUCT CHIEF
description: BUENOS AIRES, Friday, Dec. 19A group of Argentine Air Force officers kidnapped their Commander in Chief yesterday, releasing him several hours later, and seized control of two air bases.

title: Rothko Executors Ousted; Penalties Put at $9 Million
description: Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of Manhattan removed yesterday the three executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, and assessed damages and fines totaling $9,252,000 against the executors, Frank Lloyd and Mr. Lloyd's Marlborough Galleries.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Concerto for Flute, Violin and Harpsichord in A minor, Bach; Karelia Suite, Sibelius; Cello Concerto in D, Haydn; Symphony in D, Bach.

title: Tomorrow's Pro Football: From Noon Until Midnight
description: There have been complaints that the good teams seldom show up on the telecasts of the National Football League games shown in New York. That will be rectified this weekend with a surfeit of contests and four of the eight proba b l e p l a y o f f teams will be in action, Vikings, Rams, Steelers and Colts. The viewing will begin at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow with Minnesota at Buffalo, Channel 2. Then will come Denver at Miami, Channel 4, 3:30 P.M., followed by Pittsburgh at Los Angeles, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Discounting pregame and postgame shows, that will be nine hours of football. On Sunday Channel 4 will present New England at Baltimore, 2 P.M., and Channel 2 will give the final views of this year's Giants playing in San Francisco at 4 P.M. To say goodbye to the Jets one must go to Shea Stadium where the Dallas Cowboys are the opponents. A preview of all games follows with wonlost records in parentheses:

title: Troopers at Rites Here Mourn a Slain Comrade
description: When Helen McDonagh, five months pregnant, came out of St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Riverdale yesterday morning behind her husband's coffin, she was, dryeyed and composed.

title: Coach at Lafayette Plaited by a Memory
description: After two weeks of the basketball season, Gil Fershtman surveys his scene and decides, Everything is pretty nice. and why not? Fershtman's Lafayette team has won its first four league games; he will be going for his 200th career vicstory as the Frenchies' coach today; his son, Gerry, has made his mark in basketball at Beach Channel in Queens, and one of his players is the prospective subject of a documentary film on high school basketball.

title: Tenants on West Side Protest Alleged Prostitution in Building
description: A building on the Upper West Side was picketed yesterday by residents who charged that a place of prostitution was being operated in one of the apartments there.

title: Korean Prays in House Caucus Room
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Korean revivalist whose sermons strongly imply that he may be the messiah, held what was billed as a prayer meeting today in a House of Representatives caucus room.

title: Giants Strinfi Along 3dStringer
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 18Mike Wells has to be the Giants' most valuable player this season. He's the only member of the team who hasn't contributed to a loss.

title: FORD SUPPORTERS START FILIBUSTER FOR ANGOLAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Ford Administration sought today to reach a compromise with the Senate that would allow the United State's to continue covert support operations in the Angolan civil war.

title: EARLY ANGOLA AID BY U.S. REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Ford Administration's initial authorization for substantial Central Intelligence Agency financial operations inside Angola came in January 1975 more than two months before the first significant Soviet buildup, Wellinformed officials report.

title: City Retail Sales Register Rise
description: After showing modest gains of only 5.5 percent through November, retail sales in the metropolitan area have picked up sharply in recent weeks, and they are now expected to show much larger gains during the Christmas season.

title: BANK IS SUBJECT OF STATE INQUIRY
description: The State Department of Banking, in what is believed to be an unusual action, sent a team of examiners yesterday to investigate the operations of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

title: Mr. Ford's Fraud
description: Gerald Ford's veto of lax reduction bill may or may not prove to have been bad politics. But it was bad economics and sorry leadership. If reflected callous unconcern for Amer ican wage workers and a Nixonlike contempt for American voters, who were offered a justification reeking with piety but fraudulent in every major particular.

title: City University Plan May Cut Down on Minorities
description: The new standards for admission to the City University could cut minority enrollment in next fall's freshman class by more than twothirds and eventually leave the university with the same racial composition it had before the openadmissions policy was begun five years ago, according to a study by the Board of Higher Education.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday.

title: C.A.B. Confuses Airlines in Naming Skiers' Flight
description: After once ruling that Texas International Airlines could not be confused with Trans International Airlines despite its having the same initials, the Civil Aeronautics Board did just that today in mistakenly naming the Texas carrier as the operator of a special charter flight between New York and Denver.

title: Rights Group Seeking Changes In East Orange Police Structure
description: EAST ORANGE, Dec. 18The Essex County branch of People United to Save Humanity, a civilrights organization, called for major changes in the structure and leadership of the Police Department here, as well as stricter control over the use of firearms by, the police both on and off duty.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League LAST NIGHT'S GAMES N.Y. Islanders 4, 1 Toronto 2. Buffalo 5, Minnesota 2. WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES N.Y. Islanders 3, N.Y Rangers 0. Boston 3, Washington 7. Detroit 3, Buffalo 1. Kansas City 6, Vancouver 5. Montreal 2, Los Angeles 1. Philadelphia. 4, Chicago 2. Pittsburgh 9, California 2. Toronto 6. St. Louis 2. Minnesota 3, Atlanta 2. STANDING OF THE TEAMS CAMPBELL CONFERENCE Patrick Division

title: STEPS ARE TAKEN TO REOPEN TOMBS
description: Preliminary approval was given yesterday to a plan that would provide up to $11 million in Federal funds to reopen the Manhattan. House of Detention (the Tombs) and to open nine new court part to try cases of defendants incarcerated for a year or longer.

title: Music
description: Edgard Varese was, if not the first, the most influential composer to suggest that there was no more music to be written and that organized sound would take its place. His Dserts, in which sections of instrumentally and electronically produced sounds alternate, stands as one of the significant visions of that future, in which the play of colors, the contrast of textures and the gathering and releasing of rhythmic tensions would suffice to fill all a listener's needs.

title: Board of Estimate Honors Secretary on Retirement
description: David C. O'Connor, Secretary of the Board of Estimate, who will retire on Dec. 31 after 47 years in the Civil Service, was honored yesterday by Mayor Beame and the other board members at their final meeting of the year.

title: The potential conflict between free speech and fair trial
description: SAN DIEGO. Justice Harry A. Blackmun's action in the Nebraska gag order case sustaining the right of courts to forbid the press to report on confessions and other statements that might implicate the defendant has again suggested the potential conk flirt between free speech and fair trial. And now the United States Supreme Court, refusing to lift the order is to review the case.

title: CORRECTION
description: The picture accompanying the obituary of Noble Sissle in early editions of yesterday's New York Times was not that of Noble Sissle, as stated, but of Eubie Blake, a musician who will be 93 in February.

title: Palmer, President Launch Golf Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The United States Golf Association, the governing body that traditionally has maintained a frosty remoteness from the rest of the world, made a move today toward thawing its attitude.

title: Despite Reduced Means, Donors Give to Neediest
description: The modest gifts to the New York Times Neediest Case Fund from an anonyMons donor Philadelphia and from Dorothy P. Stewart Manhattan were accompanied by letters noting that even though the economic downturn affected their own lives they still wanted to help others who were in more dire straits.

title: Surrogate in the Rothko Lawsuit
description: The Mark Rothko case involved 20,000 pages of testimony; 3,000 additional pages of legal briefs; detailed and continuous press coverage and millions of dollars in damages. Yet, when Surrogate Millard Lesser Midonick, who presided over the case and handed down his decision yesterday, was asked if it was the biggest case of, his judicial career, he replied:

title: Current Federal Taxes And Prospective Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The following tables, based on data from the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation, show the Federal income tax paid now by families of different sizes, with typical deductions, and the taxes that will be paid next year if the 1975 tax cut is allowed to lapse:

title: Israeli Who Favors State for Palestinians Is Stabbed
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 18A controversial magazine editor who advocates the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel was stabbed this morning at his home here.

title: Business Briefs
description: MONTVALE, N. J., Dec. 18 (UPI)The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said today it had signed agreements providing it with $200 million in credit. The supermarket chain said the money would give the company more room for redevelopment.

title: The Pop Life
description: The year 1975 began with dour predicitions of decline and collapse in the world of pop music.

title: MEDIATION OFFERED IN OPERA STALEMATE
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board, Vincent D. McDonnell, offered yesterday to assist the Metropolitan Opera and its orchestra members in reaching a contract settlement that would avert a strike threatened Jan. 1.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: DUBLIN AIDE LINKS U.S. FUNDS TO I.R.A
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP)Ireland's Foreign Minister, Garret FitzGerald, said tonight that it is entirely likely that most of $2 million believed to have been raised by IrishAmericans for relief aid in Northern Ireland had bought guns and explosives for the Irish Republican Army.

title: Olsons Bar a U.S. Suit on LSD Death; Hope Congress Will Pass Damages Bill
description: The family of Dr. Frank R. Olson said yesterday that it had decided against suing the Federal Government for his wrongful death 22 years ago, after he was given LSD without his knowledge in a test by the Central Intelligence Agency. But they said they hoped Congress would pass a private bill awarding them $1.25 million.

title: COURT ABSOLVES G.O.P. CHAIRMAN
description: MINEOLA, LI., Dec. 18A Nassau County Court has dis, missed an indictment charging Richard J. Zeidler, chairman of the Brookhaven Town Republican committee, with a violation of the state election laws.

title: In Memoriam
description: FITZGERALDBill. Brother Bill, on your tenth anniversary, your memory will always linger on Mass Friday, Dec. 19, at 6:45 P.M., Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 W. 71st St.

title: The Heroin Trade
description: The picture of the narcotics situation in New York City, as recently reported in The Times, is one of current tragedy and impending disaster. That picture is the result of a grim and simple equation: While the heroin traffic is rapidly climbing back to record levels, the capacity of narcotics law enforcers to cope with the problem is being steadily diminished as a result of the fiscal crisis.

title: Dr. Metlis Marries Laurie Richmond
description: Laurie Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Richmond of Hackensack, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., was Married yesterday evening to Dr. Schuyler C. Metlis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew E. Metlis of Brooklyn. Rabbi Pincus Dachowitz performed the ceremony in Temple Beth El in Hackensack.

title: Angolans in Lagos Display 2 Captured South Africans
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 18 (AP) Two white South African soldiers captured in Angola by forces armed by the Soviet Union were put on display here today as evidence of South African involvement in the Angolan civil war.

title: Minnesota Upsets Marquette Five
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 18 (AP)Undefeated Minnesota reeled off 8 consecutive points in overtime to upset previously unbeaten Marquette, 7773, tonight.

title: Hawaiian Quake: Recurring Challenge on New Island
description: KILAUEA VOLCANO, Hawaii, Dec. 18Nature and Spreading Civilization tested each other last month here on the south slope of this geologically young island.

title: Nuclear Fuel Risks . . .
description: For a quartercentury the United States has supplied 90 percent or more of the nonCommunist world's needs for enriched uranium, the fuel now used by almost all commercial nuclear reactors, providing foreign as well as domestic utilities with longterm assurances of adequate supplies as well as low prices.

title: France Chooses New Jet To ReEquip Its Air Force
description: PARIS. Dec. 13 (Reuters)France today chose a new Mirage fighter aircraft known, as the Mirage Delta2000 to equip its air force in the next decade, officials said here today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: Flexible Flyer Maker skids
description: The company that builds the Flexible Flyers that have taken generations of redcheeked American children down snowy hills has found today's economic conditions tough sledding.

title: Top Soviet Planner Predicts Slower Industrial Growth
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP)A top Soviet planner said today that industrial growth rates would be slower in the next five years because of the expensive drive to develop Siberia and the high cost of antipollution measures.

title: Impasse on Taxes
description: President Ford's veto of the tax bill and the failure of the House to override create a situation that ought not be allowed to drag into 1976 unresolved. If inaction causes income tax rates to revert to the precut levels of 1974, virtually every American family will suffer some loss in purchasing power, with further adverse effects on an already sluggish recovery.

title: Rich and Poor Nations End Paris Session With a Compromise
description: PARIS, Dec. 18The international economic conference ence moved toward the close of its first session early this morning after compromising on a procedural argument between industrial and developing countries, The wrangling foreshadowed the tough bargaining that lies ahead.

title: State Union Issues List of Pay Raises Given Carey's Staff
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18The state employees union, facing a proposal from Governor Carey for a wage freeze, counterattacked today by issuing a summary of salary increases and promotions that the Governor had granted in recent months to his own staff of appointees.

title: Man Reaches 100 and Credits Sloth
description: Donal McLaughlin celebrated his 100th birthday yesterday. His longevity, he said, was partly due to a rule established early in life.

title: Accused Con Man Taken In Himself
description: A wouldbe confidence man was himself taken in when two disguised policemen showed up to buy some swell Christmas presents for $600. District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said yesterday.

title: Developing Nation Loans Surge, Morgan Report
description: New international bank loans to the developing nations and Communist bloc borrowers increased sharply last year, a survey by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company showed yesterday.

title: Carey Settles for Package Of BusinessTax Increases
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18Governor Carey, faced with a choice, of settling for a reduced tax package or ending the year with no new taxes at all, accepted today the package designed by the Legislature's leadership that will yield $600 million in increased business taxes over the next 15 months.

title: Allis Raising Dividend
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The AllisChalmers Corporation said today it was increasing its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share from 6 cents. The dividend is payable Jan. 31 to shareholders of record Dec. 31. The company said its directors cited higher earnings, a generally improved financial position and strength in certain market areas as reasons for the increase.

title: Poland Acts to Give Party Leading Role in the State
description: WARSAW, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Poland took the first formal step today toward changing its Constitution to recognize the leading role of the Communist Party in state affairs and making the party leader, Edward Gierek, the, country's President.

title: Cartier Agrees to Sell Business to Foreigners
description: Cartier Inc., the Fifth Avenue jewelry store owned by the Kenton Corporation, has announced that it has reached an agreement in principle for the sale of its business to a new corporation controlled by foreign investors.

title: Common Market Moves To Bar Sex Bias in Jobs
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The Common Market today gave support to women's rights campaigners by outlawing all sex discrimination in lobs, informed sources said.

title: Castro Tells Party Congress Cubans Shed Blood Abroad
description: HAVANA, Dec. 18 (Reuters) Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba speaking for the second day to his party's first congress, received a standing ovation today when he declared that the Cuban Army had shed blood more than once in other countries threatened by imperialist aggression and had helped to organize the armed forces and militia of other progressive countries.

title: General Wheeler Dies
description: Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, who retired in 1970 as chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, died in Maryland at 67. Page 42.

title: Report Says Rubin Carter Passed LieDetector Tesi
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who are serving life sentences for a 1966 triplemurder in a bar in Paterson, N.J., passed liedetector tests hours after the crime a confidential report to Governor Byrne has disclosed.

title: Connors Leads Off in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 18Stay loose, yelled Jimmy Connors when United States Ambassador Joseph John Jova pulled his name first from a cup today.

title: Moroccan Editor Slain
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  Omar Benjelloun, a newspaper editor and a leader of Morocco's leftwing opposition party, was stabbed to death by three assailants outside his home here today. Mr. Benjelloun, 42 years old, was a member of the executive committee of the party, Socialist Union of Popular Forces, and had edited the party's daily, AI Mouharir, since being released from prison about a year ago.

title: People in Sports
description: Archie Griffin of Ohio State and Fran Tarkenton of the Minnesota Vikings, two little football players who have never missed a game, were named college and pro player of the year, respecttively, by the Maxwell Memorial Football Club of Philadelphia yesterday.

title: Fantasia on No Exit
description: Abraham Beanie is smiling. Governor Carey is happy. President Ford is selfsatisfied, after behaving like a combination of Cotton Mather and Jehovah. All of them are pleased, relieved and relaxed. Our city, we are told, will be saved and we, the people, should go on our way rejoicing.

title: Witness in Quinlan Case Is Freed After Questioning
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18William Dixon Zywot testified for three hours today before a statewide grand jury investigating whether Karen Anne Quinlan had been beaten before she lapsed into a coma last April, and was released to return to his parents' home in Illinois.

title: Political Prisoners A Growing Issue For Lisbon Regime
description: LISBON, Dec. 18The Portuguese authorities have come under increased attacks from left and right over the situation of political prisoners.

title: 7 Accused of Plotting to Extort Money for Sweetheart Pacts
description: Six union officials and a labor relations consultant were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to coerce and extort money from a nursing home and two business concerns in exchange for the promise of sweetheart, or favorable, contracts.

title: HOUSE VOTES BAN ON SST LANDINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The House voted a sixmonth ban tonight on landings in the United States by the supersonic Concorde jetliner.

title: About New York
description: The handmade cigar, once a staple of New York craftsmanship, is not a lost art in the city, but it is a diminished one. Time was when there was a storefront cigar factory every several blocks downtown, and cigar smoking cast an aromatic pall over the city.

title: Amex to Show Loss In the Final Quarter
description: The American Stock Exchange will lose money in the Fourth quarter but show a proit for the year of less than $500,000, Paul Kolton, chairman, said yesterday. He did not indicate the size of the loss. The Amex, lost $269,000 in the fourth quarter last year and $1.1 million in the full year.

title: City U. Plan May Cut Down on Minorities
description: The new standards for admission to the City University could cut minority enrollment in next fall's freshman class by more than twothirds and eventually leave the university with the same racial composition it had before the openadmissions policy was begun five years ago, according to a study by the Board of Higher Edu cation.

title: Rothko Executors Ousted; Penalties Put at $9 Million
description: Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of Manhattan removed yesterday the three executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, and assessed damages and fines totaling $9,252,000 against the executors, Frank Lloyd and Mr. Lloyd's Marlborough Galleries.

title: EDWARD J. GORDON
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18Ed. ward J. Gordon, associate proFessor of English at Yale University, died yesterday at his home in North Haven, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: 7 Die in Nightclub Fire Delay on Alarm Assailed
description: Seven persons died and six were injured early yesterday in a fire that destroyed the Blue Angel, a nightclub on East 54th Street.

title: THEODORE H. BALL
description: Theodore H. Ball, who retired in January 1970 as vice president and merchandise manager of accessories at Saks Fifth Avenue, the department store, died yesterday in Paris. He was 79 years old.

title: 4 ARRESTED HERE ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Four alleged members of an international drug ring that reportedly used a 54foot yacht registered in the name of a woman who is a British peer to smuggle more than a ton of hashish from Morocco to Mystic, Conn., were arraigned in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday. Officials put the street value of the hashish at $2 million.

title: Hal Pearl, 61, CoAuthor Of Dumbo, Flying Elephant
description: Hal Pearl, coauthor of the children's classic Dumbo, the Flying Elephant, which was made into a highly successful Walt Disney film in the early 1940's, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital, Miami. He was 61 years old.

title: News for Namath and N. F. L.: Alcohol Harmful Even After 20 Hours
description: Even if an athlete didn't have a trace of alcohol in his body and hadn't touched a drop in 20 hours, his skill could remain impaired from drinking, the city's deputy chief medical examiner said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: A homosexual can be brave and resourceful enough to save the life of a President, it turned out recently. There is a homosexual subculture in the hypermasculine world of professional athletics, it was reported just last week. The stereotypes are collapsing all around us. And people who know about these things have told me that C. A.

title: AMTRAK WILL USE NEW LOCOMOTIVES
description: Six new electric locomotives to haul passenger trains at speeds of up to 110 miles an hour between New York and Washington will be in service by Christmas, Amtrak announced yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Onassis Oil Deal Reportedly Upset With C.I.A.'s Help
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 18 (Reuters)  The Central Intelligence Agency helped several American oil companies to undermine a contract that would have given the late Aristotle Onassis complete control over oil shipments from Saudi Arabia, Senate sources said today.

title: PublicTV Bill Sent to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI)The House of Representatives has passed and sent to President Ford legislation to provide up to $634 million to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting over a fiveyear period. It marks the first longterm Government support for the agency. The bill, which must be implemented through annual appropriations legislation, was approved 313 to 72.

title: Panel Told of F.B.I. Plot To Discredit a Professor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Federal Bureau of Investigation attempted to discredit a University of Chicago professor in 1968 who was later beaten by an unidentified assailant for his political views, according to F.B.I. documents obtained today from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: ECONOMISTS URGE TAX CUT FOR 1976
description: Some of the nation's leading private economists said yesterday after the House refused to override President Ford's veto of the tax cut bill that if the Federal Government's personal tax cut was not extended into next year, the economic recovery, which is already rather wobbly, could weaken even further.

title: Notes on People
description: The reaction of Britain's Prime Minister Harold Wilson to a large circulation London tabloids report that he was ready to quit because he was tired and in ill health was swift. Yesterday he sued for libel.

title: 2 IN HOFFA CASE REFUSE TO TALK
description: NEWARK, Dec. 18 (AP)Two suspects in the abduction of James R. Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, appeared before a Federal grand jury today but refused to testify.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Dec. 19, 1975 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: TV: Mrs. Warren's Profession Ends a Series
description: Public television's Classic Theater series, imported from the British Broadcasting Corporation, is brought to an appropriate conclusion this week with a quite respectable production of George Bernard. Shaw's Mrs. Warren's Profession. It will be broadcast tonight at 8 on Channels 21 and 31, and tomorrow at 9 on Channel 13.

title: POPE ASKS FERVOR IN EVANGELIZATION
description: ROME, Dec. 18Pope Paul VI said today that the religious freedom of nonRoman Catholics was not violated by evangelization and called for a revival of missionary fervor in the church.

title: Carter Won't Defer to Carey in Nomination Drive
description: Jimmy Carter said here yesterday that he never intended to yield to Governor Carey nor to any other favorite son in his quest for the Democratic nomination for President, and he called unfortunate the New York law that bans the listing of Presidential candidates on the ballot along with delegates pledged to them.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Conferees Agree on a $6.5 Billion Bill for Railroads
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on a $6.5 billion compromise bill to reorganize the seven bankrupt Northeast railroads into a new Governmentoperated corporation and to aid other troubled carriers around the nation.

title: TAX CUT VETO SUSTAINED IN MUSE; PROSPECT OF INCREASES IS RAIDED AS A COMPROMISE PROVES ELUSIV.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The House of Representatives, by vote of 265 to 157, failed today to override President Ford's veto of the tax cut extension bill, thus raising the prospect of a withholding tax increase for almost everyone, starting in January.

title: Al Post, Records Chairman Of Amateur Athletic Union
description: Al Post, chairman of the Amateur Athletic Union records committee, died yesterday in Bloomfield, N.J., after having apparently suffered a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

title: 3 Guilty in Race Fix Get 5Year Maryland Ban
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 18 (AP) Three of the four, Maryland jockeys convicted recently of having participated in a racefixing scheme at Bowie Race Course drew fiveyear suspensions today from the Maryland Racing Commiscinn

title: Truce Gains in Beirut but Fighting Rages in Suburbs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18Christian and Moslem gunmen exchanged heavy fire today in the suburbs of Beirut, and clashes were also reported in the northern city of Tripoli.

title: 14 Inches of Snow Give Lift to Vermont Skiing
description: Bill Riley, promotion director of the Mount Mansfield Company's ski complex at Stowe, was asked yesterday what was new at the popular Vermont resort. Fourteen inches of delightful new powder, bellowed Riley. That's what's new. The snow fell last night, Rikey explained, just when it seemed only one or two of Stowe's lifts would be operating this weekend.

title: Ginger Snaps Aren't Just for Eating
description: As decorative as they are delicious, these blond spicy ginger wafers are easy to make and sturdy enough to hang on the Christmas tree.

title: Zionism Dispute Is Rankling Mexicans
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 18Mexican officials and businessmen are displaying signs of irritation at the continued controversy over Mexico's votes in the United Nations General Assembly for resolutions equating Zionism with racism.

title: Theodosius Dobzhansky, Geneticist, Is Dead at 75
description: Dr. Theodosius Dobzhansky, the worldfamous geneticist, died yesterday in Davis, Calif., where he had been adjunct professor of genetics since 1971 at the University of California. He was 75 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PIAF AND POETRY Eightcen ballads associated with the legendary sparrow of song, Edith Piaf, are on the bill of Dear Piaf, a concert salute by five singers and a pianist opening tonight at Mama Gail's theater restaurant, 24 Wooster Street. Tickets are $5 with an added $2.50 minimum for food. Curtain times: Friday and Saturday, 7:30 and 9:45 P.M.: Sunday, 3:30 and 6:45 P.M.; Tuesday and Wednesday, 7:30 P.M., and Thursday, 7:30 and 9:45 P.M. Reservations: 9252347.

title: New Finnish Regime Raises Gas and Cigarette Prices
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  Smokers, Motorists and higherincome earners awaiting tax relief have beer hit hard by the new coalition Government's budget, for 1976.

title: Nets Beaten By Squires In Overtime
description: HAMPTON, Va., Dec. 18 (UPI)Ticky Burden, a rookie, scored 33 points tonight to help the Virginia Squires snap a fivegame losing streak with a 9490 overtime victory over the New York Nets.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $2.29 billion, up 15 percent from the yearearlier $2 billion. Retail store sales totaled $11.61 billion, up 16 percent from $9.97 billion.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL Colleges

title: Goodyear to Raise Prices on Sheeting And Plastic Film
description: Price changes for a variety of chemical products were announced yesterday.

title: City Receives First US. Loan. As Ford Signs the Legislation
description: Without ceremony, President Ford signed into law early yesterday afternoon a $2.3 billion loan program, for New York City. Late last night, after hours of preparation of papers by lawyers and a nervous wait for a state trooper bringing from Albany a key document signed by the Governor, the first installment of Federal money$130 Millionwas finally transferred to the city's account with the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: U. S. IS SCRAPPING CARRIER PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Administration has decided to maintain three aircraft carriers in the Western Pacific and two in the Mediterranean as a demonstration of a continuing commitment to a forwardarea military strategy.

title: Revenge Believed Motive In Diggs Family Slayings
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 18With revenge remaining as the only motive  including the possibility of reprisals from impatient loan sharksdetectives and police investigators here have begun stepping up their inquiries into the personal and business life of Wesley Diggs, a Harlem bar owner whose wife and four children were murdered in their home in Teaneck earlier this month.

title: House RollCall on Vote to Override Ford's Veto of the Tax Cut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Following is the rollcall vote by which the House failed today to override President Ford's veto of the tax cut extension. A yes vote is a vote to override.

title: Trend Reversal Is a Surprise
description: The nation's money supply experienced one of its sharpest contractions on record in the latest reporting week, reversing the stron expansionary movement of preceding weeks and surprising analysts who bad anticipated a continuation of the upward trend.

title: Roquepine Dead At 14: Won Million
description: CAEN, France, Dec. 18 (Reuters)The great French trotting mare Roquepine, a twotime winner of the Roosevelt International trot, died last night on a farm near here at the age of 14.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Wood, Field and Stream: About Books
description: If your bank account is substantial and if you have a friend or spouse who fishes for Atlantic salmon and who is a collector of the literature of the sport, you might wish to present him with one of the new, limitededition volumes of Dean Sage's 1888 classic, The Ristigouche and Its Salmon Fishing.

title: BERNARD PEYTON
description: Bernard Peyton, a director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & and a descendant of the founder, Eleuthere Irne du Pont, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Madrid Police Again Break Up an Amnesty Rally
description: MADRID, Dec. 18Riot police broke up tonight the second attempt in two days by leftist opposition groups to demonstrate in Madrid in favor of amnesty for political prisoners and exiles.

title: Kallinger, in Pennsylvania Is Given 30 to 80 Years
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 18Joseph Kallinger was sentenced today to 30 to 80 years in prison for binding and robbing four suburban Harrisburg women a year ago.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: FORT WORTH, Tex.Barry's graph told part of the story. From an average of 17 verbal assaults on his parents each day, he was now calling them names or screaming at them only two or three times a day. From an average of one completed taskcutting his own meat, or cleaning his own roomevery four days, he had risen to about two a day.

title: BOMBING IN ULSTER KILLS 2 SOLDIERS
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Dec. 18 (AP)Two British soldiers were killed by a bomb explosion tonight in Londonderry, hours after Prime Minister Harold Wilson visited troops in the city.

title: Saigon Group Opens Session Tomorrow To Back Unification
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Agence FrancePresse) An assembly of representativet of the people of South Vietnam will meet here next week to ratify a recent agreement on reunification of North and South Vietnam, a reliable source said today.

title: Byrne Signs a Medicaid Abortion Curb
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18  Governor Byrne signed into law today a bill prohibiting the use of Medicaid funds to pay for abortions except to save the life of the mother.

title: Kissinger Said to Delay Latin Trip Second Time
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has postponed a tentative plan to go to Latin America next month and now expects to go some time in February, United States officials said today.

title: The Dance
description: You don't have to be religious to sense the spiritual about Seraphic Dialogue, Martha Graham's view of Joan of Arc. At the Mark Hellinger Theater on Wednesday night, when the Graham company gave it for the first time this season, the famous repertory piece seemed like'. a stainedglass window come to life.

title: Canada to Trim Spending 1.5 Billion to Cut Inflation
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 18Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau tonight outlined to the nation a supplemental antiinflation program that would include a $1.5 billion reduction in Government spending.

title: Heinz Says He Received Gulf Lobbyists' Payments
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP)  Representative H. J. Heinz 3d, a Republican seeking to become his party's nominee to succeed Senator Hugh Scott, said today that he had, received $6,000 in contributions from Gulf Oil Corporation lobbyists. The funds were never disclosed in his campaign finance resorts.

title: ACCOUNTING FIRM IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: LUS ANGELES, Dec. 18The ethics and practices of Seidman & Seidman, the accounting firm formerly headed by President Ford's economic, adviser, L. William Seidman, are under a broad attack here in a Federal investigation and a lawsuit filed by shareholders.

title: Minor Who Did Not Get The $10,000 Rejects $1
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 18 (AP)The 17yearold youth who was offered a $1 refund to cover the price of his lottery ticketafter being denied the $10,000 prize because of his ageturned down the offer today.

title: Reporter's Notebook: The New Laos Still Defies Explanation
description: VIENTIANE, LaosBehind the old halfempty bottles of whisky and pernod in the Vientiane May Bar hang two picturesone of King Savang Vatthana of Laos, the other of Ho Chi Minh Ho's picture is there because. the owner of the bar is Vietnamese. Presumably the King's picture won't be there much longer, since he was forced to abdicate earlier this month when the country's sixcentury  old monarchy was abolished and the People's Democratic Republic of Laos declared.

title: Shopping Spirit Takes Variety of Forms
description: If the departmentstore version of Santa Claus got his start right here in Metropolitan New York, as some local historians maintain there is every sign in these last hectic shopping days before Christmas that New York remains very much his town.

title: 12 Nations Walk Out at UNESCO Parley As a Protest Against AntiIsrael Action
description: PARIS, Dec. 18 A dozen nations, including the United States, members of Western Europe's Common Market, Canada and Australia wtihdrew today from a UNESCOsponsored conference to protest an antiIsraeli action taken by the meeting yesterday.

title: About New York
description: The handmade cigar, once a staple of New York craftsmanship, is not a lost art in the city, but it is a diminished one. Time was when there was a storefront cigar factory every several blocks downtown, and cigar smoking cast an aromatic pall over the city.

title: Ads for Listerine Ordered To Deny It Prevents Colds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Government has ordered the manufacturer of Listerine Mouthwash to say in its printed and televised advertisements that contrary to prior advertising, Listerine will not prevent colds or sore throats or lessen their severity.

title: Screen: Kubrick's Barry Lyndon Is Brilliant in Its Images
description: Barry Lyndon, Stanley Kubrick's handsome, assured screen adaptation of William Makepeace Thackeray's first novel, is so long and leisurely, so panoramic in its narrative scope, that it's as much an environment as it is a conventional film. Its austerity of purpose defines it as a costume movie unlike any other you've seen.

title: Legislative Tax Plan
description: There are serious flaws in the tax package that has been tentatively agreed to in Albany by the Democratic leadership of the Assembly and the Republican leadership of the Senate. Nevertheless, the new tax proposals do represent an encouraging advance toward legislative responsibility in dealing with the state's interrelated budget and credit crises.

title: Islanders Survive 2 Lapses In Goal and To Leafs, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 18  Still emotionally and physically fatigued from last night's shutout victory over the rival Rangers, the New York Islanders struggled a bit tonight before beating the colorless Toronto Maple Leafs, 42.

title: Complex Case Involving Modern Art Lasted 4 Years
description: More than four years after it began, the Mark Rothko case, one of the most complex in the history of modern art, was resolved yesterday.

title: Report Says Rubin Carter Passed LieDetector Test
description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, who are serving life sentences for a 1966 triplemurder in a bar in Paterson, N.J., passed liedetector tests hours after the crime, a confidential report to Governor Byrne has disclosed.

title: Fuel Economy Tests For '76 Autos Show 2 Imports Leading
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency announced today the official fueleconomy performances of 24 more 1976model automobiles,, with three of them beating the previous gasoline mileage record.

title: Restaurant Review
description: Take an interior of generous size, partition it into smaller areas to give a nice feeling of intimacy without crowding, add a glassedin sidewalk cafe section that is quite attractive except during garbage collection strikes, line the walls of the inner rooms with thousands of real books and install some real plants here and there, make the light just right, neither too strong nor too dim. Then serve plenty of good food and present it efficiently and courteously, and you've got a very good restaurant, good enough so that when the surprisingly moderate prices are averaged in, a reporter might be tempted to give it third star.

title: U.S REJECTS PLAN FOR SPUR ON PATH
description: The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration yesterday rejected the PATH transitline extension project as far too costly as planned.

title: Mozambique Puts Down Revolt Touched Off by Military Purge
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique; Dec. 19 (Reuters)The sixmonthold Mozambique Government said today that it had put down a rebellion by about 400 soldiers and policemen.

title: UNITED AIRLINES AND UNION REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The 14day United Airlines strike was tentatively settled yesterday with a contract agreement that may help unsnarl the Christmas travel problems of thousands of Americans.

title: U.S.CANADIAN PACT LIFTS BARS ON BEEF
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (Reuters)Canada and the United States agreed today to remove quota restrictions on trading in beef between the two countries, Canada's Agriculture Minister, Eugene Whelan, announced here.

title: Navy Grounds 400 Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The Navy said today that it had grounded about 400 training and utility planes until their ejectionseat assemblies had been inspected. The TA4 aircraft were ordered grounded temporarily following a crash

title: 76ers Top Pistons In Overtime
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP)George McGinnis's heroics in the final minute of regulation time and then in overtime enabled the Philadelphia 76ers to rally for a 115114 N.B.A. victory over the undermanned Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Nater Sparks Nets' Triumph
description: UNIONDALE, L. L, Dec. 19 Swen Nater, the onagain, offagain center of the New York Nets, had his best game of the season tonight and led his team to a 11397 victory over the San Antonio Spurs.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Drop at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Sgt. 1st Cl. Robert Curry, who has been in the Army* 21 years, has been convicted by a Fort Dix courtmartial panel on charges of selling military leaves to recruits. Ser geant Curry, 40 years old, of Mount Holly, a Vietnam veteran who was active in community and church work, was sentenced to six months at hard labor, loss of pay and pi. badconduct discharge. The Army accused him of charging;: recruits between $5 and $70 for help in obtaining leaves of absence and threatening to block their leaves if they refused to pay. He collected $651.50 from the scheme in 1974, the Army said. Sergeant Curry was convicted of a similar,. offense last March, when he was fined $1,000 and given a reprimand.

title: YOUTH AGENCY HEAD RELIEVED OF DUTIES
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)James Kagen, who was recruited from New York City to direct the State Division of Youth and Family Services, was temporarily relieved of his responsibilities today by Governor Byrne.

title: Frank Sully, a Character Actor In Hundreds of Films, 67, Dead
description: Frank Sully, a character actor whose features were familiar to a generation and more of moviegoers, died Wednesday at the Motion Picture Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills, near the Hollywood where he spent most of his career. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Net Team Tied by Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19Jimmy Connors came from the brink of defeat today to salvage a 62, 61, 36, 46, 75 triumph over little Marcelo Lara in a match that took 3 hours 10 minutes. Then Raul Ramirez beat Brian Gottfried, 61, 64, 62, in just over an hour and a half. Thus the United States and Mexico were tied at 1all after the first day's play in the 1976 North American Zone semifinal of the Davis Cup at Rafael Osuna Stadium.

title: Indiana Whips Georgia; 200th Victory for Knight
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 19 (AP)Topranked Indiana, paced by Scott May's 18 points, whipped Georgia, 9356, in the opening game of Indiana's basketball tournament tonight, giving Coach Bobby. Knight his 200th career victory.

title: 3 Councilmen in Yonkers Vow to Remove Martinelli
description: YONKERS, Dec. 19Three Yonkers City Councilmen announced today that they would seek to remove Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, a Republican, and Councilman Dominick Iannacone, a Democrat, from the city's sevenmember emergency financial control board.

title: Indian Leader Acquitted
description: RAPID CITY, S.D., Dec. 19 (AP)  Oglala Sioux Tribal Chairman Richard Wilson was found not guilty last night of assaulting two lawyers and a legal aide Feb: 26 on the Pine Ridge Reservation.

title: Georgia's Dooley Cited
description: ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 19 (AP)  Georgias football coach, Vince Dooley, was named today coach of the year in the Southern district by the American Football Coaches Association. The association names a coach of the year in each of its nine districts and they compete for the national title.

title: A Correction
description: In an article on floral arrangers in some editions of The New York Times on Dec. 17, the blue flowers in the JeanJacques Bloos arrangement were real; in the MacDonald Forbes arrangement, boxwood, not dogwapd, was used.

title: Upstate Man Dies at 102
description: Mortilner Cheshire, a former musician and one of 52 persons who had received Social Security checks since the first regular payments began Feb. 3, 1940, died yesteray at the Kent Nursing Home in Holmes, N.Y. He was 102 years old. Surviving are a grandchild and three greatgrandchildren.

title: WBAIFM Is Holding A Holiday Crafts Fair
description: WBAIFM, the local radio station supported solely by listener contributions, is holding its fourth annual holiday crafts fair today and tomorrow at Columbia University.

title: Will Rogers, on New York, More or Less
description: All I know is just what I read in the papers You know, of course, that never a day paises in New York without some innocent bystander being shot. You just stand around this town long enough, and be innocent, and somebody Is going to shoot you. One day there was four innocent people shot here. That's the best shooting ever done in this town. Hard to find four innocent people in New York.

title: Family and Dignitaries See Stevens Join Court
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 In a brief formal ceremony marked by both tradition and tight security, John Paul Stevens took his seat today as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's halffare and UniTicket programs have been extended six months, and a third program, the offpeak discount fare on commuter rail lines, has been extended for three months. The halffare program offers a round trip ride for a oneway fare Saturdays beginning at 6 P.M., all day Sunday and on ceptain holidays on the authority's subway, bus and commuter rail lines. UniTicket is designed for use where local bus routes intersect with commuter rail lines. In the offpeak program, passengers on the Long Island Rail Road and the Penn Central's commuter lines may get a 25 percent discount on oneway tickets used in nonrush hours.

title: STATE TO CHANGE 4 NURSING HOMES
description: The State Health Department yesterday disclosed plans to transfer four nursing homes here from their operator, who has been indicted on charges of Medicaid fraud, to nonprofit institutions. It predicted that a substantial number of such transfers would be needed as a result of criminal prosecutions in the next two years.

title: Ford Vetoes $45 Billion for Social Help
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19President Ford vetoed today a Sp billion appropriation for the Departments of Labor and of Health, Education and Welfare but still faced difficult political decisions on legislation on energy and construction site picketing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Inches Toward a Tax Package
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19The Legislature moved slowly tonight toward passing a $600 million package of increased business taxes, the result of a bipartisan compromise designed to restore the state's ability to borrow money by closing a substantial portion of the state budget gap.

title: 2D GUN THEORY TESTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19The Los Angeles County District Attorney said today that a 7 hour examination yesterday of the Ambassador Hotel pantry area, where Senator Robert F. Kennedy was killed in 1968, revealed no new evidence to support a socalled secondgun theory.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Roll Call in Senate On Angola Aid Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate today adopted an amendment by Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, to deny De Tense Department appropriation funds for covert military aid to antiSoviet factions in Angola:

title: The Opera: 3 by Puccini
description: For the first time since 1920, the Trittico of Puccini held the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where it had had its world premiere in 1918. Of the three oneact operas of II Trittico, the most popular, Gianni Schicchi, had already been seen at the Metropolitan Opera last season, paired with Bartok's Bluebeard's Castle.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday:

title: A Landmark Decision
description: The city's successful appeal of the Grand Central case comes as a welcome Christmas gift for New Yorkers. The decision that overturned a lowercourt denial of landmark designation is a triumph for the city and for the propriety, integrity and constitutionality of the landmarks law and for some of the enduring values that make a city great.

title: ACQUITTAL IS WON BY MISS CHESIMARD
description: Joanne D. Chesimard, a reputed former leader, of the Black Liberation Army, and a codefendant were acquitted by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of having robbed a Brooklyn bar and kidnapped a bartender three years ago.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Harry Rauch, 70, ExOfficer For Young & Rubicam, Dies
description: Harry Rauch, who retired as vice president for public relations of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency eight years ago, died Thursday in Cobbleskill, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Middleburg, N.Y.

title: Carter to Run as Jimmy
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 19 (AP)Former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter will be permitted use of the name Jimmy on the Feb. 24 Presidential primary ballot in New Hampshire, state officials say. When he filed his primary petition Dec. 11, there was some question about the use of his full name, James Earl Carter Jr.

title: Long Beach Is Chosen Port For North Slope Alaska Oil
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) The Port of Long Beach was named today as the major West Coast supertaanker terminal for oil from Alaska's North Slope, ending a year of competition with Los Angeles.

title: A. & P.'s Baked Goods Sold With a Fanfare
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has long been, known to the public as the A.&P., to its employees as the Tea Company and to the trade as the old gray lady. But this month, the 116yearold lady began kicking her heels in one of the most extensive promotional efforts undertaken by a supermarket chain in this area.

title: Dr. Bert K. Kusserow, 51, Vermont Pathology Teacher
description: Dr. Bert K. Kusserow, professor of pathology at the University of Vermont College of Medicine, who was noted for his work toward the development of an artificial heart died Thursday in Burlington, Vt. He was 51 years old and lived in Underhill, Vt.

title: Magnetism Extracts Metals Out of Ores
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19A Washington lawyer who is a graduate of the Colorado School of Mines has found a way to get metals out of their ores by magnetism. Roland H. S?? was granted Patent 3,926,789 this week for the process. The Maryland Patent Development Company Inc., Silver Spring, Md., to which it is assigned, is offering rights to industry.

title: Banks See Need for New Moves To Regain StateAgency credit
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19Banking officials, stunned by legislative proposals for increases in their taxes, cautioned today that even if the levies were approved in full, the state would still have to take several steps before credit was restored to its construction agencies or the state itself.

title: RENE MAHEU, 70, OF UNESCO IS DEAD
description: PARIS, Dec. 19Ren Maheu, who retired in November, 1974, as director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died today.

title: Queens Bank, at Hearing on Suit, Calls Moratorium a  CoverUp
description: The Flushing National Bank charged yesterday that the state's emergency law declaring a moratorium on the repayment of city notes was basically a municipal coverup and a political ripoff in complete disregard of constitutional safeguards.

title: Joan Little Surrenders To Carolina Authorities
description: WASHINGTON, N. C., Dec. 20 (AP)  Joan Little, the young black woman whose murder trial attracted national attention, turned herself in tonight following a state wide alert for her arrest, officers said.

title: State Uncovers Undercover Operation
description: If criminals in New York State have any sense, they'll ask to be nut on the state mailing list for news releases. There's no telling what useful information they might find.

title: India Arrests Former Top Aide Who Is a Bitter Foe of Regime
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 19The Government of India, continuing the crackdown on its political opponents, has arrested former cabinet minister who had been one of its most outspoken and bitter critics, according to reliable sources here.

title: 3 Senators Withdraw
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and George McGovern of South Dakota, have formally asked that their names be removed from the Massachusetts Presidential primary ballot on March 2. All are Democrats.

title: Helstoski Uses Privilege On U.S. Jury's Subpoena
description: NEWARK, Dec. 19 (UPI) Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of Bergen County, did not show up for his seventh scheduled grandjury appearance today because Congress had passed a resolution barring his testimony while the House was in session.

title: JamBreaker on Taxes
description: The nation can approach the holiday season with much greater cheer, now that the deadlock over extension of the 1975 tax reduction has been broken. To have taken an extra $17 billion out of taxpayers' pockets in 1976 would have been an act of irresponsibilityan anchor on an already lagging recovery, a blow to the consumer in a period of rekindled inflation.

title: CITY'S NEW TAXES TERMED TIMELY
description: The $200 million in new city taxes demanded by President Ford as a condition of his atiproval for Federal loans to the city will have to be used to close a hithertounknown $200 million shortfall. in the city's overall $6.6 billion threeyear credit plans, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Students, Like Business, Value Levy Advice
description: Some of the America's top businessmen regularly pay substantial fees to sit across the table from Gustave L. Levy, senior partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking house, to seek advice.

title: U.S. Collegians Defeat Japanese Golfers, 2614
description: NARASHINO, Japan, Dec. 19 (AP)Curtis Strange, the 1974 National Collegiate champion from Wake Forest, won the individual laurels. and the United States took the team honors today in a threeday collegiate golf match against Japan.

title: This Met Likes to Be in Hot Water
description: For the first time, Mickey Lolich strolled through the New York Mets' clubhouse at Shea Stadium yesterday as most onlookers stared at the belly that hung over his brown belt.

title: Nutrition Panel Urges Studies To Spur Production of Protein
description: Thirteen major areas of research that could contribute substantially to increasing the world's supply of protein are being underfunded or totally neglected, a group of leading nutrition and agriculture experts reported yesterday.

title: TOP COMMANDERS WARN MRS, PERON TO YIELD POWERS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19 The three commanders of Argentina's armed forces said at a Cabinet meeting today that President Isabel Martinez de Per6n must turn over her powers to a constitutional successor or face a military revolt, informed sources said.

title: 2 Warlords in Lebanon Explain Why They Fight
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 19 Two middleaged businessmenone Christian, the other Moslemwho have become military warlords on opposite sides in Lebanon symbolize the gulf of hatred and fear that divides the people after eight months of bloody civil war.

title: Pet Dealers Win a Stay On Giving Information
description: The State Superior Court yesterday granted pet dealers a stay in the execution of a new state regulation that requires an animal history certificate to be provided with each pet sale.

title: Albany Stalled on a Business Tax Plan
description: ALBANY, Saturday, Dec. 20 Passage of a $600 million package of increased business taxes proved unexpectedly difficult as the Republican Senate leadership's effort to round up enough votes stalled Senate action on the main bill early this morning.

title: Gov. Moore Pleads Not Guilty In West Virginia Extortion Case
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 19Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia pleaded not guilty today to a Federal extortion charge, and was promised a trial in four months.

title: A SUSPECT IS CAUGHT BY W. 103D ST. GAURD
description: A security guard employed by Upper West Side residents to patrol the streets was credited early today with the capture in a threeblock chase of a mugger armed with a knife.

title: SIR VAL DUNCAN
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Sir Val Duncan, chairman and chief executive of Rio TintoZinc, the international metals corporation, died today. He was 62 years old.

title: BOOK INDUSTRY WINS A DEMAND IN LISBON
description: LISBON, Dec. 19The Portuguese Ministry of Labor gave in today to a demand of publishers and booksellers that a study be made of their business and that, if necessary, a collective wage contract be renegotiated.

title: Ballet: Rare Moments
description: Murray Louis has been having a busy seasonmounting ballets in Berlin, Madrid and Copenhagenbut he and his company have come home for the holidays. Last night they opened their current New York season at the New York University Theater, and it will run through Jan. 10.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ROLE IN ANGOLA GROWS
description: CAPETOWN, Dec. 19South African soldiers are serving in tactical and training capacities on several fronts in the Angolan war, according to authoritative sources here.

title: Scott Dazzles Knicks As Celtics Win, 120112
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19Charlie Scott's oneonone heroics were too much for the Knicks tonight as he led the Boston Celtics to a 120112 victory before a capacity crowd of 15.320 at the Boston Garden.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ROLE IN ANGOLA GROWS
description: CAPETOWN, Dec. 19South African soldiers are serving in tactical and training capacities on several fronts in the Angolan war, according to authoritative sources here.

title: 'Tis the Season To Let Calories Go Uncounted

Darkly rich mincemeats, nut and currantstudded fruit cakes exotically spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves, clouds of whipped cream and golden seas of custard, rumscented chestnut purees and snowy rice molds are as essential to the Yuletide celebration as wreaths of holly, tinseled trees and children caroling.
