title: The Mechanics at Compromise on Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Negotiations between the White House and Capitol Hill, especially when the two are controlled by opposing political parties, are much like collective bargaining between labor and management and diplomacy between nations. Each side starts by publicly asking more from the other than it expects to receive, and each uses deadlines and vocals threats Of confrontation to advance its position.

The review had been scheduled for next year. But the trustees rejected a faculty demand for Dr. Parker's suspension and, soon after the trustees' executive committee met here Thursday, faculty members began circulating questionnaires to be used in their investigation of the school's

title: Edna Moor Jones, Founder, Of Broadway Grand Opera

title: Plastics Industry Seeking To End Ban on Packaging

title: 'Adventures of the Wilderness Family'
description: Togetherness should be synonomous with the holiday season, and "The Adventures of the Wilderness Family," which arrived at the Guild and Embassy Theaters yesterday is charmingly appropriate for the family and the season. Perhaps only curmudgeons over the age of 8 would find it unlikely that a black bear would take on a silent grizzly or that a devoted dog would hold off an entire wolfpack in defense of this family. But it's an ideally wholesome clan, and both wilderness and fauna are photogenic and endearing.The family's season in the wilds, a program note indicates, stems from a true story of escape from illness, smog and other traumas of Los Angeles to the pioneer life in the lake-studded, forest high country of the Pacific Northwest. In this case, the youthful father and mother and their little boy and girl take to their new, gorgeously rugged terrain like Sioux. And before you can say Swiss Family Robinson, they've erected their own log cabin and collected a raccoon, a pair of cuddly, motherless bear cubs and a variety of problems.Stewart Raffill, who directed from his own script, is a man to let the beauties of nature overwhelm him. Action is the key here. The children for example, innocently pick up a couple of cougar cubs, and so daddy and the family hound have to fight off the enraged mother. And, there's a rockslide and the little girl's sudden fever, which sends daddy down the rapids in search of a doctor. Also that wolfpack attack and that unfriendly grizzly.Robert F. Logan and Susan Damante Shaw are fairly restrained, natural and attractive as the pioneering parents, as are Holly Holmes and Ham Larsen, as their wide-eyed, loving youngsters. And, if they often seem to be minuscule figures against the striking uninhabited, wildlife-filled background of Utah's Uinta Mountains where the adventures were filmed, they do add appreciative bits.

title: Screen: What's Up, Doc?
description: "Bugs Bunny Superstar," which opened yesterday at the Regency and D. W. Griffith Theaters, is a 90-minute anthology film composed of 10 Warner Brothers cartoons produced between 1940 and 1948. Seven of the 10 star the pushy, incredibly self-assured rabbit whose voice, supplied by the great Mel Blanc, is as much a part of Bugs Bunny's public persona as his physique, which really isn't that much different from other rabbits you may have known.Three ace Warner Brothers animation directors  Tex Avery, Bob Clampett and Fritz Freleng  come on the screen, none too briefly, to talk about how great it was in the old days on the Warner lot when it was just one big happy family. Orson Welles bridges the gaps with facetious narration that sounds as if it had been left on someone's Phone-Mate.That's the bad news.The good news is that Bugs and several of the other creations of Warner cartoonists are enduringly comic characters, as ebullient as any that the Disney organization created and always much more irreverent. This program includes two classics, "The Corny Concerto" (1943), a wickedly funny send-up of Disney's "Fantasia," and "Rhapsody Rabbit" (1945), in which Bugs and a mouse compete to see who can get through Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsodies first, with the least amount of piano left.Of the other characters, my particular favorite is Henery Hawk, a young, intensely serious chicken hawk, who, in "Walky Talky Hawky," goes out to bag his first chicken under the near-fatal misunderstanding that dogs are chickens. Also on the program is another. Warner classic, "I Taw a Putty Tat" (1948), in which Tweety Bird, the small yellow, peculiarly nude-looking canary, matches wits with Sylvester, the big, ragged, short-tempered cat who sounds like the late Bert Lahr.Children, brought up on TV, should be dazzled by the slam-bang wit and the excellence of the animation techniques.

title: ...and the Carter Case
description: Meanwhile, in New Jersey, the case involving the convictions of Rubin Carter and John Artis becomes curiouser and curiouser. While the application for a new trial makes its tortured way through the New Jersey court system and the Passaic, County prosecutor's office stoutly defends the virtue of its original prosecution, doubts arising from the trial steadily increase.

title: Blue Stars Rally, Bead Gray, 1413
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 19 (UPI)Steve Myer of New Mexico, threw a 52yard touchdown pass to Bill Singler of Stanford with 31 seconds left tonight and gave the Blue a comeback 1413 victory in the 38th BlueGray college allstar game.

title: Diabetic Girl Taken From Hospital Here Is Returned Safely
description: Cherise Smith, a 4yearold diabetic girl taken by her father from a ward in Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx on Tuesday was returned to a hospital yesterday in relatively good condition, the police said.

title: Art: Maillol Work at Guggenheim
description: Like his nearnamesake, the fifth century B.C. Greek statesman Aristides, the French sculptor Aristide Maillol (18611944) is regarded by many people today as a good fellow, but monotonous. Much as the exemplary stewardship of Aristides is felt to lack glamour, so do the sculptures of Maillol seem bland and undemanding to eyes reared on the gamut of modern sculpture from Matisse and Picasso to Caro and Judd.

title: Price & Pride, Strolling Players
description: A. & P. put Pugh and Strait together again. So what if it doesn't sing, Manny? It's true. Ted Pugh and Ralph Strait, apronclad embodiments of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company's latest advertising pitch (The time has come to put Price and Pride together again) are now working the supermarket aisles just as they once had trod the boards at the Washington Theater Club.

title: Call for Top Red's Return Causes a Furor in Madrid
description: MADRID, Dec. 19Spain's Foreign, Minister has created a storm in Parliament, a stronghold of traditionalist sentiment, by suggesting that the exiled leader of the Spanish Communist Party be allowed to come home.

title: Two Robbers Hijack Post Office Truck In Flatbush Section
description: Two robbers dressed in Postal Service uniforms last night hijacked a truck loaded with sacks of registered mail and cash from the sale of postage and money orders.

title: WILLIAM GREENLEAF, HISTORY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. William Greenleaf, prolessor of history at the University of New Hampshire, died Wednesday of cancer in Dover, N. H. He was 58 years old and lived in Durham, N. H.

title: Jail Brutality Laid to Lisbon By Relatives and Lawyers
description: LISBON, Dec. 9  Charges, that Portuguese political prisoners have been brutually treated were made here tonight at a news conference held by a group of their relatives and lawyers.

title: Charges the Gunmen Face
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 19 (Reuters)A police spokesman said today that the seven gunmen who had held the consulate would be charged with unlawful deprivation of liberty and would go before a magistrate on Tuesday. The six train hijackers have all been charged with murder.

title: Gulifire Heard in Capital
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 19 (AP)Travelers returning from Lourenco Marques today said they heard gunfire In town, early this morning as they were boarding the South African Airways plane.

title: PANEL CITES GAINS IN HEALTH DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19National efforts to make Americans alert to the dangers of high blood pressure seem to be proving effective, specialists said today.

title: UNITED AIRLINES AND UNION REACH TENTATIVEACCORD
description: The 14day United Airlines strike was tentatively settled yesterday with a contract agreement that may help unsnarl the Christmas travel problems of thousands of Americans.

title: Solid Sculpture by James Hagan Is Shown
description: What a pleasant surprise to discover, in the hubbub of the Christmas season, a show by an artist hitherto unfamiliaran artist having his first oneman show in New York, in factthat is a solid and splendid accomplishment!

title: Coach's Pastime Is a Knotty One
description: John Symank has probably found the perfect hobby for the busy, alwaysonthego assistant football coach: macram, the art of decorative rope tying.

title: Czechoslovaks, Swedes Even
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 19 (AP) Bjorn Borg of Sweden and Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia gave their teams a 11 tie today after the first two singles matches in the 1975 Davis Cup final.

title: Downtown Ballet Opens a Run At Kennedy Children's Theater
description: Everyone's heart was in the right place Thursday night at the R. F. Kennedy Theater for Children (219 West 48th Street), where the Downtown Ballet Company opened a run through Jan. 4.

title: Rites for Noble Sissle
description: A funeral service for Noble Sissle, the song writer and orchestra leader, will be conducted Tuesday at 11 A.M. at the St. Marks United Methodist Church, Edgecombe Avenue at 137th Street.

title: Revving Up the Courts
description: Court reformers hoped for a miraculous turnaround in the last few days as the final votes were counted on Constitutional Amendment No. 3. But the official tally shows that the effort to unify the administration and financing of the state court system was defeated by a 17,448 vote margin. This result apparently grew out of an unreasonable fear that unified courts would somehow add to the tax burden; the contrary is true.

title: Text of Ford's Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)Following is the text of President Ford's statement today on the Senate vote cutting off funds for covert United States military aid in Angola.

title: Radio
description: 66:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Courtly Pastimes of 16thCentury England.

title: Order Is Revised On Lockheed Data
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19A Federal judge has changed his order regarding the conditions under which the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has to turn subpoenaed, information over to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Lie Test Cleared Carter, Defense Lawyers Argue
description: A new controversy developed yesterday over whether Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis were cleared by liedetector tests of a triple murder in Paterson nine years ago.

title: CONGRESS AND FORD AGREE ON EXTENSION OF TAX CUT; COMPROMISE BILL PASSED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Congress passed the taxcut bill tonight after incorporating a nonbinding commitment, acceptable to President Ford, to control Government spending.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: DOW DECLINES 7.71 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking and some disappointing economic news sent stock prices lower yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was down all day and closed with its first loss in five trading sessions.

title: House Unit Seking Release of 2 C.I.A. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The House Intelligence Committee voted today to seek President Ford's approval to release reports on two covert Central Intelligence Agency operations.

title: Books of The Times
description: There isn't much time left. From here on in it's going to he all bustle, scurry and hurry for all of us. In a moment of panic you may be tempted into making an unwise purchase for the young teenager on your listpajamas perhaps, or plastics, or even a pet rock. Why not a book?

title: SLAIN POLICEMAN BURIED IN L.I. RITES
description: HEWLETT, L.I., Dec. 19A chief inspector's funeral was accorded today to Matthew Giglio, a Nassau County police officer who died Tuesday of gunshot wounds suffered 10 weeks ago as he was responding to a fellow officer's call for assistance.

title: Nuclear Test Delayed
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 19 (UPI)A nuclear test was delayed today because of unfavorable wind conditions. It was the fourth delay for the test, which bears the code name Chiberta.

title: In Memoriam
description: JOSEPHBuddy. In sweet and cherished memory of our beloved. Never In he forgotten by his dear ones.

title: CITY'S NEW TAXES TERMED TIMELY
description: The $200 million in new city taxes demanded by President Ford as a condition of his approval for Federal loans to the city will have to be used to close a hithertounknown $200 million shortfall in the city's overall $6.6 billion threeyear credit plans, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Charles Gaynor, Who Created Lend an Ear, Show Girl, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) Charles Gaynor, who wrote the sketches, lyrics anddmusic for such Broadway shows as Lend an Ear and Show Girl, died yesterday at the age of 66.

title: Two Victories for U.S.: Pride and Performance
description: Athletes from the United States scored a double victory in the PanAmerican Games. They won more medals than anyone else (that was expected), and they overcame hostility from Mexican spectators who constantly showered them with boos, whistling, catcalls and worse.

title: They Speak for Their Generation
description: Singers and songwriters have always been fairly accurate barometers of their times. Here then are three new voices on new albums to speak for their generation at middecade. Tom Waits is a jazzrapping Angeleno with a mania for standup monologue. Patti Smith (who opens at the Bottom Line Dec. 26 and is profiled in this week's Sunday Times Magazine) is the current darling of the New York avantgarde and declaims her lyrics in front of a primitive but effective rock band. Joel Zoss, who just finished a week's engagement at The Other End, is a versatile New England musician who mixes mystical themes with strong melodies. Three very different artists with a common background, all were writers and poets before they became musicians.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Irene Worth has become what every young performer of talent and intelligence promises himself he will become, hell and high water notwithstanding. In the process, she has also become hard to find. She doesn't very often come where you are. You must go where she is. As I left the Brooklyn Academy of Music after a performance of Tennessee Williams's Sweet Bird of Youth a few weeks agoa performance in which Miss Worth played the ravaged but still diamondhard movie queen to Christopher Walken's stubborn young studI noticed that my companion of the evening, long a conscientious theatergoer, was seething. Virtually stamping his feet in fury on the sidewalk, he exploded. But this is a great actress! Why haven't I seen her before? Where has she been?, Where have I been?

title: Suspect in Knight Slaying Sentenced on Drug Charge
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP)Steven Maleno, a suspect in the John S. Knight 3d murder case, has been sentenced to six months to a year in jail on a drug charge.

title: Plachkov Tops Lift Mark
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 20 (AP)  Hristo Plachkov of Bulgaria bettered today his world record of 429.89 pounds by snatching 435.40 pounds in the superheavyweight category at a weightlifting competition at Sevleivo, Bulgaria, according to the BTA press agency.

title: Miss McAdoo Sets Wedding
description: The engagement of Dorothy Brown McAdoo to Malcolm MacColl, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. James R. MacColl 3d of Wellesley Hills, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. McAdoo of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Events Today
description: Fifth Avenue Holiday Festival: choral groups, jazz, dancers on Fifth Avenue which will be closed to traffic from 34th to 57th Streets; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.

title: Raises Followed Rate Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP)Seventy executives and officers of the Philadelphia Electric Company, received salary increases less than two weeks after the utility was granted a $103 million rate increase last March, a Public Utility Commission hearing was told yesterday. For 50 of the executives, the raises ranged from 11 percent to 25 percent. All 70 of the top officers make more than $40,000 a year.

title: Diana C. Lane of John o'Groats Married to Lloyd N. Cutler Jr
description: Diana Christine Lane of John o'Groats, Scotland, and Lloyd Norton Cutler Jr. of Washington, who met while students at Oxford University, were married yesterday afternoon at John o'Groats House Hotel, of which the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Lane are proprietors. John o'Groats is at the very northern point of Scotland.

title: Gonna be so big, Gonna be a star, Watch me now!
description: Patti Smith is having a wonderful time these days. She's 29, she started singing two years ago, and five weeks ago today Clive Davis's new record company, Arista, released her first album, Horses, to immediate praise from, among others, this newspaper's pop music critic and columnist, John Rockwell. Rockwell called it an extraordinary disk every minute of which is worth repeated hearings. The cover of Horses shows Patti posed A la Frank Sinatra, standing with a suit jacket thrown over her shoulderFrank's a Jersey kid like Patti. This is a conscious allusion and typical of Patti's humor: She doesn't see any reason why she shouldn't be as big a star Frank, but she finds the whole business of stardom worthy of parody. So far, both Rolling Stone and Earl Wilson are calling her a rock n roll queen, and her album is selling briskly80,000 copies to date. Next weekend, Patti will be giving seven already soldout shows at New York's No. I rock club, the Bottom Line.

title: Music: Giulini Conducts
description: Most distinctive conductors play music their way. With a Karajan or a Solti or a Bernstein, you can almost always guess the conductor no matter who wrote the music.

title: California Students Start Taking Controversial Dropout Tests to See if They Can Quit High School Early
description: The first of 13,000 California high school students 16 and 17 years old began taking today a controversial dropout test in reading, writing and reasoning to determine whether they are functionally literate and able to make their way in the world without further secondary schooling.

title: Fordham Maryland's 6th Victim
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec, 20 (AP)Unbeaten and secondranked Maryland shook off a tenacious Fordham five with an 8point string late in the first half, and went on to its sixth consecutive triumph today, 8156.

title: Ozone on the ground
description: While the ozone above us obviously protects all living things from a heap of trouble, the gas turns out to be a menace when close to the ground. In Los Angeles, where the danger was discovered, ozone is produced when hydrocarbon vapors and nitrogen oxides from car exhaust are cooked in the Southern California sun and then suddenly cooled. The product, once known as photochemical oxidant, and now identified as ozone, is responsible for the red smarting eyes, burning chest and other irritations of Los Angeles smog; as little as 0.5 particle of ozone per million will result in a firstdegree alert.

title: Opera: Puccini's Trittico Staged Complete at Met
description: For the first time since 1920, the Trittico of Puccini held the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where it had had its world premiere in 1918. Of the three oneact operas of Il Trittico, the most popular, Gianni Schicchi, had already been seen at the Metropolitan Opera last season, paired with Bartok's Bluebeard's Castle.

title: College Football in Review: AllAmerica, AllSectional and AllConference Teams
description: ALLAMERICA

title: Roster of Winners of Individual and Team Championships in Sports During 1975
description: Archery

title: State Study Says City Layoff Report Is 97% Accurate
description: The announcement last July by the Beame administration that 13,066 city employees had been laid off in the first phase of cutting this year's $12 billion budget was verified as 97 percent accurate in a report issued yesterday by the State Comptroller. Arthur Levitt.

title: Gelsey Kirkland At ABTEase Does It
description: In the summer of 1974, Gelsey Kirkland made the biggest leap of her young dancer's life, leaving the Largely modern, abstract repertory of the New York City Ballet in order to dance the classics at the rival American Ballet Theater. The leap looks more handsome now than even she could have imagined it would. Tomorrow night, one week shy or her 23d birthday, she will open Ballet Theater's winter season as Giselle, opposite Mikhail Baryshnikov. She has developed herself as an artist in directions she would have had to curtail with George Balanchine's City Ballet, and she has won the recognition that only success in ballet's great masterpieces can bring.

title: LAST VIETNAMESE RESETTLING IN U.S.
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., Dec. 20On this weatherbeaten military base today, 68 Vietnamese men, women and children, the last group of 140,000 refugees who fled Indochina to seek new lives in an Occidental world, boarded buses and headed for cities from New York to Los Angeles.

title: The F.B.I.: Can It Be Controlled At All?
description: WASHINGTONA few years ago there was a popular questionandanswer joke that went: Where do you let an 800pound gorilla sleep? Anywhere he wants! In a sense that has been the problem with the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: CHARLES MELLON, ACTIVE IN JERSEY
description: Charles H. Mellon, who resigned last summer as executive assistant to the chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, was killed at dusk Friday afternoon when he was struck by a car while jogging near his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 37 years old.

title: New Products for the Home Handyman
description: A new design shower spray recently introduced is the latest of the various pulsating or massage type shower sprays on the market. It differs from others in that it gives a vertical ovalpatterned spray that does a more uniform job of wetting the entire body at one time. Designed so that it sends spray out of three separate openings in the shower head, it has an adjustment that permits regulating for a choice of wide double spray, a highfrequency, pulsating narrow spray (out of the center opening only), or a combination of the two types of sprays (pulsating from the center opening, and double spray from the other two). In the combination position the user can vary the proportions of pulsating and conventional spray as desired. Called the Body Shaper, and priced at $24.95, this shower head is made by Chicago Specialty Manufacturing Co., 7500 N. Linder Avenue, Skokie, Ill. 60076. It threads onto any standard shower arm, and operates satisfactorily at all normal household water pressures.

title: Author's Query
description: For a life of Sylvia Pankhurst, British suffragette and political activist, now in progress, I would be very grateful for any letters, copies of newspaper articles, leads to her paintings or other pertinent material.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Four youths, ages 11 to 17 are being questioned in New Jersey in connection with a robberymurder at the Garfield Target Range. The Passaic police picked the youths up Friday after a telephone tip about guns being offered for sale. The police said 21 revolvers and a shotgun were stolen from the range, in the basement of Jimmy's Lounge, where the attendant, Robert J. Cooper Jr., 26 years old, of Wallington, was found shot to death Monday night. The shotgun and 13 of the revolvers have been recovered.

title: OpenMeeting Act Is a Puzzle
description: TRENTONTwo officials of a Mercer County municipality were having lunch the other day when they were joined by a third member of their Township Committee.

title: FIFTY DETECTIVES TO CHANGE POSTS
description: About 50 veteran detectives will soon be transferred from the police narcotics and public morals divisions to other investigation squads in what police officials described yesterday as a move to improve morale and efficiency.

title: Concert: The Ensemble
description: In 1968, Luciano Berio and Dennis Russell Davies brought together an instrumental group called The Ensemble, which devoted itself to 20thcentury works, and as recently as last season it was heard in a Lincoln Center series known as New and Newer Music.

title: U.S. Judges Here Reject Rules for Trial Lawyers
description: Defying much of the country's judicial leadership, Federal trial judges here have decisively voted down a proposal to require minimum qualifications for lawyers seeking to practice In Federal trial courts.

title: Esther Manning Westervelt, Teachers College Professor
description: Dr. Esther Manning Westervelt, former assistant professor of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, serving there from 1961 to 1969, died Thursday at Albert Einstein Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived in Goshen, N. Y.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mickey Lolich bemoans the interleague trade that brought him to New York after 13 years with Detroit: It's amazing, but I don't even know who plays for the Mets. Who's their catcher? Who plays first? Who plays second? I just never followed the National League at all.

title: Fiesta Marathon Won by Mendoza
description: SCOTTSDALE. Ariz., Dec. 20 (AP)Ed Mendoza, a University of Arizona student, pulled away from the field in the final seven miles and won the 5th annual Fiesta Bowl marathon today.

title: The work of a working writer
description: L.E, Sissman's name may he familiar to many readers, but it is hardly a household word, At the same time, he can he considered a prolific writer. Having reached middle age, he counts among his published works three volumes of poetry and numerous hook reviews and magazine essays, not to mention all of the anonymous copy he has crafted during his years as an advertising man.

title: The Kungsholm Sails As a Cruise Liner
description: The 26,678ton Kungsholm, a luxury cruise liner that had been a regular caller here for 10 years, sailed on her maiden cruise Friday afternoon under a new flag and under new management.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters pubished here pose questions similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not he published here, but who will, nevertheless, find their answers printed below. Readers sending in questions shout home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department. The New York Times, Times Square. New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: Indian Tribes Are Using The System to Win Rights
description: DENVER, Dec. 20The Indians of the West are once again fighting the Government. But this time, their battle is being waged nonviolentlyin the nation's courts, legislatures and classrooms.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: Aid Is Offered to All, of All Faiths, Who Have a Need
description: On this page and on the last two Sundays, The New York Times has published major statements from the heads of four agencies helped through the Neediest Cases Fund. Some of the special concerns of the other four agencies assisted by the fund are detailed in the following statements:

title: Disabled Mother Vows To Care for HerselfBut Finally Seeks Help
description: After Mrs. P. became paralyzed from the waist down in an automobile accident 11 years ago, she vowed not to become a vegetable but to do for myself.

title: World Bank Finds Poor Lands Poorer
description: The rich are getting richer, and the poor are getting poorer, or at least standing still, according to the forthcoming 1975 edition of World Bank Atlas, which summarizes population growth, national output and output per capita for 130 countries for the years 1960 through 1974.

title: On Balance, Losing Year
description: At Tracks; Scandal, greed and heartbreak combined to turn the 1975 season into a downer for horseracing fans.

title: Dr. James Mersey Weds Carol Peters
description: Carol Amaryllis Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Merrill Peters of London, Ohio, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. James Harris Mersey, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Mersey of New York and Robert Mersey of Port Washington, L. I.

title: Not with a bang but a pfffft?
description: Up until a year or so ago, ozone was something only Scrabble lovers (who often need a word with z) paid much attention to; if others did hear of ozone at all, it was in connection with the strong cleansing odor after an electric discharge or, just possibly, in the context of the lively supersonic transport controversy a few years hack. But on June 28, 1974, ozone leaped to the status of a household word, when two scientists from the University of California, F. Sherwood Rowland and Mario Molina, announced that the ozone belt around the earth is in danger of being destroyed by, of all things, the mass use of that symbol of 20thcentury technology, the aerosol spray.

title: FATHER, 6 CHILDREN DIE IN UPSTATE FIRE
description: A father and six children were burned to death early today in a fire in their twostory frame house in Reading. N. Y., in the western part of the state.

title: City Homesteading To Begin in Queens
description: An experiment in urban homesteading will begin shortly in South Ozone Park in Queens, where 30 abandoned singlefamily houses are to be turned over to new owners for rehabilitation and, at the same time, neighboring property owners will be offered lowinterest home improvement loans.

title: Kathryn Durhan Wed to Dennis Lyndon
description: Kathryn Rhea Durhan, daughter of Mrs. William J. Durhan of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mr. Durhan, was married yesterday noon to Dennis Charles Lyndon, son of Mrs. Dennis C. Lyndon of McLean, Va., and the late Rear Admiral Lyndon. U.S.N.

title: Swaying Left, and Right, Nation's Troubles Are Political and Economic
description: Marshal Tito has declared, after discovering proSoviet underground factions in his country: Yugolavia is not an easy prey for anyone.

title: ANTICANCER DRUG ASSAILED IN TRIAL
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 20A suburban Los Angeles physician and four other persons have been convicted on charges of conspiracy to distribute the outlawed drug laetrile to cancer sufferers in California and other states.

title: Houdini Had Nothing to Lose But His Chains
description: Today, nearly 50 years after his death, Houdini has become part of world folklorethe only stage figure I can think of to have achieved that stature. There are three new books being written about Houdini, and he is a semifictionalized character in E. L. Doctorow's current best  seller Ragtime. The 1953 movie biography, Houdinni, starring Tony Curtis, has recently been revived on prime time television, and two more feature films about the magician have been announced. He's probably more a legend now than when he died in 1926on Halloween.

title: ALBANY APPROVES $600 MILLION TAX BY A CLOSE MARGIN
description: ALBANY, Dec. 20  The Legislature approved a $600 million package of increased business taxes by the narrowest of margins early today, and Governor Carey immediately signed the measures into law.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Retirement is getting to be almost as typical of American life as hard work used to be. The idea is still so new, and so foreign to the historic Puritan ethic, that statistics about it are not available in any one place. Still, the number of people receiving Social Security retirement benefits in 1973 (probably the closest approximation of a retirement head count there is) was more than 15 million, up 14 percent over 1970, and 28 percent over 1965.

title: Study Shows Hispanic Students Are Hard Hit by the City Crisis
description: Puerto Ricans and other Hispanic people enrolled in the city's public schools and universities face profound and severe hardships because of financial cuts stemming from the city's fiscal crisis, a study by the Migration Division of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico office here contends.

title: In Memoriam
description: DE JURFrances. Beloved wife, devoted matter, adored grandmother. Lovingly remembered. Her life was one of faiths devotion and courage. FAMILY.

title: Experts Fear Great Peril If SST Fumes Cool Earth
description: A federally sponsored inquiry into the effects of possible climate changes caused by heavy supersonic traffic in the stratosphere has concluded that even a slight cooling could cost the world from $200 billion to 500 times that much in damage done to agriculture, public health and other effects.

title: The Making Of the Modern Family
description: Within the last 20 years academic history has greatly enlarged its boundariesbreastfeeding, swaddling, bundling, courtship habits were regarded as the province of the folklorists or the anthropologists, but not a concern for professional historians. Now the pendulum has swung far the other way. There is scarcely a serious historical journal that does not have a snappy article on masturbation or work bees. It all began with the demographers searching for the causes of the great population growth of Western Europe in the late 18th century: they needed to know about marriage age, family size, infant mortality.

title: Freda Roberta Weiner Is Affianced
description: Freda Roberta Weiner and Lawrence Allen Boguchwal plan to be married July 4 in Harrison, N. Y.

title: Sister Attends Miss MacMillen At Her Nuptials
description: Candace Williams MacMillen and William Francis Achtmeyer were married yesterday afternoon in Hanover, N.H. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Williams MacMillen of Hanover and Lyme, N.H., and west Southport, Me. The bridegroom's parents are Mrs. F. Dennette Adams of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and George B. Achtmeyer of Los Angeles.

title: The International Flavor of Moscow's New Plan
description: Ever since 1928, when Stalin launched a program of forced industrialization in the Soviet Union, that country's economic progress has been charted by fiveyear plans.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: HardtoFind Savings
description: For most peopleexcepting the relative few who cannot now get a discountthe new carrental prices offer minimal savings at best and at worst they can result in substantial increases over the old rates.

title: Patricia Brooks Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. Thomas Aloysius Brooks of Leonia, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Frances Brooks, to Eben Theodore Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Walker of Montclair, N. J. Miss Brooks is the daughter also of the late Mr. Brooks, who was a vice president of Hearst Radio and Television, a division of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Epilogue
description: Some Gambling Legalized

title: Equity and Mortgage Trusts
description: Perhaps the most appealing real estate investment trusts are to be found among those that Invest in property by acquiring an ownership stake in it. Such REIT's are known as equity trusts, and Kenneth D. Campbell of Audit Investment Research suggests that they can do well even amid the Holocaust that has enveloped the industry.

title: Flyers Still Best at the Violent Game
description: Violence on the ice and fiscal woes off it contributed to a controversial year for professional hockey. The roughhousing popularized by the champion Philadelphia. Flyers skirted the borders of criminality as civil authorities pressed assault charges against two National Hockey League players for actions during games. Dave Forbes of the Boston Bruins faced trial for punching Minnesota's Henry Boucha in the eye with the butt end of a hockey stick in a game Jan. 4. The trial ended in a hung jury and charges were dropped. In late November, Toronto's district attorney charged Dave Maloney of Detroit with assaulting the Maple Leafs' Brian Glennie, In the World Hockey Association, Winnipeg's venerable Bobby Hull sat out one game to protest violence in that league.

title: Senate Courtesy Scrutinized
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne plans another legislative attack on senatorial courtesy, the controversial but unwritten tradition that allows individual senators of either party to block gubernatorial nominees from their home counties.

title: Sugarplum Visions at Pier
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTSA series of 16 colorful animated scenes illustrating Clement Moore's A Visit From St. Nicholas is attracting visitors from throughout the stale to the Casino Pier in this resort community.

title: SouthTeam Cries Foul Over Clock
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 20 (AP)  To accommodate television, the clock was gerrymandered during the BlueGray football game last night. And with cold weather, it put a chill on the North's dramatic, lastminute 1413 victory.

title: Ford Claims Total Victory In Fight Over Tax Cut Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 President Ford said today that he had won a 100 percent victory in principle in his battle with Congress over tax legislation, and he predicted that he would be elected next year on his record.

title: Northern Storm
description: Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau went much too far his House of Commons blast at the departing United States Ambassador, William J. Porter, for the latter's implied criticisms of Canadian policies at an Ottawa cocktail party. Yet, as an experienced diplomat of high rank, Mr. Porter ought never to have left himself vulnerable to such an attack.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Spread of TaxExempt Property Is Accelerating in City
description: Well over a third of all property in New York City now pays no taxes.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Eastern College Athletic Confer ence's Holiday Festival starts at Madison Square Garden on Friday. In the afternoon doubleheader beginning at 1 o'clock, Manhattan plays St. Bonaventure, followed by Indiana, ranked first in the nation, against Columbia. In the evening doubleheader, St. John's faces Ternple and South Carolina plays Villanova. The semifinals begin at 7 P.M. Saturday, the final at 9 P.M. Monday, Dec. 29.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass Market Paperbacks

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: One of the least popular propositions of the last 25 years is that all art is one. (All modern art, anyway.) If this proposition could he proved, nothing would remain of the holy war with which so many of our contemporaries concern themselves. Surrealism against abstract art, Pop art against Abstract Expressionism, formalist abstraction against the esthetic equivalent of a mixed economy, earthworks against gallery art, the painstaking study of nature against a typewritten message pinned to the wallall these once seemed (and to many do still seem) matters of life and death, survival and extinction.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME Christmas presents have been opened early this year, and the biggest surprise so far is the $335 million gift from the British Government to Chrysler to continue its operations in Britain. John Riccardo, the Chrysler Corporation's chairman, went to London intending to rid himself of his troublesome British subsidiary. But every time he tried to leave the baby on the doorstep of No. 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Harold Wilson stepped out the door and pressed more millions into American hands.

title: Events Today
description: Fifth Avenue Holiday Festival: choral groups, jazz, dancer: on Fifth Avenue which will be closed to traffic from 34th to 57th Streets; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX rose seventenths 1 percent in November to 165.6 [1967 = 100] indicating a yearly inflation rate of 8.4 percent. . . Industrial Production at 116.8 in November showed an increase of 0.2 of a point, indicating a levellingoff of manufacturing activity. . . Business inventory levels rose $1.9 billion in November, the largest gain in 10 months and the third consecutive monthly gain. . . Personal income last month went up by $10.9 billion, on a seasonally adjusted annual rate, to $10.2 trillion, up 8.9 percent over November, 1974.

title: The famous character
description: To cheer her up D. H. Lawrence once wrote to Lady Ottoline Morrell. don't say you feel you're not Important in life.... Ottoline has moved men's imagination, deeply, and that's perhaps the most a woman can do. Such a contemptuous crumb was not the worst of what she got in return for feeding and housing and entertaining the articulate. What seemed to her the very worst lies between those lines: Lawence's portrait of her as the yearning, threatening Hermione Roddice of Women in Love. (Soulmush, Frieda Lawrence called what had gone on between Lawrence and Ottoline.) Then there was Aldous Huxley's Chrome Yellow with its satirical versions of Ottoline and her guests, and later. Those Barren Leaves. Other takeoffs were done not in print but in stagewhispers.

title: First Snow Here Causes Road Delays
description: The metropolitan area's first real snowfall of the season yesterday stole a march on winter's official arrival and caused numerous accidents and long delays on slippery roads especially to the north and east of New York City.

title: Trenton Is Facing a Shattering Fight Over Budget and Taxes
description: TRENTON  Administration officials and Democratic leaders in the Legislature agreed last week that the increasing resistance to new programs and new taxes in the outgoing Legislature showed every sign of extending into the session that convenes here Jan. 13. In feet, they said that they believed the resistance would intensify among the Democratic majority in the Senate and among the new, smaller Democratic majority in the Assembly that was elected last month.

title: Carey Grandchild Dies
description: Governor Carey's only grandchild, Molly, born to his daughter Susan Dempsey last November 5, died here yesterday of sudden infant death syndrome, also known as crib death, the Governor's office announced. Page 33.

description: The prelude to Dostoevsky's second marriage is too well known a tale to need retelling, and too good a one to resist.

The runners are Garry Bjorklund of Duluth, Minn.; Glenn Herold, Madison, Wis., and a woman Jacki Hansen, Los Angeles.

title: A Long Way From Bloomsbury
description: TORREMOLINOS As he says in the last few pages of his recent memoir Personal Record, Gerald Brenan and his young niece have built a house in the foothills of the mountains behind Torremolinos. The peaks cut oft the world of the Costa del Sol, also there is the smog that rolls down from the airport and suburbs of Malaga, and he has placed his writing table, in the secondfloor room where lie also sleeps, squarely across from French windows to a balcony that allows him to look down in the foreground at the town of Alhautin el Grande and beyond to the superb brown mountains of Ronda.

title: The Joys of Sport And the Drawbacks
description: For all the cynicism and oppression and betrayal, the rhythms of sport, the sensations and the emotions, are often the most intense and pleasurable ever experienced. They are universal. Billie Jean King describes how she feels after a perfect shot:

Waiting for Christmas morning to get ready' is almost certain to result in frustration and disappointment, regardless of whether one plans to take just a few snapshots; or produce a full sound movie film.

He was the minority leader in the Assembly in 1958 and has served in minority and majority leadership positions in both houses ever since.

description: The inside of the coat looks just as good as the outside, and can in fact be worn outside. The material tends to be high quality, the price ranges from $200 upward and the item is not to be mistaken for the standard reversible raincoat.

title: Calligraphy Means Beautiful Writing
description: In today's age of electric typewriters and computerized typesetting, the idea of people glorifying the art of writing by using pen and ink to form handwritten letters and words in the manner of the early scribes seems like an anachronism. Yet calligraphy, which means beautiful writing, is being practiced by surprising numbers of peopleall throughout the contry.

title: Boonton's Looking to the Past for Its Future
description: BOONTON  When Joseph Marcello talks about why he is launching his novel commercial center, The Station, Boonton U.S.A., two visions of this old hillside town usually cross his mind.

description: THEATER

title: Fong Decision Upsets Hawaii Democrats
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 20  A landmark figure in Hawaiian political history, Senator Hiram L. Fong, a Republican, will not run for reelection next year, and already the maneuvering to succeed him is causing deep rifts in the Democratic Party here.

title: Rising SelfAssurance and Salaries Encouraging Some to Enter Market
description: Genevieve Stuttaford, a Manhattan magazine editor, is one who does. Miss Stuttaford, who is divorced and calls herself a radical feminist, says she has found today's climate far more receptive to women homeowners than that of the nineteensixties. She and her former husband came close to buying property in California

title: The First World's Future
description: When Woodrow Wilson sounded his call to make the world safe for democracy, Americans saw themselves embarked on a mission not simply to defeat the Kaiser, but to carry free government to the ends of the earth. In a more optimistic age, government of, by and for the people was viewed as so irresistibly contagious that the oppressed in other nations were expected to be easily persuaded to throw off their bonds and join in the benefits of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

title: The World
description: The foreign ministers of 27 nations or groups of nations  industrial powers, oil Producers and the less fortunatehave begun what probably will be years of bargaining over how to reshape the world's economy so that poor nations get a greater share of the wealth. There is plenty of room for improvement: The average per capita income for 24 industrial nations is $4,550, for the 25least developed nations the comparable figure is $116.

title: Strike Threat at Met Part of U.S. Trend
description: The strike threatened by the Metropolitan Opera Company's orchestra for Jan. 1 is only the latest in a series of labor disputes that have silenced orchestras across the nation.

title: Dr. Hicks to Marry Mary T. Coleman

description: ALBANY, Dec. 20Following are the votes by which the Legislature today approved the $600million, 15month package of increased business taxes:

title: Giving Voice to a Heritage
description: AMITYVILLEUntil a few weeks ago, Mary DiPeri had never written more than a letter or shopping list. But then, the 72yearold widow from Wyandanch visited the Martin J. McNicholas Senior Citizens program here, wandered into a Taproot writing workshop and found a whole new world of poetry and prose that she could create herself.

title: Closing of Swedish Hospital Sharply Cuts Beds for Alcoholics
description: The closing last September of Brooklyn's Swedish Hospital, which was the only medical facility in the city dealing exclusively with alcoholism problems, has cut by twothirds the number of beds available for the treatment of this disease in the borough.

title: Brooklyn Theater Drops Its XRating
description: The owners of a Brooklyn theater that was forced by community pressure to stop showing pornographic films earlier this year are hoping that a newly refurbished facility and a policy of family entertainment will bring neighborhood residents back into their auditorium.

title: Who's That Stepping on Plymouth Rock?
description: Who's That Stepping on Plymouth Rock?Despite the disclaimers of dictionary, encyclopedia and historian, the notion that the Pilgrims of the Mayflower actually landed on Plymouth Rock has been difficult to dislodge from the American imagination. In this brief book, Mrs. Fritz demolishes this cherished belief with humor and authenticity. Her true history of that chunk of New England granite should go far toward dispelling forever from young minds the vision of Pilgrim footsteps upon it.

title: Trying to Keep a Rein on the Principal Intelligence Agencies
description: The Congressional intelligence committees approaching the scheduled end of their investigations now face the hard legislative work of recommending reforms. There are important issues on the domestic side but the intensifying debate over Angola makes even more critical the central question that the committees must face on the foreign side: Should the United States carry out covert operations abroad, and if so under what conditions?

title: The Region
description: As part of an effort to reduce expenses, New York City's Board of Higher Education has voted to modify its open admissions policy at City University beginning next fall. The now policy could keep as many as 10,000 students a year out of the university, 25 percent of those who, under present policy, would normally apply and be admitted.

description: DEMAREST  When this Bergen County community's new ordinance against loitering goes into effect, probably this week, people on both sides of the controversy it has generated will be watching to see how the police enforce it.

description: Christmas business is toy business. Americans do 60 percent of their toy buying during this season, and this year it will amount to some $3 billion.

title: Power Withheld

The vote against President Ford and Secretary Henry A. Kissinger, who have argued their case in terms not basically different from those used to justify the American role in Indochina, was heavy and bipartisan.

description: They have been crowding into the Board of Higher Education's meeting room for months now, a duncolored group of men and women in the uniform of New York's young street legionsold Army jackets, headbands, gunfighter mustaches and sneakers, the women with dark eyes and shrill voices, not always polite, not often articulate, but always there. The chants of demonstrators in the streets outside penetrate the room.

title: Immigration Head Voices Alarm Over the Problem of Illegal Aliens
description: MIAMI, Dec. 20The presence of millions of illegal aliens in the United States constitutes an alarming problem that is totally out of control, Gen. Leonard F. Chapman Jr., commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said here this week.

description: MIAMI, Dec. 20 (AP)Earl Morrall kept Miami's National Football League playoff hopes alive today, leaving the bench and engineering a lastminute touchdown drive that gave the Dolphins a 1413 victory over the Denver Broncos.

Robert Haskins performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: NEW U.S. FIGHTERS AWORRY IN EUROPE
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, West GermanyThe modernization of the United States Air Force in Europe, which will drastically reduce its tactical nuclear capability, has led to an acute debate in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Graham Greene's Raffles Is No Sherlock Holmes
description: LONDON Graham Greene once gave the world The Living Room and The Potting Shed, plays to relish and remember; but since the disaster of Carving a Statue, just 11 years ago, he has refused to be lured from his novels. Until now, that is. A visit to the Royal Shakespeare Company's Sherlock Holmes last Christmas left him itchyfingered, feeling that he himself could concoct for the RSC something at least as good as Conan Doyle's adapter, William Gillette. So here he is on the boards once morenot, he it emphasized, as sage, Catholic apologist and recurrent candidate for the Nobel Prize, but as this year's theatrical Santa Claus, with The Return of A. J. Raffles, a sackful of spies, burglars, detectives, princes and other season diversions, complete with bright paper and pretty ribbon.

title: Rosalie Ann Mestice Affianced to Dentist
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Michael Mestice of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosalie Ann Mestice, to Dr. William Mislowsky, a periodontist in Baltimore. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Mislowsky of Joppa, Md.

description: MONTREALThe largest foreign city nearest to New York is wondering whether it can happen here.

title: The City's People
description: What is the city but the people? asked the Tribune Sicinius in Shakespeare's Coriolanus, a question that past months of city crisis has posed for New Yorkers and other Americans all across the land. City people must be especially selfconscious this holiday season, understanding as they do that their mode of life together, their interaction and creative energy have a profound effect on the country as a wholeand in time of crisis the nation recognizes this fact even if some of its leaders have been inordinately slow to do so.

title: Youths at Sea Will Not Miss Santa

Both leagues named new commissioners; the Knicks, in a bold move, tried to sign George McGinnis, and Kareem AbdulJabbar, the most dominant force in the game, moved from the Milwaukee Bucks to the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Gulf Undecided on Continuing Oil Payments to Angola

description: PATERSONThe Passaic County Community College, in affiliation with the Paterson Area Chamber of Commerce, will offer a series of Workshops for Corporations here starting next month.

title: Russian Supersonic Transport To Limit First Flights to Cargo
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20Soviet officials said that their TU144, which will become the first supersonic airliner to go into regular commercial service, will carry only mail and cargo over, its 2,500mile route between Moscow and AlmaAta, the capital of Soviet Kazakhstan, when it begins service Dec. 25.

title: INVESTING
description: The real estate investment trust, as many investors know too well, was a magical idea in the 1960's that became a disaster in the 1970's.

title: Medical School for Military
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)  The new military medical school is accepting applications for its firstyear class of 36 students, the Pentagon has announced. The class will start next August. Eventually, the Pentagon expects to have an enrollment of 625 in the school, which is designed to produce, career medical officers for the Army, Navy, Air Force and Public Health Service.

title: LETTERS
description: Velocity

title: Susan Fishman Engaged to Physician
description: The engagement of Susan Fishman to Dr. Russell Howard Samson has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Fishman of Paramus, N. J. The wedding will be in April.

title: Should we play dirty tricks in the world?
description: WASHINGTON. The current spate of Congressional and press investigations of the Central Intelligence Agency has cast that organization, for many Americans, in a new and sinister light. The men who have devoted their lives to anonymous powerRichard Helms, William Colby, Thomas Karamessines, James Angletonhave had their day on national television, and they don't look good. It is not easy to look good defending illegal breakins, mailopenings, stashes of cobra and shellfish poison. Mafia connections and plots to overthrow foreign governments and assassinate foreign leaders. Past concerns over allegations of irresponsibility and zealotry within the C.I.A. have been heightened by a cumulative impression, at times, of a monster run amok. Yet there has been little debate about the question that will have to be faced after the sensations recede and the reports are all in: What kind of intelligence agency does the country need, and how are its officials to be kept under better control?

title: Miss Forbes Wed To D.W. Blackner
description: Jacqueline Marie Forbes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Caryl Forbes of Larchmont, N. Y., was married there yesterday afternoon in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church to Douglas Williams Bleckner. He is the son of Mrs. George W. Bleckner of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Mr. Bleckner.

title: Ellen Gelber Married to Joseph Gellert
description: Ellen Gelber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel A. Gelber of Sands Point, L. I., was married last evening to Joseph Bernard Gellert of New York, son of Mrs. Thomas Gellert of Hillsdale, N. Y., and the late Mr. Gellert.

title: Mrs. King Bows Out As a Queen
description: The records of 1975 can easily be looked up: Arthur Ashe and Chris Evert won more money and more major singles tournaments than any other male and female players on the tennis tour. But the year still didn't belong to them. It belonged to Jimmy Connors and Billie Jean King. Connors, the brash 22  year old left  hander with the brash 55yearold manager, Bill Riordan, managed to control, manipulate, infuriate and upstage the world of tennis as no one had done since S. W. Gore won the first Wimbledon championship in 1877.

title: Volunteers See Diminished Role on Coronary Rescue Team
description: HACKENSACKThe impending graduation of this community's first three paramedics has sparked a fear among members of the Volunteer Ambulance Corps that they will cast into a subordinate role on the threeyear old Coronary Rescue Team.

title: Hewlett Yeshiva Is Facing Closing
description: HEWLETTIt was a little heartbreaking for the children when three weeks ago, the 250student Yeshiva Toras Chaim at South Shore closed down temporarily for two days, Rabbi Benjamin Kamenetzky said.

title: JOHN J. GIBLIN

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Sensible planning has become a necessity of modern life. In a world in which populations are increasing and resources dwindling, in which shortages of food and energy threaten the wellbeing of millions, and in which crisis after crisis has shaken the marketplace, it is simply unthinkable for a Government with budgets approaching the $400 billion to act without a better system of coordination between public and private resources.

title: How a Retailer Planned the Season
description: Last June, the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, the department store chain that operates Lord & Taylor and other retailers, began recommending to its 157 stores the most promising merchandise categories for the 1975 Christmas season.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20President Ford declared today that the involvement of the Soviet Union with weapons and Cuba with troops in the Angolan civil war was harmful to dtente and destroys any opportunity for improvement of relations between Cuba and the United States.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hope for Catskill Rivers
description: Although years of unending struggle with little reward have left those who are fighting for the integrity of nearly 200 miles of lovely rivers in the Catskills somewhat skeptical, there is, according to Art Flick, Greene County Director of Catskill Waters, new hope for success.

description: Stock prices moved higher last week in moderate trading. Some of the early gains were given up to the uncertainty surrounding 1976 tax rates, disappointing reports on inflation and Friday profittaking.

title: Congressional Session Marked by Clashes With Ford on Energy and Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The 94th Congress, which began last January amid clashes with President Ford over energy policy and a tax cut, ended its first session last night squabbling with the President over energy policy and a tax cut.

title: Course in Windmills Is Offered By a University in New Mexico
description: LAS CRUCES, N.M.. Dec. 20 New Mexico State University is offering a new course in windmilling to meet nationwide requests from energyconscious ranchers, farmers and suburbantes for instruction and training in the repair, installation and maintenance of waterpumping windmills.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Some years ago when the movie industry was all there was and television was still some mad doctor's as yet uncommercialized evil scheme, Motion Picture Herald, the film trade journal, used to carry a fullpage feature in which exhibitors would report their experiences with individual films. The page was called What The Picture Did For Me, and it was often referred to as What The Picture Did To Me. It was informative, hilarious reading, full of outrage, sarcasm and smalltown candor, and it was there, in the midthirties, I think, that one irate exhibitor commented on some highly regarded Hollywood bowdlerization of a classic novel: Please don't send me any more pictures where the hero writes with a feather.

title: For Sara Moore, Brilliant Roles Enriched a Drab Life
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20On the drab muslin of her life, Sara Jane Moore embroidered many brilliantly colored selfportraits.

title: Moslem Governor Of North Lebanon Killed by Gunmen
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 (AP)Sheik Kassem Imad, the 53yearold Moslem Governor of North Lebanon was assassinated in a hail of machine gun fire outside his Tripoli home today.

title: A Harlem Prep for Newark
description: NEWARKLast June, the Project Link Educational Center here graduated a class of 54 eighthgraders. The commencement program was like that of most Newark schools: Elgar's Pomp and Circumstance march, the StarSpangled Banner, an invocation, a few speeches and so on.

title: 1975: The Action Was on the Field
description: The sports year of 1975 reached its theatrical peak at 12:33 A.M. Oct. 22 when Carlton Fisk hit a baseball over the leftfield wall in Fenway Park, Boston, and won the sixth game of the World Series for the Red Sox, 76, in the 12th inning.

title: News of the Realty Trade

title: Priscilla Lee Bride Of Louis A. Goldman

description: The worst is over for the Long Island economy and better days are definitely ahead, according to the NassauSuffolk Regional Plannine Board.

title: Love Stories
description: Love is an idea whose time has come back, says Martin Levin by way of introduction. With this bee in his bonnet, or, better, this hope in his head for the future of mankind, Mr. Levin has invited various editors, writers and lovable people to help him gather a collection of love stories dealing exclusively with loveas opposed, say, to hate, brutality, rape, violence, pornography, the usual thing. The 28 stories in this book tend to prove that editors, writers, you and I (the lovable people) will, if asked, choose out of pure nostalgia some tender or agreeable story we read once, perhaps in college, and never quite forgot. My own choice might have been John Galsworthy's The Apple Tree that, aged 18, I thought the most beautiful love story in the world. And by heaven, there it is, the final entry in the book.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: THE DEATH OF THE DETECTIVE, by Mark Smith. (Avon, $1.95.) A murderer, who fancies himself as Death, is hunted down in an inventive novel set on Chicago's dark side.

title: New Yorkers Near Bottom In Statistics
description: With the New York Giants in San Francisco to play the 49ers today, there are two teams named Giants in that town  both in trouble. But while the baseball Giants' problems are financial, the football Giants' woes are artistic.

title: Sunflower Splendor
description: Sunflower Splendor is the largest and, on the whole, best anthology of translated Chinese poems to have appeared in a Western language. This collection of new and recent versions by many scholars appropriately rounds out the 60 yearsa full cycle of the traditional Chinese calendar  cornpleted since the publication, in 1915, of the first readable book of Chinese poems in English: Ezra Pound's Cathay. It is astonishing to see how many and how able are the successors of Pound. Curiously, our translators of Chinese poetry must now outnumber the 16thcentury translators of the Bible. While we can scarcely expect translations from Chinese to affect our world so profoundly as Tyndale and his followers affected Reformation England, it is nevertheless hard to doubt that the discovery of Chinese verse is one of the causes, as well as results, of our modern literary sensibility. No such extensive effort is being made to translate the great poetic canons of Islam, which have been much longer known in the Occident.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Hoosier sunflower. Last week we reported on the growing practice of publishing new books simultaneously in hard covers and soft. The book reviewed on Page 1 this week is interesting as a case history in this respect, for it is a cooperative enterprise by two houses.

title: The great wit
description: Oscar Wilde's celebrated remark to Andre Gide, I've put my genius into my life; I've only put my talent into my works suggests why he has always been an attractive subject for biographers. Apart from the dramatic circumstances of his downfall, the trial and imprisonment that resulted from his notorious affair with the young Lord Alfred Douglas. Wilde's personality was an elaborate artifice deliberately fashioned to yield anecdotes. Where

title: Food: Aprs ski
description: We have frequently elaborated on the notion that, where our appetite IS concerned, most foods know no season. We like ice cream in December, a pot roast in July. There are, of course, certain foods that are intrinsically seasonal the first shad in spring, the first sweet basil of summer. And nothing tastes better in midwinter, after a session on the ski slopes (or simply a long walk in the woods), than a hot, masterfully made soup, particularly one than can serve as a main dish. On these pages are three soups that are, to our mind, ideally suited to cold weather. There is a tasty oxtail soup with paprika, a warming onion soup gratine and a soup with beef and vegetables.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Silver
description: Ann Silver and Michael Brennan Farrell, both recent graduates of the University of Notre Dame Law School, were married yesterday afternoon in the Rye, N. Y., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Silver. The bridegroom is a son of Rita Brennan Farrell and of William Farrell, both of Kalamazoo, Mich. State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: Australia's Foreign Policy Readjustments
description: MELBOURNEAustralia's recent attitude toward the United States has varied from sycophantic to abusive. This ambivalence is not just a consequence of varying periods of power by two opposing political parties in Australia. It reflects a lovehate condition that diplomats and historians down the years have chosen to call a special relationship.

title: Wooden Takes Title And Leaves
description: The University of California, Los Angeles, won a 10th national championship in 12 seasons, but the focus was on John Wooden. After the Bruins had reached the final with a 7574 overtime victory over Louisville, Wooden confirmed seasonlong whispers and announced his retirement.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20Rutgers' basketball coach, Tom Young, was disturbed at halftime tonight after some careless shooting by his Scarlet Knights against Temple, but he got over it quickly in the second half and his team ran away to a 9562 victory over the Owls. It was unbeaten Rutgers seventh victory.

title: Mexico Leading U.S., 21
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20The United States was beaten in four sets in the doubles today and could he headed for its second Davis Cup tennis defeat in 11 months by the rampaging Mexicans.

He can take people who say they are tone deaf, football players who at the start might not have shown any interest at all and get them to perform a two  hour Christmas concert that they remember for the rest of their lives.

title: The Greens
description: There was a time when the festive greens we gather now were symbolic of life and hope as represented by the winter solstice. The pagan celebration of the sun's turn from the brink of oblivion was like an annual triumph over the powers of darkness. It was illuminated by fire. It was made festive with holly and mistletoe, significant with pine and spruce and hemlock, all celebrating life and hope and belief.

title: Design: Ski house
description: This centuryold carriage house retains its original lines on the outside, but inside it's brand new, a combined work and recreation center for Mr. and Mrs. John Kimball and their sons, Christopher, 20, and Nicholas, 18. The Kimball home, a colonial farmhouse, has typically small rooms and low ceilings, and over the years, the family outgrew it. Mr. Kimball, a biologist and author, needed a roomy study, the boys a place to entertain their friends, especially on winter weekends after returning from the New Hampshire ski run an hour's drive distant.

title: The Moment When the Money Came

title: Book Ends
description: Tourist. We had a talk recently with Susan Brownmiller, author of Against Our Will, who had just returned from a sixweek, 27city publicity tour. She looked tired, but as chance would have it, on the very week of her return her book had made the Best Seller List, so it was all presumably worth it. From what she told us, Miss Brownmiller was a good soldier about it all, eating properly, getting to bed early, in order to cope with the average of eight interviews a day facing her each morning. A nondrinker, she didn't have to deal with the tired touring author's recurrent temptation to sit out the rest of the afternoon in a bar, and her publishers, Simon & Schuster, had scheduled her for interesting cities (e.g., Denver and San Francisco) on weekends for rest and recuperation; so, all things considered, she had gone out and done what her publishers wanted her to do: come back with a best seller (the book has since slipped off the list).

title: Some Poinsettia Pointers
description: Little did Joel Poinsett know what he started when he introduced the poinsettia to America. (It bears his name.) While serving as Ambassador to Mexico, he brought 16 poinset tia plants back to his South Carolina greenhouse in 1825. He had collected them near Taxco and gave them to friends and botanists who had greenhouses. Not until the early 1900's did the poinsettias move outdoors when Albert Ecke, a Swiss horticulturist, started to raise them in California fields for the local Christmas market. His son, Paul, expanded the business into pot plants with the variety Oak Leaf. By 1960 the New Era longlasting hybrids were introduced by J. C. Mikkelsen, an Ohio grower. Now it is not unusual for a poinsettia display to last several months and the colors may be red, pink, white marbled.

The drive takes an hour to an hour and a half from all three cities. Boatman can reach the lake by the Okeechobee Waterway from Stuart on the east coast, from Fort Myers on the west coast.

Robinson, president of the Marcona Corporation, was appointed Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs one year ago, businessmen cheered, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization expressed displeasure and more experienced hands in the Government figured they could handily ease the newcomer into a safe spot on the shelf.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: It is possible, through Jan. 20, to see two Woolworth Buildings in Lower Manhattan. The original is in its accustomed place on Broadway at the foot of City Hall Park, having survived, since 1913, the praise of the distinguished critic Montgomery Schuyler (who hailed it on completion as a shapely, satisfactory and eyefilling work of art), the scorn of the modernists (who managed to dismiss its 52 Flemish Gothic stories as a deceitful and ludicrous sham), and an impassioned reappreciation by architects and scholars today.

The Vikings have two games to play before they can qualify for the Super Bowl again, the first one a division playoff contest against the Dallas Cowboys a week from tomorrow at home in Bloomington, Minn.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The subject is bells, it being Christmas week and all that. Bells: hollow metallic vessels used for making a more or less loud noise. So goes the unforgettable definition in the great eleventh edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica Christmas is the time for bells (and their cousins, chimes and carillons). We hear them everywhere this time of the year; they even are as much a pictorial symbol of Christmas as Santa Claus.

title: Dining Out in Jersey

title: Artists' CoOp Making Itself Known
description: BROOKHAVENWhen the Bell Street Artists cooprative was formed, its members hoped to buy a house on Bell Street in Bellport. That purchase fell through, but the members of the cooperative decided they liked the name well enough to keep it, with or without the house on Bell Street.

title: The Subtle Scenes
description: The headlines melt into history. But behind the headlines are the subtle scenes. And in 1975, as in every year, those are the memories that remain.

title: Thomas Saxe Jr., 72, Founder Of White Tower Chain, Is Dead
description: Thomas E. Saxe Jr., chairman of the White Tower Management Corporation and founder of the White Tower chain of restaurants died yesterday in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Mile Mark Challenged And Falls
description: The most glamorous event in track and field is the onemile run, a race long enough to require speed and strength and short enough to keep spectators excited. They were doubly excited in 1975 because the world record for the mile was broken twice. The first breakthrough came on May 17 in Kingston, Jamaica, where Filbert Bayi of Tanzania made a dream mile out of a race advertised as the Dream Mile. He defeated a strong international field in 3 minutes 51 seconds, shaving a tenth of a second off Jim Ryun's 1967 world record. Ryun seemed unconcerned, saying, I thought the record would have been broken long ago.

title: The Goals Of the Proxy War
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Strategists of many nations are now engaged in analyzing global implications of today's power struggle in southern Africa, focusing on Angola. That this conflict is of great concern to both African and nonAfrican countries is blatantly evident; but its ultimate significance remains unclear.

title: For Newark Police and Firemen Facing Layoffs, a Time of Trial Lies Ahead

title: THE GANG IN THE RED BERETS
description: Troop 754, one of 52 Boy Scout troops in Harlem, meets every Saturday at noon in the basement of St. Joseph's Church, on the corner of Morningside Avenue and 125th Street. There are 32 boys in the troop, with a hard core of a dozen or so who come all the time. Many live in a nearby housing project. The scoutmaster is Paul Allen, a big, cheerful man who works as longshoreman on the night shift at the West Side docks. He was a scout himself, back in Illinois in the 30's, and he is proud of doing things the way his own scoutmaster did. Scouts from Troop 754 are required to know the 32 points of the compass by heart, and there is a dollar fine for using a flashlight on a canoeing trip. At meetings the emphasis is on rote learning and traditional scout lore. The boys practice sucking venom from imaginary snakebites, make slings from their neckerchiefs and drag one another across the dusty floor.
