description: A Japanese SoHo is taking root in Brooklyn.

title: State's Population Loss Could Cut Flow of U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20New York State's middecade population loss would cost the state up to $200 million a year in Federal funds through 1980 under legislation that passed the Senate unanimously this week and that the House is expected to approve, state officials said today.

title: A Haven for the Abused Child That Treats the Parents, Too
description: WASHINGTONThere is a hobbyhorse, dressup clothes, a childsized kitchen, and wonderful building blocks. Threeyearold Sammy chatters in Spanish as he plays with a wooden truck with real rubber tires; a darkeyed little girl sits absorbed with a talking doll; and 4yearold Barbara, enveloped in a yellow smock, is silently intent on fingerpainting at a low table.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The official National Bicentennial medal commemorating the nation's 200th anniversary will be available to the public starting Jan. 1. It will be on sale until the end of July. A joint announcement of this longawaited news was made last week by John W. Warner, Administrator of the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration (ARBA), and Mrs. Mary Brooks, Director of the U.S. Mint. The Mint will strike the medals for the ARBA.

title: U.S. Won't Defend Legality of Security Wiretaps
description: WASHINGON, Dec. 20The Justice Department has informed the United States District Court here that it will not defend, on behalf of the Government, the legality of the socalled national security surveillance in which warrantless wiretaps were placed on the telephones of 17 officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Nearly Finished School Focus of Budget cutback Dispute
description: A Queens public school that stands 74 percent complete but is to remain unfinished because of the city's fiscal crisis became the focus of bitter protest last week on the part of parents, educators and community officials.

title: Yugoslavia Steps Up Criticism Of U.S. Television Programs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 20Walt Disney television shows were attacked by the controlled press this week, raising the prospect that American programs might be dropped entirely from television screens.

title: Deborah Landon Bronxville Bride
description: Deborah Dodge Landon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner F. Landon of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Lake Placid, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to William Edward Huebner, son of Mrs. William Huebner of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Mr. Huebner.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (UPI)The New Zealand One Tonner, Prospect of Ponsonby, won her second successive race today in the Southern Cross Cup ocean racing teams series, being sailed out of Sydney.

title: A Joyful Noise in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Boys Chorus, an offshoot of the famed Newark Boys Chorus, will celebrate its first holiday season in New York by lifting its voice in Christmas song all around its new town.

title: Rams Win, 103, on Late Score
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 20As if making sure that the films of this game would be as uniformative as possible when studied by next week's playoff opponents, the Los Angeles Rams and Pittsburgh Steelers stuck to breadandbutter ground games tonight as the Rams scored a 103 decision.

title: The ways and means of literary critics
description: These four new hooks point dramatically to the perennial threeway split within the ranks of literary criticismthe rift between those who use a body of nonliterary theory (psychoanalysis, Marxism) in an effort to illuminate specific literary works; those who are addicted to theoretical structures largely for their own sakes, with limited application to the specific; and those who focus their scrutiny upon the works themselves within

title: Real Estate Bias Charged
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I, Dec. 20 (AP)The Rhode Island Commission for Human Rights says the state's real estate industry is practicing racial discrimination. The commission released a report yesterday on two of its staff membes, one white and one black, who posed as potential home buyers and visited real estate agencies last summer.

title: The Nation
description: The enrollment of white students in the Boston public schools has dropped by more than a third Since courtordered busing began there 18 months ago in an effort to achieve desegregation.

title: St. John's, Undefeated, Tops American U.,7866
description: Unbeaten St. John's ran its streak to seven games last night with a 7866 victory over American University at Alumni Hall in Queens.

title: Study Dims Hope For New Ferries
description: Prospects for the establishment of new ferry service between Long Island and Connecticut were dimmed Friday when the TriStdte Regional Planning Commission recommended that instead of starting more routes, Connecticut and New York help to substantially improve the existing, privately operated crossings from Port Jefferson to Bridgeport and Orient Point to New London.

title: Deaths
description: AHERNMary (nee O'Malle), Dec. 20, 1975, loving wile of the late John, beloved mother of John, Jr. Dearest sister of Patrick, Nara Masterson, Thomas, Margaret McNally and Joseph. Also survived by three grandchildren. Reposing 25 and 710 P.M., at John J. Fob A Sons, Inc., Grand Concourse at 201 St., Bronx. Mass Of Resurrection, Tuesday, 10 A.M., St. Philip Neri Church. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery.

title: CUBANS STUDYING NEW 5YEAR PLAN
description: HAVANA, Dec. 20, (Reuters) The first congress of the Cuban Communist Party, meeting in private, has begun examining details of the country's fiveyear plan.

title: ANTICANCERDRUG ASSAILED IN TRIAL
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 20A suburban Los Angeles physician and four other persons have, been convicted on charges of conspiracy to distribute the outlawed drug laetrile to cancer sufferers in California and other states.

title: PublicEmployee Unions Are No Longer Riding High
description: Civil service unions in the metropolitan region, long superachievers in the fastestgrowing section of the American labor movement, are glumly adjusting to a future full of holding actions to fend off pay freezes, forced dismissals and cuts in established benefits.

title: For young readers
description: In A Stranger Came Ashore. Mollie Hunter directs a new cast of characters in an original and suspenseful presentation, without departing from her characteristic style and setting. The place is Black Ness, a small village in the Shetland Islands, and the style is that of the traditional teller of folk legend and fairy tale.

title: What went wrong in Virginia, the postwar world, the Middle East
description: In June 1586, Francis Drake's fleet arrived off Roanoke, Virginia, carrying several hundred blacks liberated in raids on Santo Domingo and Cartagena and an even larger contingent of Indians. Before these supposedly free workers could be put ashore to reinforce the young, struggling colony, a storm dispersed Drake's ships, and the discouraged settlers pulled up stakes.

title: Paul Jeffrey Leads Flexible Jazz Octet At 2d St. Tin Palace
description: Paul Jeffrey, an unusually accessible and communicative tenor saxophonist, is sufficiently concerned with his goals as leader of a jazz group to fly in the face of current custom, which limits such groups, for reasons of economy, to a quartet or a quintet. Mr. Jeffrey says he wants flexibilitythe looseness of a small band and the big sound of a large ensemble, a full bottom sound and rich tone colors.

title: Excitement Up
description: After two decades of uninterrupted growth in gate receipts and public adoration, pro football experienced a small retrenchment this year. The World Football League, the upstart outfit that began with so much arrogance and ambition in 1974, failed to survive its second season and folded in late October, which came as no surprise. Losses were incalculable but estimated at more than $10 million.

title: Broadway Discovers Tennessee Williams
description: Life is being good to Tennessee Williams again. After a long and difficult period during which his reputation declined, he is enjoying a widespread renewal of interest in his past work. There may be, in fact, no fewer than three revivals of his plays simultaneously on Broadway during the coming weeks. The Glass Menagerie has just opened at Circle in the Square; Sweet Bird of Youth, acclaimed at the Kennedy Center and then at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, reopens at the Harkness Dec. 29, and the Phoenix Theater will present one of his shorter works, 27 Wagons Full of Cotton, as part of its opening program at the Playhouse on Jan. 26. In addition, Williams has two new plays about to open (albeit far from Broadway) and has a third in progress, and he is making headlines with his sensationally frank Memoirs, published last month.

title: BRIDGE
description: Success in the game of bridge, as in the game of life, depends partly on technical competence and partly on psychological insight. Very few performers, either microcosmic or macrocosmic, are equally adept in both fields. Anyone scoring A+ in both areas inevitably makes his mark.

title: A Slogger Is a Painfully Slow Jogger
description: I have run 3,485 miles. Being a slogger (slow jogger), it has taken me six years to reach this pinnacle of punishment. Every plodding mile has been dutifully recorded with my time and weight noted. Sloggers are compulsive recordkeepers.

title: EDUCATION BOARD SCORED BY BLACKS
description: Black legislators and educators in the City University system charged last week that the Board of Higher Education had deprived the minority community of a chance to present its position against the establishment of admission tests at the university.

title: At Budget Time, Like Scrooge
description: It is the municipal budgetmaking season in New Jersey, but, unlike the holiday season with which it coincides, it is anything but jolly, according to a sampling of municipal officials.

title: The Year in Sports: Reds and Red Sox
description: In the 100th year of the National League, the 75th year of the American League and the third year of the designated hitter, baseball supplied its 30 million cash customers with topsyturvy winners and losers in 1975.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: If a photograph is good, the gender of the photographer should not matter. But it is perhaps inevitable at the present time that exhibitions will be organized to show the work of women photographers. The best of these exhibitions to appear in New York so far is Women of Photography, organized by the San Francisco Museum of Art, currently on view at the Sidney Janis Gallery.

title: Christmas: When Jugs Are Decanters
description: At Seagram Distillers, the whiskey company, they still remember the New England fisherman who wrote to praise their special holiday packaging.

title: Pin Winner Discovers Butterflies Are Calming
description: Is it possible to be so nervous you're calm? asked Carol Anderton after winning the biggest prize in the history of bowling. That's what happened. I blanked around me and did what I had to do to win.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about todays television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Sunday Observer
description: It was that merry season when frost reddens the nose, shop windows twinkle with holly berry and tinsel, and the spicy odors of flaming pudding and balsam gum sweeten the dusk whose early arrival betokens the imminence of year's end. On such an evening, huddled bonechilled in an inadequate gray topcoat, his feet shod in scuffed loafers, his cheek pallid and his mouth eager for the warm fantasy of gin and vermouth, Santa Claus shambled through the streets of the metropolis.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Tax Cut

title: Carolyn Anderton, who earned $50,000 in one game
description: STRATTON, Vt., Dec. 19 (AP)Bob Hill of Rutland. Vt., won the men's division of the Eastern Holiday ski classic today for the second day in a row.

title: Children Stars at Planetarium
description: CENTERPORTTorten the softhearted elf and Drusus the lumbering polar bear have returned to Long Island with the good newsto the delight of the young children who sit or lie down on the floor of the Vanderbilt Planetarium during the showing of Torten's Christmas Secretthat there are no bad children. It's just that, as Torten says, Some children are better than others.

title: Chelsea: Melting Pot With a Touch of Class
description: The landed and scholarly gentleman who was called the first citizen of Manhattan's Chelsea district breathed his last at his summer home in Newport in 1863. His ancestors were Anglophilic, aristocratic, and acquisitive of Manhattan real estate. He had thus been free to follow his own pursuits: philology, languages, music, a, dabble at architecture, urban planning, and versifying.

title: STAMPS
description: The freshness and variety of young minds and youthful skills have been utilized by Canada, which selected for this year's Christmas stamps the designs of six school children on the theme of What Christmas Means to Me. There were more than 80,000 entries from children under the age of 13.

title: House Guestor Family?
description: In her hook, Hiroho Yoshikawa describes the ambivalence of her feelings about living here in the following way:

title: Kungsholm Sails On Maiden Cruise Under New Owners
description: The 26,678ton Kungsholm, a luxury cruise liner that had been a regular caller here for 10 years, sailed on her maiden cruise Friday afternoon under a new flag and under new management.

title: Amanda Millspaugh Is Engaged To Peter Ford, Fellow Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Plant Millspaugh of Huntington, L. L, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amanda Corwin Millspaugh, to Peter Burgess Ford, son of James S. Ford of Noroton, Conn., and Ann Burgess Ford of Rowayton. Conn.

title: Israeli Security Through Nuclear Deterrence
description: BALTIMOREWhatever the forum for future Middle East negotiations, the underlying realities will remain the same.

title: For young readers
description: With his first book, The Hawk in the Rain, Ted Hughes, the British poet, staked out a section of the natural world that could not have been more removed from the pastoral than if he had been writing about the prevalence of black lung among coal miners. That is, if we understand the pastoral as a prettified and romantic view of rural life. His descriptions of animals in The Hawk in the Rain and the later books were realistically openeyed and conveyed their primitiveness in powerful images driven by pistonlike rhythms. Readers will remember Pike, Thrushes, An Otter, the first section of Lupercalia.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Under orders from the commander of Argentina's air force, fighter planes yesterday strafed and bombed an air base held by rebellious airmen seeking to overthrow President Isabel Martinez de Peron. There were no casualties, but two of the rebels' planes were knocked out and runways were damaged, neutralizing the only base of rebel operations. The rebel airmen said that they would retaliate by bombing Government House in Buenos Aires, where Mrs. Pern was in her office, with ministers, labor leaders and leaders of the Peronist party, but there was no attack. Without support from other military forces, the airmen's revolt seemed to be under control. The command of the army and navy announced that all units were loyal to their natural commanders and were on full alert. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: A Correction
description: In an article on this page last week, the names of two stores in Sea Cliff were incorrectly given. The name of the antique store at 318 Sea Cliff Avenue should have been given as Artifacts Antiques. The clothing store at 310 Sea Cliff Avenue is named B's Nest.

title: Atlantic Testing a New System
description: MAYS LANDINGAtlantic County, having elected a Democrat as its first County Executive and put Republicans in control of a new and expanded Board of Chosen Freeholders, is now watching these opposing politicians struggle to make the new county government work.

title: Summaries of Loughlin Games
description: FIELD EVENTS

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Contemporary composers have often been charged with sadism when writing for the human voice. Even Beethoven, Verdi and Wagner in their time were accused of making impossible demands on the vocal cords: Just as composers have expanded the expressive potential of regular instruments over the years, so too have they found fresh means of employing singers. A number of recent records give a particularly illuminating crosssection of what has happened in the world of vocal Music over the past few decades.

title: Charge Dismissed In a Police Death In San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20Judge Edward Cragen of Superior Court has dismissed a murder indictment against a black man accused of participating in the politically motivated slaying of a policeman here four years ago.

title: What's Doing in the BERKSHIRES
description: IN THE LAP OF THE GODSNew Englanders still think of the Berkshire Mountains of western Massachusetts as the site of the American Mount Olympus. Here, the giants of art and literaturefrom Hawthorne to Edith Wharton and Serge Koussevitzkycommuned with the gods and muses. But never in winter. Time was, some swear, when even the deities forsook the peaks, retreating to Beacon Hill with the Boston Symphony at the end of its summer season at Tanglewood and abandoning the Berkshire woodlands to the woodcutters and hunters. In his popular painting, Christmas in Stockbridge, Massachusetts, 1967, Norman Rockwell depicted his fellow villagers in a lively holiday scene along his hometown's Main Street, but his brush correctly left the Red Lion Inn, the thoroughfare's dominant structure, dark and empty. The painting, which hangs in the town's Old Corner House, has since become a tourist attraction, and Jane Fitzpatrick, the Red Lion's new owner, is quick to set the record straight by informing visitors that the innthese days remains open at Christmas and will be lit up like a Yule tree during the holidays, as indeed will most of the Berkshires. Multitudes of skiers may be largely, responsible for the festive spirit, but in this Bicentennial era there's a good reason for nonsportsmen, too, to head for the Berkshire hills.

title: Israeli Diplomats Critical Of P.L.O. Role in U N. Talks
description: Israel's top diplomats in the United States said last night that participation by the Palestine Liberation Organization in next month's Security Council debate on the Middle East was intended to thwart a negotiated peace in favor of an imposed settlement.

title: The Chinese Bandit
description: Few Western novelists have written about China. Fewer still have done it well. The reasons aren't hard to find. The period of accessibility was brief, the language extremely difficult, the cities squalid, the countryside dangerous, and the society dense, closed, remote. Not coincidentally two of those who succeededPearl Buck, in The Good Earth, and John Hersey, in his lovely tale of a journey by junk through the Yangtze gorges, A Single Pebblegrew up there, the children of missionaries.

title: Swedes Score in Doubles For 21 Davis Cup Lead
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 20 (UPI) Sweden won the doubles from Czechoslovakia today and gained a 21 lead, moving to within a victory of capturing the 1975 Davis Cup tennis final.

title: Coliseum Offers 'Nutcracker
description: Impossible! Andr Eglevsky thought when he was first asked to present his Eglevsky Ballet Company in The Nutcracker at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale.

title: Rival Hospital Systems Compete in Bronx
description: The clash between municipal and voluntary hospitals over which will dominate the rapidly growing healthcare field here is coming into sharp focus in the Bronx.

title: In Millburn, Season's Treats Abound
description: MILLBURN  Christmas treats literally fill every corner of the Suburban Dessert Shop, a spacious, colonialstyle store here.

title: There's Only One No. 1, and the Cosmos Have Him
description: Pel, soccer's superlative, was lured out of retirement by the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League in June, 1975. The Brazilian's move involved not only playing soccer, but also doing promotions for the Cos mo's parent company, Warner Communications. Pel actually signed two contracts that will gross him several million dollars. His soccer contract called for 30 months, while his other contract, although never made public, was for six years.

title: TV VIEW
description: Public television's Classic Theater series closed this week with George Bernard Shaw's Mrs, Warren's Profession (which will be repeated on Channel 13 this afternoon at 5). The Channel 13 productions, imported entirely from the British Broadcasting Corporation, deserve parting comments, both for themselves and what they suggest about American television.

title: Harriet Jane Lindley Married To Edward DeWolf Kratovil
description: In the Stowe (Vt.) Community Church yesterday evening, Harriet Jane Lindley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lindley Jr. of Montpelier, Vt., became the bride of Edward DeWolf Kratovil, sort of Mr. and Mrs. Emil A. Kratovil of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Phillip Chase.

title: Lights Turning On New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThis city is extending its holiday merriment until the middle of next month, thanks to the efforts of merchants, businessmen and residents.

title: 3 Strokes Keep Nicklaus On a Grand Slam Quest
description: It was, as he said, his best season. Jack Nicklaus won his fifth Masters and fourth Professional Golfers' Association championship, and he came closer to the Grand Slam than he had in 1972. I threw away the United States Open, Nicklaus said, and let the British Open slip away. He missed the British Open by one stroke and the United States Open by two.* Still, Nicklaus reasserted a supremacy no one could challenge. He led the pro tour with five victories, three in succession. For the seventh time he won the money title$298,149and for the fourth time he was designated P.G.A. player of the year.

title: Bruins Top Sabres, Gain Tie for First
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)Hank Nowak and Bobby Schmautz capped a Boston rally today with thirdperiod goals to give the Bruins a 53 National Hockey League victory over Buffalo and a firstplace tie in the Adams Division with the slumping Sabres.

title: Miami, Ohio, 207 Winner In Tangerine
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP)Rob Carpenter plunged for two touchdowns today and lifted Miami of Ohio to a 207 victory over South Carolina in the Tangerine Bowl.

title: Experts Ask F.D.A. Control on Estrogen
description: A committee of experts last week advised the Food and Drug Administration to strictly limit the use of estrogens in the treatment of the symptoms and aftereffects of the menopause.

title: Rift Between Cohalan and Majority of Islip Town Board Reflects Republican Feud
description: ISLIPA split in the Town of Islip Republican party widened this week when a majority of the Town Board, all of whose members are Republicans, voted to remove many of the executive powers held by Peter F. Cohalan, The Town Supervisor, also a member of the G.O.P.

title: Spanish Bishops Call for an Amnesty
description: MADRID, Dec. 20 (AP)Spain's Roman Catholic bishops urged amnesty for political prisoners and wider individual liberties today while the new Interior Minister promised more political freedom but sterner punishment for those who violate the law.

title: 7th VICTIM IN FIRE IS IDENTIFIED HERE
description: The seventh victim of the fouralarm fire Thursday that demolished the Blue Angel nightclub was identified yesterday as Joseph Leopold, 40 years old, of 419 East 57th Street.

title: POLARIZATION HITS LEBANESE HAMLET
description: SIBNAY, Lebanon, Dec. 20This small Moslem hamlet in the hills eight miles south of Beirut is a telling example of the polarizationsome call it de facto partitionthat is taking place all over Lebanon. as Christians and Moslems move gut of mixed areas to seek safety among people of their own faith.

title: Children in City Thrill To Christmas Parties
description: Clasping the leash of a pet lamb, Michele Morton, 10 years old, perched on a piano stool beside a blind musical director while he led a group of visually handicapped children through a round of carols yesterday. She was one of 50 guests at a party sponsored by The Associated Blind at its headquarters on West 23d Street who had received gifts with the name tags written in Braille.

title: Busing: The Solution That Has Failed To Solve
description: Busing is one way to pay the bill for the ancient regime of racism.Senator George McGovern, a liberal Democrat. Busing is a bankrupt concept.Senator Joseph Biden Jr., a liberal Democrat.

title: Per Capita Payments Of U.S. Aid to States
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 The following is a listing of the 50 states in the order in which they receive per capita Federal funds in 1975, and the amount of per capita funds received (figures based on population estimates of July 1975):

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: Al GARDEN

title: LABOR UNIT TODRAFT REFORMS IN N.L.R.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) The National Labor Relations (Board has appointed a 26member panel of labor law experts to recommend improvements in the procedures of the N.L.R.B.

title: Music Notes: Contemporaries, Cantors and Mozart
description: The nineday Celebration of Contemporary Music which has been announced jointly by the New York Philharmonic and the Juilliard School (March 513) can be viewed in a variety of lights, all of them promising. For one thing, its Bicentennial gesture has a different twist from most. Artistic directors Pierre Boulez, music director of the Philharmonic, and Peter Mennin, president of Juilliard, will present works of 15 American composers against a background of music by seven Europeans, thereby providing an interesting perspective in two directions.

title: Foyt Rolls On, But He Wants Another Big One
description: Generations come, generations go and A. J. Foyt remains oblivious to the aging process.

title: TV Notes: AllStar Game Throws Democrats a Curve
description: The Democratic Party recently received some upsetting news. Next year's AllStar baseball game will be played on July 13, the second night of the Democrat's national convention. That means a wipeout on TV. ABC, with the sports classic, will almost surely draw away millions Of viewers from the gaveltogavel coverage of the convention on CBS and NBC.

title: Poor. Man's Bank Thrives in Newark
description: NEWARKEfforts by the City National Bank to gain a voice for black and Spanishspeaking residents in the financial structure of New Jersey's largest city have far exceeded its expectations.

title: Jews and Arabs
description: On November 24. 1973, one month after the end of the Yom Kippur War, in a discussion organized by four major European newspapers, Lihya's Colonel Kadhafi generously suggested to Jews from Arab countries that they could help solve the Middle Eastern conflict if they would go back home; that is, return to their countries of origin. One of the participants in that discussion (who declined the Colonel's offer) is the author of this book. He hits hard at a variety of myths that have obscured the relations of Jews and Arabs, of which Kadhafi's suggestion is one expression.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Would you believe a new opera house? Better, yet, a new opera house devoted to dance? It is at present a very real and wonderful possibility. Indeed, it is essential, and only a few bucks, a few million bucks actually; stand between that dream and that reality.

title: From East to West, It Was Year of Terrier
description: From coast to coast, 1975 will be remembered as the year of the terrier. In the East, a Sealyham, Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, who was imported from Wales by Mrs. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., was outstanding. She finished on a high note. Peter Green gaited her to bestinshow awards at Boardwalk, whose 3,714 dogs made it the third largest event of the year, and at Philadelphia, in a field of 3,641.

title: Chicago Nuptials For Susan Davis
description: Susan Elizabeth Davis and Lawrence Edward Hammer, both of Chicago, were married yesterday afternoon in the Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stanley Hallett, a Methodist minister, who is a vice president of Chicago's South Shore Bank, where the bride is director of development deposits.

title: BlueLaw Drive Is Disputed
description: HAUPPAUGE  Renewed enforcement of the state's blue laws, under which it is an offense for most businesses to sell goods on Sundays, has become the subject of a dispute among legislators and lawenforcement officials in Suffolk County.

title: Criminals At Large
description: On the face of it, THE LOST AND FOUND MAN by Nicholas Guild (Harper's Magazine Press/Harper & Row, $7.95) is no different from any number of espionage novels. The hero is a sort of superman; the plot complications rival Kant's Critique of Pure Reason in their involved reasonings; not until the very last pages do we know the good guys from the bad. Sound familiar? It is.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Course Is Plotted On Sea Language
description: Sometimes life is smooth sailing. However, about this time of year, by husband is taken aback by the figures in my checkbook and warns me these will be hell to pay. The IanNews guage is as common as shove of off, as cautious Boating as keep a weather eye and as fatalistic as go by the boards.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: FollowUp on The News
description: In an unusual case in Brooklyn last month, two city policemen who beat a man they were arresting were ordered by a Federal Court jury to pay $102,400 in damages. Two other policemen who were at the scene were ordered to pay $300 each.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Oberndorf, Arnsdorf, Hallein or Wagrain over the holidays, there will be Christmas Eve ceremonies or masses involving trumpet fanfares, speeches, costumes, regional songs and carols, including renditions of Silent Night in the original version. The departure point in Salzburg for these four destinations at any time of the year is Sildtirolerplatz, which houses a complex consisting of two rail stations (Hauptbahnhof and Lokalbahnhof) and two bus terminals. There are several Postautobuses and local trains a day between Salzburg and Oberndorf. The trip takes less than half an hour and costs less than $1 each way. In Oberndorf, the Silent Night Chapel is open every day from 8 A.M. to B P.M. In winter, 8 or 9 P.M. in summer. Admission is free. The Oberndorfer Heimathaus Museum is open through Jan. 11, then closes until May when Is reopens Saturday and Sunday afternoons only (plus Austrian holidays) through September. It then shuts down until midDecember. Best bets for accommodations in Oberndorf are the Braugasthof Noppinger, where a room with breakfast starts at $4.50 a person, and the Gasthof Feichtner, where rates start at $4 with breakfast. Though still in use, the Gruber School in Arnsdorf is also licensed as a museum and Mrs. Josef Aigner, the teacher, is happy to show visitors around for 27 cents (children free) during school hours, which include Saturday mornings. But you must phone ahead for an appointment(06274 33603) and have someone who speaks German make the arrangements.

title: A World Destroyed
description: The ghost of mighthavebeen hovers with particular insistency over the realm of international relations. Were there paths not taken which would have led to peace, security, freedom from fear? The development and use of the atomic bomb during World War II raises this question with intense poignancy.

title: Griffin: Little Man Sets Big Marks
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant, Alabama's football coach and athletic director, opened the season by taking the National Collegiate Athletic Association to court and closed it by picking his opponent for the Sugar Bowl gamePenn State.

title: Rise in Housing Construction Foreseen
description: EAST BRUNSWICKThe pace of housing construction in New Jersey, as depressed in the last two years as it has been in the country generally, should begin climbing again in 1976, officials of the New Jersey Builders Association here predict.

title: Christmas Eve in Mexico: Find in a Room at the Inn
description: MY husband and I were flying to Mexico for the Christmas holidays. We were to spend one night in Mexico City, then on to San Miguel Allende, where we would stay 10 days in a converted colonial hacienda that reputedly oozed charm and for which we had paid in advance. We had a receipted bill to prove it.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1975

title: Pamela Graham Murphy Wed To Edmond Whitcraft Murphy
description: The marriage of Pamela Graham Murphy to Edmond Whitcraft Murphy took place here yesterday morning at the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Murphy Jr., father and stepmother of the bride.

title: Kaianchoes Are Colorful
description: Kalanchoes are colorful Christmas plants that quickly make themselves comfortable in livingroom windows. Water them when the soil dries to touch and the blooms should last for at least six weeks. Once this attractive gift plant's culture is mastered, even the newest plant grower can become expert in the many other kinds of kalanchoes, most of which are easy to start from seed.

title: The Dance: Dark Meadow Revived
description: Dark Meadow, that mystery of all Graham mysteries, came in for a stunning revival from the Martha Graham Dance Company Friday night at the Mark Hellinger Theater on a program that also featured Takako Asakawa's exciting first appearance this season as Joan of Arc in Seraphic Dialogue.

title: C. R. Kennedy to Wed Miss Mayer
description: Mr. and Mrs Gerald M. payer Jr. of Oyster Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathey Mayer, to Charles Reed Kennedy, son of Mrs. Alfred A. Fleer of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and George D. Kennedy of Pelham, N. Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Nets Gambol Their Way To 11891 Rout of Squires
description: UNIONDALE, Dec. 21 As befits the holiday season, the New York Nets played a basketball game this afternoon that was more like a winter vacation and walked away from the Virginia Squires, 11891.

title: Bumper Crop From China
description: One of the most popular stockingstuffers this Christmas will undoubtedly be the little wheat straw boxes from China that eager shoppers are snapping up all over town. For one thing, they're fresh and new. For another, they're appropriate for almost anyone. And, best of all, they're easy on the pock etbook, ranging from $3.50 to $25 or so, depending on place of purchase.

title: Many Theories Are Offered for Cause of Crib Death
description: Painstaking and, until recently, meagerly financed, research is beginning to take some of the mystery out of sudden unexplained infant death, commonly called crib death, which is believed to have killed Governor Carey's granddaughter Saturday.

title: Theater: An Enchanting Old Musical
description: VERY GOOD EDDIE, a musical with book by Guy Bolton, based on a farce by Phillip Bartho??mae; music by Jerome Kern; lyrics by Schuyler Greene; setting and lighting by Fred Voelpel rostumes by David loser; special consultant. Alfred Simon, musical ??tion and arrangements by Russell Warner, dances and musical members staged by Dan Siretta; directed by Bill production stage manage?? Don Judge. David Merrick, Max Brown, B??on Go??man present the Goodspeed Op?? House production. At the Booth cheater, 222 West 45th Street.

title: 2 Hurt in Blast on Coast
description: CARSON, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP)  An explosion at a chemical plant in this industrial suburb of Los Angeles injured two men early today and caused an estimated $2 million in damage. Fire officials said that half of the plant, the Ai Products and Chemical Company, had been destroyed.

title: $1.5 Million Stolen L. I. A. Antiques And Art Found, Teacher Seized
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 21  A 50yearold Nassau County teacher was arrested here today on charges of breaking into estates in this fashionable resort area. The local police said they had recovered antiques and art works worth more than $1.5 million in the suspect's home in neighboring Sae Harbor.

title: A Shift in Fiscal Crises
description: ALBANY, Dec. 20Surfeited with crises, the State Legislature has finally closed out a long, harrowing year here with a series of extraordinary actions that in one three month stretch raised or created city and state taxes and curtailed New York City's selfgovernment in saving it from default, but that still left the state in the city's former position of monthtomonth battles with fiscal disaster.

title: Carey's Delegate Plan Seen as Faltering
description: The plan to run Democratic Presidential delegates who would be listed as uncommitted but would be usable on behalf of Governor Carey is falling apart, Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday in announcing his support for Senator Birch Bayh.

title: TERRORISTS RAID OPEC OIL PARLEY IN VIENNA, KILL 3
description: VIENNA, Monday, Dec. 22Six terrorists, their weapons concealed in sportsequipment bags, burst into a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries here yesterday, shot three persons to death with submachine guns and held at least 60 people hostage.

title: Books of The Times
description: The humanity of the American people, says Robert Nisbet, is being crowded out by the humanitarianism of our government. Not so much by the government we elected, he adds, but by a largely invisible array of bureaucratic commissions, agencies and departments that function more or less autonomously to usurp our autonomy. In the alleged interests of equality, welfare, education, safety, health and environment, we are increasingly being forced to surrender areas of decision we traditionally regarded as our own.

title: Ford's First National Campaign: Incumbent in Role of Underdog
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21President Ford's campaign plan, a key adviser says, is to be the best President he knows how. His central campaign problem, the same counselor adds, may be an impatient public's sense that through 16 months of his accidental term, Mr, Ford has been the best President he knows how.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: 309 Start Chilly Run
description: Despite occasional snowflakes, some icy underfooting and 22degree temperatures, 309 runners started the 10.2mile race in Central Park yesterday, part of the Pernod winter series of the New York Road Runners Club.

title: ROWLAND LEE, 84, OF FILMS IS DEAD
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI)Rowland V. Lee, a Hollywood director, died at his home today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: Levi Says He Favors Legislation to Limit the Tenure of the F.B.I.'s Director
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he would favor legislation limiting the tenure of the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Richardson, Leaving London Post, Sees Upturn for Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 21  Doom and gloom are common currency here these days, and sackcloth the raiment of those whose job it is to monitor Britain's fortunes. But there is one man who thinks this crowded island may have turned the corner. He wears impeccable pinstripes and his name is Elliot L. Richardson.

title: London Times Warns Congress on Angola
description: LONDON, Monday, Dec. 22 (Reuters)The Times of London said in an editorial this morning that Angola was not Vietnam and that the credibility of the United States as a world power was at stake in the civil war in that African nation.

title: 8 HOUSING PROJECTS MAY BE HALTED
description: Roger Starr, the city's Housing and Development Administrator, is expected to recommend today a halt in work on eight publicly financed housing projects as a result of the Legislature's failure to pass a bill allowing the city to seek private investments to finish the projects.

title: Ford May Back Continued Free Atom Weapons for Pentagon From Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The military services would continue to obtain billions of dollars' worth of atomic weapons free of charge from a civilian agency under a proposal to be submitted soon to President Ford.

title: For One Island French Legacy Is Riches
description: SAINTDENIS, Runion IslandEight thousand miles from Paris, in the Indian Ocean off Madagascar, lie two island possessions of France that illustrate the arbitrariness of colonialism.

title: Sweden Victor In Davis Cup
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 21 (AP) Bjorn Borg scored one of his greatest victories today in leading Sweden to a 32 triumph over Czechoslovakia in the 1975 Davis Cup final series and to its first victory in the world's most prestigious team tennis competition.

title: FORD POLICY HELD PERIL TO UPTURN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  A Congressional staff study warned today that budget and tax policies of the sort President Ford is advocating would cause the economic recovery to sputter out by 1977, leaving the unemployment rate at 7.5 percent.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown refleets prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) on bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Not So Close as All That
description: There was something like half a minute remaining in the 15th round of a fight that had been as rough as it was onesided. Roberto Duran, the handsome little savage who is lightweight champion of the world wherever Ishimatsu Suzuki isn't, had needed three or four rounds to solve the style of Leoncio Ortiz, his lefthanded challenger from Mexico. With that accomplished, Roberto had set out in search of the chin he felt sure must be concealed somewhere behind the hedge of black whiskers confronting him. He had found the chin and struck it, not once but many times, and he must have been disconcerted to find Ortiz still on his feet. Since Duran pounded Ken Buchanan loose from the title 3 years ago, the only challenger who had lasted into the 14th round was Ray Lampkin, and Raymond had gone home to Portland, Ore., in a wheelchair after five days in the hospital.

title: Indian Missile Tested
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) India has successfully tested an Indianmade surfacetosurface missile, the commander of the navy, Adm. Sourendra Nath Kohli, said today, according to an Indian broadcast monitored in London. The radio said Admiral Kohli had explained that the Indian Navy was trying to develop its own defense system to counter any threat from sophisticated submarines.

title: White House Study of Cable TV Is Pressed Despite Network Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Despite intense opposition led by the three television networks, the Ford Administration is continuing to consider changes in the communications law that could lead to funds. mental shifts in the multibillion dollar American television industry.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMIrving. Devoted husband of Celia, loving father of Doris Eliman and Annette Yonis. Cherished grandfather. Dear brother of Simon and Bernard. Services, Monday, 1 P.M., at The Riverside, Bronx, 179 St. and Grand Concourse.

title: Advertising
description: Until last Thursday, when the Federal Trade Commission acted against Listerine advertising, there was a question as to whether the commissioners believed that they had the authority to order corrective advertising.

title: U.S. Tightening Up Cooperation of Its Air and Ground Forces in West Germany
description: SEMBACH, West Germany, Dec. 16The old halfhostile rivalry between the fly boys of the Air Force and the Army's grunts is giving way in West Germany to an intimate cooperation that starts in the cockpit and the foxhole.

title: Microdot Sounds Alarm On TakeOver Attempts
description: GREENWICH, Conn.To American Business, began a recent newspaper ad in big, black type, Are You Next?

title: 20,000 ATTEND FAIR HELD TO AID WBAI
description: About 20,000 people attended a fourday holiday crafts fair at Columbia University in search of gifts including handmade instruments, meditation benches and blownglass chess sets.

title: College, School Results BASKETBALL.
description: Colleges

title: Robards and a Long Career's Journey
description: Nineteen years ago Jason Robards created the role of Jamie Tyrone, the roistering older brother in Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey Into Night. In 1973, he played Jamie again in A Moon for the Misbegotten when the character is at a later age. The two faces of Jamie (along with his performances in The Iceman Cometh and Hughie) consolidated the actor's reputation as the foremost interpreter of O'Neill. Of all the roles he has played in his career, Jamie is the one with which he is mostly clearly identified.

title: Angolan Thanks Soviet And Cuba for War Aid
description: HAVANA, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola has thanked the Soviet Union and Cuba for their concrete acts of assistance in the war for control of the newly independent country.

title: Mediator Seeks to Arrange Metropolitan Dispute Talks
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board said yesterday he would try to set up a mediation session for tomorrow between the Metropolitan Opera Company and its musicians, who have threatened to strike on Jan. 1.

title: Iceland Volcano Erupting
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 21 (UPI)  The Leirhnukur volcano in northern Iceland continued to erupt, today and geologists expressed concern about the increase of small earthquakes in the area, which could signal major volcanic activity. The eruption started yesterday.

title: Buying a Piano? Take Your Ears Along And If It's a Used One, Take Advice
description: When Harvey Feuerstein and his 6yearold son, Eric, arrived at the door of their East Side apartment at 6 o'clock on the night of Friday, Dec. 12, several things happened.

title: Commodities Study Set
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)  The Commodities Futures Trading Commission will investigate whether speculators with inside information profited from last summer's embargo on grain sales to Poland, Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, announced today.

title: As in Past, Pupils Give To Neediest
description: Schoolchildren who long have been devoted supporters of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are once more in the vanguard of donors to the 64th annual appeal.

title: 32 Students From 23 Schools Awarded Rhodes Scholarships
description: The names of 32 students from 23 American academic institutions, chosen over the weekend as Rhodes Scholars, were announced yesterday by William J. Barber, the United States secretary of the Rhodes Scholarship Trust.

title: Bridge
description: The first two days of play in the winter regional championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association Friday and Saturday at the New York Hilton hotel proved to he a feminine triumph. Sandy Trent and Estee Griffin, two experienced New York players, won the life master pair title and the open pair championship was then taken by Ethel Silver of Beverly, N.J., and Emily Economidas of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Law Student Weds Jennifer Rosenberg
description: In Temple Israel. Waterbury, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Jennifer Charel Rosenberg, daughter of Mrs. Harold A. Rosenberg of Waterbury and the late Dr. Rosenberg, became the bride of Mark B. LoPatin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence LoPatin of Southfield, Mich.

title: Milwaukee Blaze Controlled
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (AP)A fire that sent clouds of smoke billowing through Milwaukee's downtown area during the Christmas shopping rush yesterday was under control early today, but fire fighters remained on the scene. The cause of the blaze had not been determined.

title: Trucking Change Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) The Administration's propdsal to deregulate the trucking industry will risk destruction of America's freigth transportation system, the president of the American Trucking Associations said today! William A. Bresnahan said the cost of new, federally required equipment, difficult labor negotiations and economic uncertainty make 1976 truly critical for the trucking industry.

title: Right to Strike Is at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)  The question of whether the police and firemen should be allowed to strike is standing in the way of a Congressional move to grant state and local government employees the right to bargain collectively, Jerry Wurf, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said today, in an interview published in U. S. News & World Report.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries

title: Charley Johnson, Floyd Little Retire
description: MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP)Charley Johnson, the Denver Broncos quarterback, announced his retirement from the National Football League yesterday, ending a playing career of 15 seasons. Denver's star running back, Floyd Little, also retired yesterday.

title: Leading Fives Prove Class in Home Tourneys
description: The factors behind college basketball tournaments are many. Some coaches, with the hard sell of a travel agent, offer a trip to the Rainbow Classic in Hawaii or a chance to play at Madison Garden as recruiting inducements. Some colleges sponsor tournaments to fatten earlyseason records, and provide chances to play two extra home games and add to athletic treasuries.

title: New York Seeks to Ban Wallace's FundRaiser
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Richard A. Viguerie, the professional fundraiser who has collected over $5 million for Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace in the last two and onehalf years and has kept nearly half of that income for mailing expenses and profit, is in trouble in New York. Louis J. Lefkowitz, the state's Attorney General, is trying to ban Mr. Viguerie's Washingtonbased company from all campaign solicitations in New York. In its work for various charitable organizations, Mr. Lefkowitz has charged, the Richard A. Viguerie Company receives grossly excessive fundraising commissions and fees, to wit, as much as 75 percent of the monies raised. The Viguerie clients net so little, Mr. Lefkowitz alleged in a suit announced last month that their contracts with the fundraiser are unconscionable and a fraud upon the contributing public.

title: Criminal Construction
description: Now that Manhattan's chief construction inspector has been found guilty of taking unlawful gratuities, and 131 other cases of bribers and bribees are moving toward trial as a result of last year's highly publicized scandals, the question is how to change a city building process that virtually guarantees corrupt construction practices. The clear need is not only for punitive action but also for basic reform.

title: Personal Finance: Paying Taxes Early Isn't Simple
description: Many owners of one and twofamily homes in New York City have mortgages that are being liquidated through monthly payments. In most of these cases, the payments include not only amortization of principal and interest but also insurance premiums and real estate taxes.

title: Senate Considering Plan to Aid Continuing Education for Adults
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Senate is considering a bill that would earmark Federal Mbney to increase the opportunity of Americans to receive academic and jobrelated training throughout their lives.

title: Report on Attica Inquiry Cites Errors in Judgment
description: A special state investigator has concluded that serious errors in judgment were made in the investigation of the bloody 1971 Attica prison riot, and following a recommendation in his report, a new special prosecutor was named yesterday to determine if indictments should be sought against law enforcement officers who took part in the retaking of the prison.

title: Andrea Uffner Bride Of Alan Leigh Davis
description: Andrea Uffner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Uffner of Lawrence, L.I., was married at noon yesterday to Alan Leigh Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Davis of Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: As in Past, Pupils Give To Neediest
description: Schoolchildren who long have been devoted supporters of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are once more in the vanguard of donors to the 64th annual appeal.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Stram and Saints Confer on Job
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (UPI)Hank Stram, the former Kansas City Chiefs coach, said today he had talked with New Orleans officials but had no comment on rumors he signed a multiyear contract with the Saints.

title: Rep. Landrum Is Retiring
description: JASPER, Ga., Dec. 21 (AP)Representative Phil M. Landrum, a Georgia Democrat who has served 23 years in Congress, has announced that he will not run for reelection when his current term ends next year. I have decided that I will not be a candidate for Representative in the 95th Congress, Mr. Landrum, 66 years old, said last night from his home in Jasper.

title: Byrne Will Resubmit Request on PATH Funds
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 21 (UPI) Governor Byrne has decided to resubmit an application for Federal funds to finance extension of the PATH commuter line even though the Government just rejected the request. Officials said yesterday that Mr. Byrne also would ask for money to electrify two other lines.

title: Jonnet Steinbaum Bride of Peter Abeles
description: Jonnet Steinbaum, an associate producer of documentaries for CBS News, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Lee Abeles, president of Abeles Schwartz and Associates, planning and housing con??ltants here.

title: Madagascar Leader Gains Most of Vote in Referendum
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar Dec. 21 (Agence FrancePresse) First results in today's referendum on Madagascar indicated that support for the head of state, Lieut Comdr. Didier Ratsiraka, would exceed 90 percent of the vote.

title: Sale of Great Adventure Completed by Hardwicke
description: Hardwicke Companies Inc. announced over the weekend completion of plans disclosed last May for the sale of its Great Adventure division to a trust established for the Pritzker family of Chicago. The sale price was $37,375,000.

title: $1.5 Million Stolen L.l. Antiques And Art Found, Teacher Seized
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 21  A 50yearold Nassau County teacher was arrested here today on charges of breaking into estates in this fashionable resort area. The local police said they had recovered antiques and art works worth more than $1.5 million in the suspect's home in neighboring Sac Harbor.

title: Colts Win and Reach Playoffs
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 21The imprimatur of a good football team is the ability to come from behind in the final period of an essential same and win.

title: Scientist Warns of Great Floods if Earth's Heat Rises
description: What the world's weather will be like in the next decade, century or millennium is a subject that has provoked many theories and debates.

title: Findings From Report on Prosecution of Attica Rebellion Cases
description: Following are the findings from Bernard S. Meyer's report on the Attica rebellion:

title: NEW TAXES TO CUT BANK PROFIT HERE
description: New York City, long the nation's financial capital, will become a significantly less profitable place for banking as a result of the new tax measures imposed as part of the city and state fiscal rescue operations.

title: Vietnamese Get Sunny Welcome On a Frigid Day on Long Island
description: CUTCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 21 On his first day on Long Island today, Huynh van Hue witnessed the baptizing of his firstborn child, saw snow for the first time, was introduced to kosher hot dogs and lighted Christmas trees, was shown his first potato fieldsand was assured of his first real home since he fled South Vietnam earlier this year.

title: British Bankruptcies Rise
description: LONDON. Dec. 21 (AP)Last week was one of the worst for insolvencies in the history of British business, with 358 companies going into voluntary liquidations or courtordered bankruptcies, the Insolvency Practitioners' Association, said today. The association said the normal weekly figure was 150.

title: Island Trust
description: In debating the bill to protect Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard against reckless overdevelopment, Senator Clifford P. Hansen, Wyoming Republican, an opponent of the measure, observed: This bill creates and funds a totally new and different concept in the recreation area under the Federal wing. The Island Trust is not a national park, it is not a national monument, it is not a national recreation area and yet it involves the Federal Government in the preservation, use and management of lands which are essentially a state's responsibility.

title: Dinah Is There Anyone Finah on the Stoves of California?
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.Chare is a fish soup indigenous to California that is as much a part of American culture as Boston clam chowder in the East or oyster gumbo in the South. At its hestand the best we've ever sampled was in Dinah Shore's kitchencioppino is delectable. The origins of the soup, its name and various components are something of enigma, for no one can guess the date of its entrance into the native culture.

title: William Lundigan,Actor,Dead; Made 125 Films Over 38 Years
description: William Lundigan, who appeared in more than 125 films during his 38year career in Hollywood, died yesterday after a long illness in the City of Hope Medical Center in Duarte, a suburb of Los Angeles. He was 61 years old and lived in West Los Angeles.

title: Hunter Beats Baruch
description: Guy Hunter and Bert Lindsay combined for 40 of Hunter college's points and led the Hawks to a 5652 basketball victory over Baruch yesterday at the 69th Regiment Armory. The victory evened Hunter's wonlost record at 44. Baruch also is 44.

title: Ford Appears Bent on Making Angola Test of Will With Congress and Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Despite the sharp rebuke to its Angola policy voted by the Senate, the Ford Administration seems determined to press ahead and make Angola a test of wills, not only with the Congress but also with the Soviet Union. It is in the view of several State Department officials, a course that can add to strains with Congress and lead to a new chill in SovietAmerican relations, even jeopardizing the talks on limiting strategic arms.

title: TERRORISTS RAID OPEC OIL PARLEY IN VIENNA, KILL 3
description: VIENNA, Monday, Dec. 22Six terrorists, their weapons concealed in sportsequipment bags, burst into a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries here yesterday, shot three persons to death with submachine guns and held at least 60 people hostage.

title: Vietnamese Return Remains of 3 Pilots Killed in the War
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 21 (AP)The remains of three American pilots killed in the Vietnam war were flown from Hanoi to Bangkok today. There were indications that the remains of other Americans might soon be released by North Vietnam.

title: Giants Beat 49ers, End At 59 Mark
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21  In an errorfilled game, played in heavy rain in the second half, the New York Giants fought off the San Francisco 49ers, 2623, today and recorded a second consecutive victory for the first time in three seasons.

title: 6 Die in Philadelphia Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (UPISix persons were killed today in a fire that swept their North Philadelphia home. Fire Bureau officials identified the dead as Charlene Sessoms, 17 years old, and her children. Chawayne, 2, Windel, 18 months, and Carol, 7 months. The other victims, identified as brothers of Mrs. Sessoms, were William Sessoms, 33, and Randy Sessoms, 15.

title: Kuwait Spends Lavishly Despite Worries
description: AHMADI, Kuwait  Illegal immigrants, braving Persian Gulf sharks, swim to these oilrich shores. Oil workers are hoping for bonuses. Officials talk of building scores of new mosquesand an Arab Disneyland.

title: List of 11 Petroleum Ministers Among the Hostages
description: VIENNA, Dec. 21 (AP)Following is a list of the 11 delegates to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries who were among those taken hostage by terrorists at the organization's headquarters here yesterday:

title: Wall Street Yields to the Holiday Season
description: On Wall Street, trading volume means a lot. Its impersonal, often manic momentum determines how big the Christmas bonus will be, how quickly the orthodontist gets paid, how many new vice presidents a firm can afford. Its ripple effect even shows up in the street kettles of the Salvation Army. This Christmas, thanks at least in part to a long series of backtoback big volume days, the quintet of Salvation Army cadets pumping the sweet brass of Good Rest Ye, Merry Gentlemen and other old favorites at the corner of Wall and Nassau Streets has been doing very well indeed.

title: OLAF SKOOGFORS, 45, SILVERSMITH, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) Olaf Skoogfors, awardwinning silversmith and jeweler, died of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 45 years old.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW CONTINUING VIGOR
description: The stock market almost every December is supposed to stage a yearend rally, but this year it's the bond market that is rallying strongly. Bond prices last week scored some of their biggest weekly gains of 1975, and most traders now expect no serious setback, soon. The credit markets may quiet down for the holidays and prices may stabilize, but the advance should resume in January, many bond dealers and their customers, too, now believe.

title: Action on PCB's ...
description: In a startling repudiation of its own expert witness, the General Electric Company has in effect accepted the contention of New York State officials that the company's discharge of toxic chemicals has been heavy enough to poison the fish of the Hudson River. The volume of PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls) that it has been allowing to wash into the river has affected fish in far greater measure than the United States Food and Drug Administration has up to now regarded as tolerable for human health.

title: Against Mandatory Minimum Sentences
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  There are fashions in everything and today's fashion in criminal justice is the mandatory minimum sentence. President Ford is for it and so is Senator Edward M. Kennedy. Each has proposed his own form of Federal legislation to set minimum prison sentences that judges must impose for serious crimes.

title: U.S., Mexico Tied, 22: Connors Match Halted
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21It may well be all over, but with Jimmy Connors, anything is possible.

title: U.S. Banks Regain Rate Advantage
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Many American hanks, ineluding those based in New York City, are again getting interest rate advantages of up to threesixteenths of a percentage point over other banks in international capital markets, European bankers say.

title: Cavaliers Win 7th In a Row
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 (AP)  Clutch points by Bobby Smth and Austin Carr lifted the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 9998 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers in a National Basketball Association game today.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: The Need To Control
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21When the Vietnam war came to its inevitable end last spring, Henry Kissinger said that Congress's refusal to try to drag it on proved America's unreliability as an ally. Now President Ford is doing the same on Angola. The Senate vote to stop covert intervention there, he said, is a deep tragedy for all countries whose security depends on the United States.

title: Prisoners Rout Guards In Game to Help Ill Boy
description: REIDSVILLE, Ga., Dec. 21 Inmates at the Georgia State Prison here manhandled, overpowered and slightly embarrassed state troopers and guards over the weekendbut all for a good cause.

title: Nuptials for Terri Edersheim And Thomas Spencer Shattan
description: Terri Gallen Edersheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurits Ernst Edersheim of New York and Scarsdale, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Spencer Shattan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Boaz Merritt Shattan of New York and Rye, N. Y.

title: GOVERNOR'S SLAYING STIRS LEBANON FEAR
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 (UPI)Moslem and Christian gunmen clashed today at Zahle, 25 miles east of Beirut, while scattered fighting erupted around the capital. In North Lebanon it was feared that an assassination might spark renewed allout civil war.

title: Fairfield Trounces Seton Hall by 9173
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 21 (AP)Danny Odums, Joe DeSantis and Steve Balkun each scored 20 or more points in leading Fairfield University to a 9173 basketball victory over Seton Hall today.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Christmas and giving are natural companions, but when it comes to charities, the giving should be done with caution.

title: Report on Attica Inquiry Cites Errors in Judgment
description: A special state investigator has concluded that serious errors in judgment were made in the investigation of the bloody 1971 Attica prison riot, and following a recommendation in his report, a new special, prosecutor was named yesterday to determine if indictments should be sought against law enforcement officers who took part in the retaking of the prison.

title: HUMPHREY OUTPACED BY FORD AND REAGAN
description: President Ford and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California both lead Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Pope Calls for Charity
description: ROME, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Pope Paul VI today called for a true spirit of good will to prevail this Christmas and for Christians to show special charity toward the poor, the unemployed and the suffering.

title: JEAN BERTIN IS DEAD; INVENTED AEROTRAIN
description: PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP)Jean Bertin, a worldfamous aviation engineer who most recently developed the aerotrain, died in Paris last night of an unspecified illness, his family reported. He was 58 years old. Mr. Bertin founded in 1956 an engineering firm that obtained 3,000 patents in 20 years. They included the development of an antifog device for airport runways, a silencing system for airplane engines and several hovercraft systems.

title: BOYD M'NAUGHTON
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 21 (UPI)Boyd McNaughton, chairman since 1971 of the California & Hawaiian Sugar Company, died of cancer yesterday at a hospital here. He was 67 years old.

title: Blaze in a Sex Library Is a Puzzler in Midtown
description: The manager of a building at 35 West 43d Street, next to a firehouse, was surprised enough when he found out last year that the occupant, listed on his lease as the New Research Library, was actually a massage parlor. But when the 100yearold building burned early last Tuesday morning in a twoalarm blaze, he said he was shocked.

title: U.S. and Mexico Tied in Davis Cup; Colts and Bengals Make Playoffs
description: Darkness postponed the deciding match of the 1976 North American Zone Davis Cup semifinals yesterday between Mexico and the United States. Raul Ramirez of Mexico was ahead of Jimmy Connors, two sets to one, with Connors leading, 32, in the fourth set, The match resumes today in Mexico City.

title: A Plan to Have Leone Elected Director Of Port Agency Is Reportedly Deferred
description: A plan to name Richard C. Leone, New Jersey State Treasurer, to the top executive post of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey appears to have been deferred.

title: A LIGHT SNOWFALL ICES ROADS HERE
description: A cold spell, blustery winds andW, somewhat erratic snowfall combined yesterday to turn the streets and highways or the metropolitan area into a huge safety hazard, and drivers were advised to expect equally treacherous road condiatom today.

title: Jailed Critic of Tito Is Reported on Hunger Strike
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21Mihajlo Mihajlov, a Yugoslav writer serving a sevenyear prison sentence for criticizing the Tito Government, began a hunger strike two weeks ago and is very weak, hiS friends reported today.

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21Sagged in a chair, his skates propped on an equipment hag, Denis Potvin reflected sadly about the New York Islanders' 52 loss tonight to the Chicago Black Hawks. Chicago scored all five goals in the final period, two each for John Marks and Darcy Rota and one by Pit Martin into an empty net.

description: EGGPLANT SPAGHETTI SAUCE

title: Profit vs. the Land In Upper Michigan
description: MARQUETTE. Mich. Things are not the same these days at Frenchtnan's Pond here in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan  this wild, exotic wedge of America that stretches for 320 miles across the nation's roof; this vast, isolated, largely unspotted land, the land of Longfellow's Hiawatha and Hemingway's Big TwoHearted River.

title: Cowboys Subdue Jets, 31 to 21
description: Pelted by swirling snow, and the derisive cackling of a few thousand fans who remained to boo, the Jets ended their most dismal season yesterday in a dismal setting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Dec. 11 editorial on the State of the State misses the judgmental mark by such a wide margin that equity demands a modest response from the Republican leadership, which is singled out for a performance you view as less than satisfactory.

description: One feels sorry for those who missed Takako Asakawa's first performance this season in the title role of Martha Graham's Clytemnestra on Saturday night at the Mark Hellinger Theater. It was a spellbinding evening of artistry.

title: Quadruplex 57th St. Penthouse or Pie in the Sky?
description: Piled high under a Christmas tree that sparkles with tiny yellow lights in the airy lobby of 57th Street's ultimate new residence, the Galleria, are bright and shiny presents that are, no doubt, quite empty.

title: Kenny Burrell and Sylvia Syms Lead Jazz Benefit at Town Hall
description: As Christmas parties go, it would be difficult to improve on the one staged at Town Halle on Saturday evening as a benefit for Hale House and the North Side Center for Child Development. With a Christmas tree glowing rosily at one side of the stage, an array of jazz musicians, singers and dancers created a musical Christmas pudding whose plums included Duke Ellington, Fats Waller, contemporary Christmas songs and a historical survey of Harlem dancing.

title: Bengals Get Spot With 4717 Bang
description: No contest. Before the San Diego Chargers could run off a play from scrimmage, the Cincinnati Bengals struck for three touchdowns yesterday, paving the way to an easy 4717 victory which gave them the American Football Conference wildcard berth in next weekend's opening round of the playoffs.

description: AT NEW ORLEANS SCORE BY PERIODS

title: Food Gifts to Tranquilize Panicky Procrastinators
description: In case you need to be reminded of them facts, there are, counting today, just three more shopping days to Christmas, but before succumbing to that annual panic, take heart. There are still a number of wonderful food gifts in good supply to fit a variety of tastes and pocketbooks. And in a year when value and practicality are much in order, what could be more suitable than something good to eat?

title: Carey's Fiscal Crisis: Large Campaign Debt
description: Governor Carey's confrontation with fiscal crises in the city and state have been highly visible, but considerably less visible has been his confrontationor lack of itwith a personal fiscal crisis growing out of his gubernatorial campaign last year.

title: ... in UNESCO, Too
description: The latest perversion of the nonpolitical mandate of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is the emendation of a document on world communications to include the General Assembly's resolution branding Zionism a form of racism.

title: Police Protection Is Negligible At Site of OPEC Headquarters
description: Three years ago, officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries considered moving their headquarters from Vienna to Rome or Madrid. When one official was asked if Beirut was not the logical center for the organization, he laughed.

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21The United States Postal Service, engulfed in the usual flood of Christmas mail while it struggles to maintain services and fight off increasing competition from private carriers, is facing an increased deficit in the coming year.

description: SIMONSTOWN, South Africa, Dec. 18Behind the mountains that envelop this small naval base on the southern tip of the Cape of Good Hope is a fourstory subterranean bunker fortified with concrete to withstand a small nuclear explosion.

title: Rebel Argentine Airmen Urged to Accept Accord,
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21The vicar general of the Arigentine armed forces was seeking today to work out a peace agreement between air force rebels and the air force commander to end a revolt against the Government of President Isabel Martinez de Pern.

description: Two officers of a commodity options firmDouglas Collins of Perlin, N.J., and Dennis Turner of Brooklyn  have pleaded guilty to grand larceny in the second degree and will be sentenced on Feb. 25, according to New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. The guilty plea was made before Justice Burton Roberts of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Dr. McLarnon Is Bride of Lawyer
description: Dr. Mary Frances McLarnon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis McLarnon of Toronto, was married yesterday afternoon to Malcolm Hewitt Wiener of New York, son of Myron Wiener of Bethesda, Md., and the late Ethel Zimmerman Wiener.

title: WORKS BY WODYNSKI DANCED AT CUBICULO
description: The dances of Jan Wodynski are smooth understated ripples in a clear stream of movement that charm through their quiet accomplishment. Her company's programs at the Cubiculo over the weekend were a combination of repertory and new works that showed her subtle and considerable gifts.

title: WINE TALK
description: Some weeks ago this space was devoted to a discussion of red wines. All were picked up on a trip to local liquor stores, all were priced at under $4; and there were actually some very interesting wines among them.

title: Herstand Is Pressured to Quit At San Francisco Art Institute
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21In the 18 months since Arnold Herstand took over as president of the influential San Francisco Art Institute, his philosophy and style have alienated just about everyone at the school.

description: Film

description: HAVANA, Dec. 21 (Reuters) The first congress of the Cuban Communist Party today passed the guidelines of the island's first fiveyear plan. which features a drive toward greater industrialization and a steady. increase in sugar production.

description: MOUNT CARMEL, Conn.It bothers me that the Bicentennial is focused on battles, costumes and candlesticks of the 1770's. Pageantry is great, but a nation that has come of age should not spend all its attention on its baby pictures. After all, it's what came after that shaped it.
