title: U.S. and Mexico Tied in Davis Cup; Colts and Bengals Make Playoffs
description: Darkness postponed the deciding match of the 1976 North American Zone Davis Cup semifinals yesterday between Mexico and the United States. Raul Ramirez of Mexico was ahead of Jimmy Connors, two sets to one, with Connors leading, 32, in the fourth set. The match resumes today.

title: ACTION ON SLUMP IS URGED IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21The inability of the Japanese economy to snap out of its protracted recession is causing increased concern in the business community here. L??st week a top delegation of Japanese business leaders urged the governing party to take vigorous action to lift the economy out of its rut.

title: A Shift in Fiscal Crises
description: ALBANY, Dec. 20Surfeited with crises, the State Legislature has finally closed out a long, harrowing year here with a series of extraordinary actions that in one three ?? month stretch raised or created city and state taxes and curtailed New York City's selfgovernment in saving it from default, but that still left the state in the city's former position of monthtomonth battles with fiscal disaster.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (AP)Peter Mueller of Mequon, Wis., won his fourth men's event in the trials for the United States Olympic speedskating team when he scored a victory in a 500meter race today.

title: Restoring Perspective . . .
description: An almost morbid zeal in finding ever new pretexts to condemn Israel is making a total sham of longrespected institutions for international cooperation.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1975

title: 4 Policemen Seized as Thieves Who Looted on Job in Middlesex
description: Four members of the New Brunswick Police Department have been arrested and several more are under investigation as part of a ring of police officers that allegedly broke into and looted department stores and other establishments in Middlesex County.

title: 'Distance,' Sensitive Film Story of a Black
description: Sometimes "Distance" is awkward and sometimes it is misconceived, but it had a central virtue lacking in a number of more elaborate andto use a horrible wordcinematic films around.It wants to be made. It believes in itself, in its story, in its characters; and that belief pulls viewers into it. Sometimes they are pulled too hard, or in a certain embarrassment because the sequence is obvious or excessive or telegraphed in advance.But self-belief is an arousing quality, especially at a time when an extreme of baroque weariness gives movies such as "Three Days of the Condor" or Sam Peckinpah's "Killer Elite" the hopeless feeling that they are meant for an empty theater."Distance," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, is set in a Georgia Army post in the mid-1950's. Its protagonist is Sergeant Horne, a black man whose natural force and ability have gone into building himself a shelter against the humiliations of being a Southern black of his time.The Army gives Horne a place where his energy and intelligence can be channeled and protected. Not fulfilled, though: here the haven becomes the prison. He is too good for his job, too much a perfectionist, and he is held to the company of men to whom he knows he is superior. One of the film's many inspired touches is a scene where Horne drinks beer with his fellow-sergeants  easygoing, cynical white men. They drink from cans; he drinks from a glass.The rigidity that is Horne's protection makes him a firstrate master sergeant, but it has made a torment of his private life. He has brought over a German wife, played gracefully and touchingly by Eija Pokkinen. He loves her or has loved herthe failure of the film quite to define their relationship is a weaknessbut he has gradually closed himself to her.Her blond beauty, her gentleness and devotion are a lure and a goad. He needs to hurt her and be hurt by her. He burns like Othello, his fixation on his wife encompassing everything except the ability to see her as she is. He is his own lago; he devises his own jealousies. There is no Cassio except for a young white recruit who has the most casual brush with Mrs. Horne. The ending is tragic, predictably, and almost predictable.In fact, the tragic main plot is too pat and stagy, but it does have a use. It provides a gravely moving current that allows the film's real jewelsits freshness, its lovely characterizations, its splendid actingto be set in something other than their own self-consciousness.Perhaps the best part of the film is the subplot. The white recruit, a bright, languid young man played by James Woods, has an affair with a woman who sleeps with base commanders in order to be allowed to sell insurance to the troops.It is a splendid affair, in which both the recruit and the woman harden and soften, touch and withdraw. The young man's self-sufficiency is almost pierced, and the woman's defenses almost give way to hope. The acting of James Wood is admirable, but Bibi Besch, as the woman, gives the top performance in the picture and somewhere up among the best of the year.As Sergeant Horne, Paul Benjamin provides force and passion, and some beauty. Less subtlety; but it is not Othello's function to be subtle.This is the first full-length feature by Anthony Lover and George Coe. Their initial effort was a short, "The Dove," a charming and terribly funny takeoff on Ingmar Bergman, which is being shown along with "Distance."There is no point describing it, other than to say that it's as if Bergman's symbols were holding a drunken cast party. The dove becomes a pigeon, prodigious at doing what pigeons are most noted for. Death plays badminton instead of chess. And so on.

title: FORD POLICY HELD PERIL TO UPTURN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  A Congressional staff study warned today that budget and tax policies of the sort President Ford is advocating would cause the economic recovery to sputter out by 1977, leavling the unemployment rate at 7.5 percent.

title: About New York
description: The police blotter rarely has time to dry and New York never quite achieves a saintly Christmas quiet despite its polluted halo. But this is as pertinent a time as any to report a few items that do not end in tears or indictment.

title: Atlantic City Battles to Regain Its Status As Big Tourist and Convention Magnet
description: ??ANTIC CITY, Dec. 11 ?? the recent sentencing of the last of 24 policemen and five inspectors convicted on bribery and other charges, Atlantic City, for the time being, may have resolved its longtime problem of corruption, but this fading resort city now faces the equally pervasive problem of corrosion.

title: Critic of Attica Inquiry
description: Bernard S. Meyer, the special state investigator of the Attica prosecution, describes himself as an analytical person, whose basic legal Philosophy is that it is as important that people know that justice has been done as that it be done. The 571page, threevolume report that he submitted to Governor Carey, the first part of which was released yesterday, seems to bear out this approach to lawthat people have the right to know the basis on which a decision has been reached.

title: Truck for Washington Post Is Destroyed by Plames
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 A delivery truck of the Washington Post was destroyed by fire early today under circumstances that the Fire Department authorities described as suspected arson.

title: N.F.L. Playoffs
description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: Television
description: Morning

title: In Memoriam
description: PIOLIAnna Marie. December 22, 1965. Hanny tenth anniversary in heaven. Always in our thoughts, Masses offered.

title: Sabres Hit 14 Goals, 8 In 3d Period
description: BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 21 (UPI)The Buffalo Sabres exploded out of a scoring slump with a 142 rout of the Washington Capitals in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: NAZI DEPORTATION AUTHORIZED IN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A bill authorizing the Government to deport or exclude aliens proved to have engaged in Nazi war crimes has been introduced by Representative Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: MECHANICS RATIFY UNITED CONTRACT
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP)Striking United Airlines mechanics overwhemingly ratified a new contract today, ending their twoweek strike and clearing the way for the nation's largest domestic air carrier to resume full service, a union spokesman said.

title: Rangers Triumph, 20
description: A pair of cellardwelling hockey teams came up with a new brand of sedative last night at Madison Square Garden. Despite two goals that gave the Rangers a 20 victory over Minnesota, the New Yorkers and the North Stars played a dull, listless game that produced more yawns than shots.

title: Slip at Critical Moment Perils Officer in Queens
description: Interrupting a holdup at a social club at 8530 Roosevelt Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, at 5:30 A.M. yesterday, Police Officer William Wilkey suddenly found himself face to face with a gunman in a dark backyard.

title: John Warner, 82, ExOfficer Of Automotive Engineers
description: John A. C. Warner, retired secretary and general manager of the Society of Automotive Engineers, died yesterday in Germantown Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 82 years old and lived at Foulkways, a retirement home in Gwynedd, Pa.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Forty people, most of them women, were robbed by five armed men wearing ski masks in a social club in a secondfloor loft at 147 West 24th Street. The robbers, carrying three shotguns and two pistols, forced the patrons to put their money and jewelry in the center of the floor. They fled with $2.000 in cash and $5,000 worth of jewelry. One of the men with a shotgun threatened to kill Diane Guadie, 28 years old, a coowner of the club, and another fired a shotgun blast into the wall.

title: Carey Mourns Granddaughter's Death
description: Governor Carey visited his daughter and soninlaw in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, sharing their grief over the death of their 6weekold daughter.

title: Rebel Argentine Airmen Declare They Won't Yield
description: BUENOS AIRES, Monday, Dec. 22Rebel air force officers demanding the overthrow of President Isabel Martinez de Pern held out early today at an isolated air base against attempts to obtain their surrender.

title: Miss Brown Married To William M. Pollak
description: Georgia Lea Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Brown of Pocasset, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to William Maurice Pollak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pollak of White Plains.

title: Nuggets 122, Pacers 117
description: DENVER, Dec 21 (UPI)A stuff shot by Dan Issel with 8 seconds left, assured a 122117 victory for the leagueleading Denver Nuggets over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: Murder Most Foul
description: WASHINGTONThe revelation that the President of the United States had regular access to a woman who may have been controlled by two Mafia gangsters hired by the to kill Fidel Castro has had the expected reaction: prurient interest, compounded daily, in the logistics of White House sex whether Jackie knew, etc.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Yugoslavia's Leaders Are Stepping Up Campaign Against Religious Activity
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21Organized religion has been branded by Yugoslav Communist leaders as a dangerous domestic enemy, and strict new laws governing church activity are expected to come into force before the end of the year.

title: Snow Cancels Racing
description: Snow forced cancellation of horse racing at two New England race tracks yesterday and todayNarragansett Park in Pawtucket, R.I., and Suffolk Downs in Boston. Racing is scheduled to resume at both tracks Friday.

title: EDUCATION SYSTEM DEBATED IN CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 21A major new campaign to preserve the radical education system devised during China's Cultural Revolution has revealed what appear to be continued doubts among the nation's educators about its effectiveness.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Karen Anne Quinlan's family priest has denounced. state investigation into whether an assault might have sent her into a coma nine months ago. The priest, the Rev. Thomas Trapasso, testified in behalf of the woman's parents last month in their unsuccessful court plea for authority to disconnect her respirator so she can die with dignity.

title: Hinterseer Scores in Slalom
description: SCHLADMING, Austria. Dec. 21 (AP)Hans Hinterseer of Austria won a slalom race today with an aggregate time of 1 minute 45.32 seconds and Ingemar Stenmark, the runnerup, took the overall World Cup lead with 66 points.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CURTAIN UP Backstage, e new restaurantbar at 318 West 45th Street (next to the Martin Beck Theater), has several things going for it, starting with space. There Is plenty of room to move around in, from the large bar and small standup bar into the main drinking and dining area. This section has tables and an entertainment corner dominated by a huge, white wooden encasement of the piano, with stools and an ample rim for glasses and leaning, where Patti Wicks and Peter Howard play and sing, sitting in what amounts to the prow.

title: Merryl Jill Hiat Becomes Bride Of James Tisch
description: Merryl Jill Hiat, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Philip Hiat, spiritual leader of Mount Neboh Congregation, and Mrs. Hiat of New York, was married here last evening to James S. Tisch, son of Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and chief executive officer of the Loews Corporation, and Mrs. Tisch of Rye, N.Y.

title: How Terrorists Entered Unhindered
description: VIENNA, Dec. 21I was the first person the terrorists spoke to today when they strode into the headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here and turned a routine ministerial meeting into a nightmare of gunfire and death.

title: Michael Oremland Weds Rana Gordon
description: Rana Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Gordon of Chicago, was married there yesterday evening to Michael Oremland, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gestave Cremland of Teaneck N.J.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1975

title: Ford's First National Campaign: Incumbent in Role of Underdog
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21President Ford's campaign plan, a key adviser says, is to be the best President he knows how. His central campaign problem, the same counselor adds, may be an impatient public's sense that through 16 months of his accidental term, Mr. Ford has been the best President he knows how.

title: Organist and Trumpeter Give Spirited Program
description: This being, in theory at least, a season of joy and good cheer, it was fitting that Martin Berth.baum and Richard Morris should have brought their Toccatas and Flourishes to Tully Hall on Saturday night.

description: 17:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Symphony No. 1. Brahms; Suite from The Indian Queen, Purcell; Viola Concerto in C, Vanhal.

title: . . . Get on With It
description: The course taken by Commissioner Reid is gratifying, but the problem of PCB's cannot be solved by the actions of any one state. The Hudson may be worse than any other body of water in the country in this respect, but it is far from being the only grave example. Carp taken from the Mississippi have been buried by order the Food and Drug Administration. Excessive amounts of the chemical have also been found in fish in the Ohio River, in the oysters of a Florida bay, in the Great Lakes, the Housatonic and many other American waters. According to Russell E. Train, head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, PCB's are suspected of having contaminated the drinking water of several communities in Illinois, Indiana, California and Massachusetts.

title: Soviet Accuses Canada on Security
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 21The Soviet Ambassador here, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, has charged the Canadian Government with failure to provide proper security for his embassy building and with allowing the Canadian international radio to broadcast antiSoviet material to Eastern Europe.

title: John Lee Pratt Is Dead at 96; Millionaire ExG.M. Official
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Dec. 21 (AP)  John Lee Pratt, who rose from boyhood on a King George County farm to become one of the country's wealthiest men, died yesterday at his Chatham estate home near here. He was 96 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Aladdin's Lamp Found in Bronx Rectory
description: It was just another lampshade to me, I thought it was ugly, said 23yearold Michael Doyle, director of the financially troubled youthful offenders program at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in the South Bronx.

title: Reagan, a Fast Starter, Faces First Test
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22Ronald Reagan has struck with surprising speed in his plan to wrest the leadership of the Republican Party away from an incumbent President.

title: F.T.C. Charges Illegality In Curb on Doctors' Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Federal Trade Commission accused the American Medical Association ' today of illegally interfering with the prices that doctors charge and with keeping patients from getting information about doctors by preventing its members from advertising.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE SOUND OF YOU Tonight's rendition of Handers Messiah at Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall is the one where you come and join in, as 21 guest conductors take turns conducting segments performed by a large stage chorus in this eighth annual event, presented by the National Choral Council. Except for the soprano and bass solo arias connecting the multivoice segments, you can chime in anywhere along the way. Audience singers are encouraged to bring their own Messiah scores or buy them at the door.

title: Joan Little Bond Denied
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 22 (AP) The North Carolina Court of Appeals denied Joan Little's request for a continuance of her bond today pending her appeal of a breaking and entering conviction to the Federal courts. The decision means she will remainn in North Carolina's Correctional Center for Women.

title: President Intends to Veto Construction Picketing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22President Ford announced today that he would veto the construction industry picketing bill, the only piece of labor legislation enacted this year and a bill that the Administration had supported and helped draft.

title: Highest Court in the State Rejects Crimmins Appeal
description: The state's highest court declared yesterday that Alice Crimmins, convicted twice of having slain her 4yearold daughter in 1965, could not press her appeal any further.

title: MERRILL TO TRADE ODD LOIS ITSELF
description: As a followup to the Securities and Exchange Commission's order relaxing stock exchange trading rules, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage house, announced yesterday that it would introduce its new oddlot trading program off the New York Stock Exchange floor beginning Jan. 2.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: Monday, Dec. 22, 1975.

title: MoscowHanoi Pact
description: TOKYO (AP)North Vietnam and the Soviet Union have signed a new fiveyear agreement under which Moscow will give Hanoi economic and technical aid to build industrial enterprises and other projects from 1976 to 1980, the Vietnam News Agency has reported. The agency in a broadcast monitored in Tokyo over the weekend, said the agreement was signed in Moscow.

title: Bellin Scores Health Proposal For Independent Planning Unit
description: Dr. Lowell E. Bellin, the city's Health Commissioner, attacked yesterday a proposal calling for an independent nongovernment organization to plan the city's health care as a consummate ploy that masquerades as consumer representation but in fact sabotages consumer representation.

title: Grant Gets Court Approval To Close 133 More Stores
description: The W. T. Grant Company said yesterday that it had received court approval for its plan to close 133 additional stores. The company, which is in chapter XI reorganization and which once had 1,200 stores, said that the closings would enable it to concentrate its efforts in those market areas where its merchandising activities had proved most successful.

title: Production of Steel Off 1.7% in Week; Uptrend Reversed
description: Steel production fell 1.7 percent to 2.07 million tons last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It rose the previous two weeks.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: FORD SIGNS BILL ON ENERGY THAT ENDS POLICY IMPASSE AND CUTS CRUDE OIL PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22President Ford ended a yearlong stalemate with. Congress over energy policy today by signing into law a bill that will roll back crude oil prices and help stabilize gasoline and fuel oil prices for consumers, at least temporarily.

title: The SubPlot for the SteelersColts
description: Mercifully, the Giants and the Jets have disbanded, the nicest possible Christmas present for their seasonticket subscribers. But frustrated, or fickle, followers of pro football in New York have a rooting interest in three adopted teams in the National Football League playoffs. The Baltimore Colts, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Dallas Cowboys each won two games at Shea Stadium this season. That's as many as the Giants won there, and twice as many as the Jets won there. But the Colts are everybody's adopted team. With a new coach in Ted Marchibroda, a maturing quarterback in Bert Jones and a front four that calls themselves The Looney Tunes, the Colts won nine consecutive games and the American Conference East after having finished in last place a year ago with a 212 wonlost record. Now the Colts must confront the reality of the Pittsburgh Steelers, the reigning Super Bowl champions who appear to he the N.F.L.'s best team despite their 10.3 loss to the Los AngeleS Rams last Saturday night.

title: Friends and a Fund recall the Murdered Girl in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 21We don't talk about the murder anymore, said Libby Straight, a sophomore at Greenwich High School. We talk about Martha and the fun fe had.

title: SUBPOENA POWER FOR HYNES UPHELD
description: The state's highest court yesterday reversed a ruling of the Appellate Division here that had barred Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor, from subpoenaing the records of nursing homes.

title: Argentine Air Force Men End the Uprising Quietly
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22Rightwing air force officers today quietly ended their revolt against President Isabel Martnez de Pern.

title: OLIVER M. EVANS
description: Oliver M. Evans, a rounder and president of the Humane Society of the United States from 1963 to 1967 and a trustee of St. John's Child Development Center, both of Washington, died last Tuesday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: I.M.F. Action Spurs Gold Price Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 (UPI)The price of gold rose sharply today, buoyed by reports of a possible agreement by industrial nations to prevent a major sale from depressing the market. The dollar fell on most European money markets.

title: W.O. DILLINGHAM, LED HOFFMAN BEVERAGE
description: William O. Dillingham, former president of the Hoffman Beverage Company and executive vice president for sales of its parent company, the Pabst Brewing Company, died Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Refitting
description: Although the occasional clear December days, when she wind is gentle from the South and the temperature ??ar above freezing, tempt the Northeast angler to try once more for striped bass or cod or some denizen of ?? notyet frozen lake or ??ond, the time has come to ??ut away your fishing gear ??or another year.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Block Election Subsidy Pending Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Supreme Court refused tonight to block payments of political subsidies under the new Federal campaign financing law while it deliberates on whether the law is constitutional.

title: Connors Falls, U.S. Is Ousted
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22For the second time this year, Raul Ramirez has beaten the United States Davis Cup team.

title: Texas Car Crash Kills 7
description: WHITEWRIGHT, Tex., Dec. 22 (UPI)A car ran off Texas Highway 160 yesterday and crashed into an embankment, killing all seven persons aboard. The Department of Public Safety said all of the victims were from Sherman in north Texas. The victims were identified as Fred McKinney, 59 years old; Jean McHanney, 27; Harry McHanny, 35; Bryon Keith McHanny, 4; Mesha McHanny, 10; Gevonna McHanny, 8, and Keven Brisco, 11.

title: A Fleet of City Buses To Serve the Elderly
description: The first five buses of a fleet of 398 that have special steps to make boarding easter for the elderly or handicapped went out on the city's streets yesterday.

title: Yeo Says Economies Would Be Helped
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Edwin H. Yeo 3d, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that the aim of the forthcoming sales of gold by the International Monetary Fund was not to depress the market price of gold but to make use of a nowimmobilized asset of the fund to help the balanceofpayments position of the world's poorest countries.

title: Just the Facts
description: The Giants finished 23d in scoring in the 26team league and their defense placed 17th in allowing points. In yardage, the offense placed 22d and the defense 21st.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 36inch water main burst under the sidewalk 142d Street And Broadway yesterday morning, flooding basements and temporarily halting IRT subway and uptown road traffic in the area. Charles Samowitz, Commissioner of Water Resources, said the cause had not been determined but noted that the break involved an old cast iron pipe.

title: Leafs Win On Turnbull Goal by 43
description: TORONTO, Dec. 22 (UPI) Ian Turnbull enjoyed his 22d birthday tonight as he drove in the winning goal late in the third period to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 43 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in the National Hockey League.

title: Teachers Upheld By Appeals Court On Longer Hours
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that school boards had the authority to alter the hours of the school day but that any change in the length of a teacher's work day must be negotiated.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: Peter Serkin Guest of Chamber Society
description: Peter Serkin, who played in all, four pieces on the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's program Sunday in Alice Tully Hall (to be repeated tonight at (7:30), is a pianist of wellnigh overwhelming gifts. His interpretive personality may still be slightly out of focus which is another way of saying that, at the age of only 28, he is still growing and developing. But if the exact nature of his performing personality is still to be determined, its strength is unmistakable.

title: Historic Outhouses Prove to Be Fireplugs
description: BATSTO, Dec. 22 (UPI)Warning: Don't use the outhouses at historic Batsto Village.

title: Today's Entries at Aqueduct
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Bid for Delay in Gulf Oil Report Linked to Unexpected Witness
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22The unexpected appearance of Claude C. Wild Jr., key figure in the operation of the Gulf Oil Corporation's $5 million domestic political slush fund, appeared today to have been the key development that prompted the corporation's internal investigative committee to ask for a 15day delay in filing its report two weeks ago.

title: 110% Rate Increases Sought by Insurers
description: The nation's fire and casualty insurers plan to seek another round of sharp rate increasesaveraging about 10 percent nationwide  on premiums for automobile and home insurance to offset heavy losses on that business this year.

title: Helping New York
description: Jane Grossman's youngest son was going to be in nursery school three mornings a week. So she hired a baby sitter for those afternoons and went out looking for volunteer work three days a week:

title: Winter Wheat Crop Seen Shrinking 9%
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22America's winter wheat crop, on which so much of the world depends for its bread, is suffering from dry weather and is in danger of being smaller than this year's record crop.

title: BIRTH PILL GROUP FACES F.D.A. CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Food and Drug Administration officials will meet tomorrow with industry representatives in an effort to decide whether one group of oral contraceptive pills should be removed from the market.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that Stewart Rawlings Mott contributes money to candidates for public office through his philanthropic foundation. Mr. Mott says that he makes such contributions as an individual, and that the foundation contributes only to charitable organizations.

title: JobHunters Besiege Democrats in Suffolk
description: HOLBROOK, L. T., Dec. 22Dominic J. Baranello replaced the telephone in its cradle, shrugged wearily, then said: These days everybody wants to have lunch with me.

title: DUNGAN PREDICTS LESS COLLEGE AID
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)Rutgers University and New Jersey's eight state colleges can expect to receive at least $100 million less next year in state financing, Ralph A. Dungan, Chancellor of Higher Education, said today.

title: Presidential Privacy: A Question
description: Periodically an event occurs, or a rumor surfaces, that raises these questions for journalists and the public: How much reporting should the media do about the private lives of public figures? Should a politician's licen tiousness, vulgarity or drunkenness be reported? Should a President's? If so, under what circumstances? The questions have been raised again by the recent disclosure that President Kennedy had a close personal relationship with Judith Campbell Exner, who at the time was also dating two Mafia figures.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Witnesses testifying last week at a state hearing aimed at implementing a new unitpricing law said much more work was needed in educating the public on what unit pricing is and what it will mean for New Jersey's consumers.

title: The 3 Men Who Control Angola's Warring Factions
description: UIGE, AngolaIn terms of their personal background, the three leaders of Angola's battling nationalist factions have a great deal in common. All three are the sons of Protestant lay preachers in a country that is predominantly Roman Catholic. All were educated in mission schools and all were part of that tiny segment of Angola's black population that had risen to middleclass respectability.

title: Friends and a Fund Recall the Murdered Girl in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 21We don't talk about the murder anymore, said Libby Straight, a sophomore at Greenwich High School. We talk about Martha and the fun we had.

title: A White Christmas Swirls In, Bringing Hazards
description: Biting cold and blowing sleet made conditions unpleasant for throngs of Christmas shoppers yesterday, but the city escaped relatively lightly as the snowstorm blew off toward Newfoundland, leaving 4 to 8 inches of snow in suburban metropolitan areas.

title: POPE BACKS RIGHTS OF PALESTINIANS
description: ROME, Dec. 27 (APPope Paul VI appealed to the Israeli people today to recognize the rights and legitimate aspirations of Palestinians.

title: Albany Muddles Through
description: As a special legislative session voted new taxes last week, climaxing a year of response to deepening crises for state and local governments in New York, Governor Carey was left in a position somewhat similar to that of the Vermont farmer who was asked how much he had received for a litter of pigs he had just sold.

title: 2 BILLION IN NOTES SOLD AT 7.5% RATE
description: The United States Treasury, borrowed $2 billion yesterday by selling fouryear notes that will provide investors with an average yield of 7.50 percent me financing took place as the credit market's recent pronounced move toward higher prices and lower interest rates tended to level off amid lighter trading activity normal for Christmas week.

title: N.C.A.A to Do Business, From TShirts to Wallpaper
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is going into the dry goods business. The organization, whose declared purpose is to initiate, stimulate and improve intercollegiate athletic programs for student  athletes and promote and develop educational leadership, hopes to have a full line of N.C.A.A. Tshirts, street shoes, sneakers, athletic bags and other items in time for Christmas, 1976.

title: MANUEL ROBBINS, 65, LAWYER, DEWEY AIDE
description: Manuel Lee Robbins, a Jawyer who was special hearing examiner for the Waterfront Commission, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 179 East 70th Street.

title: 30 Hurt as a T.W.A. Jet Crashes at Milan Airport
description: MILAN, Italy, Dec. 22 (AP)A jetliner flying many ItalianAmericans to Italy for Christmas crashed here today while making an instrument landing in thick fog, injuring 30 of the 133 persons aboard. There were no deaths.

title: YONKERS MANAGER URGES DISMISSAL OF 25% ON PAYROLL
description: A proposal to meet, Yonkers's statemandated $15 million budget cut by dismissing approximately onefourth of its 4,500 municipal and school employees will be submitted today to the stateappointed Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Roard.

title: SYLVIA FINE GIVES PROGRAM OF SONG
description: Since December 1970, the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. has had 24 lyricists, mostly from the Broadway theater, discussing and demonstrating their craft. But to start the series's sixth season on Sunday evening, Maurice Levine, its artistic director, called on a different kind of lyricista specialist, Sylvia Fine.

title: Marlborough Is Expelled From Art Dealers Group
description: In what appeared to be almost simultaneous actions the Marlborough Gallery which was assessed $9.2 million in fines and damages by Surrogate Millard L. Midonick last week for wrongdoing in its dealings with the estate of the late abstract expresionist painter Mark Rothko, has resigned from and been expelled by the Art Dealers Association of America, an organization formed to promote and uphold ethical practices among dealers.

title: Reagan, a Fast Starter, Faces First Test
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22Ronald Reagan has struck with surprising speed in his plan to wrest the leadership of the Republican Party away from an incumbent President.

title: Portugal Said to Get Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund's executive board has approved a loan of more than 70 million Special Drawing Rights to Portugal under its 1975 oil facility, informed sources said today.

title: U.S.Soviet Exchanges On Agriculture Slated
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)United States and Soviet officials have agreed to exchange 29 teams of economic and scientific experts in agricultural subjects during 1976, according to a report published today by the Agriculture Department's foreign agricultural service.

title: Colonels Wallop Spirits by 126101
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 22 (UPI)  Backcourt scoring punch from Bird Averitt, with 25 points, and Ted McClain, with 21, propelled the Kentucky Colonels to a 126101 victory over the Spirits of St. Louis in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Cays No Longer A Butt of Jokers
description: Remember when Here Come the Cays was the joke of the National Basketball Association? Remember, too, when a newspaper ran a contest asking its readers to predict when the expansion  born Cleveland Cavaliers would win their first game? That was during the 197071 season when Bill Fitch, the coach, joked his way through a 15game losing streak and a 1567 wonlost record.

title: Deaths
description: ALTMANRoslyn: Our sincere condolences to the family of Roslyn Altman from the members & Board of Directors of The United Family of Judah.

title: Rebuilding; Cornerstone
description: In a candid farewell to the Jets as their interim coach, Ken Shipp described Joe Namath as a stubborn romantic who just can't conceive he can't catch up by throwing long. Shipp also labeled some of the defensive players as pitiful. And, missing no one, he indirectly condoned the dismissal of Coach Charley Winner by saying, If you can't do the job, then you ought to get fired.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday.

title: The Attica Prosecution
description: Like so many aspects of the 1971 Attica prison revolt and its aftermath, the Meyer Report on the Attica prosecution has left a series of unanswered questions. The author of the report, Bernard S. Meyer, used such words as imbalance and onesidedness to characterize the prosecution that he and his staff of eight lawyers scrutinized for six months. But as strong as these conclusions are, the facts presented in his 130page report that was released Sunday indicate that even stronger conclusions may have been warranted.

title: Boston Politics and Patronage Playing Big Role in Complex Maneuvering in the School Desegregation Fight
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22This city's busing controversy is being played out against the background of a decade of politics that has helped to institutionalize a school system resistant to desegration.

title: Inflation and Growth Are Cited By Rumsfeld for Rise in Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the Administration had approved an increase in the defense budget for next year large enough to offset inflation and permit some growth in the military establishment.

title: Ford Rebukes Israel on Leaks to Press
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 President Ford, in an unusual action, publicly rebuked Israel today for what was described as constant leakage to the press of confidential exchanges between the United States and Israel.

title: ET C. Charges Illegality In Curb on Doctors' Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Federal Trade Commission accused the American Medical Association today of illegally interfering with the prices that doctors charge and with keeping patients from getting information about doctors by preventing its members from advertising.

title: Ford Appoints Greenwald To Economic Affairs Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 President Ford announced today the nomination of Joseph Greenwald, a diplomat with long experience in international economic matters, as Assistant Secretary of State for Economic matters, as Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

title: Petrosian Takes Soviet Titlel
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Tigran Petrosian, a former world chess champion, today won his fourth Soviet chess championship. Petrosian ended the home championship series with 10 points out of a possible total of 15. Tied for second half a point behind were Rafael Vaganyan. Mikhail Tal, Boris Gulko and Oleg Romanishin. The current world champion, Anatoly Karpov, and another former champion, Boris Spassky, did not play.

title: Governor Signs Bill To Erect New Span Over the Delaware
description: BURLINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) Governor Byrne today signed a bill authorizing the construction of a new Delaware River bridge here, despite a loud protest by residents.

title: Film: Story of Adele H.
description: The Story of Adle H. was shown at the 13th New York Film Festival. The following excerpts are from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13, 1975. The film is being shown at the Cinema I, Third Avenue and 60th Street.

title: U.S. Juniors Win Sunshine Cup Title
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 22 (UPI)A decisive doubles match gave the United States its fourth consecutive Sunshine Cup tennis title yesterday. Walter Redondo and Nial Brash, Californians, split singles contests against Peter Eller and Klaus Eberhart of West Germany.

title: Roberts Estate Burns
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Dec. 22 (AP)An early morning fire today destroyed the estate of the late Kenneth Roberts, author of Northwest Passage and numerous historical novels set in Maine. The Wildes District Road House, built in 1939, was valued at more than $100,000.

title: CHILEAN PARTY CHIEF IS CRITICAL OF JUNTA
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 (AP)The bead of Chile's biggest political party, in a rare display of defiance to the ruling military junta, has declared his opposition to the indefinite suppression of personal liberties.

title: U .N . Council Calls on Indonesia To Evacuate Portuguese Timor
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution today calling on Indonesia to remove its military forces from Portuguese Timor without delay.

title: Funds for Johnson Grove
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) President Ford signed a bill today to authorize spending of up to $1 million for improvements at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Memorial Grove across the Potomac River from Washington. The grove of tall trees, for which public donations have also been solicited, is a memorial park to the late President

title: Books of The Times
description: Can a faithful biography surmount the quotidian? Must a true account of a life be a data bank, spewing out chronological details as if personal history were breakfasts and love affairs, all in a pretty row? No, it must not. For eloquent evidence to the contrary we need look no further than Reed Whittemore's William Carlos Williams: Poet From

title: Brokers in Black in October
description: After showing aggregate losses in both August and September, brokerage houses earned $81.9 million (before taxes) in October, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. However, 105 of the 414 member firms reporting had losses for the month.

title: DR. ERNEST A. MOODY, TAUGHT PHILOSOPHY
description: Dr. Ernest A. Moody profesI sor of philosophy at the University of California at Los Angeles from 1958 to 1970 and a member of the Columbia University faculty from 1939 to 1951, died Sunday at his home in Camarillo, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: N.B.A. Is Sued By Chamberlain
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 (UPI)Wilt Chamberlain today filed a suit in United States District Court charging that National Basketball Association owners had conspired to keep him from joining the New York Knicks.

title: Zarb Negotiated on Energy Bill for a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22For Frank G. Zarb, the 40yearold Federal Energy Administrator, President Ford's signature on the Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975 brought to fruition negotiations that began a year ago and more than once appeared to be at a dead end.

title: Coop City Strikers Face Contempt Fine
description: Leaders of the long resistance to an increase in carrying charges at Coop City in the Bronx were ordered yesterday to turn over to the project $17 million in Withheld charges or face more than half a Million dollars in fines.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: To Rescue Tardy Santa Clauses: Crafts Books
description: A crafts book can be an ideal solution to the lastminute scramble for a Christmas gift since there are probably few people around today who are not interested in some aspect of handwork. And there will be no trouble finding a book for virtually any specialtymost of them of the howto variety.

title: 3 IN COUNCIL VOTE ARCULEO'S OUSTER
description: Angelo J. Arculeo of Brooklyn was ousted yesterday as Minority leader of the City Council by the vote of three of the five Republicans on the Council.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: S. Carolina Routs Yale By 10066, Gains Final
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 22 (UPI)Alex English scored. 37 points tonight and paced South Carolina to a 10066 rout of Yale in the opening game of the second annual Carolina Basketball Classic.

title: TV: Giving and Getting, NBC Special
description: Giving and GettingThe Charity Business, an NBC, News documentary shown last night at 10 o'clock, opened with the promise that We'll show you what some charities do with your money and how they get it from you. It concluded with some broad generalizations for the charity giver (Before you give, ask questions everywhere) and a dash of goodthink advice: Be generous, but give with your head, not just your heart. Between strong opening and weak close, a good idea for a TV investigation was lost in attractive graphics and superficial reportorial jabbing.

title: Classic Theater Comes to Knoxville
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.Excuse me, the young waitress said, aren't you Anthony Quayle?

title: ONE PACT SEEN NEAR AT WASHINGTON POST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) The Washington Post said tonight that it hoped to sign a contract tomorrow or Wednesday with the unison representing the paper handlers in its pressroom.

title: ABANDONED INFANT GETS FOSTER HOME
description: ELIZABETH, Dec. 22 (UPI)A 20dayold infant found abandoned at Newark International Airport was placed today with foster parents, the State Division of Youth and Family Services said.

title: CONFLICTS PANEL GAINS COMPLIANCE
description: Governor Carey's panel looking into the financial affairs of highranking state officials has found 35 instances of conflicts or potential conflicts of interest and achieved compliance From employees on virtually all of them.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A band of proPalestinian terrorists ended a 20hour siege at the Vienna headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries yesterday and, taking scores of hostages and a jetliner provided by Austria, began an odyssey of Middle Eastern capitals to drop off their; captives. Most of the hostages were freed unharmed at the first stop in Algiers. The plane went on to Tripoli, Libya, and last night, it was reported to have returned to Algiers. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: GET OUT OF ANGOLA, BRITON BIDS SOVIET
description: LONDON, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Britain today called for the withdrawal from Angola of Cuban. South African and indeed any other foreign troops and for the establishment there of a government of national unity.

title: GIMBEL BROTHERS REPORTS A PROFIT
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc., which operates the 38 Gimbel department stores and 30 Saks Fifth Avenue specialty stores, reported yesterday that it was in the black in the fourth fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 and had a 17.5 percent profit gain for fiscal 1975. Sales were also higher in both periods.

title: A FootHigh Tree With 350 Baubles
description: Warik Wheatley loves Christmas. There's a ceilinghigh tree, laden with ornaments in the living room of his bachelor apartment on the East Side. When he presses a switch a bird sings in the tree and a small wooden angel plays a musicbox organ.

title: Arab Terrorism
description: The Vienna kidnapping of Arab oil ministers by their own Arab compatriots and other proPalestinian terrorists will surely rank as one of the great ironies of this era. With dozens of hostages taken, three killed and several wounded so far by the gunmen, the terrible price that can be paid by innocent victims of terrorism has again been made clear to the civilized world. Yet the Arab states for years have refused to cooperate with international action to bring terrorism under any kind of controlas has been done with aerial hijacking.

title: RCA PLANS SALE OF A SUBSIDIARY
description: The RCA Corporation anflounced an agreement in principle yesterday for the sale of a subsidiary, Cushman & Wakefield, a leading real estate management company, to Rockefeller Center Inc. The announcement was made jointly by RCA's president, Anthony L. Conrad, who took over as chief executive after the resignation of Robert W. Sarnoff on Nov. 5, and Alton G. Marshall, president of the privately held Rockefeller Center Inc. The announcement gave no terms, nor did RCA disclose any reason for the sale of Cushman & Wakefield.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times yesterday that Stewart Rawlings Mott contributes money to candidates for public office through his philanthropic foundation. Mr. Mott says that he makes such contributions as an individual, and that the foundation contributes only to charitable organizations.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed in order of pest positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: F.C.C. RULING ASKED ON SATELLITE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI) The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the Comsat General Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation sought today approval from the Federal Communications Commission to establish a domestic communications satellite system.

title: TERRORISTS FREE ALL OF HOSTAGES, GIVE UP IN ALGIERS
description: A band of proPalestinian terrorists who shot their way into the Vienna headquarters of the world oil cartel Sunday and seized 11 oil ministers and about 80 others as hostages released their remaining captives early today and surrendered in Algiers.

title: Bridge:
description: The Swiss team championship that concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel was won by one of the youngest teams in the event.

title: President Intends to Veto Construction Picketing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22President Ford announced today that he would veto the construction industry picketing bill, the only piece of labor legislation enacted this year and a bill that the. Administration had supported and helped draft.

title: Foreman Shakes Off Snowball Injury
description: It was not the Buffalo Bills but their fans who gave Chuck Foreman, Minnesota's fine running back so much trouble last Saturday. After being hit in the eye with a snowball when he scored the third of his four touchdowns, Foreman at first reparted his vision to be blurred, but yesterday he said he was all right and would be ready for the division playoff game against the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday in Bloomington, Minn. It's just about normal, said Foreman of his eye, although there still is a little pain and swelling.

title: U.S.C. Bowl Victor In McKay's Finale
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 22 (AP)Southern California's quarterback, Vince Evans, shredded Texas A. and M.'s vaunted defense with two long pass plays as the underdog Trojans scored a 200 Liberty Bowl victory tonight in John McKay's last game as a college coach.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 22 (AP)The timekeeper who juggled the clock in Friday night's BlueGray football game said today, I followed the instructions of the TV people. They had charge of the time. Two officials of the BlueGray Association conceded that the first period had been cut three minutes at the request of the independent television network, Mizlou, which carried the game. But the BlueGray general manager, Allyn McKeen, protested angrily, saying I knew absolutely nothing about it. If I had known, I would have raised hell. It wouldn't have been allowed. He also complained that after cutting the first period to 12 minutes, the network apparently changed signals and put out the word to slow the game late in the fourth quarter because it was getting over too soon. The BlueGray president, Bill Chandler, said the game had to have television revenue to keep going. Without it, he said, we won't have any players. Network officials unavailable for comment.

title: Greek Cypriotes Losing Hove of Returning Home
description: STROVOLOS, Cyprus, Dec. 15Stelios Kyprianou was working in a rock quarry in the Kyrenia district of northern Cyprus when Turkish troops invaded the island in July 1974. He and his family fled, eventually moving into a refugee camp in Strovolos, a suburb of Nicosia.

title: Reagan's Lead May Be Real
description: When the Gallup Poll recently showed that Ronald Reagan had surged into the lead over Gerald Ford among Republicans and independents, Howard H. Callaway, the Ford campaign manager, was ready with a load of debunk. The poll result, he said, was only temporary and merely reflected the publicity attending Mr. Reagan's announcement of his candidacy.

title: Stage: Rip Van Winkle
description: There is a very clear resurgence of interest in Dion Boucicault's play Rip Van Winkle, which was written in 1865 as a vehicle for Joseph Jeffersonfor it had a local production recently in summer stock, and at present a major staging is planned by the Theater of the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, starring Anthony Quayle, which will open in Knoxville, continue to the KennedyCenter in Washington as part of the Bicentennial season and, finally, may come on to New York.

title: U.S. Loses in Tennis
description: Mexico ousted the United States from Davis Cup competition, 32, yesterday in Mexico City when Raul Ramirez defeated. Jimmy Connors in the final match. Details, Page 19.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: TROOPERS LIABLE ON CAR SEARCHES
description: NEWARK, Dec. 22 (AP)Three Three New Jersey state troopers were orderd by a Fdral judge today to pay damages to drivers who were searched illegally on the state's high ways.

title: 5 Indicted in Philadelphia in Ulster Gunrunning
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters)Five Americans of Irish descent were indicted today on charges of smuggling guns and ammunition to the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, the Justice Department announced.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Wyoming Uranium Plant Set
description: DENVER, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  The Union Pacific Corporation said today its Rocky Mountaro Energy Company subsidiary and a subsidiary of the Southern California Edison Company the Mono Power Company, planned to construct a multi milliondollar uranium minemill complex at Bear Creek, Wyoming. Both subsidiaries are equal partners and Rocky Mountain will he operator for the project. Southern California Edison and the San Diego Gas and Electric Company will contract for the mill's entire uranium production.

title: ELLEGAL PRICING IS FOUND AT FORD
description: The Ford Motor Company was found guilty yesterday of unlawful price discrimination regarding a small Yonkers distributor of auto repair parts.

title: JOSEPH F. M'MANUS
description: Joseph F. McManus, retiree chief of the construction evaluation section of the Veterans Administration, died Sunday in Philadelphia, where he had been living in a retirement home. He was 79 years old and a former resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: McCormack Dismissed By Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (UPI)  Mike McCormack wag released today by the Philadelphia Eagles after a 410 wonCost season.

title: $511,084 Pledged To Aid Channel 13 In Recent Campaign
description: WNET/Channel 13's last membership drive of 1975 brought the station 22,207 new subscribers and $511,084 worth of pledges, the station has announced.

title: Warrant for Hoffa Search Extended
description: NEWARK, Dec. 22 (UPI)United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein announced today the second extension of a warrant to search a Jersey City dump where Federal authorities investigating the disappearance of James R. Hoffa believe a body may be buried.

title: Winthrop Taylor, Lawyer, 91 Raised Ayrshire Dairy Cows
description: Winthrop Taylor, a retired New York lawyer died yesterday at his home in St. James, L.I. He was 91 years old.

title: India Clinches Series
description: MANILA, Dec. 22 (AP)India took an insurmountable 30 lead over the Philippines today to advance to the Eastern Zone Davis Cup semifinals against New Zealand.

title: Savings Bond Gifts
description: A special Christmas gift for children or adults can be United States Savings Bonds, because of the happiness they bring and because they grow. Series E Bonds earn 6 percent when held for five years. Interest yields on the bonds are guaranteed. They have been increased seven times since the first Series E Bond was offered on May 1, 1941.

title: MEYER LIBEN, WRITER OF STORIES, ARTICLES
description: Meyer Liben, a shortstory writer, collapsed and died on the street Sunday evening of an apparent heart attack a few blocks from his home at 10 West 15th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: Israel Sticks to Decision To Boycott U.N. Session
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 (Reuters)  Israel said today it would not participate in a United Nations Security Council meeting next month to which representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization have been invited.

title: Conrad Snow, 86, Dies; Headed State Department Loyalty Board
description: Conrad E. Snow, a New Hampshire lawyer who served in both World Wars and headed the State Department's Loyalty Security Board in the days when the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was charging that there was Communist infiltration in the department, died yesterday in Gilmanton Iron Works, N.H., where he was living in retirement. He was 86 years old.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Renewed concern over inflation and the course of the nation's economic recovery weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the Overthecounter market.

title: Holiday Shoppers Abroad Shunning Luxuries
description: High inflation and continuing recession are curbing Christmas and yearend shopping abroad, compelling consumers to buy lowerpriced, more practical gifts and fewer luxuries than in the last two years.

title: Miss Fromme's Friend Indicted For Plot to Mail Death Threats
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 22 (UPI)Sandra Good, a former roommate of Lynette Alice Fromme, was arrested today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with conspiring to send 171 death threats through the mail.

title: Anniversaries
description: AARONSON

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Klepak Gets Post
description: Daniel Klepak, deputy state comptroller, was named yesterday by the State Health Commissioner, Robert P. Whalen, to the new post of deputy commissioner for financial affairs. Mr. Klepak, who is. 58 years old, was a health aide for many years, before taking a troubleshooting assignment in the Department of Education. His salary is Unchanged $45,382 a year.

title: Market Place
description: On Friday the Dow Jones ticker reported that the Carrier Corporation had authorized the purchase of up to 144,900 Carrier shares on or off the open market to be held for stock options or other management incentive plans.

title: Vienna Raiders, Violence at End, Seemed Friendly
description: VIENNA, Dec. 22It began here yesterday with bursts of submachinegun fire and three deaths and ended today at the airport with a handshake. It was, all involved agreed, one of the most bizarre terrorist attacks to date.

title: U.S. Seeks Cooperation Of Schools in Bias Inquiry
description: Federal Civil Rights officials have asked the Justice Departpent to institute legal proceedlugs to compel five community] school districts in the city to cooperate with a Government investigation into possible discrimination in the schools.

title: TERRORIST GROUP AND OIL OFFICIALS FLOWN TO MIDEAST
description: A band of proPalestinian terrorists ended a 20hour siege at the Vienna headquarters of the world oil cartel yesterday and, taking scores of hostages and a jetliner provided by Austria, began an odyssey of Middle Eastern capitals to drop off their captives.

title: Jane Thayer Ireland, 56, Psychiatric Social Worker
description: Jane Thayer Irelands a psychiatric social worker with the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education died Saturday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived here.

title: Killer of Six in Bungled Robbery Of Connecticut Bakery Convicted
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 22 (UPI)A Superior Court jury tonight found Ronald Piskorski, 26 years old, guilty of murdering six persons in the bungled robbery of a bakery store in New Britain in 1974.

title: Grand Jury Fails to Find Southern Bell Slush Fund
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 22 (AP)A sixmonth grand jury investigation into an alleged political slush fund at Southern Bell Telephone Company failed to uncover enough evidence to support any indictments.

title: IMPORT FEE STOPS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22President Ford ended a yearlong stalemate with Congress over energy policy today by signing into law a bill that will roll back crude oil prices and help stabilize gasoline and fuel oil prices for consumers, at least temporarily.

title: Hockey a la Russe Next on Program
description: Balance a hockey puck on your head and repeat these words: Aleksandr Yakushev, Vladislav Tretiak, Valeri Kharlamov, Yuri Liapkin, Viacheslav Anisin, Gennadi Tsygankov, Boris Mikhailov, Vladimir Lutchenko. This isn't a new type of tonguetwister; it's a list of names that will be heard and talked about starting next Sunday and continuing through Jan. 11, when two Soviet hockey teams play eight games against eight National Hockey League clubs.

title: Argentine Air Force Men End the Uprising Quietly
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22Rightwing air force officers today quietly ended their revolt against President Isabel Martinez de Pern.

title: 500 Who Won Suit In Mayday Arrests Are Still Untraced
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22More than 500 of the 1,318 persons who may be, entitled to as much as $10,000 apiece in damages for illegal arrest in the 1971 Mayday antiwar protest have still not identified themselves to the American Civil Liberties Union, that group said today.

title: Wilson Triumphs In Vermont Skiing
description: MANCHESTER, Vt. Dec. 22 (AP)Eric Wilson of Montpelier, Vt., won the men's division of the Eastern Holiday Ski Classic today at the Big Bromley ski area. He moved up from second place after Saturday's runs. Wilson recorded a firstplace finish time of 3:24.80 in a field of 76 in the giant slalom.

title: Civilized Conservative in Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 20  In Spain there are conservatives who are still fighting the Civil War and there are conservatives like Jose Maria de Areilza who are trying to move the country away from the old antagonisms. Such animosities die hard, he is finding. Ultrarightists thwarted his bid to become prime minister in King Juan Carlos's first government, so he had to settle for the post of Foreign Minister.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax).

title: Lebanese Leaders Meet With Syrians Over Crisis
description: BEIRUT Dec. 22  Prime Minister Rashid Karami of Lebanon visited Damascus today and held talks with President Hafez alAssad and other Syrian officials on the deepening Lebanese crisis.

title: In Memoriam
description: DOBZHANSKYTheodosius. Memorial service Saturday, December 27, at 3 P.M., at St. Seraphim's Russian Orthodox Church, 322 West 108th St., N.Y.C.

title: RENE FLORIOT, 73, CRIMINAL LAWYER
description: PARIS, Dec. 22Ren Floriot, France's most famous criminal lawyer, died of a heart attack last night at the American Hospital in the suburb of Neuilly. He was 73 years old.

title: A White Christmas Swirls In On Suburbs, Bringing Perils
description: Biting cold and blowing sleet made conditions unpleasant for throngs of Christmas shoppers yesterday, but the city escaped relatively lightly as the snowstorm blew off towards Newfoundland, leaving 4 to 8 inches of snow in suburban metropolitan areas.

title: GULF OIL CUTS OFF ANGOLA OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Gulf Oil Corporation announced today that it had temporarily suspended operations in Angola, had withdrawn most of its foreign personnel, and was prepared to place future royalty payments in escrow.

title: ARTHUR T. SCHMIDT
description: Arthur T. Schmidt, a lawyer here and in Montclair, N.J., died Sunday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N.J. He lived in Montclair.

title: Economic Storm Clouds
description: The country cannot afford another year of stalemate on Federal economic policy; yet that danger increases as the preelection battle lines between President Ford and the Democraticcontrolled Congress tighten.

title: Fellowships Granted to 5 By Patterson Foundation
description: The selection of five journalists to receive Alicia Patterson Foundation fellowships for travel and study in 1976 was announced yesterday by Alice Arlen, president of the foundation.

title: Six New Appointments Are Made by Governor
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)The following appointments Were made today by Governor Byrne:

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Role for Women in Senegal
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)Women are to be appointed to top government posts. President Lopold Senghor says. The announcement, made as International Women's Wear draws to a close, marks a policy departure here. A number of women hold administrative and political posts, but there are none in the Cabinet.

title: L.I. Firemen Give A Shiny Red Present To a Mexican Town
description: MELVILLE, L. I., Dec. 22Henry Colban was thumbing through a national magazine one recent day and came across a notice soliciting a fire engine for a small town in Mexico. Mr. Colban answered the appeal immediatelyhe just happened to have such a vehicle to give.

title: Woman's Best Friend Stolen Along With Car
description: The week before Christmas three years ago, Susan Toby Klein found a dog, seriously injured, lying at the side of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx. Its name tag was the same as her middle name. Toby.

title: Stocks Continue to Slide As Economy Stirs Doubts
description: Stock prices continued to slide yesterday with concern over the vigor of the economic recovery the principal question mark. In a market that was as drab as the weather, the Dow Jones industrials moved progressively lower through a sluggish session, finishing at 838.63 with a loss of 5.75 points. This followed a drop of 7.71 points on Friday.

title: News Curb Issued By a Boston Judge In Miss Saxe Trial
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP)A Superior Court judge issued an order today prohibiting the news media from recounting the record of Susan Saxe, who is facing trial on a charge of murdering a Boston policeman five years ago.

title: College, School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: ... $200 Million Gap
description: The fiscal problems of New York and some other localities have overshadowed the difficulties of New York City in recent weeks, giving this beleaguered metropolis a welcome rest after months of continual crisis.

title: Dividends
description: COMPANY REPORTS

title: Venezuela Says It Will Propose Assembly Session on Terrorism
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22Venezuela has decided to request a special session of the General Assembly at which it will ask that concrete measures be taken to combat terrorism, the country's delegate. Simn Alberto Consalvi, said today.

title: Fund Requests and Appropriations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Following is a table showing the funds requested by the Administration and amounts appropriated by Congress during the 1975 session:

title: Business Briefs
description: Baker, Weeks Inc., the researchoriented brokerage house, disclosed yesterday that top executives were taking pay cuts anti that about 35 of its 400 employees would be cut from the payroll by the end of this year. Onethird are being removed by attrition, and the others are being dismissed, the company said.

title: North South Dialogue: Kissinger's 41 Points
description: Two years ago, the industrial nations that consume more than fourfifths of the world's oil met in Washington and invited the oilproducing countries that had embargoed them and quadrupled prices to open a dialogue on price and security of supply. Until now, the consumerproducer negotiation has achieved little, but new machinery set up by the 27nation Paris conference last week may finally permit the world's rich and poor countries to skirt ideology and come to grips with the issues.

title: JUDGE ASKS TO SEE U.S. FILE ON AGNEW
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22A Federal judge ordered the Justice Department today to submit for her private inspection much of the documentary evidence in the Government's 1973 criminal investigation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew. The evidence has never been made fully public because, in a pleabargaining deal, Mr. Agnew pleaded no contest to a tax evasion charge and was not tried.

title: GULF OIL CUTS OFF ANGOLA OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 The Gulf Oil Corporation announced today that it had temporarily suspended operations in Angola, had withdrawn most of its foreign personnel, and was prepared to place future royalty payments in escrow.

title: All Gaul Is Divided Into 3 Parts: 2 French, 1 American
description: PARISThe French claim to hate Americans but they are fascinated by America, fascinated in the way they say certain birds are fascinated by snakes: Drawn by their fatal gaze, powerless to flee, they allow themselves to be devoured.

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH ASSOCIATION CUP

title: Arthur. M. Milburn Dies; Stockbroker Here Was 81
description: Arthur MacKenzie Milburn, a stockbroker here for 50 years with Henderson, Harrison & Company and its predecessors, died Sunday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived at 320 Grace Church Street, Rye, N.Y.

title: The Attica Prosecution
description: Like so many aspects of the 1971 Attica prison revolt and its aftermath, the Meyer Report on the Attica prosecution has left a series of unanswered questions. The author of the report, Bernard S. Meyer, used such words as imbalance and onesidedness to characterize the prosecution that he and his staff of eight lawyers scrutinized for six months. But as strong as these conclusions are, the facts presented in his 130page report that was released Sunday indicate that even stronger conclusions may have been warranted.

title: For Mrs. Peron, Few Friends And a Growing Number of Foes
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 During 18 months as President of Argentina, Isabel Martnez de Pern has presided over the decline of her country and the disintegration of the political movement forged by her husband. Juan Domingo Pern.

title: 25 Favorite Big A Victor Before 9,441
description: Lord Henribee scored his fourth victory in a row by capturing the $55,050 Nashua Stakes for 2yearolds at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of only 9,441 fans in snowy, 30degree weather. The son of Misty Flight, the 25 favorite, won the mile test by two lengths over Cojak, the 72 second choice and an invader from Maryland who was trying for his fifth straight triumph.

title: Air Hijacker Is Wounded And Captured in Colombia
description: MEDELLIN, Colombia, Dec. 22 (AP)Policemen disguised as mechanics, shot and severely wounded a hijacker who seized a small plane today with eight persons aboard and demanded $65.000.

title: Miss Rogers Has Nuptials
description: Josephine Witherspoon Rogers of Lexington, Va., and New York, vice president of CollinsKnowltonWing, a division of Curtis Brown Ltd., literary agents, was married here yesterday afternoon to Alexander Henderson Morrison of Lexington, a professor of economics at the Virginia Military Institute. The Rev. Ernest E. Hunt performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: The Necessity of Ideology
description: The following article was written in December, 1973. The author, a 41yearold scholar in Russian literature. now in a Yugoslav prison, is reported to be on a hunger strike for humane conditions. Last February, he was sen, tenced to seven years on charges of spreading hostile propaganda. Specifically, he was charged with writing critically about the Government in articles published abroad. This article was translated from the Russian for The New York Times by Maria Mihajlov Ivusic.

title: U.S. Agency Void.s Drug Registration Dr. Jacobson Held
description: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration revoked yesterday Dr. Max Jacobson's registration to prescribeand dispense such controlled drugs as amphetamines, barbiturates and narcotics.

title: Soybeans, Wheat and Corn Decline
description: Grain and soybean futures generally declined by a few cents a bushel yesterday in slow preholiday trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state's Department of Environmental Protection said it ha, d even the Cumberland County Sewerage Authority permission to double the capacity of the Bridgeton city sewagetreatment plant to 7 million gallons a day. The department, which acted under the Coastal Area Facility Review Act, said the expansion would lessen pollution of the Cohansey River. Sludge from the plant will be treated and sold as fertilizer to local farms and nurseries.

title: Procedural Changes Left Mark on 94th Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The procedural changes adopted by the Senate and House this year, in the view of many members of Congress, made their mark distinctly on the first session of the 94th Congress, which ended last week.

title: City Finance Aide Says Bigger Cuts Must Be Ordered
description: The city's expense budget for the next fiscal year will have to be cut $262 million below already reduced expenditures for the current fiscal year to comply with the state's mandate that the budget be balanced by mid1978, Kenneth S. Axelson, deputy mayor for finance, disclosed yesterday.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Survey Finds More Than Half the World Without a Free Press
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22  More than half the world is without a free press, the International Press Institute said today in its annual survey of events affecting the free flow of information.

title: Notes on People
description: Lately Pearl Bailey has been playing to a new audience, as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, and the Broadway closing of Hello, Dolly on Sunday was billed as her last performance on the New York stage. When she first appeared on the stage, the audience erupted in a standing ovationthe first of several, it turned out.

title: Farmers Step Up Production of Hogs As Feed Prices Dip
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) Encouraged by a bumper corn crop and improved market prices for livestock, farmers are stepping up hog production this winter for the first time in five years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Helping New York
description: Jane Grossman's youngest son was going to be in nursery school three mornings a week. So she hired a baby sitter for those afternoons and went out looking for volunteer work three days a week.

title: Aldermen Reject Teacher Contract For New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 22 (AP) The Board of Aldermen tonight voted, 17 to 6, to reject a twoyear contract that teachers and the school board worked out last month after a strike marked by the jailing of 90 teachers.

title: Court Tries Case Vital to Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22In the pink and yellow Supreme Court Building here, constitutional lawyers are arguing the merits of a case that some of them consider crucial to the future of a free society in India.

title: People in Sports
description: Who is JeanPierre Coopman. The question came as an automatic reaction yesterday to the news that Muhammad Ali would defend his heavyweight title against Coopmans on Feb. 20, according to Don King, the promoter.

title: All Year Long, Collectors Enjoy Decorations of Christmas Past
description: Most of us think it's enough to have the decorakiwi side of Christmas a couple of weeks a year, but there are a few people around who evidently can never get too much of it.

title: Chess:
description: The Alexander Memorial Tournament in Teeside, England, was won by the Russian grandmaster Efim Geller, who overcame a very strong field with a score of 91/242/2. Geller's play was of high quality throughout, but he did get an important break by drawing with Robert Huebner, a West German grandmaster, who blundered away a winning position.

title: Coop City Fee Strikers Facing Heavy Court Fines for Contempt
description: Leaders of the long resistance to an increase in carrying charges at Coop City in the Bronx were ordered yesterday to turn over to the project $17 million in withhed charges or face more than half a million dollars in fines.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, Dec. 22. 37th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: U.S. Loses in Tennis
description: Mexico ousted the United States from Davis Cup cornpetition, 32, yesterday in Mexico City when Raul Ramirez defeated Jimmy Connors in the final match. Details, Page 19.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Flute Concerto No. 1, Mozart; La Mer. Debussy; Prelude to Act III of Lohengrin, Wagner; Symphony No. 7. Sibelius.

title: No Comment in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 22Israeli officials withheld comment on the Pope's reference to the Middle East.

title: Communist Laos
description: The recent Pathet Lao seizure of absolute power in Laos wiped out both the 600yearold monarchy and the coalition government to which solemn agreement was given only nineteen months ago to end the civil war. It also has brought a reinforcement of North Vietnamese and Soviet influence and put China on the defensive there.

title: Giants Will Keep Jets Need New
description: Having ended a season that two late victories transformed from disastrous to disappointing, the Giants turned yesterday to the task of determining who would remain and who would depart. Coach Bill Arnsparger will remain. One or more of his assistant coaches may not. Nor may John Mendenhall. Other familiar Giants such as Bob Tucker, Ron Johnson and Spider Lockhart are virtually certain to depart.

title: State Rests in Trial of 2 Held In Murder of Music Arranger
description: The state yesterday rested its case in the trial of Beverly, Donna Hodge, who is accused of plotting the murder of her husband, George Howard Hodge, a rock music arranger.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1975

title: E.P.A. Chief Plans to Curb PCB Pollution
description: Russell E. Train, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced in Washington yesterday that the agency planned to modify existing water discharge permits in an effort to eliminate by July 1977 direct discharges of PCBs, a toxic group of chlorineladen chemicals, into the nation's waterways.

title: CASTRO PROMISES MORE ANGOLAN AID
description: MIAMI, Dec. 22 (AP)Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba said today that his country would continue its military support of the Angolan leftist faction that is backed by the Soviet Union despite the threats of President Ford not to renew relations with Cuba.

title: 49 Bills Await Action
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) White House officials said to day that 49 bills were awaiting Presidential action.
