title: Forced Adoptions in East Anger West Germans
description: BONN, Dec. 22  In August 1973, Otto and Barbel Grubel, who are from East Berlin, tried to crawl through the barbed wire of the CzechoslavakAustrian border with their 4yearold son, Ota, and their daughiter, Jeanette, 3. Their attempt; to escape to the West failed. Czech guards caught them.

title: Peter Whitehead, Managed Byrdcliffe Crafts Colony
description: Peter Whitehead, who managed the arts and crafts colony of Byrdcliffe, a 1,200acre estate at Woodstock, N. Y., died Sunday in Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Advertising
description: The Bank Street College of Education, pioneer in communicating with children, is about to bring out a new monthly magazine for the whole family.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND COUNTER OFF
description: Renewed concern over inflation and the course of the nation's economic recovery weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market.

title: CAREY IS CRITICAL OF TIMES ARTICLE
description: Governor Carey issued a statement yesterday criticizing an article in The New York Times on Monday about his granddaughter's death as offensive and misleading.

title: Record of Congress Session
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Following is a summary of President Ford's major legislative proposals and of the action taken by Congress during its 1975 session, along with bills pending or defeated:

title: 3 IN COUNCIL VOTE ARCULEO'S OUSTER
description: Angelo J. Arculeo of Brooklyn was ousted yesterday as minority leader of the City Council by the vote of three of the five Republicans on the Council.

title: CYNTHIA GREGORY TO QUIT DANCING
description: Cynthia Gregory, a 29yearold principal dancer with American Ballet Theater who is one of the country's leading and popular ballerinas, said yesterday that she was retiring from dancing.

title: 10% Rate Increases Sought by Insurers
description: The nation's fire and casualty insurers plan to seek another round of sharp rate increasesaveraging about 10 percent nationwide  on premiums for automobile and home insurance to offset heavy losses on that business this year.

title: Jersey Blue Cross Asks Rate Increase
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22New Jersey Blue Cross today asked the state for a rate increase, proposing to charge individual and smallgroup subscribers an additional 29.1 percent for their hospital insurance, effective March 1.

title: Dance: American Ballet Does Giselle
description: American Ballet Theater opened its sixweek season at the Uris Theater last night with a Giselle for our time with Mikhail Baryshnikov and Gelsey Kirkland.

title: ExNew Yorkers Extend Their Aid to the Neediest
description: Former New Yorkers as well as many who live here or come into the city mention its financial problems and the acute effect on those in want as they make contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: YONKERS MANAGER URGES DISMISSAL OF 25% ON PAYROLL
description: A proposal to meet Yonkers's statemandated $15 million budget cut by dismissing approximately onefourth of its 4,500 municipal and school employees will be submitted today, to the stateappointed Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: India Completes 41 Cup Victory
description: MANILA, Dec. 23 (UPI)India, which had already won its Davis Cup Eastern Zone quarterfinal match, spilt the reverse singles matches today with the Philippines to make the final score 41 India faces New Zealand next month in the semifinals.

title: CLEMENCY SOUGHT FOR A WOMAN, 33
description: HILLSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 21Executive clemency at Christmas for a Columbia County woman in jail for murdering her husband in 1968 is being sought by 18 state legislators, a dozen organizations, several prison officials, two district attorneys and a committee of convicts.

title: Books of The Times
description: Even for Americans, the old agricultural English village ranks near the top of the nostalgia list. Romanticized by the great English pastoral novelists of the 19th century, celebrated as recently as the 1970's by James Herriot in All Creatures Great and Small and All Things Bright and Beautiful, the old English village connotes Christmas, contentment, togetherness and virtually everything that can be subsumed under the word snug. It is an image that dies hard.

title: South Africa Impact in Angola Depicted
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 22South African military strategists say that there has been no appreciable stepup in terrorism in SouthWest Africa during the last four years and they therefore suggest that their country's partial mobilization and increased military activity is due entirely to the situation in Angola.

title: A.M.C. To Increase Prices on 3 Jeeps; Auto Levels to Hold
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI)The American Motors Corporation announced today a $40 price rise on three jeep models, but said it had no plans to increase sticker prices of its cars. The increase on the fourwheel drive jeep Cherokee, Wagoneer and truck models was necessary because new shoulderbelt systems will be installed after Jan. 1 under a new Federal safety standard. The price adjustments willapply to orders received after Jan. 1.

title: Computer Rates Raiders Tepid Choice
description: The closest game in the divisional playoffs this weekend will be Sunday's CincinnatiOakland contest. That is the view of Bud Goode, the noted sports analyst who has fed 123 statistical parts into the CalComp computer to determine what should happen at Pittsburgh and Los Angeles on Saturday and at Bloomington, Minn., and Oakland on Sunday.

title: 13 ARE ACQUITTED IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: Three men reputed to be among the top narcotics dealers in the city were found not guilty yesterday, after a trial that contained references to several murdered witnesses, numerous heroin deliveries and millions bf dollars in cash.

title: About Real Estate
description: At Pildes Opticians on Nassau Street many employes call the boss Danny. He is Daniel Pildes, the 32yearold son of Harry Pildes, who founded the business at 80 Nassau Street 50 years ago. Harry Pildes has retired.

title: Pan Am's November Loss About the Same as in 1974
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday in an unaudited statement, a net loss of $15.6 million for November, compared with a $15.7 million loss hr the yearearlier month, which had the benefit of a $7.6 million tax credit. Operating revenues increased 5.2 percent, while operating expenses were 1.6 percent less than in November 1974. Last month's results were adversely affected by a $1.1 million provision for mutual aid payments to a struck carrier.

title: Nets Defeat Colonels as Erving Stars
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP)Julius Erving led the way with 31 points and Rich Jones added 21 tonight as the New York Nets downed the Kentucky Colonels, 107102, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Market Place
description: Some investors who bought Arated New York City bonds less than a year ago only to see them drop to deep discounts in the flurry over possible default realize now that an investmentgrade rating is not an absolute assurance that nothing will go wrong.

title: CareyMorgenthau Texts
description: Following are the texts of statements by. Governor Carey and District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau:

title: Auto Output Down
description: The United States auto industry wound up 1975 with production of 8 percent less than in 1974 and the lowest since 1970, a strike year. Page 34.

title: Pardon Discussed
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 23 (AP)Algeria's Foreign minister, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who negotiated with the terrorists, was reported today to have raised with them the possibility of a pardon in return for the safe release of all hostages.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Governor Carey's recent pledge to submit legislation decriminalizing marijuana signals official recognition of the fact that we can no longer equate possession of one ounce of marijuana with such vicious crimes as manslaughter and arson, as is now the case under New York law. (Each of these acts is punishable as a Class C felony with a maximum fifteenyear prison term.) In drafting and submitting his actual bill, the Governor must weigh carefully a number of alternative methods of removing the criminal stigma from the marijuana smoker while not appearing to encourage or sanction use of the drug.

title: Ship Fire Suits Settled
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (UPI) The families of four workers killed in an explosion and fire aboard the lake freighter Roger Enough in 1971 won a settlement of more than $1 million in United States District Court yesterday. The court finding was against both the American Ship Building Company and the owner of the vessel, the United States Steel Corporation. Awards went to Mary Ann Moore and her six children for the death of her husband, Leonard; Angela Alexander and her three children for the death of her husband, John; Lucille Burdue for the loss of her husband, Clyde; and Phillip Adams, who lost his brother, George.

title: To Catch a Thief, Stores Use Wiles
description: It's Christmas and as the old song lyrics go, you'd better watch outonly it isn't Santa who's looking. Retail store security forces are taking anything but a ho ho attitude toward shoplifters, whose busiest season is now.

title: Peking Frees Last Of Top Nationalists It Has Held Since' 49
description: HONG KONG, Wednesday, Dec. 24China announced the release yesterday of the last of senior Nationalist officials it has held prisoner since the Communists took control in 1949.

title: Bangladesh's Drive for Progress: 4 Long Years on a Treadmill
description: DACCA, Bangladesh  Four years ago, in a bold, proud mood born of military victory, the new nation of Bangladesh sprang to the world's attention.

title: DATA ON DR. KING NOT FULLY VIEWED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Investigators for the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence have declined to examine fully the file compiled by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the activities of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., despite an offer from the Justice Department to make the complete file available to the committee staff.

title: GEORGE N. ARMSTRONG
description: George N. Armstrong, who retired in 1971 as an assistant treasurer of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Sunday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: Jersey Gets Health Grants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) The Public Health Service has awarded $428,000 in grants to fund six health programs and create jobs, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, said today. The largest grant, $148,615, was awarded to the New Jersey Department of Health for three venereal disease control programs.

title: 10 STATES URGING ACTION ON OZONE
description: Ten states have joined with the Natural Resources Defense Council and two other private groups in a petition urging that fluorocarbon aerosol propellants be banned as a threat to public health because of their suspected effect on the atmosphere's protective layer of ozone.

title: CLASHES NOTED
description: Governor Carey dismissed Maurice H. Nadjari as special state anti corruption prosecutor yesterday and announced that he would appoint Robert M. Morgenthau to the post.

title: ... Right on Picketing
description: President Ford's decision to veto the bitterly disputed construction situs picketing bill puts first things first. In terms of the national interestthe sole relevant yardstickthere never was any sound argument for enacting a law that could only make for more and bigger strikes and a further rise in the already astronomic cost of building.

title: Con Ed Rate Increase Cut Sharply by P.S.C. Official
description: A ruling by a Public Service Commission examiner yesterday cut a Consolidated Edison request for a 29.3 percent increase in electric rates to 6.4 percent, the largest reduction in a utility rate case on record in the state.

title: Opinion Polls: How Conflicting Results Tend to Spur Skepticism Over Validity
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Who's on first? Gerald Ford is ahead of Hubert Humphrey, according to George Gallup, but Louis Harris says he's behind. But where's Ronald Reagan? Ahead of Humphrey, says Gallup; behind, says Harris. If this old Abbott and Costello routine confuses you, join the club. The war of the pollsters is on. The experts are all scratching their heads this week following the release of two national political polls that directly contradicted each other.

title: Stage: Live Potatoland
description: In Rhoda in Potatoland (Her FallStarts), the latest exploration of Richard Foreman and his OntologicalHysteric Theater, potatoes are larger than life. These mammoth creatures have pinhole eyes and people feet. One of them wears a mirror over its forehead as if It were a tuberous Dr. Kronkheit. I think these vegetables also have a libido. Although Mr. Foreman says, Potatoes have no specific feeling about proximity to other potatoes, two of themone at the door, one at the windowseem to ogle the beautiful (often nude) Kate Manheim.

title: Gold Prices
description: Selected world golf prices Tuesday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Haven Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education are headed Hack to negotiations following a 17to6 rejection of the teachers' contract by the Board Aldermen. Both sides expressed hope that difficulties the contract would be straightened out in time for the Aldermen to vote on the revised contract at their next meeting, on Jan. 5.

title: About New York
description: Hardly anyone will notice, but the New York City Ballet will do The Nutcracker today for the 700th time. Some people think of Nutcracker as The Show, the way other people think of HarvardYale as The Game, and it is a fact that grown men in Nutcracker audiences weep sloppily when the Christmas tree rises up from the stage in Act One. It gets them every time.

title: Buses Collide in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 23 (UPI)Two buses filled with passengers collided today on the Pan American highway 120 miles south of Santiago. Authorities said 24 persons were believed killed and 30 injured.

title: S.E.C. SUIT SETTLED BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, accused of stock fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission last August, signed a consent decree here yesterday settling the Government case without admitting or denying the allegations of the Government agency.

title: School Authorities Seek An Extra $435 Million
description: Despite advice from the city that the school system will not get a larger budget for 197677, school authorities are planning to ask for $435 million in additional money.

title: Trabert Sums Up Defeat: Ramirez Was Too Good
description: Now the secondguessing begins.

title: Kings Beat Bruins, 43, As Dionne Gets 3 Goals
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)Marcel Dionne got his third threegoal game of the season tonight, providing the margin in the Los Angeles Kings's 43 victory over the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League. The burst gave Dionne the league lead with 24 goals.

title: Kissinger Remarks on Angola
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilitice of ABC News:

title: Rabbi Avigdor Cyperstein, Talmudic Scholar, 70, Dies
description: Rabbi Avigdor Cyperstein, a Talmudic scholar, died yesterday in Jerusalem, Israel. He was 70 years old.

title: Tax Forms in Friday Mail
description: WASHTNGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) Postmen will begin delivering 84 million Federal income tax forms on Friday. The Postal Service said the tax form deliveries would contribute to a heavier postChristmas work load than usual.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters dispatch in The New York Times Dec. 16, relating to a transfer of funds by the Swiss Credit Bank to New York, incorrectly mentioned the Mondial Commercial Corporation, which has principal offices in New York. The company involved is Mondial Commercial Ltd. of Liechtenstein.

title: In Memoriam
description: BECKENSTEINSamuel. Dec. 24, 1968. In blessed memory of our beloved father, our inspiratlon and guiding light, forever in our hearts and thoughts. His family.

title: The Best Messiah in Town Fills a West Side Apartment
description: The best Messiah in town this season took place Monday night in the dining room of a West Side apartment. This was chamber music pushed to its jolliest extreme: a harpsichord and chamber orchestra, soloists and a chorus of 25all of them performing for free and handily outnumbering their audiencecrammed into a room that measured 18 feet by 22 feet.

title: REFORM OF JAILS ORDERED IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23A Federal judge has ordered sweeping reforms in the administration and conditions of the Harris County jail system. In a report issued last week, Judge Carl O. Bue Jr, of Federal District Court, said, severe and inhumane overcrowding existed, and he hinted that he might order the closing of the jail facilities if the county did not comply with his order.

title: CLASHES NOTED
description: Governor Carey dismissed Maurice H. Nadjari as special state anticorruption prosecutor yesterday and announced that he would appoint Robert M. Morgenthau to the post.

title: INTRUDER SHOOTS 2 WOMEN
description: A 52yearold woman who made almost daily visits to a 72yearold diabetic friend was shot to death yesterday by an intruder who also wounded the older woman.

title: Columbia Dream Not Impossible, If...
description: Among his colleagues in the basketballcoaching profession, Tom Penders of Columbia has a new nicknameThe Guy Who Has to Play Indiana.

title: Rangers Stem Late Rally And Subdue Penguins, 43
description: When we last left the Rangers on Sunday, they had picked tip a victory despite dull, uninspired hockey that put Madison Square Garden in a trance.

title: Zambia Releases Woman Cult Founder
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 23 (AP)A 56yearold woman, jailed 11 years ago as the leader of a religious cult who was too dangerous to he allowed to be free, was released today by President Kenneth D. Kaunda.

title: SAMUEL RUDIN, 79, A BUILDER, IS DEAD
description: Samuel Rudin, a leading builder and owner of residential and office real estate, died Monday in his home at 945 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.

title: Dave Matthews's Jazz Band Has Come of Age in Last Year
description: Just a year ago, Dave Matthews's 12piece jazz band began playing on Monday nights at the Five Spot, 2 St. Marks Place, with Mr. Matthews hoping that the club might be a steady Monday night base for the band, as the Village Vanguard has been for the Thad JonesMel Lewis Band since 1966.

title: OffDuty Officer Kills 2 in Cab Reports They Tried to Rob Him
description: An offduty police officer fatally shot two men on Staten Island late Monday who, he said, had posed as drivers of a gypsy cab and had tried to rob him

title: Argentina in Crisis
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23Argentina's national crisis affects the country's internal security, economic organization and political leadership.

title: Sailing Vessel, a Century Old, Shivers Her Timbers in Mud at Stone Harbor
description: STONE HARBOR, Dec. 23 (AP)  A year after a northeaster uncovered her timbers, the bones of an old sailing ship remain a mystery on the beach of this Cape May County resort.

title: Sharp Gary Wins as Aqueduct Shuts for the Year
description: New York's thoroughbred racing season closed on a fitting wintry note yesterday. A thin layer of snow covered the infield and the temperatures hovered around the freezing mark as 12,625 tans turned out to bid the 1975 campaign adieu. The crowd was treated, however, to a sizzling contest between Edward R. Sharps's $5.80for$2 Sharp Gary and Hobeau's odds  on favorite, Group Plan, in the $54,200 Display Handicap. When that 2mile fixture was over it's the longest major stakes event in North AmericaSharp Gary was the winner by half a length.

title: Business Briefs
description: A group of 44 electric utilities in 32 states, most of them rural electric cooperatives, have entered into a, conditional letter of intent with the Kennecott Copper Corporation for the purchase of its subsidiary, the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer.

title: State Employees Switch Jobs With Utah Students
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 23Fulltime workers in search of a college degree and experiencehungry management students at the University of Utah are changing places this year as part of an educational tradeoff career development program funded by a twoyear $100,000 grant from the United States Office of Education

title: NOTE MORATORIUM UPHELD BY COURT; APPEAL PLANNED
description: Declaring that we must deal with this subject realistically, State Supreme Court. Justice J. Harold Baer yesterday, upheld the moratorium enacted by the Legislature on the payment or principal of $1.6 billion in maturing shortterm city notes.

title: NASA Moves to Realign Research Centers' Work
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in another effort to scale down operations in line with reduced budgets, has proposed a plan to realign the mission responsibilities of several of its research centers.

title: New Dean is Appointed By Yale forestry School
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 23Charles Henry W. Foster, a professor of environmental policy at the University of Massachusetts, has been named the new dean of the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies.

title: Dollars for Death
description: Certain Irish relief organizations in this country are reputed to be the source of as much as 85 percent of the weapons used by radical terrorists of the Irish Republican Army, according to a report published in The Times a few days ago.

title: Christmas Clemency Given to 2 Slayers Through Ford Order
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP). President Ford has commuted the prison sentences of two convicted murderers, a move that makes them eligible for parole soon, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

title: WORK TO CONTINUE ON EIGHT PROJECTS
description: The construction of eight Mitchell  Lama middle  income housing developments, threatened with suspension because of the city's budget crisis, will continue at least through January.

title: Wells Fargo Sees a Charge Against Its 1975 Income
description: Wells Fargo & Company announced yesterday that it expected a charge of about $3.5 million, or about 18 cents a share, against income for 1975. This represents the company's share of the estimated 1975 loss on its foreign investment, a 25 percent equity interest in Allgemeine Deutsche CreditAnstalt of Germany.

title: Con Ed Rate Increase Cut Sharply by P.S.C. Official
description: A ruling by a Public Service Commission examiner yesterday cut a Consolidated Edison request for a 29.3 percent increase in electric rates to 6.4 percent, the largest reduction in a utility rate case on record in the state.

title: Lesbian, in a Texas Trial, Loses Son to ExHusband
description: DALLAS, Dec. 23A jury of 10 men and two women decided today that the 9yearold son of a selfdescribed lesbian should be taken from his mother and placed in the custody of his father.

title: LATINS SET BACK IN DEVELOPMENT
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23The economic development of Latin America has suffered a serious setback this year in the world economic crisis.

title: HOLIDAY SALES UP THROUGHOUT U.S.
description: The Christmas shopping seasonthe principal reflection of the buying mood of Americans and a major indicator of 1976 economic trendsis concluding this year with an unusually strong flourish across the nation, topping last year's sales levels by 10 to 15 percent and 1973's by even more.

title: Company Earnings Issued
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise indicated. * Restated for LIFO change.

title: McKay Leaves Trojans For Pros on High Note
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 23 (UPI)John McKay, the Southern California coach, didn't send his team into the Liberty Bowl last night against Texas A. and M. with a plea to win his last collegiate game for him. That's never been his style.

title: Arbitrator Frees 2 Baseball Stars
description: A labor arbitrator ruled yesterday that two pitchers, Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally, were free agents who were no longer bound by their baseball contracts and could sell their services to the highest bidder.

title: KISSINGER INSISTS STAND ON ANGOLA WILL NOT CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, warning that SovietAmerican tensions might rise, said today that the Ford Administration would continue to opposethrough available military aid and diplomatic means the imposition of a Sovietbacked regime in Angola by force.

title: O.E.C.D. Recovery View
description: The United States, which led the world into the most serious recession since World War II, is expected to lead it out again in 1976. Yet the recovery in the major industrial countries is expected to be so sluggish as to make little or no dent in unemployment  the worst since the end of the Depression of the 1930's.

title: Approval Withheld For AliCoopman
description: LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters) The European Boxing Union will not allow JeanPierre Coopman of Belgium to challenge Muhamthad Ali for the world heavyweight title, a British boxing official said tonight.

title: Workers Warn State of a Strike If Accord Isn't Signed by Jan. 5
description: TRENTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)Five state employee unions representing 30,000 prison guards and bluecollar workers will strike Jan. 5 unless their contracts are approved, officials said Tuesday.

title: Return the Terrorists
description: Austria's demand that the six proPalestinian terrorists who seized, ten oil ministers and scores of others, killing three persons and wounding several, be returned for trial deserves an immediate favorable response from Algeria. Chancellor Bruno Kreisky has rightly warned that Arab terrorism, having begun to turn against Arab leaders, now should prove to the Arab states themselves the danger of condoning such atrocities.

title: 2 Faiths End Abortion Dialogue, Affirming Sacredness of Life
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Roman Catholic and Baptist theologians have concluded their first dialogue on the question of abortion without reaching a mutual position on the issue, but jointly affirmed the sacredness of life.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters dispatch, in The New York Times Dec. 16, relating to a transfer of funds by the Swiss Credit Bank to New York, incorrectly inentioned the Mondial Commercial Corporation, which has principal offices in New York. The company involved is Mondial Commercial Ltd. of Liechtenstein.

title: Glamour Issues Set Pace As Dow Climbs by 5.12
description: Glamour stocks  some of them depressed lately by the pressure of taxloss sellingsnapped back to life yesterday to lead a fairly strong advance. Airline issues moved higher, while the gold stocks lost ground.

title: Argentine Military Now Resolved to Control Events
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 23The Argentine armed forces have emerged from a limited air force crisis apparently more united and determined to control national affairs.

title: Court Restricts Police on Denying Pistol Permits
description: Justice Nathaniel Heiman of State Supreme Court has ruled that the New York City police have no right to ask persons to establish need when they apply to keep a pistol in their homes or businesses.

title: BIRTH PILL MAKERS GET ORDER BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 The Food and Drug Administration has made it clear to manufacturers of one class of birth control pills that they must produce evidence that there is a group of women who have a special need for pills of that particular type, a spokesman for the agency said today.

title: Use of Electric Power Gains Only 2% for Year, but Revenues Soar
description: Despite predictions earlier this year of a 5 percent increase in electric power sales by the nation's investorowned electric utilities, the gain in 1975 will be less than 2 percent over 1979, a year when no growth was registered.

title: FACTION IN ANGOLA SAYS RIVALS CLASH
description: LONDON, Dec. 23 (Reuters)The Luanda radio said today that serious fighting was going on in central Angola between forces of two allied nationalist groupsthe Union for the Total Independence of Angola and the National Front for the Liberation of Angola.

title: Advertising
description: When it comes to promoting itself, The New Yorker is not a verse to experimenting with media vehicles. Now it's about to use a Zamboni.

title: A Black TV Station Struggles to Make It
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23WGPRTV, Channel 62 in Detroit, the first blackowned, blackoperated television station in the continental United States, has not had an easy time since it went on the air last Sept. 29.

title: Money Supply Erratic
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The Federal Reserve Board and its staff now believe that the recent erratic and puzzling movements, of the nation's money supplydemand deposits and currency  may have been caused in considerable part by a littlenoticed change in banking regulations that permits businesses to have savings accounts in banks.

title: Jim McGlothlin, 32, Pitched For the Reds in 1970 Series
description: UNION, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP)Jim McGlothlin, who compiled a 1410 wonlost record while helping the Cincinnati Reds win a pennant and pitched in two World Series games in 1970, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 32 years old.

title: KISSINGER INSISTS STAND ON ANGOLA WILL NOT CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, warning that SovietAmerican tensions might rise, said today that the Ford Administration would continue to opposethrough available military aid and diplomatic means the imposition of a Sovietbacked regime in Angola by force.

title: Fannin Will Retire From Senate in '76; Sixth to Take Step
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 23Senator Paul J. Fannin, Republican of Arizona, became today the sixth United States Senator to announce that he would not seek reelection in 1976.

title: COCOA FUTURES DOWN 2C LIMIT
description: Cocoa futures dropped the daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the New York Cocoa Exchange under some heavy profit taking. Speculators, who had bought cocoa futures last week, were in the market selling following the rise of the March contract to a new contract high of 65.50 cents a pound Monday

title: CONGRESSMEN SAY HANOI SEEKS U.S. AID
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 23 The first official American delegation to visit Hanoi since the end of the Vietnam war arrived here today and reported that agreement had been reached that acts of reciprocity should be a part of improving relations.

title: MORGAN BANK SEES ECONOMIC GAIN IN '76
description: Next year could be a year of impressive economic gain according to a report in the Morgan Guaranty Survey released yesterday. Bank Anallysts foresee a possible real growth of 5 to 7 percent next year, fueled by an upswing in both business and consumer spending.

title: AMEX STOCKS UP; OTC ISSUES MIXED
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange yesterday closed higher while those in the overthe  counter market ended mixed.

title: Radio
description: 7:258:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Overture to Hansel and Gretel, Humperdinck; The Three. Bears, Coates; La Boite a Joujoux, Debussy; Cinderella, Prokofiev; Ma Mere L'Oye, Ravel.

title: Curtain Descends in Algiers on OPEC Terrorists' Fate
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 23 (Reuters)A group of proPalestinian guerrillas who burst into an oil ministers' meeting in Vienna on Sunday freed the last of their hostages at the airport here early today and rode into Algiers by car.

title: Praise and Scorn for London Hamlet
description: LONDONProbably more people have thought Hamlet a work of art because they found it interesting, than have found it interesting because it is a work of art T. S. Eliot once said. It is the Mona Lisa of literature.

title: Withdrawal of Cuban Unit From Golan Is Reported
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 23 (UPI)A Cuban armored brigade that served on the Syrian frontlines for the last two years has been withdrawn and apparently sent to Angola, Government sources said today.

title: First $2.6 Million in Election Funds Authorized
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Federal financing of political campaigns, one of the major reforms enacted after Watergate, began today when the Federal Election Commission authorized the Treasury Department to make initial payments totaling $2.6 million to the two major political parties and to 11 Presidential contenders:

title: Roosevelt Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: W. B. GATES JR., 58, ECONOMIST, DEAD
description: William B. Gates Jr., Kennan Professor of Economics at Williams College, died Monday at North Adams (Mass.) Regional Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Williamstown, Mass.

title: DONALD S. MORGAN
description: Donald S. Morgan, a retired vice president of Stone & Webster Securities Corporation, died Sunday at Palomar Memorial Hospital in Escondido, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: West Side Apartment Scene Of Best Messiah in Town
description: The best Messiah in town this season took place Monday night in the dining room of a West Side apartment. This was chamber music pushed to its jolliest extreme: a harpsichord and chamber orchestra, soloists and a chorus of 25all of them performing for Tree and handily outnumbering their audiencecrammed into a room that measured 18 feet by 22 feet.

title: DR. HERBERT GRINNELL
description: Dr. Herbert W. Grinnell, a dentist and professor emeritus of operative dentistry at the New York University School of Dentistry, died yesterday at his home at 45 Sutton Place South. He was 67 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: William P. Rogers, the former Secretary of State tinder Richard M. Nixon, was elected yesterday to The Jockey Club. Rogers is also a trustee of the New York Racing Association. As a member of The Jockey Club he joins an exclusive group, whose function is to register all thoroughbreds in this country, Canada and Puerto Rico.

title: Ford Signs Tax Cut Bill; Starts Colorado Vacation
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 23President Ford signed the $18 biltion tax cut extension today, along with nearly a score of other bills on his way to a weeklong vacation here, and then donned his skiing gear and took to the slopes.

title: Superman's Creators Get Lifetime Pay
description: With a little help from the outside, Superman came to the rescue.

title: PBS SETS PROGRAMS OF PRESS IN MOSCOW
description: Two halfhour World Press programs will be videotaped in Moscow Jan. 28 for telecast in midFebruary on the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Dance: Miss Graham's Scarlet Letter
description: The current Martha Graham season at the Mark Hellinger Theater, which runs through Jan. 3, is a triumph of modern dance. There is a feeling that modern dance can stand up to the seductive allure of classic ballet. It is a fresh allure bought at some pricewhich is the adoption of some of the qualities and manners of classic ballet. Yet this is not at all bad. Some of the mystery might have departed but the mastery remains.

title: Production of Cars Down 8% for Year; Lowest Since 1970
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23  The United States auto industry wound up 1975 with production of 6,725,682 cars, down 8 percent from 1974.

title: Prices Gain Sharply
description: Corporate bond prices rose surprisingly sharply, yesterday for a day that was supposed to slow down for the holiday week. Prices also rose, but more moderately, in the Government securities market as the Federal Reserve purchased $400 million of securities temporarily for one of its customers. Also, the Treasury's new 7 percent notes that were auctioned on Monday rose to a slight premium. All this did not add up to an earthshaking day for the credit markets, but the advance that began Dec. 10 remained intact.

title: C.I.A. Station Chief Slain Near Athens by Gunmen
description: ATHENS, Wednesday, Dec. 24The station chief of the Central Intelligence Agency in Greece was shot and killed last night by unidentified gunmen outside his home in an Athens suburb.

title: FROMME FRIENDS SEEK TO BE FREED
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP)Two close friends of Lynette Alice Fromme said today they should be freed without bail and allowed to defend themselves against charges of conspiring to mail 171 threatening letters to business and government leaders.

title: Thrift Unit Inflow Sets Monthly High
description: Money flowed into the nation's savings and loan associations last month at a record rate for November, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Bayh's Main Premise: That He's Electable
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Senator Birch Bayh is young, liberal and a relatively fresh face on the national scene. But as a candidate for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination and as a political technician he may be the most orthodox and traditional figure in the field.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: N.H.L.Soviet Games on TV Here
description: New York area fans interested in the National Hockey League's upcoming series with two teams from the Soviet Union will be able to see four of the eight games on WPIXTV, Channel 11. Mary Albert will serve as anchor host and color man for the games with each host club supplying its playbyplay announcer.

title: About Education
description: Parents who have been pondering the advisability of giving their children handheld calculators for Christmas may be pleased to learn that the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics would approve.

title: Shopping for la Solid Gold French Fry? Try Asprey's
description: LONDON, Dec. 23A gold watch studded with 2,200 diamonds for almost $40,000. A solid sterling silver model of the Concorde, the new supersonic transport plane, so painstakingly made that no price has yet been set. A late 18thcentury bookcase for $50,000. A Chinese lacquer betrothal screen for $30,000. Or perhaps a pocket toothbrush mounted in ninecarat golda virtual bargain at only $440.

title: Toronto Art Cache Linked By Rothko Aide to Gallery
description: Between $15 million and $20 million in art works purportedly owned by the Marlborough Galleries were found yesterday in a Toronto warehouse, according to Edward J. Ross, lawyer for Kate Rothko, who had sued the gallery for mishandling the estate of her father, the abstractexpressionist painter Mark Rothko.

title: LEFTISTS ATTACK ARGENTINE DEPOT
description: BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Dec. 24A large force of left wing guerrillas tried to seize an army arsenal 10 miles south of here last night the army said early today. A communiqu said that at least 50 of the attackers were killed and that shooting was continuing in the area.

title: Cash Prices
description: Tuesday. Dec. 23, 1975

title: Deaths
description: ABELSONEmma, beloved wife of George, dear sister of Anna Goldin, Pauline Silverman, Samuel Schwartz and Diana Pincus. Services Wednesday, 1:15 P.M., at The Riverside Brooklyn, Ocean Pkwy. at Prospect Park.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that banks could not legally excuse themselves, even through written agreements with customers, from responsibility for night deposits. The Appellate Division of Superior Court made the ruling in reinstating a claim for $1,585 against the New Jersey Bank in Passaic County by the HyGrade Oil Company.

title: Tarkenton To Start in Pro Bowl
description: Seven Minnesota Vikings, led by Fran Tarkenton and Chuck Foreman, have been selected to start for the National Football Conference team on Jan. 26 in the annual Pro Bowl.

title: Court Rules Police Heads May Punish Officers Who Insult Them in Public
description: NEWARK, Dec. 23 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that police superiors may discipline lowerranking officers who dis parage them in public.

title: Not Out of Sight But in Front
description: CAPETOWNSouth Africa's Prime Minister John Vorster, the 60yearold National Party leader who has been guiding his country through storms for almost a decade, has a wellarticulated principle of leadership. I have always thought, he told me, that a leader must walk in front of his people; but he should never go so far as to move out of their sight and hearing.

title: REV.EDWIN QUAIN OF FORDHAM DIES
description: The Rev. Edwin A. Quain, a Fordham University teacher and administrator, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: City Businesses to Shut Early on Christmas Eve
description: Most New York City businesses plan to close early for Christmas Eve, according to a survey by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and there will be extra trains on commuter railroads to handle the prospective exodus.

title: Graft Inquiry Begun in Nightclub Blaze
description: The city is initiating an investigation to determine whether extensive corruption uncovered among people in the construction and realestate industries and employees in the Buildings Department may have played a role in city supervision of the Blue Angel nightclub, where seven people died in a fire last Thursday.

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Vow a Vendetta Against 2 Rebels in the Council
description: The Republican county leaders of Brooklyn and the Bronx vowed yesterday to end the political careers of two Republican rebel Councilmen at Large who had voted to oust the Council's minority leader, Angelo J. Arculeo, Republican of Brooklyn.

title: SPAIN IS TESTING ITS POLICE POLICY
description: MADRID, Dec. 23  Some small steps, including the settlement of a Madrid taxi strike today without incident, have been interpreted here as the first signs that the Government will move to carry out the new policy announced over the weekend by Interior Minister Manuel Fraga Iribarne that the Government intends to distinguish between adversaries and enemies.

title: 400,000 Holiday Tourists Jam Hotels on Both Florida Coasts
description: MIAMI, Dec. 23 (UPI)Some 1400,000 tourists have swarmed into Florida for the ChristmasNew Year's holiday, filling most hotels along both coasts, travel industry authorities say. And 100,000 more are expected.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: JINGL E BELLS Alexander Schneider, who has become as much a Christmas Eve tradition in New York as Santa Claus, will be giving his seventh annual concert at midnight tonight at Carnegie Hall. Actually, tonight's performance with the New York String Orchestra is part of a series of holiday concerts by Mr. Schneider.

title: C.I.A. Station Chief Slain Near Athens by Gunmen
description: ATHENS, Wednesday, Dec. 24The station chief of the Central Intelligence Agency in Greece was shot and killed last night by unidentified gunmen outside his home in an Athens suburb.

title: Saigon Primate Bids Catholics Help Build A Reunified Nation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Archbishop Nguyen Van Binh of Saigon issued a Christmas message today urging Roman Catholics to help build an independent and reunified Vietnam.

title: When the Well Went Dry It Was Part of the Course
description: KALYMNOS, GreeceEleven young Americans have been living on this small Greek island for the last three months, and the other day their well dried up. They had to walk two miles each way to fetch fresh water.

title: Junior Assembly Is Held at Plaza
description: The Junior Assembly, held during the Thanksgiving holidays for the last four years, took place in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza last night. Mrs. Charles C. Lee Jr., this year's chairman, explained the switch in schedule this way: So many girls and boys don't come home for Thanksgiving we thought Christmas might be more festive.

title: LEFTISTS ATTACK ARGENTINE POSTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Dec. 24Five hundred leftist guerrillas attacked an army arsenal, police stations and an army regimental compound last night at points around Buenos Aires.

title: POLITICAL THEFTS LAID TO EXDEPUTY
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)A former. Santa Clan County deputy sheriff and longtime Republican Party activist committed at least 17 buiglaries of the offices of various liberal and radical organizations according to a municipal court document.

title: Toronto Art Cache Linked By Rothko Aide to Gallery
description: Between $15 million and $20 million in art works purportedly owned by the Marlborough Galleries were found yesterday in a Toronto warehouse, according to Edward J. Ross, lawyer for Kate Rothko, who had sued the gallery for mishandling the estate of her father, the abstractexpressionist painter Mark Rothko.

title: Selling New York Short
description: The current controversy over the location of the Convention Center reflects, we believe, something more significant than kicking a corpse around. Pronounced dead, the center shows surprising vitality. Its specter has now been raised at Battery Park City and at 34th Street; whether funds can be raised is another matter. But the fact remains that the Convention Center is an essential reinforcement for New York. It would build on one of the city's unique strengthsits service industries and cultural and entertainment resourcesto create jobs and an improved economy. That it has refused die is a hopeful sign.

title: U. S. Journal Named Welch
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Mr. Welch was identified as a C.I.A. clandestine operative last summer by Counterspy, a quarterly. Washington publication that came out of the war resistance movement three years ago.

title: The Superprosecutof
description: For three years Maurice Hyman Nadjari was a prosecu, for with exceptional powersand exceptional problems. He was the first and only prosecutor in the United States appointed for the sole purpose of cleaning up a soiled criminal justice system. During his first 18 months he won a string of major courtroom victories, including the conviction of a District Attorney and a City Tax Commissioner. At one point, admirers and headline writers labeled him superprosecutor.

title: 300 Stage Rally To Show Support For Blumenthal
description: About 300 politicians, officials and constituents turned out last night to show support for Albert H. Blumenthal the liberal Democrat who several weeks ago was indicted for perjury in connection with the investigation of nursing homes.

title: Mosley Returns to Spark 7566 Seton Hall Victory
description: SOUTH ORANGE. N. J., Dec. 23 (AP)Glenn Mosley, returning from a 21game suspension for a recruiting violation, hit for 16 points and pulled down 16 rebounds as Seton Hall defeated St. Francis of Brooklyn, 7566, tonight.

title: New Nations Join Search for the Man Known as Carlos
description: Austria and a number of oil producing countries have now joined the growing list of those eager to lay their hands on a pudgy young Venezuelan called Carlos.

title: James F. Lee Dead at 70; Was Writer for U.S. News
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)James F. Lee, a journalist for 48 years and a writer for U.S. News & World Report from 1959 until his retirement this year, died Monday at Georgetown Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Six days before Britain's new sexdiscrimination law goes into effect, some members of the House. of Commons challenged an ancient traditionthe natural succession of male heirs to the throne. Calling the women in the royal family to be given equal opportunity for the top job, they proposed that Princess Anne, now fourth in line of succession, move up to second. The 25yearold princess, two years younger than Prince Charles, now ranks behind her younger brothers, Prince Andrew and Prince Edward. Robert KilroySilk, a Labor M.P., said yesterday,  If you're going to make decisions on the basis of age, then sex should be irrelevant

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Dunlop Pondering Resignation As the Picket Bill Veto Looms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Secretary of Labor John T. Dunlop went home to Massachusetts today for a long, reflective holiday weekend after telling friends that he would take two or three weeks to decide whether to resign from the Cabinet.

title: ANN ZALKIND SHOWS GRACE AT THE PIANO
description: Although most of the concerts at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. are produced by the Y's education department, the Kaufmann Auditorium is available for rentals, and with a ipiano recital Monday night, Ann Zalkind became the first nonaffiliated artist to use the hall since it reopened several weeks ago.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the neatest plays of the year was made on the diagramed deal, reported by Kalman Rosenbluth of Hewlett, L.I., from a duplicate game at the Grand Baldwin Bridge Studio, Baldwin, L.I. The road to 12 tricks in notrump is not obvious with all four hands exposed, but Harry Silberstein of Far Rockaway, Queens, uncovered the winning line at the table.

title: Right on Energy. . .
description: President Ford showed a firm grasp in locating the public interest amid conflicting values when he signed into law the comprehensive Energy Policy and Conservation Act of 1975. Resisting the insistent wiles thepetroleum industryand the political contributions and influence which the oilmen might bring to bear in next year's electionMr. Ford correctly perceived that, on balance, enactment of this complex measure would benefit the public far more than its veto.

title: Muncie Wins Award
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP)Chuck Muncie, an allAmerican at the University of California, got another honor today when he was named winner of the annual Pop Warner Award. The award is made by the Palo Sports Club to the West Coast's most valuable college football player as determined by a vote of sports writers and broadcasters. Muncie will receive it at the club's annual awards dinner Jan. 27

title: Protection Debated
description: VIENNA, Dec. 23  M. O. Feyide, a Nigerian who is Secretary General of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said today that it was the Austrian authorities who had determined the appropriate security measures for protecting OPEC headquarters during ministerial meetings.

title: Chris Evert Rated No. 1 Again in U.S.
description: Chris Evert, winner of 14 tournaments; including the United States Open, and $350,000. has been ranked No. 1 in the country for the second straight year.

title: F.T.C. Seeksto End Ban On Eyeglass Price Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The Federal Trade Commission proposed today a nationwide rule permitting price advertising of, eyeglasses, charging that existing prohibitions keep prices high and prevent the poor from getting glasses.

title: The Superprosecutor
description: For three years Maurice Hyman Nadjari was a prosecutor with exceptional powersand exceptional problems. He was the first and only prosecutor in the United States appointed for the sole purpose of cleaning up a soiled criminal justice system. During his first 18 months he won a string of major courtroom victories, including the conviction of a District Attorney and a City Tax Commissioner. At one point, admirers and headline writers labeled him superprosecutor.

title: Holiday Hiring Lags This Year
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23The nation's holiday buying rush is almost over, and many retail stores are optimistically reporting better sales than in 1974. But it hasn't been a bountiful holiday season for many Americansespecially among the hardcore unemployedwho had hoped to increase their income with a temporary Christmas Job.

title: RISE IN OIL IMPORTS FORESEEN IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) The United States in 1977 will be forced to import 50 percent more oil than it does today, a Library of Congress study says.

title: Angolan War Divides Europe, With Germany Backing U.S.
description: LONDON, Dec. 23  European nations are in quiet disagreement over the Angolan civil war and its impact on Western security. Britain and France view Angola with nervousness and some uncertainty, while West Germany adheres to the Ford Administration's view that the war is crucial to EastWest relations.

title: Horse's Owner Files Suit to Build a Barn
description: MORRISTOWN, Dec. 23 (AP)An exclusionary zoning suit pits the East Hanover Board of Adjustment against a 14yearold quarter horse named Jalico whose owner charges that the goldenbrown animal was unfairly denied housing in the small suburban Morris County community.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: Tuesday, Dec. 23, 1975

title: Byrne Lauds Blood Donor
description: TRENTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)Ernest Pentek, the top blood donor in New Jersey, was honored by Governor Byrne today for donating 156 pints. The 56yearold Mr. Penter, of Newark, is an area manager for the United States Postal Service Security Division. After congratulating him, Mr. Byrne signed a proclamation making Dec. 26 through Jan. 2 blood donor week.

title: City Schools Reach Accord on Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23New York City school officials and the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, reached a compromise today that should avert legal action against five local school districts that have failed to cooperate with a civilrights investigation.

title: ExF.B.I. Agent Suing for Reinstatement
description: NEWARK, Dec. 23A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was discharged two years ago after be had criticized the bureau's handling of a loanfraud investigation sued in Federal Court here today for the return of his job and all back pay.

title: EXTORTION IS LAID TO EXDETECTIVES
description: Frank E. King, considered the prime suspect in the French Connection theft of $70 million worth of narcotics from police custody, and three other former members of a nowdefunct police narcotics unit were indicted yesterday on charges of extorting thousands of dollars from major drug dealers.

title: Boy's Lottery Claim Is Reconsidered
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 23Under mounting public criticism, Connecticut's Commission on Special Revenue, decided today to reconsider its decision two weeks ago to deny Barry Brunelle a $10,000 state lottery prize because he was only 17 and too young to have bought a ticket legally.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, Dec. 23, 1975

title: Lisbon's Shops Are Full of Joy but Short of Good
description: LISBON, Dec. 23  Lisbon shops were full of Christmas joy today but short of such vital necessities as milk, butter and eggs.

title: NOTE MORATORIUM UPHELD BY COURT; APPEAL PLANNED
description: Declaring that we must deal with this subject realistically, State Supreme Court Justice J. Harold Baer yesterday upheld the moratorium enacted by the Legislature on the payment of principal of $1.6 billion in maturing shortterm city notes.

title: College Students Give Hand to Neediest
description: Students on college ??puses, preparing for the holidays, have taken the time to remember those less fortunate and are turning up in increasing numbers in the list of contributors to the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: U.S. Judge, in Coast Case, Rules Long Solitary Confinement illegal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23Judge Alfonso. J. Zirpoli of Federal District Court ruled there last week that a long confinement in San Quentin Prison's maximum security adjustment section constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth and 14th Amendments to the United States Constitution.

title: Bayh's Main Premise: That He's Electable
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 Senator Birch Bayh is young, liberal and a relatively fresh face on the national scene. But as a candidate for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination and as a political technician he may be the most orthodox and traditional figure in the field.

title: Palestinians Report Operations
description: BEIRUT, Wednesday, Dec. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Palestinian press outlet, Wafa, said last night that guerrillas had mounted three operations in Israelioccupied territory over the last 48 hours.

title: Arbitrator Frees 2 Baseball Stars
description: A labor arbitrator ruled yesterday that two pitchers, Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally, were free agents who were no longer bound by their baseball contracts and could sell their services to the highest bidder.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1975

title: DR. HUBERT MANN
description: Dr. Hubert Mann, a cardiologist who specialized in the design, construction and operation of instruments for examining the heart and circulation. died Monday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 84

title: F.B.I. Says Crime in U.S. Rose By 11% in First 9 Months of '75
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) Serious crime reported in the United States rose 11 percent in the first nine months of 1975, but the rate of increase was less than for the same period a year ago, according to F.B.I. statistics released today.

title: Bay State Population Rises
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)The population of Massachusetts has grown to 5.79 million, according to the latest state census, an increase of 4.5 percent from that of 1971. The 1971 population figure was 5.539 million.

title: The Joyous Lilts of Christmas Cast a Spell Here
description: Like an echo bouncing back and forth across New York, the sound of music and Christmas carols are sweetening the harsh cacophony of the city these days as New Yorkers prepare for Christmas.

title: Decision on Yonkers Budget Is Put Off
description: YONKERS, Dec. 23  The Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board today postponed until Friday a decision on how to cut the city's budget by $15 million over the next 18 months.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. warning that SovietAmerican tensions might rise, said the Ford Administration would continue to use available military aid and diplomatic means to oppose the imposition of a Sovietbacked regime in Angola by force. At a Washington news conference he said the Senate vote against further secret financing in the Angolan civil war had severely complicated Administration efforts for a diplomatic solution. He said available means would be used to oppose Soviet expansion, even if SovietAmerican relations were set back. He pledged no American forces would go to Angola. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: benezer Scrooge,
description: SCRANTON, Pa.Could it be that Ebenezer Scrooge was merely the victim of bad public relations?

title: Christmas Spirit
description: Obviously, the arbitration award making Andy Messersmith and Dave McNally free agents came as no surprise to the men who own baseball, for they already had a paper prepared and signed firing the arbitrator, As soon as Peter Seitz delivered his opinion, John Gaherin, the owners' representative in labor matters, handed him a letter dismissing him as umpire in grievance cases. The owners and the players' union had agreed on Seitz as successor to another professional arbitrator, Gabriel Alexander of Detroit, slightly more than a year ago under an agreement providing that his services could be terminated by either party. Remembering that it was Peter Seitz who shook Catfish Hunter off Charlekfinley's hookthey couldn't possibly forgetthe powers, archangels and angels of the baseball hierarchy had decided before yesterday that they wanted an impartial arbitrator who would be more impartial on their side.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: South Jersey Gas Wins A $5.3 Million Rate Rise
description: NEWARK, Dec. 23 (UPI)The South Jersey Gas Company today was granted a $5.3 million rate increase which will raise utility bills an average of 14 percent.

title: Ford Is Horrified
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 23 (UPI)President Ford issued a statement tonight on the killing of Mr. Welch:

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, December 23, 1975

title: COURT BARS SALE OF RAIL PROPERTY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) A special reorganization court barred trustees of seven financiallyfailing Northeastern railroads today from selling or transferring without prior Government aproval rail properties that the Government hopes to include in the Conrail system.

title: Syria and Palestinians Accused Of Assaulting a City in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23Heavy clashes broke out again today around the predominantly Christian town of Zahle, about 30 miles east of here, amid charges of Syrian and Palestinian guerrilla involvement in the fighting.

title: Even for Single Parent, It's a Family Holiday
description: Fiveyearold Tulio Arroyo, child of divorce, may or may not get a Tiny Mighty Mo truck for Christmas tomorrow.

title: Barnard Picks 2 for Board
description: The board of trustees of Barnard College has named Roger Morley, vice chairman of the American Express Company, and Blanche K. Grauhard, president of the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College from 1972 to 1975, as new hoard members.

title: Court Rules for Du Pont On Merger of Christiana
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. announced last night that the. Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., had ruled in favor of Du Pont in a stockholder suit alleging violations of Federal securities laws in the proposed merger of the Christiana Securities Company into Du Pont.

title: E.E.C. BACKING PLAN AT BRITISH CHRYSLER
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP)The European Economic Community Commission has decided that the financial aid envisaged by the British Government for Chrysler United Kingdom Ltd. is compatible with CommOn Market treaty rules. a commission spokesman announced today The commission also went along with limited import restrictions announced by the British Government in Londcin last week even though it reiterated its opinion that unilateral import curbs were inopportune, the spokessaid.

title: Alabama Ruling Permits Courtroom TV
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23  For the first time since Colorado approved the practice nearly 20 years ago, a state supreme court has promulgated a rule that would allow television broadcasting from courtrooms.

title: Knicks Win 2d On Road
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23The New York Knicks, with a balanced attack, broke a road jinx tonight by defeating the Milwaukee Bucks in a National Basketball Association game, 110108. John Gianelli's 15footer from the side was the clinching shot.

title: Never Say Die
description: Poets have been saying for centuries that what most distinguishes mankind from other animal species is his longing for immortality. In striving for immortality, however, no human endeavor can match the staying power of bureaucracy.

title: Harvey Phillips Offers Solo Repertory for Tuba
description: Haryey PhilipsMr. Tuba himself, if you willplayed at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night in the 197576 Tuba Series that would not exist were it not for Mr. Phillips and his zeal for the big bass instrument.

title: HONEY WELL PLANS MERGER FOR UNIT
description: Honeywell Inc. said yesterday that agreements had been signed to merge its French computer subsidiary, Compagnie Honeywell Bull, with the generalpurpose computer business of Compagnie Internationale Pour l'Informatique. Honeywell said it would receive a cash payment of about $58 million on the closing.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: W. BERNARD CARLSON JR.
description: W. Bernard Carlson Jr., a principal in the New York law firm of Miller & Carlson, died Monday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune, N. J. He was 51 years old and lived in West Long Branch, N. J.

title: BYRNE VOWS TO FIGHT NEW OIL REFINERIES
description: TRENTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)Governor Byrne said today that he would fight tooth and nail to prevent the construction of oil refineries along the New Jersey coastline, even if it means he must go to court.

title: GAC CORP. UNIT FILES CHAPTER XI PETITION
description: GAC Properties Inc., community development and land sales subsidiary of the GAC Corporation, filed yesterday a petition under Chapter XI of the bankruptcy laws.

title: Globe Challenges Ruling
description: BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP)The Boston Globe his challenged Judge McLaughlin's restrictions.

title: The Dance
description: No one who has ever seen Murray Louis dance has to be reminded of his extraordinary skills, but few are aware of just how long he has maintained his special level or artistry. On Tuesday evening Program II of his company's current season at New York University's School of Education auditorium gave a 20year retrospective of his fascinating career.

title: Retarded Man, 23, Dies In Crown Heights Fire
description: A 23yearold mentally retarded Brooklyn man, home for the Christmas holiday from a state institution, died yesterday in a threealarm fire that destroyed the threestory brick and wood house occupied by his family at 743 Lincoln Place, in the Crown Heights section.

title: Radiation Dynamics Reaches A Settlement with Firestone
description: Radiation Dynamics Inc. said yesterday it has reached a settlement with the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company its former controlling shareholder. The accord, concerns certain claims the companies may have had against each other as a result of Radiation Dynamics' purchase from Firestone and its shareholders of Radiation Dynamics common stock in late 1974 and the issuance of certain interim financial statements of Radiation Dynamics for the first three quarters of 1974.

title: Sealing a Door, Pope Ends Holy Year
description: ROME, Thursday, Dec. 25Pope Paul VI ended the Holy Year last night in a Christmas Eve ceremony sealing the Holy Door of St. Peter's Basilica.

title: Deaths
description: ARMSTRONGGeorge N., of Wilton, Conn, on December 21, 1975. Husband of Janet Thompson Armstrong. Father of Thomas and James Armstrong and Mrs. Herbert M. Johnson. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Memorial services Tuesday, December 30, 11 A.M., at the Congregational Church in Wilton, Conn. In lieu of flowers danations to Amherst. College would be appreciated.

title: U.N., Citing Desperate Need, Bids 77 Nations Aid Comoros
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 24  The United Natons has appealed to 77 governments to help the Comoro Islands. It says the former French, colony is in desperate need of food, medicines and technical assistance.

title: Commercial Loans Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Commercial and industrial loans outstanding rose $416 million to $119 billion in the week ending Dec. 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This was $11.2 million lower than the level of business loans outstanding in the same week a yar ago.

title: Belgrade Reports Arrest of 200 In Underground Groups in '75
description: BELGRADE, Yogoslavia, Dec. 24The head of Yugoslavia's police reported today that about 200 political criminals from 13 different underground groups had been arrested in this country during 1975.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Residents of four areas in New Yorfk City who had protested the planned closing of precinct station houses received a Christmas present yesterday when Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd nounced that the station nouses would remain open.

title: SOME COUNTS VOIDED IN HODGE MURDER
description: Justice Edward J. Greenfield of State Supreme Court yesterday dismissed the counts against Beverly Donna Hodge that involve felony murder.

title: Knicks'
description: AT GARDEN. 7:30 P.M. RADIOWNEW, 7:30 P.M.

title: Conrail Plans 30Day Delay In a TakeOver of 7 Roads
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation, a new Governmentcontrolled corporation formed to reorganize the bankrupt railroads of the Northeast, plans a 30day delay in taking over the properties of the seven roads, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Postal Ruling Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The Court of Appeals, which had been expected to rule today on a decision that blocked a postal rate increase, has scheduled arguments for Monday. An order by United States District Judge John J. Sirica prevents the Postal Service from raising firstclass letter rates from 10 to 13 cents.

title: ARGENTINE TROOPS KILL 45 LEFTISTS
description: QUILMES, Argentina, Dec. 24Soldiers killed at least 45 leftwing guerrillas who tried to storm an arsenal here in a battle that lasted until early today.

title: MRS. ALLEN LEFFERTS
description: BAYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 24Mrs. Helen Pierce Lefferts, widow of Allen Lefferts, who hid been an executive at Tiffany & Company, New York, died Tuesday in her home on Private Lane, Bayville, L. I. She was 78 years old.

title: OFFICER ARRESTED IN MIDDLESEX THEFT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 24 (AP)A sixth local policeman was arreted today as a result of an investigation into thefts and was charged with breaking into a liquor store earlier this year.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Weekend of College Football Bowls Coming Up
description: Nebraska's football coach, Tom Osborne, says timing is more important than talent in bowl games.

title: 5 Years for Threat to Ford
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Dec. 24 (AP)Patrick Scott, 26 years old, was sentenced today to a maximum term of five years in prison for threatening the lives of President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller. He was sentenced by United States District Court Judge Wendell A. Miles.

title: Guerrillas in Custody
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 24 (Reuters)The six proPalestinian guerrillas who took ministers from oilproducing countries as hostages were still in Algerian custody today with their fate undecided, officials said.

title: U.S. SLOW TO WARN SOVIET ON ANGOLA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The United States first expressed concern over the Angolan civil war to the Soviet Union in September, a topranking Administration official said today.

title: PORTUGAL ELECTION DUE BEFORE APRIL 25
description: LISBON, Dec. 24Portugal's Government announced today that national legislative elections would be held before April 25the second anniversary of the bloodless revolution against the rightwing dictatorship.

title: The Prison Attorney
description: The legal petition for clemency filed on behalf of Martin Sostre, who has spent almost all of his adult life in jail, described him as intelligent, articulate, sensitive and percentive, a highly principled civil and human rights activist, a person who has shown and continues to show an unbroken spirit despite the traumas he has suffered.

title: New Resort in Poconos To Open This Weekend
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Dec, 24At a time in the economy when new ski areas are a rarity, Karl Hope, the head of the ShawneeonDelaware housing and sports complex, will open a well rounded ski center on Saturday as part of the complex. The development in the Poconos Mountains, which overlooks the Delaware River, is only a short shuss from the Delaware Water Gap. It will feature two double chairlifts and a snowmaking system that would do justice to a much larger layout.

title: To Stay or Not to Stay: Many Here Await Union Carbide Decision
description: Two years ago, Union Carbide Company began a painstaking study of whether it should give up its handsome 50story headquarters tower on Park Avenue and move most of its staff of 3,600 out of New York City.

title: 7 Yugoslav Miners Killed
description: ALEKSINAC, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Seven miners were killed when water and mud flooded a corridor 1,800 feet below the ground in a coal mine here this week. Rescue teams recovered four bodies yesterday, the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug reported. Three bodies were recovered Monday.

title: DAVID GRUPP
description: David Grupp, who had been a tympanist and percussionist with Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, died Tuesday at his home, 10615 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. He was 77 years old.

title: Ski Conditions
description: (Reports are supplied by resort owners. Not all lifts operating.)

title: When HoHo Becomes HoHum, Here Are Entertainments for Children
description: Films

title: Newswordy Event
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24When The New York Times, which publishes about 75 million words a year, chooses a new dictionary to serve as its primaryguide for meaning and spelling, that's big news in the world of words.

title: NEWS MEDIA WARY ON PRETRIAL RULE
description: BOSTON Dec. 24 (UPI)Some Boston news executives are uncertain about how to respond to a judge's order restricting coverage of pretrial proceedings in the Susan Saxe murder case.

title: New Canaan Becomes a Christmas Eve Picture Book
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 24Christmas Eve began here tonight as it always has, sometime between the arrival of the 6:14 train from New York and the magic moment when the last commuter trudged up the hill from the station to join his family on the Town Green with the band beginning to play Hark! The Herald Angels Sing.

title: FED REDUCES RULE ON BANK RESERVES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The Federal Reserve Board announced today a small reduction in required reserves that banks must maintain against time deposits with a maturity of six months to four years.

title: David Patten, 87, ExEditor Of Providence Newspapers
description: BARRINGTON. R.I., Dec. 24 (AP)  David Patten, retired managing editor of The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, died yesterday at the age of 87.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Girl, 13, Sues To Join Quintet
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 24 (AP)A United States District Court suit seeking to allow a girl to play on her junior high school's allmale basketball team was filed by an American Civil Liberties Union attorney today. Michael Dollinger of the A.C.L.U. said the suit seeks to force the Rhode island Junior Hich School Interscholastic League to abandon its practice of excluding girls from participation in basketball. The action was filed on behalf of 13yearold Jane Moran, an eighthgrade student at Nicholas A. Ferri Middle School in Johnson, R.I.

title: Energy Policy Debate: Some Major Issues Remain
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24In signing the Energy Policy and Conservation Act Monday, President Ford said, The time has come to end the long debate over national energy policy in the United States and to put ourselves solidly on the road to energy independence. Five sentences later, Mr. Ford commented that this bill is only a beginning.

title: PLANET FEATURES GET NOTED NAMES
description: Astronomers and space scientists from many countries are wrestling with a cultural Crisis.

title: NEW RULE IS SET FOR ROUND LOTS
description: NEW RULE IS SET FOR ROUND LOTS

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OMAN SULTAN SEES SOUTH YEMEN PERIL
description: The Sultan of Oman, Qabus bin Said, accused neighboring Southern Yemen yesterday of continuing military action against Oman after the recent suppression of a Yemenibacked insurrection in the mountains of Dhofar Province.

title: People in Sports
description: The Oklahoma football team left home today and headed for its Orange Bowl date (in Miami) with Michigan on New Year's Night Without Horace Ivory, its No. 2 ground gainer. The Sooners head coach, Barry Switzer, confirmed that Ivory had been dismissed from the squad for personal reasons.

title: Research on Orient Breed Is Revealing
description: Ruth Aston is a woman with a mission. For almost two decades she has been doing research on the ch'in breeds. In this country only the Japanese spaniel really is known, she said. However, it is but one of eight type of breeds called the ch'in in the Orient.

title: MRS. ALLEN LEFFERTS
description: BAYVILLE, L.I., Dec. 24Mrs. Helen Pierce Lefferts, widow of Allen Lefferts, who had been an executive at Tiffany & Company, New York, died Tuesday in her home on Private Lane, Bayville, L. I. She was 78 years old.

title: STATE SEEKS SHIFT IN BUYING OF LAND
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24 (AP)The state's chief environmental officer agreed today that past recreational land purchases by the state had been weighted toward rural areas, but he said a new program was attempting to shift the balance to more populous urban and suburban areas.

title: GROSSMAN PICKED AS PBS PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24Lawrence K. Grossman, a New York advertising executive with longstanding associations in the television industry, has been recommended to the board of governors of the Public Broadcasting Service as its next president.

title: Paid Layoffs for 1,300 Bring Cheer to a Plant
description: HOBOKEN, Dec. 24There was joy and exultation at the gates of the big Maxwell House coffee plant here this Christmas Eve, as 1,300 workers began an abruptly announced paid layoff until Jan. 5.

title: Jacques A. Mitchell Jr., 69, McKessonRobbins Officer
description: Jacques A. Mitchell Jr., treasurer of McKesson & Robbins Company in New York from 1948 until his retirement in 1966, died Tuesday of cancer in the Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, Vt. Mr. Mitchell, who lived in Dorset, Vt., was 69 years old.

title: Court Rules Utah State U. Not Liable in Stock Losses
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The Utah Supreme Court ruled yesterday that Utah State University was not liable for the losses sustained by companies that sold stock to the school during an illegal investment program.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Pilgrim Throng in Bethlehem Is Biggest in 8 Years
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, Thursday, Dec. 25 (UPI)Thousands of pilgrims converged on this Judean hilltop town to observe Christmas in the traditional birthplace of Jesus.

title: Bridge:
description: Players who enjoy themselves by waving a piece of paper in the faces of their bridgeplaying friends and announcing Bet you can't make this have certain favorite hands. Judging from readers' letters, the most popular is the one shown in the diagram, which is at least 20 years old.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The St. Joseph Light and Power Company said yesterday it planned to make a public offering in late March of 300,000 common shares through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc.

title: Holiday Shopping List for 2 L.I. Men: Bail for Inmates, Dinners for Orphans
description: Sal Miglio said yesterday he did not believe Christmas meant shopping for material things in department stores.

title: Germans Capture Kangaroo
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP) A kangaroo that escaped from a circus has been recaptured following 66 days of freedom in the East German countryside, the official press agency reported yesterday.

title: Seoul's Holiday Jail Release
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday Dec. 25 (Reuters)The South Korean Government today released 2,500 prisoners from jails and reformatories in a Christmas Day amnesty. It was not immediately known whether the prisoners freed included any political opponents of the Government.

title: Books of The Times
