description: Tom Burnam's The Dictionary of Misinformation is not the first book of its kind. As Professor Burnam, who teaches English at Portland State University, Oregon, points out in his Acknowledgments, his project descends from a long line of forebears, among them Bergen Evans's Natural History of Nonsense, Vilhjalmur Stefansson's Adventures in Error, Ashley Montagu's and Edward Darling's The Prevalence of Nonsense, as well as the same two authors' The Ignorance of Certainty. Nor is the book loosely speaking a dictionary, because one doesn't know what one is misinformed about and therefore can't conceive what one ought to be looking up. (Not included anywhere are the only items of misinformation that offhand occurred to menamely, the primary meaning of internecine, which is actually deadly; mutually destructive, and the notion that Roger Maris failed to hit 61 home runs in 154 games, which is incorrect because he did not hit his first home run in 1961 until the 11th game the Yankees played.)

title: NML Bond Fund Formed
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Milwaukee said yesterday it had introduced a new mutual fund, NML Bond Fund Inc., as an alternative investment vehicle for its variable annuity contracts. The NML Bond Fund will invest primarily in debt securities, the insurance company said.

title: BISTATEAREA JOBS AT A 10YEAR LOW
description: The number of jobs in the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan are fell to the lowest level in 10 years in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: People and Business
description: W. Clement Stone, a Chicago insurance millionaire, bas increased his common stock holdings in the AlbertoCulver Company, a major producer of toiletries that is also engaged in manufacturing household and rocery products.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Soldiers killed at least 45 leftwing guerrillas who attempted to storm an arsenal outside Buenos Aires. An Argentinian Army communique said that in the pursuit in surrounding areas the death toll may have reached 100. Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla, the army commander, called it a resounding triumph for the forces of order? against the biggest operation ever mounted by leftwing extremists. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: No Negotiations Are Scheduled In 9WeekOld Elevator Strike
description: Residents of buildings whose elevators have been out of service because of the nineweekold strike of maintenance and repairman will probably have to continue climbing stairs over the Christmas holidays.

title: Argentine Race Postponed
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24 (AP)The Automobile Club of Argentina said today that it was postponing the Argentine Formula One Grand Prix race, scheduled for Jan. 11, because of cost increases and a lack of time for organization. A new date will be sought for the event.

title: Bentsen Problem a Lack Of National Recognition
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas has traveled hundreds of thousands of miles in the last two years in search of recognition and support for his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but national polls and experienced politicians, including some within his own camp, agree that his long journey has left him essentially back on Square One.

title: Hotel Fire in Sydney Kills 18 and Hurts 23
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 25 (AP)Fire swept through a small hotel in the heart of Sydney's Kings Cross nightclub district this morning, killing 18 people and hurting 23, ambulance officials said.

title: DAVID GRUPP
description: David Grupp, who had been a tympanist and percussionist with Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, died. Tuesday at his home, 10615 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. He was 77 years old.

title: Cantata For an OvertCovert Christmas
description: Announcer

title: Thousands of Idle Taking to the Road In Search of Worth
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24Ron Bueckert, a 32yearold electrician who can earn more than $400 a week when times are good, drove his pickup truck here last week, 600 miles from his home and family in Northern California, in search of a job.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 (UPI)The Bank of England's minimum lending rate has been cut for the third time in less than two months, the bank announced today. The rate was cut onequarter percent to 11, down from the year's peak of 12 percent. Previous reductions were on Nov. 14 and 28.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: U.S. Extending Morocco $30 Million Wheat Credit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Agriculture Department announced today it had approved a $30 million of lin?? of Government credit to fi nance exports of American wheat to Morocco.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Stocks Strike Merry Note As List Climbs Broadly
description: With selling pressure notably absent, the stock market scored gains along a wide front yesterday in a shortened preChristmas session.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Use of 2 Pesticides Is Curbed by E.P.A. As Possible Hazard
description: The Environmental Protection Agency ordered yesterday the suspension of the sale of the widely used pesticides chlordane and heptachlor for most agricultural and home lawn and garden uses.

title: Line on Raiders: Weakened
description: OAKLAND, Dec. 24According to the supposedly dispassionate oddsmakers, the Oakland Raiders are favored by a touchdown in their playoff game against the Cincinnati Bengals here Sunday. According to some of the more apprehensive followers of Raider fortunes, they shouldn't be favored at all.

title: Paralyzed Man Dies in Fire
description: A partly paralyzed man was burned to death yesterday when, according to the Fire Department, a medicine he was taking causing him to grow numb and to drop a lighted cigarette on his clothing. The man, Walter Wisniewski, 57, was found dead, seated at a table in his kitchen at 171 Russell Street, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: City Can Do Little to Halt Migration of Companies
description: What can the city do to haft the migration of corporate headquarters from New York? Not much, according to Alfred E. Eisenpreis, the city's Economic Development Administrator.

title: Mrs. Bandaranaike Wins Sri Lanka Confidence Vote
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Dec. 24 (AP)Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike's majority in Parliament today easily defeated an opposition motion of no confidence charging the Prime Minister and her three children with improper land sales. The vote was 100 to 43.

title: Original Ulysses MS. Being Issued
description: The holograph manuscript of James Joyce's Ulysses is being published in facsimile for the first time this month after lying for 50 years in the hands of an American collector. The history of the manuscript and the problems of making it into a, book are both as complex as some readers find the novel.

title: Jacques A. Mitchell Jr., 69, McKesson & Robbins Aide
description: Jacques A. Mitchell Jr., treasurer of McKesson & Robbins Company in New York from 1948 until his retirement in 1966, died Tuesday of cancer in the Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, Vt. Mr. Mitchell, who lived in. Dorset, Vt.. was 69 years old.

title: Otto C. F. von Bismarck, 78, Last Grandson of Chancellor
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Dec. 24 (UPI)Otto Christian Fuerst von Bismarck, the last grandson of the Iron Chancellor and a longtime Christian Democratic Party member of Parliament, died today at the age of 78.

title: U.C.L.A. Triumphs
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP)Marques Johnson and Richard Washington produced 37 points between them last night as fourthranked University of California, Los Angeles, routed Baylor, 9675, for its 87th home victory in a row at Pauley Pavilion. Baylor's 6foot9inch sophomore center, Tony Rufus, got 32 points.

title: The Gift of Self
description: The spirit of giving that at Christmas brings families and friends together was not intended to constitute merely a brief interlude in the more selfabsorbed course of everyday living. On the contrary, the special holiday emphasis on bringing gladness to others was always meant as a reminder of the more routine need to think beyond one's own interests. At a time of general economic stress, the gift of self is particularly precious the readiness to be of service to others and, through such service, to lift the spirit and improve the condition of the community.

title: Judge Scores U.S. Prosecutor Oh Tactics in Suit by Prisoners
description: A Federal judge has accused a Federal prosecutor of resort ing to a Byzantine trap and a Catch22 device to resist a lawsuit that assails conditions in the new Metropolitan Correctional Center near Foley Square.

title: Deaths
description: ARMSTRONGGeorge N., of Wilton, Conn, on December 21, 1975. Husband of Janet Thompson Armstrong. Father of Thomas and James Armstrong and Mrs. Herbert M. Johnson. Also survived by ten grandchildren. Memorial services Tuesday, December 30, 11 A.M., at the Congregational Church in Wilton, Conn. In lieu of flowers danations to Amherst. College would be appreciated.

title: A Family's Santa Claus Letters Neatness Better Not Count
description: A wise man once said, Bah, humbug. Someone else chimed in with, God help us, each and every one  or words to that effect. And a third is known to have added to the season's joy by saying, Here's Christmas at our throats again.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports on changes in share ownership by leading directors, officers and stockholders of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: FORD AND FAMILY RELAX AT RESORT
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 24President Ford spent the day before Christmas skiing under a brilliant blue sky, relaxing with his family, attending to a few routine Presidential chores and going to a late church service.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD TRADITION For some it is family visiting; for others, Tom and Jerries around the fire. But for New Yorkers, Christmas afternoon is a movie day. Others snooze or booze.

title: I.M.F. ENLARGES CREDIT FACILITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  The International Monetary Fund's executive board approved yesterday a new and enlarged compensa tory financing facility, monetary sources said here.

title: Chess:
description: The Maroczy bind has suddenly and unexpectedly gone over to the attack in the last quarter of the year, reversing a long, steady, but unmistakable decline in its fortunes.

title: A Clever Blending of Fantasies By Youngsters of Munsey Park
description: MANHASSET, L.I.In a sense the audience at the Munsey Park elementary school's production of Mother Goose's Christmas Surprise was like a crowd of wellwishers at the opening of a Broadway play. All friends and mothers, they were there to love it.

title: Briggs Sues Chiefs In Contract Dispute
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 24 (AP) Bob Briggs, a defensive end, has filed suit against the Kansas City Chiefs, accusing the National Football League club of breach of contract.

title: C.I.A. Blamed for Death
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 A group called The Fifth Estate issued a long statement today charging that if anyone is to blame for Mr. Welch's death it is the C.I.A. that sent him there to spy, perhaps even to intervene, in the affairs of the Greek Government.

title: Mercifully Irrelevant
description: The church of St. MaryleBow in Cheapside, London, puts on lunchtime dialogues between its rector, the Rev. Joseph McCulloch, and guest speakers. Mr. McCulloch was chided in The Times of London recently for bullying a guest, Germaine Greer, the feminist scholar. With tongue somewhat in cheek, a Times commentator said Mr. McCulloch seemed in the most boorish and. Devilish of moods.

title: G.E.'s Legal Strategy
description: It may be late winter before the Federal Government discloses whether it will fight the General Electric Company's plans to acquire Utah International Inc., a major mining company, for more than $1.9 billion in G.E. stock. The price tag, it is believed, would be the largest for a business acquisition in the nation's history.

title: S.E.C. Restrictions on Deals Away From Big Board Will Be Maintained
description: The New York Stock Exchange told member brokers yesterday that a Government order liberalizing rules against doing business away from the exchange's trading floor would be replaced by a new rule that still retained trading restrictions on roundlot orders.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Bail of $25,000 was set for, a chemist accused of running an $85 million narcotics operation in California. The chemist, Phillip C. Radlick, 37 years old, appeared before United States Magistrate William J. Hunt in Newark after being arrested on charges that he manufactured phencyclidine, a white powder known as angel dust that produces euphoria when sniffed.

title: CAREY KNOLEDGE OF AN INQUIRY TIED TO NADJARI OUSTER
description: Maurice H. Nadjari said yesterday of his dismissal by Governor Carey that the knowledge he had about an investigation triggered his decision.

title: HARVARD STUDENT HELD IN LOAN CASE
description: BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP)A Harvard Law School student, who allegedly enrolled under separate identities twice in the last seven years, was ordered yesterday bound over for a United States grand jury on charges that he had falsified a Federal student loan application.

title: Tilly Losch, Exotic Dancer, Is Dead
description: Tilly Losch, a leading international dancer in the 1920's and 30's, died yesterday of cancer at New York Hospital. She was believed to be in her early 70's and had homes at 20 East 68th Street and in Eaton Square, London.

title: Good Deeds Time: An Unrandom Poll
description: Traditionally, Christmas is a time for good deeds and goodwill. Here is what some wellknown New Yorkers had to say on the subject yesterday:

title: Market Holiday
description: All American and foreign securities and commodity exchanges will be closed today for the Christmas holiday. Banks will also be closed, and there will be no foreignexchange trading.

title: Miss Beaven Wins State Tennis Title
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 24 Lindsey Beaven defeated topseeded Wendy Paish, 64, 62, in the final of the New York State women's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet. Club. Miss Beaven, who comes from Britain, took six straight games from 44 in the first set. Mrs. Paish is an Australian.

title: Crash Kills 7 in Texas
description: MENARD, Tex., Dec. 24, (UPI)A car carrying seven members of a Fort Worth family to Mexico for Christmas slammed into a trailer truck before dawn today on a wet and fogshrouded highway. All seven were killed.

title: Consultant Helps TV Decide What's News
description: LOS ANGELES  Political managers customarily distinguish between paid media and unpaid mediabetween the time they buy on television to promote their candidates and the time they beg, borrow or wheedle on regular newscasts. Unpaid media is by far the more effective, most of them say.

title: Another Christmas for Joe Kuharich
description: To begin with, Joe Kuharich never accepted what the doctors predicted. Perhaps that's why he doesn't think of today as being the fourth Christmas he wasn't supposed to have.

title: CYANAMID RAISES SURFACTANT PRICES
description: The American Cyanamid Company announced yesterday price increases ranging between 3 and 17 percent for a number of its surfactants.

title: GEORGE A. SEMON
description: George A. Semon, who retired as a photoengraver for The New York Times in 1972 after 10 years of service, died yesterday in a nursing home in the Bronx. He was 75 years old and lived at 494 West 207th Street.

title: Washington Post Pressmen Lose in N.L.R.R. Complaint
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 24 (AP) Claims by striking pressmen that The Washington Post was bargaining in bad faith before the strike began Oct. 1 have been rejected by a National Labor Relations Board official

title: German Advances In Tennis Tourney
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP)West Germany's Peter Elter, unseeded in what tournament officials have admitted was an oversight, defeated Tony Giammalva of Houston, 63, 63, today in the Orange Bowl world junior tennis tournament.

title: Spurs Owe $52,993
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 24 (AP)The San Antonio Spurs of the American Basketball Association will get a bill of at least $5,993 for use of the city's convention center arena, City Manager Sam Granata said. The rent is owed for the 1974 and 1975 seasons.

title: Fund for Neediest Called ExtraSpecial
description: The 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $500,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $14,720 from 420 contributors. In the campaign's third week, 2,797 donors have given an overall total of $512,267,72.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: DR. LEO DAVIDOFF, SURGEON, 73, DIES
description: Dr. Leo M. Davidoff, professor emeritus and former associate dean and professor and chairman of the departments of surgery and neurological surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died Tuesday while visiting in Wivenhoe, England.

title: Crews at Ismailia Battle an Ill Wind
description: ISMAILIA, Egypt, Dec. 24 The annual Egyptian intercollegiate rowingfestival began today on Lake. Timsah, which translated from the Egyptian means Crocodile Lake

title: Ivory Gull Makes Rare Appearance In Massachusetts
description: SALISBURY, Mass., Dec. 24The tidal estuary here has attracted another extremely rare seagull, nine months after the appearance of a Ross's gull drew hordes. of bird watchers.

title: CLEMENCY GIVEN TO SOSTRE AND 7
description: Governor Carey granted Christmas clemency yesterday to Martin Sostre, a black Puerto Rican militant whose release has been the goal of an international campaign, and seven other convicts.

title: Company Is Called Aware of Kepone's Danger
description: RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 24 (UPI)Tests indicated the pesticide Kepone was toxic to humans 15 years before 28 employees of a now defunct chemical company in Hopeville, Va., were hospitalized with the poison in their blood, a retired researcher said today.

title: Daley Again Has a Key Role as KingMaker
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24Once again, the Mayor of Chicago, Richard J. Daley, appears to have found a way to give himself a prominent role in the selection of a Democratic Presidental nominee.

title: Court Approves Coit's Plan
description: Coit International Inc. announced in Dallas yesterday that a consolidated plan of arrangement, filed in the United States Court under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, was accepted by a majority of creditors and confirmed by the court.

title: Churches Told To Repudiate Intelligence Agency Links
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The National Council of Churches said today that it had recommended to its 31 member churches that they issue policy statements repudiating intentional contacts between their personnel abroad and United States Government intelligence agencies.

title: Japan Limits Steel Exports
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 (AP)Japan's six major steelmakers said today they had decided to limit voluntarily their 1976 exports to the European Common Market to a combined total of 1.22 million tons.

title: Harris Remains Doubtful
description: LOS ANGELES, 24 (AP)James Harris's shoulder injury, leaves the Los Angeles Rams' quarterback problems unsolved, and it bothers Coach Don Coryell of the St. Louis Cardinals as well.

title: Massive Cuts Foreseen In StateAided Programs
description: TRENTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)Massive cuts in funds for mass transit, Medicaid, higher education and aid to local governments will be necessary to keep the state's budget balanced next fiscal year, according to the Governor's Budget Priorities Committee.

title: Threat Now Looming For Spring Training
description: The immediate effect of the ruling in the Andy MessersmithDave McNally case has been to get the impartial arbitrator dismissed and the club owners, in the words of one baseball officials, hysterical and out of control. The longrange effect, according to the owners, means destroying the structure of the game.

title: Good Tidings
description: On Christmas Day, year after year, the Biblical story still bears a solemn message of faith, good tidings and renewal. Across the United States and the globe, religious observances and social celebrations bring joy to the home place. It is a holy day and a holiday: a time of prayerful second chances in our personal and national lives and a time of youthful visions of sugar plums dancing in our heads.

title: Soviet Archeologists Find A 1,000YearOld Flute
description: MOSCOW, Dec 24 (UPI)Soviet archeologists working in the central Asian republic of Uzbekistan have discovered a flute made 1,000 years ago from a piece of polished bone.

title: Tokyo Living Cost Up 10.8%
description: TOKYO, Dec, 27 (AP)  The average cost of living for a Tokyo family of five increased 10.8 percent, or $63 a month, during 1975, the metropolitan government's price bureau has reported. It estimated that in December a family of five was spending $653 a month for living expenses.

title: De Rivera, the Sculptor, Alleges That He'll Retire
description: No one quite believes that Jose de Rivera will put down his heavy sledgehammer for keeps, but the 71yearold sculptor says he's done his last large work. Having taken two years to forge, weld, hammer, file and buff his 5foot stainless steel arabesque, Construction ??158, into final shape; he'll rest his esthetic case.

title: Notes on People
description: Announcing a Jan. 1  20 trip to Asia, Senator George McGovern said yesterday that he would explore Vietnamese interest in resuming relations with the United States. The South Dakota Democrat, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's Subcommittee on Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, will be accompanied by his wife Eleanor and members of the subcommittee staff.

title: Stocks Decrease For Distillate Oil From Prior Week
description: Stocks of distillate oil, which is used for home heating, dipped slightly last week, according to the Statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Pitcher Won't Comment
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP)Andy Messersmith, the Dodger pitcher, refused to talk about his future today or comment on the arbitration ruling that made him a free agent.

title: Radio
description: 7:258:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Christmas Oratorio, J. S. Bach.

title: New Diabetes Drug Gets U.S. Sanction For License Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (Reuters)The Justice Department cleared the way today for limited worldwide licensing of a new diabetes drug known as Somatostatin.

title: BARGAIN HUNTING LIFTS AMEX PRICES
description: Continued bargain hunting and a lessening of yearend taxselling pressure helped raise prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading.

title: Mozambique Says Chiefs Of Revolt Face Tribunals
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Mozambique radio has said that the leaders of a threeday revolt last week by members of the army and the police would be tried before socalled peoples' tribunals.

title: RESEARCHERS SEE NO QUAKE LIMIT
description: Two scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have disputed the widely held belief that there is a clearcut limit on the magnitude of great earthquakes. They propose that some may be four times as strong as any recorded in recent years.

title: Lakers 111. Kings 97
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP)Gail Goodrich scored 35 points, his season high, and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 11197 victory over the Kansas City Kings last night. Kareem AbdulJabbar added 23 points, hauled down 22 rebounds and was credited with seven blocked shots as the Lakers snapped a fourgame losing streak and ran their home court record to 151.

title: Former Surgeon Puts Expertise to Film Conception
description: The genus film producer may teem with exlawyers, exagents and the like but it now includes Robert Abrams, a 37yearold former New Yorker, who is its only former neuroendocrinologist and medical school dean.

title: National Bond Issue At Record in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24The Parliameet authorized tonight the floating of a $7.6 billion national bond issue to bring the total for this fiscal year to a record $18.3 billion, two and a half times the amount issued last year.

title: Rare U.N. Unanimity
description: At a time when support in the United States for the United Nations is at a low point, a unanimous action of the Security Council should not go unnoticed. The Council achieved its rare unanimity in calling for withdrawal of Indonesian forces from Portuguese Timor and for measures to enable that territory's 620,000 inhabitants freely to decide their political future.

title: Manila Frees 545 Detainees
description: MANILA, Dec. 24 (UPI)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ordered the release of 545 martiallaw detainees in time for them to spend Christmas with their relatives, military authorities announced. About 6,000 people have been detained since martial law was proclaimed three years ago, ofificials said.

title: Ford Extends Sympathy
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 24 (Reuters)  President Ford today sent his condolences and sympathy to Mrs. Welch in Athens

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Using funds under a Federal training program, the Fire Department reappointed 63 firemen who were laid off in July because of the city's fiscal crisis. They are part of a group of 150 being reappointed through funds provided by the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act program. The first group of 71 firemen was reappointed Dec. 15 and the remaining 16 are to be reappointed soon, according to Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan.

title: 2 BANK ACQUISITIONS ARE BLOCKED BY FED
description: The Federal Reserve Board rejected yesterday two proposed bank acquisitions in separate decisions. It turned down the application of the Popular Bancshares Corporation of Miami, a bank holding company, to acquire 97.4 percent of the stock of the Security State Bank of Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Soviet Camp Film Is Said To Show Construction Site
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (Reuters) A Moscow weekly newspaper said today that a film purporting to show a Soviet prison camp, which has led to a public squabble between the Kremlin and French Communists, was a fabrication.

title: Moroccan Troops Reported Preparing Final Sahara Drive
description: SMARA, Spanish Sahara, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Moroccan troops are preparing to dislodge Algeria  backed nationalists from their last northern stronghold in the Spanish Sahara, military sources said here today.

title: SANCTION IMPOSED ON WNJUTV FOR ADS
description: The Federal Communications Commission has imposed sanction on WNJUTV (Channel 47) in Linden, N. J., for televising too many commercials.

title: Most Senators Get Political Advantage From Their Own Wealth
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24A?? a time of increasing scrutiny by Federal and private groups of Congressional pay and allowances, and complaints by legislators of the financial hardships of public service, a study by The New York Times has found that a majority of senators are men of means whose wealth may give them an edge in staying in office.

title: Byrne Will Ask Two Pension Funds To Return $40 Million Temporarily
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24 (AP)The Byrne Administration acknowledged today that it wanted two publicemployee pension funds to give back more than $40 million temporarily just in case the state needed the cash, to pay its bills during next next six months.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES IN A SLIGHT RISE
description: Soybeans advanced slightly in slow preholiday trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, while wheat and corn closed almost unchanged in price. March delivery soybeans ended at $4.66 a bushel, up 3 cents.

title: A Christmas In Wales
description: After a slightly uneven recorder recital, the announcement of the penmanship honors, and the awarding of a stuffed alligator to the tidiest classroom, the stellar event in the St. Bernard's School Christmas performance began.

title: 3 Critical Owners Fined by Rozelle
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP)The National Football League has fined Ralph Wilson, owner of the Buffalo Bills, and Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, $5,000 each for criticizing officiating during games, it was reported today.

title: Holiday Shifts Emphasis at Therapy Center
description: WEST ORANGE, Dec. 24The Christmas season is unlike any other time of year at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation here.

title: COURT RULING AIDS M.A.C. BOND SWAP
description: A decision in State Supreme Court upholding the moratorium on shortterm New York City notes spurred investors yesterday to trade their notes for longterm Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

title: Personal Finance
description: Many elderly homeowners find they can no longer afford to live in their houses. For if they have little or no current income, real estate taxes, insurance and maintenanceplus the amortization of principal and interest, if a mortgage is still outstandingmay be too much fors them.

title: At St. Patrick's Christmas, Isn't Rushed
description: Like many of the weary, giftladen shoppers who fled the hubbub outside this week for a moment of tranquillity and repose in its pews, St. Patrick's Cathedral unfailingly leaves its Christmas chores to the last.

title: Creeks Searchfor Killers Of C.I.A. Man Unfruitful
description: AMENS, Dec. 24The Greek Government apparently made little progress today in the search for the killers of Richard S. Welch, the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency in Greece.

title: APPELLATE JUDGES CHOSEN BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey yesterday named two justices of the State Supreme Court, Harold Birns and Samuel J. Silverman, as justices of the Appellate Division, First Department.

title: SHOPS FEEL IMPACT OF S.I. TRANSIT STRIKE
description: Many smallshop keepers along the 14.5mile route of the Staten Island Rapid Transit System complained about business lost because of the twoweek walkout as picketing continued yesterday.

title: Stracey Fouls Reported
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 24 (AP)Jose Sulaiman, president of the World Boxing Council, said today that John Stracey of Britain committed several fouls in defeating Jose Napoles of Mexico for the world welterweight title on Dec. 6 but that the council could not order a rematch. Sulaiman made the statement after viewing a film of the fight, which Stracey won by a technical knockout.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: Australia's Labor Party Gains 2 Seats in Late Count
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Australia's Labor Party, ousted from office in the Dec. 13 general elections, today won two more parliamentary seats in late returns, bringing its total to 35, compared with 91 for the LiberalNational Country Party coalition.

title: ABRAHAM ZIMMON
description: Abraham Zimmon, who had been a stereotyper and partner and treasurer of Gilliams & Rubin, a stereotyping concern here, died yesterday in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 87 years and lived in Coral Gables.

title: Man Dies of Fumes After Safety Report On Furnace Is Cited
description: A 66yearold man died yesterday and four persons lost consciousness when they were overcome by coal gas in a cityowned building in Washington Heights whose furnace had been reported unsafe five days ago.

title: BISTATEAREA JOBS AT A 10YEAR LOW
description: The number of jobs in the New YorkNew Jersey metropolitan are fell to the lowest level in 10 years in October, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Use of 2 Pesticides Is Curbed by E.P.A. As Possible Hazard
description: The Environmental Protection Agency ordered yesterday the suspension of the sale of the widely used pesticides chlordane and heptachlor for most agricultural and home lawn and garden uses.

title: Thousands of Idle Taking to the Road In Search of Work
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24Ron Bueckert, a 32yearold electrician who can earn more than $400 a week when times are good, drove his pickup truck here last week, 600 miles from his home and family in Northern California, in search of a job.

title: Sealing a Door, Pope Ends Holy Year
description: ROME, Thursday, Dec. 25.Pope Paul VI ended the Holy Year last night in a Christmas Eve ceremony sealing the Holy Door of St. Peter's Basilica.

title: DR. LEO DAVIDOFF, SURGEON, 73, DIES
description: Dr Leo M. Davidoff, professor, emeritus and former associate dean and professor and chairman of the departments of surgery and neurological, surgery at the Albert EinStein College of Medicine, died Tuesday while visiting in Wivenhoe, England.

title: Fund for Neediest Called ExtraSpecial
description: The 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $500,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $14,720 from 420 contributors. In the campaign's third week, 2,797 donors have given an overall total of $512,267.72.

title: Midwestern Life Says Insurer In Netherlands Is Seeking Deal
description: The Midwestern United Life Insurance Company, Fort Wayne, Ind., in a letter to shareholders, said it has learned that the Netherlands Insurance Company, The Hague, is interested in making a cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of Midwestern United at $19 a share. Midwestern United has 2.3 million shares outstanding, indicating that the proposed acquisition would be valued at about $43.7 million.

title: Marijuana Haul Seized
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Dec. 24 (UPI)A task force of 20 deputies confiscated more than 12 tons of marijuana today and arrested seven persons on smuggling charges. Also confiscated were four cabin cruisers, four trucks, four trailers, one car, several firearms and $7.000 in cash.

title: Bernard Herrmann, Composer, Oscar Winner for Score, Dead
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP) Bernard Herrmann, an Academy Awardwinning composer who wrote the score for the film classic Citizen Kane, died in his sleep early today. He was 64 years old.

title: JOSEPH R. DONNELLY
description: Joseph R. Donnelly, assistant night city editor of The Daily News since 1970, died yesterday, apparently of a heart at tack, in his sleep. He was 56 years old and lived at 22 Mariner Circle, West Islip, L. I.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday. Dec. 24. 1975 (In bushels, 000 omitted) Tues.

title: Powers Says Printing Shops, Now Agree to 10Year Pact
description: Bertram A. Powers, president, of New York Typographical Union No. 6 said yesterday that commercial printing shops employing 80 percent of the local's members who worked, for Printers League employers had agreed to a new 10year contract that opened the way for unlimited automation.

title: The Dance: Herodiade
description: It could just be possible to look upon Herodiade, Martha Graham's study of a woman about to make a momentous decision, as a picture of a woman trying to decide whether she should go to Bloomingdale's or Saks. Like other of the world's most serious creative minds, Miss Graham has been open to parody.

title: Blazers 125, Sonics 100

title: Hostage Division Described

title: Free Spenders of Past Are on Christmas Budget
description: NEWARK, Dec. 24New Jersey residents who were never unemployed through the births of several. children and who always spent hundreds of dollars at Christmas time this year are buying gifts only for their children and have relied on relatives to pick up the slack through the holiday season.

title: Fire Again Hits Queens Church And Police Call It Suspicious
description: Two towers and the remaining front section of the 127yearold St. James Episcopal Church in Elmhurst, Queens, the sanctuary of which was buried out on Oct. 11, were destroyed early yesterday by another fire, which the police termed suspicious.

title: Laos Still Beset by International Rivalries
description: VIENTIANE, Laos  Despite the end of the war and the drive of the new Laotian Communist rulers for selfreliance, this small country remains embroiled in the rivalries of larger outside powers.

title: Dance: A WellDone Repertory Night
description: If American Ballet Theater Is a beleaguered camp, as certain newspaper reports have suggested, then it does not show. For a company supposedly rent with dissension it is dancing remarkably well. Even for a company not rent with dissension it is dancing remarkably well. But then we have always known that in ballet, dissidents remain good team players.

title: Lightning Kills 21 in Africa
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Lightning killed 21 persons when it struck a but in which they were seeking shelter from rain, the Rhodesian police reported today. The dead included 14 children. The total of dead from lightning in Rhodesia since Oct. 1 is 53, one of the worst tolls on record.

title: Bond Price Advance Continues in Spite Of Short Session
description: The credit markets shut down early yesterday and not much trading was done even while they were, open for business because it was the day before Christmas. Even so, bond prices continues to advance, extending their current climb to an even two weeks and giving the bond community its first preChristmas rise since 1971.

title: Police Toughening Antiterrorist Tactics
description: LONDON, Dec. 24  Police officials in Britain and other countries are developing new and tougher tactics to deal with the terrorist kidnappings that in recent months have become a chillingly routine phenomenon in Europe.

title: Bentsen Problem a Lack Of National Recognition

title: Braves Suspend McAdoo
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 24 (AP)Bob McAdoo, the National Basketball Association's leading scorer, was suspended indefinitely by the Buffalo Braves today in a dispute over his refusal to play.

title: MURDR PLAN LAID TO OPEC RAIDERS

title: DISTRICT 37 GIVES CHRISTMAS PARTY

title: Estonians Are Restoring a MedieVal Tallinn

description: Hope Brooks Meryman, an artist and illustrator and the wife of Richard Meryman, a former editor of Life magazine, died Monday at her home, 71 Horatio Street. She was 44 years old

title: Griffith Out of Fight
description: PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP) Emile Griffith has pulled out of his scheduled Jan. 12 middleweight bout against Loucif Hamani of Algeria because of a back injury. Rudy Nobbles of Los Angeles will replace Griffith.

title: Electronic Games Bringing a Different Way to Relax
description: The delighted cries of young children this Christmas morning will be punctuated in many homes by blips and pongs as families settle down to the latest crazeelectric games.

title: Calm Before Storm For Basketball Stars
description: Although Wayne McKoy and Albert King are generally acknowledged as two of the fittest high school basketball players in the country the recruiting hurricane will not swirl in their direction this season. Each has been in the limelight for several year now, but each is only a junior. College coaches know them, of course, but for now their interest lies elsewhere. McKoy and King cannot officially be recruited until they are seniors.

title: Mrs. Meir Casts Doubt on Reliability Of U.S. Guarantee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24Golda Meir, the former Prime Minister of Israel suggested today that lack of Congressional support for Angola had cast doubt on the value of any future American security guarantees for Israel.

title: Diego Garcia Refugees Unhappy in Mauritius
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Dec. 18But this isn't for us, it's not ours, the short, dark man said in Creole, the pidgin French of these islands.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A diversity of people from the arts will participate in the National Conference on Jewish Cultural Arts from Jan. 10 through 12. Dore Schary will serve as chairman. The conference, celebrating the Bicentennial, will be held at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, the Park Avenue Synagogue and the Jewish Museum.

title: Argentine Guerrilla Toll Put as High as 100 in Raid
description: QUILMES, Argentina, Dec. 24Soldiers killed at least 45 leftwing guerrillas who tried to storm an arsenal here in a battle that lasted until early today. As a result of pursuit operations against guerrillas who hid in shantytowns and wooded areas near the arsenal, the death toll may have reached 100, an army communiqu said.

title: Fairchild Settles Suit
description: The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and Litronix Inc. announced a settlement yesterday of a Litronix lawsuit filed 12 days ago against Fairchild and John P. Haynes, an employee. The suit alleged that Mr. Haynes, a former Litronix employee hired by Fairchild, possessed confidential information related to Litronix's digital watch program that might be revealed to Fairchild. Litronix asked for an injunction and $20 million in punitive damages.

title: Market Place
description: Stock purchasers may not be aware of, it, but it is sometimes possible to obtain a discount from the market at year's end by entering cash orders for shares at a specific limit price below the current bid.

title: Principle, Not Interest, Irks Red Tape's Victim

It's his feeling that the city should itself pay the interest because he insists it was the city's failure, over a 20month period, to give him the information necessary to pay the tax and the help he needed in threading his way through the city bureaucracy and tax code that led to the delay.

Cunningham, 40, was the pilot of the twinengine aircraft.

Y., Dec. 25Snow began falling late this afternoon, just as the ski lifts were closing downtoo late to supplement the snowmaking machines today, but auguring well for the weekend. Conditions remained, good throughout the Catskills area. At Holiday Mountain, one of the area's larger centers, about 500 skiers had frolicked over slopes mostly covered with artificial snow, and conditions were excellent.

title: HUNT SAYS C. I. A. MD ASSASSIN UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25E. Howard Hunt the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who was convicted of helping carry out the 1972 Watergate breakin, says he was told in the mid1950's that the C.I.A. had a small unit set pp to arrange for the assassination of suspected double agents and similar lowranking officials. In a recent interview at the Federal correctional institution at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, where he is serving an eightyear sentence imposed for his role in the Watergate conspiracy, Mr. Hunt said he recalled having been told by C.I.A. superiors in 1954 or 1955 that Boris T. Pash, an agency official, was in charge of the assassination unit.

title: Red Smith
description: With the matchless John Unitas at quarterback, the Baltimore Colts were losing to Dallas, 210. It was the fifth game of the 1972 season and this would be the Colts fourth defeat, their first by a shutout in seven years. With 12 minutes to play, half the crowd had walked out and the other half was booing, jeering, and sailing paper gliders toward the field. That's when Joe Thomas realized what he had to do. Joe Thomas is a reformed football coach who, starting from scratch in Minnesota and Miami, had laid the foundations for championship teams. Resign ing as executive assistant and personnel director of the Dolphins, he had helped engineer the deal in which Robert Irsay bought the Los Angeles Rams and swapped them to Carroll Rosenbloom for the Colts. Now, as vice president and general manager, it was his job to repair that team's dwindling fortunes. But first came the rotten job of getting rid, of individuals who had been great but couldn't hack it any more.

Kenny Scawthorn, the clerk of scales, called the stewards, who had no choice but to disqualify Brave Game.

title: Screen: 'Luckly Lady' Is Misnomer of Miscast and Mismanaged Comedy
description: In Stanley Donen's "Lucky Lady," a Prohibition-era comedy about rum-running off the California coast, Liza Minnelli may remind you of the character played by Madeline Kahn in "Sherlock Holmes' Smarter Brother." Claire (Miss Minnelli) never says it, but everything about her performance reminds you of Miss Kahn's very funny, phony introductory line: "I'm an actress. I am simultaneously funny and sad."Miss Minnelli's Claire is neither funny nor sad but an actress trying like hell to convince you that she is. The more she tries, the worse she gets. About half-way through the movie you feel like shaking her. You want to tell her to start over, to stand up straight, not to walk pigeon-toed and to wipe that silly-sad grin off her face. Waifhood is being abused.As Miss Minnelli's performance is a mistake in make-believe, so is the entire over-produced, under-thought-out production. "Lucky Lady," which opened at two theaters yesterday, is, down deep, a nervous little sparrow of a movie that has been pumped up to the size of a peacock and outfitted accordingly. It's ridiculous without the compensation of being funny or fun.This is difficult to understand, considering the people who are involved. Mr. Donen has directed some of our best musicals and comedies ("Singin' in the Rain," "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers," "Two for the Road," etc.) and he's a man of taste, but here, perhaps, taste is just what's wrong."Lucky Lady," written by Willard Huyck and Gloria Katz (who wrote "American Graffiti"), is about three down-on-their-luck losers, Claire, Kibby (Gene Hackman) and Walker (Burt Reynolds), who come together in a Mexican border town during the worst of the American Depression. Through some mysterious alchemy, they become immensely successful bootleggers and, even more surprising to them, a very happy mnage  trois.Seediness should be the operative word if the film is to be funny or sad, yet Mr. Donen and Geoffrey Unsworth, the photographer, have chosen to shoot the movie as if it were a fashion layout for Vogue. Everything is lacquered with chic, even the old yacht, the Lucky Lady, with which the rum-runners begin their business. Seascapes and landscapes are the bleached, shimmery backdrops one associates with tall, bored yogurt-thin models. The film also contains a couple of art deco interiors so stunning they deserve marquee credit.Thus upstaged by the scenery, the actors receive no help from their material, which is virtually nonexistent. The screenplay contains supposedly funny encounters with other bootleggers, the Coast Guard and one fairly spectacular sea battle, but there is nothing in the way of characterization other than what the actors bring to their roles. This is an impossible burden if you're Miss Minnelli and most at ease singing, or Mr. Hackman, whose comedy touch would punch a hole in the side of a battleship.Mr. Reynolds comes off much better. He has a feeling for comedy, especially for the details that make vulgar second-rateness funny.The failure of the ensemble acting is more a failure of casting than of talent, and perhaps three other actors, more suited to each other's moods and styles, could have made something interesting of the central three-sided relationship. Miss Minnelli, Mr. Hackman and Mr. Reynolds can't. They work and work and work, often intelligently, and you don't once believe them. They laugh frequently, but there's not a moment of spontaneous feeling in the whole film.A theoretical case could be made for comic possibilities in having "Lucky Lady's" heroine and her two suitors settle down together happily ever after. One can imagine that Marlene Dietrich could have arranged some such thing with George Raft and Edward G. Robinson. In "Manpower" (1941) she was a presence to reckon with, but Miss Minnelli is neither interesting nor demanding enough to pull it off, even as a joke."Lucky Lady" is really an old-fashioned movie made out of new, cheap, synthetic materials.

title: FORD GRAIN POLICY ANGERS FARMERS
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 25  There were abundant signs this week that resentment against President Ford was rising among Republican farmers in the Middle West.

The leading chain store organizations reported that November sales were ahead of the corresponding month last year by 10.5 percent.

title: The Screen:'Black Bird' Certainly No 'Maltese Falcon'
description: "The Black Bird" is an enchanting half-hour spoof of Humphrey Bogart and "The Maltese Falcon." Too bad it lasts over an hour and a half.It is the problem with takeoffs. A haunted house needs a house as well as a ghost. A movie needs legs as well as decoration. It's all very well to spring out at a party wearing a preposterous costume, but sooner or later you have to say something or at least help pass the sandwiches.There is a lot to be happy with in the early parts of "Bird." George Segal is Sam Spade Jr. He has had a soft childhoodyou can see it in his placidity and air of being put-uponand is by no means the man his father was. A point that his secretary, a screaming fright named Effie, constantly dins into him.Anyway he's stuck with his father's private-eye business, a waiting-room full of freaky clients he does his best to avoid, and the Maltese Falcon wrapped in a Miami Beach towel and stashed away in a file cabinet.In marches a representative of the Knights Templar, an undernourished gentleman in an opera cape who offers him $300 to find the falcon and dies quickly. Spade, who wants no trouble, immediately tries to pawn the bird but he's only offered $14.50 and so, reluctantly, he begins to deal.A sidekick turns up. He is Andrew Jackson Immelmanplayed by Lionel Standerand the best thing in the movie. He is made of bricks, talks tough, refuses to hit women despite Spade's urging, reprimands him for calling policemen "pigs" and wears a bright green plaid suit.Various rival would-be acquirers of the falcon arrive on the scene. Among them are four Hawaiian gangsters, a midget Nazi and an elegant woman (Stephane Audran) who lives in the silk-draped basement of a Greek Orthodox church.Miss Audran is not cut out for this kind of romp: she always seems to be wearing her best clothes. But that's not the main trouble. Having assembled his carnival, David Giler, the writer, and director, prods them down the endless corridor of a very narrow and winding plot. All of them are on the same level of preposterousness; there is no pace or variety and nothing much for them to do.Delight turns to affection, which turns to tolerance, which turns to a wish that all these funny people would go home. Humphrey Bogart would have sent them home. George Segal is nice and charming and lovable, but he is no private eye: more of a private blink.

title: Screen: George Scott in 'Hindenburg'
description: As disaster movies go, "The Hindenburg" is so brainless and so peculiarly optimistic that it could have been the work of Ross Hunter, but wasn't. It is pricelessly funny at the wrong moments. It confirms portentiousness as school of cinematic art. It has George C. Scott, as a good German, saying through a mostly clenched jaw not long after the take-off, "I have an uneasy sense of disaster."It has his wife complaining primly, "That song is going to make me sick," as if it were "Blue Suede Shoes" and not "The Horst Wessel Song." It has characters talking about "Hermann" (whose last name is Gring), and it makes completely implausible a perfectly plausible theory about the events that led up to May 6, 1937, when the German dirigible Hindenburg, the Titanic of all lighter-than-air craft, exploded and burned while landing at Lakehurst, N.J.Yet I wouldn't have missed a single foolish frame of it. I sort of like disaster movies, even bad ones, for reasons that have to do with the special effects and with other things that probably go back to the prenatal state.I'm also fascinated by dirigibles, those huge, cigar-shaped, rigid-framed (unlike the "soft" blimps of today) aircraft that Germany pioneered, gave a name to (Zeppelin, after the count who built them) and maintained successfully for so many years while ours, including the Macon and Shenandoah, kept cracking up.If "The Hindenburg" does nothing else, and I'm not sure that it does, it may at least tease your imagination enough to research this curious chapter in aviation, the first most easily available source being "The Hindenburg," Michael M. Mooney's book, which provides the source material for the film. Like the Mississippi steamboat, the dirigible had a short, glorious, glamorous life and then suddenly expired. Very little of this sense, however, is conveyed by the film that opened at three theaters here yesterday."The Hindenburg" is far more schizoid than its three most notable predecessors "The Poseidon Adventure," "The Towering Inferno" and "Earthquake"). Unlike those films, which were total fictions, "The Hindenburg" is torn between known facts and the fictional narrative that sounds as if it had been manufactured in a Beverly Hills sauna.According to Robert Wise, the director, Nelson Gidding, who wrote the screenplay, and Richard Levinson and William Link, who slipped the other two the story idea, much as if it were a Mickey, the Hindenburg was sabotaged by a young German crew member who wanted to embarrass the Nazis. That part is plausible but the way this is dramatized makes you long for the sanity of "Take the Money and Run."Remove the last 10 minutes of the film, which is the length to which Mr. Wise quite effectively stretches the actual disaster and original newsreel footage that lasted less than one minute, and "The Hindenburg" is just another, somewhat more tedious "Grand Hotel in the Sky" picture.The cast includes just about everybody you didn't especially want to see in a movie right now, though Dana Andrews, Shelley Winters, George Kennedy and Helen Hayes are not in it.Among those who are aboard are William Atherton (the saboteur), Gig Young, Burgess Meredith and Anne Bancroft, who fools around as a German countess named Ursula, which gives Mr. Scott the opportunity to say to her, when he catches her smoking in a potentially inflammable part of the ship."Behave, Ursula, you know that's dangerous." The dialogue in this film may be as quietly loony as any you've heard all year.

Those earlier generations, he said, had inoculated youth with concepts of war for power and materialism as the only justice. [Page 1, Column 2]

title: Screen: 'Friday Foster'
description: Times change. Christmas used to inspire great music or enduring sentimental literature. Now it brings us a pile of corpses and a movie equally full of holes called "Friday Foster."Students of comic strips will need no introduction. Discriminating moviegoers will want none. Friday Foster, the black model turned photographer, began life in the so-called funnies; and, judging by this film, which opened Christmas Day at the Penthouse and other theaters, has not bettered herself artistically by changing media.Condensing the plot of "Friday Foster" actually calls for the talents of an alchemist. But basically, Friday, on assignment from Glance magazine, finds herself in the middle of an attempt to assassinate "the black Howard Hughes." Then she finds herself stalked, even into the shower, by one of the would-be assassins. Her efforts to find out what's behind it all lead her to a plot against the nation's black leaders.The action is faster than the calendar, so much so that it comes as a shock to discover that what seems like six days of running around actually takes place in the span from New Year's Eve to St. Valentine's Day.Pam Grier plays the fearless Miss Foster. Yaphet Kotto, whom she calls her "main man" after bedding down with Blake Tarr, "the black Howard Hughes" (Thalmus Rasulala), and a United States Senator (Paul Benjamin), renders assistance as a private detective.Among those who pass mercifully out of the picture as corpses are Eartha Kitt, who plays a fashion designer, and Godfrey Cambridge, who appears as an effeminate couturier.This is one of those movies where everything and everybody looks a little too goodthe clothes; the pimps; the hookers; the cars; the streets; the bosoms fleetingly bared; and even the blood, which looks as though it ought to carry a vintage.Christmas used to bring us great feasts, too. Now it gives us mental and visual junk food.
