title: Drive Aimed at Rail Town
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 25 (UPI)  AntiCommunist forces fighting for control of Angola announced today the start of a campaign to drive troops equipped by the Soviet Union out of a strategic railroad town on the Zambian border.

title: Soviet Indicates Rebuff to U.S. By Continuing Aid to Angolans
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union indicated today that it did not plan to drop its involvement in Angola despite the threat to dtente with the United States. It alleged that collusion among the United States, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and South Africa could end in a joint antiblack offensive in Africa.

title: Governor's Clemency
description: Governor Carey acted in a classic tradition of compassion when he granted clemency on Christmas Eve to eight convicts in state prisons. Most public attention yesterday centered on Martin Sostre, the remarkable black Puerto Rican militant who used his years in jail to educate himself in the law with results that have had wide repercussions. Mr. Sostre had become the subject of an international campaign. for his release, one that extended even to the Soviet Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov and Amnesty International. Both Dr. Sakharov and Amnesty International undoubtedly wish Leonid Brezhnev were similarly responsive to appeals for the release of Soviet political prisoners.

title: New Hearing Is Ordered In AccesstoBeach Case
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court, setting aside a 10yearold verdict, has ordered a lower court to hold a new hearing to determine whether a municipality can zone against recreational use of a beachfront.

title: Aaron Loves, Harlem Film, At 2 Theaters
description: AARON LOVES ANGELA, directed by Gordon Parks Jr.; written by Gerald Sanford, produced by Robert J. Anderson, photographed by Richard Kratina; music and songs by Jose Feliciano and Janne Merlyn Feliciano Columbia Pictures. Running time 98 minutes. At Cinerama, Broadway at 47th Street, and RKO 86th Street at Lexington Avenue.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Release Executive of MercedesBenz
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 25 (AP) Guerrillas have freed a West German who is the production manager of the MercedesBenz subsidiary here, the company confirmed today.

title: Gag Order in Murder Case Stirs Little Debate in Nebraska Town
description: SUTHERLAND, Neb.The house is a tiny frame dwelling on the northern edge of this forlornlooking town ?? 840 persons in Nebraska cattle country where the elements are harsh and the vistas treeless.

title: The Beaten PATH
description: Federal rejection of New Jersey's bid for Urban Mass Transportation funds to extend the PATH transit line from Newark to Plainfield, with a Newark Airport connection, represents a disappointing setback for the metropolitan region.

title: Candy Store Owner Held As a CockFight Operator
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 25 (AP)A Hartford candystore owner has been charged with cruelty to animals for allegedly holding cock fights in the basement of his building, the police said.

title: Attendance Up in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (AP)Almost 15 million spectators turned out to watch 36 major horse races in Japan in 1975, the Japan Central Horse Racing Association said today. Proceeds totaled more than $3 million, a 17 percent increase over the previous year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday presented a 111yearold Albanian woman who came here in 1974 with a letter from the White House notifying her that President Ford had signed a bill making her a United States citizen. The presentation to Mrs. Mrika Mrncaj was made at Party in the apartment of her son, Marash, at 2796 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. Her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren attended the party.

title: EDGAR BROMBERG
description: Edgar Bramberg, an industrialist, died Wednesday at Jefferson Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 64 years old and a resident of Princeton, N.J.

title: ELIZABETH M'NEIL
description: Elizabeth Quinn MacNeil, widow of Neil. MacNeil; former assistant managing editor of The New York Times, died Tuesday at the Fairland Nursing Home, Silver Spring, Md. She was 84 years old and a resident of the home. She is survived by two daughters, Mrs. John Kramer and Mrs. Harold Cumbadgh; a son, Neil MacNeil Jr.. and 11 grandchildren.

title: NADJARI CONFIRMS HE BEGAN INQUIRY ON WIRETAP LEAK
description: Maurice H. Nadjari yesterday confirmed a report that less than a week before he was dismissed as special state prosecutor by Governor Carey he ordered an inquiry into who had leaked information about a vital wiretap being used to investigate a possible connection between highranking Democratic officials and judicial corruption.

title: CHURCH WORSHIPS DESPITE 2 BLAZES
description: During three services on Christmas Eve and one yesterday morning, the congregation of the St. James Episcopal Church, in Elmhurst Queens, celebrated the holiday with all the, beauty that they could gather  sitting on hard metal chairs in the auditorium of the parish house, next door to the charred remains of their church.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Colts Have Believer in Greene
description: Joe Greene, whom many people consider the most ferocious member of the most ferocious front four in football, should know a good front four when he sees one. The Pittsburgh tackle hasn't seen much of the Baltimore Colts' young defensive line, but he knows it's a good one.

title: Free Tuition as Public Policy
description: For 128 years New York City has provided higher education for its residents at the lowest possible cost to students. The City University of New York has been for thousands of young people a ramp out of poverty; it has kept many from welfare rolls and moved others off; it has produced a roster of distinguished graduates including four living Nobel laureates. Tax collections from those whose economic circumstances have been bettered by their C.U.N.Y. education amply repay the city's investment.

title: Hospitals Lax on ConflictofInterest Data
description: A year and a half after the city asked 87 voluntary hospitals to certify that neither they nor their directors were involved in conflicts of interest, half of the hospitals and even more of the directors have not responded.

title: Athens Reinforces U.S., Soviet Guard And Hunts Killers
description: ATHENS, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Greek security authorities today reinforced guards outside the United States and Soviet embassies here, and policemen have been assigned to guard the homes of Americans named by Athens newspapers as members of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Stage: Marilyn Project at Garage
description: For The Marilyn Project, Richard Schechner has turned the upstairs at the Performing Garage into a replica of a Hollywood sound stage. The audience, sitting on benches or on the floor, overhears the event, as if it were on tour of a movie studio and had wandered behind the scenes.

title: MAN SHOT HELPING, OFFICER SUCCUMBS
description: A 32yearold father of two who was shot last week while aiding a police officer in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn died on Christmas Eve in Kings County Hospital.

title: 15 Students Sue New Brunswick Over Canceled Jobs as Firemen
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 25 Fifteen Rutgers University students have sued the city for canceling its plan to use them as low paid firemen to save the city funds.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, a dispatch from Washington in Wednesday editions of The Times reported that the Senate Intelligence Committee was not considering asking the Justice Department for all of its files on the activities of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The article should have said that the committee was considering making such a request.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: There are some hardy souls so captivated by flyfishing that when the present cold snap abates they will be trying their luck on such regional trout streams as the Farmington or Housatonic in Connecticut, or the upstream portion of the Battenkill in New York State.

title: Hospitals Lax on ConflictofInterest Data
description: A year and a half after the city asked 87 voluntary hospitals to certify that neither they nor their directors were involved in conflicts of interest, half of the hospitals and even more of the directors have not responded.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: America Discovers Greek Is Beautiful
description: In the last few years a strange thing has been noticed by Americans of Greek descent, from the hotdog vender on the corner to Telly Savalas  it's chic to be Greek.

title: 1976 Surprise: Carter Is Running Well
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 25The surprise of the 1976 Presidential campaign, thus far, is Jimmy Carter.

title: ARABS CONFERRING ON DEBATE IN U. N.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 25Highlevel Arab consultations are under way over the united Nations Security Council debate on the Middle East problem scheduled to begin Jan. 12.

title: POPULATION SHIFT IN JEWS HERE SEEN
description: The American Jewish Com mitteE has reported that the Jewish population of the greater New York area declined by 383,000 between 1962 and 1970I while the same period witnessed a substantial movement of Jews from the city to the suburbs.

title: 7 Hurt in Plant Blast
description: HOMER CITY, Pa., Dec. 25 (UPI)  An explosion and fire ripped through the Pennsylvania Electric Company power plant in this Indiana County community today, injuring seven workmen, one seriously. Officials said the men were hosing down fly ash in a hopper inside the plant when it came in contact with hot slag and exploded. The workers suffered facial and hand burns.

title: Increased Grain Production in China
description: CANBERRA, AustraliaNew grainoutput figures released by the Chinese Government indicate that agricultural production in China has taken off in the 1970's, and is increasing at a rate markedly higher than estimated by Western Chinawatchers. Senior officials of the Ministry of Agriculture in Peking told me recently that total grain production in 1974 was 274.9 million tons.

title: 12YearOld Dies in Fire
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 25 (AP)Michael Troy, 12 years old, was killed and his parents and two firefighters were injured early today in a blaze of undetermined origin in the family's home. Officials listed smoke inhalation as the cause of the boy's death. His parents, James M. Troy, 62, and Mavis, 51, were in satisfactory condition at the hospital, also suffering from smoke inhalation.

title: Last Passengers Quit Ship Grounded Off Virgin Islands
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 25 (UPI)A group of private boats today rescued the last of 75 passengers, most of them Americans, whose cruise ship went aground on a reef oft the British Virgin Islands.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks, should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and for. warded to F.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: Consumer Service Agrees To Refund Counseling Fees
description: A company that advertised itself as a consumer credit counseling service has agreed to refund all fees it collected. It did so after Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said he had found that the company did not employ credit counselors and could not offer effective consumer counseling.

title: 2d Man Charged in Death Of Knight Murder Suspect
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 25 (UPI)  A second suspect has been charged with murder in connection with the shooting death of Isias Melendez, one of three men who allegedly killed John S. Knight 3d, grandson of John S. Knight, head of the Knight Ridder newspaper chain.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Chemical Company Denies It Is Guilty In Pesticide Case
description: RICIENIOND, Dec. 26 (UPI)The Allied Chemical Corporation said today that it had never concealed the highly toxic nature of the pesticide Kepone and is free of blame in the poisoning of 28 former workers at a defunct chemical plant in nearby Hopewell.

title: Oxford Boat Triumphs in Nile Regatta
description: CAIRO, Dec. 26Oxford University, the only participant that has rowed in all the previous year's races, won the fifth annual rowing festival today. Cologne Sport University of West Germany was second and Harvard third

title: LTV Aerospace Plans To Use Vought Name
description: The LTV Aerospace Corporation will change its name to the Vought Corporation, effective Jan. 1, the company said yesterday.

title: JAPAN CAR EXPORTS INCREASE BY 11.5%
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Japan's exports of motor vehicles totaled 240,386 units in November, down 33 percent from October but up 9.4 percent from November, 1974, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: Soviet Skaters Set Pace
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Evgeni Kilikov and Vera Kransnova clocked the fastest times in the world this season for men's and women's 500 meters, in the Soviet Union speedskating championships today. Kilikov won it 38.58 seconds and Miss Krasnova in 41.94.

title: 15 Students Sue New Brunswick Over Failure to Get Fireman Jobs
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 26 Fifteen Rutgers University students are suing this city for withdrawing its offer to use them as lowpaid city firemen.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Christine Alexander, Curator Of Greek Art at Met, Is Dead
description: Christine Alexander, curator emeritus of the department of Greek and Roman art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died here Wednesday, at the age of 82.

title: First SST Trip Is on Time, Soviet Asserts
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (Reuters) The Soviet Union's Tupolev144 airliner, rival of the BritishFrench Concorde, flew a supersonic schedule today on what was billed as its first regular flight carrying freight and mail.

title: Kissingers Reach Jamaica
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and his wife, Nancy, arrived here tonight by private jet plane for a nineday vacation. The couple, accompanied by several State Department officials, will stay at the plantation home of Sir Harold Mitchell, a wealthy publisher.

title: Transcript of Nadjari Statement Rejecting His Ouster
description: Following is a transcript of the statement by Maurice H. Nadjari, special state prosecutor, made yesterday at 2 World Trade Center, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Rams' Owner Wants the Title, And He Doesn't Want to Wait
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 26There is a sense of urgency about Carroll Rosenbloom, the 67yearold owner of the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Regents Ask for 8% SchoolBudget Rise, But Don't Hold Much Hope for Getting It
description: The State Board of Regents will ask the Legislature for a record $3.4 billion education budget for next year, while acknowledging that the chances of having the full sum appropriated during the current state fiscal crisis are slim.

title: Navy Drops Search for 2
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 26 (UPI)The Navy has given up the search for two Marine Corps officers lost when their F4 jet fighter crashed into the Pacific Ocean near San Clemente Island on Wednesday. A spokesman said that a twoday search of a 600squaremile area by ships and planes had turned up no trace of the men from the El Toro Marine Corps Air Station. The pilot and radio intercept officer were seen ejecting from the jet just before it hit the water. The names of the men were not made public.

title: Children Found Dead
description: Two small Queens children whose mother had reported losing them in a crowded Queens department store on Christmas Eve were found dead in a rubblestrewn lot in East Harlem last night and the mother and a man with whom she lives were charged with their murder. Details on Page 4.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR. Piano. Concerto No. 1, Tomasek; Suite in C, Telemann; Overture to The Siege of Corinth, Rossini; Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Handel, BrahmsRubbra; Rapsodie Espagnole, Ravel: Overture to Olympia, Kraus; Cello Concerto No. 2, Herbert; Cortege Solennel, Glazunov; Toccata, Tose r.

title: New Zealand Jobless Hit by Rising Prices
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 26Buster Caspersen is a member of a select group, one of the 5,700 unemployed in New Zealand's labor force of 800.000.

title: PRISON IS DAMAGED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 26 (UPI)More than half the cells at the New Hampshire State Prison were damaged beyond use by inmates angered over the refusal to release a dozen prisoners from solitary confinement for their Christmas Day meal.

title: Greene Won't Start for Steelers Today
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26The unimaginative may speak of the Baltimore Colts as a Cinderella team, but Fred Cook, who doesn't rush the passer in glass slippers, will have none of that fairytale stuff. He sees tomorrow's American Conference playoff game with the Pittsburgh Steelers in Biblical terms.

title: 2 Children Found Dead
description: Two small Queens children whose mother had reported losing them in a crowded Flushing department store on Christmas Eve were found dead in a rubblestrewn lot in East Harlem last night, and the mother and a man with whom she lives were charged with their murders

title: Nadjari Case Is Expected To Spill Into Legislature
description: Maurice H. Nadjari's open defiance of his dismissal as special state prosecutor is not likely to save his job, but it has embroiled Governor Carey in a major political controversy that will very likely spill over into the next session of the Legislature, Democratic and Republican politicians agreed yesterday.

title: Population Shifts Affect Papers in Detroit
description: DETROIT  In one of the fiercest dailynewspaper circulation battles in the country, The Detroit Free Press has finally caught up with, and barely surpassed, The Detroit News. For this city, it Is as if suddenly more Fords than Chevrolets were being sold.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Weed ended Dec. 26, 1975

title: School Ban Ends on Piri Thomas Book
description: A Queens school district has repealed its 1971 ban on Piri Thomas's autobiography, Down These Mean Streets, which vividly depicts the life and language of Spanish Harlem.

title: 2 Hurt in Vermont Blast
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Dec. 26 (AP)Two persons were injured in an explosion at the Brattleboro Kiln and Drying Company today, a company spokesman said. The two men, Ervin Ryan and Walter Bruce, were listed in good condition in the Brattleboro Memorial Hospital with multiple burns and bruises. The explosion was believed to have been caused by a spark from a boiler that ignited dust on the roof.

title: Helping Children in Trouble
description: For too long now, this nation's juvenilejustice system has hidden its woefully inadequate performance behind lofty aspirations and wishful dreams.

title: Group Seeks to Improve Benefits In Thrift Food Stamp Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) The Food Research and Action Center of New York, a publicinterest group that has already forced the Government to liberalize parts of the food stamp program, is preparing to take the Agriculture Department back to court to win new benefits for the poor.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey has announced adoption of its first standards to control chemical and oiltank emissions into the air. The rules will take effect next March 1, the Department of Environmental Protection said in Trenton.

title: 15 Dead in Australian Fire
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 26 (Reuters)The death toll in a fire at a Sydney hotel yesterday rose today to 15 when a 70yearold woman died of burns. Sight of the dead have not been identified, the police said.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: The Elite Still Meet To Ski at Sun Valley
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 26The Flexible Flyer may be out of production, but that other perennial old favorite of winter sports, Sun Valley, shines on and on.

title: Thalhimer to Buy Norfolk Building
description: Thalhimer Brothers Inc. of Richmond, a leading department store operator in the South Central region, said yesterday that it was acquiring the building occupied by the J. B. Hunter store in Norfolk. The cost of acquiring the building and remodeling it into a Thalhimer store will, total $8 million. J. B. Hunter, a subsidiary of the Allied Stores Corporation, a national department store chain, will close its operations next month and Thalhimer contemplates opening in the fall of 1976. The store, which has 157.000 square feet, is situated in the Military Circle Shopping Center in Norfolk at the intersection of Virginia Beach Boulevard, Interstate Highway 64 and. Military Highway. The shopping center, which has an area of 975,000 square feet includes J. C. Penney, Smith & Welton and Liggetts Depart ment Store.

title: NADJARI REJECTS OUSTER AND ASKS PUBLIC'S SUPPORT
description: Maurice H. Nadjari yesterday defied Governor Carey's abrupt decision to remove him as special state prosecutor and appealed to the public to join him in protesting the Governor's action.

title: Spain Says It Freed 6,370
description: MADRID, Dec. 26 (AP) The Justice Ministry said today that 6,370 prisoners had been released since King Juan Carlos I granted a pardon on Nov. 22. The announcement said that 52R had been political offenders. Spain's prison population on Dec. 21 was 9,171, the ministry said.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: IslandersRed Wings Game in Detroit Postponed Because of Heavy Snow
description: DETROIT, Dec. 26The Detroit Red Wings called off Their game today with the New York Islanders because of a heavy snowstorm that struck the area yesterday.

title: Deathh Toll Pat at 100 In Sahara Port Battle
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, Dec. 26 (AP)A nineday battle over the port of La Guera in southern Spanish Sahara has ended with nearly 100 persons dead and Mauritanian forces in control of the city, an official announcement said today.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: 12 Killed in Lebanese Fighting; Karami Confers With Arafat
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26Twelve people were killed in MoslemChristian fighting here last night and today.

title: . . . Unclosed Hospitals
description: The answer to the need for major cutbacks in the municipal hospitals is not to nibble away at their vital but relatively inexpensive facilities for ambulatory care. Rather, it lies in a recognition that no valid line can be drawn between the municipal and the voluntary hospitals in a period when thirdparty payments through Medicare, Medicaid, Blue Cross and other insurance programs account for well over threequarters of all hospital revenue.

title: OPTIMISM IS FOUND IN APPAREL FED
description: After a strong year when apparel outshone consumer durables and helped to keep overall retail sales at a generally high level, the country's apparel industry enters 1976 in a position of strength.

title: PERES BACKS TALKS WITH PALESTINIANS
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 26 (AP) Defense Minister Shimon Peres said today that the Israeli Government should agree to talk with Palestinian representatives other than members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Slow Economic Upturn Is Seen for State in 1976
description: TRENTON, Dec. 27 (AP)Leading, state economists have concluded that New Jersey, like the rest of the nation, can expect a slow economic recovery next year that will be insufficient to reduce significantly the state's 13 percent unemployment rate.

title: Protecting Pensions
description: During the critical days when municipal employees' pension funds emerged as the last hope to rescue the city from default, the understandable response was universal relief. Cliff hanging permitted little time for longterm analysis of the rescue operation's potential impact on the rescuers.

title: Burial Set for C.I.A. Man
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)  The body of Richard S. Welch, the Central Intelligence Agency chief in Athens who was murdered outside his home Tuesday, will be returned to Washington early next week for burial.

title: GLADYS B. ADAMS
description: Gladys B. Adams, wife of Val Adams, television and radio writer for The Daily News and former TV and radio editor of The New York Times, died Thursday of cancer at the Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N. J. She was 58 years old.

title: Roosevelt Entries
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Scientist Tracks Old Logs for Prehistoric Clues
description: BISHOP, Calif.You realize, of course, how much of a needleinahaystack job this is, Henry N. Michael remarked, shifting into a lower gear and steering the Toyota Land Cruiser across the dusty alluvial plain toward Silver Canyon.

title: Syria Denies Reports It Arrested 300 Communists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26Reports published in Cairo that Syria had arrested 300 members of the Syrian Communist Party were denied in Damascus today by a Government spokesman.

title: Highs and Lows
description: NEW HIGH23

title: Stocks on Amex and Counter Advance on Bargain Hunting
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading finished higher yesterday in light trading.

title: Making Monkeys Neurotic, Dogs Shriek, Etc., Etc., Etc., Etc., Etc
description: VICTORIA, AustraliaA bill introduced Dec. 11 in the House of Representatives by New York Congressmen Edward I. Koch and Edward W. Pattison seeks to establish an 11member commission on the humane treatment of animals to investigate the extent of abuses to animals on farms, in research, in sports, in the home and in their, natural environment.

title: 25% Municipal and School Cuts Voted for Yonkers by State Unit
description: YONKERS, Dec. 26A plan cutting school and municipal personnel and services in this city by approximately 25 percent was approved by the stateappointed Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board at a closed meeting in City Hall today.

title: E.P.A. ACTS TO PARE SEWER GRANT COST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26A new set of regulations has been issued by the Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to protect the financial integrity of the $18 billion program of Federal grants to cities for waste treatment plants.

title: Canada Gasoline Norms Due
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 26 (AP)The Canadian government plans to announce mandatory gasoline efficiency standards for automobiles early next year. Energy Minister Alastair Gillespie said. He added that details would be disclosed after discussions with automobile manufacturers.

title: Trims Force Botanical Garden Closings
description: The begonias will bloom unseen at the New York Botanical Garden for 20 days in January.

title: OPEC Invited to Abu Dhabi To Resume Talks on Prices
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26 (AP)  Abu Dhabi has invited the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to resume their interrupted Vienna meeting in the Persian Gulf emirate in February, the Saudi Arabian radio reported today.

title: Trends in Portugal Buoying Exiles in Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 24Shifting events in Portugal, with economic disaster threatening and Communist power receding, have buoyed the hopes of rightwing Portuguese exiles here.

title: Business Briefs
description: WHITE PINE, Mich., Dec. 26 (AP)The Copper Range Company today said it was curtailing operations at its copper mine and mill facilities in White Pine and laying off 2,100 workers on Jan. 4. Chester O. Ensign Jr., president and chief executive, announced the layoffs in New York The work force at the White Pine operation totals 2,900

description: ACROSS

title: THAIS SAID TO SEEK U. S. PULLOUT DELAY
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec 26 (UPI)Thailand is attempt ing to delay the withdrawal of United States combat forces set for next spring, because of border problems with its neighbors, military sources said today.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET ARM FOR WAR, CHINA SAYS
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (AP)China declared today that the United States and the Soviet Union were preparing for a new world war, and the arms race between them is proceeding at a feverish pace neveh seen before.

title: Art: Peggy Bacon Savors Whole Human Comedy
description: Any artist who sustains a public career over the course of many decades is bound, sooner or later, to suffer from the usual shifts in fashion and taste. It sometimes requires a strong sense of humor, not to mention other strengths of character, to persist in the face of such vicissitudes. Fortunately for Peggy Bacon, the American painter, illustrator and writer who turned 80 this year, a, sense of humor has always been a basic constituent of her manysided talents. Much of her work consists of satirical, though affectionate, glimpses of the art world a her day, and the whole human comedy has been her abiding subject. She is well equipped to savor the irony as well as the pleasure of the revival her art is currently enjoying.

title: 6 Tenants and Doorman Robbed Of $3,562 in Lobby on East Side
description: Three armed robbers invaaea the lobby of a luxury apartment building on Manhattan's East Side last night and seized $3,562 in cash and jewels from six tenants and the doorman after herding them into a small hallway, the police reported.

title: JOHN E. BURCHARD, EXDEAN AT M.I.T.
description: John Ely Burchard, clean emeritus of the. School of Humanities and Social Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and in 1954 president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 77 years old.

title: INDONESIAN ATTACK IN TIMOR REPORTED
description: DARWIN, Australia, Dec. 26 (Reuters)A radio message, believed to be from a member of the leadership of the leftwing Revolutionary Front in Portuguese Timor, said today that Indonesian forces had opened a major new offensive. in the territory.

title: Rainfall for Year Here Exceeded Only by 1972's
description: Yesterday's rainfall increased the total for the year in the city to more than 60 inches. This made 1975 at least the second wettest year on record, surpassed only by the 67.03 inches that fell in 1972. The average annual rainfall for the city is 40.19 inches.

title: NADJARI REJECTS OUSTER AND ASKS PUBLIC'S SUPPORT
description: Maurice H. Nadjari yesterday defied Governor Carey's abrupt decision to remove him as special state prosecutor and, appealed to the public to join him in protesting the Governor's action.

title: Michael Singer Blends Nature With Art at a Show Here
description: Traditional outdoor sculpture competes With its environment. It also stands apart from it in such a way that no one could confuse the two. The final effect may be complementary rather than competitive, as it is in the Boboli Gardens in Florence or the park at Versailles; but it remains historically true that in such contexts art was art and nature was nature and no one could mistake one for the other.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26A new set of regulations has been issued by the Environmental Protection Agency in an effort to protect the financial integrity of the $18 billion program of Federal grants to cities for waste treatment plants.

title: Some Bullish on Banks Although Showing Is Off
description: According to a timenonored Wall Street maxim, the moment to turn bullish is when gloom prevails and stocks are deeply depressed.

title: Business Loans Up At City Banks Again
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that business loans at major New York City banks rose $89 million in the week ended Wednesday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 22 Die in Peru Bus Plunge
description: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 26 (AP)A bus slid off a mountain road into a gorge high in the Andes on Christmas Eve, killing at least 22 persons and injuring 30 others, reports from the ancient Inca capital of Cuzco said today.

title: MONEY BRINGS FISH TO DETROIT RIVER
description: DETROIT (AP)It took ah investment of some $750 million and 10 years of labor to bring the Chinook salmon and steelhead trout back to the Detroit River

title: PROXMIRE CHIDES BANKING AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, said today employees of Fecleral agencies that regulate banks spend lavishly for travel, office space and furnishings.

title: Paterson Merchants Protest Parking Meters
description: PATERSONWe intend to fight this all the way, said Anthony Colornbini, president of the Downtown Mall Merchant's Association, referring to a city plan to install public parking meters at a small parking lot now used exclusively as free parking for mall merchants and their customers.

title: L. I. Pupils Aid Neediest for the 6th Year
description: For the sixth consecutive year, the students of Mrs. Miriam Gemson's seventhgrade socialstudies class of Lawrence (L.I.) Junior High School have remembered the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: ITE Imperial Asks Ohio to Block Gould Offer
description: The ITE Imperial Corporation, which has been fighting off a takeover hid by Gould Inc. for the last 14 months, has asked the Ohio Division of Securities to block the tender offer.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HELD OVER The first of five additional performances of the Soviet Circus (formerly the Moscow Circus) will be held at the Felt Forum, at Madison Square Garden today. Additional performances also will be held Monday, Tuesday, and Jan. 3 and 5.

title: Unbeaten N.C. State Captures 6th, 11098
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 26 (AP)Kenny Carr scored a careerhigh 40 points and Phil Spence added 30 to lead ninthranked North Carolina State to a 11098 victory over Western Kentucky tonight in the second game of the Holiday Doubleheader.

title: Harry J. Becker Is Dead at 66; A Leader in Community Health
description: Harry J. Becker, a leaning specialist in medical economics and community health care, died Tuesday at his home in Biookfield Center, Conn. He was 66 years old.

title: Oil Payments in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 26 (AP)The Venezuelan Government will pay slightly more than $1 billion to the private oil companies being nationalized Jan, 1, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said today. The compensation will be paid in three installments: on Jan. 1, in February and in March. The amount of each installment was not disclosed.

title: Budget Cuts Upset Coaches at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 26Cornell University's athletic program is in serious financial difficulty. Coaches are wondering whether their programs will survive, and many have begun looking for jobs elsewhere.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Leading state economists in Trenton have concluded that New Jersey, like the rest of the nation, can expect a slow economic recovery next year that will be insufficient to reduce significantly the state's 13 percent unemployment rate. The state's Economic Policy Council, in issuing its yearend review and New Year's forecast, said statistics now show that the state and nation are in a recovery period but recovery from the deepest recession in forty years still leaves an excessive number of people willing and able to work, without jobs.

title: FundShort States Cut Services
description: Faced with insufficient tax revenues and increased expenses, many large states are cutting their contributions to welfare and education in an effort to present mandatory balanced budgets while trying to avert politically unpopular tax increases.

title: FundShort States Curb Services
description: Faced with insufficient tax revenues and increased expenses, many large states are cutting their contributions to welfare and education in an effort to present mandatory balanced budgets while trying to avert politically unpopular tax increases.

title: STATE WINS CASE FOR WIRE TAPPING
description: TRENTON, Dec. 26 (UPI)A state appeals court today ordered the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company to trace calls to establish the indentity of criminals when properly requested by law enforcement officials.

title: LowTar Cigarettes Taking Increasingly Higher Share of Market
description: A persistent critic of the tobacco industry observed in angry admiration recently that the clever fiends have even learned to capitalize on smokers' health worries to sell them more of the stuff that makes them sick

title: Newspaper in Cairo Says Libya Financed Raid on OPEC Talks
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Dec. 27 (Reuters)  A leading Cairo newspaper said today that the Libyan leader, Muammar elQaddafi, financed last Sunday's terrorist attack on the Vienna headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Unaborted Clinics . . .
description: The fourteen family planning clinics operated by the municipal hospital system, which were to have closed next week as an austerity measure, have been given a onemonth reprieve. The delay will afford all health groups in this city a chance to explore possible outside financing for these invaluable clinics or alternate means of supplying their services.

title: Suzanne Cott Becomes Bride Here
description: Suzanne Cott, editorial associate of WCBSTV and widow of Ted Cott, the television producer and former radio announcer, was married here yesterday afternoon to Lester Wunderman, president and chief executive officer of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline Inc.. advertising agency. and executive vice president of Young & Rubicam International Inc. State Supreme Court Justice Xavier C. Riccobono performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment.

title: French Consumer Prices Up
description: PARIS, Dec. 26 (AP)French consumer prices rose between 9.6 percent and 9.9 percent this year, the National Statistics Institute said today. For the first 10 months of 1975, inflation was running at a monthly average of 0.8 percent, they said.

title: MIXED YEAR LISTED BY PAPER INDUSTRY
description: The paper industry in the United States had a roller coaster year in 1975, starting off on a deep descent and finishing on a steep climb in sales and production, according to the American Paper Institute.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high lido at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: BELGRADE HOLDING AN EXPARTY AIDE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26The Yugoslav Governmen today publicly acknowledged for the first time that it was holding a Belgian resident who disappeared in Rumania last August and was presumed kidnapped by Yugoslav agents bringing into the open a cloak anddagger case that has beer the subject of gossip here for months.

title: PRESIDENT URGES A FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 26President Ford expressed concern today about the entry of heroin from Mexico into the United States and said that he would soon send to Congress a message proposing a broad Government response to the drugabuse problem in this country.

title: Temple Ousted With Villanova at Garden
description: St. John's defeated Temple, 6759, last night in the first game of the Holiday Festival doubleheader at Madison Square Garden, but it hardly was the predicted mismatch. Before the unbeaten Redmen won their eighth game, Coach Lou Carnesecca went through the handwaving, bodytwisting routine of his that springs from close games.

title: Money
description: Friday, December 26, 1975.

title: Manhattan Puts Bonnies Out by 6765
description: Indiana, an irresistible force on the basketball court, advanced to the semifinals of the Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternon with a devastating 10663 victory over a severely overmatched Columbia team.

title: OFFICER SHOT TWO IN BACK OF HEAD
description: Two men who were killed by an offduty police officer on Staten Island late Monday night during an alleged robbery attempt were each shot twice in the back of the head, it was revealed in an autopsy report issued yesterday by the Medical Examiner's office.

title: Sony Corp. Net Income Down For Year and Final Quarter
description: The Sony Corporation, the Japanese television and electronics manufacturer, announced yesterday that its net income fell in its fiscal year and final quarter, ended Oct. 31.

title: Nadjari Case Is Expected To Spill Into Legislature
description: Maurice H. Nadjari's open defiance of his dismissal as special state prosecutor is not likely to save his job, but it has embroiled Governor Carey in a Major political controversy that will very likely spill over into the next session of the Legislature, Democratic and Republican politicians agreed yesterday.

title: Messenger of Song Wins Before 54,648
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP)  Messenger of Song captured the $33,300 Palos Verdes Handicap today as Santa Anita opened its 77day winter meeting before a crowd of 54,648, the largest turnout in California horse racing this year.

title: FRANCIS PRATT, 72, EXTIME SALES AIDE
description: Francis DeWitt Pratt, former circulation director of Time, Life and Fortune magazines, died Wednesday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Arizona State Rally Tops Nebraska, 1714
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 26 (AP) Danny Kush, the coach's son, kicked a 29yard field goal with 4 minutes 50 sec??onds to play and gave Ari??ona State a 1714 upset victory over Nebraska in the Fiesta Bowl today.

title: Bruins Beat Sabres, 63, Trail by 2
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 26 (AP)The Boston Bruins overcame twogoal deficits twice and defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 63, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: SERAPHIC DIALOGUE BY GRAHAM DANCERS
description: Peter Sparling's debut as St. Michael and Diane Gray's first appearance this season as Joan marked the Martha Graham Dance Company's performance of Seraphic Dialogue yesterday afternoon at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

title: Farms Are Sprouting On Chinese Prairie
description: URUMCHI, ChinaMore than a million ethnic Chinese settlers have hacked out vast state farms in the oncebarren virgin lands of the Sinkiang Uigur Autonomous Region on China's remote northwestern frontier.

title: New Arab Red Mayor Promises To Stress Nazareth Development
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 26  Toufik Zayad, the Israeli Communist and Arah nationalist who Was elected Mayor of Nazareth, took office today and pledged to keep politics out of City Hall.

title: In the Capital of Estonia, West Meets East
description: TALLINN, U.S.S.R,  In the:cozy puppet theater on Lair Street, excited small childrendressed in their Saturdaybest were cheering a matinee performance of Punamutsike, the Estonianlanguage version of Little Red Riding Hood.

title: Iowa Aides Misjudge Old Courthouse Value
description: ALLISON, Iowa, Dec. 26 (AP)Butler County supervisors wish they had heard earlier of Dudley Gray's offer to purchase an Iowa courthouse for up to $100,000. They just signed a contract to pay $4,720 to demolish their old one.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary of Nathan S. Stern, automotive pioneer in The New York Times last Saturday, his age was incorrectly given. He was 96 years old. Survivors include two daughters and three grandchildren.

title: People in Sports
description: Jackie Sherrill, University of Pittsburgh defensive coordinator, has been named head football coach at Washington State and was scheduled to begin his duties immediately after the Panthers 3319 victory over Kansas in the Sun Bowl at El Paso yesterday.

description: In an obituary of Nathan S. Stern, automotive pioneer, in The New York Times last Saturday, his age was incorrectly given. He was 96 years old. Survivors include two daughters and three grandchildren.

description: Ask Lewis Salton if he ever thinks of himself as being something of a latterday Santa Claus and he replies without hesitation that he is not.

title: Lloyd Advances At Aussie Net
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec 26 (AP)John Lloyd of Britain wasn't thrilled with the way he played today but it was good enough to produce an openinground victory in the Australian open tennis championships. Lloyd heat Bob Carmichael of Australia, 75, 61, 46, 61

description: The Hudson River Museum a small, 53yearold arts refite perched high on the bank o the Hudson in Yonkers, mad be the first cultural casualty of the fiscal crises spreading to cities throughout the unites States.

title: The U. S. Black Connection
description: PRETORIA, South Africa  United States policy toward the African continent is emotionally influenced by two historical legacies. The first is a tradition of anticolonialism dating from our own revolutionary origins and reaffirmed this century by Presidents Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt.

title: One Missing and 7 Saved As 2 Craft Sink in Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (UPI)Two ships servicing offshore oil rigs sank in rough seas and 45 mileanhour winds in the Gulf of Mexico yesterday. One man is missing.

title: 49ers Drop Nolan as Coach
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP)Dick Nolan was dismissed as head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, Louis G. Spadia, the club's president and general manager, announced today.

title: Chile Tells Briton to Leave
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, Dec. 26 (AP)Dr. Sheila Cassidy, the Britis physician detained by authorities since Nov. 1, has been ordered to leave Chile by Monday, the military government said today. Dr. Cassidy was accused of treating a wounded leftist guerrilla leader and sheltering other fugitive extremists but was never formally charged.

title: Power Disruption Delays Trains on IRT and BMT
description: Signal troubles caused by a power failure in a Consolidated Edison substation were blamed by the Transit Authority for extensive delays on IRT and BMT subway lines last evening.

title: Trial for Woman With Dagger
description: LOS ANULLES, Dec. 26 (UPI) Christine Nicholson, 43 years old, must stand trial for possession of a 5inch dagger that the police found in her handbag Dec. 9 as she waited outside the Los Angeles Times building where Vice President K??cketeller was conferring with editors. Municipal Court Commissioner Richard A. Margolin said he would set a date for the trial on Jan. 9.

title: Notes on People
description: Gerald W. Lynch, a 38yearold psychology professor who delivered a paper in Frenchon police operations in the United Statesat the French national police school, has been named acting president of the City University's John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Dr. Lynch had been vice president and deputy to Dr. Donald H. Riddle, who resigned after eight years to become chancellor of the Chicago Circle campus of the University of Illinois.

title: Antiques: Kirk Silver
description: YONKERSThe sparkling teapots and platters set out in such splendid arrangements against bright green felt backgrounds seem totally in keeping with what should have been a festive holiday season here at the Hudson River Museum.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is no better example of the hollowness of the publicprivate strike dichotomy than the elevenday work stoppage of private carting companies which has just ended. The public interest is no longer served by perpetuating the artificial legalism that special horrors attach only to public employee strikes. The private carters clearly demonstrated that a private sector stoppage may have a greater social impact than some public employee strikes.

title: Pitt Beats Kansas in Sun Bowl. 33 19
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 26Gov. Milton Shapp of Pennsylvania was the first person tossed under the shower in the University of Pittsburgh dressing room today after the Panthers, convinced they are on the verge of a new era in football, whipped Kansas, 3319, in the 41st annual Sun Bowl name.

title: Delta State Women Notch Record 36th
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP)Led by Louisa Harris's 30 points, the defending national champion, Delta State University, rolled to a 9155 victory over Southern Connecticut State in a women's basketball tournament game at the Palestra tonight.

title: Family of 4 Dies in Fire At Home in Massachusetts
description: HOLLISTON, Mass., Dec. 26 (UPI)  A family of four, trapped by flames and dense smoke that prevented rescue, was killed today in an earlymorning house fire, the police said

description: The clumsiness with which Governor Carey booted out Special Prosecutor Nadjari is creating just the impairment of public confidence in the state's anticorruption drive that the firing was ostensibly designed to avoid.

description: Frosted glass has a peculiarly oldfashioned association. Its image conjures up icy opaque flowers rimming goblets; sinuous figures lolling across Lalique bowls.

description: TRENTON, Dec. 26  New Jersey's Presidential primary elections next summer are currently being described by officials from both parties as nearly classic examples of political futility.

description: At Bloomingdale's they pushed their way into crowded elevators. At Macy's they waited in line. At Saks Fifth Avenue they rushed to use their credit on newly markeddown bargains.

title: . . .Protectionist Peril
description: No significant complaint has been upheld so far, but West European, Japanese and other exporters are subjected to uncertainties that make it difficult for them plan and proceed with normal trade with the United States. The European Common Market has charged that 20 to 25 percent of its exports to the American marketabout $5 billion, with half represented by automobiles alonehave been affected by Federal investigations, pending or actual. The Treasury Department has refused to entertain the second biggest complaint, involving $2 billion of European steel exports. But as long as legal action is open to American steel companies to reverse the Treasury ruling, uncertainty remains.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY BARS DISMISSAL OF KEY GOVERNOR
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 26The army asserted its growing influence in political affairs today by blocking a demand by Peronist labor leaders that the federal Government remove the Governor of Buenos Aires Province.

description: Quickly, the score was 20.6 and the coach, hunched in intensity on the edge of his seat, clapped his hands and snapped, C'mon now, let's work, let's work, be sharp dotwn here. But it was the voice, of the coach whose team was winning, not the coach whose team was behind, and that's why Bobby Knight's team, topranked Indiana University, usually wins. There's a certain level of consistency that we're trying for, Bobby Knight likes to say. You're really playing against yourself. In the Holiday

description: The begonias will bloom unseen at the New York Botanical Garden for 20 days in January.

title: CONTESTS ARE SET IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 26The filing period for the New Hampshire Presidential preference primary, the earliest in the nation, ended at 5 P.M. today with the main event shaping up as a confrontation between President Ford and former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.

title: Children Found Dead
description: Two small Queens children whose mother had reported losing them in a crowded Queens department store on Christmas Eve were found dead in a rubblestrewn lot in East Harlem last night and the mother and a man with whom she lives were seized in connection with their murder. Details on Page 4.

title: Ballet: Basic Giselle
description: What was so good about Eleanor D'Antuono and Ted Kivitt's first Giselle of American Ballet Theater's season Friday evening at the Uris Theater was the way their acting consistently flowed into the dance movement.

title: Japan Sets Color TV Peak
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26 (Reuters,)Japan's deliveries of color television sets to domestic ?? export markets in November rose to a record of 891,000 units, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan reported today. Exports dropped 2 percent to 242,000 but were 21 percent above the year earlier level.

title: Some Markets Closed
description: Most commodity exchanges in the United Sixes were closed yesterday, as were securities and commodity exchanges in Canada and Europe.

title: Trade Boom...
description: The news that the United States is running its biggest trade surplus in history, at a whopping annual rate of $11.5 billion for the first eleven months of 1975, raises questions about the validity of the protectionist panic that seems to have seized wide segments of American business and labor this year.

title: Market Place
description: Tender offers, out of vogue for years following the bear market of the early 1970's, are back in a new form that is proving especially hard for management to deal with and for shareholders to evaluate.

description: A hot towel was wrapped around Spencer Haywood's valuable left wrist as he sat in his 64th Street apartment overlooking Central Park yesterday afternoon.

title: Couple Complete the Faithful Restoration of a 1790 House in Newark
description: NEWARK, Dec. 26An 18thcentury farmhouse in the center of Newark has become a museum piece, thanks to a historically minded, imaginative local couple, Mr. and Mrs. Dorlan Henderson.

title: 15 Sue for Fireman Jobs
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 26Fifteen Rutgers University students are suing this city for withdrawing its offet to use them as special lowpaid firemen. The suit asks that the city compensate the students in place of the program which was voted down by the City Council on Dec. 3.

description: The community wanted something else, and here it is, said Jeffrey Deneroff, one cif the owners of the remodeled Beverly Twin Theater, at Church and McDonald Avenues in the Kensington section of Brooklyn.

title: Report on Soviet Grain Shows a Low '75 Crop
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Figures released by the Government newspaper, Izvestia, for average Soviet grain output over the last five years show that the 1975 total was less than 133 million metric tons. Western observers said today.

title: Honda Plans Price Increase
description: The Honda Motor Company announced in Tokyo yesterday that it would raise motorcycle prices about 5.5 percent, effeetive Jan. 1. The company sells a large number of its motorcycles in the United States.

description: TRENTON, Dec. 26 (AP) Government Byrne was at his desk shortly after 9 A.M. today and spent the day at the State House in staff meetings,

title: Woman to Be Carey Appointments Aide
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 26  Governor Carey today named Judith Hope, the outgoing Supervisor of this resort town, as his new appointments secretary, making her one of the topranking members of his administration.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GATES OF HELL. By Harrison E. Salisbury. 409 pages. New York: Random House. $10.

title: Iraq and Iran Sign Accords On Border and Other Issues
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  Iraq and Iran, which settled a longstanding border dispute last March, today signed a series of goodneighbor agreements.

title: 10 at Seaport Restoring Wavertree to Glory of 1885
description: Behind the aging fish markets of Fulton Street, down on the brooding wharves of the waterfront, 10 men are at work on the sailing ship Wavertree, trying to reverse a disaster that began 65 years ago in a November gale.

title: Girl, 11, Who Lost a Bid For Horse, Finds a Santa
description: Dari Kaplan, an 11yearold Peekskill, N. Y., girl whose Christmas dreams appeared to have fallen apart last week with her unsuccessful bid for a surplus New York City police horse, had a wonderful holiday after all.

title: Williamsburg Rabbi Shot During Walk By Two From a Car
description: A 65yearold Orthodox rabbi walking in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning was shot three times and seriously wounded by two assailants who fled in an automobile.

title: Y.W.C.A. Bid to Bar Swimming Parties In Nude Is Appealed
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP)The question of mixed swimming in the nude at the Young Women's Christian Association has been given to Judge Ruth Abrams of Superior Court to resolve.

title: Bridge:
description: There is one basic rule of discarding: Hang on to length in a suit in which dummy has length. But it is wrong to follow any rule without considering its application in a particular case.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (UPI)  George McGinnis capped a 31point, 20rebound performance on a driving layup with 43 seconds left and gave the Philadelphia 76ers a 9695 comeback victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight

description: The stock market's yearend rally kept rolling along yesterday as glamour, airline, savingsandloan, bluechip and oilfield equipment issues scored gains along a broad front.

title: Helen Iswolsky, 79, Writer On Russia and the Church
description: Helen Iswolsky, author and onetime associate of Dorothy Day in the Catholic Worker movement, died of cancer Wedneday in Beacon (N.Y.) Hopital. She was 79 years old and lived in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: ApplianceRepair Licensing Investigated by Trade Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was investigating the licensing of radio, television and other appliancerepair services to determine whether they restrain competition.

title: New Polarioid Camera Due
description: The Polaroid Corporation announced yesterday plans to market a nonfolding instant camera that uses its SX70 film. The new camera will retail for less than $70 and is expected to reach a larger market than now available for the more expensive folding type SX70 models that produce finished pictures outside the camera shortly after the picture is taken.

title: Nets Win From Spirits, 105101
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 26The New York Nets, enjoying their biggest home crowd of the season, coasted to a 105101 victory over the Spirits of St. Louis tonight.

title: Clark Equipment to Close Factory and Lay Off 300
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mien., Dec. 26 (AP)The Clark Equipment Company will shut down its heavy construction equipment factory at ,Benton Harbor on Jan. 5 for nearly a month and lay off 300 factory employees, the company said today. Charles W. Johnson, vice president for manufacturing, said the shutdown was scheduled because of rising inventories and slack demand.

title: The Stage: Angel Street
description: Whatever happened to the good, oldfashioned melodrama? It probably drifted over to television and died. Just about 35 year ago (immediately before Pearl Harbor, actually) Patrick Hamilton's English thriller, Angel Street, opened on Broadway with resounding success. It was directed and produced by Shepard Traube. Last night, at the Lyceum Theater, Mr. Traube attempted an encore. It was not called for. was directed and produced by Shepard Traube. Last night, at the Lyceum Theater, Mr. Traube attempted an encore. It was not called for.

title: Smithsonian Considers Acquisition Of Capital's Museum of African Art
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26The Smithsonian Institution is considering, merging with the Museum of African Art. The Smithsonian's regents have asked a team of Smithsonian professionals to study the proposal. If the merger goes through, It would bring to seven the number of art museums administered by the Smithsonian. The African museum expects that a merger would ease its fundraising burden.

title: MRS. HODGE HELD A PATSY FOR MEN
description: Describing his client as a woman who liked sex better than common sense, Herbert Siegal told a State Supreme Court jury here yesterday that Beverly Donna Hodge had much to lose and nothing to gain from the death of her husband.

title: LONGTIME DONORS GIVE TO NEEDIEST
description: The 11yearold boy wanted to send the $5 he had saved to make a happier holiday for some child, and the New Yorker said he could not think of a more appropriate way to celebrate his 85th birthday than by contributing to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Cubans Reject Socialist As Part of Nation's Name
description: HAVANA, Dec. 27 (Reuters) The Republic of Cuba will not be renamed the Socialist Republic of Cuba as had been proposed during a discussion of the island's first constitution draft since the 1959 revolution, a Communist Party leader said.

title: Vacation Homes Target Of Tax Reform Effort
description: A middleaged New York City insurance salesman and his wife go out to Montauk on Long Island each September and live in their little tax shelter by the seaa cottage that they, rent to others tin July and August.

title: Did Industry Cry Wolf?
description: Late in 1974, a trade association representing nearly all of the chemical manufacturers using vinyl chloride gas, a proven cause of cancer, marched into Federal court in an attempt to overturn strict Labor Department Health standards about to go into effect.

title: A Cartoon History Of United States Foreign Policy, 17761976
description: Do not be misled. This cartoon history is no droll look back at our foreign policy. It is, instead, a depressing recognition of a persistent and dangerous impulse that has run through our relationships with the world. If these illustrations really reflect the American public's opinion of the world beyond the oceans, it is no wonder that so much rancor and pain has accompanied our foreign policy. Whatever other nations and peoples think of us, we don't seem to have very much affection for those lesser breeds across the waves.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Amy Yeager Bride Of Philip Geier 3d
description: Amy Marie Yeager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Dunn Yeager of Old Chatham, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Philip Otto Geier 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Geier Jr. of Cincinnati.

title: A 32 Favorite Pays $150,000 in Sweeps
description: LEOPARDSTOWN, Ireland, Dec. 27 (AP)Night Nurse began drawing away with two hurdles remaining and easily won the twomile Irish Sweepstakes Hurdle at Leopardstown today, making a halfdozen sweeps ticketholders each richer by $150,000.

title: Truman Capote, The Movie Star?
description: LOS ANGELES I liked Truman Capote a lot the moment I met him. He's a cute, little guyjockey height, with a freckled pink face, thinning blond hair and a thickening midsection. He was wearing whitestriped maroon jogging pants and a purple sweat shirt. At 51, he looks like a Buddha who's been around the track more than once. Very charming and hospitable, too. When I rang the door of his rented Coldwater Canyon home he greeted me warmly. Come in my dear, he said, immediately offering me something to drink. I took him up on a glass of Soave Bretone. He poured some grapefruit juice for himself and lay back on the couch and watched me nurse my wine.

title: Historic Area for Trenton
description: TRENTON  Most state governments take for granted the neighborhoods that immediately surround them. In many capitals, this has meant that urban decay and crazyquilt commercial development have encroached upon state houses and legislative chambers.

title: Jackson Views the Issue As Ability, Not Charisma
description: MIAMIFor Senator Henry M. Jackson, the 63yearold Washington Democrat, it had been a long, hard day. But then, almost every day is long and hard for a man who has been seeking his party's Presidential nomination since 1971, while remaining one of the most active members of the Senate.

title: Ragtime J. Is Victor In Pacing
description: WESTBURY, N. Y., Dec. 27 Ragtime J. won the first of four weeks of $25,000 elimination races in the Holiday Pacing Series at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The $50;000 final will be on Jan. 24.

title: The Education of Mikhail Baryshnikov
description: Since he defected from the Soviet Linton 18 months ago, Mikhail Baryshnikov  the most celebrated new talent in the world of dancehas strikingly expanded his art. He has added to his repertory more than 15 roles in ballets ranging from the strictly classicalSwan Lake and La Sylphideto a variety of contemporary works; such as Shadowplay and Le Jeune Homme et la Morte.

title: GERMAN OFFERS A SPACE TRUCK
description: STUTTGART, West Germany For 15 years Lutz T. Kayser, an aerospace engineer from Stuttgart, has asked himself why the rockets that propel unmanned satellites aloft are so expensive.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: From Mexico City came reports of conductor Jos Serebrier sticking his baton through his hand during a concert and heroically finishing in a welter of blood and grimlipped courage. I managed to get a hankerchief out of my pocket during a brief pause in the music, Serebrier was quoted as saying. I stuffed it into my hand and made a fist and continued that way for another 20 minutes until the finale.

title: FLEEING VETERAN RELIVES THE WAR
description: KIEFER, Okla., Dec. 27 (UPI) A farmer, who chased a man he had found hiding in his barn, said today that the stranger resembled pictures of a World War II veteran who had fled a nursing home believing he was being pursued by German soldiers.

title: Carol Lavin Plans To Marry in May
description: Carol Lavin, an assistant product manager with AlbertoCulver Company, manufacturer of toiletry products in Melrose Park, Ill., and Howard Bernick, who is with the First Boston Corporation in Chicago, plan to be, married next May.

title: FARM UNION FOES LINKED TO THEFTS
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 27A former deputy sheriff who has been arrested for burglary has told law enforcement officials here that he was paid by two. California growers to break into offices of the United Farm Workers union in the mid1960's and steal union documents.

title: Cynthia Manning FitzPatrick Wed
description: Cynthia Manning FitzPatrick and Kevin Shannon Duffy were married yesterday afternoon in the Old Base Chapel at the Plattsburgh (N.Y.) Air Force Base. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. James E. Toole of Schuylerville, N. Y., a cousin of the bride.

title: GIAP SAYS VIETNAM PLANS UNIFIED VOTE
description: PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP)De fense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap of North Vietnam says tha general elections, will be held in 1976 in both North and South Vietnam for the estab lishment of a national assembly for all of Vietnam.

title: MICHAEL DURSO
description: Michael Durso, who had been a musical director at the Copacabana nightclub in this city, died Thursday at his home in Bolton Landing, N.Y. He was 70 years old.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERChristine,. on Dec. 24. Service private. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be appreciated.

title: SovietU.S Hockey Schedule
description: TonightSoviet Army at Rangers. (7:30 P.M.)

title: A Painted Devil
description: When mysteriously beautiful Fenella glimpses Edward, the brilliant young painter, on the Ponte Vecchio, they frown briefly and move on. Very British, that frown: After all, they haven't been introduced, and a smile would have been a vulgarity. Soon Fenella is Edward's model, a state of affairs that makes Edward's lover, Tristram, understandably uneasy. Without really seeming to like each other much, the three become inseparable: In Florence, the English countryside and London. they discourse weightily on art and death and continue to scorn vulgarity, a key concept having to do with honest or vulnerable behavior of any sort. Fenella and Tristram are nice but weak, no match for Edward, who is not just a genius, but selfish. vain and cold as a fish to boot. Marrying him drives Fenella into a melancholia Edward is too busy with painting and older women to notice, while Tristram, abandoned by Edward, lets his own artistic energies dissipate into marijuana  induced fantasies. The somewhat contrived end of it all is as bloody as the vulgarest reader could desire

title: The Quid and the Dead: Thieves and Tombs Along
description: IN 1871 a number of rare scarabs, statuettes and papyri began to the surface in e antiquities markets of Luxor, Egypt. In itself, this was not unusual. More than 3,000 years ago, Luxor had been the site of Thebes, the capital of Egypt during one of its richest periods, and the local fellahin often unearthed artifacts from the hundreds of tombs across the Nile. But the new objects seemed to have come from a series of hitherto Unknown royal burials, and as more and more of them appeared over the net few years, it became obvious that someone had made an astouding discovery. Suspicion focused on one familythe Abd el Rasuls of Sheik Abd el Gourna, a village on the west bank of the Nile at the edge of the ancient City of the Dead.

title: Snow making's First Fall to Be Hailed
description: A blast that should have Instantly been heard round the skiing world just 25 years agobut wasn'tis scheduled to be heard next Friday at the same Big Boulder winter resort of Lake Harmony, Pa. The occasion will be the cornmemoration of skiing's first snowmaking attempt at Big Boulder during the 1950 holiday season. Scheduled is a demonstration of artificial snow machines thattoday manufacture snow at several hundred ski centers across the United States.

title: Officers' Argument Over Driving Car Leads to Shooting
description: FLINT, Mich., Dec. 27 (AP)  A policeman and a policewoman were wounded today in a shootout during an argument over who was going to drivet their patrol car, the police said.

title: Washington never told a lie, or a joke either
description: The humor in Bissell's book is only fo fo.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1MAGNUM/LEONARD FREED

title: 2 New Teams Pick for Picks
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27The owners of the National Football League's newest franchises, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Seattle Seahawks, each plucked an envelope out of a red football helmet today and both came out winners.

title: China Reports It Has Built 40 New Berths at Ports
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 27 (Reuters)China has built 40 deepwater berths at its major seaports, each able to accommodate vessels of more than 10,000 tons, Hsinhua, the official Chinese press agency, has reported.

title: Christmas Gifts Get Postholiday Tryout
description: Twas two days after. Christmas and all through the city New Yorkers tested, displayed and enjoyed the presents they had received. Washington Square Park is the proving ground here.

title: G.O.P. Girding for Role in State Budget Planning
description: TRENTON  Despite the prospect of a budget gap that may approach $1 billion next year, the Legislature's Democratic majorities apparently are prepared to wait for Governor Byrne's budget message in February before formulating a fiscal response of their own. However, the Republicans already have begun to establish their fiscal posture in the Legislature, particularly in the Assembly, where their current small minority will more than double when the new session convenes on Jan. 13.

title: What's Doing in COPENHAGEN
description: THE MIXTURE  Despite Denmark's modern ideas on sex, pornography and social welfare, Copenhagen remains an Old World city, preserving its red brick buildings topped with copper spires turned green with age; many of which, like the Stock Exchange and the Round Tower, were erected in the 17th century during the 60year reign of Christian IV. Here and there modern, structures intrude, but the city fathers have been careful to maintain Copenhagen's charm. Traffic. is banned from a growing number of streets, and Copenhageners are managing to avoid the frenzied pace that characterizes so many metropolises. The intense campaign in the late nineteensixties to promote the city as the sex cauldron of the western world brought a corresponding increase in the criminal element. In response, the police cracked down on the sex houses, and the tourist industry began stressing Hans Christian Andersen, the Little Mermaid, Danish design and hygge, an untranslatable word implying coziness, comfort and human warmth. But pornography, in the form of pictures, movies and various sexual utensils, is here to stay as is the Danes' love of nudity, amply displayed on beaches in summer and in newspapers all year round.

title: The world's Only Shipboard College Awash in Sea of Debt and Uncertainty
description: After 10 years of smooth sailing, the self  styled world's only shipboard college is about to sink in an ocean of red ink.

title: Visiting Photographer
description: Andre Kertsz was born in Budapest in 1894, moved to Paris in 1925, and came to New York in 1936. Like so many visitors to the New World in the thirties, he and his wife Elizabeth expected their stay in the States to be a temporary one; their plans, and the subsequent course of their lives, were radically altered by the outbreak of the Second World War. Intensely European, they were yet able to make themselves at home in New York, and this may have been in part because they were also intensely urban: however different from one another the countries of the world may be, great cities tend to have much in commonmuch to which the energetic exile can learn to accommodate himself.

title: Steekrs, Rams Use Defense To Score Playoff Victories
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27Terry Bradshaw and Franco Harris, Pittsburgh's primary offensive threats, shrugged off leg injuries and played the whole game. The Baltimore Colts, however, couldn't shrug off Bert Jones's injury or the Steelers' devastating defense and lost the American Football Conference playoff game, 2810, today.

title: Richard Nenoff Marries Miss Ridley
description: In the First Presbyterian Church of Englewood, N. J., early last evening Deborah Lynn Ridley, a graduate of the Cornell UniversityNew York Hospital School of Nursing, was married to Richard S. Nenoff, a member of the class of '76 at the Cornell Medical College.

title: Program to Spur College Hiring of Women and Minority Teachers Lags Amid Continuing Controversy
description: More than five years after the start of the Federal Government's affirmative action program to promote the hiring of more women and minoritygroup faculty members by colleges and universities, the accomplishments are meager and the effort remains immersed in the controversy in which it began.

title: Cards Lose on Coast, 3523
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27The Los Angeles Rams played right to form today as they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3523, in a divisional playoff game before a crowd of 72,650 in the Coliseum that had the proper cheerDefense, defense, defense.

title: Judge in. Saxe Case Says No Gan Order Was Issued
description: BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Chief Justice Walter H. McLaughlin of Suffolk Superior Court has told The Boston Globe that he never imposed any formal restraints on news coverage of the murder trial of Susan Saxe, according to the newspaper.

title: The Promise And the Performance
description: This is not quite the book that, at first glance, its title suggests that it is going to be. It does not offer a clear answer to the question of how far John Kennedy's performance as President fell below the promise the held forth to the American people, much less is it a rejoinder to Henry Fairlie's spirited and stylish attack, The Kennedy Promise.

title: The Hockey Referee: Lonely Traffic Cop
description: Hockey has always been a violent game. For good and ill, violence is a hockey tradition. Violent body contact can make a fast game disciplined; violent fouling can transform a disciplined game into chaos.

title: Douglas Adler to Wed Prudence Schlesinger
description: The engagement of Prudente Schlesinger to Douglas Ochs Adler has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Edward B. Schlesinger of Alpine, N.J., and Lakeville, Minn., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of. Anne Freeman Adler and Julius Ochs Adler of New York.

title: Football Honor For Capozzoli
description: Tony Capozzoli, quarterback at St. Dominic's High School, Oyster Bay, L.I., has been named as a member of the 13th annual. Parade Magazine High School. AllAmerican Football team. The squad is chosen by high school and college coaches, sportswriters and radio and TV announcers.

description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124, North Salem, N.Y. Amateurowner, local and green working hunters; adult horsemanship. 8 A.M.

title: Nathan M. Rudich Dies at 56; A 20th CenturyFox Official
description: Nathan M. Rudich, national director of marketing services for the 20th CenturyFox Corporation since 1973, died of cancer Friday at a hospital in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 56 years old and had lived here before moving to California.

title: The World
description: Despite the precision and drama of their act, kidnapping most of the leading petroleum officials of the oilproducing world, the terrorists who invaded the Vienna office of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna last week made political demands that were notably vague.

title: WAGEPRICE CURB CALLED POSSIBLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Federal controls on wages and prices are possible by the end of 1976, the chief economist of the United States Chamber of Commerce said today.

description: Only one out of three Americans now say the United Nations is doing a good job, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

description: PISCATAWAY  Members of the Rutgers University community here, who sometimes trudge miles just to buy a pair of shoes, may be saved the trouble if a proposal for a small shopping mall on the local campus becomes a reality.

description: To the Editor:

title: Steelers and Rams Playoff Victors
description: The Pittsburgh Stealers, defending Super Bowl champions, rallied and defeated the Baltimore Colts, 2810, as the National Football League playoffs got under way yesterday. The Steelers thus advanced to the American Conference championship game Jan. 4.

title: INDIA MINE BLAST AND FLOODS TRAP HUNDREDS IN PITS
description: NEW DELHI, India, Sunday, Dec. 28An explosion ripped through a major coal mine in northeastern India yesterday, setting off flooding that trapped hundreds of workers, according to reliable reports from the scene. The men were feared dead.
