title: The Beef Bill in Congress Has Dramatized Divisions in Agricultural Community
description: A proposal for a Governmentsponsored promotion campaign to sell the public on the virtues of eating more beef has provoked an unusual controversy Congress. The controversy has not only pitted representatives of urban consumers against representatives of farm states but has also brought out deep, and normally hidden, divisions In the agricultural community itself.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 27 (AP) Five Soviet citizens were sentenced to death and 59 others to prison in a gigantic agricultural swindle that resulted in a loss to the state of about $12 million, a regional paper has revealed.

title: Arnold Schoenberg
description: By Charles Rosen. 113 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $7.50. Paper, $2.50.

title: The Creators
description: Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster are finally sitting on top of Metropolis. The two cartoonists who dreamed up Superman signed away their rights to their creation in 1948. Both had become nearly destitute, while the cartoon character has earned millions of dollars through comic books sales; television shows and related products. After the cartoonists' difficulties became public, however, the current owner of the rights to Superman, Warner Communications Inc., agreed to negotiate a settlement with them. Thanks mostly to public pressure, the two have won a settlement of $20,000 a year each for life, plus payment of legal expenses, additional medical benefits and payments to their heirs. One other bonus: their bylines will be restored to all future Supermen creations.

title: Picture Brightens at Recreation Center
description: NEWARK  The sixyearold Ironbound Recreation Center still stands as a scarred monument to $6 million in poor planning and the apparent contempt of vandals for the previous administration's proposed solution to some of the problems of youngsters seeking a place to play.

title: Texas Defeats Colorado, 38 to 21
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  The brother combination of Tim and Earl Campbell helped Texas score 24 points in the third period today en route to a 3821 victory over Colorado in the 17th AstroBluebonnet Bowl.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Corporate managements spend millions of dollars communicating with customers. They spend hundreds of thousands of dollars communicating with a narrow and limited audience of security analysts and other specialists who deal with a small range of often esoteric financial information. But, typically, they spend almost nothing in terms of money, time or thought on communications with the largest single force in the production of goods and services at a profittheir employees.

title: Marilynn Israel Is Bride
description: At the Oakland Jewish Center in Bayside, Queens, last night Marilynn Israel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Israel of Flushing Queens, was married to Steven P. Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Kaplan, of Brooklyn. Rabbi Irwin Isaacson performed the ceremony.

title: China Frees Copter And Russian Crew Captured in 1974
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 27China today released a Soviet helicopter and its three crewmen who were captured nearly two years ago when they intruded into Chinese territory, the official Chinese press agency Hsinhua reported.

title: Nancy Bloodgood Wed at St. Patrick's
description: In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Nancy Mary Bloodgood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Bloodgood of Duxbury, Mass., became the bride of Frederick William Tecklenburg; son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry. Christian John Tecklenburg Jr. of Orangeburg, S. C.

description: LevinWeinshall

description: The men and women who serve as directors of American corporations are living in confusing and turbulent times. They are under increasingly heavy attack and at the same time, they are flexing their muscles as never before.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: We used paint remover to remove the paint from the bricks around our fireplace. However, there are stilt spots where the paint remains in porous spots or holes in the brick. Is there any way to get these remaining spots or blemishes out of the brick?Mrs. M.N.S., Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Bomb Found in Shop Center
description: WILLOW SPRINGS, Ill., Dec. 27 (AP)A homemade bomb was found behind a travel agency only minutes after more than 1,000 shoppers were evacuated from the crowded low Spring Shopping Center in this Chicago suburb. An anonymous telephone caller with a heavy accent told a clerk at the Easy Way Travel Agency that a bomb would explode at 5 P.M. A policeman found the bomb hidden between the travel agency and a fence. He took it to a pistol range, and detonated it.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ONLY a few more days to go before the liftoff into 1976and still counting. There's not much time left to change the quality of an old year that has been so dramatic in many respects, but there is still opportunity for Government leaders, businessmen, labor leaders and the allimportant American consumer to draft some worthwhile resolutions to make things bettera whole lot betterin the new year.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Pro Basketball

title: The Little Decision
description: After a year of haggling, Congress has passed and President Ford signed a bill that deals directly with one aspect of the nation's energy problem, high oil prices, but only indirectly with another, the continuing, even growing dependence on foreign oil supplies.

title: Spontaneous Presidential Visits Called Safest by Secret Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) The Secret Service believes the best way to protect a President who wants to mix with crowds is to make his appearances very spontaneous.

title: Laurie Seiden Fiancee of Michael Silver
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seiden have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Ann Seiden, to Michael Mehnuth Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Silver. Both families live in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Now that it is popularly believed that New York is on its way to becoming a crumbling ruin and the corporate flight to the suburbs appears to be jetpropelled, it is instructive note two substantial new commercial undertakings in Lower Manhattan: the major renovation of 100 Broadway for the Bank of Tokyo and the new 40story Bankers Trust Building on Greenwich Street.

title: The Region
description: A controversial component of the plan that saved New York City from default has been, given legal approval irt, the first step of what probably will be a long process. Ruling on a challenge by the Flushing National Bank, a state Supreme Court judge last week decided that the moratorium voted by the State Legislature on the payment of principal of shortterm city notes was legal.

title: Knicks Notch 4th Straight
description: Spencer Haywood scored 26 points yesterday, Earl Monroe added 23 and with Butch Beard, at times, made the Madison Square Garden crowd of 15,337 forget that Walt Frazier was sidelined with an injured hip. But an unnoticed hero as the Knicks posted a 108101 triumph over the New Orleans Jazz for their fourth straight triumph may have been Dr. James Nicholas, the New York team doctor.

title: This Growling Hamlet Is No Sweet Prince
description: LONDON British Hamlets  Peter O'Toole, David Warner, Nicol Williamson, Alec McCowenhave been getting more virile in recent years. But I can remember none further removed from the sweetprince tradition of John Gielgud than the Hamlet that Albert Finney has thrown together for the National Theater. He rampages through Elsinore with a headband tied round his shaggy brown hair, looking like something out of The Seven Samurai. In the middie of one soliloquy he growls, brandishes his fists, and starts to shadowbox with the empty air; and even to be or not to be becomes a sort of verbal Russian roulette, delivered breathlessly and urgently, dagger in hand, after he has literally galloped on from the wings.

title: Gaston Gallimard, 94, Is Dead; A Leading Publisher of France
description: PARIS, Dec. 27Gaston Gallimard, France's foremost publisher, died at his home here on Christmas day. He was 94 years old.

title: P .D .Q. Bach Shows Age In Visit to Fisher Hall
description: There were two kinds of humor in the opening of the annual P.D.Q. Bach series at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night (the final two performances are tonight and tomorrow night): verbal and musical. This cumudgeonly reviewer found the verbal humor mildly amusing and the musical humor not so mildly sophomoric.

title: Suez Traffic Nears Record
description: PORT SAID, Egypt, Dec. 27 (AP)The Suez Canal Authority announced that 55 ships passed through the canal today, the largest number since the waterway was reopened last June 5, and approaching the record of 60 ships set before it was closed by war eight years ago.

description: Painting time. Executive types discover urgent business out of town. Housewives take to their beds. Needed yet dreaded, the fainter may well be the most unpopular man in town.

Charles Michael Schwab (18621939) was a western Pennsylvania country boy with all the Horatio Alger qualitiesinexhaustible energy, burning ambition, dauntless courage and incredible luckthat makes a modem biographer wince with embarrassment, even while discovering that the subject really was like that and that such things

description: The line that separates the sublime from the unsound is a hair's  breadth wide, which perhaps justifies the speculative sacrifice.

title: UPSTATER TO TAKE STATE FARM POST
description: ALBANYRoger Barber, a dairy farmer and vegetable grower in the Schoharie Valley, will take office Monday as the State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, the third person to hold that office this year.

title: Lag Is Found in Programs To Aid Juvenile Offenders
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27Despite evidence that communitybased correctional programs for juvenile offenders are less cotly and more effective than state institutions, a research report released today found that, on the average, only 17 percent of juvenile offenders were placed in community programs.

title: Brian Joseph Parker Weds Susan Ferdman
description: Susan Gail Ferdman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Ferdman of Massapequa Park, L.I., and Brian Joseph Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Parker of New York, were married yesterday in the Oceanside (L. I.) Jewish Center. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David Seligson.

description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz gold yesterday that he had not yet decided whether to go along with Governor Carey's decision to remove Maurice H. Nadjari as the special state anticorruption prosecutor.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 27 (AP)  Experiments in gene mixing will be overseen by faculty committees being set up at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in an effort to avoid inadvertent production of new organisms that could harm humans.

description: Anne Venze and Mark Brian Sendor, students at the Shappell College of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem, Israel, will be wed there Jan. 15.

John Baron, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

description: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Sarah Anne Fergusson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Carter Fergusson of Gladwyne, Pa., to Anthony Janney Brown, son of Medford Jennings Brown of Bryn Mawr, and the late Mrs. Anne Janney Brown.

description: Residences for women, which offer comfort and security at reasonable rates, are alive and flourishing, but decreasing in number here.

description: Before lawyers had a code of ethics, William F. Howe and Abraham Hummel, a pair of 19thcentury Manhattan attorneys who represented much of the carriage trade as well as the bestknown: criminals of their day, planted on top of their downtown office building a 40footlong, fourfoothigh sign with enormous block letters: spelling out Howe & Hummers Law Offices.

description: HACKENSACKAn elderly widower recovering from a stroke expressed concern the other day over the proposed Medicaid cuts.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Hundreds of workers were trapped in a major coal mine in northeastern India yesterday when an explosion caved in the walls and the water from a nearby reservoir rushed down the shafts. The men were believed to have died. Official sources in New Delhi said that 250 to 300 miners had been trapped in the mine near Dhanbad, but other reports reaching New Delhi said at least 700 miners may have been trapped. Ten hours after the explosion, rescue attempts by the national and state governments brought forth only four bodies and no survivors. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: L.I. Jewish Hospital Weighs Plan to Convert Rockaway Division to Outpatient Clinic
description: NEW HYDE PARK  The Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center is considering a new plan to convert its South Shore Division in Far Rockaway, Queens, to a large outpatient clinic and to build a major teaching hospital at a site in Nassau County.

title: ST. LOUIS SCHOOLS IN RACIAL ACCORD
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27A plan announced this week to desegregate the St. Louis school system without busing has been hailed by both sides of a suit that resulted in the agreement. The plan was called a way to avoid the kind of violence prompted by busing in Boston and Louisville. Ky.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: As the numismatic hobby grows more sophisticated and complex, collectors are under growing pressure to become better informed on an everwidening range of topics, including some of a legal or technical nature that are gaining in importance. But the attempts of most collectors to arm themselves with vital and varied knowledge have been frustrated by the necessity of digging through many different sources to find it. That problem has just been greatly simplified by Amos Press, Inc., of Sidney, Ohio, publisher of the weekly hobby newspaper, Coin World. They have published the Coin World Almanac, an 833page compendium of facts, figures and indepth information from many hundreds of references.

title: Peter AllenRadio's New Mr. Opera
description: I'm keenly aware of just how tremenopusly Milton Cross was loved and admired, saysPeter Allen, who on the afternoon of last January 4 stepped in to narrate the Metropolitan Opera broadcast of Rossini's L'Italiana in Algeri one day after Cross's sudden death. The 55yearold Allen, who had been serving on a standby basis, continued to man the broadcast booth for the duration of that season. Since then, his status has risen from that of standby to that of official replacement for Cross, who had been the host/narrator of the Saturday matines broadcasts for 43 years. Allen returned to the national airwaves earlier this month, when the Met opened its 197576 Texacosponsored broadcast season.

title: U.S. Sends Top Envoy On Mission to Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The Ford Administration has sent its new Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, William E. Schaufele Jr., on an unannounced tour of East Africa to lobby for its view that all foreign intervention should cease in Angola, State Department sources confirmed today.

title: 3 Bodies Recovered in Gulf; 2 Crewmen Are Still Missing
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (UPI)Coast Guard searchers recovered three bodies from the Gulf of Mexico yesterday, leaving two men still missing in two accidents involving oil rig supply boats.

title: The Nation

description: TRENTONNow that the Senate Democrats have resolved their leadership battle with the election of Matthew Feldman of Bergen County as president of the upper house for the next two years, jockeying for chairmanship of the Senate's 10 standing committees has begun to preoccupy the party's leadership.

title: Carey Postpones State Purchase of Open Land
description: State agencies that have been in the process of purchasing 2,600, acres of land on Long Island for conservation and park use have been ordered by Governor Carey to postpone action because of the state's fiscal crises and the uncertainty of the bond market.

title: Relays Title Is Captured By Molloy
description: Archbishop Molloy won four events, and McClancy High School three in the Molloy Invitation Relays yesterday on the Queens school's allweather track. Molloy won the team championship.

description: St. John's, relying on patience, and Indiana, showing overwhelming strength, advanced to the final of the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

description: There are more jobs in butter than guns.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 27 (AP)Leah Poulos, a 1972 Olympic performer, shattered two rink records today, and her fianc, Peter Mueller, continued to dominate men's competition in the United States Olympic speed skating trials. Miss Poulos of Northbrook, Ill., won the women's 1,000meter test as she and five others bettered the mark for the event at the 400meter Olympicstyle rink at State Fair Park.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Nastase Image/Tutoring Pro Punters
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Millville Nursery Is Hub for Holly
description: MILLVILLEPeople here call it Holly Land.

title: STAMPS
description: As they have for almost threequarters of a century, stamps are being used at this time of year, when the holiday spirit is high, to raise funds for those in needthe young and the aged, the infirm and the destituteand for activities that better the lot of man.

title: Does The Wiz Say Something Extra to Blacks?
description: Does The Wiz, the popular black musical now in its second season on Broadway, say different things to blacks than to whites? As one of the black theatergoers who made up about half the audience at the Majestic one evening recently, I thought I saw signs that It does. Several more visits to The Wiz confirmed my first impression: blacks responded in a special way at certain dramatic points in the show, and to some of its songs and dances.

title: A Show of Children's Chairs
description: MORRISTOWNA chair, particularly a child's chair, would seem to be a simple, utilitarian object. But the fact is that generations of Americans have lovingly crafted chairs for their children in every conceivable fashion, style or mode.

title: Arab Decision
description: The major decision facing leaders of the Arab world involves finding a constructive basis for pushing their resolve to draw the Palestine Liberation Organization into the international framework for negotiating a settlement with Israel.

title: ART VIEW
description: It was no doubt Inevitable that the current boom in photographysignificantly enlarging the market for photographic prints at the same time it has brought a greatly expanded consciousness of their esthetic valueWould sooner or later come to embrace the vast quantities of work produced for the more snobbish, affluent and trendsetting publications of the fashion world. And so it now has. Earlier this season, Robert Littman organized a large exhibition, called Fashion Photography: Six Decades, for the Emily Lowe Gallery, at Hofstra University. This exhibition, which will later travel to the Baltimore Museum of Art, and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, has now come to the Kornblee Gallery, where, if I am not mistaken, it will draw sizable crowds of curiosity seekers as well as aficionadoes of fashion, photography and whatever it is that passes for the latest artistic sensation.

title: New Jersey
description: THEATER

title: Louisville Victor in Tourney
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 27 (UPI)Louisville, led by Phil Bond's 23 points and eight assists, trounced Texas A. and M., 10288, tonight and won the final of the Holiday Classic tournament.

title: Sindy L. Foose Becomes Bride
description: Sara Linda Foose, a doctoral candidate in American civilization at George Washington University, was married last evening to Bruce Bassett Parrott, an assistant professor of Soviet studies at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Malthusian Math Is Right: It's Crowded

title: The Ballet: Bejart in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27Maurice Bjart's Ballet of the 20th Century from Brussels is currently on a North American tour that is bypassing New York Cityalthough it does plan a return in the spring with a Madison Squat e Garden spectacular. The present tour is being undertaken by a comparatively smallby Bjart standardstroupe. There are, however, a number of ballets by Bjart having their American premieres, and the company is as beautiful look at as ever.

title: Diane Abrams Is Wed To Michael Rattner
description: The marriage of Diane Abrams to Michael Rattner took place last evening in the Kings Bay Yacht and Country Club in Miami. Rabbi Richard Davis of the Hillel Foundation performed the ceremony.

title: Candida Staempfli Plans May Nuptials
description: Mrs. Fordyce E. Van Winkle of Bedford, N. Y., and George W. Staempfli of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Candida E. Staempfli, to James David Berg, son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Berg of Louisville, Ky. A wedding is planned in May.

title: Player Pianos. Music to Ears Of a Hobbyist
description: FLORHAM PARKWhen Charles ??ng moved into his own house here last year, he finally found a home for his extensive collection of player pianos and other oldtime music machines.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: You've heard this one so often that no doubt you began to think that you had better get in the swing or you'll never be able to get the ball to reach the pins.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadiens Win, 21, On Opponent's Goal
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (UPI) Bryan Hextall of the Minnesota North Stars deflected a shot into his own net toMontreal Canadiens a 21 victory. Bob Gainey got credit for the goal that was scored with 55 seconds left to play.

title: Tips on Tools Tending
description: Most weekend gardeners secretly looked forward to that comforting feeling of finality when the hoe was hurled into the tool shed to stay until next spring. The remaining garden tools lie dumped willynilly into a tangled heap. After a summer of toil, they are left to survive the ravages of winter as best they can.

title: Research Spending Rise of 5.8% Forecast
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27 (UPI)The Battelle Memorial Inititute has estimated that expenditures for research and development in the United States next year will reach $38.15 billion, or 5.8 percent more than in 1975.

title: Nuggets Beat Nets By 130113
description: DENVER, Dec. 27 (UPI)The Denver Nuggets, led by the ballhawking antics of Ralph Simpson, erupted for 39 points in the third quarter tonight, to notch a 130113 victory over the New York Nets in the American Basketball Association.

title: New River, Old Battle
description: Next to the Nile, the New River in Virginia and North Carolina is considered by geologists to be the oldest in the world. The rocks through which it has cut its way indicate an age approximating 100 million years. But the paradoxes concerning the river do not end with the name. They only begin there. The New happens also be one of the most beautiful streams in North America and one remarkably rich in archeological finds; yet the possibility is all too great that in a matter of weeks its beauty and history will be traded for two ugly reservoirs and a pumped hydroelectric storage project.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police arrested three men who mugged and robbed an offduty transit police sergeant as he gOt out of his car in Queens Village. Sgt. Edward O'Hara, who was not uniform, said he had been struck on the head and knocked to the ground. The sergeant pulled his gun and fired four shots as the men fled. He called the police and then helped to catch the men several blocks away. The suspects were not immediately identified.

title: Eight Are Presented At Regina Cotillion
description: The Bishop's Fund for Children will receive the proceeds of last evening's 18th annual Regina Cotillion at the Plaza, at which eight young women from Long Island were presented to Bishop Walter P. Kellenberg of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: Free at Last
description: Governor Hugh Carey of New York has granted Christmas clemency to Martin Sostre, a selftaught legal expert and Puerto Rican nationalist whose cause has been supported by prominent persons around the world. Mr. Sostre was serving a 30to41year sentence for allegedly selling $15 worth of heroin in a Buffalo bookstore he owned. Despite the facts that the chief witness against him later recanted his testimony, and that the chief police officer in the case was later dismissed from the force in connection with a drug theft from a police locker, Mr. Sostre had been unable to win a new trial. His legal struggles have been fruitful elsewhere, however. Petitions drawn and filed by him have won prisoners the right to practice the Muslim religion, the right to sue for damages when confined in solitary illegally, and the right to obtain radical literature. He also successfully challenged the validity of allwhite parole boards. He has already accepted an offer to work as a legislative assistant for a Democratic Assemblywoman

title: A City in the Sea: 10,000 Live on 400 Rigs and Platforms in Gulf
description: WEST DELTA 73, Gulf of Mexico, Dec. 27Harold Sanders likes his neighborhood. He has lived here, 27 miles from shore, for seven years. The work, food and fishing are much too good to consider moving. Besides, every other week he gets a sevenday vacation back on land at his second home, where his family lives.

title: Rams Play It by the Book
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27The still and heavy atmosphere of the loser's dressing room, occupied by, the St. Louis Cardinals, was best explained by Freddie Dryer of the victorious Los Angeles Rams.

title: LETTERS
description: Trade Policy

title: Clinic Treats the Holiday Blues
description: HACKENSACKThe telephone rings more often during the holiday season. Pathetically, the messages are usually the same.

title: LEONARD P. POOL, 69, AIR PRODUCTS HEAD
description: Leonard P. Pool, founder and board chairman of Air Products and Chemicals Inc., died yesterday at his home in Allentown. Pa. He was 69 years old.

title: Philadelphia Exports a Disappointment
description: Don't let the title give you the idea that Portrait of Young America, a new exhibition at the Whitney, is a show of children's art. But perhaps with the Bicentennial upon us, there's no danger of mistaking the intended reference to this nation's youthful years. Young America is a selection of loans from America's most venerable, but most undervenerated, art institution, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. The Academy, which was founded in 1805, flourished until about 1930, was static by 1945, closed for, restoration in 1974, and is currently on the point of bursting forth, entirely refurbished, in all the pride and glory of its heyday.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: There are really two stages in use during the Vivian Beaumont's production of Hamlet. One is the great central, circular acting area, a thing of solid and conscientiously polished oak that seems a poker table constructed for giants, to play at. It glistens in its vast loneliness, backed only by modest pine paneling suitable for a recreation room, populated by modestly (though handsomely dressed) performers who face one another across its naked reaches. The other stage, of course, is the fragile rectangle, patched together out of bits and pieces and in no more than a trice or two, on which the visiting players play their play.

title: Above the Law
description: Abuse of governmental power is the common thread that runs through the composite experience of the deceptions which made possible the drift into Vietnam, the long contempt for the law by the Federal Bureau of Investigation under its late director J. Edgar Hoover, the persistent violations of its own charter and of fundamental civil liberties by the Central Intelligence Agency and similar transgressions by the Internal Revenue Service. What must be acknowledged, if there is to be hope for effective reform, is that the integrity of American institutions has been eroded not by a few occasional scoundrels, but by the careless, irresponsible and often arrogant attitudes of a handful of the nation's lite.

title: King of Schlock
description: HOLLYWOOD. You no doubt were bedazzled by the glamour of Ingrid Bergman, Shirley MacLaine et as you watched the last Academy Awards presentations on TV. But at the Los Angeles Music Center, where the Oscar ceremonies took place, much of the inhall dazzle centered around a man whom you probably would not have recognized had all nine television cameras transfixed him simultaneously. Peering through the aura of diamonds and shirred shirts, Best Screenplay winner Robert Towne (Chinatown) expressed it most aptly. This joint, he exclaimed looks like a meeting of the Roger Corman alumni association.

title: Institute Set Up to Provide Specialists to Aid Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27Congress, which some legislators contend is lacking in original thought, has become a willing cosponsor of a proposal to create a system that would allow academicians to give unfettered advice to senators and representatives.

title: U.S. Flag Lines Building Liquefied Gas Carriers
description: The first two United Statesflag units of what is expected to be a sizeable fleet of expensive and highly specialized vesselsliquefied natural gas carriers  were moved into shipyard outfitting basins in Massachusetts and Louisiana last week.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: Lisbon's Effort to Reorganize Cabinet Runs Into Snags
description: LISBON, Dec. 27Prime Minister Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo has run into problems in his effort to reorganize his Cabinet.

title: Cherry Hill to Join in a Show of Hands
description: CHERRY HILLThere will be a mammoth, handholding in this Camden County township next Sunday, 10,000 pairs to be exact.

title: Mihajlov Again
description: Yugoslav writer Mihajlo Mihajlov has reportedly been on a hunger strike for the last month, and has become perilously weak. Mr. Mihajlov was sentenced to seven years in prison last year for publicly criticizing the Tito Government. Hundreds of others have been arrested on similar charges. Friends say he is seeking an improvement of the conditions of his imprisonment, particularly release from solitary confinement and access to more books.

title: Wanted: New Ghostwriters
description: You could set a bear trap in a cathedral and not catch better men than Chub Feeney, president of the National League, and Lee MacPhail, his opposite number in the American. They are not only decent guys, they are also reasonable. But they need new material for their act. Whoever is writing their stuff makes them sound like boobs.

title: Barbara Jo Bannin Fiancee of Teacher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Bannin of Hewlett, L, L, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jo Bannin, to Edward Lintott Kelley, son of Mrs. Charles Kelley of Bangor, Me., and the late Mr. Kelley. A February wedding is planned.

title: Spaniels On Stage, Starting New Year
description: When the American Kennel Club, dogdom's ruling body, was organized in 1884, the American Spaniel Club was already three years old. Next Saturday and Sunday, in the first dog show event in East for 1976, the A.S.C. will stage its 59th fixture in the Statler Hilton Hotel. It has drawn 609 dogs, with all 11 spaniel breeds represented. Clark Thompson, a former A.S.C. president, is to name best in show.

title: FREDERICK L. PATTERSON
description: TORONTO, Dec. 27 (AP)Frederick L. Patterson, president of Nestle Canada, died of viral pneumonia Thursday in a hospital here. He was 49 years old.

title: Deborah Bentley Bride of Officer
description: Deborah Lynn Bentley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Clarence Bentley of Sewickley, Pa., was married yesterday evening to Lieut. James Hillman Oliver, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cunningham Oliver Jr. of Pittsburgh.

title: Although Money Is Tight in Britain, There Are Always a Few Pence to Bet
description: LONDON, Dec. 27When you haven't got enough money to save, said a man who tours factories and pubs soliciting 30cent bets for one of the legal soccer pools, why not have a gamble for a few pence? This year's biggest payoff, he added, was $1.2 million.

title: C.I.A. Aide to Be Buried in Arlington
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 27President Ford arranged today to have Richard S. Welch, the Central Intelligence Agency officer murdered this week in Athens, buried in Arlington National Cemetery. The President said through a spokesman that publication of Mr. Welch's C.I.A. identity had been at least partially responsible for his death.

title: How Advisers Line Up
description: Economists are beginning to gather around the Presidential candidates to offer advice and, potentially, themselves as officials in a future Administration. Most economists advise more than one candidate at a time. While they learn about the politiciansand viceversa  few economists have actually endorsed a candidate. But the following list shows roughly who's been talking to whom. Among the declared Presidential hopefuls:

title: For A Radical Restructuring of the Political System
description: WASHINGTONSince early 1975, a number of people have been planning the beginning of a national citizen's movement. This new movement would build on the civil rights, antiwar, women's and ecology movements of the last fifteen years. It is to be strengthened with the participation of some unions. The discussions have included people from the antiauthoritarian right who oppose the corporate state. The movement's provisional name is the Federation for Democratic Reconstruction,

title: Mulligan Jazz Sextet Plays Cohesively
description: The sextet that Gerry Mulligan introduced to New York early in November at Carnegie Hall has settled into the cafe at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street. The group represents a new, expanded phase in Mr. Mulligan's career.

title: Criminals At Large
description: By now books about the Jews, Arabs and the continuing struggle in the Middle East have assumed the status of heavy industry. Herewith, four to add to the output. At least one of them is amusing.

title: ExBanker Named To Planning Board
description: MINEOLA  Harold V. Gleason, chairman of the defunct Franklin National Bank, who has been appointed to the NassauSuffolk Regional Planning Board, said his first priority would be to implement the fiveyear master plan.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Ghetto Church Builds Anew
description: NEWARKThe congregation of Bethany Baptist Church on seedy West Market Street has built a $1.9 million testimonial to its commitment in the inner city, a project totally financed by members of the church.

title: The Handgun, the Hunter And the Public Concern
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Detroit Paper Raises Price
description: DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP)The Detroit Free Press is raising the price of its Sunday edition to 50 cents from 35 cents. The newstand price of the daily edition will remain at 15 cents. The paper said that the price increase was needed because of steadily rising newsprint and operating costs.

title: Engagements
description: RutenbergWaxenberg

title: Guide to Working With Wallboard
description: For the homeowner who wants to finish the walls and ceilings of a new addition to his house, or an extra room that is being built in a previously unfinished attic or basement, one of the simplest and least expensive paneling materials he can use is gypsum wallboard.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Racing Attendance Over 6 Million in '75
description: Attendance went up at major motor sports events around the world during 1975 despite depressed economic conditions, according to the Racing Division of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. During 1975, Goodyear serviced 163 major races and the total attendance at them was 6,303,771 an increase of more than a half million fans over the 1974 total for 160 major races.

title: Bridal for Anne Murray And R.A. Tomlin Is Held
description: St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in West Simsbury, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternon for the marriage of Anne Murray to Robert A. Tomlin.

title: Christy Sutherland Nettles a Bride
description: Christy Sutherland Nettles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Fuhrman Nettles of Rumson, N.J., was married here yesterday afternoon to David Kellock Elwell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwell of Westport. Conn.

title: Sunday Observer
description: In deference to ancient journalistic custom, this column has called home its chief contributing correspondents for the annual year end roundup, and they are sitting here now waiting to round up the annual year. Let's hear first from Buck Strothers, our correspondent who covers the vital national  trends beat. What kind of year was 1975 nationaltrendwise, Buck?

title: ORBITAL CROWDING EXPECTED BY 1985
description: The launching last week of a Soviet communications satellite called Statsionar I toward a stationary orbit above the Indian Ocean focused new attention on potential crowding among such radio relay stations in space.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS RARELY EXPELLED
description: PEKING, Dec. 27A young man in the commune's machineryrepair plant had impressed everyone with his skill and energy, so he was given a strong recommendation for admission to Tsinghua University, a leading science and engineering school.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE BANKERS, by Martin Mayer. (Ballantine, $2.25.) A veteran explainer of how Institutions work skillfully unravels banking's mysteries: its details are fascinating, though not particularly useful to the average depositer or borrower,

title: Miss Orbison Wed to John Zachara 2d
description: Katherine Tucker Orbison and John Michael Zachara 2d, graduates of Bucknell University, were married yesterday in the Rooke Chapel on the Bucknell campus by the bride's cousin, the Rev. Luther Tucker, an Episcopal priest.

title: The Trail That Led to Suspects in Slaying of 2 Queens Children
description: Minor inconsistencies in the initial stories told by Debra Mackall and the man with whom she was living about the departmentstore disappearance of her two young children helped the police break the murder case, detectives said yesterday.

title: Suffolk Will Sell Bonds to Aid Industry
description: MONTAUKIn an effort to expand its business base Suffolk County has started an Industrial Development Agency, which will float taxfree bonds so concerns can get lowinterest financing for construction and related purposes.

title: Britain Investigating LonelyHearts Trade
description: LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP)Britain's lonely hearts got a new ally today, the Office of Fair Trading, which launched an inquiry into computer dating concerns, marriage bureaus and introduction agencies.

title: Vikings, Cowboys a Contrast
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn Dec. 27Their twoyear rebuilding plan an obvious success, the Dallas Cowboys return to the National Football Conference playoffs, tomorrow against the Minnesota Vikings who, it seems, have been trying but failing to, win the Super Bowl since. Fran Tarkenton was in diapers.

title: Words on the Tip of Your Tongue
description: For 40 years I have been stumping friends by asking for the name of the little sink that splits one's upper lip in two. Recently I even put the question in doggerel:

title: TV VIEW
description: Dazed by the relentless mediocrity of the new fall season, the casual TV observer might reasonably conclude that 1975 was a complete disaster in terms of programming. That is not quite so. As it happens, most of the good stuff was presented in the first half of the year. And, not surprisingly at this point, much of it could, be found on public television: The following is an entirely subjective compilation of the best, plus the worst of an uncommonly bad lot.

title: Magnetic Pull of Minerals Affects Instruments of Jets Overhead
description: NAIROBIThe agreement by the Gulf Oil Corporation to block its petroleum royalty payments to the Sovietbacked Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola underscores the commercial value of countries in southern Africa.

title: Hunter Tourney Goes to L. I. U.
description: The Hunter College Invitational Christmas tournament, originally scheduled for Hunter tomorrow and Tuesday, will be played instead at. Long Island University's Founders Hall on the same dates. The change was made necessary because of the Board of Higher Education's decision to close all city university campuses for the Christmas recess.

title: Raiders To Try Again
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 27 The Oakland Raiders start their eighth trip in the last nine seasons toward the elusive Super Bowl tomorrow when they take on the Cincinnati Bengals in an American Football Conference playoff game that will be televised in New York by Channel 4 at 4 P.M.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Assassin's trail? Hugh C. McDonald, retired California law enforcement officer and helicopter service operator, has a wondrous tale to tell. Back in 1964, while serving as head of security for Presidential candidate Barry Goldwater, he was told by his onetime C.I.A. boss the name of the man who actually killed John F. Kennedy. Saul, a professional assassin, had been hired by certain private interests who had reason to desire Lyndon B. Johnson in the Presidency; Lee Harvey Oswald had been recruited to fire at the same time to cover up the hired killer's guilt.

title: Drug Prices Held To Vary Widely
description: MINEOLAA variety of questionable pricing practices has been discovered in a survey of 27 Nassau County drugstores, according to a consumer group.

title: Africa: An Inviting Arena for Moscow
description: MOSCOWWe've been supporting our friends In Angola for more than a decade. Why should we stop now just to satisfy Mr. Kissinger? a wellplaced Soviet insider asked here the other day. Besides, he said with a smile, It would antagonize Congress.

title: Boston Vandals Steal Statue of Christ Child
description: BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP)The manger in the Nativity scene that annually decorates Boston Common is empty today, except for a small sign explaining the absence of the Christ child statue.

title: JOHN MANN DIES; AMEX LEADER, 69
description: John J. Mann, who served five consecutive oneyear terms as chairman of the American Stock Exchange, died Wednesday at his home, 10 Wildwood Court Larchmont, N.Y. He was 69 years old and had formerly lived in Brooklyn.

title: McAdoo Returns, Braves Top 76ers
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 27 (AP)Bob McAdoo returned, from the suspended list and sparked a secondquarter spurt that led the Buffalo Braves to a 130105 rout of the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: LET THE PUNISHMENT
description: When President Ford was confronted with Lynette Fromme's loaded gun, he was on his way to address the California State Legislature on the subject of violent crime. Among the key themes of his speech was a criticism of our current sentencing laws, under which judges and parole boards exercise wide discretion in determining a convicted criminal's sentence. Pointing to the fact that nearly 4 out of 10 persons using firearms to kill . . . or rob . . . are returned to the streets . . . without serving a prison sentence, the President called for the adoption of mandatory sentences in order to restore the certainty of confinement that is presently lacking.

title: Steven Beslity Fiance Of Carol Ann Johnson
description: Carol Ann Johnson, a flight attendant with Eastern Airlines, and Steven John Beslity, a marine insurance specialist with Marsh & McLennan, Inc., plan to be married May 8.

title: Computers With a Personal Touch Are Helping Teach Math and Reading to Inner City Pupils
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 27Thank you, Bridgett, said the computer to a sixth grader at a Southwest Side elementary school in Chicago.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Cambria Heights Is Seeking Improvement of Area Through SelfHelp
description: A plan to preserve and improve Cambria Heights, a middleclass neighborhood of homeowners in eastern Queens, is moving forward at a time when many efforts et community betterment are being abandoned in the wake of the city's budget crisis.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES TRADE SURPLUS in November was $1.1 billion, the Department of Commerce reported, and for all of 1975, could set a record at about $12 billion. The excess of exports over imports in the first 11 months totaled $10.6 billion, exceeding the previous high of $7.1 billion for the period set in 1964... The International Monetary Fund has expanded its credit facility for member countries to 50 percent of their quotas in a 12month period, double the amount now available. The fund expects to start selling onesixth of its gold at auction next year for the benefit of lessdeveloped countries, but the House Banking Committee argued the move must await Congressional approval of changes in the I.M.F. charter.

title: Ford Approves More Funds Fir Small Reclamation Jobs
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 27 (UPI)President Ford signed today a bill to increase authorized funding under the Small Reclamaion Projects Act from $100 million to $400 million.

title: The Owls Know
description: The owls know it. The owls are wise in ways that man may only guess at, and they give us few clues in their midnight conversations. They probably feel change in their bones. Birds do that, since their hollow bones are builtin barometers. They know when storms are coming, when change is due.

title: Miss Satz Fiancee Of Stephen Swigert
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milton Satz of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margery Ann Satz, to Stephen Bruce Swigert. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Bruce Swigert of Rye, N. Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: There is a lovely oneact play by Chekhov, called The Wedding, in which a Greek pastry cook, trying to explain the inexplicable and dangerous problem of the inexplicably dangerous, stands up at a wedding reception and, with a charming smile, comments: There is Greece and there is Russia. The voice falters a little, although the smile continues unabashed. Indeed it broadens, as the man makes the second and final point of his brief speech, And there is Russia and there is Greece.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: When Joan D. Manley, the 43yearold publisher of TimeLife Books, was given the additional title of group vice presidentbooks of Time Inc. last October, one of her former bosses referred to her as a Yankee peddler from California who represents the best of both worlds.

title: Business Leaders Aid Byrne On Budget
description: TRENTON  Confronted with a budget gap that could go as high as $1 billion, Governor Byrne has appointed a blueribbon committee of six businessmen to help him make the tough fiscal decisions that lie ahead.

title: The promoter and the composer
description: My gaudiest musical memory is from 1952 in Paristhat least musical of citieswhen for 30 April nights a festival called Masterpieces of the Twentieth Century offered mixed pleasures to an international lite. One after another major revivals and massive premieres, by Stravinsky, Virgil Thomson, Alban Berg, Benjamin Britten and scores of others, were conducted by Pierre Monteux, Igor Markevich, or the composers themselves, all immaculately produced, and very, very costly. The funds came froth the C.I.A., a fact then not known to the diasporic Jackofallartistictrades who singlehandedly launched the evenings, Nicolas Nabokov.

title: Ping! Boing! Buzz! Tilt!
description: The pinball machine, with its flashing lights, buzzers and bells, is a fantasy world of comic book art that comes alive with the release of a plunger. A steel ball propelled onto the game surface wends its way erratically through a maze of bumpers, automatic kickers, and manually controlled flippers which the player can activate in his effort to change the ball's path so that it will fall into one of the highscoring holes, rather than into scoreless oblivion at the bot tom end of the machine.

title: Claudia Praeger Bride Of Francis Sargent Jr.
description: Claudia Elisabeth Praeger was married yesterday afternoon in Chilmark, Mass., to Francis Williams Sargent Jr., son of Mr. Sargent, Governor of Massachusetts from 1968 to 1974, and Mrs. Sargent of Dover and East Orleans, Mass.

title: Susan P. Whitcomb Is Married
description: Susan Prescott Whitcomb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to James Kelly Ahern of Cincinnati, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lee Ahem of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Tabulators Focus On Birds Again
description: BERNARDSVILLE  Serious bird watchers in New Jersey have been getting out their binoculars, telescopes, pencils, notebooks and long woblen underwear in order to participate in the National Audubon Society's 76th annual Christmas Bird Count.

title: Boating Industry Is Recovering From 1974's Financial Problems
description: Slowly but surely, the recreational, boating industry is righting itself from last year's financial capsizing. Yearend figures compiled by the industry show that in 1975 more Americans went down to the sea in more ships than ever before. While the general economic recession brought sales of new equipment down from last year, there were increases of 1.3 percent both in the number of persons going boating and in the number of boats in use in the United States.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The Alps, 727 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 3339707

title: Deadline Is Extended for Flag Contest
description: SOMERVILLE  Deadline for entries in the Somerset County flagdesign contest has been extended to Feb. 12, Lincoln's Birthday. In keeping with the Bicentennial theme, announcement of the winning entry will be made on Feb. 23, Washington's birthday.

title: LIBERTY IN WORLD DECLINED IN 1915
description: Over the last year, freedom declined for 743.2 million persons in eight countries, according to a comparative survey by Freedom House, a nonprofit organization based here.

title: Senegal Declares Islands A Sanctuary for Sea Birds
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Dec. 27 gal has declared the socalled Barbary Spit Islands off its northwestern Atlantic coast a sanctuary for sea birds that are threatened with extinction by pollution.

title: South Africa's Great White Hope
description: PRETORIA, South AfricaSouth Africa's great white hope is black: Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, head of the socalled homeland of Kwazulu and himself of royal Zulu blood. He sees the destiny of all people in this huge, rich state as a single destiny, regardless of pigmentation.

title: Tests on Heat of Pulsars Back Theory Of Superfluidity, Not Just Superdensity
description: Using the moon as a curtain moving progressively across the Crab Nebula, physicists at Cblumbia University believe they have confirmed that pulsars are not only superdense objects but are also superfluid.

title: The World
description: On Dec. 16 in Paris, representatives of the nations of the world began a portentous undertaking, the reordering of their economic relationships. The occasion was described by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France as the first date when global economic problems enter the collective consciousness of mankind.

title: How I Wrote My Third Symphony
description: IOWA CITY, IOWA I'd had a longstanding invitation to visit the University of Iowa, internationally known for, among other things, its Writers' Workshop, but something always got in the way of acceptance. Then I received a letter from Jim Dixonnot the hero of Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim but the conduotor of the Iowa University Symphony Orchestraasking me if I had anything in stock, musical of course not literary, that the orchestra might perform when, if, I came there.

title: Camden Man Dies in Fire
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 27 (AP) A man was killed and his sister was injured today when fire swept through a house here. The body of Casmir Mroczkowski was found in a back bedroom on the second floor, authorities said. His sister Clara Miller, suffered smoke inhalation. The police said they were investigating whether a robbery was connected with the fire.

title: South Korea Banning Decadent Foreign Music, Including Many Protest Songs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 27 A South Korean cultural agency has begun purging the country's popular music of what it calls decadent foreign influences. Two blacklists containing names of 261 piecesprotest songs, folk ballads and rock and psychedelic musicwere issued this month and all radio stations have been asked not to play them.

title: Is lithium the third psychiatric revolution?
description: Reading Moodswing has gotten me into a bad mood. I started this book with the highest of expectations, for I know Dr. Ronald Fieve to be a leading authority in the area of the depressive disorders and one of the handful of people active in pioneering the use of lithium in the treatment of manic depressive illness. I looked forward, therefore, to an intelligent summaryan overview, albeit presented on a popular levelof the highly interesting research on mania and depression that has been carried out over the course of the past two decades. What I found instead was a poorly organized mixture of fact and fantasy, presented in a somewhat hucksterish style. It left me with the unpleasant impression that Fieve was, for some unaccountable reason, trying to do a hard sell on the virtues and uses of the drug lithium.

title: An African Leader Calls His Diplomats Dishonest
description: PARIS, Dec. 27 (Reuters)President JeanBedel Bokassa of the Central African Republic said in a quarterpage advertisement published here today that his Government had been the victim of dishonest tendencies on the part of some of its diplomats in Europe.

title: The First Three Years Of Life
description: If this book's central thesis is correct, that the first three years of postnatal life are crucial to all of subsequent psychological development, then parents' heedfulness or imperviousness to the message of this book can shape, for better or for worse, the future of American society. Are our children to become a race of morons, Machiavellians, authoritarians, psychopaths, psychotics, emptyheaded hedonists, dithering neurotics, or, happy day, balanced, loving, strong and, above all, competent? It is too late for us whose children have already slipped past the threeyear boundary; the future seems to rest on the new generation of parents those born recently enough to absorb and apply the insights that Burton White has generated in 17 years of research into these matters.

title: Can the Great Wall Stand Up Under 12 Candidates?
description: With two Republicans and at least ten Democrats seeking the Presidency, 1976 promises to be the year of the media event. Roughly defined, a media event is a happening that has little intrinsic news interest or value but is staged nonetheless to get maximum publicity, particularly on television.

title: Josephine Crane Fisher Engaged
description: The engagement of Josephine Crane Fisher to David de B. de Give has been announced by, Bruce Crane Fisher of Charles, City, Va., mother of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul de B. de Give of New York and Southampton, L.I.

title: TRIP TO CHINA BEGUN BY CONGRESSWOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) Seven. Congresswomen led by Representative Margaret M. Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, left today for a twoweek trio to China.

title: Sold only in the West, Coors beer is smuggled to the East. Henry Kissinger drinks it. So does Paul Newman, though he would abhor the Coors family's politics.
description: Once upon a time, a young Germanborn beerhitch driver, who had fled his homeland to avoid the draft, was hiking in the hills west of the rowdy mining town of Deaver, when he came across a picturesque valley watered by a stream aptly named Clear Creek. This, he decided, would be the ideal place for a brewery. He set out to build one, and it grew and grew as the management was passed on from father to son. A little more than a century later, the young immigrant's dream had become the fourth largest beer manufacturer in the United States.

title: Sect Is Persecuted in Southern Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 27 (AP)The Jehovah's Witnesses religious sect says its members are being driven from country to country in southern Africa by beatings, rape, torture and political pressure.

title: The Mythic Image
description: The high praise given to Joseph Campbell's earlier books, The Hero With a Thousand Faces and The Masks of God, must be given again, more enthusiastically than ever, to his new work, The Mythic Image. Ranging over all of human nature's time and space, bringing together fragments of art and literature from the oldest cultures this planet has known and the newest (and from virtually everything between) Campbell creates a visionary image of humanityour struggles and sorrows, our transcendent aspirations and in the final analysis our decencythat towers heroically over those shoddy notions of human nature we too often take, these days, for fact.

title: Two novels
description: By Bernard Packer. 309 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $8.95.

title: LOUIS AND TROUPE DANCE AT N.Y.0

description: Sir Patrick Shaw, Australian Ambassador to the United States, died in Washington yesterday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

It is pursuing its own interests while maintaining good relations with all nations, blocs and international groupings.

title: NEWS MEDIA EFFECT ON JURORS DOUBTED
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 27 (AP) Pretrial news coverage probably does not strongly influance jurors in criminal cases, an assistant professor of psychology at Marquette University says. He conducted a study concerning the Patricia Hearst case.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Photocopying machines are about to disappear from post offices across the country, despite assertions that they have been a valuable service to consumers.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP)  Victims of crimes will get counseling help in a new Governmentsupported service that the Philadelphia Bar Association inaugurates next week.

title: The Case of Sills vs. Herbert
description: There was something about a glamorous, prima donna that always brought out the beat in Victor Herbert. Among his most successful nooses, Mlle. Modiste, Naughty Marietta, The Fortune Teller, The Enchantress and Sweethearts were written for the likes of Fritzi Scheff, Emma Trentini, Alice Nielsen, Kitty Gordon, and Christie MacDonald. For these ladies, each a tyracooloratura, Herbert created a collection of songs dazzling showpieces, pert comic numbers and, of course, suave, romantic melodiesthat have become a cherished part of the treasury of American theater music. And so, it was only to be expected that sooner or later Beverly Sills would turn her attention to this repertory.

title: Blessed Oblivion
description: The final days of the year in which the United States brought home the last of its troops from the battlefields of Southeast Asia are appropriate for remembering those Americans who still have not been allowed to come home again. Three months ago, President Ford signed an executive order to terminate the Presidential Clemency Board which he had created a year earlier to help war resisters return to their normal lives.

title: When the Revolution was young
description: It is 1919. The conquered city is St. Petersburg, newly unchristened Petrograd. The Reds are its conquerorsbut for how long? They are threatened from withoutWhite armies on the move, predatory bands prowling the countryside and from withina stubborn peasantry, grumbling factory workers, merciless speculators, starving children, disorganization and discontent everywhere. The great threat, however, the one which Victor Serge knows must doom the conquerors, lies in the inherent demands of the Revolution and in the souls of the revolutionaries. They don't know history, a perplexed scholar mutters to himself, but they are making it . . . But what are they making? What are they making?

title: Punch in! Punch out! Eat quick!
description: In the office of the U.S. Catholic Conference in Fort Chaffee, Ark., a Vietnamese family sat for an interviewthe two older men sitting stiffly in their new Western suits, their wives standing behind, straightbacked, their faces as sharpplaned and expressionless as those in an American Gothic portrait. How many are you? What are your skills? The few necessary questions had been asked and answered, and now the Catholic Conference representative was describing, through an interpreter, a poultry enterprise in Oklahoma that had asked to sponsor a number of Vietnamese. The eldest of the men nodded and asked: Was this place near a Catholic church? How cold it? How close to the sea? The answers given, he put his hand on his son's shoulder and rose slowly, saying they would think about it. The family moved away through the crowd to be replaced by another familya former helicopter pilot with his father and younger sistersto consider a proposal from an engineering firm in Pittsburgh.

title: Technology Threatening Sponge Divers of Greece
description: KALYMNOS, GreeceThe men sat at a big round table, eating fish and drinking wine and singing the songs that fill the long, lonely days of a sponge diver's life. When a girl tells her mother that she wants to marry a diver, one man remarked, the mother says, I'd rather drown you.

title: Controlling the Flow
description: The business practices of Richard A. Viguerie, a professional fundraiser who has raised over $5million for Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, are being challenged in a New York State Court by state Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. Mr. Lefkowitz is seeking to block any further mail solicitations by Mr. Viguerie in the state. He is charging that, in his work for various charities, Mr. Viguerie has received excessive commissions and fees totaling as much as 75 percent of the funds raised. Mr. Viguerie has admitted to keeping nearly half of the monies raised in the Wallace campaign for expenses and profit.

title: Eclitors' Choice 1975
description: Completely unbidden the Book Review staff, for several years now, has singled out a handful of books from the 30,000 to 40,000 published annually and called them significant or outstanding, a cautious way of saying best. It was a high mission, and more often than not voices were raised. Two years ago some interesting titles were dropped in fierce negative trading; when it was over, a very fine liquor of three books remained. This yearhave we mellowed? come to see alternatives?we have turned up a generous list: 13 books. The discussion that led to their choice was, for the most part, easy and positive. We kept seeing sense in our colleagues reasonings. So we make no absolute claims, only ask that these 13 books be considered as special: that durable, solid, different.

title: Notes: Who's on First For the Bicentennial?
description: WHEN churchbells strike midnight Wednesday, the celebration of the nation's 200th birthday will officially commenceand virtually every city, village and town plans to make the scene with Bicentennial exhibits and programs. The celebration has all the earmarks of one of the greatest commercial promotions in history, with farflung regions vying for recognitionand tourists. Even before the preBicentennial year of 1975 is out, a battle of sorts has erupted for the title of first event of the Bicentennial year. In essence, it's the Liberty Bell v. Mummers Parade v. Cotton Bowl v. Rose Parade.

description: Her article was no longer than a single page in the Magazine on Mother's Day, but Martha Lear says that she has never had such an overwhelming response anything else she has written. In the piece, she meditated upon her ambivalent relationship with her mother (Happy Mother's Day. What a curious ritual for our time, filled with love and lies.) She received mail for nearly three months afterward, and is still introduced to people who remember her as the one who wrote that Mother's Day piece.

description: Mary King Patterson, who retired as women's editor of The Daily News in 1969 after a newspaper career of more than 60 years, died yesterday at her home in Riverdale, the Bronx. She was 90 years old.

title: For young readers
description: The German occupation of Europe during World War II is a surprisingly effective setting for juvenile literature. Without stretching a facile analogy too far, young people live in occupied territory all the time. They are at the mercy of the powerful, often only dimly perceived figures and institutions that shape their lives. They can witness and sometimes suffer through the events of the day, but they cannot substantially affect them. A story set in the French underground may seem as distant and exotic as a buccaneering epic on the Spanish Main, but I suspect young readers may empathize with the principal characters more than we realize.

title: Answers/Questions
description: SWEET POTATO VINE [Dec. 14] A B.K., a Manhattan reader, asked how to grow a sweet potato vine from a fresh, uncooked  sweet potato. Here are three ideas. From C. W. Williams, Freehold, N.J., Select a healthy firm sweet potato and put the broader end down in a narrow neck glass jar or vase. Use toothpicks stuck into the sides of the potato, if needed, to keep an inch or so of the base in water. Put the potato in light but not full sun and soon roots and green shoots will develop. Keep the roots covered with water. From Nancy J., a Manhattan, reader, Wash a sweet potato in warm water, cut it in half and suspend the halves cut side down over a glasi of water with onethird of the potato submerged. Purple knobs will appear which turn into leaves and thin roots from the bottom will soon appear. In a month, pot in ordinary soil, leaving the rounded top exposed. From Harriet Cohen, another Manhattan reader, Find a sweet potato that hasn't been treated with chemicals to prevent bud sprouting. Once a natural sweet potato is found, wash it and place it on a bed of mediumsized pebbles arranged in a shallow bowl. Partially fill with water so the water touches the bottom of the sweet potato. Lovely vines will develop and the tuber can in soil.

The trading pace, however, was quite restrained and brokers noted that the bulk of their clients remained cautious about making new stock commitments.

title: BRIDGE
description: A player whose bridge is limited to a weekly game can expect to pick up a 7600 distribution once in about 12 years, But this calculation is based on the naive assumption that every deal is equally likely, and that the shuffling and dealing will produce a totally random result. This is true in most forms of tournament play, with hands dealt by a computer; almost true in the average rubber bridge game; and not true at all in those commuter games in which ghoulis are the rule. The cards are not shuffled, and are then dealt in bunches, eccentric distributions become commonplace. A group of cards of the same suit, forming a trick on one deal, tend to remain together in one hand for the next.

title: ROME ALLOWS BOOK ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: After two years of review, a Jesuit priest here has received permission from his superiors in Rome to publish his book on the Catholic Church and homosexuality.

description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27In recent weeks, the people of Pittsburgh have considered the Super Bowl to be part of the Steelers' schedule. I wonder, men taverns Would say over their sboi and: beer, who we'll play this time. And toddy nobody had to cancel their reservations to Miami because the Steelers 2810, over the Baltimore Colts in the opener of the NationalFootball League playoffs. The Steelers prevailed despite an unusual number of mistakes  for them. But virtually all, these mistakes were made by their offensive unittwo fumbles and two interceptions.

title: Sallie C. Spence, Kevin Costelloe Plan Marriage
description: Dr. and Mrs. Donald Pond Spence of Princeton, N. J., have announced the engage. meat of their daughter, Sarah Coolidge Spence, to Kevin Martin Costelloe, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Costelloe of Centeaport, L. I., and Lenox. Mass.

title: Site of 1935 Lindbergh Kidnapping Trial Still Draws Visitors
description: FLEMINGTON (UPI)  A constant stream of people still visit the scene of the courtroom drama where, 40 years ago, Bruno Richard Hauptmann was sentenced to death for the kidnapmurder of Charles A. Lindbergh's son.

title: Humphrey Vs. Reagan
description: Ronald Reagan of California and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota are now the leading choices of their parties for the 1976 Republican and Democratic Presidential nominations, the Gallup poll discloses. Dr. Gallup and the Harris poll disagree as to which of the two would defeat the other, but the likelihood of a campaign between them  neither was given much of a chance a year ago  adds interest to the election year.

title: CHILDREN FOUND UNHURT BY SMOG
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) Researchers have found that an airpollution crisis here last month caused few immediate health problems for school children but may have caused other health difficulties.

title: Jenifer DuBose Heyward Married
description: Jenifer DuBose Heyward was married yesterday afternoon to Judson Wood Jr., a lawyer here for Sterling Drug Inc. The Rev. Thomas Pike performed the ceremony in the Calvary Episcopal Church near Gramercy Park.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: PAKISTAN EXPANDS CURB ON OPPOSITION
description: ISLAMBAD, Pakistan, Dec. 27 (AP)The Government proclaimed yesterday that office bearers in banned political parties may not serve in Parliament or provincial legislatures or run for election to them for five years.

title: Suffolk Bagpiper, 91, Is Too Busy to Get Old
description: WAINSCOTT Peter Morrison will celebrate another New Year this week by playing, ancient tunes on his set of pipes, as he has done for most of his 91 years.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made pay. able to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10242 or to these agencies:

title: The Region
description: In 1972, after the Knapp Commission had abundantly documented widespread corruption in the Police Department, former Gov. Nelson Rockefeller bequeathed a new remedy to the city for preventing graft within the criminal justice system. The Governor's gift was the Office of the Special State Anticorruption Prosecutor.

title: Suzanne Bixler Becomes Bride
description: Suzanne Bixler, a biology instructor at Clarkson College, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Fredrick Karl Lepple of Alexandria, Va., holder of the National Academy of Science postdoctoral research associateship at the Naval Research Laboratory in Washington.

title: Nigeria Orders an Inquiry Into Clash in Farm Center
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 27 (Reuters)The Government ordered an inquiry today into clashes between soldiers and civilians in the southern town of Ugep, where 13 people were killed, 100 others injured and 600 houses destroyed Thursday.

title: All Policies, Domestic and Foreign, Begin in Resentment
description: Any discussion of GreekTurkish relations must start from this fact: The two countries, their leaders and their people, are so suspicious and resentful of each other that rationality becomes impossible. And after 50 years of relative calm, the ancient animosities are again disturbing the peace of the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Southold to Mark. Founding in 1640
description: SOUTHOLD  Southold, which says it is the oldest Englishspeaking town in the state, will begin its observance or the Bicentennial on New Year's Day with an ecumenical service at the Southold Presbyterian Church, the oldest church in the state, dating to 1640.

title: Workers' Pay at Record High
description: TRENTON  The average weekly earnings of manufacturing workers in New Jersey rose to a record $209.25 in October, a gain of 8.6 percent over October 1974, according to the state's Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Overeaters' Group Lists New Sessions
description: HACKENSACK  A new session for those desiring to join Overeaters Anonymous, a nonprofit fellowship devoted to helping compulsive overeaters fight their problem, will begin next Friday at the Y.M.Y.M.H.A. of Bergen County, 211 Essex Street, Hackensack.

title: The MovementHasGiven Way to an Interest in jobs
description: At Mills College, a liberal arts women's school in California, administrators were presented by their incoming students with an unaccustomed surprise last fall. For the first time in years, most of the young women arrived at school not alone. They spent the first few days doing things, appearing to have great fun with their parents.

description: Dimaggio

title: A. Broadcast From Timor Says ProIndonesian Forces Advance
description: DARWIN, Australia, Dec. 27 (Reuters) About 15,000 Indonesiansupported troops are advancing in eastern Timor on mountain strongholds of a leftwing group advocating autonomy for the Portuguese colony, according to a radio message received here.

title: African Lands Fear Rifts Caused by Angolan War
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 27The civil war in Angolalike no other issue since the Biafran secession from Nigeria  is causing deep fissures in the facade of solidarity that black African leaders have sought to maintain.

title: Tiny Mauritius Seeks Amity With the World
description: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius Mauritius is one of the few developing, nonaligned countries where those two adjectives have concrete meaning.

description: Although the Democratic nomination for Vice President is considered a more realistic possibility for Governor Carey than the Presidential nomination, the Governor's closest advisers in and out of state government doubt that Mr. Carey would be interested in the sec ond spot. title: Washington Buildings: Low Profile and Boxlike Design
description: WASHINGTON  If this city remains an attractive urban environment, it does so in spite of its buildings, not because of them. Once a city of elegant townhouses and small commercial structures  aside from Government buildings, that isdowntown Washington has given way to a series of 8story to 12story office buildings that, in the last decade, have made it far more like the urban jumble of other cities than the natives here like to acknowledge.

title: National Airlines Shutdown Is Nearing Four Months
description: When you work for National, said Allison Russell, a flight attendant with 20 years experience. you save for strikes.

title: VIETNAMESE PLAN APRIL ELECTIONS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 (UPI)  North and South Vietnam will hold joint elections next spring and reunification of the country with Hanoi as the most likely capital will be completed by April 30, informed sources said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28As the election year begins, the policy of dtente with the Soviet Union is shaky and its backers are on the defensive.

title: Runaway Bus Kills Woman And Injures 30 in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 25 (UPI)A runaway city bus hit seven cars and smashed a second bus into a third one in the city's international district, killing a woman passenger in a station wagon and injuring 30 persons.

title: Democrats Naming Over 200 Delegates At State Primary
description: In the New York primary election scheduled for April 6. Democrats will elect 205 delegates to the national convention from the 39 Congressional districts (four, five or six from each district). The state committee will pick 69 more atlarge delegates, who will be apportioned among the candidates to reflect their vote percentage in the districts.

title: India's Chief Party Expected to Back Longer Emergency
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 28, (Reuters)India's governing Congress Party, which opens its national conference tomorrow, will be asked to approve a resolution that favors continuing the state of emergency imposed on the country six months ago.

title: The Theater: Murder Among Friends
description: One of the richest women in the world is married to an egocentric actor. Together with her lover, who happens also to be the actor's agent, she plans to kill him. The plan, which is set to go off in the couple's town house one New Year's Eve, is quite ingenious. But, of course, not ingenious enoughotherwise we would have no play.

title: CrossCountry Ski To Miss Rockwell
description: CABLE, Wis., Dec. 28 (AP) Martha Rockwell, of Stratford, Vt., the nation's topranked women's crosscountry skier since 1968, was clocked in 20 minutes 26.09 seconds over 5.6 kilometers (about 4 miles) today to win the opening event in qualifying for the United States Olympic Nordic ski team.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: A study of socalled Medigap health insurance policies by Consumers Union has found that policies offered by the Colonial Penn Group Inc. with the exclusive endorsement of two major groups of the elderly offer the least protection among the 16 studied.

description: Only a day after Argentina's armed services had quashed without bloodshed a revolt of rightwing air force officers against President Isabel Martinez de Pern, the army and police found themselves locked in a savage overnight battle with leftist guerrillas in the outskirts of Buenos Aires that left at least 100 dead.

description: PEKING, Dec. 28Diplomats here are puzzling over China's aboutface decision to release; three Soviet airmen who had been held 21 months on charges of espionage after they and their helicopter were captured in Chinese territory.

description: Morning

title: Cowboys and Raiders Win Playoffs
description: The Dallas Cowboys upset the Minnesota Vikings, 1714, yesterday at Bloomington, Minn., on Roger Staubach's 50yard touchdown pass to Drew Pearson in the final 24 seconds. The victory advanced the Cowboys the National Football Conference championship game Sunday against the Rams at Los Angeles.

title: TV: The Neighbors, Incredible ABC Game Show
description: Exercises in obnoxiousness are rarely more inspired than in the desperate concepts developed for television game shows. Today's incredible specimen is a new and original series called the The Neighbors. Part of ABC's revised daytime schedule, the program can be seen at 2:30 P.M. Monday through Friday.
