The George S. KaufmanEdna Ferber comedy opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and as a result of a buzza of praise is moving to the Helen Hayes Theater.

title: LEFKOWITZ BALKS AT CAREY REQUEST TO OUST NADJARI
description: Governor Carey yesterday pressed Louis. J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, to dismiss Maurice, H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, saying that Mr. Nadjari had attacked his integrity.

title: Parade Control
description: City Hall has begun to movetoo gingerly, we believe toward some rational efforts to curb the wasteful and disruptive proliferation of parades on Fifth Avenue. According to the best available official estimate, that vital business and residential artery is preempted by about thirty major parades annually. City authorities are now computing the direct cost of these events to the taxpayer; the indirect costs in police and sanitation manpower, loss of income to merchants and annoyance to residents on the route of march are incalculable.

description: BASKETBALL

description: At the Larchmont (N.Y.) Temple at noon yesterday Nancy Susan Heller and Evan John Erichevsky, 1975 graduates of Michigan State University, were married by Rabbi Leonard Poller.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Lawrence Guarino, 30 years old, of 1041 41st Street, Brooklyn was arrested and charged with planting a bomb in the Squire Coffee Shop, at 152 Madison Avenue, near 33d Street, last Tuesday, and bombsquad detectives raided a Brooklyn social club and seized seven sticks of dynamite and more, than 100 blasting caps, hand grenades and a handgun. The suspect was arrested at Canal Street and the Bowery as he sat in a car with four other men, who were also detained and charged with illegal possession of firearms.

title: Joyce Bushel Dead at 83; Lawyer, Amateur Golfer

Kolb, a retired builder of prefabricated houses, she was 83 years old and lived at 94 Mineola Avenue, Point Lookout. L.I.

title: Lebanon's Geography Favors Moslems Over Christians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23The military and ethnic geography of the civil strife in Lebanon favors the Moslems and puts the Christians at a disadvantage. This may have longrange implications as the two communities pull farther apart; more people are speaking in terms of partition.

description: Max Cantor, who retired in 1972 as dean of boys at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, died Saturday at University Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 6185 78th Street in Rego Park, Queens.

title: $163 MILLION GIVEN BY CARE OVERSEAS
description: More than $163 million worth of food, selfhelp supplies, medical and emergency aid was provided during the last fiscal year by CARE to some 24 million needy people abroad, according to the organization's 29th annual report made public yesterday.

description: Footpaths and dirt roads reach out to explore a new country and suddenly a highway is built and certain turnings are made obsolete. Movie cartooning was like that: some lovely directions were sealed off when Walt Disney made his particular style into a national monument.

description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28Even though Chris Bahr was neither injured nor sick during the regular football season, the Penn State placement specialist said today, I was much stronger at the beginning of the season than I am now.

She was 82 years old, the wife of Fred E. Hamilton, an insurance man, and lived at 136 Park Avenue in Bronxville.

description: The Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham Manor, N. Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elisabeth Jane Marie Evans, daughter of Mrs. Joseph E. Evans of Pelham Manor and the late Mr. Evans, to Peter V. Foukal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaroslav Foukal of Montreal. The Rev. Donald Kocher performed the ceremony.

description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 28 (UPI)Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. has given the trustees of the New Hampshire State Prisson a month to increase efficiency and order at the 102yearold institution, the scene of a fourhour rampage by inmates on Christmas Day.

title: For Kaye Ballard, Appearing at Plaza, Experience Counts

So, it is only appropriate that her performance draws on those three decades of experienceon her on and Off Broadway musicals, her years as a supperclub favorite and, more recently, her television appearances in The MothersinLaw.

description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched a Molniya series communicalions satellite for use primarily on domestic telephone, telegraph and television links, the Tass press agency said today.

title: Dunhill Ltd. Chairman Steps Down but Not Out
description: LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP)Silver haired, astute, genial, pipe smoking, all these epithets can be applied to the outgoing chairman of Alfred Dunhill Ltd., the world famous tobacconists and Mary Dunhill doesn't mind as long as you don't call her chairwoman or chairperson.

description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 28 (Reuters)Bangladesh's Chief of Defense Staff, Maj. Gen, Ziaur Rahman, has been retired and the post of chief of defense staff has been abolished, a statement by the armed forces said today.

title: AGNES ROUDEBUSH DAY
description: Agnes Roudebush Day, widow of Thomas M. Day Jr., former treasurer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday in Southampton, L.I. She was 79 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

description: To our mind, no matter how Texans and assorted citizens of the West and Southwest may boast otherwise, there is no such thing as the one real, authentic recipe for chili con carne. And part of the fun is in composing your own version.

title: Advertising

title: Cays Rout Braves, 11188; Victory 9th in 10 Games
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers, trailing after one period, held Buffalo to three field goals in 17 attempts in the second quarter and went on to a 11188 rout of the Braves in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: SHOTGUN BANDITS R0B 20 ON SUBWAY
description: Two robbers invaded a Bronxbound IND express train late Saturday night, terrorized about 20 passengers with a shotgun, and robbed at least, $300 from them over a 90second span as the speeding train approached the 125th Street station on the West Side.

title: Plutonium Threat...
description: A direct approach by President Ford to the leaders other nuclear supplier nations has become essential to halt the threatened spread around the world of equipment and technology to produce weaponsgrade plutonium, the explosive material for atomic bombs. This view, urged by The Times and others for the past six months, has now received powerful Congressional endorsement through Senate passage of the MondalePastore resolution.

title: Office Area Booms in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 Taxi drivers plead and bargain with their fares to avoid the area, because traffic jams fill it. And they are the interlocking kind: northsouth intersections stay crowded with immobilized automobiles while the eastwest lights are green, and vice tersa. A million horsepowet hums, and no one moves.

title: Turkish Steel Mill Opened By Soviet Prime Minister
description: ISKENDERUN, Turkey, Dec. 28 (UPI)Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, on a fourday state visit to Turkey, opened the Sovietfinanced Iskenderun steel mill today with Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel of Turkey.

title: Tennessee Downs Pennsylvania, 7770
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP)  Ernie Grunfeld sank a two free throws with two minutes to play that gave Tennessee a 7169 lead, and the Volunteers then used more free throws to clinch a 7770 victory over Pennsylvania in the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament today.

title: Soviet Skaters Give Lesson in Hockey
description: If the National Hockey League is so hellbent on expansion, what the league could use is a lot more hockey of the type the Soviet Army team brought into Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Good Guy in Chinese Films Is Now the Working Woman
description: URUMCHI, China  The stubborn male chauvinist in his last retreat in this remote northwestern frontier region of China cannot relax even at the movies any more because on the screen he is now among the chief and most dastardly of villains.

title: Expansion in Steel Industry Pauses As Capacity Needs Are Reassessed
description: The rash of expansion projects announced by the steel industry over the past two years appears headed for slowdowns and stretchouts as the industry pauses to reassess its future capacity needs.

title: West German Grocer Battles Alone Against Nation's EarlyClosing Law
description: HAAN, West GermanyHorst Hoffmann, a combative 47yearold grocer, defied the law three years ago and told his customers he'd sell them a pint of milk or a pound of butter if they came into his store at 8 or 9 P.M.

title: Janet Stoltz Married To Fred B. Sunness
description: Janet Debra Stoltz and Fred Barry Sunness were married at noon yesterday at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn by Rabbi Abraham Levene.

title: Polish Fishing Trawler Seized Off Fire I.
description: A Polish trawlerfactory ship with a crew of 98 was seized off Fire Island yesterday, the 10th foreign vessel caught poaching by the Coast Guard along the Atlantic shore this year.

description: The letter was festooned with a baby duck frolicking under a daisy and a bee flying across the page on which was penciled the message:

title: Eggs Interrupt Hockey
description: An exhibition hockey game between the New York Rangers and the Soviet Army team was interrupted for several minutes at Madison Square Garden last night after several eggs were thrown onto the ice from the stands. Arrested and charged with reckless endangerment were Benjamin Rosenstein, 23 ears old of 824 47th Street, Brooklyn, and a 13yearold boy, both believed to be members of the Jewish Defense League, the police said.

title: World, It Seems, Loves A Lovers Lane Sign
description: KILLINGWORTH, Conn., Dec. 28 (UPI)The carvedwood road sign on Lovers Lane has been stolen and replaced so many times that the situation is ridiculous, says First Selectman Donald Doster.

title: U. S. IS PRESSING FOR ANGOLA PACT; AID WILL CONTINUE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28In a twin effort to get the Angola civil war settled next month, the Ford Administration is continuing arms shipments to two factions there and has dispatched a top diplomat to line up support in other African countries, a high United States official said today.

title: A Rush Job by Hendricks
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 28 Say something about Ted Hendricks, Coach John Madden of the Oakland Raiders was urged during his postgame news conference.

title: European Bison, Once Near Extinction, Now a Big Herd in PolishSoviet Forest
description: BIELSK, PolandThanks to a vast primeval forest straddling the PolishSoviet frontierone of a diminishing number of such forests in the worldthe European bison, the wild forest horse and other species have been saved from extinction.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERChristine, on Dec. 24. Service Private. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be appreciated.

title: For a Special Prosecutor on IntelligenceAgency Abuses
description: WASHINGTONIn 1973, Congress and the public forced the Attorney General to appoint a special prosecutor independent of Justice Department control to investigate the deepening Watergate scandal. The need was clear. Former Attorneys General were under suspicion and the department had failed to move decisively when faced with a coverup.

title: Enough Investigations . . .
description: The principal result of Special Deputy Attorney General Bernard S. Meyer's Attica study  which, after the prosecution and the McKay Commission's study, becomes the third investigation in the almost fourandahalf years since the rebellionis another study.

title: 9 AIRCRASH VICTIMS FOUND IN COLORADO

description: FAYETTE, Miss.The roar of late model cars has replaced the clop and creak of muledrawn wagons along U.S. 61 as rural Jefferson County, Miss., enjoys an economic boom that apparently has not yet fully peaked.

title: G.O.P. JAY SUFFER IN WISCONSIN VOTE
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 26Democratic voters, used to Republicans crossing over and acting as spoilers in Democratic primaries in Wisconsin, will have a chance for a turnabout next year, and they could possibly make or break either President Ford or Ronald Reagan.

title: RUSSELL F. SPEIRS
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Dec. 28 (AP)Russell F. Speirs who retired as a Colgate University English professor in 1969 after 46 years at the school died yesterday in an Auburn hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Elbridge.

title: 1,000 Trip the Light Fantastic at Gala for Elderly
description: Grandparents and greatgrandparents in brightly colored party hats glided across a dance floor in Canarsie High School yesterday in highspirited renditions of the Charleston, the Flora and the Twist to get a head start on New Year's Eve.

title: Helen Gretsch Is Wed to a Teacher
description: Helen Marie Gretsch, daughter of Mr, and Mrs. Fred Gretsch Jr. of Manhasset, I I., was married there yestc ay afternoon to Ernest Lee Copley 3d of Colonial Heights, Va. The Rev. Vincent J. Hart performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Humphrey Clears His 1972 Campaign Debts by Paying Back 4 Cents on Each Dollar Owed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28for the first time in four years, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota is free and clear of Presidential campaign debts, thanks to a device that could work wonders for New York's municipal finances and for the national debt, too.

title: Thomas Morton Weds Miss McCauley
description: Kathryn Jane McCauley, a teacher of art history at Providence College, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Hellman Morton, who teaches organic chemistry at Brown University.

description: CLINTON, Wis., Dec. 28 (AP)  The presidentelect of the American Dental Association says dentists believe the country will adopt a national health insurance plan some day and want to be in on its planning.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Food and Drug Administration will probably take action to remove from the market a group of oral contraceptives called sequentials unless the manufacturers can demonstrate that there is a real need for them, the agency's chief said today.

description: There is a lovely art menagerie on the sixth floor of the Museum of Modern Art.

description: The Indiana numbers: 43 over Columbia and 36 over Manhattan. St. John's number comes up tonight.

title: Burma Abolishes 5 Clubs
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  Five clubs established by Westerners have been abolished by Burma's Minister of Home and Religious Affairs, the official newspaper, The Working People's Daily, reported today. The five banned Ribs are the Rangoon Rotary Club, the Rangoon Lion's Club, the Taunggyi Rotary Club, the Moitmein Rotary Club and the Toungoo Rotary Club.

title: WILBUR O. TEETERS
description: Wilbur O. Teeters, president of Hoke Inc., valve manufacturers of Cresskill, N. J., died Saturday at his home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: Arms Guide Says Powers Race to Develop Death Ray
description: LONDON, Dec. 28 (UPI)According to the editor of Jane's Weapons Systems 1976, the United States and the Soviet Union are locked in a costly struggle to develop the first laser beam ray, which could alter the world's military balance.

title: Touchdown in Playoff Stirs Controversy
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn:, Dec. 28  Roger Staubach's dramatic 50yard touchdown pass to Drew Pearson with 24 seconds left gave the Dallas Cowboys a stunning 1714 victory over the Minnesota Vikings today. The winning play ignited a furious protest by the Vikings and provoked a fan to throw a whisky bottle that struck an official on the forehead.

title: M. T. A. Seeking U. S. Aid to End ClicketyClacks on 3 Rail Lines
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority proposed yesterday to eliminate for commuters the familiar clicketyclack of wheels going over jointed rails on 88 miles of the Long Island Rail Road and 90 of the Harlem and Hudson Divisions.

title: WINE TALK
description: A few months ago, a writer called the editor of a wellknown magazine and proposed an article about wine. Forget it, the editor told him. Wine is dead.

title: John Holman, 57, a Leader In StockCar Racing World
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C., Dec. 28 (UPI)  John Holman, a prominent figure in stockcar racing for the last 18 years, died, apparently of a heart, attack, last evening. He was 57 years old.

title: Martha Waring Abernathy Has Nuptials
description: Martha Waring Abernathy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Herman Abernathy of Greenville, Del., was married there yesterday to Roger Henri Guichard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guichard of Walnut Creek, Calif. The Rev. John C. Scobell performed the ceremony in Christ. Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred. He was assisted by Msgr. Henri I. Foltz of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ambrosia for the New Year
description: Inspired by the celestial fare of the Greek gods, Ambrosiathe traditional Christmas dessert of the Deep Southis equally good after a New Year's dinner.

title: HAROLD LAMPORT, A BIOPHYSICIST, 67
description: Dr. Harold Lamport, a research professor of physiology and biophysics at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday in Westport, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: Father of Tarkenton Dies During Telecast
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 28 (AP)The Rev. Dallas Tarkenton Sr., father of Fran Tarkenton, the Minnesota Viking quarterback, suffered a heart attack and died today while watching his son's team play Dallas on television in the playoff game.

title: Islanders Are Upset Over Postponement
description: The New York Islanders' general manager, William Torrey, said yesterday that he was upset over the postponement of Friday night's National Hockey League game Detroit.

title: State's Poultry Farms Are Rapidly Declining
description: VINELAND, Dec. 26The Vineland Egg Auction, an institution here since 1931, no longer exists. Its elaborte building on Delsea Drive is now a truck terminal.

title: ... Clean the Slate
description: A lawful resolution of the Attica violence was rendered virtually impossible when Governor Rockefeller followed the retaking of the institutionat a cost 39 dead and 89 wounded at the hands of lawenforcement officerswith blanket praise for the state police. The prosecutors appointed by the former Governor proceeded in the same onesided spirit. At this remove, the injustices done are too grave and the trails too dusty to repair the damage or to repay individuals.

title: Everyone Has Favorite (and Authentic) Recipe
description: MARGARET FIELD'S CHILI CON CARNE

title: Beirut Seeks Guarantees on Guerrillas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 28Lebanon is seeking guarantees from other Arab nations that Palestinian guerrillas in this country will respect the authority and sovereignty of the Lebanese state.

title: IsraeliEgyptian Dispute Delays Work on Sinai Post
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 28Disagreement between Israelis and Egyptians over the site of an earlywarning station in Sinai delayed the start of construction of the post today.

title: American Reports Salgon Reacts on Dead and Missing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Dec. 28 (UPI) An American involved in the search for United States servicemen and others missing in Indochina said here that the South Vietnamese Government had asked him to submit a proposal to account for the war dead and missing.

title: FRANK PAUL KANE
description: Frank Paul Kane, a retired vice president of the Kitterlinus Company, now Zabel Brothers, lithographic printers of Philadelphia, and a member of the United States Olympic track team in 1925, died Wednesday in Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in St. David's, Pa., and Stone Harbor, N. J.

title: U.S. Ketch First In Ocean Race
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Dec. 29, Monday (UPI)The American ketch Kialoa III finished first and broke the record in the SydneytoHobart ocean yacht race today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Uruguay Accuses Reds
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 28 (Reuters)  Security forces have seized arms, a light boat, an aircraft and various vehicles in a series of raids against the outlawed Communist patty, a government report said today. It said the party was planning to start guerrilla actions.

title: 1,000 Basques in Guernica Form Democratic Assembly
description: MADRID; Dec. 28 (Reuters) About 1,000 people met in Guernica today to form a Basque Democratic Assembly that calls for an autonomous Basque government, amnesty for all political prisoners and fredom of expression and. assembly, it was announced, here.

title: ...Presidential Task
description: The I.A.E.A. cannot prevent the duplication of such plants once the knowhow has been acquiredor even diversion of weaponsgrade material from them. The I.A.E.A. has no enforcement arm. It is not even certain that the I.A.E.A. can install an effective inspection system that can detect such diversion and, especially, plant duplication elsewhere. The I.A.E.A. is studying this problem now and its initial recommendation has been to press for regional, multinational nuclear fuel centers to keep to a minimum the number of plants throughout the world at which plutonium is produced.

title: Spanking
description: NEW HAVENOne day when I was about seven years of age, trying to hide under the kitchen table to avoid a spanking my mother was energetically applying to my hindside, I experienced a sudden and profound realization. It became clear that she would have to kill me to hurt me. I knew she wouldn't do that. She cared for me. I stopped crying and she stopped spanking. I never received another spanking and I didn't become a juvenile delinquent or grow up to be a mean, vicious man. They used a better way.

title: Old Bridge Man and Marijuana Valued at $2 Million Are Held
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 28 (UPI)An Old Bridge man who authorities said was one of the major drug suppliers in central New Jersey, was arraigned today on charges of possessing marijuana worth an estimated total of $2 million at street prices.

title: Airmen Leave for Moscow
description: PEKING, Monday, Dec. 29 (Agence France  Presse)  The three crew members of the Soviet helicopter captured in March 1974 left Peking for Moscow this morning aboard a scheduled flight of Aeroflot, the Soviet airline.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FELICE NAVIDAD The San Juan Children's Choir from Puerto Rico will offer a program of popular and traditional Christmas music in Alice Tully Hall at 7:30 P.M. The performance is part of Lincoln Center's Community Holiday Festival.

title: Tonight's Entries at Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: DELEGATES SLATES CROPPING UP HERE
description: A conglomeration of coalitions is beginning to appear along with slates committed to single Presidential candidates as New York Democrats prepare to pick delegates to the party's national convention.

title: Life Cycle Social Care Urged In U.S., Including Vacation Aid
description: In a study commissioned by the Ford Foundation, two Columbia University sociologists contend that social services should be expanded in the United States)as they already have been in Europeto help the entire population gain better living standards.

title: Armenians Attack Embassy
description: BEIRUT, Dec. 28 UPI Two rockets were fired at the Turkish Embassy here today, and a group of Armenians claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: GREEK GROUP SAYS IT KILLED C.I.A. MAN
description: ATHENS, Dec. 28 (Reuters)A secret political group said today it assassinated Richard S. Welch, chief agent in Greece for the Central Intelligence Agency, to demonstrate that the Greek Government and army were under the control of United States imperialism.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1975

title: LEFKOWITZ BALKS AT CAREY REQUEST TO OUST NADJARI
description: Governor Carey yesterday pressed Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, to dismiss Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state anticorruption prosecutor, saving that Mr. Nadjari had attacked his integrity.

title: 5 Hidden by Adenaner At Home Daring War
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Konrad Adenauer, the West German Chancellor credited with the country revival after World War II, hid five French prisoners of war in his house in Rhondorf during the last days of the war, the West German radio network said today.

title: Skaters Picked for U.S. Team
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 28 (AP) Four veterans of the 1972 Olympics, along with 21yearold sensation Peter Mueller of Mequon, Wis., were among seven men and eight women chosen today for the United States Olympic speed skating team.

title: Aides Say Ford Ignores Skepticism About Ability
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 28Gerald R. Ford, undisturbed by widespread skepticism about his ability to be President, has decided that he likes his job, is good at it and wants to go on doing it for a full term.

title: President of Compton Will Enlarge His Role
description: year begins O. Milton Gossett, the 50yearold president of Compton Advertising, takes on the additional robes of chief executive, a title held since 1970 by C. Stuart Mitchell, the chairMan.

title: Flyers Bow to Bruins
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI)  Gregg Sheppard scored with 1 minute 8 seconds to play tonight, snapping a 22 tie, and the Boston Bruins went on to a 42 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers. Sheppard's 19th goal of the season gave Boston its first lead of the National Hockey League game.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two men were killed yesterday afternoon when two singleengine airplanes collided in flight near Brewster, the police said. They said the pilot of one plane was not hurt.

title: Steven E. Glickman Weds Ilene Posner
description: Ilene Diane Posner, daughter of Mrs. Edward Stern of Coral Gables, Fla., and Charles Posner of Los Angeles, was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Edward Glickman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Glickman of Roslyn, L. I. Rabbi Joseph Narot performed the ceremony at the Doral Country Club in Miami.

title: Issues and Debate
description: The next session of the New York State Legislature will be asked to abolish the city marshal system.

title: Allen Outpaces 7 Other Drivers
description: MONTICELLO , N. Y., Dec.28 Hall of Fame day at Monticello Raceway today was marked by the lineup of five local dirvers against three members of the Hall of Fame of the Trotter. The competition, involving the first three races on the 10race card, was won by Jimmy Allen, the champion at Saratoga and the leader at the winter meeting here.

title: Rangers Trounced, 73, Here As Soviet Army Opens Tour
description: In the first game of an eightgame series between two. Soviet teams and eight National Hockey League clubs, the New York Rangers were routed last night by the Soviet Army, 73, despite outsbooting the Russians, 41 to 29, and scoring the first goal after just 21 seconds.

title: Sanford Pins Victory Hope On His Nonpolitical Stance
description: DURHAM, N.C.As the first Presidential preference polls began to roll in, listing voter choices for the Democratic nomination, former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina told aides he was considering changing his name to Terry Others.

title: The Program
description: WINSOR McCAY RETROSPECTIVE, a collection of shorts by a pioneer of American animated cartooning. Includes: Little Nemo, How a Mosquito Operates, Gertie the Dinosaur. The Sinking of the Lusitanla, The Centaurs, Flip's Circus, Gertie en Tour, and three films from the series Dreams of a Rarebit Fiend. New American Film Makers Series, at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Yesterday through Jan. 6. Running time: 70 minutes.

title: Economists Debate Capital Shortage
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28The nation's top economists have begun to tangle over the seriousness of the capital shortage that allegedly confronts the nationa shortage that has produced cries and outrage and calls for tax relief from many in the business community and some in the Administration during the last year.

title: A Carefree, CarFree 5th Ave. Stirs Warm Mood on Chill Day
description: One of the Polish folk dancers wore bright green woolen gloves yesterday as she danced for pedestrians on carfree Fifth Avenue. The gloves were not part of her costume, but no one watching her seemed to mind.

title: Elizabeth Meyns Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Gage Ellis Meyns of Boston and Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday morning to Peter Merrill Watkins of Hadtyme, Conn., at whose home the Rev, Thomas Huntington Chappell performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: She Checks Aliens Seeking U.S Home
description: MIAMI, Dec. 28  Mrs. Ruth R. Zavoli looks like the grandmother that she is. She smiles often, speaks softly and listens with interest to her clients who, initially at least, feel reassured by her deferential manner.

title: Labor Zionists, Meeting Here, Are Addressed by Mrs. Meir
description: Yesterday was a homecoming for Golda Meir as 1,500 Labor Zionists gave her a standing ovation at the finalluncheon session of the annual convention of the Labor Zionist Alliance in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Aides Say Ford Ignores Skepticism About Ability
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 28Gerald R. Ford, undisturbed by widespread skepticism about his ability to be President, has decided that he likes his job, is good at it and wants to go on doing it for a full term.

title: Personal Finance
description: What happens when minor children are the beneficiaries of life insurance policies?

title: HISTORY IS MADE IN '75 FINANCING
description: To investors in the bond market, 1975 is historic because it is the year that New York City postponed payment on its notes when they became due.

description: Theater

title: Books of The Times
description: This year, the bulk of books on the decorative arts have concentrated on 19thcentury developments. Although many of the volumes publishedincluding a study of tramp art, another of hooked rugs and a third on new quilt discoveriestend to be little more than catalogues of such material, other research works shed new thinking on some old or unfamiliar areas of the arts. And one catalogue. A Craftsman's Handbook by Henry Lapp, a reproduction published by the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is a gem. The Pennsylvania German artisan's sketchbook ($6.95) is full of surprises from the wildly colorful chests he did (combining lemon yellow, purple and kelly green) to his Rube Goldberg mousetraps. Sometimes a 50page catalogue offers more than an encyclopedia.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: SOME BIRTH PILLS FACE BAN BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Food and Drug Administration will probably take action to remove from the market a group of oral contraceptives called sequentials unless the manufacturers can demonstrate that there is a real need for them, the agency's chief said today.

title: Making it Slowly
description: WAS DISMAYED when I read the comments of President Ford and many others abuut New York City. What they said and what I have experienced are entirely different. I grew up in neighborhoods the President and his advisers probably never heard of or have chosen to ignoreBrooklyn's Brownsville and East New York. I know what it is like to he a member of an economically oppressed minority. I have lived in a climate where poverty, overpopulation and hunger are the prevailing living conditions. I suffered the shame of being evicted from several apartments and of being penniless and without food for days. When I was twelve, in 1964, I was bused from Brownsville to a then nearly ailwhite Cypress Hills for the purpose of integration. I was taunted by white children and adults because I was the only white on the bus coming into their neighborhood. They jeered at my ghetto speech and made fun of my poor clothes. By the time I was sixteen both my parents were dead. I learned early what it is like to he a recipient of New York City's social welfare system. I received enough money every two weeks to buy food for my brother and myself, but there was little left for anything else.

title: Syrian Welcomed in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28 (UPI)  President Hafez alAssad of Syria today received one of the warmest welcomes accorded a foreign visitor here on his arrival for a fourday visit aimed at cementing relations between Syria and Iran. The visit is expected to yield considerable financial aid for impoverished Syria.

title: A. B. A. Boxes
description: Nuggets 110. Pacers 105 DENVER (110)

title: About New York
description: It's to die, the chic lady said. To die is an expression used only by chic ladies in New York, and it is thought to have been invented by Diana Vreeland, who was the editor of Vogue. My dear, it's to die, she would say in her husky voice, and mean that something was divine, or possibly the cat's pajamas. Other chic ladies have been saying it ever since.

title: RON W. TODGHAM
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, Dec. 28 (AP)Ron W. Todgham, who once served as chauffeur to the president of Chrysler Canada Ltd. and later became president of the company himself, died Friday in London, Ontario, of complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old.

title: ROBERT L. GIBSON
description: Robert L. Gibson, who retired in 1967 as vice president and general manager of the powerdistribution division of the General Electric Company, died Saturday at his home in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: Susan Charnelle Bride of W. D. Hooper
description: Susan Charnelle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Charnelle of New York and Remsenberg, L. I., was married yesterday noon to William Douglas Hooper, a management consultant here. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Paul Smith at the Remsenberg home of the bride's parents.

title: Caviar Caveats to Protect New Year's Party Shoppers
description: During 1975, this country imported about seven tons of fresh beluga malassol caviar, with an estimated street value of between $1,500,000 and $1,750,000. Those figures represent an averaging of the retail price range of $80 to $110 per 14ounce Russian Imperial pound, and restaurant prices that run as high as $22 per oneounce serving, or $308 for 14 ounces.

title: An Instructive Ordeal?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28Jimmy Carter has spent two nights in Cambridge recently, staying as a guest in two homes not far from Harvard Square. The next morning, after he left, each hostess went upstairs and found that he had made his bed. That is the latest political news in Cambridge.

title: Bloody Sunday for the Violent Came
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 28 As subtly as a gang tackle, the National Football League has profited by image of violence. Kill the quarterback, for example. But today that image haunted the N.F.L. when a 54yearold judge, Armen Terzian, lay sprawled on the painted green turf of Metropolitan Stadium, felled near the 5yard line by a whisky bottle thrown from the nearby bleachers. After perhaps two minutes, he trotted the length of the field, a wide bandage wrapped around his head to stop the bleeding from a vshaped gash across the hairline in the middle of his forehead. Somewhere on this frozen tundra, his assailant is alone with his conscience. Quickly, the Minnesota Vikings posted a reward of $5,000 for arrest and conviction. But to a great degree, the N.F.L. has only itself to blame. Violence breeds violence. And when the Dallas Cowboys upset the Vikings, 1714, on a controversial touchdown, somebody threw a whiskey bottle at an official because the Vikings had protested that an offensive passinterference penalty should have been called against Drew Pearson, the Cowboys' wide receiver, on Roger Staubach's pass. If you can't kill the quarterback, kill the officialpro football sometimes appeals to that mentality.

title: Washington Buildings: Low Profile and Boxlike Design
description: WASHINGTON  If this city remains an attractive urban environment, it does so in spite of its buildings, not because of them. Once a city of elegant townhouses and small commercial structures  aside from Government buildings, that isdowntown Washington has given way to a series of 8story to 12story office buildings that, in the last decade, have made it far more like the urban jumble of other cities than the natives here like to acknowledge.

title: 25 Race Horses Die in Fire
description: BEDFORD, Pa., Dec. 28 (UPI)A fastspreading fire at the Bedford fairground destroyed 25 race horses at a barn today, causing a property loss of up to $230,000, the authorities said.

title: Michigan Senator And His Wife See Liberalism Faded
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) Senator and Mrs. Philip A. Hart of Michigan said today that the optimism they brought to Washington 17 years ago the belief that liberalism could change the world  had given way to discouragement bordering on dismay.

title: Jersey's Poultry Farms Succumbing to Modernity
description: VINELAND, Dec. 26The Vineland Egg Auction, an institution here since 1931, no longer exists. Its elaborate building on Delsea Drive is now a truck terminal.

title: Bengals' Rally Falls Short in 3128 Loss
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 28 The Oakland Raiders were enjoying the occasion like tourists on a Caribbean cruise when, all of a sudden, their ship developed a leak. A fat 17point lead over the Cincinnati Bengals today sank to a 3point lead in the final quarter. Alarm swept through the stadium where 53,039 spectators had been savoring what superficially appeared to be a trouncing of the American Football Conference wildcard team from the banks of the Ohio River.

title: Sanford Pins Victory Hope On His Nonpolitical Stance
description: DURHAM, N.C.As the first Presidential preference polls began to roll in, listing voter choices for the Democratic nomination, former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina told aides he was considering changing his name to Terry Others.

title: Leo Margulies, Long an Editor Of Pulp Magazines, Dies at 75
description: Leo Margulies, a leading editor and publisher of pulp magazines and an anthologist of mystery and science fiction, died Friday in a Los Angeles hospital after having suffered a stroke in London at a meeting of the Mystery Writers of America. He was 75 years old and had still been editing Mike Shayne's Mystery Magazine.

title: India Pumps Nine To Reach Hundreds Trapped by Flood
description: PATNA, India, Monday, Dec. 29Highpowered pumps with capacities of 1,000 gallons a minute worked through yesterday and into last night to draw off water flooding a mine in Bihar State, but a Government official said that only a miracle could save hundreds of miners trapped far below.

title: 2 VESSELS COLLIDE OFF ICELAND COAST
description: ABOARD H.M.S. ANDROMEDA, off Iceland, Dec. 28 (Reuters)The British frigate Andromeda and an Icelandic patrol boat, the Tyr, collided about 60 miles off Iceland's east coast today as the Andromeda maneuvered to protect a British trawler.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: U. S. IS PRESSING FOR ANGOLA PACT; AID WILL CONTINUE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28In a twin effort to get the Angola civil war settled next month, the Ford Administration is continuing arms shipments to two factions there and has dispatched a top diplomat to line up support in other African countries, a high United States official said today.

title: Mary McCabe, 73, Soprano In Original Student Prince
description: Mary O'Connell McCabe, a lyric soprano in Broadway musicals 40 years ago under the name of Patricia O'Connell, died in New Haven last Wednesday. She was 73 years old and was the widow of Angus Shaw McCabe, a journalist here.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Levitt Study Criticizes Control Of State Homes for Aged Poor
description: Comptroller Arthur Levitt accused the State Board of Social Welfare yesterday of permitting substandard conditions in homes for the poor and in some areas showing more concern for the owners than for the residents.

title: ABUSE OF INMATES IS LAID TO PRISON
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)Several penalreform groups charged today that more than 250 Trenton State Prison inmates had been held in virtual solitary confinement for more than two months.

title: Travel Abroad for Congress Is in Full Swing During Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) While most Americans began packing the Christmas tinsel and worrying about paying holiday bills, many of those they sent to Congress were packing for trips abroad, at Uncle Sam's expense.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Construction delays in completing the Newtown Creek Water Pollution Control project, the largest capacity sewage treatment facility in the city, have resulted in increased costs and substantial continued pollution of the East and Hudson Rivers, according to an audit report by Arthur Levitt, the state Comptroller.

title: Maryland and Princeton Gain Tournament Final
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 29 (AP)Armond Hill scored 20 points, leading Princeton to a 6159 upset victory over eighthranked Alabama, and secondranked Maryland trounced Seton Hall, 10469, in the semifinals of the Maryland invitation basketball tournament tonight.

title: Bishop Gives to Help Neediest
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn gave $200 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, writing, At this time, I am grateful to you for your compassion, concern and love for the helpless and deprived. The fund is a hopeful sign for us all.

title: Bridge:
description: A trend in tournament organization was almost, but not quite, pushed to its logical conclusion in the last year. Over the last six years the boardamatch team game, in which overtricks are vital, has been displaced in almost all tournament schedules by Swiss Teams, or other events scored by international match points in which overtricks are a minor factor.

title: 23 Miss Alabama Curfew
description: NEW ORLEANS. Dec. 29Not just one or two, but 23 University of Alabama football players missed curfew last night, returning to their hotel rooms from 15 minutes to more than an hour late. Most of the late players were starters, including Richard Todd, possibly the nation's best wishboneoffense quarterback.

title: W. T. Grant Getting A Consulting Team On Future Tactics
description: A spokesman for the 11member creditors committee for the W. T. Grant Company said yesterday that the committee had appointed a group of consultants to assist in determining the future operational strategy of the merchandise chain.

title: Ballet: Rustic Coppelia
description: American Ballet Theater seems to have adopted Coppelia as its personal form of The Nutcracker  the Christmas show for the kids which will have to stop sometime, if only because I understand that Ballet Theater is considering mounting its own Nutcracker. Nevertheless Coppelia, for its adult pleasures, does make a good introduction to ballet, particularly nowadays when children are brought up on a diet of violence and will see nothing particularly odd in a hero who kills butterflies and bullies old men, or a heroine who steals keys and breaks into other people's houses. After all it's all good clean fun with pleasant peasants.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Celebration
description: We have too long accepted a traditional way of looking at nature, at nature's creatures, which has blinded us to their incredible essence, and which has made us incomparably lonely. It is our loneliness as much as our greed which can destroy us.

title: AdProgram Colleges Draw More Students
description: There is an 11 percent increase in the number of youngsters enrolled in colleges and universities with advertising programs this year compared with 1974.

title: Radio
description: 9:0610 A.M., WQXR: Piano Personalities. Adam Harasiewicz and Adrian Ruiz. Three Polonaises, Chopin: Suite for Piano in D minor, Raff.

title: City Capital Budget Is Sent to Beame Without a Change
description: The city's capital budget recommendations, which usually change every step of the way from the City Planning Commission's first draft to eventual approval, were submitted to Mayor Beame yesterday unchanged from the austere document debated in three allday public hearings two weeks ago.

title: Witnesses Tell of Horror
description: The explosion at the baggageclaim area at La Guardia Airport last night that turned a scene of holiday travel into a nightmare left witnesses talking with horror and amazement of the destruction they had seen.

title: Charleston Judge Rules Statute On Diapering Horses Is Invalid
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 29A summons issued against a Charleston carriage tour employee who drove an undiapered horse was dismissed today when a municipal court judge ruled the ordinance unreasonable and invalid.

title: British Put Laws in Force To Bar Sex Discrimination
description: LONDON, Dec. 29The British woman was relieved many of the traditional shackles of this maledominated society today and was given markedly more freedom to chart her own life.

title: Amex Seat Brings $44,000
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the sale of a seat at $44,000, unchanged from the last sale on Dec. 16. Memberships are now quoted at $42,000 bid, $49,000 offered.

title: DR. ANTONIO FERRI, AEROSPACE EXPERT
description: Dr. Antonio Ferri, a pioneer in windtunnel research in problems of supersonic flight, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home, 42 Yukon Drive, Woodbury, L. I. He was 63 years old.

title: Average $295 Billion
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday in Washington that the nation's money supply had declined again in the latest reporting week, following a sharp decline in the preceding week.

title: Queens Girl, 5, Slain in Home; Brother and Baby Sitter Missing
description: A 5yearold girl was found stabbed to death in the basement of her home in East Elmhurst, Queens, yesterday, and her 10yearold brother and a 17yearold livein baby sitter were both missing, the police said.

title: INDIA TO POSTPONE ELECTIONS A YEAR
description: CHANDIGARH, India, Dec. 29 The leaders of the Indian Government disclosed today that they intended to use their emergency powers to postpone for a year the parliamentary elections that were to have been held early in 1976.

title: Brooklyn Rites Held for Civilian Murdered Aiding a Policeman
description: Hundreds of mourners, including uniformed members of the Police Department's Tactical Patrol Unit, crowded a small Brooklyn church and the street outside yesterday for the funeral of Cecilio Mercado, the 32yearold civilian who died assisting a policeman and boyhood friend.

title: 45 Planes Rescheduled
description: Thousands of holiday travelers found their vacation plans dashed or delayed last night as airlines scrambled to cancel and divert flights at La Guardia Airport in the wake of last night's explosion.

title: Advance Mortgage Corp. Put on Probation by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that the nation's second largest mortgage lending company had agreed to stop alleged irregularities involving Federally guaranteed home loans.

title: DEMOCRATS HEAL MISSISSIPPI RIFT
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 29Mississippi's black  controlled loyalist Democrats took yesterday what appeared to be the final step in assuring merger with the predominantly white regular Democrats, ending a 12year racial split in the state party.

title: WALDHEIM SENDING A U.N. AIDE TO TIMOR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim arranged today to send a high United Nations official to Portuguese Timor despite urging from the proIndonesian regime now in control there that the visit be put off for safety reasons.

title: Knight Needles Carnesecca
description: After the tumult and the shouting died among the Holiday Festival crowd at the Garden last night, the first thing Indiana Coach Bobby Knight wanted to do was aim a gentle gibe in the direction of his St. John's counterpart.

title: DR ANTONIO FERRI, AEROSPACE EXPERT
description: Dr. Antonio Ferri, a pioneer in windtunnel research in problems of supersonic flight, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home, 42 Yukon Drive, Woodbury, L. I. He was 63 years old.

title: Tests on Heat of Pulsars Back Theory Of Superfluidity, Not Just Superdensity
description: Using the moon as a curtain moving progressively across the Crab Nebula, physicists at Cblumbia University believe they have confirmed that pulsars are not only superdense objects but are also superfluid.

title: BBC Service Is Cut By 24Hour Walkout
description: LONDON, Dec. 29 (UPI) The voice of Britain around the world was curtailed by a strike today.

title: JULIUS BORENSTEIN, YIVO INSTITUTE HEAD
description: Julius Borenstein, a Bronx builder and past president of the Bronx Real Estate Board who was also chairman of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, died yesterday in Albert Einstein College Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 2165 Bolton Street in the Bronx.

title: &L.A. DEFENDANT TO BE OWN LAWYER
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29William Harris, a member of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army, was granted permission today to act as his own attorney Feb. 2 when he and his wife, Emily, face trial on charges stemming from an alleged crime spree here in May 1974.

title: Knicks Win 5th In Row
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29  Earl Monroe and Walt Frazier, the glittering Knick guards, led New York to its fifth straight National Basketball Association victory tonight, a 9493 decision over the Chicago Bulls. It was the Knicks' seventh triumph in eight games.

title: U.S. Said to Delay Action On Endangered Species
description: The United States, which initiated and ratified an international wildlife protection pact two years ago, has so far failed to implement the agreement, a Washingtonbased conservation group charged yesterday.

title: Israel and Egypt Settle Dispute Over Sinai Monitoring Station
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 29Israeli and Egyptian generals today settled a dispute over an electronic surveillance station that had upset part of the schedule for carrying out the latest disengagement agreement in the Sinai Peninsula.

title: British Soccer Standing
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Some at Dinner for Ford Had Been Asked for Gifts
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 29A friend of President Ford who is one of his campaign workers has generated some political complications for the President by soliciting campaign contributions from at least some of the guests she invited to a dinner in his honor tonight.

title: Dow Off 3.15 After 3Day Rally; G.M. Sets New High for Year
description: Stock prices drifted downward yesterday as the yearend rally lost some of its steam. The Dow Jones industrials dipped 3.15 points, finishing at 856.66.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Dec. 29, 1975 (In bushels, 00 omitted)

title: Army Denies a Wounded Knee Massacre
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Department of the Army contended today that it was unfair and inaccurate to describe the events of Dec. 29, 1890, at Wounded Knee, S. D., as a massacre, asserting that it was instead a spontaneous and heated battle in which both sides got carried away.

title: U.S. Judge Orders District of Columbia To Move Patients
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 29In a ruling that could have national significance, a Federal judge ordered the District of Columbia government today to transfer about 1,000 inmates from its main mental hospital to outpatient residential facilities such as nursing homes and halfway houses.

title: Mexican Minister Quits
description: Mexico's Foreign Minister, Emilo O. Rabasa, resigned unexpectedly last night. Many diplomats and Mexican Foreign Ministry officials linked the resignation to the controversy aroused by Mexico's vote in the United Nations equating Zionism with racism. Details, Page 2.

title: A Republican Dilemma...
description: Nearly eight years ago, at the beginning of another Presidential campaign, Gov. George W. Romney startled the political community by withdrawing from the race for the Republican nomination before the New Hampshire primary had even been held. Since Mr. Romney was then the favored candidate of many progressive and middleoftheroad Republicans, his withdrawal left a critical can in the leadership of his party.

title: Woman Wins Reversal in Death Of Alleged Rapist's Accomplice
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (UPI)The California Court of Appeals reversed today the seconddegree murder conviction of Inez Garcia, who killed the companion of a man she said had raped her.

title: 30 Years at the Met: Three Stars Reminisce
description: Dorothy Kirsten, Robert Merrill and Jerome Hines have all reached 30th anniversaries in their careers with the Metropolitan Opera. All are Americanborn and Americantrained and have been mainstays of the company.

title: China, Renewing Attacks, Accuses Soviet on Angola
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 29In two bitterly worded attacks, China today accused the Soviet Union of being the main source of the danger of war and charged that the Russians were archcriminals who were plotting to control Angola.

title: ExJustice Alfred Gitelson, Ordered Busing on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) Retired state Superior Court Justice Gitelson, who was voted out of office after his controversial order to desegregate the city schools in Los Angeles, died yesterday. He was 69 years old.

title: Indiana Snaps. Late Deadlock And Defeats St. John's, 7669
description: Big strong Indiana, with its huge national reputation, failed to scare smaller and lessheralded St. John's last night. The nation's topranked College basketball team, whiCh has frightened some opponents into submission seconds after the opening buzzer, defeated at St. John's, 7669 in the final of the holiday festival at  Madison Square Garden after having been tied by the Redmen, R565.

title: Shapp Basing Campaign On Revamping Economy
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.If he were taller, younger, handsome, a good speaker and a Gentile, Milton Jerrold Shapp would probably be one of the major contenders in the current struggle for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The British movement for women's rights made big advances yesterday when two women's rights laws became effective. One would assure the same pay to women who have the same jobs as men, and the other would bar sex discrimination in employment, advertising and other situations where British men have had a preferred status. Two women prominent in the Labor Government were the prime backers of the legislation, which was years in preparation. They are Dr. Shirley Summerskill, member of Parliament and Under Secretary of State in the Home Officee, and Barbara Castle, Minister of Social Services. [Page 1, Cols. 23.1

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSSarah, on Dec. 27, beloved sister of William F. of Lakewood, N.J. Reposing at Woodlawn Mortician Chapel, 4418 White Plains Road (near 238th St.), Bronx. Religious services Tuesday, 8 P.M. Funeral Wednesday, 10 A.M.

title: 15th Cornelia Cotillion Held at the Plaza
description: Fourteen young women, seniors at the Cathedral School of St, Mary in Garden City, LI., and/or communicants at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, were presented in the cathedral early last evening to Bishop Jonathan Goodhue Sherman of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

title: VETERANS OFFICE CLOSED BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered the closing of his Office for Veterans Affairs and the laying off of 17 civil servants and 34 Vietnam veterans, but continued in operation the $37,344ayear post of director.

title: No Real System at Hand for Inspecting Baggage
description: All United States airlines follow a Government approved procedure designed to prevent sabotage by bombs that might be in luggage checked by passengers and loaded in the baggage hold.

title: POSTAL RATE RISE RULED INTO EFFECT EARLY TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit lifted today a lower court injunction and allowed a postal rate increase, including a threecent rise on firstclass mail to 13 cents.

title: Euell Gibbons Dies at 64
description: SUNBURY, Pa., Dec. 29Euell Gibbons, author of books on natural foods, was pronounced dead on arrival in Sunbury Community Hospital tonight. The cause of death was not immediately disclosed. He was 64 years old.

title: W.H.A. Selects Hull, Howe As AllStar Game Starters
description: Nationalism seems to be the order of the day in pro hockey. The National Hockey League is currently involved in an eightgame series with the Soviet Union, while the World Hockey Association has announced that its theme for the fourth allstar gamee will be Canada vs. the United States.

title: Collection Agencies Face Stiffer Policing As Complaints Rise
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29 (AP)Three state agencies today announced a joint effort to handle complaints against collection agencies operating in New Jersey.

title: I.M.F. Said to Expect Cut In Poorer Nations' Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (Reuters)An International Monetary Fund study estimates developing countries will face a balanceofpayments deficit of $31 billion in 1976, monetary sources said, or $4 billion less than the anticipated deficit for the current year.

title: Bethlehem Executives Get Temporary Pay Cut
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP)  The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel manufacturer, has temporarily reduced salaries of its top executives because of the continued depressed level of business, a company spokesman said today.

title: Gadsen Victor On College Mat
description: GREEN VALE, L.I., Dec. 29Charles Gadsen of the State University of New York at Farmingdale, pinned Ray Yeager of Edinborough (Pa.) State in 52 seconds and won the 177pound class at the annual C. W. Post intercollegiate wrestling tournament. For his victory, Gadsen was named the tourney's most valuable wrestler among 500 representing 50 schools.

title: Note Exchange Deadline Passes After a Rush by City Investors
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, influenced by last week's State Supreme Court ruling upholding the legality of the statepassed moratorium on city notes, voted unanimously yesterday not to extend the deadline for exchange of the notes for M.A.C. bonds.

title: Business Briefs
description: E. F. Hutton & Company, the nation's second largest brokerage house, announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to acquire another Wall Street firm, G. A. Saxton & Company.

title: The Final judgment Remains
description: More than four years after state troopers recaptured part of the Attica. Correctional Facility in a hail of indiscriminate gunfire, killing 39 men (including 10 state employees) and wounding 81 others, the state of New York has officially conceded that:

title: Shriver Listed in Illinois
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. Dec. 29 (AP) Petitions listing the name ?? Sargent Shriver, the 1972 Democratic candidate for Vice President, were filed today with the State Board of Elections for the Illinois Presidential preference primary March 16. Other Democrats entered in the nation's third primary of 1976 are former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter former Oklahoma Senator Fred R. Harris and Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace

title: 4 IN INDIANA G.O.P. FREED OF CHARGES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 29(UPI)  Judge Andrew Jacobs Sr. of Marion County Criminal Court threw out today as defective indictments against the former Indiana Republican chairman, Buena Chaney, and three other men charged with committing dirty tricks against the 1970 reelection campaign of Democratic Senator Vance Hartke.

title: Jackson Plans Bill to Curb Courts on Student Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Senator Henry M. Jackson introduced a new antibusing strategy into the 1976 Presidential campaign today, suggesting that all school desegregation cases be put before threejudge courts, and That the judges be required to consider the prospects of white flight before they ordered busing as an integration tool.

title: Tangible Benefits of Ecology Turning Up
description: Environment has suddenly become an economic Cinderella.

title: CORRECTION
description: The originator of a chili con came recipe was referred to incorrectly as the late Margaret Field in The New York Times yesterday. Mrs. Field is alive and is a resident of San Antonio, Tex.

title: Bond Prices Decline
description: Bond prices slipped yesterday as the threeweekold December rally in the credit markets encountered modest selling. Even with the move toward higher interest rates in the bond market, shortterm interest rates continued to decline and the Treasury sold bills at the lowest rates since midJune. Late in the afternoon, the Federal Reserve disclosed a $1 billion decline in the money supply, but the credit markets did not respond with any flurry of activity.

title: Soviet and Turkey Plan Document on Friendly Ties
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP)The Soviet Union and Turkey have decided to draw up a political document on friendly relations and cooperation as a result of the visit to Turkey by Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Federal Jury Hears Helstoski
description: NEWARK, Dec. 29 (AP)Representative Henry Helstoski appeared before a Federal grand jury here today as the United States Attorney's office continued an investigation into ?? financial affairs. It was the seventh grand jury appearance for Mr. Helstoski, a sixterm Democrat from Bergen County, who has asserted he is being harassed by the inquiry. A gag; order prohibits Mr. Helstoski, his attorneys or United States from commenting on the appearance.

title: F. T. C. Chief Has Final Word: Government Is Overregulating
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29In his final news conference as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Lewis A. Engman said today that there was far too much regulation by government at all levels.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: New Zealand on Its Yearly Month Off
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 28In this country, where summer comes in December, Santa Claus was one of the few people who worked this month. From midDecember to midJanuary New Zealand goes home for the holidays.

title: U.S. SAID TO STUDY NEV HEALTH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Ford Administration is considering a consolidation of the nation's health service programs into one $10 billion health revenuesharing program, Administration sources said today.

title: PITTSBURGH SEEKS SCHOOL STRIKE END
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29The Board of Public Education went into court today in an attempt to obtain an injunction that would end a strike by teachers that began Dec. 1 and has kept 62,300 students from attending classes at 105 schools.

title: Oil Contract for Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Venezuela has reached an agreement with international oil companies for the purchase of 1.5 million barrels a day of the country's nationalized oil for the first quarter of 1976, Mines Minister Valentin Hernandez said today.

title: Schmidt, Capital Coach, Resigns
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 29 (UPI)  Milt Schmidt, the coach and general manager of the struggling Washington Capitals, resigned tonight soon after his team lost, 60, to the Montreal Canadiens.

title: GIARDINO TO STAY AS HEAD OF CITY U.
description: Alfred A. Giardino, the chairman of the Board of Higher Education, has reversed a previous intention and agreed to accept reappointment by Mayor Beame for an indefinite period as head of the governing board of the embattled City University, the Mayor's office announced yesterday.

title: Goldman Firm Told to Pay Bank in Pennsy Note Loss
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street securities firm, must pay more than $500,000 to the Franklin Savings Bank for a loss the bank Suffered in the purchase of a shortterm note of the insolvent Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: Helping New York
description: Gee, I must go to 78th Street, said a friend of Genia Bonne's with a wink, one day at work. I hear you have a massage parlor on your block.

title: British Auto Exports Rise
description: LONDON, Dec. 29 (Reuters) British exports of motor products rose 23 percent to 214.9 million ($47 million) last month, compared with November, 1974, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said today.

title: State's November Jobless Rate Up a Bit
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29 (AP)The state reported today that the New Jersey unemployment rate rose slightly in November, to 13.4 percent, representing 458,900 jobless workers.

title: Station Returned to Catholics
description: LISBON, Dec. 29The Portuguese Government announced today the return of Radio Renascenca to the Roman Catholic Church after the station had been illegally occupied since May.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Monday:

title: KIN ARE QUERIED IN GIRL'S MURDER
description: NEWARK, Dec. 29Essex County detectives today questioned the mother and relatives of an 8yearold girl in an effort to determine who had taken her from her home in Elizabeth and drowned her in a lake in Weequahic Park.

title: Wamen's Champion
description: LONDON, Dec. 29Shirley Summerskill, the physicianturnedM.P. who developed Britain's Sex Discrimination Act, could not study biology in the girls' school where her parents, also surgeons, first sent her.

title: Rosewood, Musical Comedy of Anachronism, Opens
description: In the medieval kingdom of Rosewood (the title of a new musical by Joel Gross and Brian Hurley), the citizens boycott grapes, live in splitlevel thatch huts and use such expressions as flashy trash. Rosewood, it would seem, is indistinguishable from contemporary suburbia.

title: Byrne Will Push Fight For State Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29Governor Byrne said today that he would continue to fight for tax reform and a state income tax when the new Legislature convenes here next month.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Minimum retail prices for milk will be going again Friday, the State Department of Agriculture said yesterday. The increase, of 1 cent a quart, is the fourth in four months and will send the price of a quart of milk to at least 40 cents. Stores will not be allowed to charge less than 75 cents a halfgallon and $1.44 a gallon.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TAR FOR TWO New Years Eve is celebrated around the world, but everyone knows the New Year really gets going first in New York. Paris and London may welcome 1976 a few hours earlier, but do they have. Guy Lombardo?

title: Singer Co. to Phase Out Business Machines Unit
description: Joseph B. Flavin, who was named chief executive officer of the Singer Company Dec. 1, said yesterday that the concern intended to phase out its business machines division and other moneylosing operations at an estimated writedown of $400million.

title: College and School Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: Margiotta Will Not Seek ReElection To Assembly, but Will Keep Nassau Role
description: Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican leader, announced yesterday that he would not seek reelection to the Assembly next year, but would retain the county leadership; the major source of his political power.

title: Byrne Vows to Push Fight For a State Tax on Income
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29Governor Byrne said today that he would continue to fight for tax reform and a state income tax when the new Legislature convenes here next month.

title: Notes on People
description: With 1975 clearly established as a tough year for mayors, here and elsewhere, there was no letup as it limped to the finish line. Take for example, Frank Rizzo of Philadelphia, Helen P. Maney of Geneva, N. Y., and John Pearce of Strongsville, Ohio.

title: Fog and Worse on Angola
description: The Ford Administration's drive to persuade the Senate not to cut off funds for covert arms shipments to Angola failed so spectacularly because officials gave conflicting testimony on why such an American intervention was necessary.

title: SEIZURE OF SHIP IS 21ST THIS YEAR
description: The seizure of a Polish trawlerfactory ship off Fire Island during the weekend brought the total of foreign vessels seized on charges of fishing infractions in United States waters this year to 21, a peacetime record.

title: 4 BOMB SENT JET INTO SEA IN 1974
description: Yesterday's bomb blast at La Guardia Airport was the first such deadly explosion in American aviation since the crash of a Trans World Airlines jet into the Ionian Sea off Greece on Sept. 8, 1974.

title: Toy Company Pleads Guilty In Hazardous Rattle Sale
description: NEWARK, Dec. 29 (UPI)A Newark toy manufacturing concern pleaded guilty today to charges that it had marketed hazardous toy rattles which could break open when children shake them.

title: Nassau Judge Rules Blue Laws Are Discriminatory
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 29A Nassau County District Court judge today ruled that the state's blue laws, under which it is an offense for most businesses to sell goods on Sundays, were discriminatory and unconstitutional.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished mixed yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: 30 Years at the Met: Three Stars Reminisce
description: Dorothy Kirsten, Robert Merrill and Jerome Hines have all reached 30th anniversaries in their careers with the Metropolitan Opera. All are Americanborn and Americantrained and have been mainstays of the company.

title: Johnson Administration Exonerated By New Study of Blame for Inflation
description: DALLAS, Dec. 29  Economists have widely criticized President Lyndon B. Johnson and his advisers for their failure to raise taxes in the mid1960's to finance the growing United States involvement in the war in Vietnam. The former President's secrecy about the war buildup and the related delay in tax policy, according to critics, started the nation down the road to troublesome inflation.

title: Israel Says Troops Enter Lebanon and Take 3 Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 29The Israeli command announced tonight that some of its troops had entered Lebanon, captured three Arabs suspected of aiding terrorists and brought them to Israel for questioning.

title: In Memoriam
description: CANNONFlorence (Pellman). In cherished memory of my beloved sister, who entered into eternal rest on Dec. 30, 1954.

title: Maryland Upsets Florida In Rainy Gator Bowl, 130
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP)  Maryland's football resurgence reached its highest point in 20 years tonight when the Terrapins turned two firsthalf interceptions into Larry Dick's 19yard touchdown pass to Kim Hoover and Mike Sochko s 20yard field goal and upset favored Florida, 130, in the Gator. Bowl.

title: Beatrice Foods Reports Profit Rise
description: The Beatrice Foods Company reported yesterday profit gains of 8.4 percent for the third fiscal quarter and 6.6 percent for the nine months ended Nov. 30, The Chicago food processor said both earnings and sales set records in both periods.

title: HELEN REED TOWER
description: Helen Reed Tower, widow of Lawrence Phelps Tower, former president of the United States ??lag Foundation, died Thursday aboard a cruise ship off Honduras. She lived here.

title: Statements by Lefkowitz And Governor on Nadjari
description: On Dec. 23, 1975, Governor Carey announced his intention to replace Maurice Nadjari as special prosecutor.

title: British Put Laws in Force To Bar Sex Discrimination
description: LONDON, Dec. 29The British woman was relieved of many of the traditional shackles of this maledominated society today and was given markedly more freedom to chart her own life.

title: POSTAL RATE RISE RULED INTO EFFECT EARLY TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit lifted today a lower court injunction and allowed postal rate increase, including a threecent rise on firstclass mail to 13 cents.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities

title: Rev. Theodore L. Conklin, 74, Of Council of Churches Dies
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 29 (UPI)The Rev. Theodore L. Conklin of Syracuse, former associate general secretary of the New York State Council of Churches, died Sunday at a nursing home. He was 74 years old.

title: Market Place
description: Christmas is the worst time of the year to raise money, but many selfemployed persons have had to put funds into their pension accounts during this period to qualify for a current tax deduction.

title: SPAIN'S ASSEMBLY HINTS CHALLENGE
description: MADRID, Dec. 29Spain's Parliament met today under the new Government and indicated that it might try to impose its views on the conduct of affairs.

title: ARGENTINES SEIZE GUERRILLA CHIEF
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29Roberto Quieto, one of Argentina's three mostwanted guerrilla leaders, has been arrested by armed men who identified themselves as federal police officers, according to Mr. Quieto's wife.

title: Homework for Chub and Lee
description: Probably the most common misapprehension about baseball's reserve system is that it has the approval of the Supreme Court of the United States. It does not. When Peter Seitz, impartial chairman of baseball's grievance panel, ruled that Andy Messersmith of the Dodgers and Dave McNally of the Expos had played out their options and were free agents, Chub Feeney and Lee MacPhail, presidents of the National and American Leagues, charged in a joint statement that the arbitrator was overreaching his authority when the Supreme Court, the Congress and other authorities have clearly placed the reserve system above narrow, individual disputes. If Chub and Lee believe those words to be true, then they haven't done their homework and should be ashamed of themselves. If they knew when they released the statement that they were feeding the public a lot of malarkey, they ought to have their mouths washed with soap.

title: Pension Fund Lends State $49 Million So That It Can Pay Its December Bills
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29 (AP)The trustees of th state's Teachers Pension and Annuity Fund agreed to the temporary return of $49 million to the State Treasury so that the state could pay its December bills on time.

title: Witnesses Tell of Horror
description: The explosion at the baggageclaim area at La Guardia Airport last night that turned a scene of holiday travel into a nightmare left witnesses talking with horror and amazement of the destruction they had seen.

title: Like a Morgue, Except That the Bodies Are Alive
description: For anyone wondering what it's like to work for New York City during the fiscal crisis, I hope to provide perspective from within. The ninth floor of the city agency where I work has become strikingly similar to a hospital morgue.

title: Thomas E. Morrissey, 79, Dies; An ExState Justice in Brooklyn
description: Thomas E. Morrissey, who retired three years ago as a justice of the State Supreme Court in the civil term in Brooklyn, died Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 79 vears old.

title: City Hall Shuffle
description: Mayor Beanie's choice of two old City Hall hands to head two key municipal departments marks a disappointing beginning to a new year in which New York must drastically overhaul its bureaucracy in order to function effectively.

title: Fliers Reach Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (Reuters) Three Soviet fliers held for 21 months in China on suspicion of spying flew into Moscow today and were whisked from their plane for debriefing.

title: FILM CRITICS AWARD NASHVILLE 4 PRIZES
description: Nashville, the drama set against the background of the Tennessee city's celebrated country and Western music scene, won four of the eight awards in the 10th annual poll of the National Society of Film Critics. The 20 critics, representing newspapers and periodicals, voted the film the best of the year, named Robert Altman the best director and Henry Gibson and Lily Tomlin the best supporting performers.

title: ExArms Control Chief Says U.S. Delays Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament, Agency expressed concern today that the negotiating position of the United States might be undermining progress toward a new agreement with the Soviet Union for limiting strategic nuclear arms.

title: Metropolitan Club Ball
description: At the 10th annual Metropolitan Club Debutante Ball, held at the club here last night, five young women related to club members were presented. They were Phyliss Pumroy Meaders, Martha Fitzgerald Childs, Monica Rourke Dolan, Sheila Rigby Dolan and Pamela Cederquist. Mrs. Paul Porzelt was ball chairman.

title: Rain Halts Aussie Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 29 (Reuters)Sixthseeded Helen Gourlay of Australia defeated Wendy Turnbull, 61, 61, today in a secondround match at the $103,000 Australian open tennis championships. Rain washed out the rest of the day's program.

title: Jury Begins Deliberating in Hodge Case
description: The jury in the trial of Beverly Donna Hodge and Robert Eschert began deliberating yesterday afternoon after hearing a lengthy charge from Justice Edward J. Greenfield of the State Supreme Court. During his charge he cautioned the jurors:

title: LEFKOWITZ REBUFFS CAREY ON PLEA TO OUST NADJARI; EXTENDS TERM 6 MONTHS
description: Louis J.Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General, yesterday rejected Governor Carey's request to dismiss Maurice H. Nadjari quickly and instead gave the special state prosecutor six months to finish his investigations of political and judicial corruption.

title: Angola Airline Protests U.S Ban on Sale of 2 Planes
description: LISBON, Dec. 29Angola's commercial airline has protested that the United States has revoked the sale of two Boeing 737 aircraft to the airline. It called the act discriminatory.

title: Helping New York
description: Gee, I must go to 78th Street, said a friend of Genia Bonn's with a wink, one day at work. I hear you have a massage parlor on you block.

title: Kin Queried on Murder of Girl in Lake
