description: NEWARK, Dec. 29Essex County detectives today questioned the mother and relatives of an 8yearold girl in an effort to determine who had taken her from her home in Elizabeth and drowned her in a lake in Weequahic Park.

title: Books of The Times
description: After something like 50 operations, Hildegarde Knef looks at her body in The Verdict. There is a blood red streak, held together by black threads [that] runs diagonally across the ribs and disappears in ?? shape under the shoulder. This is the scar of the mastectomy she has just undergone. Her stomach is crisscrossed with other scars. She has hepatitis, colitis and gallstones. She has had polio, rheumatic fever, a ruptured appendix, a hysterectomy.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION REDUCED BY 8.4%
description: As a result of the Christmas holiday, steel production last week dropped 8.4 percent to 1,896,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Bickering on Angola
description: In the face of the Senate's overwhelming vote against further covert American arms assistance to two of the three factions in Angola's civil war, the Ford Administration would have been well advised to give priority to repairing its relations with Congress. Instead, it seems determined to continue the arms shipments by going beyond the $9 million that Secretary Kissinger said last week was still available for arms aid to Angola.

title: U.S. Sextet Triumphs
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 29 (UPI)The United States Olympic Hockey team won the Walter A. Brown international tournament yesterday by beating Spartak of the Soviet Union, 65. Gary Ross of Bemidji State scored the deciding goal with 34 seconds left.

title: Copper Range Laying Off 2,100 at Plant in Michigan
description: The Copper Range Company, saddled for months by a drop in demand, has announced a sharp costcutting plan, including laying off of 72 percent of its workers at its White Pine, Mich., operation.

title: Goldman, Sachs to Pay
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has been ordered to pay the Franklin Savings Bank $500,000 plus interest in connection with losses incurred by the bank on holdings of notes of the insolvent Penn Central Transportation Company. Page 33.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSSarah, on Dec. 27, beloved sister of William F. of Lakewood, N.J. Reposing at Woodlawn Morticlan Chapel, 4418 While Plains Road (near 230th St.), Bronx. Re, ligious services Tuesday, 8 P.M. Funeral Wednesday, 10 A.M.

title: 45 Planes Rescheduled
description: Thousands of holiday travelers found their vacation plans dashed or delayed last night as airlines scrambled to cancel and divert flights at La Guardia Airport in the wake of the explosion.

title: U.S. Hopeful of O.A.U. Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A highranking United States official said today that in the last few days the Administration had begun to hear from African countries that have already recognized the government proclaimed in Luanda by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola that they would support a resolution by the Organization of African Unity calling on all foreign forces to withdraw from the former Portuguese colony.

title: . . . a Liberal Opportunity
description: But there is no reason why G.O.P. moderates should stultify themselves. They have several leaders who are potentially of Presidential quality and who have every right to seek the nomination actively. This group includes Senator Percy of Illinois, Senator Mathias of Maryland, Governor Evans of Washington, Secretark of Commerce Richardson, and even Vice President Rockefeller himself.

title: TRADING IS QUIET IN COMMODITIES
description: Half empty trading floors told the story of slow volume and generally declining commodity prices yesterday, especially at the Chicago Board of Trade. During the Christmas and New Year's holiday period, trading tends to diminish sharply.

title: JOHN M. CUMMINS JR.
description: John M. Cummins Jr., assistant general counsel of Trans World Airways, died Sunday in New York Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 44 years old and lived in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: Phone Company Is Losing On DirectoryHelp Calls
description: The New York Telephone Company has been losing money on its directoryassistance operations since it began charging customers for the service in September, according to the Public Service Commission.

title: PRISON GUARD HURT IN ESCAPE ATTEMPT
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29 (AP)A state official reported today that a guard at the Annandale Youth Correction Facility was injured last night during an apparent escape attempt by inmates.

title: Mexican Aide Quits in Move Tied to Vote on Zionism
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 29 Mexico's Foreign Minister, Emilio O. Rabasa, resigned, unexpectedly tonight and wasl succeeded by Alfonso Garcia Robles, a veteran career diplomat who until today was Mexico's permanent representative at the United Nations.

title: Luzon Storm Toll 13
description: MANILA, Dec. 29 (Reuters)The death toll from a tropical storm that hit Luzon in the Philippines on Christmas Day rose to 13 today after four days of heavy rain.

title: Justice Dept. to Review G.E.Utah Merger Plan
description: The Justice Department will conduct a review of the proposed merger of Utah International Inc. into the General Electric Company, for more than $1.9 billion in G. E. stock, the antitrust division of the department announced in Washington yesterday.

title: Thomas E. Morrssey, 79, Dies; An ExState Justice in Brooklyn
description: Thomas E. Morrissey, who retired three years ago as a justice of the State Supreme Court in the civil term in Brooklyn, died Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 79 years old.

title: TV: For Paying Viewers, Robert Klein's Comedy
description: The year draws to a close with a review not of commercial or public television but of payTV, the new kind on the competitive block. The production, in this case, is being, financed by Home Box Office, which, for a monthly fee, delivers sports, films and assorted programs via cable to 32,000 subscribers in lower Manhattan and 60,000 subscribers in Long Island. The product is the first in a planned series of In Concert specials, featuring entertainers before paying customers in nightclubs, hotels, and auditoriums.

title: Shapp Basing Campaign On Revamping Economy
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.if he were taller, younger, handsome, a good speaker and a Gentile, Milton Jerrold Shapp would probably be one of the major contenders in the current struggle for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: People in Sports
description: Woody Hayes, whose Ohio State team needs only a Rose Bowl victory to clinch the national championship, was named coach of the year by the Football Writers Association of America. Hayes received 80 votes with Bud Moore, the firstyear coach at the University of Kansas, next with 56. Gil Krueger, who guided Northern Michigan from a wonlost record of 010 in 1974 to the National Collegiate Division II title, placed third.

title: CORRECTION
description: The originator of a chili con carne recipe was referred to incorrectly as the late Margaret Field in The New York Times yesterday. Mrs. Field is alive and is a resident of San Antonio, Tex.

title: Poverty Still Pinches Rural Alabama Blacks
description: HAYNEVILLE, Ala.We can vote now and we got a few colored people into office, a disabled black farmer, Bill Grant, told a visitor, but we still got real problems getting food and buying clothes and shoes and things.

title: Africans Urged to Back Luanda Regime
description: NAIROBI. Kenya. Dec. 29With two weeks to go before leaders of the Organization of African Unity meet to take up the Angolan question, supporters of the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola have launched a diplomatic effort to get a majority of African nations to recognize its Luandabased government.

title: Body of Missing Willowbrook Patient, 20, Is Found
description: The halfclad body of a profoundly retarded 20yearold patient, missing since Christmas Eve at the state's Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island, was found in woods 1,500 feet from the administration building yesterday morning.

title: There Is No Objective Need for the Cruise Missile
description: WASHINGTONThe latest United States proposal on the limitation of strategic nuclear arms, which was made privately in September but came to the surface only in late November, seems patently unreasonable, on the assumption that our objective is genuine arms control.

title: Storms Batter Australia
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 29 (Reuters)Floodwaters and fresh rains battered Queensland and Victoria States today, leaving hundreds stranded and whole townships cut off.

title: Rev. Theodore L. Conklin, 74, Of Council of Churches Dies
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 29 (UPI)The Rev. Theodore L. Conklin of Syracuse, former associate general secretary of the New York State Council of Churches, died Sunday at a nursing home. He was 74 years old.

title: Rising Temperatures Chill Resort Operator
description: NEWBURY, N.H., Dec. 29 The temperature rose from 5 degrees above zero at dawn to about 25 by the end of the afternoon today and Dick Parker, the head of the stateowned Mount Sunapee ski center, was a little perturbed. The forecast is calling, for snow tomorrow, said Parker, this resort's manager since 1952. But our weatherman tells me it may change to rain tomorrow night. All I can say iswhat a way to spoil the holiday season.

title: 'Urgent' Dispatch Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Stab Department said today that the United States was arranging urgently for the dispatch of experts and 10 special pumps to aid in rescue attempts at the flooded mine in eastern India.

title: U.S. SAID TO STUDY NEW HEALTH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Ford Administration is considering a consolidation of the nation's health service programs into one $10 billion health revenuesharing program, Administration sources said today.

title: BOMB REPORTED IN COIN LOCKER
description: It was explosion that came without warning or threat, and the investigators had to start from scratch.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1975

title: Regime in Chile Expels British Woman Doctor
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 29 (AP)Dr. Sheila Cassidy, a British physician held by Chile's military Government since Nov. 1, was expelled from the country today.

title: Advertising
description: We've had The Anderson Tapes and the White House tapes, and soon a very select group of businessmen in the apparel field will be exposed to the Hoechst Tapes.

title: 14 KILLED, 70 HURT AT LA GUARDIA BY BOMB IN BAGGAGECLAIM AREA; AIRPORT IS CLOSED UNTIL TONIGHT
description: At least 14 people Were killed and more than 70 others were injured last night When a powerful bomb ripped through a crowded baggageclaim area in the main terminal at La Guardia Airport.

title: Agency Told to Pay Costs Of Employee It Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) The United States Civil Service Commission was ordered today to pay legal fees that could run as high as $400,000 to a Pentagon employee who was dismissed after he told Congress about $2 billion in cost overruns on the Air Force's C5A transport plane.

title: Disaster Drills at Hospitals Pay Off OffDuty Staff Members Rush Back
description: It was something they had drilled for, but no amount of disaster training could prepare the hospitals of Queens for the horror that descended on them last night in the aftermath of the explosion at La Guardia Airport

title: INDIA TO POSTPONE ELECTIONS A YEAR
description: CHANDIGARH, India, Dec. 29 The leaders of the Indian Government disclosed today that they intended to use their emergency powers to postpone for a year the parliamentary elections that were to have been held early in 1976

title: Rams Unsure of Quarterback; Steelers Count On Bradshaw
description: As the playoff chimes sounded over the weekend, four of the eight seats in the National Football League's version of musical chairs were swept away and those remaining In the game project various pairings for the Super Bowl in Miami on Jan. 18.

title: STATE COURT BARS NOW ACCOUNTS
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the checking accounts, or socalled NOW accounts, offered by savings banks in New York State are illegal and must be phased out by March 31.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: P.L.O. Denies Any Blame; Calls Bombing Dastardly
description: After yesterday evening's bombing at La Guardia Airport, The Associated Press and United Press International said they had received anonymous calls by persons claiming it was the work of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: PENN CENTRAL LOSS TRIMMED IN OCTOBER
description: The Penn Central Railroad reported yesterday a $1.8 million net loss for October, which was $3.5 million less than the $5.4 million net loss reported for the yearearlier month.

title: Chess:
description: How do you play against a man who uses your own favorite defense?

title: Algeria Reported to Grant Asylum to 6 in Vienna Raid
description: ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 29 (AP)The Algerian Government has granted political asylum to six terrorists who seized the headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna, killed three persons and held scores hostage, official sources said today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The Association of American Railroads estimated today that freight traffic for the week ended Dec. 20 was 14.1 billion ton miles, 5.1 percent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings for the week totaled 430,195 cars, 3.2 percent below the same week in 1974 and 7.3 percent below the preceding week of 1975. The American Trucking Associations Inc. said that truck tonnage for te week was 3.1 percent below the preceding week.

title: Amid the Grime, A Woman Earns A Job Offshore
description: ON MARLIN RIG NO. 2, Gulf of MexicoRalph rises at 5 A.M. climbs into greasy covralls, laces up steeltoe shoes, plops on a hard hat, eats breakfast and begins a 12hour workday that oftens stretchs into 16, 18 or even 20 hours.

title: Mexican Minister Quits
description: Mexico's Foreign Minister, Emilio O. Rabasa, resigned unexpectedly last night. Many diplomats and Mexican Foreign Ministry officials linked his resignation to the controversy aroused by Mexico's vote in the United Nations equating Zionism with racism. Details, Page 2.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES NINE IN TRANSJERSEY CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a suit yesterday in the United States District Court in Newark against the TransJersey Bancorp, the onebank holding company of the Bank of Bloomfield, and the U.S. Funding Corporation, company involved in lease discounting with the New Jersey bank.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: WRITERS' POLL

title: RETAILERS EXPECT GOOD '75 PROFITS
description: The nation's retailers wound up the Christmas season with strong sales and low inventories. As a result, profits are expected to be up substantially for the fourth quarter and the full year.

title: Met Opera Strike Deadline Thursday; New Money Offer Is Possible Today
description: With less than two days till the strike deadline at the Metropolitan Opera, the company and its orchestra are deadlocked on practical issues as well as on the philosophical issues that underlie them.

title: N.F.L. Is Strengthening. Playoff Crowd Controls
description: The National Football League plans to bolster security in the championship playoffs and Super Bowl to prevent such incidents as the beaning of an official in Minnesota last Sunday by a whisky bottle.

title: NATO Warned by Kissinger on Allowing Reds in Cabinet Posts
description: PARIS, Dec. 27  Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger insisted during his recent trip to Western Europe that the United States is determined to do what it can to prevent Communists from moving into Western governments.

title: SAFETY UNIT DENIES BAN ON GAS SPRAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission turned down today a request to ban fluorocarbon gases in aerosol sprays and refrigerants, saying there is insufficient evidence to prove they pose a danger to the atmosphere.

title: Playboy's Publisher Is Cleared In U.S. Narcotics Investigation
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) The Federal Government said today that it had cleared the Playboy Magazine publisher, Hugh M. Hefner, of allegations that he or his employees had been involved in distributing cocaine at his mansions in Chicago and Los Angeles.

title: DayCare Workers Win Stay in Closing Of 12 Centers Here
description: A union of daycare workers obtained a temporary restraining order in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday in a final effort to keep the city from closing at least 12 of the 28 daycare centers now scheduled to cease operations on Thursday.

title: Colonel Sanders Wins Dismissal of Libel Suit
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (UPI)  A libel suit filed against Harland Sanders, founder and whitebearded trademark of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, was ordered dismissed today in curcuit court.

title: Russian Wings Beat Penguins, 74
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29Using the same magic with which their Soviet Army comrades hypnotized the Rangers last night, the Wings of the Soviet beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 74, tonight in the second game of an eightgame series with National Hockey League teams.

title: AUDIT SAYS ARMS AID HARMS U.S. POSITION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)  A secret Government audit said today that the military readiness of United States forces had been adversely affected as a result of weapons aid to South Vietnam and Israel.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST!

title: City's November Job Total Hits Bottom
description: New York City set another record low for employment in November, with 144,100 fewer jobs counted here than in November 1974, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Tone of Portugal's Press Reflects Shift in Powel
description: LISBON, Dec. 29A month or so ago, Portugal's leading newspapers were calling for workercontrol, popular power and the ousting of the Government.

title: Others' Misfortune Helps Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory CoastIn a world of rising oil costs and sharp ups and downs in prices of other commodities, setbacks for sonic producers bring almost instant benefit to others. An example is the timely trade gain being made by this West African country because of frost in Brazil and fighting in Angola.

title: CoOp City Strike Leaders Are Fined $1,000 a Day
description: Fines of $1,000 a day will begin accumulating today against each of the leaders of the long resistance to an increase in monthly carrying charges at Coop City in the Bronx.

title: Colonels Set Back Nets, 110102
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (UPI)Kentucky exploded for 16 straight points in the first quarter tonight and scored a 110102 victory over the New York Nets, led by Artis ,Gilmore's 25 points and 21 rebounds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: What Governor Carey has done in dismissing Maurice H. Nadjari as special state prosecutor and appointing Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau to the post can only be described as outrageous and a cynical attempt by the Governor to undermine one of the outstanding good government forces in this state.

title: U.S. Rushing Pumps to Mine in India
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 29 (UPI) India announced today that the United States, France and Switzerland had offered to rush highcapacity pumps to a flooded coal mine 180 miles, northwest of Calcutta in the faint hope that a few of the hundreds of trapped miners may still be alive.Government officials said it would be a miracle if there were any survivors at the Chasnala colliery, but pledged that rescue operations would continue as long as there was the slightest chance of success.

title: 20.9% Rate Rise Is Sought By Hackensack Water Co
description: NEWARK, Dec. 29  The Hackensack Water Company petitioned the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for an increase of 20.9 percent in the rates it charges its 160,000 customers.

title: SleekLooking French Ski Suits Command High Prices at High Altitudes
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho Throw out your warmups, your down vest, your Gators, your multicolor gloves and your fake fur apresski boots. If you want to be fashionably with it in the posh ski resorts this season, you'll simply have to run out and pick up a few $300 onepiece. French ski suits, a pair of one  color boxing glove mittens and a set of moon boots to prop up in front of the fire after coming down off the slopes.

title: Airport Lockers Here Barred From Use
description: All parcel lockers at La Guardia, Kennedy International and Newark International Airports are being closed to the public indefinitely as a result of Monday's explosion of a bomb hidden in a locker at La Guardia.

title: List of Dead and Injured
description: Following is a list of those persons identified as dead or injured as result of Monday night's explosion at La Guardia Airport:

title: Music: Tashi's Intensity
description: The easy informality of the members of TashiFred Sherry dressed in a sports shirt and sweater, Peter Serkin wandering through the hail greeting friends before the concert, and so onis balanced by a fierce emotional commitment to the music they play. Not surprisingly, this fusion was reflected in the audience they attracted to Carnegie Hall on Monday night: predominantly young, raptly attentive and enthusiastic,to the point of applauding after the first movement of a Bach Partita.

title: Traffic Death  Toll for 75 At Low Point for 14 Years
description: The nation's traffic death toll for the year 1975 will drop by about 1,000 in spite of increased travel, marking the second straight yearly decline in fatalities and the lowest death total in 14 years, according to a check of all 50 states.

title: BUSINESS RECORDS
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Economists Debate Planning, but Mostly With Gibes
description: DALLAS, Dec. 30Economic planning, a stillilldefined concept that nevertheless has been championed in the last year by some of the nation's leading politicians and businessmen, is still a frightening thought to many of the nation's top economists.

title: INDIA TIES OUTSIDERS TO BANGLADESH ILLS
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 30 (UPI) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi charged unnamed foreign powers today with responsibility for the continued instability in neighboring Bangladesh.

title: 2 Inquiries Open on Deaths Of 3 Boys Hit by a Train
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Dec. 30The Essex County Prosecutor's Office and the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners opened separate investigations today into the deaths of three teenage boys who were run down by an ErieLackawanna passenger train in South Orange last night.

title: Baseball Ban Lifted
description: The Little League baseball organization has rescinded a ban against foreign teams competing in the Little League World Series. Page 27.

title: 700 End BBC Walkout
description: LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP)More than 700 journalists of the British Broadcasting Corporation ended their 24hour strike today with a warning that they were planning similar oneday stoppages every week until their pay demands were met.

title: List of Dead and Injured
description: Following is a list of those persons identified as dead or injured as result of Monday night's explosion at La Guardia Airport:

title: Sports Today
description: Sugar Bowl, Alabama vs. Penn State, at the Superdome, New Orleans. (TelevisionChannel 7, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Graham Dancers Excel In The Scarlet Letter
description: Martha Graham's dance theater has always been an extension of herself and the current historic season by the Martha Graham Dance Company has proved again that the force of her genius lives through her works.

title: Gold Rush in U.S. Didn't Pan Out
description: By most assessments, the national gold rush of 1975 has been a failure.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The police were without a clue in the killing of 5yearold Susanah Toro, who was found strangled and stabbed death in the basement of her home at 3010 94th Street, Queens, near La Guardia Airport, on Monday. Edwin T. Dreher, chief of Queens detectives, said that the girl's brother, Oscar Jr., 10, and Liliana Bustamante, the 17yearold baby sitter, who lived with the Toro family, were still missing. The body was found by the parents, Oscar Sr., 34, a jewelry salesman, and Yomaira, 30, who works in a Rego Park beauty parlor. A police spokesman said that Miss Bustamante had come here from Honduras last Nov. 25 to work for the Toro family.

title: Market Place
description: A number of Wall Street analysts seem to agree that chemical companies will find it increasingly difficult to raise prices substantially in the years ahead. However, they also believe that companies in the group are good longterm investments.

title: Braves Conquer Bucks As McAdoo Pours In 40
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 30 (AP)Ken Charles and Bob McAdoo combined to lead 162 thirdquarter burst that sparked the Buffalo Braves to a 118106 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: U.S. Seeks Talks on P.L.O., Denies a Change in Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The Ford Administration, looking for ways of breaking the impasse in Middle East negotiations, has undertaken a cautious effort to open up for serious discussion by Israelis and Arabs the question of how to deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: DR. B.B. LANGROD, 73, PSYCHOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Bronislawa Bruner Langrod, clinical psychologist and psychoanalyst who was active in the Polish underground against the Nazis in World War II, died Saturday at her home, 467 Central Park West. She was 73 years old.

title: Closing of Field Forces 70,000 to Change Plans
description: An estimated total of 70,000 to 75,000 air travelers normally expected to use La Guardia Airport were shifted by the airlines yesterday either to Kennedy or Newark International Airportsor in a large number of cases were left with no flight at all.

title: New Year Open House Is Postponed by Carey
description: ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP)Governor Carey announced today that the traditional open house at the Executive Mansion, normally held on New Year's Day, would be postponed this year until spring.

title: Development of Rozelle Rule Is Traced From Owens Case
description: The socalled Rozelle rule, found illegal yeaterday by a Federal judge in Minneapolis, is Paragraph H of Section 1 of Article 12 in the National Football League's constitution and bylaws.

title: THAILAND TO REOPEN BORDER WITH LAOS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 30 (AP)Thailand will reopen its border with Laos on Thursday as a New Year's gesture to the Laotian Communist regime and the people of Laos, Foreign Minister Chatichai Choonhavan announced today.

title: Inquiries Open on Rail Deaths of 3 Boys
description: SOUTH ORANGE, Dec. 30The Essex County Prosecutor's Office and the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners opened separate investigations today into the deaths of three teenage boys who were run down by an ErieLackawanna passenger train in South Orange last night.

title: Dance: Las Hermanas
description: The American premiere of Las Hermanas, a ballet by Kenneth MacMillan, was given by American Ballet Theater in New York eight years ago. It was not particularly successful then, and one idly wonders now why it was thought necessary to repeat the failure at the Uris Theater Monday night. For it is one of those dramatic ballets that lack both drama and ballet.

title: FED ACTION BUOYS ACTIVITY IN BONDS
description: Credit Markets

title: Journalist's Book on Loeb New Hampshire Best Seller
Mrs. Peron, Under Pressure, Moves Against ExStrongman
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30  In an apparent attempt to counter widespread charges of corruption, Argentina's Peronist Government today moved against the President's exiled special assistant, who has been accused of having misused public funds.

title: A Case of Slow Readers Leading the Slow Reader
description: The classic tutoring technique has traditionally called upon the brightest students to help the slowest. But a reading program in the Bronx has turned this concept around to use youngsters who are at least a year and a half behind in reading to tutor younger children, and both are said to be making gains.

title: Mexican Campus Quiet Again After Years of Unrest
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30The graffiti still shout such allpurpose slogans as Freedom for Political Prisoners and Down With Imperialism, but they seem to be ignored by the students quietly reading on the lawns or playing soccer under the huge mural on the School of Medicine.

title: Slain C.I.A. Man Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (Reuters)The body of Richard S. Welch, the slain Central Intelligence Agency representative in Athens, arrived at Andrews Air Force Base near here today aboard a special military transport.

title: AngolaBound Cuban Jets Said to Refuel in Azores
description: ANGRA DO HEROISMO, Azores, Dec, 30 (Reuters) Planes from Cuba carrying troop reinforcements to Angola are refueling in the Azores, according to the local newspaper A Unio.

title: Family Gets 4 Sons Back After 6Year Court Fight
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 30  After six years of litigation, family disruption and heartbreak, an Iowa couple have been reunited with the four sons taken from them in 1969 under an Iowa statute that permitted the state to break up the family and abolish the parents natural rights to their children.

title: Jersey Bank Sues F.D.I.C. On $4.3 Million Coast Loan
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 30 (UPI)The First National Bank of New Jersey has filed a $4.3 million suit against the Federal Insurance Corporation, charging it has not been paid for a 1972 loan to the nowdefunct United States National Bank of San Diego.

title: Shriver Stressing Kennedy Connection
description: Robert Sargent Shriver Jr. is going at full throttle to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, and his greatest drawing card in that quest is also one of his greatest handicaps. It is called the Kennedy connection.

title: A Met Musician in Search of a Raise
description: Playing in the orchestra pit at tonight's performance of Tosca at the Metropolitan Opera will be Seymour Berman, a 53yearold third violist who is in his 21st season with the Met and is one of 100 musicians threatening to strike at midnight.

title: Digital Watches: The Technologically Chic Way to Tell Time
description: Well, it's almost 1976 and soon the P.P.s (Punctual People) will be sitting around in their party hats, watching their digital watches and waiting for the midnight readout.

title: BURGER BARS STAY OF MAIL RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger denied today a lastminute petition by lawyers for the bulkmailing industry to block midnight increases in postal rates.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: Opera Dispute Approaches Its Deadline
description: The Metropolitan Opera's representatives and the union representing its orchestra met briefly yesterday in a negotiating session that broke up when the Met failed to make any movement on the issue of guaranteeing 52 weeks employment.

title: Hanoi Offers to Return Last 2 American War Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The. North Vietnamese Government has informed Senator Edward M. Kennedy that it is prepared to return the remains of two marines who were the last American servicemen killed in the Vietnam war.

title: BURGER BARS STAY OF MAIL RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 31Postal rates increased at midnight after Chief Justice Warren E. Burger denied a lastminute petition yesterday by lawyers for the bulkmailing industry to block the rise.

title: CHLOROFORM BAN IN DRUGS IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30A consumer group associated with Ralph Nader asked the Food and Drug Administration today to ban all cough medicines, mouthwashes and related products that contain chloroform.

title: South Korea G.N.P. Up
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 30 (UPI)South Korea's gross national product in 1975 is estimated at $8.22 billion, up 7.4 percent from last year, the Bank of Korea said today. The bank also estimated that per capita income this year rose to $531 from $483 in 1974.

title: Kremlin Team, Long in Power, Gives No Hint It Will Step Down
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 30The Soviet Communist Party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, turned 69 years old on Dec. 19, a reminder that he has run the Soviet Union longer than anyone but Stalin.

title: About Education
description: A few years ago it looked almost like a massive, overgrown slag heap, one observer recalled, describing books, many with crumbling bindings, and faded brown documents and papers that had been stored haphazardly in a dark and dusty basement area of the huge New York City Board of Education building in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Dutchmen Finish 1, 2, 3 in Speed Skating
description: INZELL, West Germany, Dec. 30 (UP)Dutchmen placed 1, 2, 3 in the men's 500meter sprint of an invitation speed skating meet today. Jos Valentin took first place 38.86 seconds, with Jan Bazen runnerup in 39.50. Eppie Bleeker was next in 39.85.

title: Unidentified Body Is Found
description: FLEMINGTON, Dec. 30 (AB)  The body of anunidentified man about 50 years old was found by a telephonecompany line worker in a creek near this Hunterdon County community today. The police said there were no marks on the body found beneath a bridge over the Second Neshanic Creek two miles southeast of here in Raritan Township.

title: W.C.T.Cuts Draws, Adds a Pair of Aces
description: World Championship Tennis will open its new season on Monday with tournaments in Columbus, Ohio, and Monterey, Mexico. Virginia Slims begins the following week with the women playing in Houston, then Bill Riordan's Independent Players circuit pushes off in Birmingham, Ala. So far no tournament are scheduled in New York.

title: PERCY M. STEWART, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Percy M. Stewart, an investment banker and limited partner in Kuhn, Loeb & Company, died yesterday, on his 85th birthday, at the Putnam Weaver Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn. He lived on Sunset Lane in Rye, N. Y.

title: Equal Rights for Women
description: Remarks by John Paul Stevens at Senate confirmation hearings on his nomination as a United States Supreme Court Justice illustrate half the problem faced by Equal Rights Amendment proponents. The E.R.A., he implied, would not do much. It is primarily symbolic. The Federal Constitution's equal protection guarantee, he said, already safeguards women against arbitrary treatment.

title: Ramapo Project Helps Institutionalized
description: MAHWAH  To former mental patients, Art in Action means creating a mural. To the elderly resident of a nursing home, it is a dancing figure twisted of foil, and to an inmate at the county jail, it is the feel of working with clay.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The too 20, with points figured on a 1098.7-6-5.4.3.2.1 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wanlost records through games of last Sunday.

title: Song for a TappedOut Town
description: New York, N.Y., is a hell of a town; Taxes are up and employment's down; It's the home of losersGiants; Jets, Yankees, Rangers, Knicks and Mets. Though Abe may cling to an idle dream Of getting the city back on the Beame. Forget it. We heard that same old jive Through all of Nineteen SeventyFive. New York's in a pickle, New York's fix.

title: French Population Rises
description: PARIS, Dec. 30 (Reuters) The population of France has increased by almost three million over the last five years and is now 52,658,253, according to official figures just published.

title: PLANS ADVANCED IN FISCAL CHANGE
description: Three basic facts of the city's new fiscal life were set into place yesterday during a meeting of the state's Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Ban Lifted By Little League
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Dec. 30 (AP)Little League baseball has rescinded its rule banning foreign teams from the Little League World Series.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Echange and overthecounter marker finished lower yesterday in heavier trading.

title: OLIN RAISES PRICE ON FOAM PRODUCT
description: The Olin Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its price of Thermolin brand 101 chlorinated phosphate ester for flexible foam by 6 cents a pound, effective on Friday. The new price will be 85 cents a pound in bulk quantities f.o.b. Inman, S. C.

title: New Singers in Cast of Met's Boris
description: The seventh Boris Godunov of the Metropolitan Opera's current season on Monday night, and the first since Nov. 10, introduced several new singers to the cast. None of them disturbed the prevailing impression of this production.

title: Judge Rules City Can Defer Wage Increases for Police
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the city did not have to pay its 20,000 police officers percent wage increases totaling $19 million until June 30, 1978, or later than that if the State Legislature extended the city's wage freeze.

title: ILLEGALITY CITED IN GULF PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30In a detailed picture of the Gulf Oil Corporation's massive payments to politicians and candidates here and abroad, an independent investigative committee today described the company's domestic contributions as shot through with illegality.

title: French Population Rises
description: PARIS, Dec. 30 (Reuters) The population of France has increased by almost three million over the last five years and is now 52,658,253, according to official figures just published.

title: ILLEGALITY CITED IN GULF PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 In a detailed picture of the Gulf Oil Corporation's massive payments to politicians and candidates here and abroad, an independent investigative committee today described the company's domestic contributions as shot through with illegality.

title: LA GUARDIA BLAST YIELDS NO LEADS IN INVESTIGATION
description: Investigators were reconstructing yesterday a locker area where one of the most lethal bombs ever exploded in New York City killed 11 persons and injured about 75 at La Guardia Airport's main terminal Monday evening. But they appeared still to be without a clue to the bomber or to the motive.

title: Kaunda's Plain Talk
description: CHINSALI, ZambiaThe combination of liberal, isolationist and politically motivated forces in the United States Congress which seems out to get the executive branch on Angola regardless of consequences might do well to heed the words of Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda before crippling American freedom of action.

title: Power Consortium Delays Plan On Big CoalFired Plant in Utah
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 A consortium of electric companies planning the $3.5 billion Kaiparowits coalfired power plant in Utah announced today that it was deferring for a year preparatory work scheduled for 1976 because of delays in regulatory approvals.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax.)

title: The Jackson Bus Stop
description: The announcement by Senator Henry M. Jackson that he will introduce legislation designed to end the school busing controversy is likely to have precisely the opposite effect: It increases the risk that the political rhetoric will further obscure the real issues of school desegregation.

title: GUNMEN HOLD UP POST OFFICE HERE
description: Three men held up a post office in the Cypress Hills section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Bay State Lottery Gross Up
description: BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP)State Treasurer Robert C. Crane said today that gross lottery sales amounted to $94.5 million in 1975, up 10 percent from 1974, and $41.6 million will be distributed to the state's 351 cities and towns.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for, Tuesday.

title: Con Ed's Board Meets to Clear. The Sale of Indian Point Plant
description: Under pressure from Governor Carey, Consolidated Edison's board of trustees held an unscheduled meeting yesterday to push ahead for the sale of the company's Indian Point No. 3 nuclear generating plant to the state by midnight tonight.

title: Debris of Blast Is Sifted for Clues, But Many Key Pieces Are Missing
description: On the concrete floor of a hangar at La Guardia Airport, not far from where a bomb exploded Monday evening, the police yesterday chalked a grid of 12 squares three up and four acrossexactly like the front of a block of airport coin lockers.

title: State Restricts Fishing for Sea Clams
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30 (AP)The Department of Environmental Protection adopted under emergency procedures today a regulation setting a minimum size of sea clams to be taken by fishermen in New Jersey waters and assessing a 1.5cent fee on each bushel harvested.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Dec. 30, 975

title: F.T.C. LISTS RULES FOR WARRANTIES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission ordered manufacturers and retailers who offer warranties today to put them on display so consumers can become better comparison shoppers.

title: A TAP WAS PLACED ON DIFALCO OFFICE
description: Some information in Maurice H. Nadjari's investigation into a possible connection between high Democratic officials and judicial corruption was obtained from a series of courtsanctioned wiretaps, one of which was placed in the office of S. Samuel DiFalco, the Manhattan Surrogate.

title: Heaven Help the Upper Slopes
description: LONDONDERRY, Vt., Dec. 30Hans Thorner, the head of Magic Mountain, looked hopefully at the afternoon skies as sizable snowflakes started to drop. This may be just what we News need, he said. Our snowmakers ers have helped Skiing us put down substantial depths on lower areas. Now we need some help from heaven for our upper part.

title: A TAP WAS PLACED ON DIFALCO OFFICE
description: Some information in Maurice H. Nadjari's investigation into a possible connection between high Democratic officials and judicial corruption was obtained from a series of courtsanctioned wiretaps, one of which was placed in the office of S. Samuel DiFalco, the Manhattan Surrogate.

title: Bridge
description: A declarer who has heard some bidding from the opponents is usually much better off than one who has not, since such information will usually allow him to place the missing high cards with some accuracy.

title: Redmen Get Fans Even as Losers
description: Although it lost the basketball game, St. John's won a lot of admirers in the final of the 24th annual Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden Monday night.

title: Greeting the New YearSome With a Bang,Some With a Whimper
description: No, not everybody went to the Caribbean or to a ski resort over the holidays. It just seems that way. There will still be plenty of revelry in Gotham on New Year's Eve tonight, according to some of the stayathome notables who were asked what they were doing to toast the new year,

title: ECOLOGICAL GAIN IN 1975 IS CITED
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)State Environmental Commissioner David J. Bardin said today that he viewed 1975 as the year New Jersey finished the job of protecting its western flank against the Tocks Island Dam and turned eastward to guard against an offshore oil rush.

title: State Democrats Set Up Procedure on Delegates
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)The New Jersey Democratic Party said today that it would sidestep its central panel and allow the 91member elected delegation to select delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Kaiparowits Power Plan In Southern Utah Delayed
description: Completion of the controversial $3.5 billion coalfired Kaiparowits Power Project in southern Utah will be delayed by one year, utilities sponsoring the project said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Smith Gains In Australian Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (UPI)Stan Smith of Sea Pines, S.C., troubled by a painful right elbow injury, struggled to beat John James of:Australia 75, 46, 57, 61, 63, in the second round of the Australian open tennis championships Charlie Pasarell, the other American left in the men's singles, and topseeded John Newcombe and Ken Rosewall won easily.

title: 2 Little Girls Help Neediest
description: In Japanese the name Yuko can mean fortunate and lucky and Junko means kind and obedient. These are the names of the two young daughters of Katsu and Kyoko Isobe of Great Neck, L. I., who were among 219 contributors giving $9,513.50 yesterday to the 64th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Lebanese Order Troops to Shoot Bearers of Arms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 (Reuters)A committee comprising security forces and the warring Lebanese factions tonight ordered that beginning late tomorrow anyone carrying arms on the streets of the capital be shot on sight.

title: Berkeley Bank Bombed
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 (UPI)A bomb explosion tore hole in a basment door at a Bank of America branch tonight, but no one was hurt. The blast was heard by residents a halfmile away. The police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents converged on the scene, and the area was cor doned off. A special bomb squad was called.

title: Arizona Utility Cuts Budget
description: The Arizona Public Service Company, one of the principal electric utilities in Arizona, anounced yesterday a $64 million cut in its 1976 construction budget to about $201 million. Keith L. Turley, company chairman, said the cutback was a result of a decline in the growth of power sales and delays in receiving approval of rate in crease requests.

title: Terrorists Who Raided OPEC Reported to Leave Algeria
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 30 (AP) Terrorists who attacked the Vienna headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week and surrendered here were freed today and flown out of the country, authoritative sources reported.

title: Agencies Urged to End Communications Squabbling
description: The House Subcommittee on Communications has recommended in a staff report that steps be taken to end the petty squabbling and power plays among Government agencies concerned with telecommunications so that there can be effective research and policy development in that field.

title: Lafayette High Upsets Lutheran
description: Earl Nesbit sank two free throws with 1 minute left to play. giving Lafayette High School a 7270 upset of Long Island Lutheran in the Elmcor Christmas Classic basketball final at St. John's University's Jamaica, Queens, court last night.

title: page="1">CAREY DENOUNCES HINTS BY NADJARI ABOUT A COVERUPpage="1">Calls Them Despicable ant Asserts He Is Willing to Testify Under Oathpage="1">HE ORDERS AN INQUIRYpage="1">Governor Favors Michael Armstrong as a Special Corruption Prosecutorpage="8">Carey Denounces Nadjari Suggestion of CoverUp
description: ALBANY, Dec. 30Governor Carey, denouncing suggestions made by Maurice H. Nadjari as despicable, today ordered a special inquiry into Mr. Nadjari's implication that the Governor had dismissed him because he was investigating high figures in the Democratic Party.

title: O.A.U. Rejects Proposal By South Africa on Angola
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 30 (AP)The Organization of African Unity rejected today a reported South African offer to withdraw from Angola in return for O.A.U. concessions.

title: Goldman, Sachs to Appeal $500,000 Court Decision
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, a major Wall Street securities firm, will appeal a Federal Court decision announced yesterday that it must pay $500,000 to the Franklin Savings Bank for a loss suffered in the Penn Central collapse, a spokesman said.

title: Residential Climb Fails to Offset Other Dips
description: A surge in residential building contracts in November failed to offset declines in other types of building and the total value of construction contracts last month was 6 percent below the level of November 1974, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: TRAIN ASKS DELAY ON ALASKA LEASES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has asked Secretary of the Interior Thomas S. Kleppe to postpone indefinitely the sale of oil and gas leases in the Northern Gulf of Alaska, scheduled for next month, because of environmental hazards.

title: Subsidy for Electric Heat Is Ruled Illegal
description: The temporary subsidy granted this year to homeowners with electric heat was ruled illegal by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Move for Political Change
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 (AP)Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that Lebanon was moving away from religionbased political system in an attempt to end ChristianMoslem rivalry and nine months of fighting.

title: Hangover Will Be the Only Penalty
description: After midnight tonight, it will no longer be a crime to have one drink too many in New York.

title: 2d Post for Morgenthau Faces Legislative Hurdles
description: Despite Governor Carey's decision yesterday to reinforce with legislation the mandate of Robert M. Morgenthau, legal questions remained concerning the Governor's plan to have Mr. Morgenthau serve both as Manhattan District Attorney and as the special anticorruption prosecutor.

title: Oil Drilling Area Off New England Is Sharply Reduced
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) The Interior Department has tentatively selected 1.1 million acres off the New England coast to offer for oil and gas drilling leases, a department spokesman said tonight.

title: People in Sports
description: The Washington Capitals, who have been in business for 116 games, losing 95 times, got their fourth coach, yesterday.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENBAUMMarilyn Faith. It's five years, my darling, that you are gone. I miss you very much. MOM.

title: Steven Ford Drops Out Of University in Utah
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)President Ford's son Steven, 19 years old, is dropping out of Utah State University and hopes to line up a parttime job in California raising horses and to go to school.

title: CAREY DENOUNCES HINTS BY NADJARI ABOUT A COVERUP
description: ALBANY, Dec. 30Governor Carey, denouncing suggestions made by Maurice Nadjari as despicable, today ordered a special inquiry into Mr. Nadjari's implication that the Governor had dismissed him because he was investigating high figures in the Democratic Party.

title: British Mobilize to Save Canterbury Cathedral
description: CANTERBURY, England, Dec. 29Across Britain posters say: St. Augustine founded it. Becket died for it. Chaucer wrote about it. Cromwell shot at it. Hitler bombed it. Time is destroying it.

title: Books of The Times
description: Once upon a time there was a poor cobbler's son who was afraid of the dark and trolls and evil spirits. When he grew up he tried to be an actor and failed. Then he turned his hand to poetry, which many people admired, including the King of Denmark. The King was even more pleased by a fantasy that the cobbler's son wrote, so he dipped into his purse and granted him a traveling pension, which the young man used to visit many European countries and to write his impressions of them.

title: Transcript of Carey Statement
description: I discussed with the Attorney General late last night and early today my program to strengthen the effectiveness of the state's investigation of corruption in the criminal justice system in New York City and to reassure the continuity of that system under capable leadership.

title: Judge Rules City Can Defer Wage Increases for Police
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the city did not have to pay its 20,000 police officers 6 percent wage increases totaling $19 million until June 30, 1978, or later than that if the State Legislature extended the city's wage freeze.

title: Baseball Ban Lifted
description: The Little League baseball organization has rescinded a ban against foreign teams competing in the Little League World Series. Page 27.

title: Journalist's Book on Loeb New Hampshire Best Seller
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.Three years ago, Kevin Cash was an outofwork newspaper journeyman who had gypsied through a number of papers, including two periods at The Manchester Union Leader here in the town of his birth.

title: Notes on People
description: Women hold up half the sky, according to one of Chairman Mao Tsttung's thoughts, and yesterday they seemed to be sustaining at least that share of AmericanChinese interchange. Twelve members of the House arrived in Peking on what their leader, Representative Margaret M. Heckler, Republican of Massachusetts, said was the first allwoman official American diplomatic mission.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Stony Brook Cutback
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Dec. 30Charging that the administration of the State University center here acted illegally in eliminating an education program, the chairman and faculty members of the education department have filed a suit to prevent the decision from taking effect.

title: Shriver Stressing Kennedy Connection
description: Robert Sargent Shriver Jr. is going at full throttle to win the Democratic Presidential nomination, and his greatest drawing card in that quest is also one of his greatest handicaps. It is called the Kennedy connection.

title: LISBON GETS IDEAS ON ROLE FOR ARMY
description: LISBON, Dec. 30Portuguese political parties submitted proposals today to the ruling Council of the Revolution for changes in the pact that gives all essential power to the armed forces.

title: Knicks Win 6th in Row As Monroe Stars Again
description: Earl Monroe and the Knicks winning ways have become a habit.

title: Levitt Audit Suggests Merging Underused DrugAbuse Centers
description: The State Office of Drug Abuse Services could achieve substantial savings through further consolidation of its underused centers for the treatment and rehabilitation of narcotics addicts, the office of Comptroller Arthur Levitt reported in an audit released yesterday.

title: Companies Report Earnings and Sales
description: For periods ended Nov. 30 unless otherwise Indicated.

title: Representative of City At Albany Is Appointed
description: Richard L. Rubin, executive secretary of the Queens Democratic County Committee and executive assistant to the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Steingut, was appointed the city's representative in Albany by Mayor Beame yesterday.

title: Anna Petersen, Journalist, Dies; On Staff of The Times 30 Years
description: Anna Petersen, a retired newspaperwoman and a member of the local news staff of The New York Times for 30 years, died Sunday at Doctors Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 61 West Ninth Street.

title: U.S. Is Told to Represent 2 Indian Tribes in Maine
description: PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 30 The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit has ruled that the Justice Department must represent two Indian tribes in suits against the state of Maine. In the suits, the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot tribes seek $150 million each in compensation for lands the Indians say were taken from them illegally.

title: 47 Presented at International Debutante Ball
description: Fortyseven young women representing 9 countries and 14 states were presented last night at the 21st annual International Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the WaldorfAstoria.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Oil and chemical plants in New Jersey will be painted white under the state's first airpollution control standards designed to reduce vapor emissions. Under rules adopted last March by the State Department of Environmental Protection, existing aboveground storage tanks throughout the state must be painted white and apparatus must be attached to the tanks to prevent vapors from escaping into the air.

title: Church Gives City $8,529
description: Shortly before 1 P.M. yesterday, Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland, the pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, left $8,529 in contributions at City Hall as a token of loyalty and committed interest on the part of our church for the wellbeing of our beloved city.

title: College and School Results
description: Pro Transactions

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1975

title: Pasco Holders Approve a Plan For Liquidating the Company
description: Pasco Inc., an oil producing and marketing company that is 55.5 percent owned by StudebakerWorthington Inc., announced yesterday that shareholders had approved a plan for liquidation of the company. Pasco's crude oil producing properties and two gas plants were previously sold to Amoco Production, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) for $223.8 million in accordance with the May 21, 1973, recommendation of the Pasco board.

title: About New York
description: It was damp and cold inside the broken terminal in the small hours yesterday, and water stood an inch or two deep on the floor. Blood had turned most of the water brown, but here and there were pools of red. Police officers pushed them with brooms.

title: FRENCH DEAL SET BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: PARIS, Dec. 30The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the French Government announced today an agreement under which Westinghouse will sell its interest in a nuclear technology company and France will receive greater control over its nuclear. industry.

title: BERNARD KLEIN
description: Bernard Klein, founder and hoard chairman of Crown Paper Company in Yonkers, died yesterday at Miami Beach. He was 84 years old and a resident of Yonkers.

title: ALAN B. OVERSTREET
description: Alan B. Overstreet, a professor of government, died Monday at Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, Vermont. He was 60 years old and a resident of Bennington.

title: Agency Grants a Reprieve For Rail Line to the Shore
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30  New Jersey's Commuter Operating Agency granted a onemonth reprieve today to the railroad linking Philadelphia with South Jersey shore resorts that it had chided last August to abandon.

title: Decriminalizing Pot
description: Governor Carey wisely included changes in the state's marijuana laws in the reforms he wants the Legislature to make in the criminal justice system during the next session.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The New York Botanical Garden has acquired for $64,000 what it believes to be the two oldest copies in existence of a manuscript called the Circa instans, written in the Middle Ages. The title comes from the first two Latin words of the documents, which are deemed of special interest today to historians of botany, pharmacology and medicine.

title: BROOKLYN MAN HELD IN 11 BANK HOLDUPS
description: NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP)A Brooklyn man wanted in connection with 11 bank robberies in New Jersey, New York and California was arraigned here today before a United States magistrate, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. The 30yearold suspect, whose name is Captain Juerode Darby, was arrested on a warrant charging him with the Oct. 2 robbery of the Colonial Savings and Loan Association in Roselle Park. An F.B.I. spokesman said additional charges were pending against him in connection with six bank robberies in Essex County, one in Union County, one in Brooklyn and two in Los Angeles. The robberies all took place within the last six months, the F.B.I. said.

title: Theater: 2 Classics in 1
description: Following a triumphant tour of Europe and the Mideast, Andrei Serban has returned to the United States with his astonishing versions of Greek classics, two of which, The Trojan Women and Electra are being performed on weekends at La Mama Annex under the title Fragments of a Trilogy.

title: Braves Conquer Bucks As McAdoo Pours In 40
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 30 (AP)Ken Charles and Bob McAdoo combined to lead 162 thirdquarter burst that sparked the Buffalo Braves to a 118106 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight.

title: Advertising
description: Yesterday morning television stations affiliated with the National Broadcasting Companyand the pressgot their first look at the new corporate symbol, the latest graphics triumph from Lippincott & Margulies, the design firm.

title: Connecticut Again Bars Lottery Prize to Minor
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 30 (UPI) The Connecticut Gaming Commission upheld its previous decision to deny payments of a $10,000 lottery prize to 17yearold Barry Bundle of Stafford Springs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1975

title: Seoul Prosecutors Interrogate Chief of Key Opposition Party
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 30  The leader of South Korea's major opposition party was extensively questioned today by Government prosecutors who were investigating whether he had violated an emergency decree banning criticism of the Constitution.

title: W.C.T. Cuts Draws, Adds a Pair of Aces
description: World Championship Tennis will open its new season on Monday with tournaments in Columbus, Ohio, and Monterey, Mexico. Virginia Slims begins the following week with the women playing in Houston, then Bill Riordan's Independent Players' circuit pushes off in Birmingham, Ala. So far no tournament are scheduled in New York.

title: Sights and Sound of War Prove Elusive in Angola
description: NAIROBI, Kenya. Dec. 30 On of the more bizarre aspects of the war in Angola is that hardly anyone has seen it.

title: Farmers Going to China
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Dec. 30 (AP)A group of farmers and farm experts from Kansas, Iowa and Missouri will leave tomorrow for a threeweek trip to China to exchange information with Chinese farmers.

title: I.M.S. INTERNATIONAL ARRANGES FINANCING
description: I.M.S. International Inc., a statistical gathering and processing company primarily in the health and personal care field, said yesterday that it had arranged a $5 million loan and a $3 million Eurodollar facility with the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: Beirut Allocates Fund Aid To American University
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 (AP)The Lebanese Government will allocate funds to enable the American University of Beirut to reopen next Monday for at least two more semesters, the university's president, Samuel B. Kirkwood, said today.

title: Power Consortium Delays Plan On Big CoalFired Plant in Utah
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30A consortium of electric companies planning the $3.5 billion Kaiparowits coalfired power plant in Utah announced today that it was deferring for a year preparatory work scheduled for 1976 because of delays in regulatory approvals.

title: In Loving Homes, Korean Orphans Outgrow Effects of Early Deprivation
description: A study of Korean orphans who were adopted by American families has shown that the adverse effects of malnutrition early in life can be largely overcome by improved nutrition and an enriched environment later on.

title: A. F. COBURN,  EXPERT ON RHEUMATIC FEVER
description: Dr. Alvin F. Coburn, a specialist on rheumatic fever, died Monday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 76 rears old.

title: U.N. Group Recommends Wider Rhodesia Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 30A Security Council committee has recommended expansion of United Nations trade sanctions against Rhodesia by including in the ban the insurance of cargo and use of trade names and franchises.

title: Harding Bancroft of Times Retiring
description: Harding F. Bancroft, vice chairman of The New York Times Company, will retire today under the company's policy of mandatory retirement for executives at the age of 65, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and president.

title: The Rozelle Rule
description: Any player whose contract with a league club has expired, shall thereupon become a free agent and shall no longer be considered a member of the team of that club following the expiration date of such contract. Whenever a player, becoming a free agent in such manner, thereafter signs a contract with a different club in the league, then, unless mutually satisfactory arrangements have been concluded between the two league clubs, the Commissioner may name and then award to the former club one or more players from the active, reserve or selection lists (including future selection choices) of the acquiring club, as the Commissioner in his sole discretion deems fair and equitable; any such decision by a Commissioner shall be final and conclusive.

title: Montreal Hockey Capital
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 30In this North American hockey capital where most playgrounds are equipped with skating rinks and Guy Lafleur's every shot on goal is reported in the newspapers, the Montreal Canadiens find themselves rated the underdogs tomorrow night in a contest with the Soviet Army team.

title: Waiting for the Fire
description: Not just the temples, lifting lotuses out, of the tangled trees, not the moon on cool canals, the profound smell of the paddies, evening fires in open doorways, fish and rice the perfect end of wisdom; but the small bones, the grace, the voices like clay bells in the wind, all wasted. If we ever thought of the wreckage of our unnatural acts, we would never sleep again without dreaming a rain of fire: somewhere God is bargaining for Sodom, a few good men could save the city; but in that dirty corner of the mind we call the soul the only wash that purifies is tears, and after all our body counts, our rape, our mutilations, nobody here is crying; people who would weep at the death of a dog stroll these unburned streets dryeyed. But forgetfulness will never walk with innocence; we save our faces at the risk of our lives, needing the wisdom of losses, the gift of despair, or we could kill again. somewhere God is haggling over Sodom: for the sake of ten good people I will spare the land. Where are those volunteers to hold back the fire? Look: when the moon rises over the sea, no matter where you stand the path of the light comes to you.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi

title: British Mobilize to Save Canterbury Cathedral
description: CANTERBURY, England, Dec. 29Across Britain posters say: St. Augustine founded it. Becket died for it. Chaucer wrote about it. Cromwell shot at it. Hitler bombed it. Time is destroying it.

title: Earth Slowing Down; A Second Older Today
description: BOULDER, Colo., Dec. 30 (UPI)Scientists will add an extra second to the age of the earth tomorrow.

title: British Surgeon Says Chilean Captors Tortured Her
description: LONDON, Dec. 30A British woman surgeon who had been held prisoner in Chile for 59 days returned here today and said she had been tortured for having treated a wounded man accused of being a leftist guerrilla.

title: Record Tuna Catch
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 30 (AP) A record catch of tuna has been reported by the United States fleet for 1975, but canneries dropped the price from $580 a ton at the start of the year to $500. The 146boat fleet pulled in a record 258,000 tons of fish.

title: Terror at La Guardia
description: No major community in the free world today is exempt from the kind of terror attack suffered by New York in the La Guardia Airport bombing Monday evening. There are too many mad or vicious people, nursing too many private and group hatreds, which they seem to think can be assuaged by the random slaughter of innocent men, women and children. The needed expertise in making a bomb is too well dispersed, and dynamite and plastic explosives are too easily available. In an age of violence such as we are now experiencing, efforts to respect civil rights and individual privacy sometimes result in the creation of massive security gaps that make every public place a potential human deathtrap.

title: Greek General Given Life in Killing of Students
description: ATHENS, Dec. 30 (AP)  Gen. Demetrios Ioannides, former Greek strongman, was sentenced to life in prison today for the bloody suppression of student rebellion against the Government in November 1973. More than 40 persons were shot and killed and over 2,000 wounded in the episode.

title: City to Recheck Night Clubs, Other Public Places
description: Mayor Beame yesterday gave the city's Building Department 15 days to make sure all of the city's night clubs, restaurants and other assembly halls are operating with valid city permits.

title: JAMES TRAINOR
description: DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP)  James Trainor, a well respected city editor, died of cancer in Detroit hospital yesterday. He was 76 years old.

title: New Dallas Busing Plan Is Like One Court Barred
description: DALLAS, Dec. 30  A desegregation expert appointed by the Federal court here has recommended a plan that calls for the busing of 23,232 students but would still leave 40 predominantly minority schools intact. The proposal closely parallels a busing plan drawn by the Dallas school trustees, which was rejected by the court earlier this year.

title: PROXMIRE ASSAILS OFFICIALS JET FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the Air Force was running a $66 million fleet of 23 jets to transport Government officials at a cost to the taxpayers of more than $6 million a year.

title: NonCooperators
description: The reality which the rebellious tenants at Coop City seem unwilling to face is that the state cannot grant them additional subsidy, not only because its own funds are overcommitted but because there is no justification for giving them a position even more favored than the one they now enjoy.

title: LA GUARDIA BLAST YIELDS NO LEADS IN INVESTIGATION,
description: Investigators were reconstructing yesterday a locker area where one of the most lethal bombs ever exploded in New York City killed 11 persons and injured about 75 at La Guardia Airport's main terminal Monday evening. But they appeared still to be without a clue to the bomber or to the motive.

title: LOBBYING STARTS ON NOW BANKING
description: Savings bankers opened an intensive lobbying effort yesterday to obtain New York State legislation that would legalize checking accounts for thrift institutions, called NOW accounts, amid widespread predictions that such accounts would be offered nationwide within a few years.

title: Long Slump Drives Japanese to Drink, And Aids Pickpockets and Pawnshops
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26Tokyo's drunkards seem to be drinking more but enjoying it less, presumably because of the protracted recession.

title: Authoritarian India
description: When Prime Minister Indira Gandhi clamped a state of emergency on India last June, imposing censorship and arresting thousands of political opponents, she expressed confidence that conditions would speedily improve to enable us to dispense with this proclamation as soon as possible. Now Mrs. Gandhi has announced an extension of the emergency and postponed for a year the parliamentary elections scheduled for early in 1976.

title: Behind the Soviet Union's Grain Purchases
description: For signing a long-term agreement on grain purchases with the United States, Soviet leaders hardly expect applause, either at home or abroad.

title: Alabama Big Choice Tonight
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 The football match that Coach Paul (Bear) Bryant wantedhis University of Alabama team against his handpicked opponent, Penn Statewill take place tomorrow night in the 42d Sugar Bowl game, but the first in the New Orleans Superdome.

title: Aussies Take Test Cricket Lead
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (Reuters)Strong batting by the West Indian captain, Clive Lloyd, failed to stop Australia from winning the third test match by eight wickets at the Melbourne Cricket Ground today.

title: Post for Mathews Causing a Dispute At U. of Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30A dispute has developed within Alabama's state university over what post is to be given to Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare F. David Mathews, who is on leave as president of the University of Alabama.

title: Other U.S. and Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: Tuesday, December 30, 1975

title: Business Briefs
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30 (Reuters) Honeywell Inc. today announced the signing of an agreement with the Xerox Corporation under which Honeywell Information Systems will take over maintenance and marketing support services for Xerox mainframe computer customers in the United States. The agreement generally follows the terms set out in an Oct. 15 letter of intent.

title: Synagogue Unit Criticizes Pope on Palestinian Appeal
description: The Synagogue Council of America yesterday called on Pope Paul VI to oppose what it termed aspirations of the Palestine Liberation Organization for Israel's destruction.

title: Basic Pay Gains in Britain Show November Increase
description: LONDON, Dec. 31 (Reuters)Basic pay increases totalled the equivalent of $33 million in November against $26.3 million in the same month last year, the Department of Employment Gazette said.

title: Contract Awards
description: The PeabodyGalion Corporation announced yesterday that its French subsidiary was selected by the Government of Libya to provide two refuse disposal systems utilizing the Peabody Nusoil technique. The proprietary process converts municipal refuse into composting material for use as a soil improver. The two disposal plants will cost $62 million.

title: Rozelle Rule Found In Antitrust Violation
description: A United States District Court judge in Minneapolis ruled yesterday against the National Football League and in favor of 15 players on the matter of a compensation system called the Rozelle rule.

title: Juan Carlos on Stamps
description: MADRID, Dec. 30 (AP)A fourstamp series honoring the ascension of King Juan Carlos I were put on sale yesterday and collectors stood in line for hours to get them. Two of the stamps carry likenesses of the King and Queen Sofia, his wife. Another carries the King alone and the fourth, the Queen alone.

title: One Stick of Dynamite Can Uproot a Stamp
description: A stick of dynamite  the basis for comparison used in recent explosionsmay commonly be 8 inches long by 1 in diameter, weighing a third to a half pound.

title: Slump and Recovery
description: How will 1975 go down in the annals of American business?

title: Slain C.I.A. Man Honored
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (Reuters)The body of Richard S. Welch, the slain Central Intelligence Agency representative in Athens, arrived at Andrews Air Force Base near here today aboard a special military transport.

title: U. S. Concerns Said to Approach Hanoi About Offshore Oil Rights
description: PARIS, Dec. 30American oil companies reportedly have made informal contact with Hanoi to determine under what type of arrangements they might resume exploring for oil in the South China Sea off the coast of South Vietnam.

title: Dow Average Drops 4.25 As Profit Taking Prevails
description: Profit taking and yearend taxloss selling weakened stock prices yesterday in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 4.25 points to close at 852.41.

title: Jazz Selects Malone in Draft
description: The New Orleans Jazz and the Los Angeles Lakers gambled yesterday that the American Basketball Association would fold, would merge with the National Basketball Association or that some A.B.A. contracts would be breached.

title: National Health Insurance Now Considered Just Remote Possibility
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 When this year began, the enactment of some form of na tional health insurance appeared to be one of the more likely eventualities in this Congressionial session.

title: Buyers Rush for Stamps As Cost Goes Up 3 Cents
description: The postal rate increases that went into effect at 12:01 A.M. today produced a rush for 3cent stamps in post offices throughout the city yesterday.

title: Damaged Airport Area Being Speedily Restored
description: Despite the enormous force of the fatal explosion at La Guardia Airport Monday evening, much of the damaged area was ready to serve passengers by the time the airport reopened last night.

title: Sights and Sound of War Prove Elusive in Angola
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 30 One of the more bizarre aspects of the war in Angola is that hardly anyone has seen it.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHRISTIE'S BAIT One original way to salute the new year would be to catch a quietly tingling suspense package like Agatha Christie's The Mousetrap, which opened in London on Nov. 25, 1952, and is still playing as the longest running hit in theater history. Even so only a surprisingly small number of people see it when Dame Agatha's astonishingly durable whodunit occasionally appears here on the smalltheater circuit. Rather curiously, the play bypassed Broadway.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENBAUMMarilyn Faith. It's five years, my darling, that you are gone. I miss you very much. MOM.

title: NEW FINES LEVIED IN COOP CITY CASE
description: New fines were imposed yesterday against leaders of the resistance to paying increased monthly carrying charges at Coop City for their refusal to turn over $17 million they have collected from residents of the huge Bronx housing development.

title: Sniper Attack in Corsica
description: AJACCIO, Corsica, Dec. 30 (UPI)Snipers fired on two police cars today and escaped, officials said. No one was injured. The police believe the snipers are Corsican nationalists seeking home rule on this Frenchruled island in the Mediterranean.

title: Nashville and Nicholson Get Film Critics' Awards
Joan Braden to Become State Department Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 Joan Braden, wife of the newspaper columnist Tom Braden and a friend of Vice President Rockefeller and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, will be named coordinator of consumer affairs for the State Department.

title: Holdup Suspects Stall in Traffic
description: An offduty police sergeant driving to work on the trafficjammed Gowanus Expressway yesterday morning picked up two policemen running after a pair of armed bank robbers, then shot one suspect fatally and wounded the other in an exchange of gunfire.

title: Pittsburgh Four Bows
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (AP) Cleveland State scored a 6056 victory tonight over an undermanned University of Pittsburgh college basketball squad. Pittsburgh left home seven players, including three starters, who had broken a team rule. Then, three Pittsburgh players fouled out and the team played with four players for the last minute 35 seconds.

title: Head of Study on Gulf Oil Funds
description: Being president of the World Bank, or chairman of the. Chase Manhattan Bank, or chairman of the Ford Foundation, or a senior partner in one of the nation's

title: India Gives Up Hope That Some in Mine Survived Disaster
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 30 (AP) The Indian Government today gave up hope of finding survivors among the 372 miners listed as trapped in the flooded Chasnala coal mine and conceded that an international pumping operation was only for taking out dead bodies.

title: Airport Lockers Here Barred From Use
description: All parcel lockers at La Guardia, Kennedy International and Newark International Airports are being closed to the public indefinitely as a result of Monday's explosion of a bomb hidden in a locker at La Guardia.

title: Islanders Outplay Flyers In Brawling Contest, 62
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 30 So much for Christmas spirit. Signaling an end to the season of good will and peace on earth, the Islanders and Philadelphia Flyers grappled tonight in a roughandtumble hockey game that resulted in a total of 84 minutes in penalties.

title: But Continued Slow Growth Rate in the Economy Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The Government's composite index of leading indicators of the economy took a modest turn upward in November after small drops in September and October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Nominees as Prosecutors
description: The chief assistant Manhattan district attorney . . was chief assistant district attorney under Michael F. Armstrong in Queens for 18 months after the indictment and resignation of Thomas J. Mackell . . . called a great trial lawyer by his former chief, Frank S. Hogan, the late district attorney . .. was chief of the Manhattan homicide bureau and on the staff since 1956. . . successfully prosecuted about 100 felony cases and 34 murder cases, including the conviction of Richard Robles in the 1963 slaying of Janice Wylie and Emily Hoffert . . . a 46yearold native Manhattanite and registered Republican . . . graduate of Regis High School, Manhattan College and Fordham Law School . lecturer at leading law schools . . . faculty member of National College of District Attorneys in Houston . . . served two years in Army in Japan and Korea . . . lauded for amiable and countrylawyer manner . . . lives here with his wife and a daughter.

title: Economic Woes Dim Black County's Hopes
description: MAYFIELD, Ga.This county right smart pitiful eight years agothe colored peoples had no rights, and we didn't even know we should have them, said Deacon Ed Andrews, a graying, stocky man of 66 whose hands are gnarled from decades of chopping cotton and hauling logs.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey Bankers Association has noted that cases of bankruptcy, folcases of bankruptcy, following a national trend, have in the state, including a sharp increase in the number of individual noncommercial filings.

title: PRICE UNCHANGED IN CORN FUTURES
description: Preholiday dullness again marked trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday where wheat, corn and soybeans closed pennies a bushel higher or unchanged in price.
